THE STATION MAY BE REACHED FROM THE SAN JUAN LUIS MUNOZ MARIN INTERNATIONAL AIRPORT BY TAKING HIGHWAY 26 WEST TO THE JUNCTION WITH HWY 25 THEN PROCEED NORTH AND WEST ON HWY 25 ALONG THE NORTH SIDE OF OLD SAN JUAN TO A POINT JUST WEST OF FORT SAN CRISTOBAL. TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE JUNCTION OF HIGHWAYS 1 AND 173 THAT IS 7.1 MILES NORTH OF CAGUAS, GO SOUTHERLY ON HIGHWAY 173 FOR 4.1 MILES TO THE JUNCTION OF HIGHWAYS 173 AND 793.  TURN RIGHT AND GO WEST AND NORTHWEST ON HIGHWAY 793 FOR 1.4 MILES TO THE STATION.  THE MAST IS A 4-LEGGED SELF-SUPPORTING STEEL STRUCTURE, PAINTED ALTERNATELY RED AND WHITE AND IT HAS AN ANTENNA ATOP AND CENTER.  THIS MAST IS THE SOUTHEAST AND HIGHEST MAST OF TWO MASTS.  THE MAST IS 200 FEET HIGH AND OVERALL HEIGHT OF THE STRUCTURE IS 289 FEET.  POINT INTERSECTED IS THE RED OBSTRUCTION LIGHT ATOP AND CENTER OF THE ANTENNA.
PTIVE TEXT AVAILABLE.

markers.description: BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1995 (CSM) LOCATED IN THE NORTHWEST PORTION OF THE ISLAND OF PUERTO RICO AT THE MUNICIPIO DE AGUADILLA U.S. NAVAL TRANSMITTER SITE ABOUT 3 MI (4.8 KM) SOUTHWEST OF ISABELLA, PUERTO RICO.  TO REACH FROM THE INTERSECTION OF HIGHWAY 2 AND ROUTE 112 ABOUT 2 MI (3.2 KM) SOUTH OF ISABELLA, PROCEED WEST ON HIGHWAY 2 FOR 2.3 MI (3.7 KM) TO A ROAD RIGHT AT THE ENTRANCE TO THE NAVAL TRANSMITTER FACILITY.  TURN RIGHT AND PROCEED NORTHERLY FOR 0.2 MI (0.3 KM) TO THE GATE OF THE FACILITY, PASS THROUGH THE GATE AND CONTINUE NORTHERLY FOR 0.05 MI (0.08 KM) TO THE STATION IN A GRASSY AREA TO THE RIGHT.  THE STATION LIES IN THE FIELD ON THE OUTSIDE OF THE ROAD THAT CIRCLES THE MAIN BUILDING CONSTRUCTED IN THE SHAPE OF A CROSS AND IS IN LINE ON RANGE WITH THE SOUTHWEST AND SOUTHEAST EDGES OF THE MAIN BUILDING.  MARK IS A STAINLESS STEEL ROD DRIVEN TO REFUSAL IN A GREASED FILLED SLEEVE ENCASED IN A 12 CM DIAM PVC PIPE WITH A ALUMINUM ALLOY LOGO CAP.  THE SS ROD IS ROUNDED AND CENTER PUNCHED.  IT IS 110 FT (33.5 M) NORTHEAST OF THE NORTH CORNER OF THE GUARDSHACK AT THE GATE (BUILDING NUMBER 3122) , 104 FT (31.7 M) WEST-SOUTHWEST OF A WITNESS POST NEXT TO A LIGHTPOST, 84 FT (25.6 M) NORTHWEST OF THE FENCELINE SURROUNDING THE FACILITY AND 43 FT (13.1 M) SOUTH OF THE SOUTH EDGE OF THE CIRCULAR DRIVE AROUND THE MAIN BUILDING.  DESCRIBED BY M.L. ASLAKSEN JR.                            STATION RECOVERY (2002)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 2002 (JMW) 9.30 KM (5.75 MI) EASTERLY ALONG STATE HIGHWAY 2 FROM THE JUNCTION OF STATE HIGHWAY 107 IN AGUADILLA, THENCE 0.4 KM (0.25 MI) NORTHERLY ALONG AN ENTRANCE ROAD LEADING TO A NAVAL TRANSMITTER FACILITY, PASSING THRU A SECURITY GATE TO A GUARD SHACK, 33.1 M NORTHEAST OF THE NORTH CORNER OF THE GUARD SHACK, 32.0 M WEST OF A WITNESS POST AND A SECURITY LIGHT POLE, 31.4 M NORTHEAST OF THE CENTERLINE OF THE ENTRANCE ROAD, 25.5 M NORTHWEST OF A CHAIN-LINK FENCE, 16.1 M SOUTH OF THE CENTER OF A DRIVEWAY, 0.3 M BELOW THE LEVEL OF THE DRIVEWAY. NOTE--THE MARK IS ON PROPERTY OWNED BY THE U.S. GOVERNMENT, NAVAL TRANSMITTER FACILITY, CONTACT JIM BAILEY, CWO2, U.S. COAST GUARD, ESD AND, 5 CALLE LA PUNTILLA, SAN JUAN, PR, PHONE 787-729-4353.                            STATION RECOVERY (2002)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 2002 (JMW) RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED.

markers.stability: PROBABLY HOLD POSITION/ELEVATION WELL

TO REACH FROM THE INTERSECTION OF HIGHWAY 2 AND ROUTE 112 ABOUT 2 MI (3.2 KM) SOUTH OF ISABELLA, PROCEED WEST ON HIGHWAY 2 FOR 2.3 MI (3.7 KM) TO A ROAD RIGHT AT THE ENTRANCE TO THE NAVAL TRANSMITTER FACILITY, TURN RIGHT AND PROCEED NORTHERLY FOR ABOUT 80 FT (24.4 M) TO THE STATION ON THE LEFT IN A GRASSY SHOULDER AREA ADJACENT TO A BARBED WIRE FENCE.  THE STATION IS A STAINLESS STEEL ROD DRIVEN TO REFUSAL IN A GREASED FILLED SLEEVE ENCASED IN A 12 CM DIAM PVC PIPE WITH AN ALUMINUM ALLOY LOGO CAP.  THE SS ROD IS ROUNDED AND CENTER PUNCHED.  IT IS 88 FT (26.8 M) WEST OF A LARGE ELEVATED MANHOLE ACCESS PAINTED YELLOW, 78 FT (23.8 M) NORTH-NORTHWEST OF THE NORTH EDGE OF HIGHWAY 2, 39 FT (11.9 M) WEST-SOUTHWEST OF THE WEST EDGE OF THE ENTRANCE ROAD TO THE TRANSMITTER FACILITY AND 3 FT (0.9 M) EAST OF A WITNESS POST IN THE BARBED WIRE FENCE LINE.  DESCRIBED BY M.L.  ASLAKSEN JR.                            STATION RECOVERY (2002)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 2002 (JMW) 9.30 KM (5.75 MI) EASTERLY ALONG STATE HIGHWAY 2 FROM THE JUNCTION OF STATE HIGHWAY 107 IN AGUADILLA, 45.0 M WEST OF KILOMETER POST 116.3, 30.6 M NORTH OF THE CENTERLINE OF THE WESTBOUND HIGHWAY, 14.5 M WEST OF THE CENTER OF A ROAD LEADING TO THE U.S. COAST GUARD AND NAVAL TRANSMITTER FACILITY, 1.1 M SOUTHEAST OF A WITNESS POST, 0.9 M WEST OF A FENCE, AND 0.5 M ABOVE THE LEVEL OF THE HIGHWAY. NOTE--THE MARK IS ON PROPERTY OWNED BY THE U.S. GOVERNMENT, NAVAL TRANSMITTER FACILITY, CONTACT JIM BAILEY, CWO2, U.S. COAST GUARD, ESD AND, 5 CALLE LA PUNTILLA, SAN JUAN, PR, PHONE 787-729-4353. markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1901 (JEM) STATION IS ON THE HILL WHICH IS CALLED INESTA CEBALLOS (LOCALLY CALLED INESTA SAVOIA).  STANDING AT THE RAILROAD STATION INESTA CEBALLOS SHOWS AS A LONG, HIGH, FLAT-TOPPED HILL.  ON THE E END OF THE SUMMIT IS A SMALL CLUMP OF TREES, THEN COMES A BARE SPACE, AND THEN A PECULIAR LOW UMBRELLA-TOPPED TREE, THE NATIVES NAME FOR WHICH IS FRAMBOYAN, THE ONLY TREE OF THIS KIND ON THE HILL.  THE WESTERN END OF THE HILL IS BARE OF BRUSH AND TREES.  THE LAND BELONGS TO SENOR BARDI, A RESIDENT OF AGUADA.  THE SIGNAL IS NEAR A 16-FOOT BRACED POLE WITH A SMALL FLAG NAILED ON ITS TOP.  A NAIL IN THE BOTTOM OF THE POLE FITS INTO THE HOLE IN CEMENT, WHICH FILLS THE 2-INCH IRON PIPE USED AS A SURFACE MARK.  THIS PIPE IS 18 INCHES LONG AND ONLY ABOUT 2-1/2 INCHES PROJECT ABOVE THE GROUND, A MASS OF CEMENT SURROUNDS THE TOP.  THE UNDERGROUND MARK IS THE CENTER OF THE TOP OF A PINT BEER BOTTLE, WHICH WAS BURIED UNDER THE IRON PIPE.  ON THE FACE OF FRAMBOYAN TREE FRONTING THE SIGNAL A BLAZE WAS CUT NEAR THE GROUND AND FROM THIS BLAZE TO THE SIGNAL IS 54.0 FEET.  STANDING AT THE STATION A LINE TO THE CENTER OF ROOF OF CEDROS HOUSE, THE HOUSE WITH CORRUGATED IRON ROOF, PAINTED GRAY, ON THE HILLTOP PASSES 3.5 FEET N OF FRAMBOYAN TREE.  A LINE TO THE LONE TREE ON THE HIGH RIDGE BOUNDING THE HORIZON N OF MOCHA VALLEY WOULD PASS 4.5 FEET S OF THE FRAMBOYAN TREE.  TO REACH IT GO W FROM THE RAILROAD STATION TO THE FIRST ROAD RUNNING N AND S ACROSS THE TRACK.  THE ROAD GOES N TO THE TOWN OF AGUADA, AND S TO THE STATION.  A PERSON CAN DRIVE FROM THE TOWN OF AGUADA, TO THE FOOT OF INESTA CEBALLOS, TO WITHIN 7 OR 8 MINUTES WALK OF THE SIGNAL.  WE PACKED OUR INSTRUMENT, ON FOOT FROM RAILROAD STATION TO THE SIGNAL IN 35 MINUTES, AND HAD TO GO SLOW AS THE FIRST PART OF THE ROAD WAS MUDDY AND WET.  A CREEK IS CROSSED ENROUTE TO SIGNAL, BUT IT IS VERY NARROW AND SHALLOW.  STANDING AT THE RAILROAD STATION, AND LOOKING TOWARD INESTA CEBALLOS ON THE LEFT OF THE RIDGE NEAR THE TOP, ONE WILL NOTE ABOUT 100 FEET OF THE TRAIL WHICH GOES UP TO THE HILLTOP, AND CROSSES THE SUMMIT BETWEEN THE FRAMBOYAN TREE AND THE TREES E OF IT AND THEN TURNS PARALLEL TO AXIS OF RIDGE UNTIL NEARLY ABREAST OF THE SIGNAL.
markers.setting: OBJECT SURROUNDED BY MASS OF CONCRETE
markers.stability: MARK OF QUESTIONABLE OR UNKNOWN STABILITY

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1901 (JEM) OVER THE CENTER OF THE W FRONT IS AN ORNAMENTED CAMPANILE, AND ABOVE THE CENTER OF THIS IS AN IRON CROSS.  PINNACLE, AGUADA CHURCH IS THIS CROSS.  THE BELLS ARE HUNG IN THE OPENINGS UNDER THE CROSS.  AT THE E END OF THE CHURCH IS THE SANCTUARY, AND OVER THIS IS A SMALL DOME, ON TOP OF WHICH IS A SMALL PYRAMIDAL FINIAL, PAINTED WHITE.
BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1934 STATION IS THE CENTER OF CROSS ON A GRAYISH COLORED SPIRE WITH ROUNDED ROOF IN VILLAGE OF AGUADA.

BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1901 (JEM) THIS SIGNAL STATION IS ON ONE OF THE BLUFF PEAKS OVERLOOKING THE TOWN OF AGUADILLA, AND IS ON THE LAND OF JULIUS A. ROQUE, ONE OF THE ACCOUNTANTS IN THE LARGE BANKING AND COMMERCIAL ESTABLISHMENT OF J. T. SILVA AND COMPANY.  THE STATION MARK IS A 2-INCH IRON PIPE SUNK IN THE ROCK FOR A DEPTH OF 13 INCHES AND THEN FIRMLY CEMENTED IN PLACE, OVER THIS THE POLE WAS SET.  A TRAIL WAS CLEARED OUT THROUGH THE THICK BRUSH SO AS TO INSURE EASY ACCESS.  IT LEADS FROM THE SWEET POTATO FIELD TO THE SUMMIT.  TO OCCUPY THE STATION INSTRUMENTS SHOULD BE TAKEN (IN VEHICLES) TO THE CABIN, IF ON PACK HORSE THEY CAN GO AS FAR AS THE SWEET POTATO FIELD, THEN THEY MUST BE CARRIED BY PORTERS.  THE STATION CAN BE APPROACHED FROM TWO DIRECTIONS AND THE ROUTES OF ACCESS ARE AS FOLLOWS--FOLLOW THE SAN JUAN ROAD, EASTWARD FROM AGUADILLA UP THE STEEP SLOPE BY WHICH IT LEAVES THE TOWN TO THE FIRST LEVEL STRETCH ON THE HIGH LEVEL ALMOST TO A PASS WHICH CARRIES THE ROAD BETWEEN A BUTTE ON YOUR RIGHT (THE N) AND THE ENCIRCLING RIM OF HILLS WHICH SURROUND AGUADILLA.  A VERY NOTABLE MARK WHICH WILL IDENTIFY THIS PASS IS THE LARGE WATER BASIN PARTLY NATURAL AND PARTLY ARTIFICIAL WHICH WILL BE NOTED JUST S OF THE ROAD IN THE BASE OF THE NW CORNER OF THE HILL IN THE S SIDE OF THE ROAD.  MR. ROQUES FARM IS ON THE W SIDE OF THE RANGE, S OF THE ROAD AND HE HAS UTILIZED ONE OF THE LARGE CAVE LIKE HOLES OF THE HILL TO MAKE A GREAT BASIN, WHOSE SIDES ARE CEMENTED UP WITH WALLS WHERE BREAKS FORMERLY EXISTED.  STANDING AT THE GATE WHICH LEADS INTO A SHED USED FOR STOCK AND GIVES ACCESS TO A WRETCHED LOOKING HOUSE, WHICH SEEMS TO BE USED BY MR. ROQUES CARETAKER, JUST W OF THE GREAT BASIN AND LOOKING TOWARDS THE RIM OF HILLS, ONE WILL NOTE FOUR SEPARATE ONES S OF THE MAIN ROAD.  THE MAIN ROAD WINDS AROUND THE BASE OF THE FIRST ONE, WHICH HAS A LONG BROAD TOP.  THE SECOND HILL SHOWS A GOOD DEAL OF BARE ROCK NEAR ITS SUMMIT AND S SIDE.  THE THIRD HILL IS SUGAR LOAF IN SHAPE AND HAS A LARGE NUMBER OF MASSIGO TREES ON IT, (THE MASSIGO IS THE REDDISH BARKED PUERTO RICAN TREE WHICH IS SO BRITTLE AND UNSAFE TO CLIMB), THE FOURTH SEEMS TO HAVE AN OVER-HANGING TOP AND THE FACE (TOWARDS THE SEA) OF THE UPPER HALF IS VERY BARE AND PRECIPITOUS.  IT WAS ON THE FOURTH HILL THAT AGUADILLA WAS LOCATED.  THE FOURTH HILL CUTS OFF ALL VIEW OF THE OTHER HILLS (S) FROM A MAN STANDING AT SENOR ROQUES GATE.  TO REACH THE SIGNAL ONE SHOULD ENTER SENOR ROQUES N GATE AND FOLLOW HIS FARM ROAD TO HIS S GATE, AND THEN GO INTO THE BASE OF THE HILL, BUT IT IS AN EXTREMELY ROUGH TRAIL TO THE BASE AND A VERY MEAN CLIMB UP THE FACE OF THE BLUFF AND PARTICULARLY BAD FOR AN INSTRUMENT.  A MAN HAS TO DRAG HIMSELF UP BY HIS ARMS IN PLACES.  THE SECOND AND PREFERABLE ROUTE IS FOR THE MAN TO CONTINUE ON THE SAN JUAN MAIN ROAD EASTWARD THROUGH THE PASS WHERE A BRANCH ROAD JOINS THE MAIN ROAD, COMING FROM THE N COAST.  THIS BRANCH ROAD PASSES ON S SIDE OF THE MILITARY RIFLE RANGE AND CAMP OF INSTRUCTION.  AT THE JUNCTION POINT JUST REFERRED TO, ARE TWO SMALL BUILDINGS.  ON THE N SIDE IS A SMALL BOOTH WHICH IS USED AS A BUTCHER SHOP, ACROSS THE ROAD IS A LARGE CABIN.  THE CABIN HAS A DOOR AND WINDOW ON THE SIDE FRONTING THE ROAD AND THE FLOOR IS SOME LITTLE DISTANCE ABOVE THE LEVEL OF THE ROAD, ENTRANCE TO THE HOUSE CAN BE HAD BY MEANS OF A LITTLE TWO-STEP LADDER.  ON THE E SIDE OF THE HOUSE THE WALL IS COVERED WITH CLAPBOARDS.  E OF THE HOUSE IS A SMALL PATCH OF BEANS.  LEAVE THE ROAD AT THE CABIN THROUGH THE GATE ON ITS E SIDE AND FOLLOW TRAIL, WHICH LIES BETWEEN THE BEAN FIELD AND THE FOOT OF THE HILL (AT WHOSE BASE THE CABIN IS BUILT), EASTWARD, KEEPING ON UNTIL YOU ENTER AN OLD FIELD BENDING GENERALLY TOWARDS YOUR RIGHT.  THIS COURSE WILL BRING YOU AFTER PASSING THROUGH THE FIELD TO A PLACE WHERE THE ROAD NARROWS, A GROWTH OF BUSHES ON YOUR LEFT AND SMALL BUTTE ON YOUR RIGHT, NARROWING IT MATERIALLY.  THE BUTTE JUST REFERRED TO, IS DISTINCT FROM THE FIRST HILL. THE NARROW SECTION LASTS FOR ABOUT 150 FEET AND THEN YOU ENTER ANOTHER OLD FIELD.  JUST AS YOU REACH THE END OF THE NARROW SECTION, AS YOU LOOK AHEAD, YOU WILL NOTE WHAT SEEMS TO BE A NARROW DEEP PASS THROUGH THE HILLS, WHICH APPARENTLY LEADS THROUGH TO THE SEA.  ON THE RIGHT (N) SIDE OF THIS PASS IS A ROUND TOPPED HILL AND ON THIS HILL IS AGUADILLA.  AS YOU STAND IN THE PASS THE LEFT HALF OF AGUADILLA HILL SEEMS THICKLY COVERED WITH TALL BARE-LIMBED TREES OF A REDDISH BROWN COLOR (MASSIGO TREES).  THEY SEEM TO RUN FROM THE GAP (LEADING THROUGH TO THE SEA) ALMOST TO THE TOP OF THE HILL, BUT THEY DO NOT QUITE REACH THE TOP.  FROM WHERE THE TRAIL STRIKES THE BEGINNING OF THE SECOND OLD FIELD THE TOP OF AGUADILLA HILL BEARS MAGNETIC 249 DEG.  AT THE END OF A SECOND OLD FIELD IS A FENCE AND BEYOND THAT A LARGE PATCH OF SWEET POTATOES IS GROWING.  THE SWEET POTATO FIELD EXTENDS TO THE BASE OF AGUADILLA HILL.  THE TOP OF AGUADILLA HILL IS VERY SMALL, JUST ABOUT LARGE ENOUGH FOR THE SIGNAL STATION, AND ALL THE GROWTH WAS CHOPPED AND CLEARED AWAY.

BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JWC) THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 1-1/2 MILES SOUTHWEST OF AGUADILLA.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE JUNCTION OF HIGHWAYS 111 AND 122 ON THE SOUTH SIDE OF AGUADILLA, GO SOUTHWEST ON HIGHWAY 122 FOR 0.7 MILE TO A SIDE ROAD RIGHT.  TURN RIGHT AND GO NORTHWEST FOR 0.6 MILE TO A Y-FORK.  TAKE THE LEFT FORK AND GO WESTERLY FOR 0.4 MILE TO THE STATION ON THE RIGHT.  THE MAST IS A STEEL-TRUSS STRUCTURE, PAINTED ALTERNATELY RED AND WHITE, SUPPORTED BY GUY WIRES AND IT IS ABOUT 120 FEET HIGH.  POINT INTERSECTED IS THE TOP AND CENTER OF THE MAST.                            STATION RECOVERY (1975)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1975 (JDS) STATION RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.  THE ORIGINAL DESCRIPTION IS ADEQUATE.

BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JWC) THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 6 MILES SOUTH-SOUTHWEST OF BOQUERON, 1-1/2 MILES NORTHWEST OF CABO ROJO LIGHTHOUSE AND ON THE EAST ONE OF TWO ROCKY POINTS OF LAND LOCALLY KNOWN AS POINT AGUILA.  THE LAND IS OWNED BY MR. JUAN RIOS.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE JUNCTION OF HIGHWAYS 102 AND 103 IN CABO ROJO, GO SOUTH ON HIGHWAY 103 FOR 5.2 MILES TO A T-ROAD, THE JUNCTION WITH HIGHWAY 101.  TURN RIGHT AND GO WEST ON HIGHWAY 101 FOR 0.7 MILE TO A SIDE ROAD LEFT.  TURN LEFT AND GO SOUTH AND WEST ON THE PAVED ROAD FOR 2.9 MILES TO A Y-FORK.  KEEP THE RIGHT FORK AND CONTINUE WEST FOR 2.15 MILES TO A T-ROAD AT KILOMETER POST 7.7.  TURN LEFT AND GO SOUTH ON THE PAVED ROAD FOR 0.25 MILE TO THE END OF THE PAVEMENT AND WHERE THE SAND ROAD BEGINS AT KILOMETER POST 8.1.  FOLLOW THE SAND ROAD SOUTH AND WEST FOR 1.05 MILES TO A T-ROAD AND A CAFE ON THE RIGHT.  TURN RIGHT AND FOLLOW THE SAND ROAD WEST AND SOUTH, ALONG THE SHORELINE, FOR 1.1 MILES TO A STEEL GATE ON THE RIGHT, WEST, SIDE OF THE ROAD AT A GROUP OF WHITE BUILDINGS.  TURN RIGHT, PASS THROUGH THE GATE AND GO SOUTH AND WEST ON THE SAND ROAD FOR 1.0 MILE TO A Y-FORK.  KEEP THE LEFT FORK AND GO WEST AND SOUTH FOR 0.1 MILE TO THE END OF TRUCK TRAVEL AT THE BASE OF A LOW ROCKY KNOLL ON A SMALL POINT OF LAND.  PACK SOUTHERLY FOR ABOUT 100 YARDS TO THE HIGHEST POINT OF THE HILL AND THE STATION.  THE STATION MARK IS A STANDARD DISK, STAMPED AGUILA 1966, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN OUTCROPPING BEDROCK THAT PROJECTS 1 INCH.  REFERENCE MARK 1 IS A STANDARD DISK, STAMPED AGUILA NO 1 1966, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN BEDROCK THAT IS FLUSH WITH THE SURFACE OF THE GROUND.  REFERENCE MARK 2 IS A STANDARD DISK, STAMPED AGUILA NO 2 1966, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN BEDROCK THAT IS FLUSH WITH THE SURFACE OF THE GROUND.  THERE WAS NO SUITABLE LOCATION FOR AN AZIMUTH MARK.                            STATION RECOVERY (1968)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1968 (JKW) STATION MARK AND REFERENCE MARK NO. 2 WERE RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 1 HAS BEEN BATTERED AND IS LOOSE IN THE DRILL HOLE, BUT STILL REMAINS IN PLACE.  THE STAMPINGS WERE VERIFIED.  THE ORIGINAL DESCRIPTION IS ADEQUATE.
markers.setting: SET IN ROCK OUTCROP
markers.stability: MOST RELIABLE AND EXPECTED TO HOLDPOSITION/ELEVATION WELL

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JJL) THE STATION IS LOCATED ON THE HIGHEST POINT OF A BRUSH AND TREE COVERED HILL WHICH IS LOCATED ABOUT 13 MILES WEST-SOUTHWEST OF GUAYAMA, 8 MILES EAST-SOUTHEAST OF SALINAS AND 1 MILE NORTH-NORTHWEST OF CENTRAL AGUIRRE.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE JUNCTION OF HIGHWAY 3 AND HIGHWAY 705 IN THE VILLAGE OF COQUI, GO SOUTH ON HIGHWAY 705, TOWARD CENTRAL AGUIRRE, FOR 0.55 MILE TO A Y-FORK JUST AFTER CROSSING A DOUBLE RAILROAD TRACK.  TAKE THE RIGHT FORK AND FOLLOW THE NARROW PAVED ROAD, SOUTH, FOR 0.05 MILE TO A CROSS-ROAD.  TURN RIGHT AND GO ABOUT 100 FEET THEN TURN LEFT AND GO SOUTHWEST ON THE DIRT ROAD FOR 0.2 MILE TO A Y-FORK.  KEEP THE RIGHT FORK AND FOLLOW THE DIRT ROAD, WEST, FOR 0.25 MILE TO A METAL GATE ON THE RIGHT, NORTH, SIDE OF THE ROAD.  A 4-WHEEL DRIVE VEHICLE IS REQUIRED TO REACH THE STATION FROM THIS POINT.  TURN RIGHT, PASS THROUGH THE GATE AND GO NORTHERLY ON THE TRACK ROAD, KEEPING TO THE WEST SIDE OF THE FENCE, UPHILL ONTO AND ALONG THE RIDGE FOR 0.3 MILE TO A POINT ALONG THE FENCE WHERE A VEHICLE CANNOT BE DRIVEN ANY FURTHER DUE TO THE STEEP SIDEHILL.  AT THIS POINT THE FENCE CAN BE LET DOWN.  BEAR TO THE RIGHT, PASSING THROUGH THE FENCE AND CONTINUE NORTHERLY UPHILL FOR 0.1 MILE TO THE HIGHEST POINT OF THE HILL AND THE STATION.  THE STATION MARK IS A STANDARD DISK, STAMPED AGUIRRE 1965, BRAZED TO THE TOP OF A 3-INCH DIAMETER CAST IRON PIPE THAT PROJECTS 6 INCHES.  REFERENCE MARK 1 IS A STANDARD DISK, STAMPED AGUIRRE NO 1 1965, BRAZED TO THE TOP OF A 3-INCH DIAMETER CAST IRON PIPE THAT PROJECTS 6 INCHES AND IT IS ON THE SAME ELEVATION AS THE STATION.  REFERENCE MARK 2 IS A STANDARD DISK, STAMPED AGUIRRE NO 2 1965, BRAZED TO THE TOP OF A 3-INCH DIAMETER CAST IRON PIPE THAT PROJECTS 6 INCHES AND IT IS ON THE SAME ELEVATION AS THE STATION.  THE DISTANCE BETWEEN REFERENCE MARK 1 AND REFERENCE MARK 2 IS 35.85 FEET OR 10.929 METERS.  THERE WAS NO SUITABLE LOCATION FOUND FOR AN AZIMUTH MARK.                            STATION RECOVERY (1970)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1970 (JKW) THE STATION MARK WAS PRESUMED TO BE RECOVERED INASMUCH AS THE DISK WAS REMOVED.  THE REMAINING PIPE WAS FOUND AT THE UPPERMOST PART OF THE HILL.  REFERENCE MARKS 1 AND 2 WERE SEARCHED FOR AND NOT FOUND.  THEY WERE APPARENTLY DESTROYED BY BULLDOZER.  THE DESCRIPTION BY JJL IN 1966 WAS CHECKED AND FOUND TO BE ADEQUATE WITH THE FOLLOWING CHANGE--THE ROAD NOW EXTENDS TO THE TOP OF THE HILL.  FWD IS NEEDED.                            STATION RECOVERY (1971)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1971 (EKM) THE STATION WAS RECOVERED, DISK MISSING, ON THE TOP OF THE WESTERNMOST OF TWO HILLS.  NO REFERENCE MARKS WERE FOUND.  THEY ARE PRESUMED TO BE LOST DUE TO BULLDOZING.  THE DESCRIPTIONS BY JJL IN 1966 AND JKW IN 1970 ARE ADEQUATE WITH THE EXCEPTION THAT A FOUR-WHEEL DRIVE VEHICLE IS NOT NEEDED.  THE FOLLOWING ARE VISIBLE FROM THE STATION--MUERTOS ISLAND LIGHTHOUSE, CORTADA SUGAR COMPANY STACK, CENTRAL FORTUNA (CONCRETE STACK), AGUIRRE SUGAR ASSOCIATION STACK, SANTA ISABEL EAST MUNICIPAL WATER TANK, SANTA ISABEL WEST MUNICIPAL WATER TANK, AND A WATER TANK (TIN SOLDIER TYPE) IN NORTHEAST SALINAS.                            STATION RECOVERY (1975)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1975 (RMB) THE STATION AND REFERENCE MARKS WERE SEARCHED FOR BUT WERE NOT FOUND AND ARE PRESUMED LOST.  THE AREA HAS BEEN CLEARED AND UTILITY TRANSMISSION TOWERS HAVE BEEN BUILT ON THE HILL.
markers.setting: SET INTO TOP OF METAL PIPE DRIVEN INTO GROUND
markers.stability: MARK OF QUESTIONABLE OR UNKNOWN STABILITY

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JJL) THE STATION IS LOCATED IN THE SOUTH EDGE OF AGUIRRE AND ABOUT 1/4 MILE NORTH OF THE AGUIRE BOAT DOCK.  IT IS THE TALLEST ONE OF TWO STACKS WHICH ARE WHITE IN COLOR.  THE STATION IS THE TOP AND CENTER OF THE STACK.                            STATION RECOVERY (1971)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1971 (EKM) STATION WAS RECOVERED IN APPARENT GOOD CONDITION.  DESCRIPTION BY JJL IN 1966 IS ADEQUATE BUT ADD THE FOLLOWING-- THE SHORTER STACK IS TAN IN COLOR.                            STATION RECOVERY (1975)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1975 (RMB) RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION AS DESCRIBED.

BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1900 (SF) THIS STATION IS ON A MOUNTAIN PEAK ABOUT 1 MILE S OF THE TOWN OF AIBONITO, WHICH WAS USED AS A SIGNAL STATION BY THE SIGNAL CORPS OF THE U.S. ARMY IN 1898, IN SIGNALLING BETWEEN SAN JUAN AND PONCE.  WHILE THIS STATION WAS BEING OCCUPIED A WAGON ROAD WAS UNDER CONSTRUCTION, WHICH LEADS FROM AIBONITO, AND PASSES VERY NEAR THE SUMMIT OF THE PEAK.  THERE IS A DWELLING HOUSE ON THIS PEAK JUST E OF THE STATION, AND BETWEEN THE HOUSE AND STATION IS A TRACK MADE BY THE SPANISH ARMY FOR DEFENSE.  THERE ARE ALSO SEVERAL LARGE BOULDERS NEAR THE STATION FROM WHICH MEASUREMENTS WERE MADE TO THE STATION.  THE STATION IS THE CENTER OF A CROSS CUT INTO THE TOP OF A BOULDER, IN ITS NATURAL POSITION, WHICH PROJECTS ABOUT 6 INCHES ABOVE THE GROUND.                            STATION RECOVERY (1934)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1934 THIS STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 2-1/2 KILOMETERS BY ROAD TO THE SE OF AIBONITO.  IT IS ABOUT 1/2 KILOMETER S OF THE MAIN HIGHWAY.  THE HILL SELECTED FOR THE STATION WAS ONE HAVING THREE VERY LARGE BOULDERS ON TOP.  ON ONE OF THESE LARGE BOULDERS THERE IS A MARBLE INSCRIPTION WHICH READS AMAY TRABAJA.  THE CENTER OF THE STATION CONSISTS OF A CROSS MARK ON A BOULDER THAT PROJECTS ABOUT 6 INCHES FROM THE GROUND.  REFERENCE MARK NO.1 IS A CROSS MARK CUT ON AN ALMOST VERTICAL FACE OF PROMINENT ROCK, 49.10 FEET FROM THE STATION, IN TRUE AZIMUTH OF 66 DEG 18 MIN.  REFERENCE MARK NO.2 IS ANOTHER CROSS MARK CUT ON VERTICAL FACE OF SECOND LARGE BOULDER, 23.59 FEET FROM STATION IN A TRUE AZIMUTH 319 DEG 47 MIN.  REFERENCE MARK NO.3 IS A CROSS MARK ON THIRD LARGE BOULDER, 47.2 FEET FROM STATION IN TRUE AZIMUTH OF 37 DEG 30 MIN.  TO REACH THIS STATION TAKE THE AIBONITO TO SALINAS IMPROVED ROAD AT THE TOWN OF AIBONITO, AND UPON REACHING THE TOP OF THE RIDGE TURN TO THE RIGHT (W) FOLLOWING RIDGE UP TO THE ABOVE DESCRIBED POINT.  THIS HILL HAS ON IT SEMI-CIRCULAR EXCAVATIONS WHICH ARE SUPPOSED TO BE TRENCHES DUG DURING THE WAR IN 1898.
markers.setting: SET IN A BOULDER
markers.stability: MAY HOLD, BUT OF TYPE COMMONLY SUBJECT TOSURFACE MOTION

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1967 (SCM) THE STATION WAS RECOVERED.  A STANDARD DISK WAS SET, REPLACING THE STEEL PIN, AND A NEW DESCRIPTION FOLLOWS--  STATION IS LOCATED APPROXIMATELY 4-1/2 MILES SOUTHWEST OF ISABEL SEGUNDA ON THE NORTH COAST OF VIEQUES ISLAND.  THE STATION WAS ESTABLISHED TO OBTAIN A POSITION FOR A HI-FIX ANTENNA IN CONTROLING HYDROGRAPHY IN VIEQUES SOUND.  NO REFERENCE MARKS WERE SET.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE POLICE STATION AT THE PLAZA IN THE CENTER OF ISABEL SEGUNDA, PROCEED SOUTH FOR ONE BLOCK AND TURN LEFT AND GO EAST FOR ONE BLOCK.  TURN RIGHT AND GO SOUTH FOR 0.25 MILES TO A SIDE ROAD LEFT.  CONTINUE STRAIGHT AHEAD FOR 0.10 MILES TO A FORK.  TAKE RIGHT FORK AND CONTINUE WESTERLY ON THE MAIN ROAD BETWEEN ISABEL SEGUNDA AND PT. ARENAS FOR 0.50 MILE TO A SIDE ROAD RIGHT.  CONTINUE STRAIGHT AHEAD 0.20 MILES TO A SIDE ROAD LEFT.  CONTINUE WESTERLY ON MAIN ROAD FOR 0.50 MILE TO CROSSROADS.  CONTINUE STRAIGHT AHEAD FOR 0.8 MILES TO THE JOB CORPS CENTER ON LEFT AND CONTINUE STRAIGHT AHEAD FOR 1.35 MILES TO THE EAST END OF THE RUNWAY OF THE NEW VIEQUES AIRPORT ON THE RIGHT.  CONTINUE STRAIGHT AHEAD FOR 0.50 MILES TO A FARM ROAD LEFT.  CONTINUE STRAIGHT AHEAD FOR 0.75 MILES TO MILEPOST K7H3 AND FARM ROAD LEFT AND A CORRAL ON LEFT.  TURN LEFT AND GO SOUTH PASSING THROUGH GATE.  CONTINUE SOUTH ON FARM ROAD THROUGH PASTURE FOR 0.10 MILES AND STATION ON RIGHT.  STATION MARK, A STANDARD DISK SET IN CONCRETE, STAMPED AIR 1966 IS 67.1 FEET WEST OF THE CENTERLINE OF THE FARM ROAD, 139 PACES SOUTH-WEST OF THE SOUTHEAST CORNER OF THE CORRAL, AND 49 PACES EAST OF A LONE TREE WITH A TRIANGULAR BLAZE.  THE STATION IS 5.4 FEET EAST OF A WELL DEFINED HORSE TRAIL, AND 14.0 FEET SOUTH OF A Y-INTERSECTION IN THE HORSE TRAIL.  THE STATION IS SET FLUSH WITH THE GROUND.
markers.setting: SET IN TOP OF CONCRETE MONUMENT
markers.stability: MAY HOLD, BUT OF TYPE COMMONLY SUBJECT TOSURFACE MOTION

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JJL) THE STATION IS LOCATED ATOP THE PONCE, MERCEDITA AIRPORT CONTROL TOWER BUILDING ABOUT 2 MILES EAST OF PONCE ON HIGHWAY 1.  THE STATION MARK IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED AIRPORT 1966, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN THE CONCRETE ROOF OF THE CONTROL TOWER BUILDING.  IT IS 37.5 FEET WEST OF THE WEST SIDE OF THE CONTROL ROOM.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 1 IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED AIRPORT NO 1 1966, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN THE CONCRETE ROOF OF THE BUILDING.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 2 IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED AIRPORT NO 2 1966, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN THE CONCRETE ROOF OF THE BUILDING.  THE DISTANCE BETWEEN RM 1 AND RM 2 IS 29.92 FEET OR 9.120 METERS.                            STATION RECOVERY (1970)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1970 (JKW) STATION MARK AND REFERENCE MARKS 1 AND 2 WERE RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.  THE STAMPINGS AND DISTANCES WERE CHECKED AND FOUND TO BE GOOD.  DESCRIPTION BY JJL IN 1966 IS ADEQUATE FOR RECOVERY.                            STATION RECOVERY (1977)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1977 (PDC) THE STATION MARK AND REFERENCE MARKS WERE RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION AS DESCRIBED.                            STATION RECOVERY (1982)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1982 (JCL) THE STATION AND BOTH REFERENCE MARKS WERE RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION. DISTANCES FROM THE STATION TO REFERENCE MARK 1 AND BETWEEN THE REFERENCE MARKS CHECKED THE OLD DATA, HOWEVER THE MEASUREMENT FROM THE STATION TO REFERENCE MARK 2 WAS NOTED TO BE 0.004 METER LONGER.  THE DIRECTION BETWEEN THE REFERENCE MARKS ALSO COMPARED FAVORABLY TO THE OLD DATA.  THE STATION IS LOCATED ATOP THE ROOF OF THE PONCE POLICE STATION ABOUT 3.2 KM (2 MI) EAST OF PONCE AND ON HIGHWAY 1.  OWNERSHIP--CITY OF PONCE.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE JUNCTION OF 1, 2, AND 133 ON THE WEST SIDE OF PONCE, GO EAST ON HIGHWAY 1 FOR 1.8 KM (1.15 MI) TO A POINT WHERE THE HIGHWAY BEARS LEFT AND GOES NORTH AND THE JUNCTION OF HIGHWAY 52.  TURN RIGHT AND GO EASTERLY ON HIGHWAY 1 FOR 1.9 KM (1.2 MI) TO THE PUERTO RICO POLICE DEPARTMENT, PONCE DIVISION, ON THE LEFT (THIS WAS THE OLD AIRPORT TERMINAL).  TURN LEFT AND ENTER THE POLICE STATION PARKING LOT.  AIRPORT 1966 IS LOCATED ON THE WEST SIDE OF THE ROOF OF THE POLICE STATION.  THE STATION IS A STANDARD CGS DISK STAMPED---AIRPORT 1966---, SET INTO A DRILL HOLE IN A CONCRETE ROOF AND SURROUNDED BY A TAR FILLED FORM 21 CM SQUARE AND  RECESSED 5 CM BELOW THE ROOF.  IT IS LOCATED 11.55 METERS (37.90 FT) WEST FROM THE NORTHWEST CORNER OF THE OLD CONTROL TOWER, 9.61 METERS (31.55 FT) NORTH FROM THE SOUTH EDGE OF THE ROOF, AND 7.71 METERS (25.30 FT) SOUTH FROM THE NORTH EDGE OF THE ROOF.  REFERENCE MARK NUMBER 1 IS A STANDARD CGS DISK STAMPED ---AIRPORT NO 1 1966---, SET INTO A DRILL HOLE IN A CONCRETE ROOF AND SURROUNDED BY A TAR FILLED FORM 9 CM BY 12 CM AND  RECESSED 5 CM BELOW THE ROOF.  IT IS LOCATED 10.97 METERS (36.0 FT) SOUTH FROM THE NORTH EDGE OF THE ROOF, 7.73 METERS (25.35 FT) SOUTH-SOUTHWEST FROM THE SOUTHWEST CORNER OF THE OLD CONTROL TOWER, AND 6.28 METERS (20.6 FT) NORTH FROM THE SOUTH EDGE OF THE ROOF.  MARK IS LEVEL WITH STATION.  REFERENCE MARK NUMBER 2 IS A STANDARD CGS DISK STAMPED ---AIRPORT NO 2 1966---, SET INTO A DRILL HOLD IN A CONCRETE ROOF AND SURROUNDED BY A TAR FILLED FORM 12 CM SQUARE AND RECESSED 5 CM BELOW THE ROOF.  IT IS LOCATED 16.37 METERS (53.7 FT) WEST-SOUTHWEST FROM THE NORTHWEST CORNER OF THE OLD CONTROL TOWER, 4.24 METERS (13.91 FT) NORTH FROM THE SOUTH EDGE OF THE ROOF, AND 1.60 METERS (5.25 FT) EAST FROM THE WEST EDGE OF THE ROOF.  MARK IS LEVEL WITH STATION.  HEIGHT OF LIGHT SHOWN ABOVE THE MARK WAS 1.4 METERS.  TRIANGULATION STATION LYNCH 2 1966 COULD SERVE AS AN AZIMUTH MARK.  THIS STATION WAS USED FOR DOPPLER OBSERVATIONS AT THIS TIME.                            STATION RECOVERY (2004)  RECOVERY NOTE BY UNIVERSITY OF PUERTO RICO AT MAYAGUEZ 2004 (EJV) MARK NOT FOUND.
markers.setting: SET IN A MASSIVE STRUCTURE
markers.stability: PROBABLY HOLD POSITION/ELEVATION WELL

markers.description: BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1934 LOCATED ABOUT 7 KILOMETERS BY ROAD AND TRAIL SE OF SAN GERMAN AND ABOUT 9 KILOMETERS SW OF SABANA GRANDE, ON A PROMINENT PEAK IN THE RANGE OF LOW MOUNTAINS EXTENDING E FROM CABO ROJO, S OF MAIN HIGHWAY FROM MAYAGUEZ TO PONCE, VIA SAN GERMAN, SABANA GRANDE, YAUCA AND GUAYANILLA.  PEAK IS KNOWN BY LOCAL INHABITANTS AS ALGARROBO OR CERROTE DE LA BANDERA BECAUSE OF A LONE TREE KNOWN AS THE ALGARROBO WHICH USED TO STAND ON THIS PEAK AND IN WHICH MANY YEARS AGO THERE WAS PLACED A FLAG OR BANNER.  SUMMIT IS ABOUT 40 FEET IN DIAMETER AND STATION IS LOCATED NEAR CENTER.  PEAK IS FRINGED WITH A THIN GROWTH OF BRUSH NEAR THE TOP, MOST OF WHICH WAS CUT, AND THERE IS A LONE ROYAL PALM ON W SLOPE ABOUT 50 METERS FROM STATION, AND ONE ON N SLOPE ABOUT 100 METERS FROM STATION.  STATION MARK IS A STANDARD TABLET, STAMPED ALGARROBO 1934, CEMENTED IN A LARGE ROCK SET IN THE GROUND.  REFERENCE MARK NO.1 IS A SHARP POINT OF A NEARLY VERTICAL LEDGE OF ROCK PROJECTING ABOUT 1 FOOT ABOVE SURFACE, 16.83 FEET FROM STATION IN TRUE AZIMUTH 140 DEG 59 MIN.  REFERENCE MARK NO.2 IS A CROSS CUT IN FLAT SURFACE OF LARGE EMBEDDED ROCK AT S EDGE OF TOP, 21.27 FEET FROM STATION IN TRUE AZIMUTH 340 DEG 07 MIN.  TO REACH STATION FROM SAN GERMAN, FOLLOW MAIN HIGHWAY E FOR ABOUT 3.5 KILOMETERS TO POST K 209 AT BEND IN HIGHWAY, THEN FOLLOW MUNICIPAL ROAD WHICH LEADS TO LA MINA OR MANGANESE MINE, FOR 0.75 KILOMETER, TURN S AT T-ROAD AND FOLLOW TO FOOT OF HILLS.  CROSS DRAIN TO E AND FOLLOW RIDGE TO TOP.  SIGNAL--POLE WITH WHITE FLAG, ANCHORED OVER STATION MARK, AND SURROUNDED BY SMALL MONUMENT OF ROCK.                            STATION RECOVERY (1952)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1952 (JOP) STATION IS LOCATED ON A HIGH, BRUSHY HILL, ABOUT 5 MI. E OF THE TOWN OF LAJAS.  IT IS A STANDARD U.S.G.S. TRIANGULATION BENCH-MARK DISK, STAMPED ALGARROEO 1934 AND SET IN CONCRETE IN A DRILL HOLE IN OUTCROPPING BEDROCK.  REFERENCE MARK 1 IS ABOUT 1 FT. LOWER THAN THE STATION MARK.  IT IS A STANDARD REFERENCE-MARK DISK, STAMPED ALGARROBO NO 1 1934 AND SET IN A DRILL HOLE IN BEDROCK.  REFERENCE MARK 2 IS ABOUT 2 FT. LOWER THAN THE STATION.  IT IS A STANDARD REFERENCE-MARK DISK, STAMPED ALGARROBO NO 2 1934 AND SET IN A DRILL HOLE IN BEDROCK.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE SE CORNER OF THE PLAZA IN LAJAS, GO S ON THE MAIN ROAD FOR 1.1 MI. TO WHERE THE ROAD FORKS LEFT, TURN LEFT AND GO 3.5 MI. TO A T-ROAD LEFT, TURN LEFT AND GO 1.6 MI. TO A GATE ON THE RIGHT AND THE END OF TRUCK TRAVEL, THIS IS ABOUT 100 YDS. FROM THE TOP OF A GRADE.  FROM HERE TURN SHARP RIGHT THROUGH A GATE AND PACK IN A SE DIRECTION TO THE TOP OF A HILL AND STATION AS DESCRIBED.  (ABOUT A 30-MIN. PACK.)  HEIGHT OF LIGHT ABOVE STATION MARK 1 M.                            STATION RECOVERY (1956)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1956 (EAT) THE STATION WAS RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED BY J.O.P. IN 1952 AND ALL MARKS WERE FOUND IN GOOD CONDITION AS DESCRIBED.  A NEW TO REACH FOLLOWS--  REACHED FROM THE JUNCTION OF HIGHWAYS 2 AND 118, WHICH IS 2.2 MILES EAST OF SAN GERMAN VIA HIGHWAY 2, BY GOING SOUTHERLY ON HIGHWAY 118 FOR 2.6 MILES TO KILO POST 2 KM 4 HM ON THE RIGHT AND A GATE IN A FENCE ON THE LEFT.  THENCE FOLLOW OLD DESCRIPTION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1966)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JWC) THE STATION MARK, REFERENCE MARK 1 AND REFERENCE MARK 2 WERE FOUND.  THE STATION MARK WAS IN GOOD CONDITION BUT REFERENCE MARKS 1 AND 2 HAVE BEEN BADLY BATTERED AND THE STAMPING IS BARELY VISIBLE.  THE REFERENCE MARKS ARE SOLID YET AND WERE USED AT THIS DATE.  A NEW DESCRIPTION FOLLOWS--  THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 3-1/2 MILES SOUTHWEST OF SABANA GRANDE, 3 MILES SOUTHEAST OF SAN GERMAN, 1-3/4 MILES SOUTH OF HIGHWAY 2 AND ON A LOW, BRUSH COVERED HILL THAT IS THE MOST SOUTHERLY ONE IN A RANGE OF LOW HILLS.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE POST OFFICE IN SAN GERMAN, GO SOUTHEAST ON HIGHWAY 102 FOR 1.45 MILES TO THE JUNCTION WITH HIGHWAY 118.  TURN RIGHT AND GO SOUTH ON HIGHWAY 118 FOR 1.5 MILES TO KILOMETER POST 2.6 AND THE END OF TRUCK TRAVEL.  PACK EAST, PASSING THE SOUTH SIDE OF A HOUSE, FOR ABOUT 10 MINUTES TO THE TOP OF A SADDLE.  BEAR LEFT AND PACK NORTH FOR 10 MINUTES TO THE HIGHEST POINT OF THE HILL AND THE STATION.  THE STATION MARK IS A U.S. GEOLOGICAL SURVEY BENCH MARK DISK STAMPED ALGARROBO 1934, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A BOULDER THAT PROJECTS 2 INCHES AND IS ON THE HIGHEST PART OF THE HILL.  IT IS 12 FEET EAST OF A WIRE FENCE.  REFERENCE MARK 1 IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED ALGARROBO NO 1 1934, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A BOULDER THAT PROJECTS 6 INCHES.  IT IS ON THE SOUTH SLOPE OF THE HILL AND 1 FOOT LOWER IN ELEVATION THAN THE STATION MARK.  IT IS 16 FEET EAST OF A WIRE FENCE.  REFERENCE MARK 2 IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED ALGARROBO NO 2 1934, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A BOULDER THAT PROJECTS 10 INCHES.  IT IS ON THE SOUTH SLOPE OF THE HILL AND 1 FOOT LOWER IN ELEVATION THAN THE STATION MARK.  IT IS 21 FEET EAST OF A WIRE FENCE.  NO AZIMUTH MARK WAS SET.  AIRLINE DISTANCE AND DIRECTION FROM NEAREST TOWN 3 MILES SOUTHEAST OF SAN GERMAN.
markers.setting: SET IN A BOULDER
markers.stability: MAY HOLD, BUT OF TYPE COMMONLY SUBJECT TOSURFACE MOTION

markers.description: BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1981 OFFICE NOTE--STATION IS DESTROYED.  SEE G-16362 OFFICE COMPUTATION REPORT.
markers.setting: OBJECT SURROUNDED BY MASS OF CONCRETE
markers.stability: MARK OF QUESTIONABLE OR UNKNOWN STABILITY

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1900 (WCH) STATION IS ON THE SW PART OF THE POINT SO CALLED, LYING ON THE W SIDE OF BAHIA HONDA.  IT IS NEAR A HOUSE WHICH STANDS CLOSE TO THE NEXT LITTLE HARBOR (VERY POOR) SW OF BAHIA HONDA.  IT IS IN A FIELD WHICH, THOUGH VERY ROCKY, HAS BEEN CULTIVATED.  THE SURFACE HERE IS PRETTY FLAT BUT THE STATION IS ABOUT ON THE SUMMIT.  MARKED BY A 3/4-INCH IRON BOLT WITH A SQUARE HEAD SET IN A BED OF CONCRETE.                            STATION RECOVERY (1904)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1904 (RLF) STATION RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED.  TRIPOD SIGNAL WAS STANDING.  STATION IS MARKED BY A SQUARE-HEADED 5/8-INCH IRON BOLT PROJECTING ABOUT 3 INCHES ABOVE THE ROCK OR CEMENT.                            STATION RECOVERY (1922)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1922 (FTS) ORIGINAL MARK DESTROYED.  STATION MARK WAS FOUND BROKEN INTO FRAGMENTS THROUGH CENTER OF MARK, IN ORDER APPARENTLY TO SECURE THE 3/4-INCH IRON BOLT USED FOR THE GEODETIC POINT.  THESE FRAGMENTS WERE FOUND ON THE HIGHEST POINT OF THE HILLOCK JUST ALONGSIDE OF A SMALL IRREGULAR HOLE, WHICH HAD EVIDENTLY HELD THE ORIGINAL MARK.  A HYDROGRAPHIC SIGNAL WAS ERECTED IN THIS HOLE FOR USE IN THE WIRE DRAG WORK IN THE VICINITY.  THE SIGNAL IS PLACED WITHIN A FOOT OR TWO OF THE OLD MARK, WHICH LOCATION IS CLOSE ENOUGH FOR ALL PRACTICAL PURPOSES.
markers.setting: OBJECT SURROUNDED BY MASS OF CONCRETE
markers.stability: MARK OF QUESTIONABLE OR UNKNOWN STABILITY

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1941 (RLS) STATION IS LOCATED ON THE ROOSEVELT ROADS NAVAL RESERVATION, AT THE SW SIDE OF ENSENADA HONDA, ON POINT CASCAJO, AT OR NEAR THE PROPOSED SITE OF A MINE DEPOT, ABOUT 700 METERS SW OF THE HIGHEST HILL ON THE POINT, ON THE HIGHEST POINT OF A HILL NEAR THE W END OF THE POINT, ABOUT 150 METERS E OF THE E SHORE OF A SMALL BAY BETWEEN POINT CASCAJO AND POINT ALGODONES, ABOUT 85 METERS N OF THE HIGH-WATER LINE AT THE EXTREME S END OF THE POINT.  THE ELEVATION OF THE STATION IS ABOUT 52 FEET.  THE MARK PROJECTS 10 INCHES ABOVE GROUND.  AN OLD MARK, WHICH WAS AN IRON BOLT IN CONCRETE AS DESCRIBED IN THE 1900 DESCRIPTION OF ALGODON AND REPORTED DESTROYED IN 1922, WAS FOUND IN PLACE.* THIS OLD MARK WAS BUILT UP WITH CONCRETE AND A STANDARD DISK STAMPED ALGODON 2 1941 WAS SET IN THE TOP DIRECTLY OVER THE CENTER OF THE IRON BOLT.  REFERENCE MARKS ARE STANDARD DISKS SET IN CONCRETE, AS DESCRIBED IN NOTE 11A.  THERE IS NO UNDERGROUND MARK.  REFERENCE MARK NO.1 IS NW OF THE STATION AND 0.90 METER LOWER THAN THE STATION.  THE MARK PROJECTS 6 INCHES ABOVE GROUND.  REFERENCE MARK NO.2 IS ON THE N SLOPE OF THE HILL, 1.18 METERS LOWER THAN THE STATION AND PROJECTS 8 INCHES ABOVE GROUND.  OFFICE NOTE--*COMPUTATIONS SHOW THAT THIS IS NOT THE ORIGINAL STATION OF 1900.                            STATION RECOVERY (1961)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1961 (MLO) STATION AND REFERENCE MARKS WERE SEARCHED FOR BUT NOT RECOVERED.  CONSIDERABLE GRADING FOR A HOUSING DEVELOPMENT IN THE APPROXIMATE AREA OF THE STATION HAS PROBABLY DESTROYED THE MARKS.                            STATION RECOVERY (1965)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1965 (JJL) THE STATION AND REFERENCE MARKS WERE SEARCHED FOR BUT THEY WERE NOT RECOVERED.  IT IS BELIEVED THAT ALL MARKS HAVE BEEN DESTROYED.
markers.setting: SET IN TOP OF CONCRETE MONUMENT
markers.stability: MAY HOLD, BUT OF TYPE COMMONLY SUBJECT TOSURFACE MOTION

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1965 (JJL) THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 10-1/2 MILES SOUTH OF FAJARDO, 7 MILES WEST-SOUTHWEST OF NAGUABO, ON A LOW KNOLL, ON THE SOUTHWEST EDGE OF ROOSEVELT ROADS NAVAL STATION, NEAR THE BEACH AND ON PROPERTY OWNED BY THE U.S. GOVERNMENT.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM GATE NUMBER 1 AT ROOSEVELT ROADS NAVAL STATION, GO SOUTHEAST FOR 0.1 MILE TO A FORK.  TAKE THE LEFT FORK AND CONTINUE SOUTHEAST FOR 1.75 MILES TO A FORK.  TAKE THE RIGHT FORK AND GO WESTERLY ON FORRESTAL DRIVE FOR 0.2 MILE TO A SIDE ROAD LEFT.  TURN LEFT AND GO SOUTH ON LANGLEY DRIVE FOR 2.05 MILES TO A SIDE ROAD LEFT.  TURN LEFT AND GO EAST ON F.D.R. DRIVE FOR 2.1 MILES TO A SIDE ROAD RIGHT.  TURN RIGHT AND GO SOUTH ON COWPENS DRIVE FOR 0.15 MILE TO A T ROAD.  TURN RIGHT AND GO WEST ON CABOT DRIVE FOR 0.1 MILE TO THE END OF THE STREET.  CONTINUE WEST FOR 130 FEET TO THE TOP OF A LOW KNOLL AND THE STATION ON THE HIGHEST POINT.  THE STATION MARK IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED ALGONDON 3 1965, SET IN THE TOP OF A ROUND CONCRETE POST THAT PROJECTS 3 INCHES AND IS 12 INCHES IN DIAMETER.  IT IS 130 FEET WEST OF THE END OF CABOT DRIVE.  REFERENCE MARK 3 IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED ALGODON 3 NO 3 1965, SET IN THE TOP OF A ROUND CONCRETE POST THAT PROJECTS 2 INCHES AND IS 12 INCHES IN DIAMETER.  IT IS 101 FEET WEST-NORTHWEST OF THE END OF CABOT DRIVE AND 1 FOOT LOWER IN ELEVATION THAN THE STATION MARK.  REFERENCE MARK 4 IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED ALGODON 3 NO 4 1965, SET IN THE TOP OF A ROUND CONCRETE POST THAT PROJECTS 2 INCHES AND IS THE SAME ELEVATION AS THE STATION MARK.  IT IS 134 FEET WEST OF THE END OF CABOT DRIVE.  NO AZIMUTH MARK WAS SET.  THE DISTANCE BETWEEN RM 3 AND RM 4 IS 64.84 FEET OR 19.764 METERS.                            STATION RECOVERY (1973)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1973 (JGC) THE STATION MARK, REFERENCE MARK 3 AND REFERENCE MARK 4 WERE RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.  DUE TO ROAD CHANGES, A NEW DESCRIPTION FOLLOWS--  THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 10-1/2 MILES SOUTH OF FAJARDO, 7 MILES WEST-SOUTHWEST OF NAGUABO, ON A LOW KNOLL, ON THE SOUTHWEST EDGE OF ROOSEVELT ROADS NAVAL STATION, NEAR THE BEACH AND ON PROPERTY OWNED BY THE U.S. GOVERNMENT.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM GATE NUMBER 1 AT ROOSEVELT ROADS NAVAL STATION, GO SOUTH FOR 0.1 MILE TO A FORK.  TAKE THE LEFT FORK AND GO SOUTHEAST FOR 0.75 MILE TO A T-INTERSECTION.  TURN LEFT ONTO TARAWA DRIVE AND CONTINUE FOR 1.7 MILES TO A FORK.  TAKE THE RIGHT FORK ONTO FORRESTAL DRIVE AND CONTINUE WESTERLY FOR 0.25 MILE TO A SIDE ROAD LEFT.  TURN LEFT ONTO LANGLEY DRIVE AND GO SOUTH AND SOUTHWEST FOR 2.15 MILES TO A SIDE ROAD LEFT.  TURN LEFT ONTO F.D.R. DRIVE AND GO EAST AND SOUTH FOR 2.15 MILES TO A SIDE ROAD RIGHT.  TURN RIGHT ONTO COWPENS DRIVE AND GO SOUTH FOR 0.2 MILE TO A T-INTERSECTION.  TURN RIGHT AND GO WEST ON CABOT DRIVE FOR 0.1 MILE TO THE END OF THE STREET.  CONTINUE WEST FOR 130 FEET TO THE TOP OF THE KNOLL AND THE STATION ON THE HIGHEST POINT.  THE STATION MARK IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED ALGODON 3 1965, SET IN THE TOP OF A ROUND CONCRETE POST THAT PROJECTS 3 INCHES AND IS 12 INCHES IN DIAMETER.  IT IS 130 FEET WEST OF THE END OF CABOT DRIVE.  REFERENCE MARK 3 IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED ALGODON 3 NO 3 1965, SET IN THE TOP OF A ROUND CONCRETE POST THAT PROJECTS 2 INCHES AND IS 12 INCHES IN DIAMETER.  IT IS 101 FEET WEST-NORTHWEST OF THE END OF CABOT DRIVE AND 1 FOOT LOWER IN ELEVATION THAN THE STATION MARK.  REFERENCE MARK 4 IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED ALGODON 3 NO 4 1965, SET IN THE TOP OF A ROUND CONCRETE POST THAT PROJECTS 2 INCHES AND IS THE SAME ELEVATION AS THE STATION MARK.  IT IS 134 FEET WEST OF THE END OF CABOT DRIVE.  THERE IS NO AZIMUTH MARK.  STATION ALGODON 4, 1973 WAS ESTABLISHED 147.83 FEET NE SINCE FUTURE CONSTRUCTION WILL PROBABLY DESTROY ALGODON 3.  HEIGHT OF LIGHT ABOVE STATION MARK 1.32 METERS.                            STATION RECOVERY (1977)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1977 (WFP) STATION WAS SEARCHED FOR BUT NOT RECOVERED, AND IS BELIEVED DESTROYED DUE TO THE CONSTRUCTION OF TWO LARGE HOUSES NEARBY.  AIRLINE DISTANCE AND DIRECTION FROM NEAREST TOWN ON ROOSEVELT ROADS NAVAL BASE.
markers.setting: SET IN TOP OF CONCRETE MONUMENT
markers.stability: MAY HOLD, BUT OF TYPE COMMONLY SUBJECT TOSURFACE MOTION

markers.description: BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1973 (JGC) THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 10-1/2 MILES SOUTH OF FAJARDO, 7 MILES WEST-SOUTHWEST OF NAGUABO, ON A LOW KNOLL, ON THE SOUTHWEST EDGE OF ROOSEVELT ROADS NAVAL STATION, NEAR THE BEACH AND ON PROPERTY OWNED BY THE U.S. GOVERNMENT.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM GATE NUMBER 1 AT ROOSEVELT ROADS NAVAL STATION, GO SOUTH FOR 0.1 MILE TO A FORK.  TAKE THE LEFT FORK AND GO SOUTHEAST FOR 0.75 MILE TO A T-INTERSECTION.  TURN LEFT ONTO TARAWA DRIVE AND CONTINUE FOR 1.7 MILES TO A FORK.  TAKE THE RIGHT FORK ONTO FORRESTAL DRIVE AND CONTINUE WESTERLY FOR 0.25 MILE TO A SIDE ROAD LEFT.  TURN LEFT ONTO LANGLEY DRIVE AND GO SOUTH AND SOUTHWEST FOR 2.15 MILES TO A SIDE ROAD LEFT.  TURN LEFT ONTO F.D.R. DRIVE AND GO EAST AND SOUTH FOR 2.15 MILES TO A SIDE ROAD RIGHT.  TURN RIGHT ONTO COWPENS DRIVE AND GO SOUTH FOR 0.2 MILE TO A T-INTERSECTION.  TURN RIGHT AND GO WEST ON CABOT DRIVE FOR 0.1 MILE TO THE END OF THE STREET.  THEN PROCEED NORTHWEST FOR 150 FEET TO THE STATION ON THE NORTHEAST SLOPE OF THE KNOLL.  THE STATION MARK IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED ALGODON 4 1973, SET IN THE TOP OF A ROUND CONCRETE POST THAT IS DEPRESSED 3 INCHES BELOW THE SURFACE AND IS 10 INCHES IN DIAMETER.  IT IS 147.83 FEET NORTHEAST OF STATION ALGODON 3 1965, AND 2.3 FEET NNE OF A METAL WITNESS POST.  REFERENCE MARK 5 IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED ALGODON 4 NO 5 1973, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN THE EAST RADIUS CURBLINE AT THE EAST END OF CABOT DRIVE.  IT IS 29.2 FEET NORTHWEST OF THE TOP NUT OF FIRE HYDRANT C-84, 43.0 FEET WEST OF THE SOUTHWEST CORNER OF THE HOUSE AT 5 CABOT DRIVE, AND 54.3 FEET NORTH OF THE NORTHWEST SUPPORT OF THE CARPORT AT 24 CABOT DRIVE.  REFERENCE MARK 6 IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED ALGODON 4 NO 6 1973, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A CONCRETE WALKWAY ON THE NORTH FACE OF THE HOUSE AT 5 CABOT DRIVE.  IT IS 10.6 FEET WEST-NORTHWEST OF THE NORTHEAST CORNER OF THE HOUSE.  NO AZIMUTH MARK WAS SET.  IT IS NOT POSSIBLE TO MEASURE BETWEEN THE REFERENCE MARKS.  HEIGHT OF LIGHT ABOVE STATION MARK 1.42 METERS.                            STATION RECOVERY (1977)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1977 (WFP) STATION WAS SEARCHED FOR BUT NOT RECOVERED, AND IS BELIEVED DESTROYED DUE TO TWO LARGE HOUSES HAVING BEEN BUILT SINCE THE LAST RECOVERY IN 1973.  AIRLINE DISTANCE AND DIRECTION FROM NEAREST TOWN ON ROOSEVELT ROADS NAVAL STATION.
markers.setting: SET IN TOP OF CONCRETE MONUMENT

markers.description: BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1934 STATION ON A PROMINENT LIMESTONE HILL N OF A LEVEL REGION THAT LIES S OF A PLAIN CROSSED BY THE ARECIBO-BARCELONETA ROAD AT K 70 TO K 73, AND SEPARATED FROM IT BY A CHAIN OF HILLS.  IT IS ON LAND OWNED BY OLIVER AND KNOWN AS ALIANZA.  ENTER A GOOD ROAD THAT STARTS S FROM K 72 TO H 7 FROM MAIN ARECIBO-BARCELONETA ROAD, FOLLOWING IT 1.9 MILES TO A CATTLE DRINKING EARTH DEPOSIT. FOLLOW THERE A DIRT ROAD W 0.25 MILE, TURN N AND FOLLOW A ROAD THROUGH A CANE PLANTATION TO HILL THAT SPURS S FROM MAIN CHAIN.  THE HILL IS WOODED ON ALL SIDES.  STATION MARK IS A STANDARD U.S.G.S. TABLET CEMENTED ON NATURAL ROCK.  REFERENCE MARK NO.1 IS A NAIL AND WASHER CEMENTED ON NATURAL ROCK, 2.65 METERS SW OF STATION, TRUE AZIMUTH 48 DEG 23 MIN.  REFERENCE MARK NO.2 IS A NAIL AND WASHER CEMENTED TO A NATURAL ROCK, 10.28 METERS N OF STATION, TRUE AZIMUTH 187 DEG 23 MIN.                            STATION RECOVERY (1941)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1941 (GBG) STATION AND REFERENCE MARKS RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.  DESCRIPTION IS ADEQUATE.  STATION MAYBE REACHED FROM THE CATTLE DRINKING POND BY FOLLOWING A PATH NW ACROSS PASTURE TO FOOT OF HILL, AND CONTINUING STRAIGHT UP TO STATION.
markers.setting: SET IN UNSPECIFIED ROCK OR BOULDER
markers.stability: PROBABLY HOLD POSITION/ELEVATION WELL

markers.description: PTIVE TEXT AVAILABLE.

BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1941 (RLS) STATION IS ABOUT 1 MILE NE OF NAGUABO PLAYA, ABOUT 0.6 MILE S OF COLONIA MONTIDA, ABOUT 0.8 MILE SE OF THE CROSSING OF INSULAR HIGHWAY 3 AND THE AMERICAN RAILROAD, ABOUT 195 METERS W OF THE PROPOSED W BOUNDARY (LONG. 65 DEG 42 MIN) OF THE ROOSEVELT ROADS NAVAL RESERVATION, ON A BRUSH-COVERED HILL WITH LARGE MANGO TREES AT THE TOP.  THERE ARE 2 HIGH POINTS ON THE HILL WITH A SADDLE BETWEEN.  THE STATION IS ON THE NORTHWESTERLY OF THESE 2 HIGH POINTS, ABOUT 10 METERS SE OF THE HIGHEST POINT OF THE HILL, AND AT THE NW END OF THE CLEARING ON THE SADDLE OF THE HILL. THE MARK PROJECTS 6 INCHES ABOVE GROUND.  THE ELEVATION OF STATION IS ABOUT 131.8 METERS.  STATION AND REFERENCE MARK NO.1 ARE STANDARD BRONZE DISKS SET IN CONCRETE, AS DESCRIBED IN NOTES 1A AND 11A.  THERE IS NO UNDERGROUND MARK.  REFERENCE MARK NO.1 IS ON THE SW SLOPE OF THE RIDGE AND 1.97 METERS LOWER THAN THE STATION.  THE MARK PROJECTS 6 INCHES ABOVE GROUND.  REFERENCE MARK NO.2 IS A STANDARD DISK SET IN CONCRETE IN A CAVITY OF THE STUMP OF A LARGE LIMB ON THE N SIDE OF A 30-INCH MANGO TREE ON THE SUMMIT OF THE RIDGE.  THE MARK IS ABOUT 2 FEET ABOVE THE GROUND.  THE MARK IS 0.35 METER HIGHER THAN THE STATION.  THE WITNESS MARK IS A TRIANGULAR BLAZE ON AN 18-INCH MANGO TREE WHICH IS THE NORTHEASTERLY LARGE TREE OF A GROUP OF MANGO TREES AT THE NW END OF THE TOP OF THE HILL.  THE MARK IS ON THE SE SIDE OF THE TREE AND 2 FEET ABOVE THE GROUND.                            STATION RECOVERY (1965)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1965 (JJL) REFERENCE MARK 2 WAS RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED IN THE 1941 DESCRIPTION.  THE STATION MARK AND REFERENCE MARK 1 WERE DESTROYED.  A NEW STATION MARK, REFERENCE MARK 3 AND AN AZIMUTH MARK WERE ESTABLISHED.  SEE THE DESCRIPTION FOR TRIANGULATION STATION ALTURA 2.
markers.setting: SET IN TOP OF CONCRETE MONUMENT
markers.stability: MAY HOLD, BUT OF TYPE COMMONLY SUBJECT TOSURFACE MOTION

markers.description: BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1934 THIS STATION IS SITUATED ON A GRASSY POINTED PEAK, WITH COFFEE GROVES ON W SIDE, THAT SPURS TOWARD THE S OF MAIN RIDGE BETWEEN PICACHO AND PUNTA.  IT IS ON BO. FRONTON OF CIALES ON PROPERTY OF EMILIO REYNES.  STATION MARK IS A STANDARD U.S.G.S. BENCH MARK CEMENTED ON ROCK, STAMPED ALTURA 1934.  REFERENCE MARK NO.1 IS A GALVANIZED NAIL AND A STANDARD BRONZE WASHER ON CENTER OF TRIANGLE BLAZED ON MAMEY TREE, 12.10 METERS FROM STATION IN TRUE AZIMUTH 68 DEG 30 MIN.  REFERENCE MARK NO.2 IS A GALVANIZED NAIL AND COPPER WASHER ON CENTER OF TRIANGLE BLAZED ON MAMEY TREE, 13.24 METERS FROM STATION IN TRUE AZIMUTH 152 DEG 00 MIN.  IT IS REACHED FROM K 25 H 7 OF CIALES JUANO DIAZ ROAD, WHERE FOLLOW BY CAR 1 MILE W TO FARM OF JOSE COLON THROUGH A PRACTICALLY GOOD ROAD.  FROM HERE FOLLOW W MUNICIPAL ROAD TO MAMEYEZ.  ABOUT 7 KILOMETERS FROM FARM OF JOSE COLON YOU WILL MEET EMILIO REYNES FARM.  FIVE HUNDRED METERS E OF FARMHOUSE IS HILL OF STATION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1941)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1941 (GBG) STATION AND R.M. 2 RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.  R.M. 1 COULD NOT BE FOUND.  NEW DESCRIPTION FOLLOWS--  LOCATED ON A SHARP, GRASSY PEAK, IN THE BARRIO FRONTON OF CIALES, ON COFFEE PLANTATION OF EMILIO REYNES.  IT IS ABOUT 6-3/4 MILES DIRECTLY SW OF CIALES.  AND ABOUT 0.5 MILE SE OF BUILDING OF REYNES PLANTATION.  THE STATION IS STANDARD TABLET STAMPED ALTURA 1934 CEMENTED TO ROCK, FLUSH WITH GROUND.  REFERENCE MARK 1 NOT RECOVERED.  REFERENCE MARK 2 RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED.  TO REACH FROM CIALES, LEAVE PLAZA ON ROAD TO MANATI, AND GO ABOUT 1/2 MILE TO N END OF BRIDGE AND T-ROAD LEFT (W).  TAKE THIS ROAD AND PROCEED W 7 MILES TO SETTLEMENT OF FRONTON SABANA.  TAKE LEFT FORK 0.15 MILE BEYOND HERE, AND GO 0.7 MILE TO GATE OF HACIENDA ANTONIA, WHERE, TAKE LEFT FORK DOWN GRADE.  FOLLOW THIS ROAD WHICH WINDS UP HILL ABOUT ONE MILE TO REYNES HACIENDA.  CONTINUE ON ROAD, PAST STABLES, ABOUT 1/2 MILE TO GATE, LEFT.  WHERE LEAVE CAR AND WALK NE ABOUT 100 METERS TO TOP AND STATION.  IN 1941 THE FRONTON ROAD WAS BLOCKED BY CONSTRUCTION AT KM. 7.  AND ABOVE MILEAGES ARE APPROXIMATE BY PACING.  CAR CAN ORDINARILY BE DRIVEN CLEAR TO STATION.
markers.setting: SET IN UNSPECIFIED ROCK OR BOULDER
markers.stability: PROBABLY HOLD POSITION/ELEVATION WELL

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1965 (JJL) THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 6 MILES SOUTHWEST OF COIBA, 2-1/2 MILES EAST-SOUTHEAST OF NAGUABO AND ON THE HIGHEST POINT OF A GRASSY RIDGE WITH TREES COVERING THE NORTHWEST SLOPE.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE PLAZA IN COIBA, GO SOUTH ON HIGHWAY 3 FOR 5.95 MILES TO A FORK.  KEEP THE LEFT FORK AND GO SOUTHERLY ON HIGHWAY 3 FOR 0.5 MILE TO A RAILROAD CROSSING AND THE AZIMUTH MARK SET IN THE CONCRETE BASE OF THE RAILROAD SIGNAL ON THE RIGHT, WEST, SIDE OF THE ROAD.  CONTINUE AHEAD, SOUTH, FOR APPROXIMATELY 50 YARDS TO A SIDE ROAD LEFT.  TURN LEFT AND GO EAST ON THE DIRT ROAD FOR 0.35 MILE TO A GATE AND A HOUSE ON THE LEFT. (PERMISSION TO ENTER THE PROPERTY MAY BE OBTAINED HERE.) PASS THROUGH THE GATE AND GO EASTERLY ON THE TRACK ROAD, THAT WINDS UPHILL, FOR 0.7 MILE TO A FENCE CORNER AND A GATE ON THE RIGHT.  TURN RIGHT, PASS THROUGH THE GATE, AND CONTINUE WESTERLY UPHILL, ALONG THE RIDGE FOR 0.2 MILE TO THE HIGHEST POINT OF THE HILL AND THE STATION.  NOTE--A 4-WHEEL DRIVE VEHICLE IS REQUIRED TO REACH THE STATION.  THE STATION MARK IS A STANDARD DISK, STAMPED ALTURA 2 1965, SET IN THE TOP OF A 12-INCH ROUND CONCRETE MONUMENT THAT PROJECTS 3 INCHES.  REFERENCE MARK 2 IS A STANDARD DISK, STAMPED ALTURA NO 2 1941, CEMENTED IN THE TRUNK OF A MANGO TREE AND IT IS ABOUT 3 FEET ABOVE THE SURFACE OF THE GROUND.  REFERENCE MARK 3 IS A STANDARD DISK, STAMPED ALTURA 2 NO 3 1965, SET IN THE TOP OF A 12-INCH ROUND CONCRETE MONUMENT THAT PROJECTS 6 INCHES.  THE AZIMUTH MARK IS A STANDARD DISK, STAMPED ALTURA 2 1965, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN THE CONCRETE BASE OF A RAILROAD SIGNAL.  IT IS LOCATED 13.2 FEET WEST OF THE APPROXIMATE CENTER OF HIGHWAY 3 AND 12.7 FEET NORTH OF THE APPROXIMATE CENTER OF THE RAILROAD TRACK.
markers.setting: SET IN TOP OF CONCRETE MONUMENT
markers.stability: MAY HOLD, BUT OF TYPE COMMONLY SUBJECT TOSURFACE MOTION

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1901 (JN) STATION IS SITUATED ABOUT 1/2 MILE NW OF THE TOWN OF CAMUY.  IT IS ON THE SAND HILLS CALLED CENO LA PLAYA ABOUT 75 METERS S OF THE OCEAN SHORE AND ON THE PROPERTY OF PEREZ NOLASEO.  THE HILLS MENTIONED ARE PLAINLY THE HIGHEST IN THE VICINITY.  THE STATION IS AT THE NE END OF THE FLAT TOP (ABOUT 35 FEET LONG) OF THE HIGHEST HILL.  IT IS ABOUT 650 METERS W OF THE MAIN N AND S STREET THROUGH CAMUY, AND DIRECTLY N FROM A SMALL CEMETERY ON SLOPING GROUND S OF COAST HIGHWAY AND W OF TOWN.  THE STATION IS MARKED BY AN IRON PIPE 2 FEET BY 2 INCHES SET IN CEMENT AND THE CENTER OF THE TOP OF THE PIPE MARKS THE STATION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1959)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1959 (MM) THE STATION WAS NOT FOUND.  THE SAND HILL ON WHICH IT WAS LOCATED HAS SHIFTED, AND IT IS ASSUMED THAT THE STATION IS DESTROYED.                            STATION RECOVERY (1963)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1963 (CFO) A SEARCH WAS MADE IN THIS AREA AND THE STATION WAS NOT RECOVERED.
markers.setting: UNSPECIFIED SETTING

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1900 (SF) CHIMNEY IS LOCATED IN THE VICINITY OF THE TOWN OF PONCE.  HEXAGONAL, LIGHT RED.  BELL.  TOP AND BASE WITH PLASTER.  SQUARE BOTTOM, NEAR STONE OR BRICK FACTORY.

BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1964 (GWM) STATION IS LOCATED IN THE ROOF OF THE AMERICANA HOTEL IN ISLA VERDE, PUERTO RICO, 9 MILES E OF SAN JUAN.  THE STATION IS A BRASS SCREW SET IN THE NE CORNER OF THE ROOF OF THE HOTEL, 13.6 FT SW OF THE NE CORNER, 12.6 FT W. OF THE E. WALL, AND 5.4 FT S. OF THE N. WALL.  REFERENCE MARKS NO 1 AND NO 2 ARE STANDARD DISKS STAMPED, AMERICANA RM NO 1 AND AMERICANA RM NO 2, SET IN DRILLED HOLES IN THE N WALL OF THE HOTEL ROOF.  NO AZIMUTH MARK WAS ESTABLISHED.                            STATION RECOVERY (1994)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US POWER SQUADRON 1994 RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.                            STATION RECOVERY (2008)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 2008 (DW) AMERICANA HOTEL IS NOW THE INTERCONTINENTAL HOTEL AT 5961 ISLA VERDE AVE.  CONTACT MAINTENANCE DEPT. FOR ROOF ACCESS.  STATION WAS NOT SEEN, BUT PROBABLY EXISTS UNDER NEW ASPHALT ROOF SHEETS.
markers.setting: SET IN A MASSIVE STRUCTURE
markers.stability: PROBABLY HOLD POSITION/ELEVATION WELL

markers.description: BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1934 STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 9 KILOMETERS NE OF THE TOWN OF ANASCO, ON A PROMINENT PEAK ON THE MAIN RIDGE LYING TO THE N OF THE VALLEY OF RIO GRANDE DE ANASCO AND JUST E OF RIO HUMATA.  THE PEAK WAS COVERED WITH THICK BRUSH ON THE TOP AND HAS A COFFEE PLANTATION ON THE N SLOPE.  THE S SLOPE BEING PRACTICALLY BARE, MOST OF THE BRUSH WAS CLEARED FROM THE TOP, LEAVING A SECTOR OF ABOUT 45 DEG TO THE N WITH VIEW OBSTRUCTED.  TWO ROYAL PALMS, A LIVING GUAMA STUMP ABOUT 10 FEET HIGH, AND THE SIGNAL TREE WERE LEFT STANDING ON THE TOP AND THERE IS A LARGE TRIMMED MANGO TREE ON THE W SLOPE NEAR THE TOP.  THE TOP HAS SEVERAL DEEP TRENCHES WHICH WERE USED FOR BURYING THE DEAD DURING A SMALL POX EPIDEMIC MANY YEARS AGO AND IS KNOWN BY THE OLDER, LOCAL NATIVES AS CEMENTERIO VIEJO.  THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 3 FEET N AND NEAR THE EASTERN END OF THE TRENCH FARTHEST TO THE S AND W.  STATION MARK IS A STANDARD TABLET, STAMPED ANASCO 1934, CEMENTED IN TOP OF RETANGULAR-SHAPED ROCK SET IN GROUND.  REFERENCE MARK NO.1 IS A COPPER NAIL AND WASHER IN TRIANGULAR BLAZE ON MANGO TREE STUMP, 28.06 FEET DISTANT IN TRUE AZIMUTH 25 DEG 14 MIN.  REFERENCE MARK NO.2 IS A COPPER NAIL AND WASHER IN TRIANGULAR BLAZE ON GUAMA STUMP, 21.5 FEET DISTANT IN TRUE AZIMUTH 148 DEG 25 MIN.  REFERENCE MARK NO.3 IS A ROYAL PALM TREE, 47.85 FEET DISTANT IN TRUE AZIMUTH 213 DEG 00 MIN. REFERENCE MARK NO.4 IS A ROYAL PALM TREE, 16.15 FEET DISTANT IN TRUE AZIMUTH 331 DEG 50 MIN.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM ANASCO, FOLLOW THE MAIN HIGHWAY E FOR 5.5 KILOMETERS TO A MAIN TRAIL, OR CAMINO WHICH LEADS ACROSS THE MOUNTAINS TO SAN SEBASTIAN AND PASSES JUST UNDER THE PEAK ON THE N.  THE LAND IS OWNED BY MANUEL FLORES GONZALEZ WHO LIVES JUST UNDER THE PEAK TO THE NW.                            STATION RECOVERY (1966)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JWC) THE STATION MARK WAS RECOVERED AND FOUND IN GOOD CONDITION.  REFERENCE MARKS 1 AND 2 WERE SEARCHED FOR BUT NOT FOUND.  TWO NEW REFERENCE MARKS WERE ESTABLISHED.  A COMPLETE NEW DESCRIPTION OF THE STATION FOLLOWS--  THE STATION IS LOCATED 10 AIRLINE MILES SOUTHEAST OF AGUADILLA, 8 AIRLINE MILES NORTHEAST OF MAYAGUEZ AND ON THE TOP OF A HIGH BRUSH COVERED HILL.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE SOUTHEAST CORNER OF THE PLAZA IN ANASCO, GO EASTERLY ON HIGHWAY 109 FOR 3.45 MILES TO A SIDE ROAD LEFT.  TURN LEFT AND GO NORTHERLY ON HIGHWAY 405 FOR 2.2 MILES TO A TRAIL ON THE LEFT AT KILOMETER POST 3.5 AND END OF TRUCK TRAVEL.  FROM HERE PACK SOUTHWEST UPHILL ON THE TRAIL FOR ABOUT 200 YARDS TO THE TOP OF THE BRUSH COVERED HILL AND THE STATION.  THE STATION MARK IS A U.S. GEOLOGICAL SURVEY BENCH MARK DISK STAMPED ANASCO 1934, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A ROCK WHICH PROJECTS 6 INCHES.  REFERENCE MARK 5 IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED ANASCO USGS NO 5 1934 1966, BRAZED TO THE TOP OF A 3-INCH ROUND CAST IRON SOIL PIPE WHICH PROJECTS 4 INCHES.  REFERENCE MARK 6 IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED ANASCO USGS NO 6 1934 1966, BRAZED TO THE TOP OF A 3-INCH ROUND CAST IRON SOIL PIPE WHICH PROJECTS 3 INCHES.  NO AZIMUTH MARK WAS ESTABLISHED AT THIS STATION.  AIRLINE DISTANCE AND DIRECTION FROM NEAREST TOWN 3-1/2 MILES ENE OF ANASCO.
markers.setting: SET IN ROCK OUTCROP
markers.stability: MOST RELIABLE AND EXPECTED TO HOLDPOSITION/ELEVATION WELL

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JWC) THE STATION IS LOCATED 10 AIRLINE MILES SOUTHEAST OF AGUADILLA, 8 AIRLINE MILES NORTHEAST OF MAYAGUEZ, 3-1/2 AIRLINE MILES EAST-NORTHEAST OF ANASCO AND ON THE TOP OF A BRUSH COVERED HILL.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE SOUTHEAST CORNER OF THE PLAZA IN ANASCO, GO EASTERLY ON HIGHWAY 109 FOR 3.45 MILES TO HIGHWAY 405.  TURN LEFT AND GO NORTHERLY ON HIGHWAY 405 FOR 2.2 MILES TO A TRAIL ON THE LEFT AT KILOMETER POST 3.5 AND END OF TRUCK TRAVEL.  FROM HERE PACK SOUTHWEST UPHILL FOR ABOUT 200 YARDS TO THE TOP OF THE BRUSH COVERED HILL AND THE STATION.  THE STATION MARK IS A STANDARD REFERENCE MARK DISK STAMPED ANASCO USGS NO 5 1934 1966, BRAZED TO THE TOP OF A 3-INCH ROUND CAST IRON SOIL PIPE WHICH PROJECTS 4 INCHES.

BY DEFENSE MAP AGENCY 1984 (RSS) THE STATION IS LOCATED AT ROOSEVELT ROADS NAVAL STATION AT THE DRONE LAUNCH SITE ON CABRAS ISLAND AND ON THE ROOF OF A 7.0 X 4.9 METER CONCRETE BLOCK BUILDING.  A SMOOTH BRASS DISK, EPOXIED IN A DRILL HOLE ON THE TOP AND CENTER OF THE CONCRETE ROOF, FLUSH WITH THE SURFACE AND STAMPED --ANGEL 1984--.  A PUNCH HOLE IN THE CENTER OF THE DISK MARKS THE STATION.

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1939 (HAC) STATION IS LOCATED ON THE FLAT TILE ROOF OF THE MIRAMAR APARTMENT HOUSE, SANTURCE, SAN JUAN.  THIS APARTMENT HOUSE IS ON THE W SIDE OF THE STREET PASSING S ALONG THE EASTERN SIDE OF THE UNION CLUB.  IT IS THE THIRD BUILDING FROM THE CORNER, UNION CLUB IS ON THE CORNER, MIRAMAR CLINIC (SECOND) AND MIRAMAR APARTMENT HOUSE (THIRD).  THE MIRAMAR APARTMENT HOUSE IS THE TALLEST BUILDING IN THIS VICINITY WITH A TOWER (ELEVATOR) ON THE N SIDE OF THE BUILDING.  THE ELEVATOR IN THE TOWER RUNS DIRECTLY TO THE ROOF OF THE APARTMENT HOUSE.  STATION IS LOCATED IN THE NW CORNER OF THE ROOF.  IT IS MARKED BY A SMALL CROSS CUT IN THE TOP SURFACE OF ONE OF THE ROOF TILES.  THE POINT CAN BE EASILY LOCATED FROM DIMENSIONS GIVEN IN THE SKETCH.                            STATION RECOVERY (1964)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1964 (GWM) THE ORIGINAL DESCRIPTION IS ADEQUATE FOR THE RECOVERY OF THIS STATION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1966)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (DCW) RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED EXCEPT SMALL CROSS HAS BEEN COVERED BY PAINT.

OWNERSHIP--ARECIBO OBSERVATORY JOSE MALDONADO, ASSISTANT DIRECTOR, HC BOX 53995, ARECIBO, PR 00612, PHONE 787-878-2612.  AN ARRANGEMENT MUST BE MADE FOR SPECIAL TRANSPORTATION TO THE SITE.  THE DISK IS NOT STAMPED.                            STATION RECOVERY (2004)  RECOVERY NOTE BY INDIVIDUAL CONTRIBUTORS 2004 (AE) RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JWC) THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 2-1/2 MILES NORTHEAST OF ARECIBO AND ON THE CONCRETE ROOF OF THE ARECIBO LIGHTHOUSE BUILDING.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE JUNCTION OF HIGHWAYS 2 AND 10 IN THE EAST PART OF ARECIBO, GO EAST ON HIGHWAY 2 FOR 0.7 MILE TO A Y-FORK.  TAKE THE LEFT FORK AND GO EAST ON A PAVED ROAD FOR 0.25 MILE TO A CROSSROAD.  CONTINUE EAST AND NORTH ON THE PAVED ROAD FOR 0.8 MILE TO A T-ROAD.  TURN LEFT AND GO WEST AND NORTH ON A PAVED ROAD FOR 0.4 MILE TO A SIDE ROAD ON THE RIGHT.  TURN RIGHT AND GO EASTERLY ON A GRAVELED ROAD FOR 0.2 MILE TO THE STATION ON THE LEFT.  THE STATION MARK IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED ARE 1966, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN THE CONCRETE ROOF OF THE LIGHTHOUSE BUILDING.  IT IS 47 FEET NORTHWEST OF THE SOUTHEAST CORNER OF THE BUILDING, 46.5 FEET SOUTHWEST OF THE NORTHEAST CORNER OF THE BUILDING, 46 FEET NORTHEAST OF THE SOUTHWEST CORNER OF THE BUILDING AND 44.5 FEET SOUTHEAST OF THE NORTHWEST CORNER OF THE BUILDING.  NO REFERENCE MARKS WERE SET.  NO AZIMUTH MARK WAS SET.                            STATION RECOVERY (1975)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1975 (JDS) THE STATION WAS RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED IN THE 1966 DESCRIPTION AND FOUND TO BE IN GOOD CONDITION.

markers.description: BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1901 (JN) THE LIGHTHOUSE IS ABOUT 3/4 MILE E OF ARECIBO, ON A ROCKY POINT CALLED EL CERO.  THE STATION OCCUPIED IS ECCENTRIC, THE INSTRUMENT BEING SET UP AS NEAR THE CENTER OF THE LANTERN PIER AS POSSIBLE.  THE CENTER OF THE PIER IS THE STATION.  THE INSTRUMENT WAS SET UP ON THE BRICK ROOF OF THE LIGHTHOUSE BUILDING. TRIANGULATION STATION ARE WAS ESTABLISHED AT THIS DATE IN THE NEAR VICINITY.  SEE DESCRIPTION THEREOF. TAKE THE LEFT FORK AND GO NORTHEASTERLY FOR 1.0 MILE TO A Y-FORK.  TAKE THE LEFT FORK FOR 0.5 MILE TO THE STATION.  THE MAST IS A 3-LEGGED, SELF-SUPPORTING STEEL TOWER, PAINTED ALTERNATELY RED AND WHITE AND IT HAS A REFLECTOR SCREEN ATOP.  THE MAST IS ABOUT 210 FEET HIGH.  POINT INTERSECTED IS THE RED OBSTRUCTION LIGHT ATOP THE MAST.                            STATION RECOVERY (1975)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1975 (JDS) STATION DESTROYED. TURN LEFT, AS PER SIGN, AND GO EASTERLY FOR 2.6 MILES TO A SIDE ROAD RIGHT.  TURN RIGHT AND GO SOUTHERLY FOR 2.6 MILES TO THE STATION.  THE TOWER IS A CONCRETE, PILLAR-SHAPED STRUCTURE, WHITE IN COLOR, WITH FIVE GUY CABLES ON THE SOUTHEAST SIDE AND IT IS 250 FEET HIGH.  IT IS THE SOUTHEAST TOWER OF THREE TOWERS.  POINT INTERSECTED IS THE RED OBSTRUCTION LIGHT ATOP THE TOWER.

BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1900 (WCH) STATION IS ON THE LOW, SANDY POINT (TAKING ITS NAME FROM THAT CIRCUMSTANCE) WHICH FORMS THE NW EXTREMITY OF VIEQUES ISLAND AND FROM WHICH A DANGEROUS SAND SHOAL EXTENDS SEVERAL MILES TOWARDS PUERTO RICO.  THE OUTER PART OF THIS POINT SEEMS TO BE CHANGEABLE, BEING COMPOSED OF LOOSE SAND.  THE STATION WAS PLACED ON THE FIRMER, GRASSY FLAT BETWEEN THE BEACH AND THE BUSHES.  MARKED BY A PIECE OF 2-INCH IRON PIPE SET IN CONCRETE AND WITH ABOUT 6 INCHES OF THE PIPE PROJECTING.  TRIPOD SIGNAL, 30 FEET TO FLAG.                            STATION RECOVERY (1902)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1902 (RLF) RECOVERED.  SIGNAL STANDING IN POSITION AND VERTICAL.  STATION MARKS NOT EXAMINED.  SIGNAL IN GOOD CONDITION.  TARGETS AND BOARDS PUT ON SIGNAL FOR HYDROGRAPHIC WORK.  DESCRIPTION OF STATION IS AMPLE.                            STATION RECOVERY (1904)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1904 (RLF) STATION COULD NOT BE FOUND.  THE STATION HAS EITHER BEEN WASHED AWAY OR ELSE DEEPLY BURIED IN THE SANDS, BY THE ACTION OF THE SEA.  A SIGNAL WAS ERECTED IN THE VICINITY FOR HYDROGRAPHIC WORK AND POSITION LOCATED BY SEXTANT ANGLES.  STATION NOT PERMANENTLY MARKED.                            STATION RECOVERY (1922)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1922 (FTS) STATION WASHED AWAY BY EROSION OF SHORE LINE.                            STATION RECOVERY (1959)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US NAVY 1959 STATION WAS DESTROYED BY EROSION OF BEACH BY HIGH WAVES.  REFERENCE POINTS WERE FOUND AND MEASUREMENTS TO THE MARK WAS CHECKED.  NEW HOUSE BUILT IN VICINITY OF MARK AND CONCRETE SIDEWALK BUILT OVER POSITION OF MARK.  1/2-INCH DRILL HOLE IN SIDEWALK WAS ESTABLISHED FROM REFERENCES AND LEAD PLUG WAS PLACED IN DRILL HOLE.
markers.setting: UNSPECIFIED SETTING

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1910 (NHH) THIS STATION IS ON A SANDY POINT, CALLED POINT ARENAS, ABOUT 1-1/2 MILES S OF GUANAJIBO POINT, ON LAND OF R. CABANILLAS.  IT IS IN THE SAND 50 FEET FROM MEAN HIGH WATER TO THE S AND 40 FEET FROM MEAN HIGH WATER MARK TO THE N.  IT IS 138.4 FEET FROM THE NW CORNER OF A HOUSE WHICH BEARS ABOUT E BY S.  STATION MARK IS A 5-INCH TILE, 3-1/2 FEET LONG, PROJECTING 6 INCHES ABOVE THE SURFACE, WHICH IS FILLED WITH AND SURROUNDED BY CEMENT.  THE CENTER MARK IS A WIRE NAIL, THE HEAD BEING FLUSH WITH THE CEMENT IN THE TILE.  IN THE CEMENT ARE THE LETTERS U.S.C. AND G.S. 1910.
markers.setting: SET IN CONCRETE IN A CLAY TILE PIPE
markers.stability: MARK OF QUESTIONABLE OR UNKNOWN STABILITY

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1922 (FTS) STATION IS ON POINT ARENAS ON NW END OF VIEQUES ISLAND, AND IS ABOUT 10 METERS FROM S BEACH AND 15 METERS FROM EDGE OF UNDERBRUSH AND 175 METERS FROM THE EDGE OF A COCONUT GROVE.  THE STATION AND REFERENCE MARKS ARE STANDARD BRONZE DISKS SET IN CONCRETE AS DESCRIBED IN NOTES 1A AND 11A.  THE STATION MARK WAS PLACED IN A PIER OF CONCRETE PROJECTING 1-1/2 FEET ABOVE THE SURFACE, WITH WOODEN FORM LEFT IN PLACE.  THE REFERENCE MARKS ARE SIMILAR, THE PIER PROJECTING ABOUT 6 INCHES ABOVE THE SURFACE.  THEY ARE IN THE DIRECTION OF THE COCONUT GROVE FROM THE STATION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1926)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1926 (GCM) STATION RECOVERED.  SANDY POINT IS BECOMING OVER-GROWN WITH VEGETATION SO THAT RECOVERY OF STATION AND REFERENCE MARKS OUGHT TO BE POSSIBLE IN THE FUTURE.  MARKS ARE NOW SAFE FROM EFFECTS OF SEVERE STORMS.  TO AID IN FUTURE RECOVERY, THE FOLLOWING ADDITIONAL INFORMATION IS FURNISHED.  THE SOUTHERLY HIGH-WATER MARK IS NOW ABOUT 25 METERS FROM THE STATION, THE BEACH HAVING BUILT OUT ABOUT 15 METERS SINCE THE STATION WAS ESTABLISHED.  COCONUT PALMS HAVE BEEN PLANTED BETWEEN THE OLD GROVE AND THE STATION.  FOUR OF THESE PALMS ARE CONSPICUOUS FOR THEIR SIZE AS COMPARED WITH THE REST OF THE VEGETATION SURROUNDING THEM.  THESE FOUR PALMS APPEAR TO BE ABOUT FIVE YEARS OLD AT THIS DATE.  THE NEAREST PALM IS 12 METERS TO THE EASTWARD OF THE STATION, 106 DEG 00 MIN FROM THE CABRAS ISLAND LIGHTHOUSE.  THE NEXT TWO PALMS ARE CLOSE TOGETHER AND ABOUT 30 METERS FROM THE FIRST. THE FOURTH PALM IS ABOUT 30 METERS FROM THE TWO CENTER ONES. THE FOUR PALMS ARE PRACTICALLY ON LINE AND FORM A RANGE WHICH PASSES ABOUT 5 FEET TO THE NORTHWARD OF THE STATION.  STATION AND REFERENCE MARKS WERE FOUND IN GOOD CONDITION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1927)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1927 (RJA) STATION AND REFERENCE MARKS RECOVERED ALTHOUGH COVERED BY ABOUT TWO FEET OF SAND.                            STATION RECOVERY (1962)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1962 (ELJ) STATION AND REFERENCE MARKS WERE SEARCHED FOR.  NO EVIDENCE OF THE MARKS WAS FOUND AFTER ABOUT 1-1/2 HOURS OF SEARCHING.  THE STATION AREA IS NOTHING BUT A SHIFTING SAND SPIT WHICH COULD HAVE BUILT UP OR WORN AWAY SINCE THE LAST RECOVERY IN 1927.  MEASUREMENTS TO THE STATION MARK WERE TO A SHIFTING HIGH WATER LINE AND FOUR PALM TREES.  NO TREES IN THE RELATIONSHIP DESCRIBED IN 1926 WERE POSITIVELY IDENTIFIED.  IF THE STATION OR REFERENCE MARKS ARE STILL THERE, THEY MAY BE COVERED WITH A NUMBER OF FEET OF SAND.  A CONCERTED PROBING EFFORT IN ALL LIKELY PLACES MAY LOCATE THE STATION MARK.
markers.setting: SET IN TOP OF CONCRETE MONUMENT
markers.stability: MAY HOLD, BUT OF TYPE COMMONLY SUBJECT TOSURFACE MOTION

markers.description: BY ANDREGG INCORPORATED 1995 (DJR) TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE BOQUERON POST OFFICE, GO EAST 0.25 MILES (0.40 KM) ALONG HIGHWAY PR 101 TO HIGHWAY PR 100  THE STATION IS LOCATED IN THE NORTHEAST ISLAND AT THE INTERSECTION OF HIGHWAYS PR 100 AND PR 101, 4.6 MILES (7.4 KM) SOUTH OF THE INTERSECTION OF HIGHWAYS PR 100 AND PR 102.  THE STATION IS 4.3 METERS (14.1 FT) EAST OF THE EAST EDGE OF PAVEMENT OF NORTH-BOUND HIGHWAY PR 100, 4.4 METERS (14.4 FT) WEST OF THE WEST EDGE OF PAVEMENT OF ON-RAMP FROM HIGHWAY PR 101 TO HIGHWAY PR 100, AND 37.5 METERS (123.0 FT) NORTH OF CONCRETE TRAFFIC SIGNAL POLE AT THE NORTHEAST CORNER OF INTERSECTION OF HIGHWAYS PR 100 AND PR 101  THE STATION IS 1 METER (3.3 FT) SOUTH OF A CARSONITE SURVEY MARKER WITNESS POST  THE STATION IS A 3-1/4 INCH BRASS CAP STAMPED CENTRO DE RECAUDACION DE INGRESSOS MUNICIPALES, PUERTO RICO GPS CONTROL, C.R.I.M., UNLAWFUL TO DISTURB, ARENAS 2A, SET ATOP A 9/16 INCH STAINLESS STEEL ROD DRIVEN TO REFUSAL AND COVERED FLUSH WITH THE GROUND BY AN ALUMINUM COVER EPOXYED ONTO A 6 INCH SCHEDULE 40 PVC PIPE SET IN CONCRETE INSIDE AND OUT                            STATION RECOVERY (2004)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 2004 (EJS) RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.                            STATION RECOVERY (2012)  RECOVERY NOTE BY POLYTECHNIC UNIVERSITY OF PUERTO RICO 2012 MARK RECOVERED IN POOR CONDITION.

TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE INTERSECTION OF PR-2, PR-680 AND PR-681 IN ARECIBO, GO NORTH ON PR-680 FOR 0.1 MI (0.2 KM) TO THE STATION ON THE RIGHT AT THE START OF CONCRETE BRIDGE.   THE STATION IS 11.84 M (38.8 FT) NORTH OF A 20-INCH (51 CM) TREE, 8.87 M (29.1 FT) NORTHWEST OF A METAL GUARD RAIL, 7.96 M (26.1 FT) EAST OF THE CENTERLINE OF PR-680, 2.93 M (9.6 FT) NORTHWEST OF A BEND IN BRIDGE RAIL AND 1.97 M (6.5 FT) WEST OF THE CONCRETE BRIDGE RAIL.

THE STATION IS 14.37 M (47.1 FT) SOUTHWEST OF THE CORNER OF A BUS STOP, 8.66 M (28.4 FT) NORTHEAST OF PR-10 SOUTHBOUND, 5.21 M (17.1 FT) SOUTHWEST OF THE CENTERLINE OF PR-10 NORTHBOUND AND 0.39 M (1.3 FT) NORTHWEST OF THE SOUTHEAST END OF CONCRETE MEDIAN.
