BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1900 (JBB) THIS STATION IS ON THE HIGHEST POINT OF THE RIDGE W OF ALOE POINT.  TWO LARGE ROCKS LIE W BY N OF THE STATION SOME 10 METERS DISTANT.  STATION WAS MARKED BY A NAIL SET IN A CEMENT POST 4 BY 4 INCHES IN SIZE AND PROJECTING SOME 6 INCHES ABOVE THE GROUND.  STATION IS BEST REACHED BY LANDING IN VALLEY MIDWAY BETWEEN ALOE POINT AND BASS POND AND PASSING UP THROUGH THE CLEARED LAND.  A TRAIL LEADS FROM THE HIGHEST CULTIVATED PATCH TO THE STATION, WHICH IS SOME 40 METERS ABOVE ITS SW CORNER.  A TRIPOD SIGNAL WAS ERECTED OVER THE STATION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1922)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1922 (FTS) STATION RECOVERED.  MARK IN POOR CONDITION, HAVING BEEN BROKEN OFF AT SURFACE, PROBABLY BY CATTLE.  SUBSURFACE PORTION OF MARK HAD NOT BEEN DISTURBED.  ORIGINAL MARK WAS REPLACED BY CONCRETE POST 6- BY 6- BY 24-INCH WITH A STANDARD BRONZE DISK CEMENTED IN THE TOP.  SAME WAS SET IN GROUND TO PROJECT ABOUT 3 INCHES ABOVE SURFACE AND A HEAP OF LOOSE ROCK MADE OVER THE ROCK.  TWO REFERENCE MARKS WERE ESTABLISHED BEING STANDARD BRONZE DISKS CEMENTED INTO TWO LARGE BOULDERS NEARBY.  REFERENCE MARK NO.1 IS CEMENTED INTO THE TOP OF A ROCK 8 FEET HIGH AND 15 FEET LONG OF CYLINDRICAL SHAPE ON S SIDE OF FENCE LINE S OF STATION.  REFERENCE MARK NO.2 IS CEMENTED IN LARGER AND MORE DISTANT OF TWO BOULDERS W OF STATION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1926)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1926 (GCM) STATION RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED BY F.B.T.S.  PART OF THE TOP OF THE POST HAD BEEN BROKEN OFF AND STATION MARK REMOVED, LEAVING IMPRESSION (IN CEMENT) OF ONE-HALF OF A STANDARD BRASS DISK.  A NEW STATION MARK WAS NOT ESTABLISHED BECAUSE OF THE POSSIBILITY OF BEING REMOVED BY THE NATIVES.  THE IMPRESSION OF THE STEM OF THE MARK WAS USED IN ERECTING INSTRUMENT FOR OBSERVING.  A TRIPOD SIGNAL WAS FOUND STANDING OVER STATION IN GOOD CONDITION.  REFERENCE MARK IN GOOD CONDITION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1963)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US NAVY 1963 STATION RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED BY G.C.M., 1926.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 1 DESTROYED.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 2 - IN GOOD CONDITION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1966)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JJL) THE STATION MARK WAS NOT RECOVERED BUT THE CONCRETE MONUMENT WITH THE IMPRESSION OF THE DISK STEM WAS RECOVERED.  A NEW DISK WAS SET IN THIS IMPRESSION AND THE MONUMENT WAS REINFORCED WITH CEMENT.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 2 WAS RECOVERED AND FOUND IN GOOD CONDITION.  A SEARCH WAS MADE FOR REFERENCE MARK NO. 1 BUT IT WAS NOT RECOVERED AND REFERENCE MARK NO. 3 WAS ESTABLISHED.  A COMPLETE DESCRIPTION FOLLOWS--  THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 1-1/4 MILES NORTH-NORTHWEST OF THE EXTREME SOUTH TIP OF CULEBRA ISLAND, 3/4 MILE SOUTHEAST OF CULEBRA AND ON THE HIGHEST POINT OF A RIDGE THAT IS PARTIALLY COVERED WITH TREES.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE POST OFFICE IN CULEBRA, GO EASTERLY FOR 0.05 MILE TO A Y-FORK.  TAKE THE LEFT FORK FOR 0.05 MILE TO A REVERSE Y-FORK.  TURN SHARP RIGHT AND GO SOUTHERLY FOR 0.1 MILE TO A CROSSROAD.  THIS IS JUST AFTER CROSSING A CONCRETE BRIDGE AND JUST BEFORE REACHING A CHAIN-LINK FENCE GATE.  TURN LEFT AND GO EAST AND SOUTH FOR 1.2 MILES TO A GATE ON THE RIGHT, ON THE NORTH SIDE OF A CORRAL.  TURN RIGHT AND PASS THROUGH THE GATE, THENCE TURN LEFT AND PASS THROUGH THE CORRAL TO THE SOUTH SIDE OF THE CORRAL.  (A FOUR-WHEEL DRIVE VEHICLE IS REQUIRED FROM THIS POINT.) BEAR RIGHT AND GO SOUTH-WEST FOR 0.05 MILE TO THE TOP OF A RIDGE.  BEAR RIGHT AND GO WESTERLY, GENERALLY FOLLOWING THE RIDGE, FOR 0.3 MILE TO A NORTH-SOUTH FENCE LINE.  TURN RIGHT AND GO NORTH ALONG THE FENCE FOR ABOUT 100 YARDS TO A T-FENCE CORNER AND THE END OF TRUCK TRAVEL.  PACK WESTERLY ALONG THE SOUTH SIDE OF THE FENCE FOR ABOUT 100 YARDS TO THE HIGHEST POINT AND THE STATION.  THE STATION MARK, STAMPED AST 1900 1966, IS A STANDARD DISK SET IN THE TOP OF A CONICAL-SHAPED CONCRETE MONUMENT THAT PROJECTS 3 INCHES.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 2, UNSTAMPED, IS A STANDARD DISK CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A LARGE BOULDER THAT PROJECTS 5 FEET.  (NOTE 12C).  REFERENCE MARK NO. 3, STAMPED AST NO 3 1900 1966, IS A STANDARD DISK CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A LARGE BOULDER THAT PROJECTS 6 FEET.  (NOTE 12C).  AIRLINE DISTANCE AND DIRECTION FROM NEAREST TOWN 3/4 MILE SOUTHEAST OF CULEBRA.

BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1900 (JN) STATION IS ON THE TOP OF THE LEFT-HAND PEAK OF THE HIGH MOUNTAIN JUST BACK OF TRES HERMANOS STATION ON THE MAYAGUEZ-AGUADILLA BRANCH OF THE FERRE CARRILES DE P.R.  THE MOUNTAIN SEEMS TO HAVE A FAIRLY LEVEL TOP (BUT IT HASNT) FROM THE RAILROAD STATION AND THE POINT ON WHICH THE SIGNAL IS SEEMS TO BE THE HIGHEST PEAK.  IT IS ENTIRELY CLEAR OF TREES, BUT ABOUT 25 FEET BELOW THE TOP IS A LITTLE GROUP OF MANGOES.  THESE SHOW AS ONE TREE A LITTLE WAY BELOW THE TOP AND ON THE LEFT RIDGE COMING FROM THE SUMMIT.  THE STATION MARK IS A 2-INCH IRON PIPE, BURIED IN THE GROUND FOR ABOUT 17 INCHES AND LEAVING ABOUT 2-1/2 INCHES EXPOSED.  IT WAS EMBEDDED IN CEMENT AND THE CENTER OF THE PIPE WAS FILLED WITH THE SAME MATERIAL.  IN THE MIDDLE OF THE PIPE WAS SET AN IRON NAIL AND THE CENTER OF THE HEAD OF THIS NAIL MARKS THE STATION.  ABOUT 25 FEET (VERTICALLY) BELOW THE SIGNAL AND ABOUT SW FROM IT, IS A ROW OF MANGO TREES, YOUNG AND THRIVING.  THE SPANIARDS HAD A SIGNAL ABOUT 9 OR 10 FEET E OF THIS ONE, BUT LEFT NO STATION MARK AND WE ONLY KNOW OF ITS FORMER EXISTENCE HERE FROM THE REPORT HEARD FROM THE NATIVES.  TO REACH THE SUMMIT, TWO WAYS CAN BE UTILIZED.  ONE IS TO FOLLOW THE TRACK WESTWARD FROM TRES HERMANOS AND CROSSING TWO BRIDGES, GO ON FOR A FEW HUNDRED METERS WHERE INQUIRIES SHOULD BE MADE FOR A ROAD THAT GOES UP THE BED OF A CREEK AT THE BEGINNING AND LEADING OUT OF THIS WILL BE FOUND A FAIR BUT VERY STEEP ROAD, WHICH CAN BE FOLLOWED TO THE SUMMIT AND THE STATION.  ON A VERY SURE FOOTED HORSE OR MULE, ONE CAN RIDE MOST OF THE WAY UP.  THE SECOND AND BETTER WAY OF REACHING THE SIGNAL IS TO GO TO CORSICA (OR CORCHEGA) STATION FOR A STARTING POINT.  AT CORSICA, ATALAYA SHOWS IN THE E AS THE HIGHEST MOUNTAIN IN VIEW.  A GUIDE CAN BE SECURED HERE WHO WILL TAKE ONE UP.  IF HE DOES NOT KNOW THE STATION BY NAME, OR AS THE BANDERA CERRO HE WILL KNOW WHERE TO TAKE ONE WHEN ASKED TO LEAD TO MIGUEL CARREROS HOME.  MIGUEL CARRERO IS THE OWNER OF THE HILLTOP AND HIS HOME IS AT THE HEAD OF A LITTLE GULCH JUST E OF THE SIGNAL AND ABOUT 75 FEET (VERTICALLY) BELOW IT.  A TRAIL LEADS RIGHT OVER THE SUMMIT OF THE MOUNTAIN AND THE SIGNAL HAVING BEEN ESTABLISHED IN THE CENTER OF THE PATH.  SENOR CARRERO DEFLECTED THE PATH, CUT OUT A NEW LOCATION AND PLACED A FENCE OF WILD PINEAPPLE BUSHES BETWEEN THE SIGNAL AND THE NEW TRAIL.  THE TOP OF THE PEAK IS VERY LIMITED IN EXTENT AND THE SIGNAL IS ON THE VERY HIGHEST PART OF IT AND ABOUT IN ITS CENTER.                            STATION RECOVERY (1901)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1901 (JEM) THE SURFACE MARK WAS FOUND APPARENTLY UNDISTURBED IN JANUARY 1901, BUT A STORM OF LAST OCTOBER LEFT ONLY ABOUT 20 INCHES OF THE JAGGED END OF THE POLE ABOVE THE TRIPOD BOLT, AND THE S LEG WAS BROKEN (AT A SPLICE) BY THE SAME STORM.  THIS WAS AFTERWARDS REPLACED AND A NEW POLE WAS SET IN PLACE ON THE SIGNAL.                            STATION RECOVERY (1910)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1910 (NHH) THE STATION MARK IS GONE, BUT THE CONCRETE IS NEARLY ALL THERE.  IT IS IN TWO PIECES, LEFT WHEN THE PIPE WAS BROKEN OUT, THE LARGER OF WHICH IS UNCHANGED IN POSITION.  THE CENTER CAN BE ACCURATELY OCCUPIED.  THERE WAS NO CHANCE TO REPAIR THE STATION MARK AS THE TRIANGULATION WAS COMPLETED AT THE TIME IT WAS RECOVERED.
markers.setting: SET INTO TOP OF METAL PIPE DRIVEN INTO GROUND
markers.stability: MARK OF QUESTIONABLE OR UNKNOWN STABILITY

markers.description: BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1934 STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 15 KILOMETERS BY ROAD AND TRAIL N OF MAYAGUEZ, ON A HIGH SHARP PEAK AT W END OF THE HIGH RANGE EXTENDING WESTWARD TO THE COAST BETWEEN MAYAGUEZ AND AGUADILLA.  THIS STATION IS ON THE SAME PEAK AS THE FORMER U.S.C. AND G.S. STATION ATALAYA, WHICH COULD NOT BE RECOVERED, ONLY TRACES OF BROKEN CONCRETE BEING FOUND ON THE PEAK, BUT AS THE SUMMIT IS VERY LIMITED THE NEW STATION IS PROBABLY VERY NEAR THE OLD ONE.  THE SURFACE MARK IS A STANDARD TABLET, STAMPED ATALAYA 2 1934 CEMENTED IN A BOULDER SET IN THE GROUND DIRECTLY OVER THE UNDERGROUND MARK.  THE UNDERGROUND MARK IS A CROSS CUT IN A ROUNDED BOULDER.  REFERENCE MARKS--NAIL IN END OF ROOF JOIST AT NE CORNER OF TIENDA 30.98 FEET (INCLINED DISTANCE) FROM STATION IN TRUE AZIMUTH 335 DEG 46 MIN.  A NAIL IN END OF JOIST AT NW CORNER OF TIENDA, 28.60 FEET (INCLINED DISTANCE) FROM STATION IN TRUE AZIMUTH 358 DEG 02 MIN.  A NAIL IN BLAZE ON MANGO TREE 3 FEET ABOVE GROUND, 70.9 FEET (INCLINED DISTANCE) FROM STATION IN TRUE AZIMUTH 64 DEG 13 MIN.  A CROSS CUT IN EXPOSED ROCK ON SW SLOPE 37.55 FEET (INCLINED DISTANCE) FROM STATION IN TRUE AZIMUTH 100 DEG 00 MIN.  THE STATION IS BEST REACHED FROM THE S BY GOING TO THE MAYORDOMOS RESIDENCE AND EMPLOYEES QUARTERS OF CENTRAL IGUALDAD, WHICH ARE AT THE FOOT OF THE MOUNTAINS, N OF THE HIGHWAY AT KILOMETER POST K.172-H4 THERE IS A TIENDA OR STORE JUST BACK OF THE LONG SHED AND EMPLOYEES QUARTERS AND A GOOD TRAIL FROM HERE TO THE TOP.  A NEW TIENDA HAS JUST BEEN BUILT IN A SHELF CUT INTO THE N SIDE OF THE PEAK VERY NEAR THE TOP AND EVEN THOUGH THE BUILDING SHOULD LATER BE DESTROYED, THE DUG SHELF WILL BE IN EVIDENCE FOR MANY YEARS.                            STATION RECOVERY (1952)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1952 (JOP) STATION IS LOCATED ON THE HIGHEST POINT, A BARE KNOB, OF HIGH MOUNTAIN AND IS ABOUT 3 MILES EAST OF THE TOWN OF AGUADA.  IT IS ON THE APPROXIMATE CENTER OF THE KNOB AND IS A STANDARD U.S.G.S. TRIANGULATION BENCH MARK DISK CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A BOULDER FLUSH WITH THE GROUND AND IS STAMPED ATALAYA 2 1934.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 1 A STANDARD U.S.C. AND G.S. REFERENCE MARK DISK AND IS ABOUT 4 FEET LOWER THAN THE STATION MARK AND IS STAMPED ATALAYA 2 NO 1 1934.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 2 IS A STANDARD U.S.C. AND G.S. REFERENCE MARK DISK STAMPED ATALAYA 2 NO 2 1934, AND IS ABOUT 3 FEET LOWER THAN THE STATION MARK.  TO REACH FROM THE TRAFFIC LIGHT IN THE SOUTH EDGE OF AGUADA GO EAST ON A PAVED ROAD FOR 3.7 MILES OF PAVEMENT, CONTINUE STRAIGHT AHEAD FOR 0.1 MILE TO A LARGE BUILDING ON THE RIGHT, CONTINUE STRAIGHT AHEAD UP STEEP HILL ON A DIRT ROAD FOR 1.0 MILE TO A T-ROAD RIGHT, TURN RIGHT AND GO 0.5 MILE TO WHERE ROAD FORKS AND END OF TRUCK TRAVEL.  FROM THIS POINT TAKE LEFT TRAIL AND FOLLOW IT ALONG RIDGE FOR ABOUT 1.25 MILES TO WHERE TRAIL PASSES BY THE HIGHEST POINT AND THE STATION AS DESCRIBED. (ABOUT A 25 MINUTE PACK).  HEIGHT OF LIGHT ABOVE STATION MARK 1 METER.                            STATION RECOVERY (1956)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1956 (EAT) THE STATION WAS RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED BY J.O.P. IN 1952 AND THE STATION MARK WAS FOUND IN GOOD CONDITION.  BOTH REFERENCE MARKS HAVE BEEN DESTROYED.  NO NEW REFERENCE MARKS WERE SET BY THIS PARTY.                            STATION RECOVERY (1966)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1966 STATION DESTROYED.  TV TOWER BUILT AT SITE.

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1965 (JJL) THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 2-1/2 MILES SOUTHEAST OF LUQUILLO, 3-1/2 MILES NORTHWEST OF FAJARDO AND 1/4 MILE NORTH OF THE MOUTH OF MARTIN CREEK. IT IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED ATLANTIC NO 2 1965 AND SET IN A 12 INCH ROUND CONCRETE MONUMENT PROJECTING 2 INCHES.

THE STATION IS 0.3 MILE SOUTHWESTERLY OF THE GATE.  PERMISSION TO VISIT THE STATION MUST BE OBTAINED FROM UNION CARBIDE OFFICIALS.                            STATION RECOVERY (1971)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1971 (EKM) THE STATION WAS RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.  THE DESCRIPTION BY JJL IN 1966 SHOULD BE ALTERED TO READ--  THE STATION IS THE TRIANGULAR-SHAPED TARGET (APEX OF A DIAMOND SHAPED DAYMARK) THAT SETS--------  THE TO-REACH SHOULD READ--  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE INTERSECTION OF MARINA STREET AND THE PONCE BY-PASS IN PONCE, GO WEST ON PONCE BY-PASS (HWY 2) FOR 8.2 MILES TO THE TALLABOA EXIT (HWY 127) ON THE RIGHT.  TURN RIGHT AND FOLLOW ROAD TO THE LEFT AND UNDER HWY 2 TO A T INTERSECTION.  TURN RIGHT AND FOLLOW HWY 127 FOR 1.4 MILES TO UNION CARBIDE INC. MAIN OFFICE ON THE LEFT.  PERMISSION WILL BE REQUIRED OF UNION CARBIDE TO VISIT THE STATION.  DIRECTIONS AS TO THE PREFERRED ROUTE TO REACH THE STATION SHOULD BE OBTAINED FROM UNION CARBIDE WHEN OBTAINING ENTRY PERMISSION.

BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JJL) THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 9-1/2 MILES WEST OF PONCE, 3-1/2 MILES EAST-SOUTHEAST OF GUAYANILLA AND ON THE GROUNDS OF THE UNION CARBIDE REFINERY.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE PLAZA IN GUAYANILLA, GO EASTERLY ON HIGHWAY 2 FOR 4-1/2 MILES TO THE UNION CARBIDE REFINERY AND THE STATION ON THE RIGHT, SOUTH, SIDE OF THE HIGHWAY.  THE STATION IS THE TRIANGULAR-SHAPED TARGET THAT SETS ATOP AND ON THE SOUTH SIDE OF A CYLINDRICAL CONCRETE TOWER THAT IS BROWN IN COLOR AND IS ABOUT 100 FEET HIGH.                            STATION RECOVERY (1969)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1969 (JKW) THE STATION WAS RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.  THERE IS ANOTHER, AND LARGER, DIAMOND SHAPED TARGET (DAYMARK) ON THE SOUTH SIDE OF THE CONCRETE TANK.  THIS TARGET IS DIRECTLY UNDER THE TARGET MENTIONED IN THE ORIGINAL DESCRIPTION.  THE REMAINDER OF THE ORIGINAL DESCRIPTION IS ADEQUATE.  A NEW TO REACH FOLLOWS--FROM THE INTERSECTION OF MARINA STREET AND PONCE BYPASS IN PONCE, GO WEST ON PONCE BYPASS (HWY 2) FOR 8.2 MILES TO THE TALLABOA EXIT (HWY 127 AND OLD HWY 2), TAKE EXIT AND CONTINUE 1.5 MILES TO THE MAIN GATE OF THE UNION CARBIDE COMPANY REFINERY.  THE STATION IS APPROX 0.9 MILE SOUTH SOUTHWEST OF THE GATE.  PERMISSION MUST BE OBTAINED FROM UNION CARBIDE OFFICIALS BEFORE VISITING THE STATION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1971)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1971 (EKM) THE STATION WAS RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.  THE DESCRIPTION BY JJL IN 1966 SHOULD BE ALTERED TO READ--  THE STATION IS THE TRIANGULAR-SHAPED TARGET (APEX OF A DIAMOND SHAPED DAYMARK) THAT SETS--------  THE TO-REACH SHOULD READ--  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE INTERSECTION OF MARINA STREET AND THE PONCE BY-PASS IN PONCE, GO WEST ON PONCE BY-PASS (HWY 2) FOR 8.2 MILES TO THE TALLABOA EXIT (HWY 127) ON THE RIGHT.  TURN RIGHT AND FOLLOW ROAD TO THE LEFT AND UNDER HWY 2 TO A T INTERSECTION.  TURN RIGHT AND FOLLOW HWY 127 FOR 1.4 MILES TO UNION CARBIDE INC. MAIN OFFICE ON THE LEFT.  PERMISSION WILL BE REQUIRED OF UNION CARBIDE TO VISIT THE STATION.  DIRECTIONS AS TO THE PREFERRED ROUTE TO REACH THE STATION SHOULD BE OBTAINED FROM UNION CARBIDE WHEN OBTAINING ENTRY PERMISSION.

BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1901 (JN) THIS STATION IS ON THE HIGHEST HILL CALLED CUEVA DE LAS GOLONDRINA NEAR VEGA BAJA.  IT IS ABOUT 1/3 MILE SW OF THE PLAZA IN VEGA BAJA, ON THE HIGHEST POINT OF A HILL 20 FEET E OF THE W EDGE OF DECLIVITY.  THE STATION IS MARKED BY A GALVANIZED-IRON PIPE 2 FEET BY 2 INCHES CEMENTED INTO A HOLE DRILLED IN THE SOLID ROCK.  THE POINT IS THE CENTER OF A 20-PENNY SPIKE CEMENTED INTO THE UPPER PART OF THE PIPE.                            STATION RECOVERY (1931)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1931 STATION RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED.  LAND OWNED BY ANDRES GUERRERO.  CONCRETE MONUMENT WITH IRON ROD MARKS THE STATION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1946)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US ARMY CORPS OF ENGINEERS 1946 LETTER FROM MR. E.G. RUBIO, HQ. ANTILLES DEPT., OFFICE OF DEPT. OF ENGR., A.P.O. 851, C/O P.M., MIAMI, FLORIDA, DATED OCTOBER 30, 1946--  THE PIPE STILL IN PLACE.  HAD BEEN PULLED OUT BUT FOUND AND REPLACED IN ORIGINAL HOLE.                            STATION RECOVERY (1959)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1959 (MM) THE STATION WAS LOCATED AS DESCRIBED, AND IT WAS FOUND IN GOOD CONDITION.
markers.setting: SET INTO TOP OF METAL PIPE DRIVEN INTO GROUND
markers.stability: MARK OF QUESTIONABLE OR UNKNOWN STABILITY

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1967 (SCM) THE STATION IS THE LIGHT ATOP OF THE BAJOS CHINCHORO DEL SUR FIXED AID TO NAVIGATION.  IT IS 4.2 MILES EAST OF PUNTA PUERCA 7.8 MILES NORTHEAST OF PTA. ARENAS, AND 6.7 MILES NORTHWEST OF PUNTA MULAS.  THE LIGHT IS RATED AT 800 CANDLE POWER AND CAN BE SEEN AT A DISTANCE OF 9 MILES.  THE LIGHT IS ATOP OF A STEEL- TOWER MOUNTED ON FOUR PILINGS.  FOUR RED AND WHITE CHECKERED DAY MARKERS ARE SECURED TO THE TOWER.

BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1934 STATION IS 10 KILOMETERS BY ROAD NW OF MOROVIS AND 4 KILOMETERS NE OF THE JUNCTION OF CARRETERA NO.20 AND CARRETERA NO.30 AND ABOUT 1 KILOMETER W OF THE LATTER, ON A PROMINENT CORAL LIMESTONE PEAK ON LAND OWNED BY FRANCISCO JIMENEZ MENA OF VEGA BAJA.  IT IS ON THE FIRST HIGH PEAK W OF CARRETERA NO.30, ABOUT OPPOSITE POST K 8 AND IS BEST REACHED FROM THIS POINT.  THE STATION IS NEAR THE CENTER OF THE SUMMIT OF THE PEAK.  STATION MARK IS A STANDARD U.S.G.S. TABLET, STAMPED BARAHONA 1934, CEMENTED IN A NATURAL LIMESTONE CAP ROCK.  REFERENCE MARKS ARE DRILL HOLES IN EXPOSED LIMESTONE ROCKS.  REFERENCE MARK NO.1 IS 16.10 FEET FROM STATION IN TRUE AZIMUTH 53 DEG 13 MIN.  REFERENCE MARK NO.2 IS 17.00 FEET FROM STATION IN TRUE AZIMUTH 213 DEG 43 MIN.  SIGNAL--A QUADRIPOD OF SAWED LUMBER COVERED WITH BLACK CROSS TARGETS ON CENTER POLE.                            STATION RECOVERY (1941)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1941 (GBG) STATION AND REFERENCE MARKS RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED IN GOOD CONDITION.  TO REACH FROM VEGA BAJA, GO W ON ROAD 2 ABOUT 1-1/2 MILES TO JUNCTION WITH ROAD 30.  FROM HERE GO S 5.1 MILES TO VICINITY OF KM.8.  LEAVE CAR.  AND TAKE PATH W UP HILL, BEARING LEFT AS FIRST HOUSE IS APPROACHED.  PASS THROUGH FENCE AND CONTINUE CLIMBING TO ANOTHER HOUSE.  CONTINUE ON DIM TRAIL PAST HOUSE AND FOLLOW AROUND BASE OF HILL ABOUT 200 METERS, WHERE, TURN RIGHT AND GO DIRECTLY UP TO RIDGE.  AND THEN W TO TOP AND STATION.
markers.setting: SET IN ROCK OUTCROP
markers.stability: MOST RELIABLE AND EXPECTED TO HOLDPOSITION/ELEVATION WELL

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1901 (JBB) ON THE POINT N OF THE HARBOR OF YABACOA.  STATION IS IN CENTER OF THE RIDGE MAKING BACK FROM THE END OF THE POINT AND ABOUT 80 METERS FROM IT.  ON AN OPEN GRASSY PLOT JUST OUTSIDE OF THE LARGE BRUSH.  STATION IS MARKED BY A CEMENT POST 18 INCHES LONG BY 6 INCHES SQUARE WITH A NAIL IN THE CEMENT MARKING THE CENTER.                            STATION RECOVERY (1902)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1902 (RLF) STATION MARKS RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.  CEMENT BLOCK MARKED U.S. ON TOP.                            STATION RECOVERY (1961)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1961 (MLO) SEARCH OF THE AREA WAS MADE BUT THE STATION MARK COULD NOT BE FOUND.
markers.setting: SET IN TOP OF CONCRETE MONUMENT
markers.stability: MAY HOLD, BUT OF TYPE COMMONLY SUBJECT TOSURFACE MOTION

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JJL) THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 1 MILE NORTH OF BARCELONETA.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE SOUTH SIDE OF THE PLAZA IN BARCELONETA, GO WEST FOR 0.2 MILE TO A CROSSROAD.  TURN RIGHT AND GO NORTH FOR 0.2 MILE TO A Y-FORK.  TAKE THE RIGHT FORK AND GO NORTHERLY FOR ABOUT 1/2 MILE TO THE STATION.  THE STACK IS A CYLINDRICAL, CONCRETE STRUCTURE, WHITE IN COLOR AND IT IS ABOUT 200 FEET HIGH.  THIS IS THE TALLEST STACK OF TWO STACKS.  POINT INTERSECTED IS THE TOP AND CENTER OF THE STACK.

BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1965 (JJL) THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 5 MILES SOUTHWEST OF PALMAS, 3 MILES SOUTH OF GUAYAMA, 1/2 MILE SOUTH OF THE CENTRAL MACHETE SUGAR CANE MILL, ON A LOW BLUFF THAT OVERLOOKS THE OCEAN AND IS SITUATED BETWEEN TWO GULLIES.  THE PROPERTY IS OWNED BY THE GOVERNMENT OF PUERTO RICO.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE SOUTHEAST CORNER OF THE GUAYAMA PLAZA, GO SOUTH AND EAST ON HIGHWAY 3 FOR 0.55 MILE TO A T ROAD AT THE JUNCTION WITH HIGHWAY 744.  TURN RIGHT AND GO SOUTH ON HIGHWAY 744 FOR 1.6 MILES TO A Y FORK.  TAKE THE LEFT FORK AND GO SOUTH AND WEST FOR 0.15 MILE TO A RAILROAD CROSSING AND A T INTERSECTION.  TURN LEFT AND GO EAST FOR 0.1 MILE TO A T ROAD AND A SHED ON THE LEFT.  TURN RIGHT AND GO SOUTH AND EAST FOR 0.1 MILE TO A SIDE ROAD ON THE RIGHT.  TURN RIGHT AND GO SOUTH ON A DIRT ROAD FOR 0.35 MILE TO THE END OF THE ROAD.  PACK EASTERLY ON A TRAIL ALONG THE NORTH SIDE OF HOUSES FOR 5 MINUTES TO THE STATION JUST EAST OF A CANE FIELD.  THE STATION MARK IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED BARR 1965, BRAZED TO THE TOP OF A 3-INCH CAST IRON PIPE THAT PROJECTS 2 INCHES.  IT IS 39 FEET NORTH OF THE SOUTH EDGE OF A 30 FOOT BANK AND 31 FEET EAST OF A TRAIL.  REFERENCE MARK 1 IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED BARR NO 1 1965, BRAZED TO THE TOP OF A 3-INCH CAST IRON PIPE THAT PROJECTS 2 INCHES.  IT IS 53 FEET EAST OF THE TRAIL, 15 FEET NORTH OF THE SOUTH EDGE OF THE 30 FOOT BANK AND 1 FOOT HIGHER IN ELEVATION THAN THE STATION MARK.  REFERENCE MARK 2 IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED BARR NO 2 1965, BRAZED TO THE TOP OF A 3-INCH CAST IRON PIPE THAT PROJECTS 2 INCHES.  IT IS 9 FEET EAST OF THE TRAIL, 3 FEET NORTH OF THE NORTH EDGE OF A GULLY AND THE SAME ELEVATION AS THE STATION MARK.  NO SUITABLE PLACE WAS FOUND FOR AN AZIMUTH MARK.                            STATION RECOVERY (1969)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1969 (JKW) THE STATION MARK AND BOTH REFERENCE MARKS WERE RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.  THE ORIGINAL DESCRIPTION IS ADEQUATE, BUT THE GULLY TO THE WEST OF THE STATION HAS ERODED AND THE STATION MARK IS NOW ONLY 12 FEET TO THE EAST OF THE WEST EDGE OF THIS GULLY.  THE STAMPINGS WERE VERIFIED.  A NEW TO REACH FOLLOWS--TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE SOUTHEAST CORNER OF THE PLAYA IN GUAYAMA, GO SOUTH AND EAST ON HIGHWAY 3 FOR 0.55 MILE TO A T ROAD AT THE JUNCTION WITH HIGHWAY 744.  TURN RIGHT AND GO SOUTH ON HWY 744 FOR 1.6 MILES TO A Y FORK JUST INSIDE THE ENTRANCE TO THE CENTRAL MACHETE SUGAR CANE MILL.  TAKE THE LEFT FORK AND GO SOUTH AND WEST FOR 0.15 MILE TO A RAILROAD CROSSING.  TURN LEFT ACROSS RAILROAD TRACKS, THEN TURN RIGHT AND TAKE ROAD TO WEST OF A METAL GATE THAT PASSES BETWEEN TWO METAL SHEDS (THESE SHEDS ARE THE MOST WESTERLY IN THE REFINERY SOUTH OF THE RAILROAD TRACKS), CONTINUE ON THIS ROAD TO A Y FORK AND A SHED ON THE RIGHT, TAKE THE RIGHT FORK AND GO 0.18 MILE TO A 3 WAY FORK, TAKE THE LEFT FORK AND FOLLOW A ROUGH TRAIL ALONG THE TOP OF A LOW BLUFF FOR 0.12 MILES TO THE STATION ON THE RIGHT.                            STATION RECOVERY (1971)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1971 (EKM) THE STATION MARK AND REFERENCE MARKS WERE RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED BY JJL IN 1965 AND JKW IN 1970.  ALTER TO-REACH AS FOLLOWS--  ---FOR 0.15 MILE TO A RAILROAD CROSSING.  TURN LEFT ACROSS RAILROAD TRACKS, THEN RIGHT AND PROCEED SOUTH AROUND THE WESTWARD OF THE TWO METAL SHEDS.  CONTINUE SOUTH ON THIS ROAD------                            STATION RECOVERY (1975)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1975 (RMB) STATION BARR 1965 AND REFERENCE MARK 1 WERE RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.  REFERENCE MARK 2 HAS APPARENTLY BEEN DESTROYED DUE TO GULLY EROSION.  A NEW TO REACH FOLLOWS--  TO REACH THE STATION START AT THE U.S. POST OFFICE ON THE SQUARE DOWNTOWN GUAYAMA, GO EAST ON DERKES ST. 1-1/2 BLOCKS TO STOP SIGN, TURN RIGHT (SOUTH) ONTO ASHFORD ST., GO 0.5 MILE TO HY 744, TURN RIGHT ON HY 744, GO 1.6 MILES TO CROSSROAD, CONTINUE STRAIGHT AHEAD 0.15 MILES PAST CROSSROAD AROUND CURVE TO RIGHT, TO RAILROAD TRACK AND T-ROAD, CROSS TRACKS AND TURN LEFT, GO 0.1 MILE TAKE RIGHT FORK, GO 0.1 MILE TURN RIGHT AGAIN, GO 0.35 MILE TO FORK IN ROAD, TAKE LEFT FORK, ROAD THEN CURVES LEFT IN FRONT OF SEVERAL SMALL HOUSES, FOLLOW ROAD ALONG NORTH SIDE OF HOUSES FOR 0.1 MILE, OR ALMOST 200 FEET PAST LAST HOUSE, AND JUST PAST FIRST GULLY ON RIGHT.  STATION IS 40 FEET TO THE SOUTH OF THE ROAD AND DIRECTLY TOWARD OCEAN, 10 FEET EAST OF THE EAST EDGE OF PREVIOUSLY MENTIONED GULLY.  THERE IS A CANE FIELD ON NORTH SIDE OF ROAD.  THE STATION IS ABOUT 35 FEET BACK FROM THE EDGE OF A DIRT BLUFF, 30 FEET HIGH ALONG THE SHORELINE.
markers.setting: SET INTO TOP OF METAL PIPE DRIVEN INTO GROUND
markers.stability: MARK OF QUESTIONABLE OR UNKNOWN STABILITY

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1926 (GCM) STATION IS ON THE EDGE OF A BANK APPROXIMATELY 20 FEET ABOVE THE WATER LINE.  THE STATION SITE IS 0.7 MILE W OF POINT BARRANCAS AND IS ON THE TOP OF THE EASTERN BANK OF A SMALL GULLY.  THERE IS A SMALL LAGOON AND GROWTH OF UNDERBRUSH IN THE GULLY.  MEADOWLAND SURROUNDS THE SITE.  STATION MARKED BY A 2-INCH PIPE, 3 FEET LONG, SET IN CONCRETE ABOUT 28 METERS BACK FROM THE HIGH-WATER LINE.  REFERENCE MARKS ARE STANDARD BRONZE DISKS SET IN IRREGULAR MASSES OF CONCRETE.  HEIGHT OF SIGNAL ABOVE STATION MARK - 5 METERS.                            STATION RECOVERY (1963)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1963 (CFO) NO EVIDENCE OF THE STATION MARK OR THE REFERENCE MARKS WERE FOUND.  THE AREA IS COVERED WITH TALL GRASS AND VINES AND WAS HARD TO MAKE A THOROUGH SEARCH.
markers.setting: OBJECT SURROUNDED BY MASS OF CONCRETE
markers.stability: MARK OF QUESTIONABLE OR UNKNOWN STABILITY

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1900 (JBB) STATION IS SOME 30 FEET S OF THE S HOUSE OF THE VILLAGE, AND SOME 70 FEET W OF HIGH WATER MARK ON NE SIDE OF POINT.  SIGNAL IS ERECTED ON POINT OF LAND AT SE END OF PLAYA DE FAJARDO.  (PUNTA DE BARRANCAS).  SMALL PILE OF CONCH SHELLS WERE SET ABOUT THE MARK, A CEMENT BLOCK WITH NAIL IN CENTER.                            STATION RECOVERY (1904)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1904 (RLF) STATION RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.  DESCRIPTION ADEQUATE, A FOOT PATH RUNS ACROSS TOP OF STATION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1922)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1922 (FTS) STATION NOT RECOVERED.
markers.setting: SET IN TOP OF CONCRETE MONUMENT
markers.stability: MAY HOLD, BUT OF TYPE COMMONLY SUBJECT TOSURFACE MOTION

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1926 (GCM) STATION AND REFERENCE MARKS IN GOOD CONDITION.  STATION MARKS EXPOSED TO EROSION BY STORMS AND DAMAGE THROUGH FISHERMEN HAULING OUT BOATS.                            STATION RECOVERY (1961)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1961 (MLO) NO ORIGINAL DESCRIPTION WAS AVAILABLE, BUT IT APPEARS THAT STATION AND REFERENCE MARKS HAVE BEEN DESTROYED.
markers.setting: UNSPECIFIED SETTING

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1965 (JJL) THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 11 MILES NORTHEAST OF YABUCOA, 5 MILES SOUTHEAST OF HUMACAO, ON THE TOP OF A LOW HILL WHICH IS THE HIGHEST POINT IN THE GENERAL VICINITY AND ON THE PROPERTY OF MR. ENRIQUE SANCHES WHO LIVES IN HUMACAO.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE JUNCTION OF HIGHWAYS 3 AND 909 IN THE SOUTH PART OF HUMACAO, GO SOUTH ON HIGHWAY 3 FOR 1.1 MILES TO A SIDE ROAD LEFT.  (THIS IS 0.1 MILE AFTER PASSING KILOMETER POST 87.4.) TURN LEFT AND GO EAST ON A DIRT ROAD FOR 1.05 MILES TO A Y FORK.  TAKE THE LEFT FORK AND GO NORTHEASTERLY ON A DIRT ROAD FOR 0.35 MILE TO A T ROAD.  TURN RIGHT AND GO SOUTHEAST ON A DIRT ROAD FOR 0.65 MILE TO A RAILROAD CROSSING.  CONTINUE SOUTHEAST ON THE DIRT ROAD FOR 0.9 MILE TO A POINT WHERE THE ROAD TURNS TO THE RIGHT AND THE AZIMUTH MARK ON THE LEFT, EAST SIDE OF THE ROAD.  BEAR RIGHT AND GO SOUTH ON THE DIRT ROAD FOR 0.35 MILE TO A FORK.  TAKE THE LEFT FORK AND GO EAST ON A TRACK ROAD FOR 0.25 MILE TO AN IRON GATE.  (THE KEY TO THE GATE WAS OBTAINED FROM MR. ENRIQUE SANCHES IN HUMACAO.) PASS THROUGH THE GATE AND CONTINUE EAST ON A DIM TRACK ROAD FOR 0.05 MILE TO THE TOP OF THE HILL AND THE STATION.  THE STATION MARK IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED BAT 1965, SET IN THE TOP OF A 12 INCH SQUARE CONCRETE POST THAT PROJECTS 4 INCHES.  IT IS 71 FEET SOUTHWEST OF THE SOUTHWEST CORNER POST OF A BEACH HOUSE.  REFERENCE MARK 1 IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED BAT NO 1 1965, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN OUTCROPPING BEDROCK THAT PROJECTS 1 FOOT.  IT IS 30 FEET SOUTH OF THE SOUTHWEST CORNER POST OF THE BEACH HOUSE.  REFERENCE MARK 2 IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED BAT NO 2 1965, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN OUTCROPPING BEDROCK THAT PROJECTS 1 INCH.  IT IS 64 FEET WEST OF THE SOUTHWEST CORNER POST OF THE BEACH HOUSE.  THE AZIMUTH MARK IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED BAT 1965, SET IN THE TOP OF A 12 INCH SQUARE CONCRETE MONUMENT THAT IS FLUSH WITH THE SURFACE OF THE GROUND.  IT IS 20 FEET EAST OF THE CENTER OF A DIRT ROAD, 9 FEET NORTH OF THE CENTER OF A WIRE GATE AND 1 FOOT WEST OF A WIRE FENCE.                            STATION RECOVERY (1969)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1969 (JKW) THE STATION MARK AND REFERENCE MARK NO. 1 WERE RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 2 HAS BEEN DESTROYED.  THE ORIGINAL DESCRIPTION IS ADEQUATE EXCEPT THAT THE PROPERTY IS NOW OWNED BY PUNTA AURORA CORPORATION, 1620 PONCE DE LEON AVE., SANTURCE, PUERTO RICO.  THE STAMPINGS AND DISTANCES WERE VERIFIED.                            STATION RECOVERY (1970)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1970 (JKW) STATION MARK AND REFERENCE MARK 1 BOTH RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.  REFERENCE MARK 2 IS DESTROYED, AS IN PREVIOUS RECOVERY NOTE.  THE ORIGINAL DESCRIPTION BY J.J.L. IN 1965 AND THE RECOVERY NOTE BY J.K.W. IN 1969 ARE ADEQUATE.
markers.setting: SET IN TOP OF CONCRETE MONUMENT
markers.stability: MAY HOLD, BUT OF TYPE COMMONLY SUBJECT TOSURFACE MOTION

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1901 (JBB) ON THE NE END OF BATATA CAY, 4 MILES S OF THE PLAYA DE HUMACAO.  STATION IS ON HIGHEST PART OF CAY, ABOUT 6 METERS FROM THE TOP OF THE BLUFF TO THE EASTWARD AND 7 METERS FROM THE BLUFF ON THE WESTERN SIDE.  STATION IS MARKED BY A NAIL IN THE CENTER OF A CEMENT POST 6 INCHES SQUARE BY 18 INCHES LONG.  POST MARKED U.S.                            STATION RECOVERY (1923)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1923 (FTS) ORIGINAL DESCRIPTION SUFFICIENTLY ACCURATE.  CAY COVERED WITH THICK GROWTH OF UNDERBRUSH.  POLE SIGNAL ERECTED AND CLIFF AT SE POINT WHITEWASHED.                            STATION RECOVERY (1926)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1926 (GCM) RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED.  STATION MARK IN GOOD CONDITION.  THICK GROWTH OF UNDERBRUSH, USED AS NESTING PLACE BY PELICANS.                            STATION RECOVERY (1940)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1940 RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED IN ORIGINAL AND AS NOTED IN RECOVERIES OF 1923 AND 1926.  THERE IS NOW A DAY BEACON CONSISTING OF A 4 BY 4 INCH SAWED TIMBER POLE, SECURELY BRACED, AND WITH SEVERAL HORIZONTAL SLATS AT RIGHT ANGLES TO ONE ANOTHER ERECTED DIRECTLY OVER THE MARK.  AND THIS WAS USED AS THE SIGNAL.  BOTTOM OF LOWEST SLAT IS 9.9 FT. ABOVE STATION.  SKETCH IN ORIGINAL DESCRIPTION IS NOT GOOD AT PRESENT.  THE HIGH ROCK FORMING THE ISLAND CAN BE CLIMBED ON THE NE OR THE WEST SIDES.  BEST LANDING FOR SMALL BOAT ON WEST SIDE.  BUT LANDING IS DANGEROUS IN HEAVY SEA.  SMALL, SHALLOW, DRAFT SAILBOAT CAN BE HIRED AT HUMACAO PLAYA.  BUT IN DRY WEATHER IT IS REACHED MORE QUICKLY FROM HUMACAO AS FOLLOWS--  FROM HUMACAO (PLAZA) GO ON ROAD TOWARDS HUMACAO PLAYA 1.6 MILE.  TURN RIGHT ON DIRT ROAD AT CURVE AND ESPERANZA BAR.  GO 0.1 MILE AND BEAR RIGHT.  GO NEARLY 0.1 MILE AND KEEP STRAIGHT AHEAD (RIGHT).  GO 0.8 MILE, CROSS ONE TRACK AND TAKE LEFT FORK ACROSS R.R..  GO 1.0 MILE AND TURN LEFT THROUGH GATE.  FOLLOW TRAIL NEARLY TO BEACH, AND LEAVE CAR.  THIS IS JUST A FEW HUNDRED FEET FROM WHERE BOAT CAN BE OBTAINED.                            STATION RECOVERY (1961)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1961 (MLC) STATION WAS RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED.  MARK IS IN GOOD CONDITION.  DAYBEACON OVER MARK HAS ROTTED AND FALLEN DOWN.                            STATION RECOVERY (1965)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1965 (JJL) THE STATION WAS RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED AND FOUND IN GOOD CONDITION.  THE STATION WAS VISITED BY A BUILDING PARTY ONLY AND A SIGNAL WAS ERECTED FOR INTERSECTION PURPOSES.  DUE TO THE INACCESSIBILITY OF THIS STATION A NEW STATION WAS ESTABLISHED. SEE THE DESCRIPTION FOR STATION BAT.  A COMPLETE DESCRIPTION FOLLOWS--  THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 4 MILES SOUTH OF PLAYA DE HUMACAO AND ON THE NORTHEAST END AND HIGHEST POINT OF A SMALL, BRUSH-COVERED ISLAND KNOWN AS BATATA CAY.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE JUNCTION OF HIGHWAYS 3 AND 909 ON THE SOUTH SIDE OF HUMACAO, GO SOUTHERLY ON HIGHWAY 3 FOR 1.0 MILE TO A SIDE ROAD LEFT.  THIS IS 0.1 MILE AFTER PASSING KILOMETER POST 87.4.  TURN LEFT AND GO EAST AND NORTH FOR 0.2 MILE TO A Y-FORK.  TAKE THE RIGHT FORK AND GO EAST FOR 0.7 MILE TO A Y-FORK.  TAKE THE LEFT FORK AND GO NORTH FOR 0.4 MILE TO A T-INTERSECTION.  TURN RIGHT AND GO EASTERLY FOR 0.7 MILE TO A RAILROAD CROSSING AND A SET OF BUILDINGS.  CROSS THE RAILROAD TRACKS AND GO EAST, SOUTH AND EAST FOR 1.4 MILES TO THE END OF TRUCK TRAVEL AT THE END OF THE ROAD.  PACK EASTERLY ALONG A TRAIL FOR ABOUT 150 YARDS TO THE SHORE.  A BOAT MAY BE HIRED AT THIS POINT.  THE ISLAND IS ABOUT 3/4 MILE EAST EAST OF THIS POINT.  LAND ON THE NORTH SIDE OF THE ISLAND, THENCE PACK SOUTH AND WEST FOR ABOUT 100 YARDS TO THE STATION.  THE STATION MARK IS A NAIL SET IN THE TOP OF A 6-INCH SQUARE CONCRETE MONUMENT THAT PROJECTS 3 INCHES.  THE LETTERS U.S. ARE INSCRIBED ON THE TOP OF THE CONCRETE MONUMENT.  REFERENCE MARKS WERE NOT ESTABLISHED AT THIS STATION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1970)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1970 (JKW) STATION RECOVERED IN APPARENT GOOD CONDITION.  THE SIGNAL ERECTED IN 1965 STILL REMAINS INTACT.  THE RECOVERY NOTE BY J.J.L. IN 1965 IS ADEQUATE.
markers.setting: SET IN TOP OF CONCRETE MONUMENT
markers.stability: MAY HOLD, BUT OF TYPE COMMONLY SUBJECT TOSURFACE MOTION

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1900 (WCH) THIS STATION IS ON THE SUMMIT OF A SMALL LEDGE OF ROCK NEAR THE NORTHERN SIDE OF A SMALL ISLET OF THAT NAME IN MANGROVE HARBOR, CULEBRA ISLAND.  A PIER WAS BUILT HERE FOR THE ZENITH TELESCOPE AND OBSERVATIONS FOR LATITUDE WERE MADE BY F.M.L.  THE EXACT CENTER WAS MARKED BY A CUT IN THE CEMENT SURFACE OF THE PIER.                            STATION RECOVERY (1922)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1922 (FTS) STATION EASILY LOCATED ON THE ISLAND WHICH IS SMALL IN EXTENT.  STATION IN EXCELLENT CONDITION, THE BEST FOR AN EXPOSED MARK ON CULEBRA ISLAND.                            STATION RECOVERY (1926)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1926 (GCM) RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED, AND IN GOOD CONDITION.

BY LOCAL ENGINEER (INDIVIDUAL OR FIRM) 1966 (JJL) STATION ESTABLISHED BY PRS.  THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 5 MILES SOUTHWEST OF CATANO, 2-1/2 MILES NORTHWEST OF BAYAMON AND ON THE HIGHEST ONE OF A GROUP OF TIMBERED, LIMESTONE HILLS WITH OVERHANGING CLIFFS ON THE WEST SIDE.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE JUNCTION OF HIGHWAY 2 AND HIGHWAY 167 IN BAYAMON, GO WEST ON HIGHWAY 2 FOR 2.0 MILES TO A SIDE ROAD ON THE RIGHT AT A TRAFFIC LIGHT.  TURN RIGHT AND GO NORTH ON THE PAVED ROAD FOR 0.6 MILE TO A T-INTERSECTION.  TURN LEFT AND GO WEST ON THE DIRT ROAD FOR 0.15 MILE TO A WOODEN GATE AND A HOUSE ON THE LEFT.  (PERMISSION TO ENTER THE LAND MAY BE OBTAINED HERE.) TURN LEFT, PASS THROUGH THE GATE AND GO SOUTH ACROSS THE LOT TO THE SOUTHWEST CORNER AND THE END OF TRUCK TRAVEL.  FROM THE SOUTHWEST CORNER OF THE LOT, PACK SOUTH FOR ABOUT 30 FEET, TURN RIGHT AND GO WEST BETWEEN TWO FENCE ROWS FOR ABOUT 100 YARDS TO A WOODEN GATE ON THE LEFT.  TURN LEFT, PASS THROUGH THE GATE AND PACK SOUTH UP THE CANYON THROUGH TALL WEEDS AND BRUSH FOR ABOUT 10 MINUTES TO A POINT OPPOSITE A SADDLE ON THE RIGHT, WEST, JUST NORTH OF THE LAST HILL ON THE RIGHT.  HERE BEAR TO THE RIGHT AND PACK WEST UP THE STEEP HILL, THROUGH SMALL TREES AND BRUSH FOR ABOUT 10 MINUTES TO THE SADDLE MENTIONED PREVIOUSLY.  BEAR RIGHT AND PACK NORTHERLY ALONG THE RIDGE TO THE HIGHEST POINT OF THE HILL AND THE STATION. NOTE--A 30 MINUTE PACK.  THE STATION MARK, ESTABLISHED BY THE PUERTO RICO DEPARTMENT OF PUBLIC WORKS, IS AN IRON ROD WITH A CHISELED CROSS CEMENTED IN A LIMESTONE OUTCROP THAT PROJECTS 6 INCHES WITH BAYAMON 1963 INSCRIBED IN THE CEMENT.  REFERENCE MARK 1 IS A STANDARD DISK, STAMPED BAYAMON PRS NO 1 1963, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A BOULDER THAT PROJECTS 6 INCHES AND IT IS ABOUT 4 FEET BELOW THE LEVEL OF THE STATION.  REFERENCE MARK 2 IS A STANDARD DISK, STAMPED BAYAMON PRS NO 2 1963, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A BOULDER THAT PROJECTS 2 INCHES AND IT IS ABOUT 5 FEET BELOW THE LEVEL OF THE STATION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1993)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL OCEAN SERVICE 1993 RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.
markers.setting: SET IN ROCK OUTCROP
markers.stability: MOST RELIABLE AND EXPECTED TO HOLDPOSITION/ELEVATION WELL

markers.description: BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1934 STATION IS 5 KILOMETERS, NW OF THE TOWN OF BAYAMON, 0.75 KILOMETER N OF CARRETERA NO.2, ON THE HIGHEST ONE OF THE GROUP OF CORAL LIMESTONE PEAKS N OF HOSPITAL SAN ALBERTO.  FROM THE CARRETERA IT APPEARS AS THE THIRD PEAK FROM THE E END, COUNTING THE FIRST LOW ONE.  THE PEAK HAS A HIGH OVERHANGING CLIFF ON ITS WESTERN SIDE AND THE STATION IS ON THE HIGHEST PART, ABOUT 3 FEET FROM THE EDGE OF CLIFF.  STATION MARK IS A STANDARD U.S.G.S. TABLET, STAMPED BAYAMON 1934 CEMENTED IN THE SOLID LIMESTONE TOP OF PEAK.  REFERENCE MARKS ARE ONE-INCH DRILL HOLES IN SOLID LIMESTONE ROCK.  REFERENCE MARK NO.1 IS 28.63 FEET FROM STATION MARK IN TRUE AZIMUTH 240 DEG 03 MIN.  REFERENCE MARK NO.2 IS 33.28 FEET FROM STATION MARK IN TRUE AZIMUTH 325 DEG 06 MIN.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM BAYAMON, FOLLOW CARRETERA NO.2 TO KILOMETER POST K15 H1, ABOUT 100 METERS E OF HOSPITAL SAN ALBERTO, TURN N ON MUNICIPAL ROAD AND GO TO PLANTATION OF MR. E.E. GREELY, ABOUT 1 KILOMETER FROM THE CARRETERA.  FOLLOW HIS PRIVATE ROAD PAST HOUSE, THROUGH CITRUS GROVE, AND ON INTO DRAW BETWEEN HILLS, FROM A POINT NEAR UPPER END OF THIS CLIMB TO THE RIGHT (WESTWARD) TO TOP OF RIDGE, THEN KEEP SOUTHWARD ALONG EDGE OF CLIFF TO HIGHEST POINT.                            STATION RECOVERY (1941)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1941 (GBG) STATION AND REFERENCE MARKS RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.  NEW DESCRIPTION FOLLOWS--  LOCATED ABOUT 4 KILOMETERS NW OF BAYAMON.  AND 3/4 KILOMETER N OF ROAD 2.  ON THE HIGHEST OF A GROUP OF CORAL LIMESTONE PEAKS N OF HOSPITAL SAN ALBERTO.  FROM THE CARRETERA IT APPEARS AS THE THIRD PEAK FROM THE E END, COUNTING THE FIRST LOW ONE.  THE PEAK HAS A HIGH, OVERHANGING CLIFF ON ITS WESTERN SIDE.  THE STATION IS A BRONZE DISK STAMPED BAYAMON 1934 CEMENTED TO THE LIMESTONE ON THE HIGHEST LEDGE, AND ABOUT 3 FEET FROM THE EDGE OF THE CLIFF.  REFERENCE MARK 1 IS A ONE-INCH DRILL HOLE IN SOLID LIMESTONE, 28.63 FEET FROM STATION IS AZIMUTH 240 DEG 03 MIN.  REFERENCE MARK 2 IS SIMILAR TO 1.  AND IS 33.28 FEET FROM STATION.  IN AZIMUTH 325 DEG 06 MIN.  TO REACH FROM BAYAMON (Y-FORK IN W END OF TOWN), GO W ON ARECIBO ROAD (2) 2.0 MILES TO A T-ROAD RIGHT, JUST E OF HOSPITAL SAN ALBERTO.  GO N ON THIS ROAD 0.6 MILE TO A DRIVEWAY AND A HOUSE, LEFT.  FROM THE HOUSE, THE STATION IS ON THE PEAK THAT BEARS S 70 DEG W (MAG.).  WALK FROM HERE THROUGH GRAPEFRUIT GROVE TOWARDS THE STATION, PASSING THROUGH GAP TO S TO A SMALL, OVERGROWN PASTURE.  ABOUT THE MIDDLE OF THE W SIDE OF THIS IS A TRAIL THAT GOES STRAIGHT UP TO RIDGE.  AT RIDGE TURN LEFT (S) AND CONTINUE CLIMBING ALONG SHARP RIDGE TO STATION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1965)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1965 (JJL) THE STATION MARK WAS DESTROYED AND THE PUERTO RICO DEPARTMENT OF PUBLIC WORKS ESTABLISHED A NEW STATION MARK.  THE ORIGINAL REFERENCE MARKS 1 AND 2 WERE RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED IN THE 1934 DESCRIPTION AND STANDARD DISKS FOR REFERENCE MARKS 1 AND 2 WERE ESTABLISHED IN THE 1-INCH DRILL HOLES DESCRIBED AS REFERENCE MARKS.  SEE BAYAMON (PRS) 1963 FOR THE NEW DESCRIPTION.
markers.setting: SET IN ROCK OUTCROP
markers.stability: MOST RELIABLE AND EXPECTED TO HOLDPOSITION/ELEVATION WELL

markers.description: BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1934 NO CHECK ON POSITION.  STATION IS THE ORNAMENT ON DOME OF CATHOLIC CHURCH IN TOWN OF BAYAMON. STATION RECOVERY (1964)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1964 (GWM) THE ORIGINAL DESCRIPTION IS ADEQUATE.

markers.description: BY RLDA SURVEYING AND MAPPING 2010 (RLD) THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 11.3 MI (18.2 KM) SOUTHEAST OF LARES, 8.5 MI (13.7 KM) NORTH OF SANTO DOMINGO, 6.3 MI (10.1 KM) SOUTHWEST OF UTUADO AND 2.4 MI (3.9 KM) NORTHWEST OF ADJUNTAS.   TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE INTERSECTION OF PR-123 AND PR-135 1.5 MI (2.4 KM) NORTHWEST OF ADJUNTAS, GO WEST ON PR-135 FOR ABOUT 1.3 MI (2.1 KM) TO THE STATION ON THE LEFT.   THE STATION IS 12.85 M (42.2 FT) EAST OF THE NORTHEAST CORNER OF A HOUSE, 10.63 M (34.9 FT) SOUTHWEST OF A POWER POLE AND 9.51 M (31.2 FT) NORTHWEST OF A FENCE CORNER.

markers.description: BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1982 3.0 KM (1.86 MI) NE FROM PONCE. FROM THE JUNCTION OF HIGHWAYS 14 AND 139 ABOUT 4.0 KM (2.5 MI) NORTHEAST OF PONCE, GO NORTHERLY ON HIGHWAY 139 FOR 0.4 KM (0.3 MI) TO A CROSSROAD, TURN RIGHT AND GO EAST AND NORTH ON HIGHWAY 139 FOR 2.7 KM (1.7 MI) TO A FORK, TAKE THE RIGHT FORK AND CONTINUE NORTHERLY ON HIGHWAY 139 FOR 2.6 KM (1.6 MI) TO A DIRT FORK RIGHT, TURN RIGHT AND GO EASTERLY DOWNHILL FOR 0.2 KM (0.1 MI) TO A CREEK, AND THE STATION ON THE OTHER SIDE OF THE CREEK, 6.15 METERS (20.2 FT) NORTH FROM A TWO FOOT DIAMETER TREE, 10.1 METERS (33.0 FT) FROM THE EAST BANK OF THE CREEK AND 9.40 METERS (30.8 FT) SOUTH OF A TWO FOOT DIAMETER TREE. THE MARK IS 10.0 FT ABOVE CREEK.

markers.description: BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1982 (JCL) THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 8 KM (5 MI) NORTH-NORTHEAST OF PONCE, 0.75 KM (1/2 MI) WEST OF THE WEST END OF THE  PROPOSED PONCE, 0.75 KM (1/2 MI) WEST OF THEWEST END OF THE PROPOSED CERRILLOS PROPOSED CERRILLOS DAM, ALONG THE -HUD- ROAD, AND ON  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE JUNCTION OF HIGHWAYS 14 AND 139 ABOUT 4 KM (2-1/2 MI) NORTHEAST OF PONCE, GO NORTHWEST ON ON HIGHWAY 139 FOR 0.5 KM (0.3 MI) TO A CROSS STREET AND JUNCTION WITH HIGHWAY 505.  TURN RIGHT AND GO NORTHEAST ON HIGHWAY 139 FOR 3.1 KM (1.95 MI)  TO A FORK.  BEAR LEFT UP GRADE ON PAVED ROAD FOR 0.9 KM (0.55 MI) TO A DIRT ROAD RIGHT. TURN RIGHT AND GO NORTH FOR 3.2 KM (2.05 MI) TO THE TOP OF THE GRADE (JUST PAST BULLDOZED ROAD ON THE RIGHT LEADING DOWN HILL), A 15-FOOT HIGH BANK ON THE LEFT AND THE STATION ATOP THE BANK.  THE STATION IS A STANDARD NGS DISK STAMPED---BEARD 1982---, EPOXIED TO THE TOP OF A 1/2 INCH STEEL ROD DRIVEN 0.7 METER TO ROCK AND ENCASED IN A CONCRETE FILLED PLASTIC TILE. IT IS LOCATED 8.8 METERS (29.0 FT) WEST FROM THE CUT BANK EDGE AND 4.9 METERS (16.0 FT) NORTH FROM THE CENTER OF A MULTI-TRUNKED TREE.  REFERENCE MARK NUMBER 1 IS A STANDARD NGS DISK STAMPED---BEARD NO 1 1982---, EPOXIED TO THE TOP OF A 1/2 INCH STEEL ROD DRIVEN 0.7 METER TO ROCK AND INSIDE A CONCRETE FILLED PLASTIC TILE. IT IS LOCATED 6.1 METERS (20.0 FT) NORTH FROM THE CUT BANK EDGE AND 3.3 METERS (11.0 FT) WEST FROM THE CENTER OF A MULTI-TRUNKED TREE. MARK IS BELOW STATION 0.3 METER.  REFERENCE MARK NUMBER 2 IS AN INDENT IN THE TOP OF A 1/2 INCH REBAR SET FLUSH IN THE CENTER OF A 1 METER DEEP CONCRETE POST IN THE ROAD. IT IS LOCATED 1.8 METERS (6.0 FT) WEST FROM A 12-INCH TREE AND 1.2 METERS (4.0 FT) EAST FROM THE CENTER OF THE DIRT ROAD. MARK IS BELOW STATION 6 METERS.  NO MEASUREMENT BETWEEN REFERENCE MARKS BECAUSE OF EXTREME SLOPE OF HILL SIDE. HEIGHT OF LIGHT SHOWN ABOVE THE MARK WAS 1.7 METERS. NO AZIMUTH MARK WAS SET FOR THIS STATION.

markers.description: BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1966 (JJL) THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 8 MILES SOUTHWEST OF CAGUAS, 7 MILES SOUTH OF AGUAS BUENAS, 7 MILES NORTHEAST OF CAYEY AND ON THE HIGHEST ONE OF TWO GRASSY HILLS THAT ARE ABOUT 200 FEET APART.  THE PROPERTY IS OWNED BY MR. DIAZ GONZALES OF SAN JUAN.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE POST OFFICE IN CAGUAS, GO SOUTH ON HIGHWAY 1 FOR 7.7 MILES TO THE JUNCTION WITH HIGHWAY 172.  TURN RIGHT AND GO WESTERLY ON HIGHWAY 172 FOR 0.85 MILE TO A SIDE ROAD ON THE LEFT AT KILOMETER POST 18.7.  TURN LEFT AND GO SOUTHERLY ON A DIRT ROAD FOR 0.2 MILE TO A FORK.  TAKE THE LEFT FORK AND CONTINUE SOUTHERLY ON A DIRT ROAD FOR 0.15 MILE TO THE TOP OF THE HILL AND A LOCKED GATE ON THE RIGHT.  THIS IS THE END OF TRUCK TRAVEL AT THIS TIME DUE TO WET WEATHER.  (A 4-WHEEL DRIVE VEHICLE CAN BE DRIVEN TO THE STATION IN DRY WEATHER BY PASSING THROUGH THE GATE AND FOLLOWING A TRACK ROAD TO THE TOP OF THE HILL.) FROM THE LOCKED GATE PACK WESTERLY FOR 5 MINUTES TO THE HIGHEST POINT OF THE HILL AND THE STATION.  THE STATION MARK IS A 1/2-INCH METAL BOLT, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A LARGE BOULDER THAT PROJECTS 3 FEET.  IT IS 20 FEET SOUTH OF THE HIGHEST POINT OF THE HILL.  REFERENCE MARK 1 IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED BEATRIZ USGS NO 1 1965, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A LARGE BOULDER THAT PROJECTS 4 FEET AND IS 2 FEET HIGHER IN ELEVATION THAN THE STATION MARK.  IT IS ON THE HIGHEST PART OF THE HILL.  REFERENCE MARK 2 IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED BEATRIZ USGS NO 2 1965, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A SMALL BOULDER THAT PROJECTS 1 FOOT AND IS 1 FOOT LOWER IN ELEVATION THAN THE STATION MARK.  IT IS ABOUT 20 FEET SOUTH OF THE HIGHEST PART OF THE HILL.  NO SUITABLE PLACE WAS FOUND FOR AN AZIMUTH MARK.                            STATION RECOVERY (2004)  RECOVERY NOTE BY UNIVERSITY OF PUERTO RICO AT MAYAGUEZ 2004 (UPR) MARK RECOVERED IN POOR CONDITION.
markers.setting: SET IN A BOULDER
markers.stability: MAY HOLD, BUT OF TYPE COMMONLY SUBJECT TOSURFACE MOTION

BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1899 (WCH) THIS STATION IS ON A POINT ON THE NW END OF BERBERIA ISLAND, ABOUT 5 MILES E OF MUERTOS ISLAND LIGHTHOUSE.  THIS STATION IS ABOUT 30 FEET FROM HIGH WATER ON A SAND RIDGE.  STATION IS MARKED BY A 4- BY 6-INCH BOX 2 FEET LONG FILLED WITH CEMENT AND SHELLS.  IT PROJECTS ABOVE THE GROUND ABOUT 4 INCHES.  THE POINT OF A WIRE NAIL EMBEDDED IN THE CEMENT MARKS THE STATION.  A TRIPOD SIGNAL ABOUT 30 FEET HIGH WAS BUILT OVER THIS STATION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1926)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1926 (GCM) LOST.  ISLAND HAS CHANGED, AND RIDGE WASHED AWAY.  POSITION OF STATION NOW AT WATER LINE.

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1926 (GCM) STATION IS ON THE MOST NORTHWESTERLY POINT OF BERBERIA ISLAND.  POINT IS SAND SPIT, 2 FEET IN ELEVATION, BUILT UP BY STORMS.  IT IS 32 METERS BACK OF END OF POINT, 15.3 METERS FROM HIGH-WATER LINE IN THE DIRECTION OF MUERTOS ISLAND LIGHTHOUSE AND 8.7 METERS FROM HIGH-WATER LINE IN THE OPPOSITE DIRECTION.  SOUTH TANGENT OF CARACOLES ISLAND, TO THE EASTWARD IS JUST VISIBLE N OF MANGROVES.  A LINE OF SIGHT TO JAUCA 2 WAS CLEARED THROUGH MANGROVE GROWTH.  BERBERIA ISLAND IS COVERED WITH DENSE MANGROVE GROWTH WITH THE EXCEPTION OF THE POINT ON WHICH THE STATION IS LOCATED.  STATION IS MARKED BY OLD IRON ROD 1-INCH ON EACH SIDE, 4 FEET LONG, DRIVEN IN SAND.  PROJECTING 6 INCHES ABOVE THE SURFACE.  REFERENCE MARK NO.1 IS SET IN A TREE STUMP.  REFERENCE MARK NO.2 IS MARKED BY A STANDARD BRONZE DISK SET IN AN IRREGULAR MASS OF CONCRETE.  HEIGHT OF SIGNAL ABOVE STATION MARK - 5 METERS.                            STATION RECOVERY (1970)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1970 (JKW) STATION MARK AND REFERENCE MARKS WERE SEARCHED FOR BUT NOT FOUND.  PRESUMED LOST.                            STATION RECOVERY (1971)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1971 (EKM) STATION DESTROYED.  RECOVERABLE TOPOGRAPHIC STATION KAY 1970 WAS ESTABLISHED IN NEAR VICINITY OF STATION BERBERIA 2.

TURN TO THE RIGHT AND CONTINUE NORTHEAST ON THE AIRPORT ROAD FOR 0.06 KM (0.04 MI) TO THE MARK ON THE LEFT IN THE GREEN AREA. THE STATION IS ABOUT 38 METERS WEST OF A SMALL HOUSE, 14 METERS NORTH OF THE BANK WHICH OVERLOOKS THE BEACH AND 72 METERS EAST OF THE TOP OF THE BANK ON THE EXTREME WESTERN END OF THE POINT. STATION RECOVERY (1964)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1964 (GWM) STATION RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED.  THE CONCRETE BASE NOW IS ABOUT FOUR (4) INCHES ABOVE GROUND LEVEL.  THERE IS NO EVIDENCE OF A SMALL HOUSE IN AREA.  THE STATION IS IN A GRASSY AREA APPROXIMATELY THREE (3) FEET WEST OF BUSHES. BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JJL) THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 5 MILES EAST OF SANTA ISABEL, 3 MILES WEST OF SALINAS AND 0.1 MILE SOUTH OF HIGHWAY 3.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE SOUTHWEST CORNER OF THE PLAZA IN SALINAS, GO WEST ON HIGHWAY 3 FOR 3.1 MILES TO A METAL GATE ON THE LEFT.  TURN LEFT, PASS THROUGH THE GATE AND GO 30 FEET TO A FORK.  TAKE THE LEFT FORK AND GO SOUTH ON A TRACK ROAD FOR 0.1 MILE TO A WIRE GATE.  PASS THROUGH THE GATE AND GO 60 FEET TO THE STATION AT THE EDGE OF A BANK WHICH IS JUST ABOVE THE BEACH.  THE STATION MARK IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED BOCAMAR 1966, SET IN THE TOP OF A CONCRETE CYLINDER THAT PROJECTS 2 INCHES AND IS 12 INCHES IN DIAMETER.  IT IS 57 FEET SOUTH-SOUTHWEST OF THE CENTER OF A WIRE GATE AND IS 27 FEET EAST OF A WIRE FENCE.  REFERENCE MARK 1 IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED BOCAMAR NO 1 1966, SET IN THE TOP OF A CONCRETE CYLINDER THAT IS FLUSH WITH THE GROUND AND 12 INCHES IN DIAMETER.  IT IS 70 FEET SOUTH OF THE CENTER OF THE WIRE GATE AND 2 FEET EAST OF THE WIRE FENCE.  REFERENCE MARK 2 IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED BOCAMAR NO 2 1966, SET IN THE TOP OF A CONCRETE CYLINDER THAT PROJECTS 6 INCHES AND IS 12 INCHES IN DIAMETER.  IT IS 31 FEET SOUTHWEST OF THE CENTER OF THE WIRE GATE AND 8 FEET EAST OF THE FENCE.  NO AZIMUTH MARK WAS SET.                            STATION RECOVERY (1969)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1969 (JKW) STATION MARK RECOVERED IN FAIR CONDITION.  THE BANK HAS ERODED AND LEFT ABOUT 2 FEET OF THE MONUMENT EXPOSED.  THE MARK IS IN DANGER OF BEING WASHED AWAY.  REFERENCE MARK NO.1 WAS SEARCHED FOR BUT NOT FOUND.  IT IS PRESUMED DESTROYED BY EROSION.  REFERENCE MARK NO.2 WAS RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.  THE STAMPINGS WERE VERIFIED.  A WOODEN O STAND, THE LEGS EMBEDDED IN CONCRETE, STANDS OVER THE STATION.  THE ORIGINAL DESCRIPTION IS ADEQUATE.                            STATION RECOVERY (1970)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1970 (JKW) STATION MARK RECOVERED IN FAIR CONDITION.  REFERENCE MARK 2 WAS RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.  REFERENCE MARK 1 IS LOST, AND BELIEVED TO BE DESTROYED.  THE ORIGINAL DESCRIPTION BY JJL IN 1966 AND THE RECOVERY NOTE BY JKW ARE ADEQUATE.                            STATION RECOVERY (1971)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1971 (EKM) THE STATION MARK AND REFERENCE MARK 2 WERE RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED.  EROSION HAS EXPOSED 2.2 FEET OF CONCRETE CYLINDER CONTAINING THE STATION MARK. markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1900 (JN) THIS STATION IS IN THE HACIENDA OF DR. PABLO HERNANDEZ E OF THE BRIDLE AND FOOT PATH WHICH RUNS INTO THE ROAD, WHICH PASSES ALONG THE E LINE OF HIS COCOANUT GROVE, COMING FROM THE GENERAL DIRECTION OF THE BASE OF THE HILL ON WHICH MARIQUITA STANDS (IN THE BERMEJA SIERRA ON MATZAMBIQUE MOUNT).  ON THE E SIDE OF THE ROAD, OR PATH JUST REFERRED TO, THE LAND IS MORE BRUSHY THAN IT IS IN THE W.  THE WESTERN SECTION IS NOW USED FOR GRAZING.  IT IS SO CLEAR FROM ALL TREES THAT WE WOULD INFER IT HAS BEEN CULTIVATED AT NO VERY REMOTE PERIOD BUT JUST NOW IT IS USED ONLY FOR STOCK.  STATION MARK IS A 2-INCH IRON PIPE, 2 FEET LONG, SUNK IN THE GROUND UNTIL ONLY A COUPLE OF INCHES PROJECT.  IT WAS THEN PACKED AND SURROUNDED WITH CEMENT AND IN THE CENTER AN IRON NAIL WAS SET WHOSE CENTER MARKS THE STATION.  AFTER FILLING UP THE SPACE AROUND THE PIPE, A MASS OF CEMENT WAS NICELY ROUNDED UP ABOUT THE PROTRUDING SECTION OF THE PIPE, COVERING IT TO ITS TOP.  THE PLANE-TABLE SURVEY OF THE BASE LINE WILL SHOW AN ACCURATE REPRESENTATION OF THE BASE AND THE STATION AND ITS SURROUNDINGS.  THE FACT THAT THE POINT IS IN A FLAT VALLEY BOTTOM WITH NOTHING IN ITS IMMEDIATE VICINITY TO ATTRACT ATTENTION, MAKES IT DIFFICULT TO DESCRIBE THE POINT IN WORDS SO AS TO BE CERTAIN IT CAN BE FOUND.  THE MARK WE HAVE PLACED IN THE GROUND, HAS RATHER A PRECARIOUS CONDITION TO LOOK FORWARD TO, BECAUSE OF THE NUMBER OF CATTLE WHICH WILL TRAMP OVER IT.  THE PEOPLE OF DR. HERNANDEZ MILL WILL BE GOOD GUIDES AND THE PLANE-TABLE SKETCH ABOVE REFERRED TO WILL ALSO BE OF GREAT VALUE.  PEREGRIN TORRES OF BOQUERON WAS WITH THE PARTY AT THIS STATION.
markers.setting: SET INTO TOP OF METAL PIPE DRIVEN INTO GROUND
markers.stability: MARK OF QUESTIONABLE OR UNKNOWN STABILITY

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1900 (JN) STATION IS IN A FIELD, NOW USED FOR GRAZING, BELONGING TO SENOR EQUESTO LAPATA.  IT IS ABOUT 137 METERS E OF THE STATION AND 36 METERS N OF THE LINE TO EAST BASE IS A LARGE, FINE, THRIVING, MANGO TREE.  A CONTINUATION OF THE BASE LINE ABOUT 150 METERS W OF THE STATION WOULD INTERSECT A PRIVATE GRAVEYARD, THE PROPERTY OF A ONCE WEALTHY FAMILY.  IN THE ENCLOSURE AT PRESENT ARE SEVERAL SUBSTANTIAL BRICK TOMBS.  MARK FOR THE STATION IS A 2-FOOT PIECE OF 2-INCH IRON PIPE SUNK IN THE GROUND UNTIL ONLY TWO INCHES OF THE LENGTH PROTRUDE.  CEMENT WAS POURED IN AROUND THE OUTSIDE OF THE PIPE AND WAS ALSO USED TO FILL THE PIPE.  IN THE CENTER OF THE PIPE, A SCREW WAS EMBEDDED IN THE MORTAR.  THE MIDDLE OF THE E LINE OF THE SLOT IN THE SCREW IS THE STATION CENTER.  PEREGRIN TORRES OF BOQUERON KNOWS OF THE WHEREABOUTS OF THE STATION AS DOES ALSO SENOR LAPATA.

BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1925 (GCM) STATION IS ON THE SW SIDE OF MANGROVE HARBOR, 150 METERS N OF SMALL MANGROVE BORDERED INLET.  STATION IS MARKED BY A 1-INCH DRILL HOLE IN THE HIGHEST PART OF THE CUBE OF ROCK (ABOUT 20 INCHES ON INSIDE) WHICH SETS ON, AND IS PART OF AN OUTCROP OF ROCK ABOUT 3 BY 5-FOOT, SURROUNDED BY BROKEN OUTCROP.  STATION IS 5 FEET ABOVE AND 8 FEET IN FROM WATER EDGE, ON RANGE WITH OUTERMOST ROCK OF NEGRA POINT, AND N TANGENT OF SAIL ROCK.  THERE IS A LARGER OUTCROP OF ROCK 25 METERS NW ABOUT THE SAME DISTANCE FROM THE WATER.  A SHORT POLE AND BANNER WAS ERECTED OVER THE MARK.

BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1901 (JN) THE INSTRUMENT WAS MOUNTED ECCENTRICALLY ON THE UPPER BALCONY OF THE LIGHTHOUSE.  THE LIGHTHOUSE IS ON A LOW SAND BEACH ON THE NW CORNER OF THE ISLAND OF PUERTO RICO.

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JWC) THE STATION IS LOCATED 3-1/2 AIRLINE MILES SOUTH OF ENSENADA, 3-1/2 AIRLINE MILES SOUTH-SOUTHWEST OF GUANICA AND ON A POINT OF LAND WHICH IS KNOWN AS PUNTA BREA.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE POST OFFICE IN ENSENADA, GO SOUTHERLY ON A PAVED ROAD FOR 3.5 MILES TO THE JOROBADO BOAT DOCK.  FROM HERE GO EAST BY BOAT FOR ABOUT 2 MILES TO THE WEST EDGE OF A POINT OF LAND.  FROM HERE PACK EAST ALONG SHORE LINE FOR ABOUT 15 MINUTES TO THE MOST SOUTHERLY EDGE OF PUNTA BREA AND THE STATION ON THE TOP OF A LOW BLUFF.  THE BOAT WAS OBTAINED FROM MR. FELIX RODRIGUEZ VEGA AND HE LIVES IN JOROBADO.  THE STATION MARK IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED BREA 1966, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN OUTCROPPING BEDROCK WHICH PROJECTS 3 INCHES.  IT IS ABOUT 150 YARDS NORTH OF THE SHORE LINE.  REFERENCE MARK 1 IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED BREA NO 1 1966, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN OUTCROPPING BEDROCK WHICH IS FLUSH WITH THE SURFACE.  REFERENCE MARK 2 IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED BREA NO 2 1966, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN OUTCROPPING BEDROCK WHICH PROJECTS 4 INCHES.  NO AZIMUTH MARK WAS ESTABLISHED AT THIS STATION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1970)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1970 (KAM) STATION MARK AND REFERENCE MARKS NO. 1 AND NO. 2 WERE RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.  THE ORIGINAL DESCRIPTION FOR REACHING THE STATION IS INADEQUATE.  A NEW TO REACH FOLLOWS--  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE POST OFFICE IN ENSENADA, GO SOUTHERLY ON A PAVED ROAD FOR 2.7 MILES, BETWEEN 4.3 AND 4.4 KILOMETER POSTS, TURN LEFT ON TO A DIRT ROAD AND GO 0.8 MILES TO A Y IN THE ROAD, TAKE THE LEFT FORK FOR 1.2 MILES TO ITS END AT THE BEACH.  FROM HERE PACK EAST ALONG THE SHORELINE FOR 8 MINUTES TO THE MOST SOUTHERLY EDGE OF PUNTA BREA AND THE STATION ON TOP OF A LOW BLUFF.                            STATION RECOVERY (1971)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1971 (EKM) STATION MARK AND REFERENCE MARKS RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.  NEED TO ADD THE FOLLOWING AFTER.....A LOW BLUFF.  A 16 FOOT OBSERVING STAND AND INSTRUMENT STAND ARE OVER THE STATION MARK.  THE INSTRUMENT STAND IS WEIGHTED DOWN WITH BOULDERS WHICH WILL COVER THE STATION MARK WHEN THE LUMBER ROTS.

BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1939 STATION IS LOCATED W OF DORADO AND N OF VEGA ALTA, ON LAND OWNED BY CENTRAL SAN VINCENTE, ABOUT 1 KM. W OF THE LIMITS OF THE PROPERTY OF MISS CLARA LIVINGSTON.  THE VICINITY IS KNOWN AS BRENA.  THE LOW HILL WHERE THE STATION IS LOCATED LIES BETWEEN TWO SMALL BAYS BRENA ON THE W AND LOS TOCONES ON THE E.  APPROACHED FROM DORADO BY MUNICIPAL ROAD THAT STARTS FROM TOWN WESTWARD TO HOME OF MISS LIVINGSTON, FROM WHERE PROCEED BY DIRT ROADS TO THE W LIMIT OF THE PROPERTY AT A POINT ABOUT 1 KM. S OF BEACH.  FOLLOW N TO A LOW PALM-COVERED POINT E OF LOS TOCONAS BAY, FROM WHERE PROCEED W ALONG BEACH TO FIRST LOW HILL JUST AFTER PASSING BAY AND DRAIN.  THE TOP OF HILL RUNS ABOUT SW TO NE WITH ITS HIGHEST POINT AND STATION IN ABOUT THE CENTER.  STATION MARK--STANDARD TABLET STAMPED BRENA 1939, CENTERED OVER CONCRETE MONUMENT, ANCHORED ON NATURAL ROCK LEDGE.  REFERENCE MARK 1--R.R. SPIKE CEMENTED TO NATURAL ROCK LEDGE W OF STATION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1966)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JJL) THE STATION MARK WAS FOUND AND IN GOOD CONDITION.  THE REFERENCE MARK WAS SEARCHED FOR BUT WAS NOT FOUND.  A COMPLETE NEW DESCRIPTION FOLLOWS--  THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 6 MILES NORTH OF VEGA ALTA, 5 MILES NORTHWEST OF DORADO, ON A LOW BRUSH COVERED HILL THAT LIES BETWEEN TWO BAYS, BRENA BAY ON THE WEST AND LOS TOCONES BAY ON THE EAST.  THE LAND IS LEASED BY MR. DAVE SARTIN OF THE STAR RANCH.  THE OWNER WAS NOT CONTACTED.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE POST OFFICE IN DORADO, GO WEST ON HIGHWAY 693 FOR 0.5 MILE TO THE JUNCTION WITH HIGHWAY 798 AT A SIDE ROAD ON THE RIGHT.  CONTINUE WEST ON HIGHWAY 693 FOR 0.5 MILE TO A FORK.  TAKE THE LEFT FORK AND CONTINUE WESTERLY ON HIGHWAY 693 FOR 3.25 MILES TO A SIDE ROAD ON THE RIGHT.  TURN RIGHT AND GO NORTH ON A DIRT ROAD FOR 0.6 MILE TO A T ROAD.  TURN RIGHT AND GO EAST FOR 100 FEET TO THE END OF THE ROAD.  CONTINUE EAST ALONG THE SOUTH SIDE OF THE CREST OF A GRASSY RIDGE FOR 0.2 MILE TO THE BASE OF A LOW HILL AND THE END OF TRUCK TRAVEL.  FROM HERE PACK SOUTHEASTERLY THROUGH HEAVY BRUSH FOR 75 YARDS TO THE STATION ON THE HIGHEST POINT OF THE LOW HILL.  THE STATION MARK IS A U.S. GEOLOGICAL SURVEY BENCH MARK DISK STAMPED BRENA 1939, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A ROCK OUTCROP THAT IS FLUSH WITH THE GROUND.  REFERENCE MARK 1 IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED BRENA USGS NO 1 1939, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A ROCK OUTCROP THAT IS FLUSH WITH THE GROUND.  IT IS 1 FOOT LOWER IN ELEVATION THAN THE STATION MARK.  REFERENCE MARK 2 IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED BRENA USGS NO 2 1939, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A ROCK OUTCROP THAT IS FLUSH WITH THE GROUND.  IT IS 1 FOOT LOWER IN ELEVATION THAN THE STATION MARK.  NOTE--AFTER OBSERVATIONS WERE COMPLETED, PART OF THE STATION MARK DISK WAS BROKEN OFF BY VANDALS.  A NEW DISK WAS SET IN THE SAME DRILL HOLE AND THE POSITION AND ELEVATION WAS HELD.  THE NEW MARK, STAMPED BRENA USGS 1939, IS A STANDARD COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY DISK.  AIRLINE DISTANCE AND DIRECTION FROM NEAREST TOWN 5 MILES NORTHWEST OF DORADO.
