markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1939 (HAC) STATION IS THE TOP CENTER OF THE LARGEST RUM STORAGE TANK AT THE BRUGAL DISTILLERY JUST SE OF PUEBLO VIEJO BAY, SAN JUAN HARBOR.  THIS DISTILLERY IS LOCATED ON THE NW SIDE OF THE SAN JUAN HIGHWAY, AT A POINT WHERE THIS HIGHWAY APPROACHES THE FIRST HILLS BORDERING THE S SIDE OF SAN JUAN HARBOR.  THE PARTICULAR TANK IS LOCATED DIRECTLY BEHIND THE BOTTLING BUILDING AND TO THE LEFT OF THE DISTILLING PLANT.  THERE IS A SMALL VENTILATING BONNET ON THE TOP OF THE TANK, THE TIP OF THIS BONNET IS THE STATION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1964)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1964 (GWM) THE ORIGINAL DESCRIPTION WAS USED IN AN ATTEMPT TO FIND THE STATION.  THE BRUGAL DISTILLERY IS NOW A SHELL OIL TANK FARM.  I COULD NOT DETERMINE WHICH TANK OF THE GROUP WAS THE STATION.

BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1939 (HAC) STATION IS THE SMALL STAFF SURMOUNTING THE TOWER OF THE DISTILLING PLANT AT THE BRUGAL DISTILLERY.  THIS DISTILLERY IS LOCATED ON THE NW SIDE OF THE SAN JUAN HIGHWAY AT A POINT WHERE THIS HIGHWAY APPROACHES THE FIRST HILLS BORDERING THE S SIDE OF SAN JUAN HARBOR.  THE DISTILLING PLANT IS THE LARGEST BUILDING AT THE DISTILLERY.  THERE ARE TWO IRON STACKS A SHORT DISTANCE NW OF THE TOWER.                            STATION RECOVERY (1964)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1964 (GWM) THE STATION WAS DESTROYED WHEN THE BUILDING WAS REMOVED.

BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1902 (JN) STATION IS ON A SANDY KNOLL OF MODERATE ELEVATION ABOUT 10 MILES S OF E FROM SAN JUAN, AND ABOUT 3 MILES S OF POINT CONGREJOS.  IT IS ABOUT 2-1/2 MILES NW FROM THE TOWN OF CAROLINA, ON THE ROAD FROM SAN JUAN TO FAJARDO.  THE STATION IS ON ABOUT THE HIGHEST PART OF THE HILL IN AN OPEN PLACE IN THE BUSHES.  THERE IS A BOARD HOUSE WITH A THATCHED ROOF ABOUT 150 FEET NE FROM THE STATION.  THERE ARE SOME SCATTERING COCOANUTS AND OTHER TREES ON THE HILL.  THE STATION IS IN THE BARRIO OF CAROLINA.  ANDRUS BRUTRONE, THE OWNER OF THE LAND LIVES NEAR THE STATION.  THE STATION IS MARKED BY A 2-INCH PIPE 2 FEET LONG SET INTO CEMENT.  THE PIPE PROJECTS A FEW INCHES ABOVE THE SURFACE.  THE CENTER OF THE HEAD OF A NAIL CEMENTED INTO THE CENTER OF THE PIPE MARKS THE STATION.  A TRIPOD AND SCAFFOLD SIGNAL 20 FEET HIGH WAS ERECTED HERE.  THE INSTRUMENT WAS MOUNTED ON THE TOP OF THE TRIPOD.                            STATION RECOVERY (1962)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1962 (MLO) THE STATION WAS SEARCHED FOR BUT NOT RECOVERED.  ROADS AND BUILDINGS HAVE BEEN CONSTRUCTED ON TOP OF THIS HILL AND A QUARRY IS LOCATED NEAR THE TOP OF THE HILL.  THE STATION IS BELIEVED TO HAVE BEEN DESTROYED.
markers.setting: SET INTO TOP OF METAL PIPE DRIVEN INTO GROUND
markers.stability: MARK OF QUESTIONABLE OR UNKNOWN STABILITY

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1900 (JN) STATION IS ON HILL E OF CABO ROJO KNOWN AS BUENA VISTA.  ON THE VERY SUMMIT OF HILL IS THE HOUSE OF THE OWNER OF THE LAND, DON JOSE MARIA YRISARRE.  BECAUSE OF THE VALUE TO HIM OF THE TREES SURROUNDING HIS HOME, IT WAS DEEMED BEST TO ERECT THE SIGNAL ON THE HILLSIDE W OF HOUSE, THIS PLACE BEING PERFECTLY SATISFACTORY IN OTHER RESPECTS.  SIGNAL IS ALMOST AT THE FOOT OF THE FIRST STEEP DESCENT LEADING W FROM TOP OF HILL WHERE DON YRISARRES HOUSE IS.  A TRAIL LEADS DOWN THE SLOPE (SOUTHWESTERLY) FROM YRISARRES HOUSE TO A 1-ROOM CABIN AT THE W END OF THE TOP SLOPE FROM WHICH THE DESCENT IS ALMOST PRECIPITOUS TOWARD THE VALLEY IN WHICH CABO ROJO LIES.  ALONG THIS TRAIL IS AN ORANGE TREE, THE MOST WESTERLY OF THE TREES ON THE HILL SUMMIT, AND OUR STATION IS 11.60 METERS SW OF THIS TREE. THE RIDGE IS ABOUT 9 METERS WIDE AT THE SIGNAL.  IN LINE WITH BUENA VISTA AND MELONES (ALSO WITH NECK OF LAND ENCLOSING BOQUERON LAGOON ON SEASIDE) IS A SMALL TREE (LOCAL NAME ACHIOTA) DISTANCE 7.5 METERS.  A WHITE-BARKED CALABASA OR GOURD TREE IS ALONGSIDE OF THE ACHIOTA.  STATION IS MARKED BY A SECTION OF IRON PIPE 22 INCHES LONG AND 2 INCHES IN DIAMETER.  THIS WAS SUNK IN GROUND FOR A LENGTH OF 15 INCHES AND THEN SECURED AND FILLED WITH CEMENT IN WHICH AN IRON NAIL WAS SET.  CENTER OF NAIL HEAD IS CENTER OF STATION.  TO REACH STATION ONE SHOULD COME TO CABO ROJO, TAKE MILITARY ROAD TOWARDS MAYAGUEZ, FOLLOW IT TO FIRST LARGE ROAD TURNING TO LEFT.  ON WAY ANYONE CAN DIRECT THE INQUIRER TO BUENA VISTA HILL.                            STATION RECOVERY (1934)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1934 FOUND AS DESCRIBED AND IN GOOD CONDITION.  LAND NOW OWNED BY PABLO VELEZ AND PABLO LUGO.  HOUSE ON SUMMIT OF HILL HAS BEEN DESTROYED.  NEW STATION BUENA VISTA 2 ESTABLISHED ON SUMMIT.  TO REACH FROM CABO ROJO, FOLLOW CARRETERRA NO. 29 TO STORE OF ISMAEL ROMOS TOWLS AT K0-H8 1/2.  CART ROAD FROM HERE TO FOOT OF HILL AND TRAIL TO TOP.
markers.setting: SET INTO TOP OF METAL PIPE DRIVEN INTO GROUND
markers.stability: MARK OF QUESTIONABLE OR UNKNOWN STABILITY

markers.description: BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1934 STATION IS LOCATED 5 KILOMETERS BY ROAD AND TRAIL E OF CABO ROJO, NEAR THE W END OF A LOW RANGE OF MOUNTAINS, WHICH EXTENDS E TO YAUCO.  THIS STATION IS VERY NEAR STATION BUENA VISTA WHICH WAS FOUND BUT COULD NOT BE USED FOR EXPANSION BECAUSE OF OBSTRUCTED VIEW TO THE E.  THE HOUSE ON TOP OF PEAK, MENTIONED IN DESCRIPTION OF BUENA VISTA, IS NOW GONE AND PEAK IS BARE WITH EXCEPTION OF SOME SCATTERED BRUSH, MOST OF WHICH WAS CUT, ALSO THE TOP OF A LARGE MANGO TREE ON N SLOPE WAS CUT OFF TO PERMIT A VIEW IN THAT DIRECTION.  STATION IS ON HIGHEST PART OF PEAK WHICH HAS SEVERAL LARGE PILES OF LOOSE ROCK UPON IT.  STATION MARK IS A STANDARD U.S.G.S. TABLET STAMPED BUENA VISTA-2-1934 CEMENTED IN A PECULIAR ROUNDED FORMATION IN SOLID ROCK.  REFERENCE MARK NO.1 IS A CROSS CUT ON A PROJECTING ROCK ON SW SLOPE, 34.70 FEET FROM STATION IN TRUE AZIMUTH 62 DEG 29 MIN.  REFERENCE MARK NO.2 IS A DRILL HOLE IN LARGE ROUND BOULDER, 36.48 FEET FROM STATION IN TRUE AZIMUTH 111 DEG 31 MIN.  STATION BUENA VISTA IS 127.21 FEET DISTANT IN TRUE AZIMUTH 110 DEG 55 MIN.  TO REACH STATION, GO TO KILOMETER POST K0-H 8-1/2 ON CARRETERA 29, A SECOND CLASS ROAD, AT POINT WHERE ROAD MAKES SHARP TURN FROM S TO E, WITH TIENDA ON W SIDE AT TURN.  TAKE CART ROAD LEADING S AND FOLLOW FOR ABOUT 1 KILOMETER, TURN LEFT (E) AND FOLLOW ROAD TO FOOT OF MOUNTAIN, FROM WHICH POINT A WELL USED TRAIL LEADS TO TOP.  AFTER REACHING TOP, STATION IS ABOUT 100 METERS TO RIGHT (W) OF TRAIL.  SIGNAL IS WHITE TRIPOD WITH BLACK CROSS TARGETS ON CENTER POLE.                            STATION RECOVERY (1952)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1952 (JOP) STATION MARK WAS RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED IN 1934 AND FOUND IN GOOD CONDITION.  THE ROUTE TO STATION IS ADEQUATE.  THE OLD REFERENCE MARKS WERE NOT RECOVERED.  TWO NEW ONES WERE ESTABLISHED.  BOTH ARE STANDARD USC AND GS REFERENCE DISKS IN DRILL HOLES IN BOULDERS.  REFERENCE MARK 1, STAMPED BUENA VISTA 2 1934 NO 1, IS IN A BOULDER ABOUT 1 FOOT IN DIAMETER AND 2-1/2 FEET LOWER THAN THE STATION MARK.  REFERENCE MARK 2, STAMPED BUENA VISTA 2 1934 NO 2, IS AT THE SOUTHEAST EDGE OF A GROWTH OF TREES.  IT IS IN A BOULDER ABOUT 2-1/2 FEET IN DIAMETER AND 1 FOOT HIGHER THAN THE STATION MARK.  NO AZIMUTH MARK ESTABLISHED.  NOTE--MARKS WERE TO BE CUT IN LATER.                            STATION RECOVERY (1956)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1956 (EAT) THE STATION WAS RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED BY J.O.P. IN 1952 AND THE STATION MARK WAS FOUND IN GOOD CONDITION.  BOTH REFERENCE MARKS WERE FOUND MUTILATED AND LOOSE IN THEIR DRILL HOLES AND WERE REINFORCED WITH CONCRETE BY THIS PARTY.  ADDITIONAL NOTES FOLLOW--  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE JUNCTION OF HIGHWAYS 4 AND 102 AT THE NORTHEAST EDGE OF CABO ROJO GO EASTERLY ON HIGHWAY 102 FOR 0.5 MILE TO A CURVE IN THE ROAD, A BRIDGE AND A SIDE ROAD RIGHT.  TURN RIGHT, SOUTHERLY, AND GO SOUTH AND EAST ON A GRADED DIRT ROAD FOR 1.5 MILES TO THE END OF ROAD AT A STONE QUARRY.  THENCE FOLLOW OLD DESCRIPTION.  OBSERVATIONS MADE FROM A FOUR FOOT STAND.                            STATION RECOVERY (1966)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JWC) THE STATION WAS RECOVERED AND ALL MARKS WERE FOUND IN GOOD CONDITION.  A COMPLETE NEW DESCRIPTION OF THE STATION FOLLOWS--  THE STATION IS LOCATED 5 AIRLINE MILES WEST OF SAN GERMAN, 5 AIRLINE MILES NORTHWEST OF LAJAS, 2 AIRLINE MILES SOUTHEAST OF CABO ROJO AND ON THE TOP OF A HIGH BRUSH COVERED HILL.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE NORTHEAST CORNER OF THE PLAZA IN CABO ROJO, GO NORTH ON A PAVED STREET FOR 1 BLOCK TO HIGHWAYS 102 AND 103.  TURN RIGHT AND GO EAST AND NORTH ON HIGHWAYS 102 AND 103 FOR 0.5 MILE TO A FORK.  KEEP RIGHT AND GO EAST ON HIGHWAY 102 FOR 0.55 MILE TO A SIDE ROAD RIGHT JUST BEFORE REACHING A SMALL BRIDGE.  TURN RIGHT AND GO SOUTH AND EAST ON A BLADED ROAD FOR 0.65 MILE TO A T-INTERSECTION.  TURN RIGHT AND GO SOUTH AND EAST ON A BLADED ROAD FOR 0.7 MILE TO THE END OF TRUCK TRAVEL AT A SMALL HOUSE ON THE RIGHT.  FROM HERE PACK SOUTH UPHILL ON A TRAIL FOR ABOUT 100 YARDS TO THE TOP OF THE BRUSH COVERED HILL AND THE STATION.  A 5 MINUTE PACK AND 4 WHEEL DRIVE VEHICLE STATION.  THE STATION MARK IS A U.S. GEOLOGICAL SURVEY BENCH MARK DISK STAMPED BUENA VISTA 2 1934, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A BOULDER WHICH PROJECTS 3 INCHES.  REFERENCE MARK 1 IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED BUENA VISTA 2 NO 1 1934, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A BOULDER WHICH PROJECTS 1 FOOT.  (NOTE 12C)  REFERENCE MARK 2 IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED BUENA VISTA 2 NO 2 1934, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A BOULDER WHICH PROJECTS 2 FEET.  (NOTE 12C)  NO AZIMUTH MARK WAS ESTABLISHED AT THIS STATION.  AIRLINE DISTANCE AND DIRECTION FROM NEAREST TOWN 2 MILES SOUTHEAST OF CABO ROJO.
markers.setting: SET IN UNSPECIFIED ROCK OR BOULDER
markers.stability: PROBABLY HOLD POSITION/ELEVATION WELL

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JWC) THE STATION IS LOCATED 14 AIRLINE MILES NORTHWEST OF MAYAGUEZ, 9 AIRLINE MILES SOUTHWEST OF AGUADILLA, 2 AIRLINE MILES NORTHWEST OF RINCON AND ON THE TOP OF A CULTIVATED HILL.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE PLAZA IN RINCON, GO NORTHERLY ON HIGHWAY 115 FOR 0.15 MILE TO A FORK.  KEEP LEFT AND GO NORTHWEST ON HIGHWAY 413 FOR 1.55 MILES TO A FORK.  KEEP RIGHT AND GO NORTHEAST ON A PAVED ROAD FOR 0.4 MILE TO A TRAIL ON THE RIGHT AT KILOMETER POST 3.1 AND END OF TRUCK TRAVEL.  FROM HERE PACK SOUTH ON THE TRAIL PASSING A SCHOOL HOUSE FOR ABOUT 200 YARDS TO THE TOP OF THE CULTIVATED HILL AND THE STATION.  THE STATION MARK IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED BULL 1966, SET IN THE TOP OF A MASS OF CONCRETE WHICH PROJECTS 2 INCHES.  REFERENCE MARK 1 IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED BULL NO 1 1966, SET IN THE TOP OF A MASS OF CONCRETE WHICH IS FLUSH WITH THE SURFACE.  REFERENCE MARK 2 IS AN IRON PEG SET IN THE TOP OF A 14-INCH SQUARE CONCRETE MONUMENT WHICH PROJECTS 1 INCH.  IT HAS SANTONI INSCRIBED IN THE TOP OF THE CONCRETE MONUMENT.
markers.setting: OBJECT SURROUNDED BY MASS OF CONCRETE
markers.stability: MARK OF QUESTIONABLE OR UNKNOWN STABILITY

markers.description: BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1934 STATION IS ABOUT 3 MILES FROM CAGUAS IN AN EASTERLY DIRECTION, 1.5 MILES FROM SAN LORENZO IN A NORTHERN DIRECTION AND ABOUT 1 MILE FROM GURABO, ON A GRASS-COVERED PEAK RATHER LONG IN AN E AND W DIRECTION.  ON THE EASTERN SLOPE THERE ARE THREE LARGE ROYAL PALMS AS WELL AS A SWEET-POTATO PATCH.  THE UNITED PORTO RICO SUGAR COMPANY IS ITS PRESENT OWNER.  STATION MARK IS A U.S.G.S. BENCH MARK SET AND STAMPED ON A CONCRETE BASE.  REFERENCE MARK NO.1 IS A SMALL HOLE DRILLED ON BOULDER WHICH IS 14 FEET 3 INCHES DISTANT FROM STATION IN TRUE AZIMUTH 09 DEG 13 MIN.  REFERENCE MARK NO.2 IS A CROSS ON BOULDER, 12 FEET 8 INCHES DISTANT, IN TRUE AZIMUTH 84 DEG 05 MIN.  TO REACH THE STATION TAKE THE CAGUAS-SAN LORENZO ROAD AND TURN N AT KILOMETER 2 H 6, CROSSING THE RIVER AND FOLLOWING THE RURAL ROAD NORTHWARD UP TO THE CAMINO REAL.  TURN TO THE RIGHT AND FOLLOW ROAD AS FAR AS POSSIBLE.  THE HILL IS A SHORT DISTANCE FROM IT.                            STATION RECOVERY (1940)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1940 STATION AND R.M.6 RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED, IN GOOD CONDITION.  MARK IS 2 FT. N OF FENCE.  A BETTER WAY TO REACH STATION IS AS FOLLOWS--FROM GURABO, TAKE MAIN ROAD TOWARD JUNCOS 0.1 MILE TO K7 H8.  TURN RIGHT (S) AND FOLLOW IMPROVED ROAD TO END OF HARD SURFACE (2.5 KM.).  AT THIS POINT THE STATION CAN BE SEEN ON PEAK THROUGH SADDLE TOWARD SW.  CONTINUE IN CAR ALONG ROAD ANOTHER 1/2 KM., AND TAKE TRAIL ACROSS FARM OF MARCUS TORRES TO STATION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1963)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1963 (CPO) THIS STATION MARK WAS RECOVERED AND FOUND TO BE IN GOOD CONDITION, EXCEPT THE DISK HAS BEEN BATTERED CONSIDERABLE.  THE REFERENCE MARKS WERE SEARCHED FOR AND NOT LOCATED.
markers.setting: OBJECT SURROUNDED BY MASS OF CONCRETE
markers.stability: MARK OF QUESTIONABLE OR UNKNOWN STABILITY

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1965 (JJL) THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 3-1/2 MILES SOUTHEAST OF LUQUILLO, 2-1/4 MILES NORTHWEST OF FAJARDO AND ON THE HIGHEST POINT OF A GRASSY, PARTIALLY TREE COVERED HILL OWNED BY MR. FRANCISCO DIEZ.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE ALCALDIA (CITY HALL) ON THE WEST SIDE OF THE PLAZA IN LUQUILLO, GO SOUTH AND EAST ON THE PAVED STREET FOR 0.1 MILE TO A CROSSROAD.  TURN RIGHT AND GO SOUTH ON HIGHWAY 193 FOR 0.4 MILE TO THE JUNCTION WITH HIGHWAY 3.  TURN LEFT AND GO SOUTH ON HIGHWAY 3 FOR 2.45 MILES TO A SIDE ROAD RIGHT AT KILOMETER POST K42 H1.  TURN RIGHT AND FOLLOW THE PAVED ROAD NORTHWESTERLY FOR 0.35 MILE TO A SIDE ROAD LEFT AT KILOMETER POST K2 H6.  TURN LEFT AND FOLLOW HIGHWAY 984 WESTERLY FOR 1.1 MILES TO A Y-FORK AT KILOMETER POST OHMO.  KEEP THE LEFT FORK AND FOLLOW THE NARROW PAVED ROAD SOUTHWESTERLY FOR 0.5 MILE TO A WIRE GATE ON THE LEFT AND A HOUSE ON THE RIGHT, WEST, SIDE OF THE ROAD AT KILOMETER POST K2 H6 AND THE END OF TRUCK TRAVEL.  (TO REACH THE AZIMUTH MARK FROM THIS POINT, CONTINUE AHEAD ON THE NARROW PAVED ROAD FOR 0.55 MILE TO A SMALL, CONCRETE BOX CULVERT ON THE RIGHT, WEST, SIDE OF THE ROAD AND THE AZIMUTH MARK.) FROM THE ROAD, PASS THROUGH THE GATE AND PACK DOWNHILL IN AN EASTERLY DIRECTION FOR ABOUT 75 YARDS TO A SMALL STREAM.  CROSS THE STREAM AND BEAR TO THE LEFT, PACKING IN A NORTHEASTERLY DIRECTION, UPHILL ALONG A WELL DEFINED TRAIL TO A RIDGE.  BEAR SOUTHEASTERLY FOLLOWING THE TRAIL ALONG THE TIMBERED RIDGE TO A HOUSE.  FROM THE HOUSE PACK EASTERLY FOR ABOUT 100 YARDS THEN BEAR SOUTHEASTERLY ON THE TRAIL ALONG THE GRASSY HILLSIDE FOR ABOUT 0.2 MILE TO THE BASE OF A GRASSY HILL.  PACK EASTERLY UP THE STEEP, GRASSY HILLSIDE TOWARD A GROUP OF LARGE BOULDERS TO THE HIGHEST POINT OF THE HILL AND THE STATION.  (A 1 HOUR PACK.)  THE STATION MARK IS A STANDARD DISK, STAMPED BURROS 1965, BRAZED TO THE TOP OF A 3-INCH DIAMETER CAST IRON PIPE THAT PROJECTS 2 INCHES.  REFERENCE MARK 1 IS A STANDARD DISK, STAMPED BURROS NO 1 1965, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A BOULDER THAT PROJECTS 2 FEET AND IT IS ABOUT 1 FOOT BELOW THE LEVEL OF THE STATION.  REFERENCE MARK 2 IS A STANDARD DISK, STAMPED BURROS NO 2 1965, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A BOULDER THAT PROJECTS 8 INCHES AND IT IS ABOUT 5 FEET BELOW THE LEVEL OF THE STATION.  THE AZIMUTH MARK IS A STANDARD DISK, STAMPED BURROS 1965, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN THE CONCRETE HEADWALL OF A CULVERT.  IT IS 10.6 FEET SOUTHWEST OF THE APPROXIMATE CENTER OF THE PAVED ROAD.  THE IRON ROD IS A SECTION OF T-SHAPED IRON EMBEDDED IN A MASS OF CONCRETE THAT IS FLUSH WITH THE GROUND.  IT WAS ESTABLISHED BY THE PUERTO RICO PUBLIC WORKS DEPARTMENT, PHOTOGRAMMETRY DIVISION.
markers.setting: SET INTO TOP OF METAL PIPE DRIVEN INTO GROUND
markers.stability: MARK OF QUESTIONABLE OR UNKNOWN STABILITY

markers.description: BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1934 THIS STATION IS LOCATED ON TOP OF A FLAT CONCRETE ROOF OF THE HOUSE OF MR. WOODFING L. BUTTE, ON THE ROAD TO THE SAN JUAN WATER FILTER PLANT.  THE HOUSE IS LOCATED ON TOP OF HILL 3 KILOMETERS E OF THE ROAD.  STATION IS CENTER OF FLAT SQUARE ROOF, EQUIDISTANT FROM INSIDE OF THE 4 CORNERS.  NOT MARKED.                            STATION RECOVERY (1940)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1940 STATION RECOVERED (NOT MARKED).  NEW DESCRIPTION FOLLOWS--  ABOUT 1-1/2 MILES NORTH OF GUAYNABO.  1000 FT. NE OF SAN JUAN WATERWORKS FILTER PLANT.  AND 600 FT. SE OF THE SAN JUAN MAGNETIC STATION OF THE U.S.C. AND G.S.  THE STATION IS THE CENTER OF A DIMLY MARKED CROSS IN THE FLAT CEMENT ROOF, EQUIDISTANT FROM THE INSIDES OF THE FOUR CORNERS OF THE NORTH SECTION, ON THE HOUSE OF DONA RITA CALAF.  TO REACH FROM GUAYNABO, DRIVE NORTH ON THE ROAD TO RIO PIEDRAS ABOUT 1-1/2 MILES TO A PROMINENT FORK, LEFT.  TAKE THIS ROAD, WHICH IS ALSO THE ROAD TO THE MAGNETIC STATION.  AND FOLLOW UP HILL.  AT RIDGE TAKE LEFT FORK (RIGHT GOES TO MAGNETIC STATION), AND PROCEED ABOUT 0.2 MILE TO DRIVEWAY LEFT, LEADING UP STEEP HILL TO THE CALAF FINCA, THE HIGHEST IN THE VICINITY.                            STATION RECOVERY (1941)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1941 (GBG) STATION RECOVERED (NOT MARKED).  NEW DESCRIPTION FOLLOWS--  ABOUT 1-1/2 MILES N OF GUAYNABO.  1000 FEET NE OF THE SAN JUAN WATER WORKS FILTER PLANT.  AND 600 FEET SE OF THE SAN JUAN MAGNETIC STATION OF THE U.S.C. AND G.S.  THE STATION IS THE CENTER OF A DIMLY MARKED CROSS IN THE FLAT, CEMENT ROOF, EQUIDISTANT FROM THE INSIDES OF THE FOUR CORNERS OF THE N SECTION, ON THE HOUSE OF DONA RITA CALAF.  TO REACH FROM GUAYNABO, DRIVE N ON THE ROAD TO RIO PIEDRAS ABOUT 1-1/2 MILES TO PROMINENT FORK LEFT.  TAKE THIS ROAD, WHICH IS ALSO THE ROAD TO THE MAGNETIC STATION.  AND FOLLOW UP HILL.  AT RIDGE TAKE LEFT FORK (RIGHT GOES TO LOWER SIDE OF MAGNETIC STATION) AND PROCEED ABOUT 0.2 MILE TO DRIVEWAY, LEFT, LEADING UP STEEP HILL TO THE CALAF FINCA, THE HIGHEST IN THE VICINITY.  IN 1942 THE U.S. ENGINEERS HAVE MARKED THIS POINT WITH ONE OF THEIR TABLETS.  SEE ALSO BUTTE, ECC. 1942.                            STATION RECOVERY (1958)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1958 (RWS) STATION WAS RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.  A SEARCH WAS MADE FOR BUTTE ECCENTRIC BUT THE STATION WAS NOT FOUND.  THERE IS NO TANK ON THE ROOF.                            STATION RECOVERY (1964)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1964 (GWM) THE STATION DESCRIPTION IS ADEQUATE.  THE WATER TANK THAT WAS ON THE ROOF AND CALLED BUTTE ECC. IS GONE.                            STATION RECOVERY (1965)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1965 (JJL) THE STATION MARK WAS FOUND AND IN GOOD CONDITION.  A NEW DESCRIPTION FOLLOWS--  THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 4 MILES SOUTHEAST OF BAYAMON, 1-1/2 MILES NORTH-NORTHEAST OF GUAYNABO AND ON THE ROOF OF THE RESIDENCE OF MR. JORGE ORTIZ TORO BRUNET.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE OVERPASS AT THE JUNCTION OF HIGHWAYS 2, 19 AND 20 ABOUT 4 MILES NORTHEAST OF BAYAMON, GO SOUTH AND SOUTHEAST ON HIGHWAYS 19 AND 20, (GUAYNABO AVENUE), FOR 1.1 MILES TO A T ROAD.  TURN RIGHT AND GO SOUTHWESTERLY ON HIGHWAY 20 FOR 0.35 MILE TO THE JUNCTION WITH HIGHWAY 21.  CONTINUE SOUTH-SOUTHWEST ON HIGHWAY 20 FOR 0.5 MILE TO THE JUNCTION WITH HIGHWAYS 177 AND 833 AT THE AMERICAN MILITARY ACADEMY.  TURN RIGHT AND GO WEST ON HIGHWAYS 177 AND 833 FOR 0.35 MILE TO A SIDE ROAD ON THE LEFT.  TURN LEFT AND GO SOUTH FOR 0.25 MILE TO A FORK.  TAKE THE LEFT FORK AND CONTINUE SOUTH FOR 0.2 MILE TO A FORK.  TAKE THE LEFT FORK PASSING BETWEEN TWO PILLARS WITH THE NAME, ORTIZ TORO BRUNET PAINTED ON THEM AND GO SOUTHEASTERLY ON THE PRIVATE DRIVEWAY FOR 0.25 MILE TO A THREE STORY HOUSE AND THE STATION ON THE TOP.  THE STATION MARK IS A U.S. CORPS OF ENGINEERS DEPARTMENT SURVEY DISK THAT IS UNSTAMPED.  IT IS CEMENTED IN THE TOP OF THE CONCRETE ROOF OF THE HOUSE, 13.9 FEET SOUTHWEST OF THE NORTHEAST WALL OF THE HOUSE, 11.5 FEET SOUTHEAST OF THE NORTHWEST WALL AND 10 FEET NORTHWEST OF THE SOUTHEAST WALL OF THE HOUSE.  AIRLINE DISTANCE AND DIRECTION FROM NEAREST TOWN 1-1/2 MILES NORTH-NORTHEAST OF GUAYNABO.                            STATION RECOVERY (1970)  RECOVERY NOTE BY THOMAS ENG AND SURV 1970 (HBW) BUTTE 1934 UNDISTURBED.

BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1982 IN PONCE. LOCATED ABOUT 2.0 KM (1.2 MI) NORTH ALONG THE RIO BUCANAS CANAL FROM THE HIGHWAY 1 BRIDGE IN THE TOP OF THE WEST ABUTMENT OF A LARGE CONCRETE CANAL STRUCTURE RESEMBLING AN OPEN GATE.
markers.setting: SET IN A MASSIVE STRUCTURE
markers.stability: PROBABLY HOLD POSITION/ELEVATION WELL

markers.description: BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1995 (CSM) THE STATION IS LOCATED IN THE NE SECTION OF THE MUNICIPALITY OF SAN JUAN IN THE SANTA TERESITA SUBDIVISION ALONG THE NE EDGE OF PARQUE BARBOSA IN A TRIANGULAR TRAFFIC ISLAND.  TO REACH FROM THE ROUTE 26 OVERPASS AND CALLE PROVEDENCIA, PROCEED NORTH O.3 MI ON CALLE PROVEDENCIA WHICH TURNS INTO AVIENDA LAS AMERICAS, TO THE TRAFFIC ISLAND WITH STATION.  IT IS A STAINLESS STEEL ROD DRIVEN TO REFUSAL IN A GREASE SLEEVE WITH A LOGO CAP STAMPED ---C 1001 1995--- SET FLUSH WITH THE GROUND 58.6 FT (17.9 M) WEST OF TELEPHONE POLE NUMBER 22-13-30, 37.3 FT (11.4 M) EAST OF THE NORTHEASTERN MOST BLACK LIGHT POLE OF PAQUE BARBOSA, AND 2.7 FT (0.8 M) NORTH FROM SOUTH CORNER OF TRIANGULAR MEDIAN.  A STAINLESS STEEL ROD DRIVEN TO REFUSAL WITH GREASE SECURITY SLEEVE ENCASED IN 5 INCH PVC PIPE WITH AN ALUMINUM ACCESS COVER.  THE SS ROD WAS ROUNDED AND CENTERPUNCHED TO FACILITATE PRECISE LEVELING AND INSTRUMENT CENTERING.  THE MARK IS REPORTED AS BEING SUITABLE FOR GPS OBSERVATIONS BUT NO SUCH OBSERVATIONS WERE CONDUCTED AT THIS TIME.  DESCRIBED BY M.L.  ASLAKSEN.                            STATION RECOVERY (2002)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 2002 (JMW) RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED.  THE ROD WAS SAID TO BE DRIVEN TO REFUSAL BUT NO DEPTH WAS RECORDED.                            STATION RECOVERY (2007)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 2007 (MR) RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED                            STATION RECOVERY (2009)  RECOVERY NOTE BY JAVIER E. BIDOT AND ASSOC. 2009 (CFA) RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED.
markers.setting: STAINLESS STEEL ROD IN SLEEVE (10 FT.+)
markers.stability: MOST RELIABLE AND EXPECTED TO HOLDPOSITION/ELEVATION WELL

markers.description: BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1982 (JCL) THE STATION IS LOCATED 7.7 KM (4-3/4 MI) NORTHEAST OF PONCE, 8.0 KM (5 MI) WEST-NORTHWEST OF THE SMALL TOWN OF JUANA DIAZ, AND 0.4 KM (1/4 MI) SOUTHEAST OF THE CERRILLOS DAM SITE. OWNERSHIP--U.S. ARMY CORPS OF ENGINEERS.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE JUNCTION OF HIGHWAYS 1, 2, AND 133 ON THE WEST SIDE OF PONCE, GO NORTH AND WEST ON HIGHWAY 1 FOR 1.1 KM (0.7 MI) TO THE JUNCTION OF AVENUE EMELIO FAGOT. TURN RIGHT AND GO NORTH ON AVENUE EMELIO FAGOT FOR 1.7 KM (1.05 MI) TO THE JUNCTION OF HIGHWAY 14.  TURN RIGHT AND GO NORTHEAST ON HIGHWAY 14 FOR 1.7 KM (1.05 MI) TO A TRAFFIC LIGHT AT A CROSSROAD.  TURN LEFT AND GO NORTHERLY  ON A PAVED ROAD (HIGHWAY 139) FOR 0.5 KM (0.3 MI) TO A CROSSROAD. TURN RIGHT AND GO EAST AND NORTH ON HIGHWAY 139 FOLLOWING A WINDING ROAD FOR 3.1 KM (1.95 MI) TO A FORK.  TAKE RIGHT FORK AND CONTINUE NORTHERLY ON HIGHWAY 139 FOR 3.7 KM (2.35 MI) TO THE CORPS OF ENGINEERS LABORATORY BUILDING ON THE LEFT AND A GATE.  CONTINUE AHEAD ON HIGHWAY 139 FOR 65 METERS (104 FT) TO THE STATION ON THE RIGHT IN THE EAST EDGE OF THE ROAD.  THE STATION IS A STANDARD USE DISK STAMPED---USCE C 41 15 1 16 80---, SET INTO THE TOP OF AN IRREGULAR MASS OF CONCRETE 20 CM IN DIAMETER FLUSH WITH GROUND.  IT IS LOCATED 32.03 METERS (105.1 FT) NORTH-NORTHEAST FROM A POWER POLE, 12.45 METERS (40.8 FT) SOUTHEAST FROM A SOUTHWEST CORNER OF A 7-FOOT HIGH CHAIN LINK FENCE, 2.85 METERS (9.2 FT) EAST-SOUTHEAST FROM THE CENTER OF HIGHWAY 139, AND 2.14 METERS (7.02 FT) WEST-NORTHWEST FROM A BARB WIRE FENCE. STATION RECOVERY (1982)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1982 9.50 KM (5.90 MI) NE FROM PONCE. FROM THE JUNCTION OF HIGHWAY 14 AND 139, WHICH IS ABOUT 4.0 KM (2.5 MI) NORTHEAST OF PONCE, GO NORTH ON HIGHWAY 139 FOR 0.5 KM (0.3 MI) TO A CROSSROAD, TURN RIGHT AND GO EAST AND NORTHERLY ON HIGHWAY 139 FOR 3.2 KM (2.0 MI) TO A FORK LEFT, KEEP RIGHT AND CONTINUE NORTHERLY ON HIGHWAY 139 FOR 3.9 KM (2.4 MI) TO A GATE ON THE LEFT TO THE CORPS OF ENGINEERS LABORATORY, CONTINUE AHEAD ON HIGHWAY 139 FOR 0.2 KM (0.1 MI) TO THE STATION ON THE RIGHT, 32.0 METERS (105.1 FT) NORTH NORTHEAST OF A POWER POLE, 12.5 METERS (40.8 FT) SOUTHEAST FROM THE SOUTHWEST CORNER OF A 7 FOOT HIGH CHAIN LINK FENCE, 2.8 METERS (9.2 FT) EAST SOUTHEAST FROM THE CENTER OF HIGHWAY 139, 3.1 METERS (7.0 FT) WEST-NORTHWEST OF A BARB WIRE FENCE. markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1967 (SCM) THE STATION IS LOCATED ON THE SOUTHWEST EDGE OF ROOSEVELT ROADS NAVAL STATION ON CABRAS ISLAND.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM GATE NUMBER 1 OF ROOSEVELT ROADS NAVAL STATION, GO SOUTHEAST ON TARAWA DRIVE FOR 0.1 MILES TO A FORK.  TAKE THE LEFT FORK AND CONTINUE SOUTHEAST ON TARAWA DRIVE FOR 1.8 MILES TO A FORK.  TAKE THE LEFT FORK AND GO EAST ON FORRESTAL DRIVE FOR 0.7 MILES TO A FORK.  TAKE THE RIGHT FORK AND CONTINUE ON FORRESTAL DRIVE FOR 1.95 MILES TO A FORK.  TAKE THE RIGHT FORK AND GO SOUTHWEST ON A DIRT ROAD FOR 0.3 MILES TO A FORK.  TAKE THE LEFT FORK AND GO SOUTHWEST ON A DIRT ROAD FOR 0.4 MILES TO A SIDE ROAD LEFT.  CONTINUE STRAIGHT AHEAD FOR 0.2 MILES TO A SIDE ROAD LEFT.  CONTINUE STRAIGHT AND DOWN HILL FOR 0.1 MILES AND OFFICERS BEACH ON LEFT.  CONTINUE STRAIGHT AHEAD FOR 0.1 MILES TO TOP OF HILL AND STATION ON THE LEFT.  THE STATION MARK IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED CAB 1967 SET IN THE TOP OF A CONCRETE MONUMENT 6 INCHES IN DIAMETER AND FLUSH WITH THE GROUND.  IT IS 95 FEET EAST OF ISLA CABRES NAVIGATION LIGHT, 41 FEET NORTHWEST OF A CONCRETE BLOCK HOUSE, AND 49 FEET WEST OF AN OLD CONCRETE FOUNDATION.  NO REFERENCE MARKS WERE SET.  THE STATION WAS USED FOR A HI-FIX ANTENNA FOR CONTROLLING HYDROGRAPHY IN VIEQUES PASSAGE.

THIS MASS OF MATERIAL IS SUBJECT TO MOVEMENT AS EVIDENT FROM THE LOCATION OF FORMER STATION WHICH IS NOW UNDER WATER.  STATION MARK IS A STANDARD BRONZE DISK SET IN CONCRETE AS DESCRIBED IN NOTE 1A.  NO REFERENCE MARKS WERE ESTABLISHED.

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1941 (RLS) THIS INTERSECTION STATION IS ABOUT 5 MILES ESE OF CEIBA, ON THE ROOSEVELT ROADS NAVAL RESERVATION, ON A SMALL ISLAND TO THE EASTWARD OF PINEROS ISLAND AND CALLED CABEZA DE PERRO, ABOUT 100 METERS WNW OF THE HIGH-WATER LINE AT THE EXTREME E END OF THE ISLAND.  THE LIGHT IS ON A SQUARE, SKELETON-STEEL STRUCTURE PAINTED RED AND IS SUPPORTED BY A SOLID CONCRETE FOUNDATION. THE LOWER 8 FEET OF THE STEEL STRUCTURE IS ENCLOSED FORMING A SHELTER FOR THE LIGHTING APPARATUS.  THE HEIGHT OF THE STEEL STRUCTURE FROM THE TOP OF THE FOUNDATION TO THE CENTER OF THE LIGHT (AS MEASURED BY THIS PARTY) IS 9.7 METERS (31.8 FEET). THE TOP OF THE FOUNDATION IS 1 METER ABOVE THE GROUND (MEASURED).  THE GROUND ELEVATION AT THE STATION IS ABOUT 55 FEET (FROM RECENT TOPOGRAPHIC SURVEYS).  THIS MAKES THE LIGHT ABOUT 90 FEET ABOVE THE WATER INSTEAD OF 50 FEET AS GIVEN IN THE ABOVE LIGHT LIST DESCRIPTION.  THE TOP OF THE STRUCTURE IS 2 FEET ABOVE THE CENTER OF THE LIGHT.  OBSERVATIONS BY THIS PARTY WERE MADE IN THE DAYTIME ON THE TIP OF THE STRUCTURE WHICH IS DIRECTLY OVER THE CENTER OF THE LIGHT.  THERE IS A SMALL SHACK ON THE W SIDE OF THE LIGHT AND THE REMAINS OF AN OLD FOUNDATION BETWEEN THE SHACK AND THE LIGHT.                            STATION RECOVERY (1964)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1964 (GWM) STATION WAS RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED.

BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1941 (RLS) THE LIGHT AS LOCATED IN 1923 STILL EXISTS APPARENTLY IN ITS ORIGINAL POSITION.  THE LIGHT IS DESCRIBED IN THE 1939 LIGHT LIST AS FOLLOWS--NO.3371.  ON E POINT OF CABEZA DE PERRO ISLAND.  LIGHT 50 FEET ABOVE WATER.  TOP OF LIGHT 30 FEET ABOVE GROUND.  RED SKELETON STRUCTURE.  BUILT IN 1922.                            STATION RECOVERY (1981)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1981 OFFICE NOTE--ACCORDING TO G-16362 COMPUTATIONS, STATION RECOVERED IN 1941 WAS NOT THE 1923 LIGHT.  STATION MUST BE CONSIDERED LOST.  SEE CABEZA DE PERRO LIGHT 1941.

BY US AIR FORCE 1966 (JWC) THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 12 MILES SOUTH OF CABO ROJO, 12-1/2 MILES SOUTHWEST OF LAJAS, ON THE EXTREME SOUTHWEST POINT OF THE ISLAND OF PUERTO RICO AND ON U.S. GOVERNMENT PROPERTY.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE JUNCTION OF HIGHWAYS 103 AND 102 IN CABO ROJO, GO SOUTH ON HIGHWAY 103 FOR 4.95 MILES TO THE JUNCTION WITH HIGHWAY 101.  TURN RIGHT AND GO WESTERLY ON HIGHWAY 101 FOR 0.65 MILE TO A SIDE ROAD ON THE LEFT.  TURN LEFT AND GO SOUTHERLY ON HIGHWAY 301 FOR 2.75 MILES TO THE JUNCTION WITH HIGHWAY 303.  TURN RIGHT AND GO WEST AND SOUTH ON HIGHWAY 301 FOR 2.3 MILES TO A SIDE ROAD ON THE RIGHT AT THE END OF THE PAVEMENT.  CONTINUE SOUTH ON A GRAVELED ROAD FOR 0.25 MILE TO A Y-FORK.  TAKE THE RIGHT FORK AND GO SOUTHWEST AND SOUTH ON A DIRT ROAD FOR 0.7 MILE TO A T-ROAD.  TURN RIGHT AND GO WEST AND SOUTH ON A DIRT ROAD FOR 3.0 MILES TO THE CABO ROJO LIGHTHOUSE AND THE STATION ON THE LEFT.  THE STATION MARK IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED CABO ROJO USAF, SET IN THE TOP OF A 6-INCH SQUARE CONCRETE POST THAT IS FLUSH WITH THE GROUND.  IT IS 36.4 FEET SOUTH OF A FENCE CORNER POST, 34.4 FEET NORTHWEST OF THE NORTHWEST CORNER OF A U.S. COAST GUARD BUILDING AND 26.7 FEET SOUTHWEST OF A MESH WIRE FENCE.  REFERENCE MARK A IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED CABO ROJO RM A, SET IN THE TOP OF A 6-INCH SQUARE CONCRETE POST THAT PROJECTS 3 INCHES.  IT IS 46 FEET EAST OF A FENCE CORNER POST AND 19 FEET NORTHEAST OF THE MESH WIRE FENCE.  REFERENCE MARK B IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED CABO ROJO RM B, SET IN THE TOP OF A 6-INCH SQUARE CONCRETE POST THAT PROJECTS 2 INCHES.  IT IS 38.6 FEET NORTH OF THE NORTHWEST CORNER OF A GARAGE AND 27 FEET WEST OF THE FENCE CORNER POST.  NO AZIMUTH MARK WAS ESTABLISHED.                            STATION RECOVERY (1970)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1970 (KAM) THE STATION AND REFERENCE MARKS WERE RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.  A NEW DESCRIPTION FOLLOWS--THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 12 MILES SOUTH OF THE TOWN OF CABO ROJO, 12-1/2 MILES SOUTHWEST OF LAJAS, ON THE EXTREME SOUTHWEST POINT OF THE ISLAND OF PUERTO RICO, AND ON U.S. COAST GUARD PROPERTY.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE JUNCTION OF HIGHWAYS 103 AND 102 IN CABO ROJO, GO SOUTH ON HIGHWAY 103 FOR 4.95 MILES TO THE JUNCTION WITH HIGHWAY 101.  TURN RIGHT AND GO WESTERLY ON HIGHWAY 101 FOR 0.65 MILES TO A SIDE ROAD ON THE LEFT.  TURN LEFT AND GO SOUTHERLY ON HIGHWAY 301 FOR 2.75 MILES TO THE JUNCTION WITH HIGHWAY 303.  TURN RIGHT AND GO WEST AND SOUTH ON HIGHWAY 301 FOR 2.3 MILES TO A SIDE ROAD ON THE RIGHT.  CONTINUE STRAIGHT AHEAD (SOUTH) ON A DIRT ROAD FOR 0.25 MILES TO A Y FORK.  TAKE THE RIGHT FORK, AND GO SOUTHWEST AND SOUTH ON A DIRT ROAD FOR 0.7 MILES TO A T ROAD AT THE WATERS EDGE.  TURN RIGHT AND FOLLOW THE DIRT ROAD AROUND THE BAY FOR 3.0 MILES TO THE CABO ROJO LIGHTHOUSE, AND THE STATION ON THE LEFT.  THE STATION MARK IS INSIDE THE COMPOUND FENCE NEAR THE NORTH CORNER OF THE COMPOUND.  IT IS ONE FOOT FROM A HEAVY IRON STAKE DRIVEN IN THE GROUND AND PROJECTING ABOUT 6 INCHES.  THE MARK IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED CABO ROJO USAF, SET IN THE TOP OF A 6 INCH SQUARE CONCRETE POST THAT IS FLUSH WITH THE GROUND.  IT IS 36.4 FEET SOUTH OF THE NORTH CORNER POST OF THE COMPOUND, 34.4 FEET NORTHWEST OF THE NORTH CORNER OF THE MAIN, AND LARGEST COAST GUARD BUILDING, AND 26.7 FEET SOUTHWEST OF THE COMPOUND CHAIN LINK FENCE.  REFERENCE MARK A IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED CABO ROJO RM A, SET IN THE TOP OF A 6 INCH SQUARE CONCRETE POST, THAT PROJECTS 3 INCHES.  IT IS 46 FEET SOUTHEAST OF THE NORTH CORNER POST OF THE COMPOUND, AND 19 FEET NORTHEAST OF AND OUTSIDE THE COMPOUND FENCE.  REFERENCE MARK B IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED CABO ROJO RM B, SET IN THE TOP OF A 6 INCH SQUARE CONCRETE POST THAT PROJECTS 2 INCHES.  IT IS 38.6 FEET NORTH OF THE NORTH CORNER OF A GARAGE BUILDING, WHICH IS JUST TO THE LEFT OF THE MAIN GATE OF THE COMPOUND, AND 27 FEET WEST OF THE NORTH CORNER POST OF THE COMPOUND.  NO AZIMUTH MARK WAS ESTABLISHED.                            STATION RECOVERY (1974)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1974 (JDS) THE STATION WAS RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.  REFERENCE MARKS A AND B HAVE APPARENTLY BEEN DESTROYED BY VANDALS.  PIECES OF CONCRETE WERE FOUND IN THE AREA WHERE THE MARKS WERE ORIGINALLY SET.  THE RECOVERY NOTE BY K.A.M. IN 1970 IS ADEQUATE.                            STATION RECOVERY (2005)  RECOVERY NOTE BY UNIVERSITY OF PUERTO RICO AT MAYAGUEZ 2005 MARK NOT FOUND.
markers.setting: SET IN TOP OF CONCRETE MONUMENT
markers.stability: MAY HOLD, BUT OF TYPE COMMONLY SUBJECT TOSURFACE MOTION

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1900 (JN) STATION OCCUPIED ECCENTRICALLY.  THIS BUILDING IS ON THE EXTREME SW POINT OF THE ISLAND OF PUERTO RICO.  IT IS NOT REALLY ON THE MAIN ISLAND, AS A SMALL ARM OF THE SEA WHICH CONNECTS BAHIA SUCIA WITH BAHIA SALINAS MAKES AN ISLET OF THE POINT.  THERE ARE TWO HILLS ON THE ISLAND WHICH ARE CALLED LOS MORRILLOS DE CABO ROJO.  THE LIGHTHOUSE IS ON THE LOWER AND MORE WESTERN MORILLO.  THE LIGHTHOUSE WAS OF THIRD-ORDER IN THE SPANISH CLASSIFICATION AND IS A FINE SUBSTANTIAL STRUCTURE.  ACCORDING TO THE RECORD IN THE KEEPERS OFFICE, THE PRESENT LIGHT WAS FIRST LIT ON AUGUST 20, 1882, AND HAS BEEN IN CONTINUOUS OPERATION SINCE.  THE MAIN BUILDING IS ORIENTED WITH THE LONGER FACE ESE TO WNW.  IT IS RECTANGULAR IN PLAN, 27.70 METERS BY 11.55 METERS, AND ITS MEAN ELEVATION IS 5 METERS IN HEIGHT.  THE BASE IS 23.80 METERS ABOVE SEA LEVEL AND THE FOCUS OF THE LIGHT IS 38.80 METERS ABOVE THE SAME LEVEL.  THE LANTERN RISES FROM THE BASE ON THE FRUSTRUM OF A HEXAGONAL PYRAMID AND IT IS DECAGONAL - LENSES OCTAGONAL.  THE INTERIOR OF THE MAIN TOWER IS CIRCULAR IN SECTION (3.20 METERS IN DIAMETER) AND CONTAINS A SPIRAL CAST-IRON STAIRWAY WHICH LEADS TO THE LIGHT.  THE LITTLE TOWER JUST BELOW THE LAMP ROOM, CONTAINING THE MACHINERY FOR WORKING LAMP AND LENSES, IS 2.5 METERS IN DIAMETER WITH WALLS 0.45 METER THICK.  THE MAIN BUILDING SEEMS TO HAVE A BRICK ROOF.  THIS IS CEMENTED OVER AND SURROUNDED BY A PARAPET SO AS TO CATCH RAIN WATER FOR THE USE OF THE KEEPERS.  MAIN TOWER IS 12.50 METERS FROM TOP OF WEATHER VANE POST TO GROUND.                            STATION RECOVERY (1934)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1934 THIS POINT IS SITUATED ON THE FEDERAL LIGHTHOUSE ON CABO (CAPE) ROJO.  STATION IS THE CENTER POINT OF LIGHT TOWER.  NOTE--COMPUTERS STATE THIS IS SAME AS BOQUERON LIGHTHOUSE (USGS).                            STATION RECOVERY (1968)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1968 (JKW) STATION RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.  THE LIGHT IS NOW AN AUTOMATIC OPERATION.  THE ORIGINAL DESCRIPTION IS ADEQUATE.                            STATION RECOVERY (1974)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1974 (JDS) THE STATION WAS RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED AND FOUND TO BE IN GOOD CONDITION.

BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JWC) THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 1-3/4 MILES SOUTHEAST OF CABO ROJO AND ON THE HIGHEST POINT OF A LOW HILL.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE SOUTHEAST CORNER OF THE PLAZA IN CABO ROJO, GO SOUTHEASTERLY ON HIGHWAY 312 FOR 1.9 MILES TO A SIDE ROAD RIGHT.  TURN RIGHT AND GO SOUTHWEST AND WEST FOR 0.2 MILE TO THE STATION.  THE TOWER IS A FOUR-LEGGED, SELF-SUPPORTING STEEL STRUCTURE, PAINTED ALTERNATELY RED AND WHITE AND IT IS 209 FEET HIGH.  ABOUT MID-WAY OF THE TOWER THERE ARE VARIOUS ANTENNAS THAT PROJECT HORIZONTALLY FROM THE TOWER GIVING IT A MASSIVE AND ODD-APPEARING SHAPE FROM A DISTANCE.  POINT INTERSECTED IS THE RED OBSTRUCTION LIGHT ATOP THE TOWER.

BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1934 STATION LOCATED 7 KILOMETERS BY ROAD AND TRAIL SW OF OROCOVIS, ABOUT 0.5 KILOMETER SE OF SALTO RURAL SCHOOLHOUSE, 200 METERS W OF TIENDA OF CEFERINO BURGOS, ABOUT 30 METERS N OF THE S END OF GRASSY CREST WHICH IS ABOUT 100 METERS IN LENGTH AND 20 METERS WIDE, IT IS 30 METERS N OF THE MAIN TRAIL WHICH CROSSES THE RIDGE.  STATION MARK IS A STANDARD U.S.G.S. TABLET, STAMPED CABRA 1934, CEMENTED IN BOULDER SET IN GROUND WITH TOP FLUSH WITH SURFACE.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 1 IS A COPPER NAIL AND WASHER IN BLAZE IN 2-INCH STUMP 3 FEET HIGH, OF MANTEGUERO BUSH, 38.70 FEET FROM STATION IN TRUE AZIMUTH 136 DEG 26 MIN.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 2 IS COPPER NAIL AND WASHER IN 5-INCH TREE, 156.45 FEET FROM STATION IN TRUE AZIMUTH 156 DEG 44 MIN.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 3 IS WILD ROYAL PALM TREE ON NE SLOPE, 115 FEET FROM STATION IN TRUE AZIMUTH 232 DEG 07 MIN.  SIGNAL--QUADRIPOD OF SAWED LUMBER WITH BLACK CROSS TARGETS ON CENTER POLE.  TO REACH STATION FROM OROCOVIS, FOLLOW THE CARRETERA LEADING TO COAMO AND VILLALBA FOR 5.2 KILOMETERS.  AT PRESENT TIME THIS CARRETERA IS COMPLETED 4.7 KILOMETERS SOUTHWARD FROM OROCOVIS, WITH OLD GRADE CONTINUING.  AT THIS POINT INQUIRE FOR TRAIL LEADING TO SALTO SCHOOLHOUSE, AND FOLLOW THE TRAIL WHICH PASSES CLOSE BY STATION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1954)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1954 (JOP) THE STATION WAS RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED IN 1934.  THE DISK HAD BEEN REMOVED FROM THE BOULDER.  A NEW DISK WAS RESET IN THE DRILL HOLE IN THE BOULDER AND STAMPED CABRA ASTRO 1954.  REFERENCE MARKS 1 AND 2 HAVE BEEN DESTROYED.  THE ROYAL PALM TREE MENTIONED IN THE DESCRIPTION HAS NOT BEEN DISTURBED. A COMPLETE NEW DESCRIPTION--  STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 7 KM. SW OF OROCOVIS, AND ABOUT 0.5 KM. NE OF THE SALTO RURAL SCHOOLHOUSE.  IT IS 100 FT NW OF A ROADBANK, 160 FT. S OF AN E-W FENCE LINE, AND 4.3 FT. S OF AN OUTCROPPING OF BEDROCK WITH A CROSS CUT IN IT.  TO REACH FROM THE SW CORNER OF THE PLAZA IN OROCOVIS, GO S ON HIGHWAY 155 FOR 3.5 MI. TO A SIDE ROAD RIGHT AND A GROCERY STORE ON THE LEFT, TURN RIGHT AND GO 2 KM. TO THE TOP OF A HILL AND A GROCERY STORE ON THE LEFT AND A SIDE ROAD RIGHT, CONTINUE STRAIGHT AHEAD FOR ABOUT 500 YD. TO THE HIGHEST POINT OF A HILL AND THE STATION ON THE RIGHT AS DESCRIBED.                            STATION RECOVERY (1963)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1963 (CFO) THE STATION MARK WAS RECOVERED AND WAS IN GOOD CONDITION (CEMENT AROUND THE DISK LOOKS NEW) AND THE DISK IS STAMPED CABRA ASTRO 1954, NOT 1934.  IT IS 11 PACES NORTH OF A NEW CONCRETE WATER RESERVOIR RECENTLY BUILT ON THE HILL.  REFERENCE MARKS 1, 2 AND 3 HAVE BEEN DESTROYED.  REFERENCE MARK 4 RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED AND IS IN GOOD CONDITION.  IN THE SAME ROCK IS A DRILL HOLE WITH A CHISELED TRIANGLE AROUND SAME.
markers.setting: SET IN A BOULDER
markers.stability: MAY HOLD, BUT OF TYPE COMMONLY SUBJECT TOSURFACE MOTION

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1899 (WCH) STATION IS ON THE HIGHEST GROUND IN THE WESTERN PART OF THE SMALL ISLAND OF CABRAS, ON THE WESTERN SIDE OF SAN JUAN ENTRANCE.  MARKED BY A PIPE SET IN CONCRETE.
markers.setting: UNSPECIFIED SETTING

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1901 (JN) THIS STATION IS SITUATED ON THE HIGHEST GROUND AT THE NW END OF CABRAS ISLAND (LEPER ISLAND) NEAR THE SAN JUAN.  IT IS 18 FEET NE OF THE TOP OF THE SW BANK FORMED BY CORAL ROCK AND 10 FEET SW OF A VERY DEEP FISSURE IN THE CORAL ROCK WHERE IT HAS CRACKED OFF DUE TO THE UNDERWASH OF THE BREAKERS.  IT IS 110 FEET S FROM THE NEAR END OF A WALLED ENCLOSURE (FLOWER GARDEN) AT THE EXTREME NW OF THE ISLAND.  THE STATION IS MARKED BY A BRASS BOLT SET IN A INVERTED PYRAMID OF CEMENT 18 INCHES DEEP AND EXTENDING 2 INCHES ABOVE THE GENERAL SURFACE OF THE GROUND.  THE BOLT EXTENDS FROM THE MOUTH OF A BOTTLE FILLED WITH SAND AND SET HALF WAY DOWN IN THE CEMENT.  THE HEAD OF THE BOLT EXTENDS 1/8 INCH ABOVE THE SURFACE OF THE CEMENT AND THE CENTER OF THE BOLT IS THE POINT.                            STATION RECOVERY (1963)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1963 (CFO) NO EVIDENCE OF THE STATION LOCATED, BELIEVE IT HAS BEEN DESTROYED BY VARIOUS CONSTRUCTION IN THE AREA.
markers.setting: SET IN TOP OF CONCRETE MONUMENT
markers.stability: MAY HOLD, BUT OF TYPE COMMONLY SUBJECT TOSURFACE MOTION

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1926 (GCM) STATION OCCUPIED ECCENTRICALLY AS USUAL.                            STATION RECOVERY (1941)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1941 (RLS) THE LIGHT WAS RE-BUILT IN 1937 (SEE LIGHT LIST).  THE LIGHT BUILT IN 1937 WAS LOCATED BY THIS PARTY.  SEE DESCRIPTION OF CABRAS ISLAND LIGHT.

BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1939 (HAC) ON THE WESTERN HALF OF CABRAS ISLAND, STANDS THE FAIRLY WELL PRESERVED RUINS OF A LARGE MASONRY BUILDING.  IT IS THE LARGEST BUILDING ON THE ISLAND.  POINT OBSERVED UPON WAS THE EXTREME EASTERLY CORNICE OF THE ROOF.  A LARGE AREA HAS BEEN PAINTED RED TO IDENTIFY THIS CORNER.

BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1941 (RLS) THIS IS AN INTERSECTION STATION ON THE ROOSEVELT ROADS NAVAL RESERVATION E OF ENSENADA HONDA, S OF PUERCA BAY, ON CABRAS ISLAND, ABOUT 60 METERS N OF THE SE CORNER OF THE ISLAND AND ABOUT 25 METERS W OF THE E END OF THE ISLAND.  THE LIGHT IS ON A GRAY STONE STRUCTURE ABOUT 45 FEET HIGH.  RISING ABOVE THE E CORNER OF THE MAIN PART OF THE STRUCTURE IS A SMALL, ROUND, STONE TOWER ABOUT 10 FEET HIGH HOLDING THE LIGHT.  THE LIGHT IS ABOUT 50 FEET ABOVE THE GROUND.  THE GROUND ELEVATION AT THE STATION IS ABOUT 21 FEET.  THE LIGHT IS DESCRIBED IN THE 1939 LIGHT LIST AS FOLLOWS-- NO.3373.  ON THE E END OF ISLAND, NW SIDE OF VIOQUES PASSAGE.  LIGHT 77 FEET ABOVE THE WATER.  GRAY, SQUARE, STONE TOWER.  LIGHT 52 FEET ABOVE GROUND.  ESTABLISHED 1908.  RE-BUILT 1937.  OBSERVATIONS BY THIS PARTY WERE MADE IN THE DAYTIME ON THE TIP OF THE STRUCTURE WHICH IS DIRECTLY OVER THE CENTER OF THE LIGHT.                            STATION RECOVERY (1961)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1961 (MLO) STATION WAS RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED.  THE GROUND ELEVATION WAS DETERMINED TO BE 21 FEET.  HEIGHT OF CENTER OF LIGHT ABOVE MEAN HIGH-WATER WAS DETERMINED TO BE 71 FEET.                            STATION RECOVERY (1965)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1965 (MTP) STATION WAS NOT VISITED BUT SEEMS TO BE IN VERY GOOD CONDITION.  LIGHT IS STILL IN USE.                            STATION RECOVERY (1977)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1977 (WFP) STATION DESTROYED DUE TO CONSTRUCTION.  LIGHTHOUSE DISMANTLED.  AIRLINE DISTANCE AND DIRECTION FROM NEAREST TOWN CABRAS ISLAND, ROOSEVELT ROADS NAVAL STATION.

BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JJL) THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 8 MILES NORTH-NORTHWEST OF VILLALBA, 3-1/2 MILES EAST OF JAYUYA, ON THE MOST NORTHERLY ONE OF THREE PEAKS, ON A MOUNTAIN THAT IS LOCALLY KNOWN AS THREE PEAKS.  THE PROPERTY IS OWNED BY MR. OSCAR DEDAZ.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE PLAZA IN JAYUYA, GO SOUTH FOR 0.05 MILE TO A T ROAD.  TURN LEFT AND GO EAST ON HIGHWAY 144 FOR 0.1 MILE.  TURN RIGHT AND GO SOUTHEASTERLY ON HIGHWAY 144 FOR 3.55 MILES TO THE JUNCTION WITH HIGHWAY 539.  TURN LEFT, GO EAST FOR 150 FEET TO A SIDE ROAD LEFT AT THE EAST END OF A CONCRETE BRIDGE.  TURN LEFT AND GO NORTH ON A PAVED ROAD FOR 0.15 MILE TO A FORK.  TAKE THE LEFT FORK AND CONTINUE NORTH FOR 0.25 MILE TO A SIDE ROAD RIGHT.  (A 4-WHEEL DRIVE VEHICLE IS REQUIRED TO REACH THE END OF TRUCK TRAVEL FROM THIS POINT.) TURN RIGHT, PASS THROUGH A SMALL VILLAGE AND GO EAST ON A DIRT ROAD FOR 1.3 MILES TO A DIM TRACK ROAD ON THE RIGHT AND THE END OF TRUCK TRAVEL.  FROM HERE, PACK NORTHEAST ON THE DIM TRACK ROAD FOR 10 MINUTES TO A TRAIL ON THE LEFT.  TURN LEFT AND FOLLOW THE STEEP, SWITCH BACK TRAIL NORTH AND EAST TO THE TOP OF THE MOUNTAIN.  BEAR LEFT AND PACK NORTHERLY ALONG THE CREST OF THE RIDGE, CROSSING TWO PEAKS TO THE STATION ON THE TOP OF THE THIRD PEAK.  NOTE--A 1-1/2 HOUR PACK.  THE STATION MARK IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED CACH 1966, BRAZED TO THE TOP OF A 3-INCH CAST IRON PIPE THAT PROJECTS 3 INCHES.  IT IS LOCATED IN A CLEARED AREA ON THE HIGHEST POINT OF THE HILL.  REFERENCE MARK 1 IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED CACH NO 1 1966, BRAZED TO THE TOP OF A 3-INCH CAST IRON PIPE THAT PROJECTS 4 INCHES AND IS 1 FOOT LOWER IN ELEVATION THAN THE STATION MARK.  REFERENCE MARK 2 IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED CACH NO 2 1966, BRAZED TO THE TOP OF A 3-INCH CAST IRON PIPE THAT PROJECTS 4 INCHES AND IS THE SAME ELEVATION AS THE STATION MARK.  NO SUITABLE PLACE WAS FOUND FOR AN AZIMUTH MARK.
markers.setting: SET INTO TOP OF METAL PIPE DRIVEN INTO GROUND
markers.stability: MARK OF QUESTIONABLE OR UNKNOWN STABILITY

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JWC) THE STATION IS LOCATED 9 AIRLINE MILES NORTHWEST OF MAYAGUEZ, 7 AIRLINE MILES WEST-NORTHWEST OF ANASCO, 3-1/2 AIRLINE MILES SOUTH-SOUTHEAST OF RINCON AND ON THE TOP OF A LOW GRASS COVERED HILL.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE PLAZA IN RINCON, GO SOUTHWEST AND SOUTHEAST ON HIGHWAY 115 FOR 1.75 MILES TO A SIDE ROAD RIGHT AT KILOMETER POST 10.8.  TURN RIGHT AND GO SOUTHWEST ON A PAVED ROAD FOR 0.2 MILE TO A CROSSROAD.  TURN LEFT AND GO SOUTHEAST ON HIGHWAY 429 FOR 1.2 MILES TO A TRAIL ON THE LEFT AT KILOMETER POST 2.3 AND END OF TRUCK TRAVEL.  FROM HERE PACK NORTHEAST UPHILL BETWEEN TWO HOUSES FOR ABOUT 10 MINUTES TO THE TOP OF THE FIRST LOW HILL AND THE STATION.  THE STATION MARK IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED CADENA 1966, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN OUTCROPPING BEDROCK WHICH IS FLUSH WITH THE SURFACE.  REFERENCE MARK 1 IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED CADENA NO 1 1966, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN OUTCROPPING BEDROCK WHICH IS FLUSH WITH THE SURFACE.  REFERENCE MARK 2 IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED CADENA NO 2 1966, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN OUTCROPPING BEDROCK WHICH PROJECTS 1 INCH.  NO AZIMUTH MARK WAS ESTABLISHED AT THIS STATION.                            STATION RECOVERY (2000)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US POWER SQUADRON 2000 (RVH) MARK NOT FOUND.                            STATION RECOVERY (2004)  RECOVERY NOTE BY UNIVERSITY OF PUERTO RICO AT MAYAGUEZ 2004 (AAB) MARK NOT FOUND.
markers.setting: SET IN ROCK OUTCROP
markers.stability: MOST RELIABLE AND EXPECTED TO HOLDPOSITION/ELEVATION WELL

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1965 (JJL) THE STATION IS LOCATED IN THE NORTHEAST SECTION OF CAGUAS AT THE JUAN PONCE DE LEON NATIONAL GUARD ARMORY AND APPROXIMATELY 200 FEET SOUTHEAST OF THE ENTRANCE TO THE ARMORY BUILDING.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE POST OFFICE IN CAGUAS, GO NORTHERLY ON HIGHWAY 1 FOR 0.05 MILE TO A SIDE ROAD ON THE RIGHT, HIGHWAY 30, TURN RIGHT ON HIGHWAY 30 AND GO 0.3 MILE TO THE NATIONAL GUARD ARMORY ON THE LEFT AND THE STATION.  THE STATION IS 61 FEET NORTH OF THE APPROXIMATE CENTER OF HIGHWAY 30, 13 FEET WEST OF A FENCE CORNER, 8 FEET SOUTH OF THE END OF A CONCRETE SIDEWALK AND 8 FEET SOUTHWEST OF THE CORNER OF A WIRE FENCE WITH CONCRETE POST.  IT IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED CAGUAS 1965 AND SET IN A 12 INCH ROUND CONCRETE MONUMENT FLUSH WITH THE GROUND.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 1 IS 28 FEET NORTH OF THE APPROXIMATE CENTER OF HIGHWAY 30 AND 2-1/2 FEET NORTHWEST OF THE SOUTHEAST END OF A CONCRETE CURB.  IT IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED CAGUAS NO 1 1965 AND SET IN A 12 INCH ROUND CONCRETE MONUMENT FLUSH WITH THE GROUND.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 2 IS 82 FEET NORTHEAST OF KILOMETER POST 0.7, 61 FEET NORTH OF THE APPROXIMATE CENTER OF HIGHWAY 30, 55 FEET EAST OF THE APPROXIMATE CENTER OF THE ENTRANCE TO A SMALL PARKING AREA AND 10-1/2 FEET SOUTH OF THE NORTH EDGE OF THE CONCRETE SIDEWALK.  IT IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED CAGUAS NO 2 1965 AND SET IN A 12 INCH ROUND CONCRETE MONUMENT FLUSH WITH THE GROUND.
markers.setting: SET IN TOP OF CONCRETE MONUMENT
markers.stability: MAY HOLD, BUT OF TYPE COMMONLY SUBJECT TOSURFACE MOTION

markers.description: BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1934 STATION IS A WHITE SLENDER SPIRE ON OUTSKIRTS TO S OF CAGUAS.  NO CHECK ON THIS POSITION.

BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1940 THE TOP OF THE SPIRE SURMOUNTING THE TOWER OF THE JOSE J. ALVAREZ SCHOOL, IN THE SE PART OF CAGUAS.  THE BUILDING IS NEW AND OF CONCRETE PAINTED YELLOW, AND IS CLOSE TO THE MUNICIPAL HOSPITAL.  THE TOWER APPEARS TO BE MADE UP OF FOUR DECKS OF DECREASING DIAMETER GOING UP, CENTERED ON A HEAVY MAST.

BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 2019 STATION IS A GPS CORS.  LATEST INFORMATION INCLUDING POSITIONS AND VELOCITIES ARE AVAILABLE IN THE COORDINATE AND LOG FILES ACCESSIBLE BY ANONYMOUS FTP OR THE WORLDWIDE WEB.    https://geodesy.noaa.gov/corsdata/coord/coord_14     https://geodesy.noaa.gov/corsdata/station_log     https://geodesy.noaa.gov/CORS
markers.marker: _MARKER: STATION IS THE ANTENNA REFERENCE POINT OF THE GPS ANTENNA

markers.description: MENT IS ASSOCIATED WITH CORS SITE 'MIPR' LATEST INFORMATION INCLUDING POSITIONS AND VELOCITIES ARE AVAILABLE IN THE COORDINATE AND LOG FILES ACCESSIBLE BY ANONYMOUS FTP OR THE WORLDWIDE WEB.    https://geodesy.noaa.gov/corsdata/coord/coord_14    https://geodesy.noaa.gov/corsdata/station_log    https://geodesy.noaa.gov/CORS RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED.

BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1939 LOCATED ABOUT 2 KMS. SE OF THE TOWN OF CANOVANAS, ON LAND OWNED BY MR. RAFAEL CALDERON, ON THE MOST PROMINENT POINT OF A RIDGE RUNNING ALMOST PARALLEL TO RD. AT KM. 20.  THE HILL IS COVERED WITH ELEPHANT GRASS ON THE N SIDE AND WITH BRUSH ON THE S SIDE.  APPROACHED FROM CANOVANS BY RD. 3 TO KM. 20.05, THEN S ALONG CANE RD. PASSING FIRST A T-RD. TO W AND A Y-RD. FORK TO SE CONTINUING ON E SIDE OF DRAIN TO FOOT OF STATION HILL.  STATION MARK--STANDARD TABLET STAMPED CALDERON 1939 CEMENTED TO NATURAL ROCK ALMOST FLUSH WITH GROUND ON HIGH POINT AND ABOUT 6 METERS N OF BRUSH LINE.  SIGNAL--POLE WITH WHITE AND BLACK CROSS TARGETS CENTERED OVER STATION MARK.  R.M. NO. 1--HOLE DRILLED ON ROCK 5.7 METERS W OF STATION.  R.M. NO. 2--HOLE DRILLED ON ROCK 1.8 METERS NE OF STATION.  INSTRUMENT CENTERED OVER STATION MARK.
markers.setting: SET IN UNSPECIFIED ROCK OR BOULDER
markers.stability: PROBABLY HOLD POSITION/ELEVATION WELL

markers.description: BY LOCAL ENGINEER (INDIVIDUAL OR FIRM) 1965 (JJL) STATION ESTABLISHED BY PRS.  THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 5 MILES WEST-NORTHWEST OF LUQUILLO, 3-1/2 MILES EAST-NORTHEAST OF RIO GRANDE AND ON THE HIGHEST POINT OF A LOW, ROCKY, BRUSH COVERED HILL LOCALLY KNOWN AS CORRO BRAVO.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE JUNCTION OF HIGHWAY 3 AND ROAD 968 AT MAMEYES (PALMER), GO NORTH AND WEST ON ROAD 968 FOR 2.35 MILES TO A SIDE ROAD LEFT AND A WIRE GATE ON THE LEFT.  TURN LEFT, PASS THROUGH THE GATE AND GO WESTERLY ON THE TRACK ROAD FOR ABOUT 25 YARDS TO THE AZIMUTH MARK ON THE RIGHT, NORTHEAST, SIDE OF THE ROAD IN A LARGE BOULDER.  CONTINUE AHEAD IN A WESTERLY DIRECTION ON THE TRACK ROAD FOR 0.1 MILE TO THE CREST OF THE RIDGE AND THE END OF TRUCK TRAVEL.  PACK NORTHWESTERLY ALONG THE ROCKY, BRUSHY RIDGE FOR ABOUT 1/8 MILE TO THE HIGHEST POINT OF A LOW BRUSH COVERED HILL AND THE STATION.  NOTE--A 10 MINUTE PACK.  THE STATION MARK, ESTABLISHED BY THE PUERTO RICO DEPARTMENT OF PUBLIC WORKS, IS A CENTER PUNCHED RAILROAD SPIKE CEMENTED IN A 2-INCH, STEEL PIPE THAT PROJECTS 2 INCHES ABOVE THE SURFACE OF THE GROUND.  REFERENCE MARK 1 IS A STANDARD DISK, STAMPED CAMEZON NO 1 1965, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A LARGE BOULDER THAT PROJECTS 4 FEET.  REFERENCE MARK 2 IS A STANDARD DISK, STAMPED CAMEZON NO 2 1965, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A BOULDER THAT PROJECTS 2 FEET.  THE AZIMUTH MARK IS A STANDARD DISK, STAMPED CAMEZON 1965, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A LARGE BOULDER THAT PROJECTS 3 FEET.  IT IS 37.4 FEET SOUTHWEST OF THE FENCE LINE AND 12 FEET NORTHEAST OF THE APPROXIMATE CENTER OF THE TRACK ROAD.
markers.setting: UNSPECIFIED SETTING

markers.description: BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1926 (GCM) ON HIGHEST POINT OF GRASSY HILL ABOUT ONE MILE E OF GUAYAMA AND 1/2 MILE OF THE CARRETERA.  HILL IS ABOUT 700 FEET HIGH AND HIGH POINT IS CLOSER TO N SLOPE.  STATION IS MARKED BY A 3/4-INCH ROD ABOUT 3 FEET LONG, PROJECTING ABOUT 9 INCHES ABOVE THE NATURAL SURFACE, BUT WITH STONES PILED AROUND IT TO THE LEVEL OF HIGH POINT.  THIS IS THE ORIGINAL U.S. GEOLOGICAL SURVEY MARK.  HEIGHT OF SIGNAL ABOVE STATION MARK - 3 METERS.
markers.setting: METAL ROD DRIVEN INTO GROUND. SEE TEXT FOR ADDITIONAL
markers.stability: MARK OF QUESTIONABLE OR UNKNOWN STABILITY

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1941 (RLS) ON THE ROOSEVELT ROADS NAVAL RESERVATION, ABOUT 400 METERS W OF THE NW END OF THE PROPOSED LOCATING OF THE DRY DOCK IN PUERCA BAY, IN THE CONSTRUCTION CAMP AREA, 6.2 METERS S OF THE E CORNER OF THE CONSTRUCTION CAMP RECREATION HALL, AND ABOUT 240 METERS SW OF THE EXTENSION OF THE PROPOSED CENTER LINE OF THE DRY DOCK.  THE LINE BETWEEN THIS STATION AND STATION KID IS AT RIGHT ANGLES TO THE CENTER LINE OF THE DRY DOCK.  THE MARK IS ABOUT FLUSH WITH THE GROUND.  THE DISK IS UNSTAMPED.  SURFACE MARK IS A STANDARD DISK SET IN CONCRETE, AS DESCRIBED IN NOTE 1A.  THE ELEVATION OF THE STATION IS ABOUT 68.7 FEET.  NO UNDERGROUND OR REFERENCE MARKS WERE SET.                            STATION RECOVERY (1961)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1961 (MLO) STATION RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED EXCEPT THAT THE CONSTRUCTION CAMP RECREATION HALL HAS BEEN REMOVED.  A STEEL PIPE TRIPOD AND CENTERPOLE WITH LEGS IMBEDDED IN CONCRETE IS CENTERED OVER THE MARK.  THE STATION IS 7.5 METERS WEST OF THE CENTERLINE OF A ROAD LEADING DOWN HILL.
markers.setting: SET IN TOP OF CONCRETE MONUMENT
markers.stability: MAY HOLD, BUT OF TYPE COMMONLY SUBJECT TOSURFACE MOTION

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JWC) THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 7 MILES NORTHEAST OF MANATI, 4 MILES NORTHWEST OF VEGA BAJA AND 50 YARDS NORTH OF THE CAMP TORTUGUERO AIRPORT RUNWAY.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE JUNCTION OF HIGHWAYS 2 AND 686 IN VEGA BAJA, GO NORTH AND WEST ON HIGHWAY 686 FOR 4.5 MILES TO A CROSSROAD.  TURN RIGHT AND GO NORTH FOR 0.3 MILE TO THE STATION.  THE MAST IS A STEEL-TRUSS STRUCTURE, PAINTED ALTERNATELY RED AND WHITE, SUPPORTED BY GUY WIRES AND IT HAS TWO REFLECTOR SCREENS ATOP.  THE MAST IS ABOUT 75 FEET HIGH.  POINT INTERSECTED IS THE RED OBSTRUCTION LIGHT ATOP THE MAST.

BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1941 V. A. ELEVATION 102.61 METERS.  STATION IS IN THE NORTH CENTRAL PART OF VIEQUES ISLAND ABOUT 1 KM. SOUTH OF THE COAST, 5 KMS. EAST OF ISABEL II AND ABOUT 1/2 KM. NW OF COMPANA FARMHOUSE.  STATION MARK IS A STANDARD TABLET STAMPED CAMPANA 1941 SET IN ROCK.  R.M. NO. 1.  DRILL HOLE IN FLAT ROCK 5.13 METERS FROM STATION.  PLANE AZIMUTH 35-20.  R.M. NO. 2.  DRILL HOLE IN FLAT ROCK 2.14 METERS FROM STATION.  PLANE AZIMUTH 263-21.  TO REACH FROM ISABEL II DRIVE EAST ABOUT 7-1/2 KM. TO COMPANA FARMHOUSE.  TAKE TRAIL NORTH TO SADDLE THEN SW TO TOP AND STATION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1964)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1964 (GWM) STATION RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED.  NO R.M.S FOUND.  THE STATION IS LOCATED NW OF RANGE 4 ON CAMP GARCIA, ATOP THE HIGHEST HILL.  THE OLD FARM HOUSE IS NOW IN RUINS.                            STATION RECOVERY (1965)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1965 (JMC) STATION MARK RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.  LOCATED NE OF RANGE 3, CAN BE DRIVEN TO WITH A 4 WHEEL DRIVE VEHICLE.                            STATION RECOVERY (1965)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1965 (MTP) STATION RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED.  STATION MARK IS IN GOOD CONDITION AND CAN BE REACHED BY CLIMBING TO HIGHEST WEST OF CAMP GARCIA RANGE 4.  THE HIGHEST PART IS ABOUT IN THE MIDDLE OF THE RIDGE THAT RUNS NORTH-SOUTH.                            STATION RECOVERY (1970)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US MARINE CORPS 1970 STATION RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.  IT IS IN THE NORTH CENTRAL PART OF VIEQUES ISLAND AND ON THE SOUTHWEST PART OF THE TOP OF A HILL CALLED CERRO DEL MUERTO.  ROUTE FROM USMC DIVISION CAMP--TAKE RANGE CONTROL AND TURN NNW ON ROAD HAVING SIGN RANGE 3, PROCEED TO WITHIN 100 FEET OF MACHINE GUN RANGE, TURN EAST AND FOLLOW RIDGE TO TOP.  DISTANCE FROM DIVISION CAMP IS 5 MILES.
markers.setting: SET IN UNSPECIFIED ROCK OR BOULDER
markers.stability: PROBABLY HOLD POSITION/ELEVATION WELL

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1941 (RLS) ABOUT 400 METERS SW OF THE TOWN OF DAGUAO, ABOUT 290 METERS S OF THE AMERICAN RAILROAD BRIDGE OVER THE DAGUAO RIVER, ON TOP OF THE FIRST HILL S OF THE DAGUAO RIVER AND SE OF THE AMERICAN RAILROAD, ABOUT 30 METERS NW OF THE HIGHEST POINT OF THE HILL, AND 6 METERS NE OF THE NE SIDE OF A LANE THROUGH THE CANE, WITHIN THE PROPOSED LIMITS OF ROOSEVELT ROADS NAVAL RESERVATION.  THE MARK PROJECTS 2 INCHES ABOVE THE GROUND.  THE ELEVATION OF THE STATION IS ABOUT 75.1 METERS.  STATION AND REFERENCE MARK NO. 2 ARE STANDARD BRONZE DISKS SET IN CONCRETE, AS DESCRIBED IN NOTES 1A AND 11A.  THERE IS NO UNDERGROUND MARK.  REFERENCE MARK NO.1 IS 2 METERS SW OF THE SW SIDE OF THE LANE THROUGH THE SUGAR CANE, A STANDARD DISK SET IN CONCRETE IN A DEPRESSION IN A BOULDER PROJECTING ABOUT 30 INCHES ABOVE GROUND.  THE MARK IS ABOUT 24 INCHES ABOVE THE GROUND ON THE SE SIDE OF THE HIGHEST POINT OF THE BOULDER.  THE MARK IS 0.32 METER HIGHER THAN THE STATION.  REFERENCE MARK NO.2 IS AT THE NE EDGE OF THE NEARLY FLAT TOP OF THE HILL AND 0.24 METER LOWER THAN THE STATION.  THE MARK PROJECTS 3 INCHES ABOVE GROUND.                            STATION RECOVERY (1958)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1958 STATION WAS DESTROYED BY EARTH REMOVAL FROM TOP OF HILL.                            STATION RECOVERY (1961)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1961 (MLO) STATION AND REFERENCE MARKS WERE SEARCHED FOR BUT NOT RECOVERED.  THERE HAS BEEN CONSIDERABLE GRADING ON THIS HILL AND IT IS BELIEVED THAT ALL MARKS HAVE BEEN DESTROYED.
markers.setting: SET IN TOP OF CONCRETE MONUMENT
markers.stability: MAY HOLD, BUT OF TYPE COMMONLY SUBJECT TOSURFACE MOTION

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JWC) THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 3 MILES SOUTH OF GUANICA ON A POINT OF LAND THAT IS ON THE EAST EDGE OF THE BAHIA DE GUANICA.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE NORTHWEST CORNER OF THE PLAZA IN GUANICA, GO WEST ON A PAVED RAOD FOR 0.35 MILE TO THE JUNCTION WITH HIGHWAY 116.  TURN RIGHT AND GO NORTHEAST ON HIGHWAY 116 FOR 0.25 MILE TO A SIDE ROAD ON THE RIGHT.  TURN RIGHT AND GO SOUTH AND EAST ON A PAVED ROAD FOR 2.35 MILES TO A REVERSE Y-FORK.  TURN SHARP RIGHT AND GO SOUTHWEST ON A TRACK ROAD FOR 0.05 MILE TO THE STATION.  THE TOWER IS A STEEL STRUCTURE, PAINTED WHITE IN COLOR AND IS SELF SUPPORTING.  THE POINT INTERSECTED WAS THE FLASHING, WHITE LIGHT ATOP AND CENTER.                            STATION RECOVERY (1970)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1970 (JKW) STATION WAS RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.  THE DESCRIPTION BY JCW IN 1966 IS STILL ACCURATE BUT A NEW TO REACH IS AS FOLLOWS--  FROM THE INTERSECTION OF PUERTO RICO HIWAYS 116 AND 333, TRAVEL SOUTH ON HIWAY 333 FOR A DISTANCE OF 2.35 MILES TO A POINT WHERE THE ABANDONED GUANICA LIGHTHOUSE IS ON THE LEFT AND A TRACK ROAD ON THE RIGHT.  MAKE A SHARP RIGHT ONTO THE TRACK ROAD AND CONTINUE .05 MILE TO THE STATION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1971)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1971 (EKM) STATION RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION AS DESCRIBED.

BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1899 (WCH) THIS STATION IS ONE OF THE SPANISH STATIONS AND WAS OCCUPIED BY THEM IN 1898.  IT IS SITUATED UPON A BARE HILL, WITH THE EXCEPTION OF A FEW SCATTERING TREES, ABOUT 1-1/2 MILES E OF THE TOWN OF JUANA DIAZ AND ABOUT 1/2 MILE N OF THE MILITARY ROAD.  IT IS 1/2 MILE E OF A HIGHER AND MORE CONSPICUOUS HILL WHICH IS BARE ON THE S SLOPE AND WOODED ON THE NORTHERN.  STATION WAS MARKED BY A PIECE OF 3- BY 4-INCH PITCH-PINE STAKE 18 INCHES LONG.  A TACK IN THE TOP MARKS THE CENTER.  THE SIGNAL HILL IS ABOUT 700 FEET HIGH.                            STATION RECOVERY (1930)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1930 (GM) STATION RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED.  IT IS NOW MARKED BY A 2-INCH PIPE EMBEDDED IN CONCRETE.                            STATION RECOVERY (1934)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1934 FOUND IN GOOD CONDITION APPARENTLY UNDISTURBED.  A 2-INCH PIPE USED AS MARK FOR STATION WAS REINFORCED BY CONCRETE AND A STANDARD TABLET (BENCH MARK) SET ON TOP, NOT STAMPED.  A QUADRIPOD WAS BUILT OVER THE STATION.
markers.setting: SET INTO TOP OF METAL PIPE DRIVEN INTO GROUND
markers.stability: MARK OF QUESTIONABLE OR UNKNOWN STABILITY

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1901 (JEM) STATION IS ON A HIGH BARE-TOPPED HILL, N OF THE ROAD FROM HUMACAO TO YABUCOA, AND OF THE HOUSE OF DON ULISIO PARADES AND THE SCHOOLHOUSE OF THE BARRIO CANDELERO ARRIBA.  THE HOUSE AND SCHOOLHOUSE JUST REFERRED TO ARE ON THE N SIDE OF THE HIGHWAY.  THIS HILL IS THE HIGHEST BARE-TOPPED HILL IN THE VICINITY OF THE BUILDINGS AND IS ABOUT 3/4 MILE FROM THEM.  THE HILL IS THE PROPERTY OF SENOR PABLO SERRANO, WHO LIVES IN A COUPLE OF STRAW-COVERED SHACKS BELOW THE SIGNAL, AND BETWEEN IT AND THE HIGH ROAD.  THESE SHACKS ARE VERY NEAR THE SIGNAL, BEING ON THE N FLANK OF THE FIRST HILL (A LOWER ONE) WHICH IS E OF CANDELERO HILL.  BACK OF CANDELERO HILL IS A HIGHER RANGE OF HILLS, BUT ON ALL THEIR SUMMITS TREES ARE GROWING. THIS HILL HAS NOT EVEN A BUSH ON SUMMIT OR SIDES.  ON THE SUMMIT IS A SMALL SPACE GIVEN TO GRASS, BUT ON THE SIDES THE CASSAVA PLANT HAS BEEN PLANTED.  STATION MARK IS A TWO-INCH (DIAMETER) IRON PIPE 12 INCHES LONG.  THIS WAS SET IN THE GROUND UNTIL ABOUT 1/3 INCH WAS EXPOSED.  IT WAS CEMENTED INTO PLACE AND THE INTERIOR OF THE PIPE WAS FILLED WITH CEMENT.  IN THE CEMENT (IN THE PIPE) A NAIL WAS EMBEDDED (IN THE CENTER) THE MIDDLE OF THE NAIL HEAD IS THE STATION CENTER.  IN DIGGING IT DEVELOPED THAT THE SOIL OF THE HILLTOP IS ALMOST 3/4 SAND.  TO REACH COMING FROM HUMACAO, AFTER PASSING THE SCHOOLHOUSE TAKE THE FIRST TRAIL LEADING OFF THE MAIN ROAD TOWARDS THE RIGHT.  THE TRAIL GOES IN STRAIGHT TO PABLO SERRANOS SHACKS AND RUNS THENCE UP ALONG THE S FACE OF CANDELERO HILL.  A FAIR HORSE CAN BE RIDDEN ALL THE WAY TO THE SUMMIT.
markers.setting: SET INTO TOP OF METAL PIPE DRIVEN INTO GROUND
markers.stability: MARK OF QUESTIONABLE OR UNKNOWN STABILITY

markers.description: BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1934 STATION IS A WHITE QUADRIPOD.

BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1964 (GWM) STATION IS LOCATED ON THE N COAST OF PUERTO RICO, ABOUT 10 MILES E OF SAN JUAN, AND 1 MILE W OF POINT MALDANADO.  THE POINT IS CALLED CANGREJOS.  THE STATION IS A STANDARD TRIANGULATION DISK, STAMPED CANGREJO 1964, SET IN A DRILLED HOLE IN A CONCRETE PIER.  10.95 FT. E OF THE W END OF THE PIER, 36.3 FT. E OF A CLIFF, 8 FT. N OF S EDGE OF PIER, 7.35 FT S OF N END OF PIER.  TO REACH FROM CANGREJOS YACHT CLUB ON HWY. 187, PROCEED E FOR .1 MILE CROSSING BRIDGE TO DIRT ROAD LEFT.  TURN LEFT AND GO N FOR .15 MILE TO CONCRETE ROAD LEFT.  TURN LEFT AND CONTINUE TO BEACH, PIER, AND STATION.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 1 IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED CANGREJO RM NO 1 1964 SET IN A DRILLED HOLE IN A CONCRETE WALL, 0.9 FT. NE OF SW CORNER, 45 FT. NW OF THE CLIFF.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 2 IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED CANGREJO RM NO 2 1964, SET IN A DRILLED HOLE IN A CONCRETE WALL, 11 FT. NE OF EXTENDED CENTERLINE OF CONCRETE ROAD, 3 FT. NE OF A 3IN. FIR TREE, 2 FT. SW OF THE CLIFF.  NO AZIMUTH MARK WAS ESTABLISHED.
markers.setting: SET IN THE ABUTMENT OR PIER OF A LARGE BRIDGE
markers.stability: PROBABLY HOLD POSITION/ELEVATION WELL

markers.description: BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 2002 (JMW) IN CANOVANAS AT THE JCT OF HIGHWAY 3 AND THE MAIN ENTRANCE TO THE VILLAS DE LOIZA SHOPPING CENTER.  IT IS 44.9 M NORTHEAST OF THE CENTER OF THE WEST BOUND LANES OF THE HIGHWAY, 35.5 M SOUTHEAST OF THE CENTER OF THE ENTRANCE, 6.5 M NORTHWEST OF A WITNESS POST AND STREET LAMP BASE, 6.1 M SOUTHEAST OF A STREET LAMP, 5.0 M NORTHEAST OF THE CENTER OF A MARGINAL STREET, 2.2 M SOUTHWEST OF THE CENTER OF A SIDEWALK, AND 0.2 M ABOVE THE LEVEL OF THE STREET.  NOTE-ACCESS TO THE DATUM POINT IS THRU A 5-INCH LOGO CAP,   THE SLEEVE DEPTH DOSE NOT MEET CLASS A REQUIRMENTS, OWNERSHIP--THE MARK IS LOCATED ON CITY STREET RIGHT OF WAY.                            STATION RECOVERY (2009)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 2009 MARQTEK ENGINEERING.                            STATION RECOVERY (2012)  RECOVERY NOTE BY POLYTECHNIC UNIVERSITY OF PUERTO RICO 2012 (LSA) TO REACH THE STATION, GO WEST ON HIGHWAY 3 0.8 MILES (1.31 KM) FROM THE JUNCTION OF HIGHWAY 3 AND HIGHWAY 66 (EXIT OF THE BELTZ FACTORY OUTLET) TO THE JUNCTION OF HIGHWAY 3 AND THE ENTRANCE OF THE VILLAS DE LOIZA SHOPPING CENTER.  TURN LEFT AT THE STOPLIGHT AND AT 70 M TURN RIGHT TO THE MARGINAL STREET.  THE STATION IS AT 39.49 M AT THE NORTH SIDE OF THE PLANTING AREA OF THE MARGINAL STREET, 0.59 M SOUTHWEST FROM THE EDGE OF THE SIDEWALK, 1.19 M NORTHEAST FROM THE NORTH SIDE OF THE MARGINAL CURB, 5.67 M SOUTHWEST FROM A CONCRETE LIGHTING POLE LABELED L-33, 17.32 M SOUTHEAST FROM THE SOUTHWEST CORNER OF A BUILDING (FORMERLY BASKING ROBINS).  THE STATION IS A STAINLESS STEEL ROD W/O SLEEVE (10 FT.+. ACESS TO THE DATUM POINT IS THRU A 5-INCH LOGO CAP.                            STATION RECOVERY (2013)  RECOVERY NOTE BY POLYTECHNIC UNIVERSITY OF PUERTO RICO 2013 (LG) RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED
markers.setting: STAINLESS STEEL ROD W/O SLEEVE (10 FT.+)
markers.stability: PROBABLY HOLD POSITION/ELEVATION WELL

markers.description: BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1934 STATION IS CROSS ON CHURCH STEEPLE IN VILLAGE OF CANOVANAS (SHOWN ON SOME MAPS AS LOIZA NUEVA).                            STATION RECOVERY (1941)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1941 (GBG) RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED.                            STATION RECOVERY (1964)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1964 (GWM) ORIGINAL DESCRIPTION IS ADEQUATE.
BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1899 (WCH) THE STATION IS THE FLAGSTAFF, NEAR THE CENTER OF THE SMALL FORT NAMED CANUELO, ON THE W SIDE OF SAN JUAN ENTRANCE.

BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1922 THIS STATION IS ABOUT 4.1 KILOMETERS S 77 DEG 49 MIN E OF THE TOWN OF ISABELA, ON A BARE KNOLL OVERLOOKING THE OCEAN AND ABOUT 3/4 KILOMETERS FROM THE COAST.  IT IS ABOUT 865 METERS N OF THE CARRETERA AND 230 METERS N OF THE RAILROAD AT A POINT WHERE IT EMERGES FROM THE E END OF A DEEP ROCK CUT AND ENTERS THE HEAD OF A DEEP SHORT CANYON.  THE POINT ON WHICH THE STATION IS LOCATED LIES BETWEEN THIS CANYON AND THE OCEAN.  IT IS ON THE N SLOPE OF THE HIGHEST POINT OF THE HILL, AND 75 METERS SW FROM THE POINT OF A SPUR FROM THE MAIN RIDGE, 23 METERS W OF A N-S LINE OF HEDGE AND BRUSH, ON LAND OWNED BY JAIME ABRAMS ALVAREZ.  THE STATION IS MARKED BY A STANDARD U.S.G.S. BRONZE TABLET CEMENTED IN A NATURAL HOLE IN OUTCROPPING LIMESTONE, AND IS ABOUT 7 CENTIMETERS BELOW THE GENERAL SURFACE OF THE ROCK.  REFERENCE MARK NO.1, IS A DRILL HOLE IN A LIMESTONE OUTCROP 10.55 METERS DISTANT ON A TRUE AZIMUTH OF 129 DEG 28 MIN 02 SEC.  REFERENCE MARK NO.2, IS A DRILL HOLE IN A LIMESTONE OUTCROP 5.64 METERS DISTANT ON A TRUE AZIMUTH OF 219 DEG 24 MIN 06 SEC.  ELEVATION ABOVE SEA LEVEL IS - 77.1 METERS.                            STATION RECOVERY (1959)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1959 (MM) THE STATION WAS LOCATED AS DESCRIBED AND WAS IN GOOD CONDITION.  THE 4 REFERENCE POINTS WERE MARKED BY STEEL PINS CEMENTED INTO LIMESTONE AND DATED 1957 WERE FOUND INSTEAD OF THE 2 DRILL HOLES AS DESCRIBED IN THE STATION DESCRIPTION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1964)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US NAVY 1964 THE STATION WAS RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.  TO REACH FROM THE TOWN OF ISABELA GO E ON ROUTE 113 TO ROAD MARKER K4/H0, TURN LEFT ON DIRT ROAD JUST PAST ROAD MARKER AND PROCEED 0.4 MILE TO SHARP BEND TO LEFT.  PARK HERE.  FROM THIS POINT GO N80 DEG E FOR APPROXIMATELY 500 YARDS THRU PASTURE LAND TO TOP OF HILL AND STATION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1966)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JWC) THE STATION MARK WAS RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED AND FOUND TO BE IN GOOD CONDITION.  THE DRILL HOLES DESCRIBED AS REFERENCE MARKS 1 AND 2 ARE NOW MARKED WITH CENTER PUNCHED STEEL PINS AND A REFERENCE MARK 3 OF THIS SAME TYPE WAS LOCATED.  AN ADDITIONAL REFERENCE MARK 1 WAS ESTABLISHED.  A COMPLETE NEW DESCRIPTION FOLLOWS.  THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 4 MILES NORTHWEST OF QUEBRADILLAS, 2-1/2 MILES EAST OF ISABELA AND ON A LOW GRASS COVERED KNOLL SOUTH OF A DEEP ROCK CANYON.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE JUNCTION OF HIGHWAY 2 AND HIGHWAY 485 ON THE EAST SIDE OF QUEBRADILLAS, GO NORTHWEST AND WEST ON HIGHWAY 2 FOR 4.6 MILES TO A SIDE ROAD RIGHT AT KILOMETER POST 108.  TURN RIGHT AND GO NORTH ON HIGHWAY 446 FOR 0.7 MILE TO A T-ROAD.  TURN LEFT AND GO WEST ON HIGHWAY 113 FOR 0.25 MILE TO A SIDE ROAD RIGHT.  TURN RIGHT AND GO NORTH ON THE DIRT ROAD FOR .6 MILE TO A Y-FORK.  KEEP THE RIGHT FORK AND GO EASTERLY ON THE TRACK ROAD FOR 0.05 MILE TO A WIRE GATE AT THE BASE OF A LOW GRASSEY KNOLL.  PASS THROUGH THE GATE AND GO EASTERLY, UPHILL, ON THE TRACK ROAD THAT IS ON THE NORTH SIDE OF THE FENCE LINE FOR 0.3 MILE TO THE TOP OF THE NEXT GRASS COVERED KNOLL AND THE END OF TRUCK TRAVEL.  PACK EASTERLY, CROSSING A FENCE, TO THE HIGHEST POINT OF THE NEXT GRASS COVERED KNOLL AND THE STATION.  ABOUT A 100 YARD PACK.  THE STATION MARK IS A STANDARD U.S. GEOLOGICAL SURVEY DISK, CEMENTED IN A DEPRESSION IN OUTCROPPING BEDROCK WHICH PROJECTS ABOUT 4 INCHES AND THE MARK IS ABOUT 1 INCH BELOW THE NATURAL SURFACE OF THE ROCK.  REFERENCE MARK 1 IS A CENTER PUNCHED STEEL PIN EMBEDDED IN OUTCROPPING BEDROCK AND SURROUNDED BY CONCRETE.  THE SURFACE OF THE CONCRETE IS INSCRIBED REF 1.  IT IS FLUSH WITH THE SURFACE OF THE GROUND.  REFERENCE MARK 2 IS A CENTER PUNCHED STEEL PIN EMBEDDED IN OUTCROPPING BEDROCK AND SURROUNDED BY CONCRETE.  THE SURFACE OF THE CONCRETE IS INSCRIBED REF 2.  IT PROJECTS ABOUT 8 INCHES.  REFERENCE MARK 3 IS A CENTER PUNCHED STEEL PIN EMBEDDED IN OUTCROPPING BEDROCK AND SURROUNDED BY CONCRETE.  THE SURFACE OF THE CONCRETE IS INSCRIBED REF 3.  IT PROJECTS ABOUT 3 INCHES.  REFERENCE MARK 1 IS A STANDARD DISK, STAMPED CANYON USGS NO 1 1922 1966, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN OUTCROPPING BEDROCK THAT PROJECTS 1 INCH.  NOTE 12A  AN AZIMUTH MARK WAS NOT ESTABLISHED.  AIRLINE DISTANCE AND DIRECTION FROM NEAREST TOWN 2-1/2 MILES EAST OF ISABELA.
markers.setting: SET IN ROCK OUTCROP
markers.stability: MOST RELIABLE AND EXPECTED TO HOLDPOSITION/ELEVATION WELL

markers.description: BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1966 (JWC) STATION MARK IS A CENTER PUNCHED STEEL PIN EMBEDDED IN OUTCROPPING BEDROCK AND SURROUNDED BY CONCRETE.  THE SURFACE OF THE CONCRETE IS INSCRIBED REF 1.  IT IS FLUSH WITH THE SURFACE OF THE GROUND.
markers.setting: SET IN ROCK OUTCROP
markers.stability: MOST RELIABLE AND EXPECTED TO HOLDPOSITION/ELEVATION WELL

markers.description: BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1940 LOCATED ON A BARE HILL 3 KMS. S OF TOWN OF HATILLO AND 0.6 KM. W OF HATILLO-PAJUIL RD. ON LAND OWNED BY GERARDO OSORIO.  TO REACH FROM HATILLO DRIVE SOUTH ON HATILLO-PAJUIL ROAD 3.9 KM.  TURN RIGHT (W) AT STORE AND DRIVE W ABOUT 600 METERS (ABOUT 200 METERS PAST CHURCH).  WALK S ABOUT 100 METERS TO TOP OF HILL AND STATION.  STATION MARK--STANDARD TABLET SET IN ROCK OUTCROP AND STAMPED CAPAEZ.  R.M. NO. 1 20D NAIL CEMENTED IN ROCK OUTCROP 7.8 FT. S 40 W.  R.M. NO. 2 20D NAIL CEMENTED IN ROCK OUTCROP 6.9 FT. S 05 E.                            STATION RECOVERY (1966)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JWC) THE STATION MARK AND REFERENCE MARKS 1 AND 2 WERE FOUND AND IN GOOD CONDITION.  A REFERENCE MARK 3 WAS ESTABLISHED AT THIS DATE.  A COMPLETE NEW DESCRIPTION FOLLOWS--  THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 6-1/2 MILES WEST OF ARECIBO, 2 MILES SOUTH SOUTHEAST OF HATILLO, ON A LOW HILL NEAR THE SOUTH EDGE OF A CONCRETE WATER RESERVOIR AND ON THE PROPERTY OF THE GOVERNMENT OF PUERTO RICO.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE JUNCTION OF HIGHWAYS 2 AND 130 AT THE SOUTH EDGE OF HATILLO, GO SOUTHERLY ON HIGHWAY 130 FOR 2.2 MILES TO A SIDE ROAD ON THE RIGHT AT KILOMETER POST 3.8.  TURN RIGHT AND GO WESTERLY ON A SAND ROAD FOR 0.2 MILE TO A CROSSROAD.  CONTINUE WESTERLY ON THE SAND ROAD FOR 0.25 MILE TO THE TOP OF A LOW HILL AND THE STATION.  THE STATION MARK IS A U.S. GEOLOGICAL SURVEY BENCH MARK DISK STAMPED CAPAEZ 1937, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A ROCK OUTCROP THAT PROJECTS 1 FOOT.  IT IS 20 FEET WEST OF THE SOUTHWEST CORNER OF A CONCRETE WATER RESERVOIR AND 19.5 FEET SOUTH OF THE SOUTHEAST CORNER OF THE RESERVOIR.  REFERENCE MARK 1 IS AN IRON T-STAKE CEMENTED IN A ROCK OUTCROP THAT PROJECTS 6 INCHES.  IT IS 7 FEET SOUTHWEST OF THE SOUTHWEST CORNER OF THE RESERVOIR.  REFERENCE MARK 2 IS AN IRON T-STAKE CEMENTED IN A ROCK OUTCROP THAT PROJECTS 6 INCHES.  IT IS 7.5 FEET SOUTHWEST OF THE SOUTHEAST CORNER OF THE RESERVOIR.  REFERENCE MARK 3 IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED CAPAEZ USGS NO 3 1934 1966, CEMENTED IN A ROCK OUTCROP THAT PROJECTS 1 INCH.  IT IS 39 FEET SOUTHWEST OF THE SOUTHEAST CORNER OF THE RESERVOIR AND 24.5 FEET NORTH OF A MESHWIRE FENCE THAT SURROUNDS THE WATER TANK AND THE STATION.  NO AZIMUTH MARK WAS ESTABLISHED AT THIS DATE.
markers.setting: SET IN ROCK OUTCROP
markers.stability: MOST RELIABLE AND EXPECTED TO HOLDPOSITION/ELEVATION WELL

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1925 (GCM) STATION IS NEAR THE CENTER OF THE LARGE, FAIRLY SMOOTH, ROUNDING LEDGE, 100 FEET HIGH AND 100 FEET FROM MOST EASTERLY ROCKS OF CAPE PASSAGE POINT, CULEBRITA ISLAND.  IT IS 15 METERS TO EASTWARD IS A SHEER DROP OF 40 FEET.  STATION JUST SEES EAST END OF VIEQUES ISLAND THROUGH SADDLE ALMOST ONE-HALF WAY FROM REEF POINT TO CULEBRITA LIGHT.  STATION MARK IS A STANDARD BRONZE DISK SET IN CONCRETE IN A DEPRESSION IN OUTCROPPING BEDROCK.  REFERENCE MARK NO.1 IS 1/2-INCH BRASS ROD CEMENTED IN CRACK NEAR S SIDE OF LEDGE.  ON EXACT RANGE WITH CULEBRITA LIGHT (9.88 METERS TOWARDS LIGHT) 3 FEET HIGHER THAN STATION.  REFERENCE MARK NO.2 IS A BRASS SCREW CEMENTED IN CRACK 4 FEET LOWER THAN STATION AND ON EXACT RANGE AND 6.28 METERS TOWARD STATION PALADA CAY.
markers.setting: UNSPECIFIED SETTING

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1900 (WCH) THIS STATION IS A LARGE MASONRY STRUCTURE WITH A FLAT ROOF, AND TOWER RISING THEREFROM, ON THE SUMMIT OF THE HILL NEAR THE POINT OF THE CAPE, WHICH FORMS THE NE ANGLE OF PUERTO RICO.                            STATION RECOVERY (1901)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1901 (JBP) STATION IS ON W SIDE OF BALCONY OF LIGHTHOUSE.  NOT MARKED.  DISTANCE FROM ECCENTRIC STATION TO WALL OF TOWER, 2 FEET.  CIRCUMFERENCE OF WALL OF TOWER 35 FEET 2 INCHES.                            STATION RECOVERY (1902)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1902 (JN) THIS LIGHTHOUSE WAS OCCUPIED, ECCENTRICALLY.  THE ANGLE BETWEEN PALOMINOS AND THE CENTER OF LIGHTHOUSE BEING 77 DEG 23 MIN 55 SEC AND THE DISTANCE BETWEEN ECCENTRIC STATION AND THE CENTER OF LIGHTHOUSE BEING 2.5757 METERS.                            STATION RECOVERY (1940)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1940 ON CAPE SAN JUAN, AT NORTHEASTERN EXTREMITY OF PUERTO RICO.  LIGHTHOUSE WAS BUILT IN 1870.  STATION MARK IS CENTER OF LIGHT.                            STATION RECOVERY (1965)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1965 (JJL) THE STATION WAS RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED AND FOUND TO BE IN GOOD CONDITION.  TRIANGULATION STATION LIGHTHOUSE WAS ESTABLISHED AT THIS DATE IN THE NEAR VICINITY.  SEE DESCRIPTION THEREOF.                            STATION RECOVERY (1978)  RECOVERY NOTE BY DEFENSE MAP AGENCY 1978 (EAW) NOT STAMPED RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED.                            STATION RECOVERY (2008)  RECOVERY NOTE BY POLYTECHNIC UNIVERSITY OF PUERTO RICO 2008 (JRT) RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.
PTIVE TEXT AVAILABLE.

BY LOCAL ENGINEER (INDIVIDUAL OR FIRM) 1966 (JWC) STATION ESTABLISHED BY PRS.  THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 7 MILES SOUTH-SOUTHEAST OF YAUCO, 2 MILES SOUTHEAST OF ENSENADA, 1 MILE SOUTH-SOUTHEAST OF GUANICA AND ON THE TOP OF AN OLD FORT THAT IS LOCALLY KNOWN AS FORT CAPRON.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE NORTHEAST CORNER OF THE PLAZA IN GUANICA, GO NORTH ON A PAVED STREET FOR 0.35 MILE TO THE JUNCTION WITH HIGHWAY 116.  TURN RIGHT AND GO NORTHEAST ON HIGHWAY 116 FOR 0.25 MILE TO A REVERSE FORK.  TURN SHARP RIGHT AND GO SOUTH AND EAST ON A PAVED ROAD FOR 2.0 MILES TO A SIDE ROAD ON THE LEFT.  TURN LEFT AND GO NORTH ON A GRAVELED, MOUNTAIN ROAD FOR 0.8 MILE TO A REVERSE FORK.  TURN SHARP RIGHT AND GO SOUTHEAST ON A MOUNTAIN ROAD FOR 0.1 MILE TO THE STATION ON THE LEFT.  THE STATION MARK IS AN IRON T STAKE, CEMENTED IN A MASS OF CONCRETE IN THE FLOOR OF THE UPPER LEVEL OF FORT CAPRON.  THE CONCRETE IS INSCRIBED CAPRON PROP SEPT 15 1958.  IT IS LOCATED IN THE CENTER OF THE TOWER OF THE FORT.  NO SUITABLE PLACE WAS FOUND FOR REFERENCE MARKS AS THE TOP OF THE FORT IS ONLY 14 FEET IN DIAMETER.  NO SUITABLE PLACE WAS FOUND FOR AN AZIMUTH MARK.                            STATION RECOVERY (1971)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1971 (EKM) THE STATION WAS RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION AS DESCRIBED.  THE DESCRIPTION BY J.W.C. IN 1966 IS ADEQUATE FOR RECOVERY.
markers.setting: UNSPECIFIED SETTING

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1926 (GCM) STATION MARKED BY 2-INCH PIPE SET IN CEMENT SOME 27.0 METERS BACK FROM THE END OF THE SAND SPIT WHICH FORMS THE NW END OF CARACOLES ISLAND.  MARK IS ALMOST MIDWAY ON POINT BETWEEN HIGH-WATER LINES EXTENDING BACK.  REFERENCE MARKS NOS.1 AND 2 ARE STANDARD BRONZE DISKS SET IN IRREGULAR MASSES OF CONCRETE.
markers.setting: UNSPECIFIED SETTING

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1900 (JN) THIS STATION IS ON ONE OF THE LITTLE GROUP (W OF ATALAYA) LOCALLY KNOWN AS THE SAN FRANCISCO HILLS.  THE HILL ON WHICH THIS STATION IS LOCATED IS NOT THE HIGHEST IN THE RANGE AND STANDS BACK, FROM THE COAST, BEHIND SOME OF THE OTHERS.  THE LAND HERE BELONGS TO FRANCISCO MARTINEZ AND THE OWNERS HOME IS NEAR THE BASE OF THE HILL AT ABOUT ITS NW POINT, NEAR THE ROAD WHICH GIVES ACCESS TO THE COAST (PASSING ON THE W SIDE OF CARDENA), FOR THE HEAD OF THE VALLEY BETWEEN THIS STATION AND RINCON.  THE SUMMIT IS BARE OF TREES, BUT IN LINE TO THE CHIMNEY OF THE LARGE SUGAR PLANT AT CORSICA IS A LARGE TREE WHOSE BASE IS ABOUT 25 FEET BELOW THE LEVEL OF THE STATION.  THE SIGNAL WAS PLACED NEAR THE E END OF THE HILLTOP.  THE MARK IS AN IRON PIPE SUNK IN THE GROUND FOR ABOUT 16 INCHES AND THEN WELL-PACKED ABOUT WITH CEMENT.  AROUND THE TOP A LAYER OF STONES WERE CEMENTED ABOUT THE PIPE.  THE PIPE WAS FILLED WITH CEMENT AND IN THE CENTER AN IRON NAIL WAS SET.  THE CENTER OF THE HEAD OF THE NAIL MARKS THE STATION.  THE BEST WAY TO FIND THE STATION IS TO GO TO CORSICA (CORCHEGA) STATION ON THE FERRE CARRILES DE P.R., AND THEN TAKING THE ROAD HEADING STRAIGHT IN TOWARDS THE MOUNTAINS, FOLLOW IT UNTIL ONE REACHES OLD S. H. PLANT, IN A LOCALITY WHERE A STORE IS TO BE SEEN ON EACH SIDE OF THE ROAD.  HERE ONE SHOULD TURN TOWARDS THE SEA AND FOLLOW THE ROAD TO SENOR MARTINEZ HOME.  FROM HIS HOUSE A TRAIL STARTS WHICH LEADS STRAIGHT UP TO THE TOP OF THE HILL AND THE STATION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1901)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1901 (JEM) STATION WAS RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED.  THE HILL HAS BEEN FIRE SWEPT SINCE THE SIGNAL WAS BUILT, BUT BEYOND A CHARRING THE SIGNAL DID NOT SUFFER.  THE SE LEG WAS SEVERELY CHARRED, BUT THE SIGNAL WAS FOUND IN FAIR CONDITION.  THE SURFACE MARK HAS NOT BEEN DISTURBED BY ANYONE.  I THINK A SMALL PIECE OF CEMENT HAD BEEN BROKEN OFF THE N FACE OF THE PIPE, BUT THIS DID NOT AFFECT THE STABILITY, OR POSITION OF THE PIPE, AND SEEMS TO ME TO BE AN ACCIDENTAL AFFAIR, AND NOT DUE TO MALICIOUS INTENT ON ANYONES PART.
markers.setting: SET INTO TOP OF METAL PIPE DRIVEN INTO GROUND
markers.stability: MARK OF QUESTIONABLE OR UNKNOWN STABILITY

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1899 (WCH) THIS STATION IS THE CENTER OF A TACK DRIVEN IN A BRICK ON THE ROOF OF THE DWELLING OF THE LIGHTHOUSE.  THE ROOF IS BRICK, LAID IN CEMENT, AND APPARENTLY VERY SOLID.  AZIMUTH WAS OBSERVED FROM THIS SAME STATION.  IT IS A SHORT DISTANCE FROM THE DOOR LEADING FROM LIGHTHOUSE TO ROOF OF DWELLING.
