DISTANCE FROM ECCENTRIC STATION TO CENTER OF LIGHTHOUSE 2.92 METERS.                            STATION RECOVERY (1899)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1899 (JN) THIS ECCENTRIC STATION WAS OCCUPIED ON THE BRICK ROOF OF THE LIGHTKEEPERS DWELLING.  THE LANTERN TOWER IS ATTACHED TO THE S FRONT OF THIS DWELLING.  IN THE TOWER A FLIGHT OF STEPS GIVES ACCESS TO THE LANTERN-ROOM AND THESE STAIRS ARE ATTACHED TO AN IRON PILLAR WHICH IS IN THE CENTER OF THE TOWER.  THE PILLAR ONLY EXTENDS TO THE UNDER SIDE OF THE FLOOR OF THE LANTERN-ROOM.  ON THE TOP OF THE ROOF OF THE LANTERN-ROOM IS A GLOBE AND AN UPRIGHT IRON ROD TO WHICH ARE ATTACHED ARMS SHOWING THE CARDINAL POINTS OF THE COMPASS AND A VANE.  THE DISTANCE FROM THE ECCENTRIC STATION WAS CAREFULLY MEASURED (WITH A STEEL TAPE) TO THE IRON PILLAR AND THE ANGLE BETWEEN THE CENTER OF THE PILLAR AND RATONES 2 WAS ALSO SECURED.  THE ROOF OF THE LIGHTKEEPERS QUARTERS IS COVERED WITH BRICK AND IS A VERY SUBSTANTIAL ONE.  IT IS ALSO FURNISHED WITH A HEAVY PARAPET, EVIDENTLY DESIGNED TO CATCH THE WATER NECESSARY FOR THE PEOPLE WHO LIVE THERE.  THE INSTRUMENT WAS MOUNTED OVER THE HEAD OF AN IRON NAIL WHICH WAS FOUND BEDDED IN A BRICK, THE CENTER BEING 0.59 METER FROM THE OUTSIDE EDGE OF THE THRESHOLD OF THE DOORWAY, GIVING ACCESS TO THE ROOF FROM LANTERN TOWER.  THIS WAS PROBABLY THE STATION MARK ESTABLISHED EARLIER IN 1899.                            STATION RECOVERY (1900)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1900 (SF) THIS IS THE ECCENTRIC STATION OCCUPIED WHILE OBSERVING AT CARDONA LIGHTHOUSE, IN 1899.  IT IS ON THE ROOF OF THE DWELLING OF THE LIGHTKEEPER.  THIS ROOF IS MADE OF BRICK AND CEMENT AND IS VERY SOLID AND STEADY.  THE STATION IS MARKED WITH A STANDARD STATION MARK, A BRASS DISK SET INTO THE ROOF WITH PORTLAND CEMENT.  THE STATION MARK IS STAMPED U.S.C. AND G.S.  CENTER OF LIGHT TO ECCENTRIC STATION IS 2.91 METERS.  THE ANGLE AT ECCENTRIC STATION BETWEEN MUERTOS LIGHTHOUSE AND CARDONA LIGHTHOUSE (CENTER OF LIGHTHOUSE) IS 56 DEG 28 MIN.                            STATION RECOVERY (1966)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JJL) THE STATION WAS RECOVERED AND FOUND IN GOOD CONDITION.  TWO REFERENCE POINTS WERE ESTABLISHED.  A COMPLETE DESCRIPTION FOLLOWS--  THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 3-1/2 MILES SOUTHWEST OF PONCE, 1-1/2 MILES SOUTHWEST OF PLAYA DE PONCE AND ON THE ROOF OF THE LIGHTHOUSE ON CARDONA ISLAND.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE JUNCTION OF HIGHWAYS 1 AND 2 (PONCE BY-PASS) ON THE EAST SIDE OF PONCE, GO SOUTH AND WEST ON HIGHWAY 2 FOR 1.5 MILES TO THE JUNCTION OF HIGHWAYS 2 AND 10.  TURN LEFT AND GO SOUTH AND SOUTHWEST ON HIGHWAY 10 FOR 1.3 MILES TO A POINT WHERE THE HIGHWAY TURNS LEFT.  TURN LEFT AND GO SOUTHEAST ON HIGHWAY 10 FOR 0.05 MILE TO A SIDE STREET RIGHT.  TURN RIGHT AND GO SOUTH FOR 0.05 MILE TO THE END OF TRUCK TRAVEL AT THE PORT OF PONCE U.S. COAST GUARD STATION.  OBTAIN A KEY TO THE LIGHTHOUSE AND PERMISSION TO VISIT THE STATION AT THIS POINT.  ALSO A BOAT MAY BE HIRED IN THIS VICINITY FOR THE TRIP TO THE ISLAND.  THE STATION MARK IS A CENTER-PUNCHED BRASS DISK CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN THE ROOF OF THE LIGHTHOUSE.  THE LETTERS U.S.C. AND G.S. ARE CAST IN THE DISK.  THE DISK IS ABOUT 3 INCHES IN DIAMETER AND IT IS ABOUT 1/2 INCH BELOW THE SURFACE OF THE ROOF.  REFERENCE POINT NO. 1 IS THE TOP OF THE INSIDE CORNER OF THE NORTHEAST CORNER OF THE CONCRETE WALL ON TOP OF THE LIGHTHOUSE.  REFERENCE POINT NO. 2 IS THE TOP OF THE INSIDE CORNER OF THE NORTHWEST CORNER OF THE CONCRETE WALL ON TOP OF THE LIGHTHOUSE.  AIRLINE DISTANCE AND DIRECTION FROM NEAREST TOWN 3-1/2 MILES SOUTHWEST OF PONCE.                            STATION RECOVERY (1970)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1970 (KAM) THE STATION WAS VISITED AND STATION MARK AND REFERENCE POINTS FOUND TO BE AS DESCRIBED BY J.J.L. IN 1966.  THE OUTER PLATFORM (REFERENCE POINTS) IS STARTING TO DETERIORATE BADLY.                            STATION RECOVERY (1971)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1971 (EKM) STATION RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED.
markers.setting: SET IN A MASSIVE STRUCTURE
markers.stability: PROBABLY HOLD POSITION/ELEVATION WELL

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1899 (SF) THIS STATION IS THE CENTER OF THE LIGHT ON CARDONA LIGHTHOUSE, WHICH IS SITUATED IN CARDONA ISLAND AT THE ENTRANCE TO PONCE HARBOR, S COAST OF PUERTO RICO.                            STATION RECOVERY (1970)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1970 (KAM) STATION WAS RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.  THE LIGHTHOUSE IS UNMANNED AND BATTERY-POWERED.  PARTS OF THE STRUCTURE ARE DETERIORATING.                            STATION RECOVERY (1971)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1971 (EKM) STATION RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED.

BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1939 LOCATED ABOUT 3 KMS. DUE N OF SAN VICENTE CENTRAL, ABOUT 300 METERS S OF SHORE, ON TOP OF A LONG HILL COVERED WITH GRASS, WITH A LINE OF COCONUT PALM ON ITS N SIDE, THE ONLY HILL BETWEEN THE POINT OF CERRO GORDO AND THE MOUTH OF THE CIBUCO RIVER.  IT IS A DOUBLE-TOPPED HILL, WITH THE STATION NEAR THE W END OF THE E HALF.  LAND OWNED BY CENTRAL SAN VICENTE ON ITS COLONIA C.  IT IS APPROACHED FROM SAN VICENTE, BY FOLLOWING ALONG SECOND-CLASS ROAD ABOUT 3/4 KM. TO A Y-FORK OF ROAD AND TRACK TO NE AT A PLACE KNOWN AS LA CACHASA, TURN LEFT (NEARLY N) THERE FOLLOWING DIRT ROAD ALONG CANE TRACK.  KEEP STRAIGHT N AT FIRST Y-FORK TO E (TRACK AND ROAD FORK), TURN LEFT (W) AT SECOND Y-FORK OF ROAD AND TRACK LEAVING TRACK TO TURN RIGHT (N) AT LOW HILL TURNING LEFT (W) AND NEXT Y-FORK AT FOOT OF SAND DUNE, CONTINUE W PASSING BARN, WINDMILL AND SMALL LAGOON TO MAIN HOUSE OF THE COLONIA.  THE HILL AND STATION ARE ABOUT 600 METERS ALMOST E OF HOUSE.  STATION MARK--STANDARD TABLET IN 10- BY 10- BY 36-INCH CONCRETE POST STAMPED CARIBE 1939.  REFERENCE MARK--(1) R.R. SPIKE FIXED TO NATURAL LIMESTONE ROCK ON W EDGE OF HOLE DUG IN GROUND.  (2) R.R. SPIKE FIXED TO NATURAL LIMESTONE ROCK ON E EDGE OF HOLE.
markers.setting: SET IN TOP OF CONCRETE MONUMENT
markers.stability: MAY HOLD, BUT OF TYPE COMMONLY SUBJECT TOSURFACE MOTION

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1939 (HAC) STATION IS A TALL CONCRETE STACK OF THE CARIOCA DISTILLERY LOCATED ON PALO SECO POINT (ABOUT 1/2 MILE SW OF THE EXTREME POINT).                            STATION RECOVERY (1964)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1964 (GWM) THE STACK IS NOW PAINTED RON GALLITO RUM- OLD SAN JUAN DISTILLERY.  A NEW POWER GENERATING STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 1/2 MILE S OF THE STACK.  THE TWIN STACKS OF THIS PLANT ARE MUCH MORE PROMINENT NOW.  A COMPLETE DESCRIPTION FOLLOWS--  A TALL CONCRETE STACK PAINTED, RON GALLITO RUM- OLD SAN JUAN DISTILLERY ON PALO SECO POINT, ABOUT 0.5 MILE SW OF EXTREME POINT AND ABOUT 1/4 MILE N OF MORE PROMINENT TWIN STACKS OF POWER GENERATING PLANT.

BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1934 STATION IS TO THE NE OF THE GUAYAMA-CAYEY ROAD, AT KILOMETER 13 H 4.  AT SAID POINT LIVES CRISTOBAL CRUEL, AND FROM HERE TAKE A PATH LEADING IN AN EASTERLY DIRECTION UP TO THE TOP OF THE RIDGE, THEN FOLLOW A PATH IN A SOUTHERLY DIRECTION ALONG THE RIDGE UNTIL YOU HAVE TO DEVIATE SLIGHTLY TO THE E.  THE STATION IS THE LAST AND HIGHEST POINT ON THE RIDGE.  THIS STATION IS ABOUT 2 KILOMETERS FROM THE HIGHWAY.  STATION IS ON A GRASS COVERED PEAK WHICH IS BARE.  TO THE N THERE IS A BANANA PLANTATION, TO THE S A LOT OF WILD COUNTRY AND TO THE E OF N CAN BE SEEN THE CARITE RESERVOIR.  STATION MARK IS A STANDARD U.S.G.S. BENCH MARK STAMPED CARITE 1934 SET ON A BOULDER BURIED IN THE GROUND.  UNDER THE BOULDER A SMALL GREEN BOTTLE FILLED WITH BLACK DIRT BURIED 16 INCHES BELOW THE SURFACE.  REFERENCE MARK NO.1 IS A BRASS NAIL ON TREE TRUNK, 28.07 FEET FROM STATION IN TRUE AZIMUTH 290 DEG 06 MIN.  REFERENCE MARK NO.2 IS A BRASS NAIL ON TREE TRUNK, 18.85 FEET FROM STATION IN TRUE AZIMUTH 328 DEG 53 MIN.  SIGNAL--WHITE QUADRIPOD WITH BLACK CROSS TARGETS ON CENTER POLE.
markers.setting: SET IN A BOULDER
markers.stability: MAY HOLD, BUT OF TYPE COMMONLY SUBJECT TOSURFACE MOTION

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1926 (GCM) GRAY STACK LOCATED AT HACIENDA CARLOTA.  NOT USED AT PRESENT.  HACIENDA CARLOTA IS 1.0 MILE SE OF GUAYAMA AND NEAR THE MAIN ROAD BETWEEN GUAYAMA AND ARROYO.                            STATION RECOVERY (1970)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1970 (JKW) STATION LOST.  NO STACK WAS FOUND IN THIS LOCATION.

BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1899 (WCH) STATION IS ON A BARE PEAK ABOUT 2000 FEET ABOVE THE SEA.  IT IS NEARLY N OF THE TOWN OF SALINAS, ABOUT 7 MILES DISTANT.  MOST OF THIS DISTANCE IS OVER A ROUGH TRAIL.  THE POINT IS WELL-KNOWN BY BEING THE ONLY BARE ONE IN THE VICINITY.  THE CENTER IS MARKED BY A TACK DRIVEN INTO A STUB ABOUT 2 FEET LONG, WHICH PROJECTS ABOUT 2 INCHES ABOVE THE SURFACE.  A TRIPOD SIGNAL ABOUT 25 FEET HIGH WAS BUILT OVER THIS STATION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1934)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1934 FOUND IN GOOD CONDITION, APPARENTLY UNDISTURBED.  THE SUMMIT HAS 3 MAIN PEAKS, ONE IS ABOUT 150 METERS TO THE NE OF THE STATION AND ABOUT 15 FEET HIGHER IN ELEVATION, ANOTHER IS ABOUT 200 METERS TO THE NW OF STATION, AND ABOUT THE SAME ELEVATION.  STATION MAY BE REACHED FROM EITHER COAMO OR SALINAS.  CAR CAN BE TAKEN NEARER TO THE FOOT OF PEAK FROM SALINAS, BUT THE CLIMB TO TOP FROM THAT SIDE IS MUCH STEEPER.  TO REACH FROM SALINAS, FOLLOW CARRETERA LEADING TO CAYEY TO KILOMETER POST K5-H3, AT HOUSE AND SMALL TIENDA TURN NORTHWESTWARD THROUGH GATE AND FOLLOW A SECOND CLASS ROAD 3.7 KILOMETERS TO LARGE, RED-ROOFED, FRAME HOUSE, THEN FOLLOW A DIM ROAD WHICH TURNS TO THE LEFT ACROSS STREAM, KEEPING TO RIGHT AT FORKS, 0.9 KILOMETER FROM LARGE HOUSE, AND LATER PASSING THROUGH A DOUBLE CORRAL. AT PRESENT TIME CAR CAN BE TAKEN TO BANK OF STREAM 2.3 KILOMETERS FROM THE LARGE FRAME HOUSE.  FROM THIS POINT A TRAIL IS FOLLOWED, CLIMBING THE MIDDLE RIDGE BETWEEN MAIN DRAIN FORKS.  IF ENTERING FROM COAMO, FOLLOW MAIN HIGHWAY, LEADING TO AIBONITO FOR ABOUT 4 KILOMETERS TO SECOND CLASS ROAD BRANCHING OFF TO RIGHT AT KILOMETER POST K93-H8, KEEP TO LEFT ACROSS DRAIN AT FIRST FORKS AND CONTINUE AS FAR AS CAR CAN BE TAKEN, AT WHICH POINT INQUIRE AS TO ROUTE AS THERE IS NO MAIN TRAIL GOING DIRECTLY TO THE STATION.  STATION IS NOW MARKED BY A 2-INCH GALVANIZED-IRON PIPE PROJECTING 3 INCHES ABOVE SURFACE OF GROUND.  REFERENCE MARK NO.1 IS A COPPER NAIL AND WASHER IN A BLAZE ON A DOUBLE-TRUNKED CORCHO TREE, ABOUT 6 FEET ABOVE THE GROUND, 93.45 FEET (INCLINED DISTANCE) FROM STATION IN TRUE AZIMUTH 355 DEG 16 MIN.  REFERENCE MARK NO.2 IS A COPPER NAIL AND WASHER IN A TRIANGULAR BLAZE ON LARGE MANGO TREE, 99.65 FEET (INCLINED DISTANCE) FROM STATION IN TRUE AZIMUTH 132 DEG 44 MIN.  A QUADRIPOD OF SAWED LUMBER COVERED WITH CLOTH WAS CENTERED OVER STATION MARK.

BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1900 (JN) STATION IS ON A SMALL ISLAND, THE FIRST ONE MET BY ANYONE LEAVING GUANICA HARBOR AFTER ROUNDING POINT MESETA AND GOING E.  WHEN THE SIGNAL WAS PUT UP, THE BUILDER SAID THERE WAS A LITTLE HOUSE ON THE ISLAND AND SO THE NAME CASA WAS GIVEN TO THE PLACE AS THE LOCAL NAME ISLOTA WAS A LITTLE TOO COMMON.  ON INSPECTION THE HOUSE PROVED TO BE A PIECE OF CORRUGATED SHEET IRON WHICH WAS USED AS A SHELTER BY SOME CASUAL FISHERMAN, WHO MIGHT COME ASHORE TO MAKE COFFEE AND REST FOR AN HOUR OR SO. THE ISLET IS ABOUT 40 METERS FROM N TO S AND ABOUT 18 METERS FROM E TO W.  IT IS NEARLY CLEAR OF BUSHES.  A FEW MANGROVES LINE THE SEAWARD FACE AND THERE WERE SOME WHICH OBSTRUCTED POINT BREA, BUT THESE WERE CUT.  THE SIGNAL IS ABOUT 6 METERS FROM THE E SHORE OF THE ISLET, AND THE SAME DISTANCE FROM THE S SHORE.  STATION IS MARKED BY A 2-FOOT PIECE OF WROUGHT IRON PIPE WHICH WAS CEMENTED IN THE GROUND AND IN THE CENTER OF THE PIPE A NAIL WAS SET.  MANUEL TORRES, BOATMAN AT GUANICA, KNOWS WHERE THIS STATION IS.                            STATION RECOVERY (1900)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1900 (GLF) I FOUND THE SIGNAL AT CASA STANDING.  THE GROUND MARK WAS DUG UP AND I FOUND THE IRON PIPE ON THE ISLAND IN A CLUMP OF MANGROVES.  RESET STATION MARK BUT HAD NO CEMENT TO SURROUND IT WITH.
markers.setting: SET INTO TOP OF METAL PIPE DRIVEN INTO GROUND
markers.stability: MARK OF QUESTIONABLE OR UNKNOWN STABILITY

markers.description: BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1934 NO CHECK ON THIS POSITION.  STATION IS HIGHEST POINT OF LARGE WHITE HOUSE.                            STATION RECOVERY (1964)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1964 (GWM) THE STATION WAS RECOVERED BY USC AND GS.  THE ORIGINAL DESCRIPTION IS ADEQUATE AND FOLLOWS--  HIGHEST POINT OF LARGE, WHITE HOUSE APPROXIMATELY 100 METERS N OF ROAD INTERSECTION KNOWN AS LOS RANCHOS.

BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1934 STATION IS CATANO RED ROOFED CHURCH STEEPLE.  POINT SIGHTED WAS THE WHITE CROSS OVER RED TILED ROOF.  NO CHECK ON THIS POSITION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1939)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1939 (HAC) STATION IS THE TOWER OF CHURCH LOCATED AT CATANO PLAYA ON THE W SHORE OF PUEBLO VIEJO BAY, ABOUT 3/4 MILE SE OF CATANO.                            STATION RECOVERY (1964)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1964 (GWM) THE ONLY CHANGE NEEDED TO THE ORIGINAL DESCRIPTION IS, THE INSCRIPTION ABOVE THE DOOR OF THE CHURCH READS, LAUDARE BENDICERE PRAE DICTARE.  A COMPLETE DESCRIPTION FOLLOWS--THE TOWER OF THE CHURCH AT CATANO PLAYA ON THE W SHORE OF PUEBLO VIEJO BAY, ABOUT 3/4 MILE SE OF CATANO.  THE INSCRIPTION ABOVE THE DOOR OF THE CHURCH READS--LAUDARE BENDICERE PRAE DICTARE.                            STATION RECOVERY (1965)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1965 (MTP) STATION WAS RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED BY ENSIGN DAVID P. VAN WECLE IN 1964.  DESCRIPTION IS ADEQUATE.  STATION IN GOOD CONDITION.

BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1939 (HAC) THE STATION IS THE FRONT LIGHT OF THE CATANO RANGE WHICH MARKS THE ENTRANCE TO THE SAN JUAN HARBOR.  SEE LIGHT LIST, U.S. LIGHTHOUSE SERVICE.                            STATION RECOVERY (1965)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1965 (MTP) STATION RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED.  STATION WAS IN GOOD CONDITION.

BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JJL) THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 3-1/2 MILES NORTHEAST OF BAYAMON AND 1-1/2 MILES SOUTHWEST OF CATANO.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE JUNCTION OF HIGHWAYS 165 AND 167 IN CATANO, GO SOUTHWEST ON HIGHWAY 167 FOR 1.8 MILES TO THE STATION ON THE LEFT, SOUTHEAST, SIDE OF THE HIGHWAY.  THE MAST IS A 3-LEGGED STEEL STRUCTURE, SUPPORTED BY GUY WIRES, PAINTED ALTERNATELY RED AND WHITE, WITH A RED OBSTRUCTION LIGHT ON TOP AND IT IS APPROXIMATELY 390 FEET HIGH.  THIS IS THE TALLEST MAST OF A GROUP OF 5 MASTS.  POINT INTERSECTED IS THE TOP AND CENTER OF THE MAST.

BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1939 (HAC) STATION IS THE REAR LIGHT OF THE CATANO RANGE WHICH MARKS THE ENTRANCE TO THE SAN JUAN HARBOR.  SEE 1939 LIGHT LIST, U.S. LIGHTHOUSE SERVICE.  THIS LIGHT WAS SCHEDULED TO BE MOVED A SHORT DISTANCE TO THE NE SOME TIME DURING 1940.                            STATION RECOVERY (1964)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1964 (GWM) THIS STATION WAS RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED.  THE LIGHT WAS NEVER MOVED AS STATED IN DESCRIPTION, THIS WAS CONFIRMED BY ANGLES AT LIGHT AND INFORMATION FROM THE COAST GUARD AT SAN JUAN.  OBSERVATIONS MADE FOR VERIFICATION, NO ANGLES RECORDED.                            STATION RECOVERY (1965)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1965 (MTB) THIS STATION WAS RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED.

BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1900 (JN) STATION IS ON THE FIRST RIDGE W OF PONCE, NEAR THE SHORE FROM WHICH ONE CAN SEE THE PLAYA OF GUAYANILLA.  TRAVELING ALONG THE WAGON ROAD WESTWARD, ONE PASSES A POINT WHERE A HEAVY CUT HAS BEEN MADE IN THE RIDGE TO PROCURE MATERIAL FOR THE RAILROAD ROAD-BED, AND THEN THE ROAD RISES ALONG A BENCH WHICH HAS BEEN CUT IN THE SIDE OF THE BLUFF.  CAVE IS ON THIS BLUFF.  THE SLOPE OF THE BLUFF AT THE STATION IS VERY STEEP AND AT THE SIGNAL ONE CANNOT SEE THE ROAD OR RAILROAD.  AT THE SIGNAL THE RIGHT HAND EDGE OF CAJA DE MUERTOS ISLAND, THE POINT OF MAINLAND NEAR ROCK AND THE RIGHT HAND EDGE OF THE OUTER BAY WHERE INNER SIDE TOWARDS TORREY ARE ALMOST IN LINE.  IT SEEMS TO ME AT THIS TIME THAT I CAN SEE A THIN STREAK OF WATER (IN GUANICA BAY) BETWEEN POINT BREA AND THE POINT NEAREST ME.  ONE CAN SEE A SUGAR CHIMNEY AND TWO OR THREE OF THE MOST WESTERLY OF THE BUILDINGS AT THE PLAYA OF GUAYANILLA JUST SHOWING TO THE LEFT OF THE RIDGE ON WHICH TURN STANDS. THE CUTTING MADE TO PERMIT OBSERVATION OF TORREY, MARIA, AND TURN WILL BE A GOOD MARK FOR FINDING THE SIGNAL FOR SEVERAL YEARS.  FOR MARKING THE SIGNAL, A 2-INCH IRON PIPE WAS CEMENTED INTO THE SOLID ROCK ON WHICH THE TRIPOD STANDS.  THE TOP OF THE PIPE PROJECTS ABOUT 4 INCHES ABOVE THE ROCK.  VESSELS AT ANCHOR IN FRONT OF THE PLAYA OF PONCE CAN JUST BE SEEN OVER THE RIDGE ON WHICH TORREY STANDS, AT A POINT SEVERAL HUNDRED FEET BACK OF TORREY.  A TACK WAS SET IN THE CEMENT TO MARK THE CENTER OF STATION AND THE INSTRUMENT WAS SET UP OVER THE TACK.  THE SIGNAL IS ABOUT 250 FEET IN ELEVATION ABOVE HIGH WATER.  A YOUNG NATIVE NAMED FRANCISCO MOLOVA, WHO LIVES IN THE FIRST HAMLET ON THE WAGON ROAD E OF TALLABOA, ACCOMPANIED THE PARTY TO THIS POINT.                            STATION RECOVERY (1901)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1901 (GLF) FOUND STATION MARK UNDISTURBED.                            STATION RECOVERY (1966)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JJL) THE STATION WAS SEARCHED FOR BUT NOT FOUND.  IT IS BELIEVED ALL MARKS WERE DESTROYED.  A NEW STATION CAVE 2 WAS ESTABLISHED.

BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JJL) THE STATION IS LOCATED 8 AIRLINE MILES EAST-SOUTHEAST OF GUAYANILLA, 7 AIRLINE MILES WEST OF PONCE AND ON THE HIGHEST POINT OF A LOW BRUSH COVERED HILL.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE INTERSECTION OF HIGHWAY 132 AND 2 IN THE SOUTH EDGE OF PONCE, GO WESTERLY ON HIGHWAY 2 FOR 5.65 MILES TO A SIDE ROAD RIGHT AT A LOCKED GATE.  TURN RIGHT AND GO NORTH ON A PAVED ROAD PASSING THROUGH THE LOCKED GATE FOR ABOUT 100 FEET TO A T-INTERSECTION.  TURN RIGHT AND GO EAST ON A PAVED ROAD FOR ABOUT 100 YARDS TO A SIDE ROAD LEFT.  TURN LEFT AND GO NORTH ON A TRACK ROAD FOR 0.15 MILE TO A SIDE ROAD LEFT.  BEAR LEFT AND GO NORTHERLY ON A TRACK ROAD FOR 0.55 MILE TO THE TOP OF A HILL AT A POWER LINE.  FROM HERE PACK SOUTH FOR ABOUT 100 YARDS TO THE TOP OF THE BRUSH COVERED HILL AND THE STATION ON THE HIGHEST POINT OF THE HILL.  THE KEY MAY BE OBTAINED FROM MR. JORGE P. VALDIVIESO WHO LIVES 5 MILES NORTHWEST OF THE STATION.  THE STATION MARK IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED CAVE 2 1966, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN OUTCROPPING BEDROCK WHICH PROJECTS 1 INCH.  REFERENCE MARK 1 IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED CAVE 2 NO 1 1966, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN OUTCROPPING BEDROCK WHICH IS FLUSH WITH THE SURFACE.  REFERENCE MARK 2 IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED CAVE 2 NO 2 1966, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN OUTCROPPING BEDROCK WHICH IS FLUSH WITH THE SURFACE.  NO AZIMUTH MARK WAS ESTABLISHED AT THIS STATION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1971)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1971 (EKM) STATION MARK AND REFERENCE MARKS RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED.  ADD FOLLOWING CHANGES TO HOW TO REACH--  ...GO WESTERLY ON HIGHWAY 2 FOR 5.65 MILES TO A SIDE ROAD RIGHT.  TURN RIGHT AND GO NORTH ON A PAVED ROAD FOR ABOUT 100 FEET TO A T-INTERSECTION.  TURN RIGHT AND GO EAST ON A PAVED ROAD FOR ABOUT 100 YARDS TO A TRACK ROAD LEFT.  TURN LEFT AND GO NORTH ON A TRACK ROAD FOR 0.15 MILE TO A TRACK ROAD LEFT.  (A 4-WHEEL DRIVE VEHICLE IS REQUIRED TO REACH THE STATION FROM THIS POINT).  BEAR LEFT......  .....FROM HERE PACK EAST ALONG THE POWER LINES TO THE TOP OF THE BRUSH COVERED HILL.  THE STATION IS ABOUT 70 FEET SSW OF THE POWER POLES AT THE TOP OF THE HILL, AND ON THE HIGHEST POINT OF THE HILL.
markers.setting: SET IN ROCK OUTCROP
markers.stability: MOST RELIABLE AND EXPECTED TO HOLDPOSITION/ELEVATION WELL

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JJL) THE STATION IS LOCATED 9-3/4 AIRLINE MILES NORTH-NORTHEAST OF GUAYAMA, 1-1/2 AIRLINE MILES EAST OF CAYEY AND ON A LOW HILL OWNED BY THE GEOPHYSICAL OBSERVATORY IN CAYEY.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE INTERSECTION OF HIGHWAYS 1 AND 15 IN THE SOUTH EDGE OF CAYEY, GO NORTHEAST ON HIGHWAY 1 FOR 0.7 MILE TO A GATE ON THE RIGHT AT THE GEOPHYSICAL OBSERVATORY.  TURN RIGHT, PASS THROUGH THE GATE AND GO SOUTH ON A PAVED ROAD FOR 0.05 MILE TO THE AZIMUTH MARK ON THE LEFT, JUST SOUTHWEST OF A GARAGE.  CONTINUE SOUTH AND WEST ON THE PAVED ROAD FOR 0.2 MILE TO THE END OF TRUCK TRAVEL AT A CONCRETE BUILDING.  FROM HERE PACK SOUTHEAST UP THE STEEP HILL FOR ABOUT 1/4 MILE TO THE TOP OF THE HILL AND STATION.  A 30 MINUTE PACK.  THE STATION MARK IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED CAYEY 1965, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A BOULDER WHICH IS FLUSH WITH THE SURFACE.  IT IS 4 FEET NORTH OF A FENCE CORNER.  REFERENCE MARK 1 IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED CAYEY NO 1 1965, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A BOULDER WHICH PROJECTS 4 INCHES.  IT IS 9 FEET EAST OF THE FENCE CORNER.  REFERENCE MARK 2 IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED CAYEY NO 2 1965, BRAZED TO THE TOP OF A 3-INCH ROUND CAST IRON SOIL PIPE WHICH PROJECTS 8 INCHES.  IT IS 15 FEET NORTH OF THE FENCE CORNER.  THE AZIMUTH MARK IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED CAYEY 1965, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A CURB WHICH PROJECTS 4 INCHES.  IT IS 12 FEET SOUTHWEST OF THE SOUTHWEST CORNER OF THE GARAGE.  PIER H E IS A MARBLE SLAB WHICH SUPPORTS AN INSTRUMENT.  IT IS LOCATED IN BUILDING E OF THE GEOPHYSICAL OBSERVATORY.
markers.setting: SET IN A BOULDER
markers.stability: MAY HOLD, BUT OF TYPE COMMONLY SUBJECT TOSURFACE MOTION

markers.description: PTIVE TEXT AVAILABLE.

BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JJL) THE STATION IS THE TOP AND CENTER OF A VENT PIPE ATOP THE GEOPHYSICAL OBSERVATORY MAIN OFFICE BUILDING.  THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 1-1/2 AIRLINE MILES SOUTHEAST OF CAYEY AND 0.7 MILE NORTHEAST OF THE INTERSECTION OF HIGHWAYS 1 AND 15.

BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JJL) THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 3/4 MILE EAST-NORTHEAST OF CAYEY.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE JUNCTION OF HIGHWAYS 1 AND 15 ON THE SOUTHEAST SIDE OF CAYEY, GO NORTHEAST ON HIGHWAY 1 FOR 1.5 MILES TO A SIDE ROAD RIGHT.  TURN RIGHT AND GO SOUTHEAST FOR 0.4 MILE TO THE STATION.  THE MAST IS A 3-LEGGED STEEL STRUCTURE, SUPPORTED BY GUY WIRES, PAINTED ALTERNATELY RED AND WHITE AND IT IS ABOUT 210 FEET HIGH.  POINT INTERSECTED IS THE RED OBSTRUCTION LIGHT ATOP AND CENTER OF THE MAST.

BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1926 (GCM) STATION MARKED BY 2-INCH PIPE 3 FEET LONG SET IN CEMENT AT THE EXTREME END OF CAYITO POINT.  THE MARK IS SET IN GRAVEL AT THE HIGH-WATER MARK.  GREEN IS OPEN TO THE RIGHT OF A PALM TREE AND THERE IS A LONE TREE 8.5 METERS FROM THE MARK, WHICH IS ON RANGE WITH A SMALL CLUMP OF TREES SOME DISTANCE BACK.  REFERENCE MARKS ARE 1-INCH PIPES SET IN CEMENT WITH SMALL SPIKES INSERTED AT THE TOP POINTING AT THE STATION.  HEIGHT OF SIGNAL ABOVE STATION MARK - 3 METERS.
markers.setting: UNSPECIFIED SETTING

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JJL) THE STATION IS LOCATED 10-1/2 AIRLINE MILES SOUTH-SOUTHWEST OF COAMO, 9 AIRLINE MILES SOUTHEAST OF JUANA DIAZ AND 3 AIRLINE MILES SOUTHWEST OF SANTA ISABEL.  IT IS ON A POINT OF LAND WHICH IS KNOWN AS PUNTA CAYITO.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE NORTHWEST CORNER OF THE PLAZA IN SANTA ISABEL, GO NORTH AND NORTHWEST ON HIGHWAY 1 FOR 1.7 MILES TO A CROSSROAD AT KILOMETER POST 106.5.  TURN LEFT AND GO SOUTH ON A BLADED ROAD FOR 0.5 MILE TO A CROSSROAD.  TURN LEFT AND GO EAST ON A BLADED ROAD FOR 0.15 MILE TO A SIDE ROAD RIGHT.  TURN RIGHT AND GO SOUTH ON A BLADED ROAD FOR 0.75 MILE TO A SIDE ROAD RIGHT.  TURN RIGHT AND GO WEST ON A TRACK ROAD FOR 0.1 MILE TO THE STATION ON THE LEFT, JUST NORTH OF THE SHORE LINE.  THE STATION MARK IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED CAYITO 1966, SET IN THE TOP OF A 10-INCH SQUARE CONCRETE MONUMENT WHICH IS FLUSH WITH THE SURFACE.  IT IS 20 FEET NORTH OF THE SHORE LINE.  REFERENCE MARK 1 IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED CAYITO NO 1 1966, SET IN THE TOP OF A 10-INCH ROUND CONCRETE MONUMENT WHICH PROJECTS 1 INCH.  IT IS 30 FEET NORTH OF THE SHORE LINE.  REFERENCE MARK 2 IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED CAYITO NO 2 1966, SET IN THE TOP OF A 10-INCH ROUND CONCRETE MONUMENT WHICH PROJECTS 1 INCH.  IT IS 10 FEET NORTH OF THE SHORE LINE.  NO AZIMUTH MARK WAS ESTABLISHED AT THIS STATION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1969)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1969 (JKW) STATION MARK AND REFERENCE MARK NO. 1 WERE SEARCHED FOR BUT NOT FOUND.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 2 WAS RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.  THE DISK IS BATTERED.  THE STATION MARK AND REFERENCE MARK NO. 1 MAY STILL BE IN EXISTANCE BUT COVERED BY AGRICULTURAL ACTIVITIES IN THE AREA.  THE ORIGINAL DESCRIPTION IS ADEQUATE.                            STATION RECOVERY (1975)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1975 (RMB) THE STATION MARK AND BOTH REFERENCE MARKS WERE RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION AS DESCRIBED.  A FIVE FOOT STEEL ANGLE FENCE POST, PROJECTING ABOUT 1 FOOT ABOVE GROUND, WAS SET AS A WITNESS POST 6 FEET SOUTHEAST OF THE STATION.  THE STATION IS NOW 12 FEET FROM THE MHW LINE.  CAYITO NO 1 1966 IS 26 FEET SOUTH OF THE CENTERLINE OF THE TRACK ROAD.  DISTANCES FROM THE STATION TO BOTH REFERENCE MARKS CHECKED.  THE STATION WAS REACHED BY SKIFF SO THE TO REACH INSTRUCTIONS WERE NOT CHECKED.  THE LONE PALM TREE AT THE END OF THE ROAD, 4.2 FEET FROM CAYITO NO 2 1966, IS THE ONLY PALM TREE IN THE VICINITY.  THE OTHER TREE AND SAWED-OFF PALM TREE, MENTIONED IN EARLIER DESCRIPTIONS, ARE GONE.
markers.setting: SET IN TOP OF CONCRETE MONUMENT
markers.stability: MAY HOLD, BUT OF TYPE COMMONLY SUBJECT TOSURFACE MOTION

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1962 (ELJ) THE CENTER OF THE WOODEN OBSERVATION TOWER LOCATED APPROXIMATELY IN THE CENTER OF CAYO (ISLET) ICACOS, WHICH IS THE LARGEST AND WESTERNMOST ISLAND IN THE CHAIN KNOWN AS LA CORDILLERA.  THE STRUCTURE IS ABOUT 40 FEET HIGH.  THE TOWER HAS NO DEFINITE CENTER POINT AND OBSERVATIONS WERE TAKEN ON TANGENTS.                            STATION RECOVERY (1964)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1964 (GWM) STATION RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED.

BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JJL) THE STATION IS LOCATED 4-1/2 AIRLINE MILES SOUTHEAST OF COROZAL, 2 AIRLINE MILES WEST OF NARANJITO AND ON THE TOP OF A LOW HILL.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE NORTHEAST CORNER OF THE PLAZA IN COROZAL, GO NORTH AND EASTERLY ON HIGHWAY 159 FOR 0.9 MILE TO HIGHWAY 164.  TURN RIGHT AND GO SOUTHEAST ON HIGHWAY 164 FOR 1.75 MILES TO HIGHWAY 803.  KEEP LEFT AND CONTINUE SOUTHEAST ON HIGHWAY 164 FOR 1.8 MILES TO HIGHWAY 811.  BEAR RIGHT AND GO SOUTHEAST AND EAST ON HIGHWAY 811 FOR 1.9 MILES TO A FORK AT A SMALL STORE.  KEEP LEFT AND GO EAST ON A BLADED ROAD FOR 0.05 MILE TO A FORK, KEEP RIGHT AND CONTINUE EAST ON A BLADED ROAD FOR 0.05 MILE TO THE HOME OF SR. ALEJAR ALEZANDRO TORREZ ON THE RIGHT AND END OF TRUCK TRAVEL.  FROM HERE PACK SOUTHWEST UPHILL FOR ABOUT 100 YARDS TO THE TOP OF THE LOW HILL AND THE STATION ON THE HIGHEST POINT OF THE HILL.  THE STATION MARK IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED CED 1965, BRAZED TO THE TOP OF A 3 INCH ROUND CAST IRON SOIL PIPE WHICH PROJECTS 6 INCHES.  REFERENCE MARK 1 IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED CED NO 1 1965, BRAZED TO THE TOP OF A 3 INCH ROUND CAST IRON SOIL PIPE WHICH PROJECTS 4 INCHES.  REFERENCE MARK 2 IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED CED NO 2 1965, BRAZED TO THE TOP OF A 3 INCH ROUND CAST IRON SOIL PIPE WHICH PROJECTS 6 INCHES.  THE USGS BENCH MARK IS STAMPED CEDRO 1934, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A BOULDER WHICH PROJECTS 1 FOOT AND IT IS ABOUT 2 FEET LOWER THAN THE STATION.  NO AZIMUTH MARK WAS ESTABLISHED AT THIS STATION.
markers.setting: SET INTO TOP OF METAL PIPE DRIVEN INTO GROUND
markers.stability: MARK OF QUESTIONABLE OR UNKNOWN STABILITY

markers.description: BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1934 STATION IS LOCATED 9.5 KILOMETERS BY ROAD AND TRAIL SE OF COROZAL, ABOUT 4 KILOMETERS DIRECTLY W OF NARANJITO, IN BARRIO CEDRO ABAJO, ON A PROMINENT BARE PEAK ON THE HIGH RIDGE S OF THE MAIN CARRETERA BETWEEN COROZAL AND NARANJITO AND W OF THE HEAD OF RIO NARANJITO.  THERE IS ANOTHER POINT OF RIDGE PROJECTING ABOUT 400 METERS FARTHER TO THE N WHICH IS SOMEWHAT LOWER IN ELEVATION AND IS COVERED WITH PALMS AND TREES AND HAS A HOUSE AND SHEDS UPON IT.  THERE IS A LARGE ROYAL PALM 95 FEET S OF THE STATION, STANDING IN HEAD OF DRAW JUST BELOW TOP.  THERE ARE OTHER PALMS AND TREES GROWING IN THE DRAW LOWER DOWN BUT THEIR TOPS DO NOT PROJECT ABOVE THE HORIZON, SO THAT WHEN SEEN FROM A DISTANCE THE PEAK SEEMS TO HAVE A LONE ROYAL PALM GROWING UPON IT.  THE STATION IS 200 METERS E OF THE HOUSE OF NIEVES RIVERA, ON LAND OWNED BY A BROTHER, ESTANILAO RIVERA.  IT IS NEAR THE NW END OF THE SUMMIT AND 6 FEET N OF THE TRAIL WHICH CROSSES IT.  STATION MARK IS A STANDARD TABLET, STAMPED CEDRO 1934, CEMENTED IN TOP OF LARGE BOULDER SET IN GROUND.  REFERENCE MARK NO.1 IS A COPPER NAIL AND WASHER ON LONE ROYAL PALM TREE, 95.26 FEET FROM STATION IN TRUE AZIMUTH 08 DEG 09 MIN.  REFERENCE MARK NO.2 IS A CROSS CUT ON LARGE PROJECTING BOULDER ON W SLOPE ALONG TRAIL, 44.94 FEET FROM STATION IN TRUE AZIMUTH 115 DEG 58 MIN.  SIGNAL IS A QUADRIPOD OF LUMBER WITH BLACK CROSS-TARGETS CENTERED OVER STATION MARK.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM COROZAL, FOLLOW CARRETERA LEADING TO NARANJITO FOR 7 KILOMETERS TO CAMINO WHICH BRANCHES OFF CARRETERA AT LOMAS SCHOOL AT K 11.35.  TRUCK CAN BE TAKEN OVER CAMINO FOR ABOUT 0.4 KILOMETER TO HOUSE AND FROM THIS POINT THE TRAIL CONTINUES ON UP RIDGE AND AROUND HEAD OF SHORT CREEK TO THE STATION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1966)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JJL) THE STATION WAS RECOVERED AND FOUND IN POOR CONDITION.  STATION CED WAS ESTABLISHED AND A TIE WAS MADE TO CEDRO 1934.
markers.setting: SET IN A BOULDER
markers.stability: MAY HOLD, BUT OF TYPE COMMONLY SUBJECT TOSURFACE MOTION

markers.description: BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1934 STATION IS 6 KILOMETERS BY ROAD AND TRAIL, SW OF THE TOWN OF CEIBA, 2-1/2 KILOMETERS BY ROAD AND TRAIL, W OF A SETTLEMENT KNOWN AS QUEBRADA SECA AND ABOUT 4 KILOMETERS BY TRAIL N OF DAGUAO VILLAGE, ON THE HIGHEST POINT, AT N END OF A PROMINENT RIDGE LYING TO THE W OF THE CARRETERA BETWEEN CEIBA AND PLAYA NAGUABO AND E OF THE RIO DAGUAO, ON PROPERTY OF GABINO CRUZ, 70 METERS S OF HIS HOUSE.  STATION MARK IS A STANDARD U.S.G.S. TABLET STAMPED CEIBA 1934, CEMENTED IN A LARGE ROCK SET IN THE GROUND ON HIGHEST POINT OF SUMMIT.  REFERENCE MARKS ARE 1-INCH DRILL HOLES IN PROJECTING ROCKS IN PLACE.  NO.1 IS ON N SLOPE, 88 FEET (INCLINED MEASUREMENT) FROM STATION IN TRUE AZIMUTH 217 DEG 00 MIN.  NO.2 IS ON E SLOPE, 49.65 FEET FROM STATION IN TRUE AZIMUTH 305 DEG 30 MIN.  THE STATION CAN BE REACHED BY TRAIL FROM EITHER QUEBRADA SECA OR DAGUAO, BOTH OF WHICH ARE ON THE MAIN CARRETERA BETWEEN CIEBA AND PLAYA NAGUABO.  SIGNAL--A QUADRIPOD OF SAWED LUMBER WITH BLACK CROSS-TARGETS ON CENTER POLE.                            STATION RECOVERY (1940)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1940 STATION RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED IN GOOD CONDITION.  TO REACH FROM DAGUAO, LEAVE CAR AT N END OF CARRETERA BRIDGE OVER RIVER, WHERE A TRAIL DOUBLES BACK ALONG THE RIVER.  FOLLOW THIS TRAIL PAST SEVERAL HOUSES.  AT S CORNER OF HOUSE WITH METAL SIDES PAINTED YELLOW, ON RIGHT, TURN SHARPLY UP TRAIL THAT LOOKS LIKE A DRAIN, AND FOLLOW UP RIDGE TO TOP.                            STATION RECOVERY (1941)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1941 (RLS) STATION IS ABOUT 2-1/2 MILES SW OF THE TOWN OF CEIBA, ABOUT 1-1/4 MILES N OF DAGUAO, ABOUT 1 MILE WNW OF THE VILLAGE OF QUEBRADA SECA, ON TOP OF THE FIRST HIGH HILL W OF INSULAR HIGHWAY NO.3.  THE TOP OF THE HILL HAS 2 HIGH POINTS OF ABOUT THE SAME ELEVATION WITH A SADDLE BETWEEN.  THE STATION IS ON THE HIGHEST POINT OF THE NORTHERLY OF THESE 2 HIGH POINTS, ON PROPERTY OWNED BY GABINO CRUZ AND ABOUT 70 METERS SW OF HIS HOUSE.  THE STATION IS MARKED BY A U.S.G.S. STANDARD DISK STAMPED CEIBA 1934 AND CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A BOULDER ABOUT 10 INCHES SQUARE.  THE MARK PROJECTS ABOUT 3 INCHES ABOVE GROUND.  THE ELEVATION OF THE STATION IS ABOUT 320 METERS.  THERE IS NO UNDERGROUND MARK.  BOTH OLD REFERENCE MARKS WERE RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED BY THE U.S.G.S.  NEITHER IS VISIBLE FROM THE STATION WITHOUT CUTTING THROUGH A MALLA BUSH FENCE.  BOTH OLD REFERENCE MARKS ARE 1-INCH IN DIAMETER, DRILL HOLES IN THE TOP OF BOULDERS.  THE DISTANCES AND DIRECTIONS TO THEM WERE CHECKED APPROXIMATELY.  TWO NEW REFERENCE MARKS WERE SET.  REFERENCE MARK NO.3 (NOTE 12D) IS A U.S.C. AND G.S. STANDARD DISK STAMPED CEIBA USGS NO.3 1941.  IT IS ON THE NW SLOPE OF THE RIDGE EXTENDING SW FROM THE STATION, ON A SMALL BOULDER AND FLUSH WITH THE GROUND.  THE MARK IS 2.87 METERS LOWER THAN THE STATION.  REFERENCE MARK NO.4 (NOTE 12D) IS A U.S.C. AND G.S. STANDARD DISK STAMPED CEIBA USGS NO.4 1941.  IT IS ON THE N SLOPE OF THE HILL, ON TOP OF A BOULDER ABOUT 6 FEET IN DIAMETER.  THE BOULDER PROJECTS ABOUT 4 FEET ABOVE GROUND ON THE LOW SIDE AND IS FLUSH WITH GROUND ON THE HIGH SIDE.  THE MARK IS 5.82 METERS LOWER THAN THE STATION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1965)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1965 (JJL) THE STATION MARK, REFERENCE MARK NO. 3 AND REFERENCE MARK NO. 4 WERE RECOVERED AND FOUND IN GOOD CONDITION.  A SEARCH WAS MADE FOR REFERENCE MARK NO. 1 AND REFERENCE MARK NO. 2 BUT THEY WERE NOT RECOVERED.  A COMPLETE DESCRIPTION FOLLOWS--  THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 4-1/2 MILES NORTHEAST OF NAGUABO, 2-1/2 MILES SOUTHWEST OF CEIBA, 1 MILE NORTH OF DAGUAO, ON THE NORTH END AND HIGHEST POINT OF A PROMINENT RIDGE AND ON PROPERTY OWNED BY MR. LEO V. RUBIO.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE SOUTHEAST CORNER OF THE PLAZA IN CEIBA, GO SOUTHWEST ON HIGHWAY 3 FOR 2.2 MILES TO A SIDE ROAD RIGHT.  THIS IS ABOUT 200 FEET AFTER PASSING KILOMETER POST 61.3.  TURN RIGHT AND GO NORTHERLY FOR 0.4 MILE TO A Y-FORK.  TAKE THE LEFT FORK AND GO NORTHERLY FOR 0.4 MILE TO THE END OF THE ROAD AND THE END OF TRUCK TRAVEL.  PACK EAST ALONG A TRAIL FOR ABOUT 200 FEET TO A HOUSE.  THENCE BEAR LEFT AND FOLLOW THE TRAIL NORTHERLY FOR ABOUT 3/4 MILE TO THE HIGHEST POINT OF THE RIDGE AND THE STATION.  A 3/4 HOUR PACK.  THE STATION MARK, STAMPED CEIBA 1934, IS A U.S. GEOLOGICAL SURVEY DISK CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A BOULDER THAT PROJECTS 3 INCHES.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 3, STAMPED CEIBA USGS NO 3 1941, IS A STANDARD DISK CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A BOULDER THAT PROJECTS 2 INCHES AND IS ABOUT 10 FEET LOWER THAN THE STATION.  (NOTE 12C)  REFERENCE MARK NO. 4, STAMPED CEIBA USGS NO 4 1941, IS A STANDARD DISK CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A BOULDER THAT IS 3 INCHES BELOW THE SURFACE OF THE GROUND AND IS ABOUT 15 FEET LOWER THAN THE STATION.  (NOTE 12C)  NO SUITABLE LOCATION FOR AN AZIMUTH MARK.  AIRLINE DISTANCE AND DIRECTION FROM NEAREST TOWN 1 MILE NORTH OF DAGUAO.                            STATION RECOVERY (1973)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1973 (JGC) STATION MARK, REFERENCE MARK 3 AND REFERENCE MARK 4 WERE RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED IN 1965.  THE STATION MARK AND REFERENCE MARK 4 ARE IN FAIR CONDITION, REFERENCE MARK 3 IS IN EXCELLENT CONDITION.  AIRLINE DISTANCE AND DIRECTION FROM NEAREST TOWN 1 MILE NORTH OF DAGUAO.                            STATION RECOVERY (1978)  RECOVERY NOTE BY DEFENSE MAP AGENCY 1978 (WVM) CEIBA 1934 GOOD  REFERENCE MARKS NOT SEARCHED FOR.  HILL IS BADLY OVERGROWN.  NO SIGN OF HOUSE 70 METERS FROM STATION AS DESCRIBED BY R.L.S. IN 1941.
markers.setting: SET IN A BOULDER
markers.stability: MAY HOLD, BUT OF TYPE COMMONLY SUBJECT TOSURFACE MOTION

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1941 (RLS) THIS INTERSECTION STATION IS AT CEIBA, ABOUT AT THE CENTER OF TOWN, NEAR THE CENTER OF THE TOWN PLAZA, AND ON THE SAN ANTONIA CATHOLIC CHURCH.  THE CHURCH IS A YELLOW-MASONRY STRUCTURE AND HAS A BELFRY WITH A RED-PYRAMIDAL ROOF AT THE E END.  THE CROSS IS AT THE TIP OF THE BELFRY.  THE STATION IS THE CENTER OF THE BASE OF THE CROSS.                            STATION RECOVERY (1961)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1961 (MLO) STATION RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED.

BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1939 (HAC) STATION IS THE TALL CONCRETE STACK AT THE CEMENT MILL LOCATED ABOUT 2-1/2 MILES S OF CATANO.  THIS MILL WAS ERECTED DURING 1938.                            STATION RECOVERY (1962)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1962 (MLO) THE STATION WAS RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED.  THERE ARE NOW FOUR STACKS AT THIS MILL.  THE STATION IS THE OLDEST STACK, WHICH IS THE SOUTHEASTERLY ONE OF A GROUP OF THREE.                            STATION RECOVERY (1964)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1964 (GWM) THE MILL IS ABOUT 1/2 MILE W OF HIGHWAY INTERCHANGE ON ROUTE 2 ON ROAD TO CATANO.  THE STACK IS THE SHORTEST OF 4 LOCATED BEHIND A LARGE PAPER PLANT OF THE PUERTO RICO CONTAINER CO.  A COMPLETE DESCRIPTION FOLLOWS--  ABOUT 2-1/2 MILES S OF CATANO, ABOUT 1/2 MILE W OF HIGHWAY INTERCHANGE, ROUTE 2 AND ROAD TO CATANO.  THERE ARE 4 STACKS IN THE VICINITY.  STATION IS THE OLDEST AND SHORTEST STACK NEAR PUERTO RICO CONTAINER CO.
PTIVE TEXT AVAILABLE.

BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1982 (JCL) THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 8 KM (5 MI) NORTHEAST OF PONCE AND APPROXIMATELY ON LINE WITH THE DIVERSION TUNNEL AT THE CERRILLOS DAM. THIS STATION WILL BE DESTROYED DURING EXCAVATION FOR THE DAM.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE JUNCTION OF HIGHWAYS 14 AND 139 ABOUT 4 KM (2-1/2 MI) NORTHEAST OF PONCE, GO NORTHWEST ON HIGHWAY 139 FOR 0.5 KM (0.3 MI) TO A CROSS STREET AT THE JUNCTION OF HIGHWAY 505.  TURN RIGHT AND GO NORTHEAST ON HIGHWAY 139 FOR 3.1 KM (1.95 MI) TO A FORK. KEEP RIGHT FORK DOWN GRADE ON HIGHWAY 139 FOR 3.5 KM (2.2 MI) TO THE CORPS OF ENGINEERS SOIL TESTING LABORATORY ON THE LEFT. CONTINUE AHEAD FOR 0.2 KM (0.1 MI) TO A FIELD ENTRANCE ON THE RIGHT.  TURN SHARP RIGHT ACROSS FIELD FOR 0.2 KM (0.1 MI) TO A CREEK CROSSING.  CROSS CREEK AND TURN RIGHT ON DIRT ROAD FOR 0.3 KM (0.2 MI) TO A REVERSE FORK LEFT. TURN SHARP LEFT ON DIRT ROAD FOR 0.08 KM (0.05 MI) TO A 3-WAY FPRK.  TAKE CENTER ONE OF THREE ROADS FOR 0.8 KM (0.5 MI) TO END OF TRUCK TRAVEL AT SMALL PROMONTORY AND STEEP SLOPE ON EACH SIDE. PACK 20 METERS TO PROMONTORY AND STATION ON THE OTHER SIDE.  THE STATION IS A STANDARD NGS DISK STAMPED---CENTER 1982---, EPOXIED TO THE TOP OF A 1/2 INCH STEEL ROD DRIVEN 0.5 METER TO ROCK, SURROUNDED BY A CONCRETE FILLED PLASTIC TILE 25 CM IN DIAMETER AND PROJECTING 4 CM ABOVE THE GROUND.  IT IS LOCATED 6.1 METERS (20 FT) WEST FROM THE TOP OF THE ROCK PROMONTORY AND 8 FEET LOWER THAN THE PROMONTORY.  REFERENCE MARK NUMBER 1 IS A STANDARD NGS DISK STAMPED ---CENTER NO 1 1982---, EPOXIED TO THE TOP OF A 1/2 INCH STEEL ROD DRIVEN 0.5 METER TO ROCK, SURROUNDED BY A CONCRETE FILLED PLASTIC TILE 25 CM IN DIAMETER AND PROJECTING 6 CM ABOVE THE GROUND.  IT IS LOCATED 12.2 METERS (40 FT) WEST FROM THE TOP OF THE ROCK PROMONTORY AND 13 FEET LOWER THAN THE PROMONTORY.  MARK IS BELOW STATION 1.5 METERS.  REFERENCE MARK NUMBER 2 IS A STANDARD NGS DISK STAMPED ---CENTER NO 2 1982---, SET INTO A PARTIAL DRILL HOLE IN A SHALLOW VEE OF ROCK OUTCROP AND BUILT UP WITH CEMENT.  IT IS LOCATED 1.8 METERS (6 FT) SOUTH FROM THE TOP OF THE ROCKY PROMONTORY AND 3 FEET LOWER THAN THE PROMONTORY.  MARK IS ABOVE STATION 1.5 METERS.  HEIGHT OF LIGHT ABOVE STATION MARK WAS 1.5 METERS.  NO MEASUREMENT BETWEEN REFERENCE MARKS BECAUSE OF STEEP SLOPE.  NO AZIMUTH MARK FOR THIS STATION.
markers.setting: METAL ROD DRIVEN INTO GROUND. SEE TEXT FOR ADDITIONAL
markers.stability: MARK OF QUESTIONABLE OR UNKNOWN STABILITY

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1900 (SF) TALL HEXAGONAL CHIMNEY.  VERY BLACK TOP.  NEAR HOUSE AS IN 3 EXCEPT ROOF IS TIN COLOR.  WELL BUILT HOUSE, RED WINDOWS AND DOORS.  VERY NEAR SHORE.                            STATION RECOVERY (1970)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1970 (JKW) STATION LOST.  NO CHIMNEY WAS IN ITS PLOTTED POSITION.
BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (DCW) THIS STACK HAS BEEN REMOVED, BUT THE CONCRETE BASE OF THE STACK REMAINS IN GOOD CONDITION.  THE CENTER OF THE BASE WAS USED BY THIS SURVEY.

BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1934 STATION IS THE CENTER OF LARGE BRICK STACK OF A SUGAR FACTORY SITUATED 4 MILES S OF ARECIBO NEAR ARECIBO RIVA.                            STATION RECOVERY (1942)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1942 (GBG) RECOVERED.  CENTER OF THE LARGE, BROWN, BRICK STACK OF THIS CENTRAL, 150 METERS NE OF THE ARECIBO RIVER BRIDGE OF THE AMERICAN RAILROAD, AND 2-1/2 MILES SE OF ARECIBO.

BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1934 POINTED SIGHTED--LARGEST BLACK STEEL STACK.                            STATION RECOVERY (1941)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1941 (GBG) A VERY TALL, GREY STEEL STACK AT THE CENTRAL CANOVANAS, N OF THE TOWN OF THAT NAME.                            STATION RECOVERY (1964)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1964 (GWM) A NEW GREY CONCRETE STACK HAS BEEN BUILT N OF WHERE THE OLD BLACK STEEL ONE WAS.  A TRAVERSE BETWEEN THE TWO IS QUITE POSSIBLE.  A NEW DESCRIPTION FOLLOWS.  A TALL GREY CONCRETE STACK BUILT AROUND 1950 AT CENTRAL CANOVANAS SUGAR MILL.  THE STACK TOP HAS PAINTED TRIANGLES.

BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1934 STEEL STACK, S OF CARRI BLANCO.                            STATION RECOVERY (1970)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1970 (JKW) STATION LOST.  NO STACK COULD BE FOUND AT THE PLOTTED POSITION OF THIS STATION.
BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1934 STATION IS THE BLACK STEEL STACK IN CENTRAL COLOSO.

BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1934 POINT SIGHTED UPON WAS THE BLACK STEEL STACK.                            STATION RECOVERY (1941)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1941 (GBG) RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED.
BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1934 STATION WAS RECOVERED.

BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1934 STATION IS THE BLACK STEEL STACK OF THE CENTRAL DEFENSA, CAUGUAS SUGAR COMPANY, AT CAUGUAS.                            STATION RECOVERY (1941)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1941 (GBG) NOT RECOVERED.  PROBABLY DESTROYED.

BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1934 STATION WAS A FLAG ON THE HIGHEST OF A SERIES OF WOODED POINTS ABOUT 2 MILES E OF TRIANGULATION STATION DESCANSO, AND 6 MILES N OF THE TOWN OF SAN GERMAN.  TREE IS ALSO MARKED BY WIRE NAILS, ONE OF WHICH IS CENTERED ON A TRIANGLE BLAZED ON THE TRUNK.

BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1982 (JCL) THE STATION, CERRO MARAVILLAS TELEVISION WLUZ TOWER, IS LOCATED ABOUT 17 KM (10-1/2 MI) NORTHEAST OF PONCE, 8 KM (12-1/2 MI) SOUTHEAST OF JAYUYA, 10.7 KM (6-3/4 MI) BY ROAD EAST OF THE JUNCTION OF HIGHWAYS 139 AND 143, 0.1 KM NORTHEAST OF THE JUNCTION OF HIGHWAYS 577 AND 143, ON MARAVILLAS MOUNTAIN, AND IN THE PROXIMITY OF OLD DESTROYED MARAVILLAS TV WSOR MAST.  STATION IS THE LIGHT ATOP THE POLE MOUNTED AT THE APEX OF A 3-LEGGED TUBULAR STRUCTURE PAINTED RED AND WHITE, AND 440 FEET IN HEIGHT.  A SHORTER 4-LEGGED MICROWAVE AND TV TOWER ARE ON THE SAME RIDGE.

BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1934 THIS STATION IS ON THE SECOND MOUNTAIN OF RIDGE PROJECTING N FROM MAIN RIDGE N OF ADJUNTAS-JAYUYA ROAD AT KILOMETER 9 H 2.  IT IS WOODED ON ALL SIDES EXCEPT TO THE S.  IT IS ON LAND OF ABRAHAM IRIZARRY ON BO. CONCEJ OF UTUADA.  STATION IS MARKED BY THREE 6-INCH TRIANGLES WITH NAIL AND WASHERS.  FROM KILOMETERS 9 H 2 OF ROAD, TAKE ENTRANCE TO VICTOR AUFFANTA FARM 2 MILES N, FOLLOW HORSE TRAIL NE UPHILL TO JAUCA TO TOP OF RIDGE, FOLLOW (HORSE TRAIL) RIDGE N TO TOP OF THE MOUNTAIN WHERE ON A CLEARING IS A LAUREL TREE WHICH IS THE STATION.
markers.setting: UNSPECIFIED SETTING

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1900 (JN) STATION IS ON THE FIRST HILL ONE MEETS GOING W FROM GUANICA AND IS ABOUT 3/4 OF A MILE FROM THE INSIDE EDGE OF PENONES POINT ISLAND.  STATION IS A LITTLE N OF A LINE DRAWN FROM GUANICA TO MARIQUITA.  THE HILL IS ON THE PLANTATION OF AMERIGO FAVIANI.  THE STATION MARK IS A PIECE OF BRASS ROD, ABOUT 4 INCHES LONG AND ABOUT 1/2 INCH IN DIAMETER.  THIS IS SET IN CEMENT.  AS THERE WAS SO MUCH LOOSE BROKEN STONE ABOUT, WE HAD TO GO ABOUT 10 INCHES BELOW THE SURFACE TO BEGIN TO MAKE THE HOLE FOR THE BOLT.  THIS HOLE WAS AFTERWARDS FILLED IN LOOSELY WITH STONES.  ONE REFERENCE MARK IS A CROSS, CUT IN A LARGE BOULDER (ABOUT 3-1/2 FEET HIGH ROUGHLY PYRAMIDAL IN SHAPE) ABOUT 2 FEET SQUARE ON TOP AND ABOUT 3.5 BY 3.5 FEET AT BASE.  STONE ABOUT S BY E FROM STATION AND CENTER OF CROSS ABOUT 3 FEET ABOVE GROUND.  THE OTHER MARK IS A WIRE NAIL DRIVEN IN THE TOP OF SMALL GUAYACAN (LIGNUM VITAE) BUTT.  THE TOP OF THIS GUAYACAN TREE WAS SAWED OFF ABOUT 20 INCHES ABOVE SURFACE OF GROUND.  THE GUAYACAN BUTT BEARS ABOUT NNE FROM STATION CENTER AND IS ABOUT 4 INCHES IN DIAMETER.  DISTANCE OF NAIL TO PLUMB LINE HELD OVER STATION MARK IS 0.966 METERS.  DISTANCE OF CENTER OR CROSS IN ROCK FROM STATION IS 1.885 METERS.  A LITTLE TO THE LEFT OF A LINE FROM STATION TO CABO ROJO LIGHTHOUSE, WAS A BUNCH OF ABOUT SIX BUSHES GROWING TOGETHER AND IN THE PROCESS OF CLEARING THE TOPS OF THESE BUSHES WERE CUT OFF.  AFTERWARDS ON THE ONE NEAREST TO THE STATION A SMALL BLAZE WAS MADE AT A HEIGHT OF ABOUT 4.5 FEET ABOVE GROUND AND IN THE BLAZE THREE TACKS WERE DRIVEN SO AS TO FORM A TRIANGLE.  THE DISTANCE FROM TRIANGLE TO STATION IS 3.82 METERS.  THE BEST WAY TO REACH STATION BY LAND IS TO FOLLOW THE ROAD LEADING FROM GUANICA TOWARDS LAJAS, LEAVING IT AT THE BY-ROAD TURNING IN TO FAVIANIS HOUSE.  THE RELATION OF THE HILL AND PENONES POINT (AND ISLAND) AS SHOWN BY THE PLANE TABLE SHEET WILL IDENTIFY THE HILL AT ONCE, AS THEY ARE NEAR, AND THE HILL IS VERY BALD AS SEEN FROM THE S SIDE.  THE STATION IS NOT ON THE VERY HIGHEST POINT.  SOME ROUGH MASSES OF STONE ABOUT 20 FEET AWAY BEING ABOUT 4 OR 5 FEET HIGHER.  ABAD PARDILLA OF GUANICA AND JOSE BAIS AND JOSE TORADO PARGUERA KNOW THE SITUATION OF THE STATION AND MARK.                            STATION RECOVERY (1934)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1934 STATION COULD NOT BE FOUND.  NEW STATION CERRO VERTERO 2 ESTABLISHED.
markers.setting: OBJECT SURROUNDED BY MASS OF CONCRETE
markers.stability: MARK OF QUESTIONABLE OR UNKNOWN STABILITY

markers.description: BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1934 STATION IS LOCATED 12 KILOMETERS SE OF LAJAS, ON ONE OF THE PEAKS IN THE RANGE BORDERING THE COAST, WHICH LIES BETWEEN THE CARRETERA FROM LAJAS TO GUANICA AND THE COAST, AND IS ALMOST DUE N OF THE MIDDLE OF MATEI ISLAND.  THE PEAK IS FARTHER TO THE S THAN THE GENERAL RANGE AND IS CONSIDERABLY HIGHER THAN THE OTHERS IN SAME LOCALITY.  THE PEAK IS CLEAR ON THE E END BUT HAS MUCH BRUSH ON N, S, AND W SIDES, ALSO SCATTERED AMASIGO TREES.  STATION IS ABOUT 10 FEET S OF A LARGE PROJECTING LIMESTONE ROCK WHICH IS HIGHEST POINT ON PEAK.  STATION IS MARKED BY A STANDARD U.S.G.S. TABLET, STAMPED CERRO VERTERO-2 1934, CEMENTED IN THE TOP OF A FLAT ROCK WHICH PROJECTS ONLY SLIGHTLY ABOVE GROUND.  REFERENCE MARK NO.1 IS A COPPER NAIL AND WASHER IN TRIANGULAR BLAZE ON AN AMASIGO TREE, 122.9 FEET FROM STATION IN TRUE AZIMUTH 156 DEG 07 MIN.  REFERENCE MARK NO.2 IS A SHARP POINT OF LARGE ROCK PROJECTING ABOUT 3 FEET ABOVE GROUND, 15.48 FEET FROM STATION MARK IN TRUE AZIMUTH 233 DEG 03 MIN.  REFERENCE MARK NO.3 IS A CROSS CUT ON THE N FACE OF A LARGE BOULDER, 6.28 FEET FROM STATION IN TRUE AZIMUTH 345 DEG 34 MIN.  TO REACH STATION, FOLLOW LAJAS-GUANICA ROAD TO A TIENDA ON N SIDE OF ROAD AT ABOUT KILOMETER 16, TURN RIGHT (S) ON CART ROAD AND FOLLOW IT TO GATE ON PRIVATE LANE W, TO LECHERIA, FOLLOW THIS PRIVATE ROAD PAST LECHERIA AND ON TO FOOT OF MOUNTAIN.  THERE IS ANOTHER ROAD WHICH TURNS OFF AT ABOUT KILOMETER 15 WHICH LEADS TO MATEI ISLAND AND CONNECTS WITH THE ONE WHICH TURNS OFF AT THE TIENDA.  SIGNAL--A QUADRIPOD OF SAWED LUMBER COVERED WITH WHITE CLOTH, WITH BLACK CROSS TARGETS ON CENTER POLE.  CENTERED OVER STATION MARK.                            STATION RECOVERY (1952)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1952 (JOP) STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 7 MI. S OF THE TOWN OF LAJAS, ABOUT 3 MI. NE OF THE VILLAGE OF LA PARGUERA, AND ON A HIGH ROCKY HILL JUST N OF SEVERAL LARGE SALT EVAPORATORS.  IT IS A STANDARD U.S.G.S. TRIANGULATION BENCH-MARK DISK, STAMPED CERRO VERTERO 2 1934 AND SET IN CONCRETE IN A DRILL HOLE IN OUTCROPPING BEDROCK, WHICH IS PARALLELED ON THE E AND W SIDES BY TWO OTHER OUTCROPPINGS THAT ARE ABOUT 3 FT. HIGHER THAN THE STATION AND ABOUT 10 FT. APART.  REFERENCE MARK 1 IS ABOUT 5 FT. LOWER THAN THE STATION MARK.  IT IS A STANDARD REFERENCE-MARK DISK, STAMPED CERRO VERTERO 2 NO 1 1934 AND SET IN THE TOP OF A CONCRETE POST.  REFERENCE MARK 2 IS ABOUT 2 FT. LOWER THAN THE STATION MARK.  IT IS A STANDARD REFERENCE-MARK DISK, STAMPED CERRO VERTERO 2 NO 2 1934 AND SET IN THE TOP OF A CONCRETE POST.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE SE CORNER OF THE PLAZA IN LAJAS, GO S ON THE MAIN ROAD TO LA PARGUERA FOR 5.8 MI. TO A T-ROAD LEFT, TURN LEFT AND GO 1.2 MI. TO THE END OF THE PAVEMENT AND A DIRT ROAD BEARING LEFT, FOLLOW THE DIRT ROAD FOR 0.5 MI. TO SOME SALT EVAPORATORS, TURN LEFT THEN RIGHT AROUND THE EVAPORATORS FOLLOWING THE DIRT ROAD FOR 0.4 MI. TO A LANE LEFT, TURN LEFT AND GO 0.5 MI. UP A LANE TO A GATE RIGHT, TURN RIGHT THROUGH THE GATE AND GO 0.2 MI. TO A FENCE LINE AND END OF TRUCK TRAVEL, FROM HERE PACK LEFT UP ALONG A FENCE LINE TO THE TOP OF A HILL AND STATION AS DESCRIBED.  HEIGHT OF LIGHT ABOVE STATION MARK - 1 M.                            STATION RECOVERY (1956)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1956 (EAT) THE STATION WAS RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED IN THE 1952 DESCRIPTION WITH THE FOLLOWING EXCEPTION.  THE REFERENCE MARKS WERE FOUND IN BOULDERS INSTEAD OF CONCRETE POSTS AS STATED IN THE 1952 DESCRIPTION.  THE STATION MARK AND R.M. 2 HAVE BEEN SOMEWHAT DEFACED BUT THE STAMPINGS ARE STILL LEGIBLE AND THE MARKS ARE OTHERWISE IN GOOD CONDITION.  THE MEASUREMENTS TO MARKS WERE NOT CHECKED AS THE STATION WAS NOT OCCUPIED.                            STATION RECOVERY (1966)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JWC) THE STATION WAS RECOVERED AND ALL MARKS WERE FOUND IN GOOD CONDITION.  A COMPLETE NEW DESCRIPTION OF THE STATION FOLLOWS.  THE STATION IS LOCATED ON A HIGH ROCK COVERED HILL 8 AIRLINE MILES SOUTH-SOUTHEAST OF SAN GERMAN AND 5 AIRLINE MILES WEST OF ENSENADA.  TO REACH FROM THE INTERSECTION OF HIGHWAYS 116, 117 AND 315 ABOUT 1 MILE SOUTHEAST OF LAJAS, GO SOUTH AND EAST ON HIGHWAY 116 FOR 3.1 MILES TO HIGHWAY 304.  TURN RIGHT AND GO SOUTH ON HIGHWAY 304 FOR 1.2 MILES TO A SIDE ROAD LEFT.  TURN LEFT AND GO EASTERLY ON HIGHWAY 324 FOR 2.65 MILES TO A GATE ON THE LEFT.  TURN LEFT AND PASS THROUGH THE GATE AND GO NORTH AND NORTHWEST ON A DIM TRACK ROAD FOR 0.25 MILE TO THE BASE OF THE HIGH HILL AT A LARGE BOULDER AND END OF TRUCK TRAVEL.  FROM HERE PACK WESTERLY UPHILL FOR ABOUT 20 MINUTES TO THE HIGHEST POINT OF THE ROCK COVERED HILL AND THE STATION.  THE STATION MARK IS A U.S. GEOLOGICAL SURVEY BENCH MARK DISK STAMPED CERRO VERTERO 2 1934, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A BOULDER WHICH PROJECTS 5 INCHES.  REFERENCE MARK 1 IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED CERRO VERTERO 2 NO 1 1934, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A BOULDER WHICH PROJECTS 10 INCHES.  REFERENCE MARK 2 IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED CERRO VERTERO 2 NO 2 1934, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A BOULDER WHICH PROJECTS 1 FOOT.  NO AZIMUTH MARK WAS ESTABLISHED AT THIS STATION.  AIRLINE DISTANCE AND DIRECTION FROM NEAREST TOWN 5 MILES SOUTHEAST OF LAJAS.                            STATION RECOVERY (1966)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JMC) STA, RM 2 AND CROSS ON ROCK RECOVERED.
markers.setting: SET IN ROCK OUTCROP
markers.stability: MOST RELIABLE AND EXPECTED TO HOLDPOSITION/ELEVATION WELL

markers.description: BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1934 STATION IS ON A PROMINENT SHARP PEAK OF THE MAIN DIVIDE OF PUERTO RICO, 4 KILOMETERS W OF PLACE WHERE ADJUNTAS-PONCE ROAD CROSSES MOUNTAINS.  IT IS ON THE LIMITS OF THE PROPERTIES OF GUILLARMO MORALES AND GUILLARMO SHUCK.  PEAK IS ROCKY BUT COVERED BY SOME VEGETATION TO S AND W.  FROM KILOMETER 24 OF PONCE-ADJUNTAS ROAD, FOLLOW THE DIVIDE W ALONG A TRAIL CROSSING THE PROPERTY OF LUIS PRINCIPE TO THE PROPERTY OF MANUEL RAFUCCI, THEN ALONG THE DIVIDE PARTICULARLY S TO PEAK.  PEAK IS KNOWN AS CARROTE DA PANUELAS.  STATION MARK IS A STANDARD U.S.G.S. TABLET SET ON ROCK BY CEMENT.  REFERENCE MARK NO.1 IS A BRONZE NAIL AND WASHER SET ON ROCK TO N OF STATION, 2.34 METERS IN TRUE AZIMUTH 147 DEG 23 MIN.  REFERENCE MARK NO.2 IS A STANDARD TABLET CEMENTED IN NATURAL ROCK, 9.27 METERS FROM STATION W IN TRUE AZIMUTH 211 DEG 19 MIN.
markers.setting: SET IN UNSPECIFIED ROCK OR BOULDER
markers.stability: PROBABLY HOLD POSITION/ELEVATION WELL

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JWC) THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 5-1/4 MILES SOUTH OF AGUADA, 5-1/4 MILES SOUTHEAST OF RINCON, 4-1/2 MILES NORTHWEST OF ANASCO AND ON THE TOP OF A MOUNTAIN THAT IS LOCALLY KNOWN AS PICO ATALAYA.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE SOUTHEAST CORNER OF THE PLAZA IN RINCON, GO SOUTH FOR 1 BLOCK.  TURN LEFT AND GO EAST AND SOUTHEAST ON HIGHWAY 412 FOR 5.35 MILES TO A Y-FORK, AT THE JUNCTION WITH HIGHWAY 411.  TAKE THE LEFT FORK AND GO SOUTHEAST UP A HILL, ON A DIRT ROAD FOR 0.3 MILE TO A Y-FORK.  TAKE THE RIGHT FORK AND GO SOUTHEAST ON A DIRT ROAD FOR 0.05 MILE TO A Y-FORK.  TAKE THE LEFT FORK AND GO 0.1 MILE TO THE STATION ON THE TOP OF THE HILL JUST WEST OF THE WAPA TELEVISION STATION.  THE STATION MARK IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED CHANNEL 1966, SET IN THE TOP OF A 12-INCH SQUARE CONCRETE POST THAT IS FLUSH WITH THE GROUND AND IS ON THE WEST SLOPE OF THE HILL.  IT IS 46 FEET WEST OF THE NORTHWEST CORNER OF THE WAPA TELEVISION STATION BUILDING.  REFERENCE MARK 1 IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED CHANNEL NO 1 1966, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN THE CONCRETE FOUNDATION OF A TELEVISION MAST.  IT IS 23 FEET SOUTHWEST OF THE NORTHWEST CORNER OF THE BUILDING AND 4 FEET HIGHER THAN THE STATION MARK.  REFERENCE MARK A IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED CHANNEL RM A 1966, SET IN THE TOP OF A 12-INCH SQUARE CONCRETE POST THAT IS FLUSH WITH THE GROUND.  IT IS 89 FEET NORTHWEST OF THE NORTHWEST CORNER OF THE BUILDING AND ON THE NORTHWEST SLOPE OF THE HILL.  NO SUITABLE PLACE WAS FOUND FOR AN AZIMUTH MARK.
markers.setting: SET IN TOP OF CONCRETE MONUMENT
markers.stability: MAY HOLD, BUT OF TYPE COMMONLY SUBJECT TOSURFACE MOTION

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JWC) THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 5 MILES SOUTH OF AGUADA, 5-1/4 MILES SOUTHEAST OF RINCON, 4-1/2 MILES NORTHWEST OF ANASCO AND ON THE TOP OF A MOUNTAIN THAT IS LOCALLY KNOWN AS PICO ATALAYA.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE SOUTHEAST CORNER OF THE PLAZA IN RINCON, GO SOUTH FOR 1 BLOCK. TAKE THE LEFT FORK AND GO 0.1 MILE TO THE STATION ON THE TOP OF THE HILL, JUST NORTHWEST OF THE WAPA TELEVISION STATION.  THE STATION MARK IS A STANDARD REFERENCE MARK DISK STAMPED CHANNEL RM A 1966, SET IN THE TOP OF A 12-INCH SQUARE CONCRETE POST THAT IS FLUSH WITH THE GROUND.  IT IS 89 FEET NORTHWEST OF THE NORTHWEST CORNER OF THE WAPA TELEVISION STATION BUILDING.                            STATION RECOVERY (2000)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US POWER SQUADRON 2000 (RVH) REFERENCE 'WAPA' OBSOLETE SINCE STATION IS NOW KNOWN AS 'CHANNEL 12'.   FROM SOUTHEAST CORNER OF PLAZA IN RINCON, GO SOUTH 1 BLOCK.TURN LEFT AND GO EAST AND SOUTHEAST ON HWY. 412 FOR 5.3 MI., AND 300' PAST JUNCTION WITH HWY.411 TO A Y-FORK. BEAR LEFT AND GO 0.3 MI. SOUTH, UP A STEEP HILL TO A Y-FORK. BEAR RIGHT AND GO SOUTHEAST 0.05 MI TO Y-FORK. BEAR LEFT AND TRAVEL PAST GATE, 0.1 MI. TO STATION.

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1899 (WCH) STATION IS SITUATED ON A HILL OF THE SAME NAME ABOUT TWO MILES W OF GUAYAMA AND IS ABOUT 1500 FEET ABOVE SEA LEVEL.  IT IS ON A BARE RIDGE WITH THE EXCEPTION OF A SINGLE TREE ABOUT 30 FEET W OF THE STATION.  A STUB 18 INCHES LONG BY FIVE INCHES IN DIAMETER WAS SET IN THE GROUND AND A TACK IN THE STUB MARKS THE CENTER OF THE STATION.  THE STUB PROJECTS ABOUT 4 INCHES ABOVE THE GROUND.  A PILE OF ROCKS WAS PLACED ABOUT THE STUB TO PROTECT IT.  LATER, MARKED BY AN IRON PIPE SET IN CEMENT.                            STATION RECOVERY (1926)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1926 (GCM) STATION RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED.  PIPE SET IN CEMENT SURROUNDED BY PILE OF ROCKS.  STATION IN GOOD CONDITION.  THE RIDGE IS COVERED WITH LONG TROPICAL GRASS AND THE TREE MENTIONED IN THE ORIGINAL DESCRIPTION IS NO LONGER THERE.  THE PILE OF ROCKS SURROUNDING THE STATION IS THE ONLY PILE ON THE BARE RIDGE AND CAN EASILY BE FOUND ON THE HIGHEST POINT.                            STATION RECOVERY (1934)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1934 ORIGINAL DESCRIPTION RATHER VAGUE.  THIS STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 2 MILES W OF THE TOWN OF GUAYAMA, ON A BARE HILL WHICH IS ABOUT 1500 FEET ABOVE SEA LEVEL, AND WHICH IS IN A NORTHERLY DIRECTION FROM PRESADA MELANIA.  THE STATION IS ON THE PROPERTY OF GENARO CAUTINO.  ORIGINAL STATION MARK, APPARENTLY UNDISTURBED, WAS FOUND IN GOOD CONDITION.  A NAIL WAS SET IN CONCRETE IN THE TUBE.  REFERENCE MARK NO.1 IS A CROSS ON BOULDER, 22 FEET 7 INCHES FROM STATION IN TRUE AZIMUTH 96 DEGREES 23 MINUTES.  REFERENCE MARK NO.2 IS A CROSS ON BOULDER, 21 FEET 11-3/4 INCHES FROM STATION IN TRUE AZIMUTH 182 DEGREES 50 MINUTES.  THE BEST WAY TO REACH THIS STATION IS TO TAKE CAMINO POZO HONDO AND RIDE ALL THE WAY TO THE END OF THIS RURAL ROAD.  WALK ABOUT 1/4 MILE IN AN EASTERLY DIRECTION TO THE TURN OF THE TRAIL.  CROSS THE RIVER AND FOLLOW A TRAIL EASTERLY UP TO THE MOUNTAIN.  THIS IS THE BEST POSSIBLE WAY TO GO.                            STATION RECOVERY (1967)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL OCEAN SERVICE 1967 STATION FOUND AS DESCRIBED BY USGS IN 1934.  DUE TO BRUSH COVER STATION IS DIFFICULT TO LOCATE.  SUGGEST USE OF LOCAL GUIDE WHO KNOWS LOCATION OF STATION.  PARTY WITH LOCAL GUIDE APPROACHED THE STATION FROM THE S.E..  PACKING TIME APPROXIMATELY 2 HOURS THROUGH HEAVY BRUSH.
markers.setting: SET INTO TOP OF METAL PIPE DRIVEN INTO GROUND
markers.stability: MARK OF QUESTIONABLE OR UNKNOWN STABILITY

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1900 (JBB) THIS STATION IS ON THE POINT BETWEEN THE BAYS CALLED TARGET BAY AND FIREWOOD BAY.  CALLED LOCALLY PUNTA DEL TAMARINDO LE HICO.  IT IS SOME 12 FEET N OF EDGE OF A SMALL CLIFF AND DIRECTLY S OF W SIDE OF A SHALLOW POND SOME 50 METERS AWAY.  THE RUINED STONE HEARTH OF A NATIVE SHACK LIES SOME 10 METERS TO THE EASTWARD.  STATION IS MARKED BY POINT OF A NAIL SET IN PUDDLE OF CEMENT.  A PILE OF STONES SOME 2 FEET HIGH WAS ERECTED OVER THE STATION.  A TRIPOD SIGNAL WAS ERECTED OVER THIS POINT.                            STATION RECOVERY (1904)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1904 (RLF) STATION MARK WAS DESTROYED.  A TRIPOD SIGNAL HAD BEEN ERECTED BY OBSERVERS OF THE U.S. NAVY AT A POINT SOME 10 METERS SW OF THE DESCRIBED LOCATION.

BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JJL) THE STATION IS LOCATED 6 AIRLINE MILES NORTHEAST OF MANATI, 5 AIRLINE MILES NORTHWEST OF VEGA BAJA AND ON THE TOP OF A LOW TIMBERED HILL.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE FIRE STATION ON TORTUGERO USNG MILITARY RESERVATION, GO NORTH ON A PAVED ROAD PASSING THROUGH A GUARD GATE FOR 1.85 MILES TO A CROSSROAD.  CONTINUE STRAIGHT AHEAD FOR 0.05 MILE TO A LOCKED GATE.  (KEY MAY BE OBTAINED FROM THE FIRE STATION MENTIONED ABOVE) PASS THROUGH THE GATE AND GO NORTH ON A PAVED ROAD FOR 0.25 MILE CROSSING A AIRSTRIP TO THE NORTH EDGE OF THE AIRSTRIP.  CONTINUE STRAIGHT AHEAD PASSING TO THE WEST OF A LOW MOUND OF DIRT AND GO NORTHERLY ACROSS COUNTRY FOR 0.25 MILE TO THE BASE OF THE LOW TIMBERED HILL AND END OF TRUCK TRAVEL.  FROM HERE PACK NORTH UPHILL FOR ABOUT 100 YARDS TO THE TOP OF THE HILL AND THE STATION.  THE STATION MARK IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED CHIVATO 1965, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN OUTCROPPING CORAL ROCK WHICH PROJECTS 10 INCHES.  IT IS ABOUT 150 YARDS SOUTH OF THE SHORE LINE.  REFERENCE MARK 1 IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED CHIVATO NO 1 1965, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN OUTCROPPING CORAL ROCK WHICH PROJECTS 4 INCHES.  REFERENCE MARK 2 IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED CHIVATO NO 2 1965, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN OUTCROPPING CORAL ROCK WHICH PROJECTS 6 INCHES.  NO AZIMUTH MARK WAS ESTABLISHED AT THIS STATION.                            STATION RECOVERY (2004)  RECOVERY NOTE BY UNIVERSITY OF PUERTO RICO AT MAYAGUEZ 2004 (YRR) MARK NOT FOUND.
markers.setting: SET IN ROCK OUTCROP
markers.stability: MOST RELIABLE AND EXPECTED TO HOLDPOSITION/ELEVATION WELL

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JJL) THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 6 MILES SOUTH OF VEGA ALTA, 2-1/2 MILES WEST OF COROZAL AND ON A HIGH, SHARP, BRUSH COVERED PEAK.  THE EAST SIDE OF THE PEAK IS A VERTICAL CLIFF.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE NORTHWEST CORNER OF THE PLAZA IN COROZAL, GO WEST AND SOUTHWEST ON HIGHWAY 159 FOR 0.55 MILE TO A SIDE ROAD ON THE RIGHT.  TURN RIGHT AND GO NORTHWEST ON HIGHWAY 818 FOR 1.45 MILES TO A FORK JUST AFTER CROSSING THE RIO CIBUCO BRIDGE.  TAKE THE LEFT FORK AND GO NORTHWEST ON A PAVED ROAD FOR 0.45 MILE TO A 3-WAY FORK AND THE AZIMUTH MARK JUST NORTHWEST OF THE CENTER OF THE FORK.  TAKE THE EXTREME LEFT FORK AND GO WEST ON A PAVED ROAD FOR 0.15 MILE TO A T ROAD. TURN RIGHT AND GO NORTH AND EAST ON A DIRT ROAD FOR 0.3 MILE TO THE END OF TRUCK TRAVEL AT A WIDE POINT IN THE ROAD AND SEVERAL HOUSES.  FROM THIS POINT PACK SOUTHERLY, PASSING TO THE LEFT OF TWO HOUSES AND FOLLOW A TRAIL FOR 100 YARDS TO A FENCE. BEAR LEFT AFTER CROSSING THE FENCE AND PACK SOUTH AND WEST UP THE STEEP HILL FOR 20 MINUTES TO THE HIGHEST POINT AND THE STATION.  THE STATION MARK IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED CIBUCO 1965, BRAZED TO THE TOP OF A 3-INCH CAST IRON PIPE THAT PROJECTS 2 INCHES.  REFERENCE MARK 1 IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED CIBUCO NO 1 1965, BRAZED TO THE TOP OF A 3-INCH CAST IRON PIPE THAT PROJECTS 6 INCHES AND IS THE SAME ELEVATION AS THE STATION MARK.  REFERENCE MARK 2 IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED CIBUCO NO 2 1965, BRAZED TO THE TOP OF A 3-INCH CAST IRON PIPE THAT PROJECTS 6 INCHES AND IS 3 FEET LOWER IN ELEVATION THAN THE STATION MARK.  THE AZIMUTH MARK IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED CIBUCO 1965, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A LARGE BOULDER THAT PROJECTS 3 FEET.  IT IS 61 FEET NORTHWEST OF THE APPROXIMATE CENTER OF A 3-WAY FORK, 27 FEET NORTHWEST OF A FENCE CORNER POST AND 17 FEET NORTH OF THE CENTER OF AN EAST-WEST ROAD.
markers.setting: SET INTO TOP OF METAL PIPE DRIVEN INTO GROUND
markers.stability: MARK OF QUESTIONABLE OR UNKNOWN STABILITY

markers.description: BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1934 LOCATED ABOUT 6.4 KILOMETERS BY ROAD AND TRAIL W OF COROZAL, W OF RIO CIGUCO, IN BARRIO CIBUCO AND ABOUT 0.5 KILOMETERS W OF A NEW SCHOOLHOUSE, ON A VERY SHARP CORAL LIMESTONE PEAK, WHICH IS THE FARTHEST E ONE OF A RANGE OF PEAKS WHICH LIES FARTHER TO THE S THAN THE GENERAL S LINE OF THESE PEAKS.  IT IS A DOUBLE-TOPPED PEAK, THE STATION BEING ON THE EASTERN AND HIGHEST SUMMIT.  THE EASTERN FACE OF THE PEAK IS ALMOST A VERTICAL CLIFF WHICH BREAKS OFF ALMOST FROM THE VERY SUMMIT.  THE STATION IS ABOUT 12 FEET S AND 5 FEET W OF THE VERY CREST, BUT ONLY A FEW INCHES LOWER IN ELEVATION.  STATION MARK IS A STANDARD TABLET, STAMPED CIBUCO 1934, CEMENTED IN A LIMESTONE ROCK SET IN THE GROUND.  REFERENCE MARKS CROSSES CUT ON LIMESTONE ROCKS SET IN THE GROUND.  REFERENCE MARK NO.1 ON HIGHEST POINT OF PEAK, 12.29 FEET FROM STATION IN TRUE AZIMUTH 149 DEG 48 MIN.  REFERENCE MARK NO.2 IS ON S SLOPE, 16.64 FEET FROM STATION IN TRUE AZIMUTH 331 DEG 18 MIN.  SIGNAL--A QUADRIPOD OF SAWED LUMBER WITH BLACK CROSS-TARGETS ON CENTER POLE.  TO REACH STATION FROM COROZAL, FOLLOW MAIN CARRETERA LEADING TO MOROVIS AND OROCOVIS FOR ABOUT 2 KILOMETERS TO MUNICIPAL ROAD OR CAMINA WHICH LEAVES CARRETERA AT POST K 15 H 5.  FOLLOW THIS CAMINO WESTWARD, KEEPING TO THE RIGHT, NORTHWARD, AT T-ROAD FORKS ABOUT 0.5 KILOMETER AFTER LEAVING CARRETERA.  KEEP TO RIGHT AT NEXT FORKS ALSO AND AFTER CROSSING RIO CIBUCO, AND WHEN ON RIDGE NEARLY OPPOSITE THE PEAK, TURN LEFT ON PRIVATE ROAD TO OLD (PRIVATE) SCHOOLHOUSE AND HOUSE OF FRANCISCO PADIN, TO WHICH PLACE CAR CAN BE TAKEN.  CONTINUE WESTWARD ON TRAIL ON N SIDE OF PEAK AND CLIMB FROM W OR NW SIDE.                            STATION RECOVERY (1940)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1940 STATION AND R. M. NO. 2 RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED, IN FAIR CONDITION.  R. M. NO. 1 HAS BEEN DESTROYED.  THE FOLLOWING SPEEDOMETER MILEAGES MIGHT PROVE HELPFUL IN THE DESCRIPTION OF HOW TO REACH.  FROM K15 H5, GO 0.35 MILE AND TURN RIGHT.  GO 0.8 MILE AND TURN RIGHT, GO 0.3 AND TURN LEFT.  GO 0.3 AND TURN LEFT ONTO PRIVATE ROAD MENTIONED.                            STATION RECOVERY (1941)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1941 (GBG) RECOVERED THE STATION, AS DESCRIBED, IN GOOD CONDITION.  THE DESCRIPTION IS ADEQUATE.  R.M. 1 HAS BEEN DESTROYED.  R.M. 2 CHECKS.
markers.setting: SET IN ROCK OUTCROP
markers.stability: MOST RELIABLE AND EXPECTED TO HOLDPOSITION/ELEVATION WELL

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1941 (RLS) THIS STATION IS IN THE MIDDLE OF A FLAT, OPEN FIELD.  THE LOCATION WAS SELECTED BECAUSE IT FALLS IN AN AREA COMMON TO 3 TOPOGRAPHIC SHEETS.  THE STATION IS LOCATED ON A PARCEL OF LAND OWNED BY J. ZALDUONDO, 12 PACES S OF THE BOUNDARY FENCE AND 65 PACES W OF A CREEK CALLED AGUAS CLARAS.  IT IS 1/4 MILE N OF THE MAIN ROAD LEADING TO ENSENADA HONDA FROM CARRARETERA NO.3.  THE STATION IS ON THE PROPOSED LOCATION OF A LANDING FIELD.  IT IS 1.4 MILES SE FROM CEIBA.  STATION MARK IS A STANDARD BRONZE DISK SET IN CONCRETE, AS DESCRIBED IN NOTE 1A.  THERE IS NO UNDERGROUND MARK.  NO REFERENCE MARKS WERE PLACED, BECAUSE OF THE PROBABILITY OF EXTENSIVE GRADING OPERATIONS.                            STATION RECOVERY (1958)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1958 STATION WAS DESTROYED BY CONSTRUCTION OF RUNWAY.                            STATION RECOVERY (1961)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1961 (MLO) STATION WAS SEARCHED FOR BUT NOT RECOVERED.  IT WAS PROBABLY DESTROYED IN CONSTRUCTION OF RUNWAY FOR AIRPORT WHICH NOW COVERS THIS AREA.
markers.setting: SET IN TOP OF CONCRETE MONUMENT
markers.stability: MAY HOLD, BUT OF TYPE COMMONLY SUBJECT TOSURFACE MOTION

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1900 (JBB) STATION IS LOCATED ON THE FIRST PROMINENT POINT NW OF PUNTA DEL SOLDADO AND WSW FROM STATION AST.  IT IS ON TOP OF CLIFF SOME 10 METERS ABOVE THE SEA AND 4 METERS BACK FROM FACE OF CLIFF ON HIGHEST POINT OF HUMMOCK.  STATION IS MARKED BY A NAIL SET IN A CEMENT BLOCK SOME 5 BY 5 BY 18 INCHES IN SIZE SET IN GROUND.  A SMALL PILE OF ROCKS WAS RAISED OVER THE STATION.  A TRIPOD SIGNAL WAS PLACED OVER STATION.

BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1902 (JN) THIS STATION IS ON A PROMINENT POINT W OF THE COUNTRY CLUB HOUSE AND ABOUT 200 FEET E OF MR. HAMS HOUSE NEAR THE BEACH.  IT IS ABOUT 12 FEET ABOVE HIGH WATER MARK.  IT IS ON THE PROPERTY OF DE FORD AND COMPANY, BANKERS IN SAN JUAN.  IT IS MARKED BY A 2-FOOT GALVANIZED-IRON PIPE BEDDED IN CEMENT AND PROJECTS ABOUT 4 INCHES ABOVE THE SURFACE OF THE CEMENT.  THE HOLE FOR THE PIPE WAS MADE IN CORAL ROCK.  THE TOP OF A NAIL INSIDE THE PIPE, WHICH IS FILLED WITH CEMENT MARKS THE CENTER OF THE STATION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1921)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1921 (JHP) STATION RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED.
markers.setting: SET INTO TOP OF METAL PIPE DRIVEN INTO GROUND
markers.stability: MARK OF QUESTIONABLE OR UNKNOWN STABILITY

markers.description: BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1934 ORNAMENT ON TOP OF RED-ROOFED SPIRE OR TOWER OF ALCALDEA, OR MAYORS HOUSE, IN THE TOWN OF COAMO, (MUNICIPAL BUILDING).

BY ANDREGG INCORPORATED 1995 (DJR) THE STATION IS LOCATED AT THE JUNCTION OF NORTH-BOUND HIGHWAY PR 52 AND THE OFF-RAMP TO HIGHWAY PR 53.  THE STATION IS ON THE EAST SHOULDER OF NORTH-BOUND HIGHWAY PR 52, NEAR KILOMETER POST 61.2.  THE STATION IS 16.5 METERS (54.1 FT) WEST OF THE WEST EDGE OF PAVEMENT OF OFF-RAMP TO HIGHWAY PR 53, 6.1 METERS (20.0 FT) WEST OF THE GUARD RAIL ALONG THE WEST EDGE OF OFF-RAMP TO HIGHWAY PR 53, 1.9 METERS (6.2 FT) EAST OF THE EAST EDGE OF PAVEMENT OF HIGHWAY PR 52, 1.7 METERS (5.6 FT) EAST OF THE GUARD RAIL ALONG THE EAST EDGE OF HIGHWAY PR 52, AND 5.6 METERS (18.4 FT) NORTH OF NORTHWEST CORNER OF ELECTRICAL TRANSFORMER BOX  THE STATION IS 1 METER (3.3 FT) WEST OF A CARSONITE SURVEY MARKER WITNESS POST  THE STATION IS A 3-1/4 INCH BRASS CAP STAMPED CENTRO DE RECAUDACION DE INGRESSOS MUNICIPALES, PUERTO RICO GPS CONTROL, C.R.I.M., UNLAWFUL TO DISTURB, COCO, SET ATOP A 9/16 INCH STAINLESS STEEL ROD DRIVEN TO REFUSAL AND COVERED FLUSH WITH THE GROUND BY AN ALUMINUM COVER EPOXYED ONTO A 6 INCH SCHEDULE 40 PVC PIPE SET IN CONCRETE INSIDE AND OUT                            STATION RECOVERY (2009)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 2009 (NMD) NO COVER, BUT BRASS CAP IS GOOD. MARQTEK ENGINEERING.                            STATION RECOVERY (2009)  RECOVERY NOTE BY JAVIER E. BIDOT AND ASSOC. 2009 (JEB) THE MARK IS LOCATED ABOUT 14.36 KM (8.92 MI) WEST OF GUAYAMA TOWN AND ABOUT 5.91 KM (3.67 MI) NORTHEAST OF SALINAS TOWN.  THE MARK IS LOCATED IN THE EAST SECTION OF SALINAS.   TO REACH FROM A TWO LEVEL INTERSECTION OF INTERSTATE PR-52 AND INTERSTATE PR-1, GO NORTHBOUND ON INTERSTATE PR-52 FOR 4.91 KM (3.05 MI) AND MARK TO THE RIGHT AFTER EXIT 60.   THE MARK IS 1.2 M (3.9 FT) DEEP AND 0.3 M (1.0 FT) IN DIAMETER 47.4 M (155.5 FT) NORTHEAST OF THE EXIT 60 SIGN, 9.3 M (30.5 FT) NORTH OF THE KM 61.4 SIGN, 5.7 M (18.7 FT) NORTHWEST OF A PREPA BOX AND 2.4 M (7.9 FT) EAST OF THE EDGE OF THE PAVEMENT.   OWNERSHIP--PUERTO RICO HIGHWAY AND TRANSPORTATION AUTHORITY (PRHTA).                            STATION RECOVERY (2011)  RECOVERY NOTE BY POLYTECHNIC UNIVERSITY OF PUERTO RICO 2011 (FAR) DESCRIPTION IS ADEQUATE                            STATION RECOVERY (2016)  RECOVERY NOTE BY DEWBERRY DAVIS 2016 (GDS) RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.                            STATION RECOVERY (2016)  RECOVERY NOTE BY ATKINS NORTH AMERICA INC 2016 (DWD) MARK RECOVERED DURING THE COURSE OF A TOPOGRAPHIC SURVEY FOR CAMP SANTIAGO, PUERTO RICO ARMY NATIONAL GUARD FACILITY.                            STATION RECOVERY (2017)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 2017 (CJW) RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.
markers.setting: STAINLESS STEEL ROD W/O SLEEVE (10 FT.+)
markers.stability: MOST RELIABLE AND EXPECTED TO HOLDPOSITION/ELEVATION WELL

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1901 (JN) THIS STATION IS SITUATED ON A HIGH SAND RIDGE ON THE COAST ABOUT 2 MILES E OF CAMUY, AND 7 MILES W OF ARECIBO.  IT IS ON THE SUMMIT OF A SHARP RIDGE ABOUT 25 FEET ABOVE HIGH WATER AND 1/4 MILE N OF THE RAILROAD.  THE STATION IS MARKED BY A LARGE 12 BY 18 BY 10-INCH STONE SET IN CEMENT.  A HOLE 1 INCH BY 4 INCHES WAS DRILLED IN THE STONE AND THE CENTER OF THE HOLE MARKS THE STATION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1963)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1963 (CFO) SEARCH WAS MADE FOR THIS STATION AND WAS NOT RECOVERED, PROBABLY HAS BEEN DESTROYED BY THE SHIFTING OF THE SAND DUNES IN THE AREA.
markers.setting: SET IN A BOULDER
markers.stability: MAY HOLD, BUT OF TYPE COMMONLY SUBJECT TOSURFACE MOTION

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1941 (RLS) STATION IS ABOUT 1/2 MILE SW OF DAGUAO, ABOUT 1/4 MILE NE OF COLONIA ESPERANZA, ON THE E SIDE OF THE AMERICAN RAILROAD WHICH RUNS ALONG THE BASE OF THE HILL AT THE W SIDE, ON TOP OF THE HIGHEST HILL IN THE VICINITY E OF THE RAILROAD, WITHIN THE PROPOSED LIMITS OF THE ROOSEVELT ROADS NAVAL RESERVATION, NEAR THE E CORNER OF A FIELD AT PRESENT PLANTED IN SUGAR CANE, ABOUT 15 METERS NW OF THE HIGHEST POINT OF THE HILL, 15.7 METERS NW OF A FENCE CORNER, 13.2 METERS NNW OF A FENCE, 9.2 METERS WSW OF A FENCE, AND IS FLUSH WITH THE GROUND.  THE ELEVATION OF THE STATION IS ABOUT 92.2 METERS.  STATION AND REFERENCE MARKS ARE STANDARD BRONZE DISKS SET IN CONCRETE, AS DESCRIBED IN NOTES 1A AND 11A.  THERE IS NO UNDERGROUND MARK.  REFERENCE MARK NO.1 IS 15.6 METERS ENE OF AN ANGLE IN THE FENCE, 0.3 METER NNW OF THE FENCE, 0.51 METER LOWER THAN THE STATION, AND PROJECTS 6 INCHES ABOVE GROUND.  REFERENCE MARK NO.2 IS 18.0 METERS ENE OF REFERENCE MARK NO.1, 3.5 METERS WSW OF THE FENCE CORNER, 0.3 METER NNW OF THE FENCE, 0.27 METER LOWER THAN THE STATION, AND PROJECTS 2 INCHES ABOVE GROUND.                            STATION RECOVERY (1958)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1958 (RVS) STATION RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED.  REFERENCE MARKS 1 AND 2 WERE NOT RECOVERED.                            STATION RECOVERY (1961)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1961 (MLO) STATION AND REFERENCE MARKS WERE SEARCHED FOR BUT NOT RECOVERED.
markers.setting: SET IN TOP OF CONCRETE MONUMENT
markers.stability: MAY HOLD, BUT OF TYPE COMMONLY SUBJECT TOSURFACE MOTION

markers.description: BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1934 STATION IS ON THE CENTRAL HIGHEST HILL S OF THE IMPROVED ROAD NAMED LOS TORRES ON BARRIO COLLORES DE PIEDRAS.  THE HILL IS ABOUT 1500 FEET ABOVE SEA LEVEL.  THERE IS ANOTHER BROAD HILL SOME 200 FEET LOWER THAN COLLORES AT ABOUT 30 DEGREE AZIMUTH FROM STATION AND LYING BETWEEN THE STATION AND THE HEIGHTS SW OF EL YUNQUE.  STATION IS MARKED BY A REGULAR U.S.G.S. TABLET STAMPED COLLORES 1934.  REFERENCE MARK NO.1 IS A CROSS MARK ON A STONE 13 FEET 6 INCHES DISTANT FROM STATION CENTER, ON TRUE AZIMUTH OF 208 DEG 39 MIN.  REFERENCE MARK NO.2 IS A CROSS MARK ON A STONE 15 FEET 3-1/2 INCHES FROM THE STATION CENTER, ON TRUE AZIMUTH OF 311 DEG 22 MIN.  SIGNAL--WHITE QUADRIPOD WITH BLACK CROSS TARGETS.  TO REACH THIS STATION, DRIVE UP TO KILOMETER 22 H-5 ON THE HUMACAO-LAS PIEDRAS HIGHWAY.  HERE TAKE ROAD NAMED LOS TORRES AND DRIVE TO THE END OF THE ROAD WHICH IS 4.3 KILOMETERS DISTANT FROM THE MAIN HIGHWAY.  FROM THE END OF THE ROAD GET TRAIL TO THE STATION WHICH IS ON THE HIGHEST HILL SEEN TO THE SW ABOUT ONE KILOMETER DISTANT FROM THE END OF THE ROAD.                            STATION RECOVERY (1940)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1940 THE EVIDENCE OF THE DRILLED HOLE IN ROCK FOR THE STATION TABLET WAS FOUND APPARENTLY IN PLACE.  THE REFERENCE MARKS WERE FOUND AFTER THIS.  AND CHECKED THE LOCATION ALL RIGHT.  A NEW TABLET STAMPED COLLORES 1934 WAS CENTERED IN THE OLD LOCATION AND CEMENT WAS BUILT UP AROUND IT TO FORM AN INTEGRAL MASS WITH THE BASE ROCK.  THE STATION IS ON THE PROPERTY OF RAMON DIAS, ON THE WEST END OF THE TOP OF THE HILL, WHICH IS THE MOST PROMINENT JUST TO THE NE OF LAS PIEDRAS.  IT IS IN THE BARRIO COLLORES DE PIEDRAS, DISTRICT OF HUMACAO.  TO REACH FROM LAS PIEDRAS, TAKE TORRES - NAGUADO ROAD AT W END OF TOWN AND GO TO VILLAGE OF MELILLAS.  HERE TURN RIGHT ON DIRT ROAD AND DRIVE ABOUT 1/2 MILE PAST SCHOOL, AND LEAVE CAR.  CONTINUE ON FOOT, TAKING LEFT FORK AT A T-JUNCTION OF LANES.  AFTER CROSSING STREAM, CUT ACROSS PASTURE TOWARDS HILL, AT SAME TIME WORKING EASTWARD TO A PROMINENT SPUR, ON THE LOWER PART OF WHICH ARE SOME BUTE.  CONTINUE UP THIS SPUR, PASSING THREE FENCES, TO TOP AND STATION.  THERE IS NO WELL-DEFINED TRAIL.  R. M. NO. 1 IS A CROSS MARK ON A STONE 13.5 FT. DISTANT FROM STATION IN AZIMUTH 208 DEG 39 MIN.  R. M. NO. 2 IS A CROSS MARK ON A STONE 15.3 FT. FROM STATION IN AZIMUTH 311 DEG 22 MIN.                            STATION RECOVERY (1965)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1965 (JJL) THE STATION MARK WAS RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED IN THE 1934 DESCRIPTION AND WAS FOUND TO BE IN GOOD CONDITION.  REFERENCE MARK 1 AND REFERENCE MARK 2 WERE NOT RECOVERED AND NEW REFERENCE MARKS 1 AND 2 WERE ESTABLISHED.  A COMPLETE NEW DESCRIPTION FOLLOWS.  THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 3-1/2 MILES NORTH-NORTHWEST OF HUMACAO, 2 MILES NORTHEAST OF LAS PIEDRAS AND ON THE HIGHEST POINT OF A PROMINENT GRASS AND BRUSH-COVERED HILL LOCALLY KNOWN AS CERRO COLLORES.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE SOUTHWEST CORNER OF THE PLAZA IN LAS PIEDRAS, GO SOUTH ON HIGHWAY 30 FOR 0.05 MILE TO A SIDE ROAD ON THE LEFT.  TURN LEFT AND GO EAST AND SOUTHEAST ON HIGHWAY 926 FOR 1.95 MILES TO THE END OF THE PAVED ROAD.  CONTINUE EASTERLY ON THE STEEP, DIRT, MOUNTAIN ROAD FOR 0.3 MILE TO A Y-FORK.  KEEP THE LEFT FORK AND GO NORTH ON THE DIRT ROAD FOR 0.05 MILE TO A HOUSE AND A LARGE TOBACCO BARN.  (PERMISSION TO ENTER THE PROPERTY MAY BE OBTAINED HERE.) BEAR TO THE RIGHT ON THE TRACK ROAD, PASSING BY THE SOUTHEAST SIDE OF THE TOBACCO BARN AND CONTINUE NORTHEAST FOR 0.1 MILE TO WHERE THE ROAD CURVES TO THE NORTHWEST AND A WIRE GATE ON THE RIGHT, NORTH, SIDE OF THE ROAD AND THE END OF TRUCK TRAVEL.  PASS THROUGH THE GATE AND PACK NORTHERLY ALONG THE WEST SIDE OF THE FENCE TO A WIRE GATE.  PASS THROUGH THE GATE AND CONTINUE NORTHERLY UP THE STEEP, GRASSY HILLSIDE TO THE HIGHEST POINT OF THE HILL AND THE STATION.  THIS IS A 15 MINUTE PACK.  NOTE--A 4-WHEEL DRIVE VEHICLE IS REQUIRED.  THE STATION MARK IS A U.S. GEOLOGICAL SURVEY DISK, STAMPED COLLORES 1934, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A BOULDER THAT PROJECTS 5 INCHES.  REFERENCE MARK 1 IS A STANDARD DISK, STAMPED COLLORES USGS NO 1 1934, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A BOULDER THAT PROJECTS 12 INCHES ON THE EAST SIDE AND 3 INCHES ON THE WEST SIDE.  REFERENCE MARK 2 IS A STANDARD DISK, STAMPED COLLORES USGS NO 2 1934, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A BOULDER THAT PROJECTS 10 INCHES.  AIRLINE DISTANCE AND DIRECTION FROM NEAREST TOWN 2 MILES NORTHEAST OF LAS PIEDRAS.
markers.setting: SET IN A BOULDER
markers.stability: MAY HOLD, BUT OF TYPE COMMONLY SUBJECT TOSURFACE MOTION

markers.description: BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1941 (RLS) THIS INTERSECTION STATION IS ABOUT 0.6 MILE NE OF NAGUABO PLAYA, ABOUT 3/4 MILE S OF THE CROSSING OF INSULAR HIGHWAY 3 AND THE AMERICAN RAILROAD, ON THE HIGHEST HILL E OF THE HIGHWAY AND S OF RAILROAD, ON THE HIGHEST POINT OF THE GRASS-COVERED HILL.  THE STATION IS MARKED BY A U.S.G.S. DISK STAMPED COLON 1941, AND SET IN CONCRETE IN A DEPRESSION IN A SMALL BOULDER PROJECTING ABOUT 6 INCHES ABOVE GROUND.  THE ELEVATION OF THE STATION IS ABOUT 138.3 METERS.  REFERENCE MARK NO.1 IS A U.S.G.S. DISK WITH AN ARROW CHISELED ACROSS THE CENTER AND IS STAMPED RM NO.1 1941.  THE DISK IS SET IN A DRILL HOLE IN A SMALL BOULDER PROJECTING ABOUT 3 INCHES ABOVE GROUND.  THE BOULDER IS SLOPING TOWARD THE STATION.  IT IS 21.995 METERS DISTANT FROM THE STATION IN APPROXIMATE AZIMUTH 107 DEG.  REFERENCE MARK NO.2 IS 24.135 METERS FROM REFERENCE MARK NO.1.  THE DISK IS THE SAME AS REFERENCE MARK NO.1 AND IS STAMPED NO.2 ETC., AND IS SET IN A DRILL HOLE IN A BOULDER PROJECTING ABOUT 6 INCHES ABOVE GROUND.  THE TOP OF THE BOULDER SLOPES TO THE SE.  IT IS 11.620 METERS DISTANT FROM THE STATION IN APPROXIMATE AZIMUTH 21 DEG.  THIS STATION WAS ESTABLISHED BY THE U.S.G.S. FOR CONTROL OF AIR PHOTOS.                            STATION RECOVERY (1961)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1961 (MLO) STATION MARK AND REFERENCE MARKS WERE RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED EXCEPT THAT RM 2 IS IN VERY TALL GRASS AND IS 23.0 FEET SOUTH OF A FENCE ON RIDGE.
markers.setting: SET IN A BOULDER
