BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JWC) THE STATION IS LOCATED 12 AIRLINE MILES SOUTHWEST OF LAJAS, 8-1/2 AIRLINE MILES SOUTH-SOUTHWEST OF CABO ROJO, 5 AIRLINE MILES NORTH OF THE CABO ROJO LIGHTHOUSE AND ON THE TOP OF A LOW GRASS COVERED HILL.  THE PROPERTY IS OWNED BY DR. ENRIQUE CARLO WHO LIVES 1 MILE NORTHEAST OF THE STATION.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE SOUTHWEST CORNER OF THE PLAZA IN CABO ROJO, GO WEST ON A PAVED STREET FOR 1 BLOCK TO HIGHWAY 103.  TURN LEFT AND GO SOUTH ON HIGHWAY 103 FOR 4.8 MILES TO HIGHWAY 101.  TURN RIGHT AND GO WEST ON HIGHWAY 101 FOR 0.7 MILE TO A SIDE ROAD LEFT.  TURN LEFT AND GO SOUTH ON A PAVED ROAD FOR 2.8 MILES TO A SIDE ROAD RIGHT.  TURN RIGHT AND GO WEST ON A PAVED ROAD FOR 2.0 MILES TO A T-INTERSECTION.  TURN LEFT AND GO SOUTH ON A PAVED ROAD FOR 0.25 MILE TO A SIDE ROAD RIGHT. TURN RIGHT AND GO WEST ON A PAVED ROAD WHICH TURNS INTO A SAND ROAD FOR 1.2 MILES TO A LOCKED GATE ON THE RIGHT.  (THE KEY FOR THE GATE MAY BE OBTAINED FROM THE PROPERTY OWNER) TURN RIGHT, PASS THROUGH THE GATE AND GO NORTH ON A SAND ROAD FOR 1.1 MILES TO A FORK AND THE AZIMUTH MARK JUST EAST-NORTHEAST OF THE FORK.  KEEP LEFT AND GO WEST ON A TRACK ROAD FOR 0.25 MILE TO THE TOP OF THE GRASS COVERED HILL AND THE STATION.  THE STATION MARK IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED COMBATE 1966, SET IN THE TOP OF A 10-INCH ROUND CONCRETE MONUMENT WHICH IS FLUSH WITH THE SURFACE.  REFERENCE MARK 1 IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED COMBATE NO 1 1966, SET IN THE TOP OF A 10-INCH ROUND CONCRETE MONUMENT WHICH IS FLUSH WITH THE SURFACE.  REFERENCE MARK 2 IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED COMBATE NO 2 1966, SET IN THE TOP OF A 10-INCH ROUND CONCRETE MONUMENT WHICH IS FLUSH WITH THE SURFACE.  THE AZIMUTH MARK IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED COMBATE 1966, SET IN THE TOP OF A 10-INCH ROUND CONCRETE MONUMENT WHICH IS FLUSH WITH THE SURFACE.  IT IS 80 FEET EAST-NORTHEAST OF THE FORK IN THE SAND ROAD AND 15 FEET NORTH OF THE CENTER OF THE SAND ROAD.                            STATION RECOVERY (1999)  RECOVERY NOTE BY UNIVERSITY OF PUERTO RICO AT MAYAGUEZ 1999 (SSM) RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.                            STATION RECOVERY (2004)  RECOVERY NOTE BY UNIVERSITY OF PUERTO RICO AT MAYAGUEZ 2004 (RCC) RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1964 (GWM) THERE IS A THREE WINDOWED CUPOLA NEAR THE WEST END OF THE ROOF OF CONDADO BEACH HOTEL THAT WAS THE STATION.  HOTEL IS AT AVENIDA ASHFORD AND COLLE BARRANQUITAS, SAN JUAN.

BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1941 (PR) V. A. ELEVATION 12.87 METERS.  STATION LOCATED ON THE SOUTH COAST OF VIEQUES ISLAND ABOUT 5 KMS. EAST OF PORT FERRO LIGHTHOUSE AND ON A PROMINENT PENINSULA KNOWN AS CAPE CONEJO WHICH SEPARATES ENSENADA HONDA FROM BAHIA DE LA CHIVA.  THE STATION IS ABOUT 150 METERS NW OF THE END OF THE CAPE, 42 METERS SE OF A SMALL HOUSE AND ON THE HIGHEST POINT ON THE PENINSULA.  STATION MARK IS A STANDARD TABLET STAMPED CONEJO 1941 AND SET IN A CONCRETE MONUMENT.  R.M. NO. 1 IS A DRILL HOLE IN ROCK 1.28 METERS FROM STATION.  PLANE AZIMUTH 311-21.  R.M. NO. 2 IS A DRILL HOLE IN ROCK 2.07 METERS FROM STATION.  PLANE AZIMUTH 356-41.  TO REACH FROM ISABLE II TAKE LUJAN ROAD SOUTH, THEN DRIVE EAST PAST AIRPORT ABOUT 4 KMS., THEN CONTINUE BY TRAIL TO CAPE CONEJO AND STATION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1964)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1964 (GWM) STATION DESTROYED WHEN POINT WAS LEVELED OFF BY U.S. MARINES.
markers.setting: SET IN TOP OF CONCRETE MONUMENT

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1900 (JN) STATION IS ON A SMALL ISLAND COMPOSED, AS TO ITS TOP, OF FINELY COMMINUTED FRAGMENTS OF WHITE CORAL.  ALONG THE SOUTHERN EDGE OF THE ISLET IS A LINE OF MANGROVES AND SOME OF THESE, AT THE SW CORNER WERE CUT DOWN TO PERMIT VISION TO SIGNAL TO THE WESTWARD.  THE ISLET IS ABOUT SW OF PENONES ISLAND AND IS THE FIRST MANGROVE-COVERED ISLET W OF HUMPBACK POINT, IN A LINE DRAWN FROM HUMPBACK TO CABO ROJO LIGHT.  STATION MARK IS A STUB DRIVEN IN THE SAND WITH A TACK IN ITS HEAD.  THE STUB IS ABOUT 2 BY 3 INCHES IN CROSS SECTION.  IT IS ABOUT 6 FEET S OF THE HIGH-WATER MARK ON THE N FACE OF ISLAND, ABOUT 60 FEET FROM THE EXTREME E EDGE OF ISLAND, AND ABOUT 55 FEET FROM EXTREME NW CORNER.  THE FIRST SIGNAL ERECTED HERE AND OBSERVED UPON FROM GUANICA AND MANGLIO WAS BLOWN DOWN BEFORE THE STATION WAS MARKED.  CORAL 2 STANDS ALMOST EXACTLY IN THE SAME PLACE AND THE SURFACE MARK BELONGS TO CORAL 2.  ABAD PARDILLA OF GUANICA AND JOSE BAIS OF PARGUERA CAN POINT OUT THE STATION MARK.                            STATION RECOVERY (1903)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1903 (WEP) STATION RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED AND SIGNAL REBUILT.                            STATION RECOVERY (1971)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1971 (EKM) ISLET HAS CHANGED CONSIDERABLY SINCE 1900 AND AFTER A SEARCH THE MARK WAS NOT FOUND.  STATION DESTROYED.
markers.setting: UNSPECIFIED SETTING

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1899 (WCH) STATION IS ON A BARE HILL ABOUT 2-1/2 MILES NE OF GUAYAMA, ON THE PROPERTY OF SENOR JABRIEL MINOREDO, WHO LIVES 1/4 MILE NW OF SAID HILL.  THE TOP OF THE HILL IS ABOUT 1200 FEET ABOVE SEA LEVEL AND SOME 400 FEET LOWER THAN THE MAIN RANGE OF BARE HILLS JUST N OF IT.  STATION IS MARKED BY A PIPE 18 INCHES LONG AND 2 INCHES IN DIAMETER.  A PILE OF STONES PROTECTS THE PIPE WHICH PROJECTS ABOUT 3 INCHES ABOVE THE SURFACE OF THE GROUND.  A TRIPOD SIGNAL 30 FEET HIGH WAS BUILT OVER THE STATION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1901)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1901 (JEM) STATION MARK WAS FOUND, AND AFTER OCCUPATION A BRACED POLE (ONE OF ASSISTANT HODGKINS CENTER POLES, WHICH WAS FOUND IN THE CUSTOM HOUSE AT ARROYO) WAS ERECTED OVER THE STATION MARK.  I FOUND NO HEAP OF STONES AROUND THE IRON PIPE AND AS THE HILL IS GRASS-COVERED AND THERE ARE NO LOOSE STONES ABOUT, IN ANY NUMBER, THE PILE COULD NOT HAVE BEEN A LARGE ONE.  THE PIPE WAS CEMENTED IN PLACE BUT ONE-HALF THE MASS OF CEMENT HAD BECOME DETACHED.  STILL THE PIPE SEEMED FIRM AND TO HAVE REMAINED UNMOVED SINCE IT WAS SET IN PLACE.  THE PROPERTY BELONGS TO A WIDOW, SENORA EULALIA BARBOSA, WHO LIVES NEAR THE S FLANK OF THE HILL.  SENOR JABRIEL MINOREDO (MENTIONED IN ORIGINAL DESCRIPTION) COULD NOT BE IDENTIFIED BUT A SENOR JABRIEL MIRANDA LIVES IN THE HOUSE WHERE ONE TAKES THE TRAIL WHICH BEGINS TO CLIMB ABRUPTLY UP THE N FACE OF THE HILL TO THE STATION SITE.  THERE SEEMS TO HAVE BEEN SOME MISTAKE IN THE SENTENCE (IN ORIGINAL DESCRIPTION) WHICH DESCRIBES THE RELATIVE HEIGHTS OF THE VARIOUS PARTS OF THE MOUNTAIN.  SOUTH OF CORAZON THE DESCENT IS RAPID AND ABRUPT TO THE PLAIN WHICH EXTENDS TO THE SEA AND THERE IS NO HILL S OF CORAZON AS HIGH AS THE STATION.  NORTH OF STATION THE MOUNTAIN RISES HIGHER FOR MANY HUNDRED FEET.  A NATIVE TOLD ME THE MAIN MOUNTAIN WAS CALLED CERRO DE SAN BERNALDO (BERNARDO).  TO REACH THIS STATION FOLLOW THE MAIN ROAD BETWEEN ARROYO AND GUAYAMA TO THE LANE THAT LEADS INTO THE HOME OF CARLOS MC CORMICK.  ON THE OPPOSITE SIDE OF THE MAIN ROAD IS THE END OF A COUNTRY ROAD.  TAKE THIS ROAD AND, AFTER PASSING BETWEEN SOME CABINS, FOLLOW IT TOWARDS THE MOUNTAINS TO WHERE IT CROSSES A STREAM, THEN PROCEED ALONG THE LEFT BANK FOR A SHORT DISTANCE, TAKING THE FIRST ROAD GOING IN TOWARDS THE BASE OF THE HILLS. AGAIN THE CREEK IS MET AND CROSSED.  ON THE FARTHER SIDE ENTER BY THE RIGHT-HAND GATE AND TURN EASTWARD TO THE HOUSE OF JABRIEL MIRANDA.  AFTER PASSING THROUGH THE E GATE OF HIS PROPERTY YOU WILL FIND A TRAIL WHICH WILL LEAD YOU TO THE SUMMIT AND STATION.  AT 2/3 OF THE DISTANCE TO THE SUMMIT IS A SMALL COTTAGE WHICH IS INHABITED.  STANDING ON THE SUMMIT (AT THE STATION) THE SECTION OF THE ARROYO-GUAYAMA ROAD WHICH IS ABOUT 1/4 OF A MILE LONG AND PASSES IN FRONT OF THE ARROYO CEMETERY APPEARS AS IF, WERE IT CONTINUED, IT WOULD STRIKE THE HILL, ABOUT 500 OR 600 FEET E OF THE STATION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1926)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1926 (GCM) NOT RECOVERED.  STATION SITE VISITED AND LOCATION CHECKED BY SEXTANT ANGLES.  PIPE MARKING STATION COULD NOT BE FOUND.
markers.setting: OBJECT SURROUNDED BY MASS OF CONCRETE
markers.stability: MARK OF QUESTIONABLE OR UNKNOWN STABILITY

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1900 (WCH) STATION IS ON LARGE CAY (ISLET), NEAR THE EASTERN END OF THE CORDILLERAS.  IT IS ON THE HIGHEST PART OF THE LOW SUMMIT AND OWING TO THE ROCKY FORMATION IS MARKED BY A COPPER TACK SET IN A CEMENT BASE, RESTING UPON THE LEDGE.                            STATION RECOVERY (1901)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1901 (JBB) SIGNAL ERECTED ON ISLA DIAFLS, THE MOST EASTERN OF THE LARGER CAYS OF THE CORDILLERAS REEF.  MARKED BY A LUMP OF CEMENT POURED ON THE ROCK.  SIGNAL STILL STANDING.                            STATION RECOVERY (1921)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1921 (JHP) STATION RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED.  A SMALL PORTION OF CEMENT REMAINS WITH TACK SURROUNDED BY TRIANGULAR DEPRESSION IN TOP.  SURFACE OF ISLAND IS BADLY PITTED BY A WAVE ACTION.
markers.setting: OBJECT SURROUNDED BY MASS OF CONCRETE
markers.stability: MARK OF QUESTIONABLE OR UNKNOWN STABILITY

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1962 (ELJ) THE STATION IS LOCATED ON THE HIGHEST POINT OF A SMALL CAY CALLED CAYO DIABLO WHICH IS THE LARGEST AND MOST EASTERLY OF A REEF CALLED THE CORDILLERAS.  THE BEST APPROACH TO THE STATION BY SMALL BOAT IS FROM THE SOUTHWEST TO A SHELVING SAND BEACH.  FROM THIS POINT, WALK THE BEACH LINE TO THE LEFT AND CLIMB THE HILL.  THE STATION MARK IS ON THE TOP OF A LIMESTONE RIDGE RUNNING GENERALLY NORTHEAST SOUTHWEST WITH A SMALL SHALLOW COVE AT THE SOUTHWEST POINT.  THE MARK IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED CORDILLERAS 2 1962 SET IN THE LIMESTONE OUTCROP.  REFERENCE MARK 1 IS EAST-SOUTHEAST OF THE STATION ON A LIMESTONE OUTCROP AT ABOUT THE SAME ELEVATION AS THE STATION MARK.  THE BLUFF AT THIS POINT LOOKS DOWN ON A SMALL COVE OFF THE SOUTHEAST SIDE OF THE RIDGE.  THE MARK IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED CORDILLERAS 2 RM 1 1962 SET IN THE LIMESTONE OUTCROP.  REFERENCE MARK 2 IS SOUTHWEST OF THE STATION IN A LIMESTONE OUTCROP AND IS AT ABOUT THE SAME ELEVATION AS THE STATION MARK.  THE BLUFF AT THIS POINT LOOKS DOWN ON A FLAT BRUSH COVERED RIDGE BETWEEN THE TWO PREVIOUSLY MENTIONED COVES.  THE MARK IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED CORDILLERAS 2 RM 2 1962 SET IN A LIMESTONE OUTCROP.  HEIGHT OF LIGHT ABOVE STATION MARK 1.5 METERS.                            STATION RECOVERY (1964)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1964 (GWM) STATION RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED.
markers.setting: SET IN ROCK OUTCROP
markers.stability: MOST RELIABLE AND EXPECTED TO HOLDPOSITION/ELEVATION WELL

markers.description: BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1934 POINT IS ORNAMENT ON LARGE DOME AT REAR OF CHURCH IN COROZAL.                            STATION RECOVERY (1941)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1941 (GBG) RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED.
PTIVE TEXT AVAILABLE.

BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JJL) THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 3 MILES NORTHWEST OF SANTA ISABEL.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE PLAZA IN SANTA ISABEL, GO WEST AND NORTHWEST ON HIGHWAY 1 FOR 2.8 MILES TO A SIDE ROAD RIGHT.  TURN RIGHT AND GO NORTHEAST FOR 0.5 MILE TO THE STATION ON THE RIGHT, SOUTHEAST, SIDE OF THE ROAD.  THE STACK IS A CYLINDRICAL, CONCRETE STRUCTURE, WHITE IN COLOR AND IT IS ABOUT 150 FEET HIGH.  POINT INTERSECTED IS THE TOP AND CENTER OF THE STACK.                            STATION RECOVERY (1975)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1975 (RMB) THE STATION WAS RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.  IT IS 195 FEET HIGH, AND THE CONCRETE STRUCTURE IS CIRCLED WITH STEEL BANDS SPACED AT CLOSE INTERVALS OVER ITS FULL HEIGHT.  THERE IS A LADDER ON THE SOUTH WEST SIDE.

BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1934 STATION LOCATED ABOUT -- KILOMETERS DIRECTLY NW OF SAN SEBASTIAN AND ABOUT 0.75 KILOMETER E OF WASHINGTON SCHOOL, WHICH IS ON THE MAIN TRAIL OR CAMINO LEADING LEADING FROM SAN SEBASTIAN TO ISABELA.  IT IS NEAR THE NORTHERN EDGE OF THE HIGH RANGE OF CORAL LIMESTONE PEAKS WHICH EXTENDS EASTWARD FROM THE COAST OF AGUADILLA AND WHICH HAS A NOTICEABLE GENERAL RAISE IN ELEVATION AT THIS POINT.  THE PEAKS TO THE E AND W ARE QUITE CLEAR, BUT THE ONE ON WHICH THE STATION IS LOCATED AND OTHERS QUITE NEAR IT ARE COVERED WITH BRUSH.  THE PEAK IS FLAT ON TOP AND IS ABOUT 50 BY 100 FEET IN EXTENT.  IT IS THE SECOND MAIN PEAK E OF THE MAIN TRAIL AND ABOUT 0.5 KILOMETER NE OF A ROCK-CAPPED PEAK KNOWN LOCALLY AS THE SOMBRERO.  THE STATION IS NEARER THE S END BUT NEAR THE MIDDLE OF THE TOP, FROM E TO W.  THE BRUSH WAS CLEARED FROM THE TOP, BUT WILL SOON GROW UP AGAIN.  STATION MARK IS A STANDARD TABLET, STAMPED CORTADERA 1934, CEMENTED IN SOLID LIMESTONE.  REFERENCE MARKS ARE STANDARD REFERENCE TABLETS CEMENTED IN LIMESTONE ROCK.  REFERENCE MARK NO.1 BEING 27.21 FEET FROM STATION AND REFERENCE MARK NO.2 BEING 10.87 FEET, BOTH IN THE SAME TRUE AZIMUTH OF 345 DEG 45 MIN.  SIGNAL--TWO SMALL TREES, CUT AND FASTENED TOGETHER ABOUT A SAWED POLE WITH WHITE FLAG.  THESE WERE GUYED OVER STATION MARK AND A SMALL MONUMENT OF ROCKS PLACED ABOUT THEIR BASE.  TO REACH STATION FROM SAN SEBASTIAN, FOLLOW THE CAMINO WHICH LEAVES THE HIGHWAY JUST AFTER CROSSING BRIDGE OVER RIVER ABOUT 2 KILOMETERS W OF SAN SEBASTIAN, FOLLOW THIS ROAD UP OVER THE FIRST RANGE OF HILLS AND CONTINUE ON THE MAIN TRAIL TOWARD ISABELA, ABOUT 100 METERS BEFORE REACHING WASHINGTON SCHOOLHOUSE, TURN RIGHT E ON SMALL TRAIL, KEEP LEFT HAND FORK AT FOOT OF FIRST PEAK, PASSING TO THE N OF IT, AND AFTER PASSING THIS PEAK THE STATION PEAK WILL BE SEEN IMMEDIATELY IN FRONT OF YOU.                            STATION RECOVERY (1941)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1941 (GBG) STATION AND REFERENCE MARKS RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED IN GOOD CONDITION.  TO REACH FROM CIALES, GO N ON THE ROAD TO MANATI ABOUT 1/2 MILE, TO N END OF BRIDGE OVER THE CIALES RIVER.  WHERE, TURN LEFT, UP HILL, ON THE FRONTON ROAD.  FOLLOW FOR 2.3 MILES TO K3 H 6.5 AT TOP OF RISE, WHERE THERE IS A SMALL SHACK ON THE RIGHT.  LEAVE CAR, AND FOLLOW TRAIL TO HOUSE OF SERAPIO VELEZ.  TAKE TRAIL TO RIGHT OF HIS HOUSES, AND CONTINUE TO HIS COFFEE PLANTATION IN SADDLE BETWEEN HILLS.  CONTINUE ON DIM TRAIL GOING DOWN FOR A SHORT DISTANCE, AND THEN UP SHARPLY, BEARING LEFT. CONTINUE UP, BEARING GRADUALLY LEFT, FOR A VERY STEEP CLIMB TO THE STATION ON A PINNACLE PEAK.                            STATION RECOVERY (1966)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JWC) THE STATION MARK WAS RECOVERED AND FOUND IN GOOD CONDITION, REFERENCE MARKS 1 AND 2 WERE SEARCHED FOR BUT NOT FOUND.  TWO NEW REFERENCE MARKS WERE ESTABLISHED.  A COMPLETE NEW DESCRIPTION OF THE STATION FOLLOWS--  THE STATION IS LOCATED 8 AIRLINE MILES EAST OF MOCA, 8 AIRLINE MILES SOUTHWEST OF QUEBRADILLAS, 5 AIRLINE MILES NORTH OF SAN SABASTIAN AND ON THE TOP OF A HIGH HILL.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE SOUTHEAST CORNER OF THE PLAZA IN MOCA, GO EAST ON HIGHWAY 111 FOR 0.6 MILE TO HIGHWAY 444.  TURN LEFT AND GO NORTH ON HIGHWAY 444 FOR 4.9 MILES TO HIGHWAY 112. TURN SHARP LEFT AND GO NORTH ON HIGHWAY 112 FOR 0.85 MILE TO A SIDE ROAD RIGHT.  TURN RIGHT AND GO EASTERLY ON A PAVED ROAD FOR 3.2 MILES TO THE END OF THE PAVED ROAD AT A FORK.  KEEP LEFT AND GO EASTERLY ON A BLADED ROAD FOR 0.2 MILE TO A FORK.  KEEP RIGHT AND CONTINUE EASTERLY ON A BLADED ROAD FOR 0.25 MILE TO THE END OF TRUCK TRAVEL AT AN OLD BUILDING ON THE RIGHT. FROM HERE PACK SOUTHEAST ON A TRAIL FOR ABOUT 5 MINUTES TO A SMALL CLEARING.  CONTINUE SOUTHEAST ON THE TRAIL TO ANOTHER SMALL CLEARING IN A LOW SADDLE.  BEAR LEFT AND GO EASTERLY ON A TRAIL FOR ABOUT 5 MINUTES TO A DIM FORK IN THE TRAIL.  BEAR LEFT AND GO EASTERLY ON A DIM TRAIL FOR ABOUT 10 MINUTES TO THE TOP OF THE HILL AND THE STATION.  A 30 MINUTE PACK.  THE STATION MARK IS A U.S. GEOLOGICAL SURVEY BENCH MARK DISK STAMPED CORTADERA 1934, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN OUTCROPPING BEDROCK WHICH PROJECTS 4 INCHES.  REFERENCE MARK 3 IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED CORTADERA USGS NO 3 1966, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN OUTCROPPING BEDROCK WHICH PROJECTS 1 INCH.  REFERENCE MARK 4 IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED CORTADERA USGS NO 4 1966, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN OUTCROPPING BEDROCK WHICH PROJECTS 8 INCHES.  NO AZIMUTH MARK WAS ESTABLISHED AT THIS STATION.  AIRLINE DISTANCE AND DIRECTION FROM NEAREST TOWN 5 MILES NORTH OF SAN SABASTIAN.                            STATION RECOVERY (1999)  RECOVERY NOTE BY UNIVERSITY OF PUERTO RICO AT MAYAGUEZ 1999 THIS BENCH MARK CANT FIND IT BECAUSE IT IS IN A PRIVATE PROPERTY
markers.setting: SET IN ROCK OUTCROP
markers.stability: MOST RELIABLE AND EXPECTED TO HOLDPOSITION/ELEVATION WELL

markers.description: BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1993 THE STATION IS LOCATED AT THE EAST END OF THE AIRPORT JUST NORTH OF RWY END 26.  IT IS 197.1 FT (60.1 M) NORTH OF CL END RWY 26 (MARKED WITH A SPIKE), 49.8 FT (15.2 M) NORTHWEST OF THE NORTH MOST THRESHOLD LIGHT AND 48.0 FT (14.6 M) NORTH OF THE NORTH EDGE OF RUNWAY PAVEMENT. IT IS A PK NAIL AND NOS-CGS ALUMINUM WASHER STAMPED CP D 93 CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE AT THE NORTHEAST CORNER OF AN ABANDONED THRESHOLD LIGHT BAR.  IT IS DIRECTLY IDENTIFIED ON PHOTO 92 BCN 6849.                            STATION RECOVERY (1996)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1996 (AJL) THE STATION IS LOCATED NEAR THE NORTHWEST CORNER OF THE ISLAND OF PUERTO RICO, NORTH-NORTHEAST OF AGUADILLA, AT THE RAFAEL HERNANDEZ AIRPORT.  NEAR AND NORTH OF THE NORTHEAST CORNER OF RUNWAY END 26, SET IN TOP OF AND 0.1 M (0.3 FT) SOUTHWEST OF THE NORTHEAST CORNER OF AN ABANDONED CONCRETE THRESHOLD LIGHT BAR.  OWNERSHIP--PUERTO RICO PORT AUTHORITY, RAFAEL HERNANDAZ AIRPORT, P.O.  BOX 250466, AGUADILLA, PUERTO RICO.  00604-0466.  AIRPORT MANAGER GONZALO GONZALEZ, PHONE 787-891-0006 OR 891-2286.  NOTE--CONTACT AIRPORT MANAGER ON ARRIVAL, (ESCORT REQUIRED) .  NOTE--THIS STATION WAS SELECTED AS A (SACS) . NOTE--THE STATION IS A PK NAIL AND NOS-CGS ALUMINUM WASHER STAMPED (CP D 93) , CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE NEAR THE NORTHEAST CORNER OF AN ABANDONED THRESHOLD LIGHT BAR.  LOCATED 60.0 M (196.8 FT) NORTH OF THE CENTERLINE END OF RUNWAY END 26 (MARKED WITH A SPIKE) , 15.2 M (49.9 FT) NORTHWEST OF THE NORTHERN MOST THRESHOLD LIGHT, 14.6 M (47.9 FT) NORTH OF THE NORTH EDGE OF THE RUNWAY, AND THE STATION IS ABOUT LEVEL WITH THE RUNWAY AND FLUSH WITH THE GROUND SURFACE.  BY R.G.  HAYES                            STATION RECOVERY (2000)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 2000 (APF) RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED.                            STATION RECOVERY (2002)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 2002 (JMW) 5.8 KM (3.6 MI) NORTHERLY ALONG STATE HIGHWAY 107 FROM THE JUNCTION OF STATE HIGHWAY 2 IN AGUADILLA, THENCE 1.3 KM (0.8 MI) EASTERLY ALONG ORIANDO ALACON AVENUE TO THE RAFAEL HERMANDAZ AIRPORT MAIN GATE, THENCE 0.3 KM (0.2 MI) SOUTHERLY THROUGH THE GATE AND ON TO AN APRON, THENCE 1.6 KM (1.0 MI) EASTERLY CROSSING AN APRON AND THEN ALONG A TAXIWAY TO THE HOLD BARS, THENCE 0.8 KM (0.5 MI) EASTERLY ALONG THE NORTH EDGE OF THE RUNWAY TO THE RUNWAY THRESHOLD LIGHT BAR, A PK NAIL SET IN TOP OF AND 0.1 M SOUTHWEST OF THE NORTHWEST CORNER OF A CONCRETE THRESHOLD LIGHT BASE, 60.0 M NORTH OF THE RUNWAY CENTERLINE, 36.2 M NORTHEAST OF THE 1ST RUNWAY LIGHT, 29.2 M NORTH OF THE MOST NORTHERLY THRESHOLD LIGHT, 14.5 M NORTH OF THE NORTH EDGE OF THE PAVEMENT, 0.4 M BELOW THE LEVEL OF THE RUNWAY, AND 0.1 M BELOW THE GROUND SURFACE. NOTE--A WASHER WITH THE NAIL IS STAMPED CP D 93. THE MARK IS ON PROPERTY OWNED BY THE RAFAEL HERNANDAZ AIRPORT, P.O. BOX 250466, AGUADILLA, PR 00604-0466, CONTACT GONZALO GONZALEX, AIRPORT MANAGER, PHONE 787-891-2286. THIS IS A SECONDARY AIRPORT CONTROL STATION.

BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1900 (JN) STATION IS ON THE HIGH RIDGE OF THE SAME NAME, WHICH WITH TORO AND THE RIDGE AT POINT VERRACO FORMS THE SEAWARD WALL FOR THE VALLEY AT THE HEAD OF GUAYANILLA BAY, THROUGH WHICH THE YAUCO RIVER WINDS.  THE NEAREST HACIENDA TO THE SIGNAL IS THAT OF SENOR DON HIERONIMO LLUVERAS, A WEALTHY PLANTER WHOSE SUGAR HOUSE AND QUARTERS ARE AT THE FOOT OF THE E SLOPE OF CRIOLLO.  THE LABORERS USED FOR CARRYING UP THE SIGNAL MATERIAL AND TO CLEAR THE LINES OF SIGHT ON THE MOUNTAIN WERE SECURED AT THIS HACIENDA AND IT SHOULD BE EASY FOR YEARS TO GET A MAN HERE WHO KNOWS ALL ABOUT THE SIGNAL LOCATION.  AT THE SIGNAL HEAVY CUTTING HAD TO BE DONE TO CLEAR LINES OF SIGHT TO TURN, MARIA LANGUA ISLAND, TORE, AND VAQUERO AND THE EVIDENCE OF THIS WORK WILL BE A GOOD MARK FOR YEARS.  A SCAFFOLD SIGNAL WAS ERECTED AND ABOUT EACH LEG, STONE WAS PILED UP TO THE HEIGHT OF SEVERAL FEET.  THESE WILL ALSO MAKE GOOD MARKS FOR IDENTIFICATION.  THE SIGNAL IS ABOUT 700 FEET ABOVE SEA LEVEL.  STATION MARK IS A 2-INCH IRON PIPE EMBEDDED IN THE ROCK TO A LENGTH OF ABOUT 20 INCHES AND SHOWING 4 INCHES CLEAR.  THIS WAS CEMENTED INTO PLACE AND THE CENTER OF THE PIPE WAS ALSO FILLED WITH CEMENT.  IN PROCEEDING TO THE SIGNAL, A ROAD IS FOLLOWED TO THE LAST OF THE CABINS TO THE W OF THE CANE FIELDS AND THEN CHANGE YOUR COURSE TO STRIKE THE STRONG WELL-BUILT BARBED-WIRE FENCE WHICH GOES STRAIGHT UP THE HILL.  THIS TAKES YOU ALMOST TO THE LOW SUMMIT ON THE E END OF THE RIDGE, AND FROM THIS A TRAIL RUNS ALONG THE TOP LINE OF THE RIDGE TO THE NEXT AND HIGHEST SUMMIT, ON WHICH THE SIGNAL STANDS.  AFTER REACHING THE LOW SUMMIT JUST MENTIONED, THE TRAIL INTERSECTS TWO LINES OF WIRE FENCING.                            STATION RECOVERY (1963)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1963 (CFO) THIS STATION WAS SEARCHED FOR AND NOT FOUND.
markers.setting: OBJECT SURROUNDED BY MASS OF CONCRETE
markers.stability: MARK OF QUESTIONABLE OR UNKNOWN STABILITY

markers.description: BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1934 STATION IS LOCATED 9 KILOMETERS BY ROAD AND TRAIL S OF YAUCO, NEAR THE W END OF A HIGH RIDGE WHICH EXTENDS W FROM GUAYANILLA BAY S OF RIO YAUCO.  THIS RIDGE DROPS OFF ABRUPTLY TO RIO YAUCO VALLEY ON THE N, AND SLOPES OFF MORE GENTLY TOWARDS COAST.  IT IS QUITE FLAT ON TOP FOR ABOUT 1.5 OR 2 KILOMETERS THEN DROPS OFF INTO A SERIES OF LOWER RIDGES TO THE W.  THIS STATION IS ABOUT 0.75 KILOMETER W FROM STATION CRIOLLO, ON THE LAST PROMINENT RISE ON RIDGE TO W, WHICH IS VERY ROCKY AT THIS POINT.  IT IS ABOUT 30 FEET S OF A TRAIL WHICH TRAVERSES THE RIDGE FROM E TO W.  STATION MARK IS A STANDARD U.S.G.S. TABLET STAMPED CRIOLLO-2 1934 CEMENTED IN LARGE LIMESTONE ROCK SET IN GROUND.  A QUADRIPOD OF SAWED LUMBER COVERED WITH WHITE CLOTH AND WITH BLACK CROSS TARGETS ON CENTER POLE OVER STATION MARK IS THE SIGNAL.  REFERENCE MARK NO.1 IS A COPPER NAIL AND WASHER IN TRIANGULAR BLAZE ON CORCHO STUMP, 5.75 FEET FROM STATION MARK, IN TRUE AZIMUTH 185 DEG 19 MIN.  REFERENCE MARK NO.2 IS A 1-INCH DRILL HOLE IN ROCK 5.17 FEET FROM STATION MARK, IN TRUE AZIMUTH 263 DEG 22 MIN.  TO REACH STATION FROM YAUCO, FOLLOW ROAD LEADING TO CENTRAL SAN FRANCISCO ALSO KNOWN AS CENTRAL JUEVERES, FOR 6.5 KILOMETERS TO A ROAD FORK JUST AFTER CROSSING RIO YAUCO ON BRIDGE, TURN RIGHT (S) ON ROAD PAST HOUSES AND FOLLOW TO FORKS JUST AFTER AGAIN CROSSING RIVER AT FORK, TURN RIGHT (W) ON ROAD AND FOLLOW AROUND FOOT OF MOUNTAIN TO FIRST HOUSE S OF ROAD.  ABOUT 1/3 KILOMETER FROM THIS HOUSE A TRAIL LEADS UP MOUNTAIN TO ANOTHER HOUSE AND CLEARED FIELD ABOUT 2/3 OF WAY TO TOP.  JUST AFTER CROSSING DRAW AT HEAD OF DEEP RAVINE TURN LEFT (E) ON TRAIL CROSSING FENCE LINE, AND FOLLOW DIM TRAIL UP DRAW, THEN UP SPUR RIDGE TO TOP.  AT TOP TURN RIGHT (W) AND FOLLOW DIM TRAIL ALONG RIDGE ABOUT 1,800 FEET TO STATION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1966)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JJL) THE STATION MARK WAS RECOVERED AND FOUND IN GOOD CONDITION.  TWO NEW REFERENCE MARKS WERE ESTABLISHED.  A COMPLETE NEW DESCRIPTION OF THE STATION FOLLOWS.  THE STATION IS LOCATED 5-3/4 AIRLINE MILES WEST-SOUTHWEST OF GUAYANILLA AND ON THE TOP OF A HIGH BRUSH COVERED HILL.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE INTERSECTION OF HIGHWAYS 2 AND 135 IN THE EAST EDGE OF YAUCO, GO SOUTH AND EAST ON HIGHWAY 135 FOR 3.6 MILES TO A CROSSROAD.  TURN RIGHT AND GO SOUTHERLY ON A GRAVELED ROAD FOR 0.15 MILE TO A SIDE ROAD RIGHT.  TURN RIGHT AND GO WESTERLY ON A GRAVELED ROAD FOR 0.55 MILE TO A SIDE ROAD LEFT AT A SMALL STORE.  TURN LEFT AND GO SOUTH ON A BLADED ROAD FOR 0.55 MILE TO A SIDE ROAD RIGHT.  CONTINUE STRAIGHT AHEAD AND GO SOUTH AND EAST ON THE BLADED ROAD FOR 0.15 MILE TO A SIDE ROAD RIGHT.  TURN RIGHT AND GO SOUTH ON A BLADED ROAD FOR 0.35 MILE TO A CROSSROAD IN A SADDLE.  TURN LEFT AND GO EAST ON A TRACK ROAD FOR 0.2 MILE TO THE END OF TRUCK TRAVEL AT THE END OF THE TRACK ROAD.  FROM HERE PACK EAST ON A TRAIL FOR ABOUT 10 MINUTES TO THE TOP OF THE BRUSH COVERED HILL AND THE STATION.  THE STATION MARK IS A U.S. GEOLOGICAL SURVEY BENCH MARK DISK STAMPED CRIOLLO 2 1934, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN OUTCROPPING BEDROCK WHICH PROJECTS 8 INCHES.  REFERENCE MARK 1 IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED CRIOLLO 2 USGS NO 1 1934 1966, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN OUTCROPPING BEDROCK WHICH PROJECTS 5 INCHES.  (NOTE 12A)  REFERENCE MARK 2 IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED CRIOLLO 2 USGS NO 2 1934 1966, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN OUTCROPPING BEDROCK WHICH PROJECTS 1 INCH. (NOTE 12A)  NO AZIMUTH MARK WAS ESTABLISHED AT THIS STATION.  AIRLINE DISTANCE AND DIRECTION FROM NEAREST TOWN 5 MILES SOUTH OF YAUCO.                            STATION RECOVERY (1982)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1982 (JCL) THE STATION MARK AND REFERENCE MARK 2 WERE RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.  THE STEM OF THE DISK FOR REFERENCE MARK 1 WAS RECOVERED, AND USED, BUT THE DISK WAS NOT REPLACED.  THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 9.2 KM (5-3/4 MI) WEST-SOUTHWEST OF GUAYANILLA, 5.8 KM (3-1/2 MI) SOUTH OF YAUCO, 1.6 KM (1 MI) EAST OF THE POINT WHERE THE POWER LINE CROSSES THE RIDGE, AND ON THE HIGHEST POINT OF A LONG PROMINENT BRUSH COVERED EAST-WEST RIDGE, WHICH IS BARE ON THE NORTH SLOPE APPROXIMATELY 1/4 MILE BELOW THE STATION.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE JUNCTION OF HIGHWAYS 127 AND 335 IN THE EAST EDGE OF YAUCO, GO SOUTH ON HIGHWAY 335  FOR 6.1 KM (3.65 MI) TO THE JUNCTION OF RAMAL 335, JUST AFTER CROSSING BRIDGE.  TURN RIGHT AND FOLLOW RAMAL 335 SOUTHERLY FOR 0.35 KM (0.2 MI) TO A PAVED SIDE ROAD RIGHT, JUST AFTER CROSSING SMALL CONCRETE BRIDGE.  TURN RIGHT, TAKING LOWER ONE OF TWO PAVED ROADS, AND PROCEED WESTERLY FOR 1.0 KM (0.6 MI) TO A FORK WITH A BLUE FRAME HOUSE IN THE CENTER OF SAID AFOREMENTIONED FORK.  TAKE LEFT FORK ON PAVED ROAD FOR 0.1 KM (0.05 MI) TO THE END OF PAVEMENT.   PROCEED SOUTHWESTERLY (FOUR-WHEEL DRIVE DESIRABLE BEYOND THIS POINT) ON TRACK ROAD FOR 0.8 KM (0.45 MI) TO THE TOP OF GRADE.  CONTINUE DOWN HILL ON TRACK ROAD SOUTHEASTERLY FOR 0.1 KM (0.05 MI) TO A DIM FORK.  TAKE LEFT FORK EAST AND SOUTHEASTERLY FOR 0.5 KM (0.25 MI) TO A FENCE ACROSS THE ROAD AND END OF TRUCK TRAVEL.  PACK EASTERLY ALONG COW TRAILS UP SMALL WASH TO A SADDLE IN A GRASSY AREA AND A NORTH-WEST FENCE CORNER.  BEAR RIGHT AND PACK SOUTH ALONG EAST SIDE OF FENCE TO END OF FENCE LINE, JUST BELOW THE SUMMIT OF THE STATION HILL.  PROCEED SOUTHERLY FOR APPROXIMATELY 100 METERS TO THE HIGHEST POINT OF THE HILL AND THE STATION.  THE STATION IS A STANDARD USGS DISK STAMPED---CRIOLLO 2 1934---, SET INTO A ROCK OUTCROP 0.45 METER LARGEST DIMENSION AND PROJECTING 17 CM ABOVE THE GROUND. IT IS LOCATED 9.90 METERS (32.5 FT) SOUTH FROM A EAST-WEST TRAIL.  REFERENCE MARK NUMBER 1 IS THE STEM OF OLD REFERENCE MARK 1. MARK IS BELOW STATION 1 METER.  REFERENCE MARK NUMBER 2 IS A STANDARD CGS DISK STAMPED---CRIOLLO 2 USGS NO 2 1934 1966---, SET INTO A ROCK OUTCROP.  IT IS LOCATED MARK IS BELOW STATION 0.5 METERS.  NO MEASUREMENT BETWEEN REFERENCE MARKS BECAUSE OF HEAVY BRUSH AND ROUGH TERRAIN. NO LIGHT SHOWN FROM THIS STATION AT THIS TIME.                            STATION RECOVERY (2004)  RECOVERY NOTE BY UNIVERSITY OF PUERTO RICO AT MAYAGUEZ 2004 (JMA) THE STATION MARK AND REFERENCE MARK 2 WERE NOT RECOVERED.
markers.setting: SET IN ROCK OUTCROP
markers.stability: MOST RELIABLE AND EXPECTED TO HOLDPOSITION/ELEVATION WELL

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1941 (RLS) STATION IS ABOUT 1 MILE SSW OF CEIBA, ABOUT 170 METERS S OF THE INTERSECTION OF INSULAR HIGHWAY 3 AND THE ENSENADA HONDA HIGHWAY, ABOUT 150 METERS WNW OF THE CROSSING OF THE ENSENADA HONDA HIGHWAY AND THE AMERICAN RAILROAD, AT THE E END OF A SHOULDER EXTENDING EASTWARD FROM THE HIGHER HILLS ACROSS THE HIGHWAY TO THE W, 100 METERS SW OF THE CENTER LINE OF THE ENSENADA HONDA HIGHWAY, 78 METERS ESE OF THE CENTER LINE OF HIGHWAY 3, AND 72 METERS ESE OF THE RIGHT-OF-WAY FENCE.  THE MARK PROJECTS 6 INCHES ABOVE THE GROUND.  THE ELEVATION OF THE STATION IS ABOUT 38.2 METERS.  STATION AND REFERENCE MARKS ARE STANDARD BRONZE DISKS SET IN CONCRETE, AS DESCRIBED IN NOTES 1A AND 11A.  THERE IS NO UNDERGROUND MARK.  REFERENCE MARK NO.1 IS 0.56 METER HIGHER THAN THE STATION AND PROJECTS 2 INCHES ABOVE THE GROUND.  REFERENCE MARK NO.2 IS 28.1 METERS NE OF REFERENCE MARK NO.1, 0.18 METER HIGHER THAN THE STATION, AND IS FLUSH WITH THE GROUND.
markers.setting: SET IN TOP OF CONCRETE MONUMENT
markers.stability: MAY HOLD, BUT OF TYPE COMMONLY SUBJECT TOSURFACE MOTION

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1901 (JN) STATION IS SITUATED ON LAND BELONGING TO PACO NOYA, ABOUT 1 MILE S OF THE COAST AND 2-1/2 MILES W OF THE TOWN OF CAMUY.  IT IS ON A HILL CALLED CUESTA DE LAS NOYAS WHICH IS ABOUT 335 FEET HIGH.  IT IS ON THE HIGHEST POINT OF THE W END OF THE HILL, BEING ABOUT 600 FEET E OF A ROAD LEADING UP THE HILL AND ABOUT 25 FEET S OF THE E-W LINE OF WOODS.  IT IS SITUATED IN A STONY FIELD ABOUT 175 FEET W OF A CABIN OCCUPIED BY FEDERICO RODRIQUES.  THE HILL IS THE HIGHEST IN THE VICINITY.  THE STATION IS MARKED BY A BRASS BOLT CEMENTED INTO A HOLE IN A LARGE ROCK (200 POUNDS) BEDDED IN PLACE WITH CEMENT AND STONE.  THE HEAD OF THE BOLT PROJECTS ABOUT 4 INCHES ABOVE THE SURFACE OF THE GROUND AND THE CENTER OF THE HEAD MARKS THE STATION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1962)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1962 (CFO) STATION SEARCHED FOR AND NOT RECOVERED, PROBABLY DESTROYED.
markers.setting: SET IN UNSPECIFIED ROCK OR BOULDER
markers.stability: PROBABLY HOLD POSITION/ELEVATION WELL

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1900 (WCH) THIS STATION IS ON THE SOLID ROCK FORMING THE SUMMIT OF CRUZ (OR CROSS) CAY, W OF CULEBRA.  OWING TO THE FORMATION THE STATION WAS MARKED BY A TACK IN A LITTLE CEMENT PLASTERED ON THE ROCK.                            STATION RECOVERY (1900)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1900 (JBB) ON THE NE POINT OF CAYO CRUZ OR CROSS CAY ON THE HIGHEST POINT OF HUMMOCK ABOUT 200 METERS FROM EXTREME POINT AND MIDWAY BETWEEN THE TWO SHORES.  IT IS MARKED BY A PUDDLE OF CEMENT MADE ON THE ROCK.  A NAIL IN THE CEMENT MARKS THE EXACT POINT.  A TRIPOD SIGNAL WAS ERECTED OVER THE STATION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1904)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1904 (RLF) STATION RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1966)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JJL) THE STATION WAS NOT RECOVERED.  DUE TO CONSTRUCTION IN THE AREA IT IS BELIEVED THE STATION HAS BEEN DESTROYED.  CRUZ 2 WAS ESTABLISHED IN THE NEAR VICINITY.  SEE DESCRIPTION THEREOF.

BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JJL) NOTE--THIS STATION IS LOCATED IN A GUNNERY RANGE.  PERMISSION MUST BE OBTAINED FROM THE U.S. NAVY OBSERVATION POST ON CULEBRA ISLAND BEFORE VISITING THE STATION.  THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 5-1/4 MILES WEST-NORTHWEST OF CULEBRA AND ON A FLAT, CLEARED AREA ABOUT MIDWAY BETWEEN THE NORTHWEST AND NORTHEAST POINTS OF A SMALL ISLAND KNOWN AS CRUZ, CROSS OR LOBO CAY.  THIS IS ABOUT 100 YARDS WEST-NORTHWEST OF AND 50 FEET HIGHER THAN A CONCRETE HELICOPTER LANDING PAD.  THE STATION MAY BE REACHED BY BOAT OR HELICOPTER.  THE STATION MARK, STAMPED CRUZ 2 1966, IS A STANDARD DISK SET IN THE TOP OF A CEMENT AND ROCK MONUMENT THAT IS FLUSH WITH THE GROUND.  REFERENCE MARKS WERE NOT ESTABLISHED.
markers.setting: UNSPECIFIED SETTING

markers.description: BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1939 LOCATED AT BARRIO PAJAROS AMERICANOS, AND ABOUT 2 KMS. SE OF BAYAMON AND 250 METERS S OF RD. 42 AT ITS KM.  IT IS ON LAND OWNED BY SAHTOS SUAREZ ALIAS SANTOS CUBANO.  APPROACHED FROM BAYAMON BY FOLLOWING RD. 9, 2 KMS. S TO ITS JUNCTION WITH RD. 42, FOLLOW W (RD.42) KMS. TO A HIGH POINT NEAR TWO SCHOOL BUILDINGS.  LEAVE ROAD FOLLOWING DIRT RD. N ALONG RIDGE ABOUT 250 METERS TO THE TOP OF THE RIDGE, TURN E ALONG TRAIL ABOUT 100 METERS TO THE TOP OF THE HILL.  STATION MARK--STANDARD TABLET STAMPED CUBANO 1939 CEMENTED IN CONCRETE MONUMENT 8 INCHES DIAMETER ON TOP, 12 INCHES DIAMETER ON BOTTOM BY 36 INCHES DEEP.  SIGNAL--POLE OF 1- BY 4-INCH ROUGH LUMBER WITH FLAG ON TOP AND CROSSED BLACK TARGETS 5 FT. 4-5/8 INCHES FROM STATION.  R. M. NO. 1--R.R. SPIKE FIXED TO NATURAL ROCK 5.58 METERS HOR. DIST. E OF S OF STATION.  R. M. NO. 2--R.R. SPIKE FIXED TO NATURAL ROCK 12.27 METERS HOR. DIST. E OF STATION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1941)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1941 (GBG) LOCATED ABOUT 2 MILES SW OF BAYAMON, AT BARRIO PAJAROS AMERICANOS.  AND ABOUT 300 METERS N OF ROAD 42, ON LAND OWNED BY FELIX PALACIO.  IT IS ON A PROMINENT, ROUND BARE HILL ABOUT 400 METERS NE OF THE PAJAROS AMERICANOS SCHOOL.  THE STATION IS ON THE HIGHEST POINT.  AND IS MARKED BY A STANDARD DISK, STAMPED CUBANO 1939, CEMENTED IN A CONCRETE MONUMENT 8 INCHES IN DIAMETER AT TOP, PROJECTING 4 INCHES.  REFERENCE MARK 1 IS A RAILROAD SPIKE CEMENTED TO ROCK LEDGE 5.58 METERS SE OF STATION.  REFERENCE MARK 2 IS A RAILROAD SPIKE CEMENTED TO ROCK LEDGE ON HILLSIDE 12.27 METERS W OF THE STATION.  TO REACH FROM BAYAMON.  GO TO THE Y-FORK THREE BLOCKS W OF THE PLAZA, AND TURN SW ON ROAD 9 (TO COMERIO).  GO 1.4 MILES, AND TURN SHARP RIGHT ON THE ROAD (42) TO TOA ALTA.  CONTINUE 1.4 MILES ON THIS ROAD TO THE CREST OF A GRADE JUST E OF THE PAJAROS AMERICANOS SCHOOL.  AND TAKE THE DIRT LANE N TO CREST AND FENCE.  FOLLOW FENCE EASTWARD PAST TWO HOUSES TO THE PROMINENT HILL WHERE THE STATION IS LOCATED.                            STATION RECOVERY (1969)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1969 STATION WAS REPORTED DESTROYED.
markers.setting: SET IN TOP OF CONCRETE MONUMENT
markers.stability: MAY HOLD, BUT OF TYPE COMMONLY SUBJECT TOSURFACE MOTION

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1961 (MLO) STATION RECOVERED AS THE LIGHT ATOP A WHITE CYLINDRICAL CONCRETE TOWER ON THE LARGEST AND MOST SOUTHERN OF LAS CUCARACHAS.  ACCORDING TO THE 1961 LIGHT LIST, THE LIGHT WAS LAST MOVED OR REBUILT IN 1920.  THE CONCRETE TOWER APPEARS TO BE THIS OLD.  A THEODOLITE CUT FROM CAPE, 1901 CHECKS THE COMPUTED DIRECTION OF THE LIGHT FROM THIS STATION WITHIN A FEW SECONDS.                            STATION RECOVERY (1964)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1964 (GWM) STATION RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED.

BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1934 STATION LOCATED ABOUT 10 KILOMETERS BY ROAD AND TRAIL, SW OF BARRANQUITAS AND ABOUT THE SAME DISTANCE SE OF OROCOVIS, ON THE MAIN DIVIDING RANGE OF MOUNTAINS.  IT IS ABOUT 2 KILOMETERS NW OF SCHOOL AND SETTLEMENT KNOWN AS CUCHILLA DE COAMO, OR MERELY LA CUCHILLA, AND BY WHICH NAME THE SURROUNDING COMMUNITY IS KNOWN.  (THE NAME CUCHILLA, MEANING KNIFE, IS USED TO DESIGNATE A NARROW DIVIDING RIDGE).  THE STATION IS ON A GRASSY RIDGE WHICH HAS A PROMINENT PEAK AT ITS W END WHICH IS NOT QUITE AS HIGH AS THE MAIN RIDGE WHERE THE STATION IS LOCATED, THE SLOPES AND SADDLE OF RIDGE HAS MANY SCATTERED WILD OR NATIVE ROYAL PALM TREES.  THIS RIDGE IS THE HIGHEST IN THE IMMEDIATE VICINITY AND LIES ABOUT 1 KILOMETER TO THE W OF MAIN TRAIL FROM OROCOVIS TO CUCHILLA.  THE STATION IS VERY NEAR THE SOUTHERN EDGE OF THE TOP, 65 FEET S OF A FENCE LINE WHICH CROSSES RIDGE.  IT IS ON LAND OF JOSE MARIA ORTIZ.  STATION MARK IS A STANDARD U.S.G.S. TABLET, STAMPED CUCHILLA DE COAMA 1934, CEMENTED IN ROUNDED TOP, SQUARE ROCK WHICH PROJECTS ABOUT 5 INCHES ABOVE SURFACE OF GROUND.  REFERENCE MARKS ARE CROSSES CUT ON TOPS OF ROCKS SET IN GROUND ON SLIGHTLY RAISED POINTS.  REFERENCE MARK NO.1 IS 32.29 FEET FROM STATION IN TRUE AZIMUTH 134 DEG 51 MIN.  REFERENCE MARK NO.2 IS 45.80 FEET FROM STATION IN TRUE AZIMUTH 193 DEG 31 MIN.  SIGNAL--QUADRIPOD OF SAWED LUMBER COVERED WITH BLACK CROSS-TARGETS ON CENTER POLE.  THE STATION CAN BE REACHED FROM EITHER BARRANQUITAS OR OROCOVIS BY TRAIL.  MOST ANY NATIVE OF THE COMMUNITY CAN DIRECT ONE TO THE STATION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1966)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JJL) THE STATION WAS RECOVERED AND FOUND TO BE IN A VERY POOR CONDITION.  NO REFERENCE MARKS WERE FOUND.  THE STATION MARK IS STILL WHERE IT WAS FOUND BUT IT IS BROKEN OFF AT GROUND LEVEL.  A NEW STATION KNIFE WAS ESTABLISHED NEAR THE SAME LOCATION.
markers.setting: SET IN ROCK OUTCROP
markers.stability: MOST RELIABLE AND EXPECTED TO HOLDPOSITION/ELEVATION WELL

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1900 (JBB) STATION IS ERECTED ON MEADOW LAND OWNED BY LORNAS LOPEZ, ABOUT 25 FEET S OF HIGHEST POINT OF PROMINENT HILL ON CUEVA POINT, ON GENTLE SLOPE AT CREST OF HILL.  IT IS SOME 20 METERS N OF A SMALL LEANING TREE AND ABOUT 8 METERS E BY N OF HEDGE.                            STATION RECOVERY (1922)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1922 (FTS) STATION WAS RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED AND FOUND IN GOOD CONDITION.  TWO STANDARD BRONZE DISK REFERENCE MARKS WERE SET IN CONCRETE IN DEPRESSIONS IN OUTCROPPING BEDROCK.  DISTANCES--STATION TO REFERENCE MARK NO.1, 19.31 (METERS --) IN AZIMUTH 64 DEG MAGNETIC.  STATION TO REFERENCE MARK NO.2, 16.71 (METERS --) IN AZIMUTH 128 DEG MAGNETIC.  STATION TO CAPE SAN JUAN LIGHTHOUSE, 23 DEG MAGNETIC.                            STATION RECOVERY (1926)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1926 (GCM) STATION MARK A CONCRETE POST, IS IN GOOD CONDITION.  REFERENCE MARKS WERE DESTROYED.  DESCRIPTION ADEQUATE.                            STATION RECOVERY (1961)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1961 (MLO) STATION WAS SEARCHED FOR BUT NOT RECOVERED.
markers.setting: SET IN TOP OF CONCRETE MONUMENT
markers.stability: MAY HOLD, BUT OF TYPE COMMONLY SUBJECT TOSURFACE MOTION

markers.description: BY BUREAU OF LAND MANAGEMENT 1993 TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE AIRSTRIP ON CULEBRA ISLAND, GO SOUTH-SOUTHEAST ALONG PAVED ROAD 2.0 KILOMETERS (1.25 MI) TO CEMETERY ON LEFT.  CONTINUE EAST ALONG PAVED ROAD UP A SMALL HILL 200 METERS (656.2 FT) TO MACHINE SHOP ON RIGHT (SOUTH) .  TURN RIGHT (SOUTH) ON PAVED ROAD AND CONTINUE SOUTH ON PAVED ROAD 0.4 KILOMETERS (0.25 MI) TO END OF PAVED ROAD AT OFFICE OF DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES. FOLLOW DIRT TRACK BETWEEN DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES AND FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE OFFICES TOWARD HOUSE WITH BLUE ROOF ABOUT 150 METERS (492.1 FT) TO ABANDONED HELIPAD.  THE STATION IS A 3-1/4 INCH BRASS CAP SET IN CONCRETE AT CENTER OF ABANDONED HELIPAD AT SOUTH END OF CULEBRA ISLAND.  CAP IS STAMPED U.S.  DEPARTMENT OF INTERIOR, FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE, CUL CP 3 HELIPAD 1993.                            STATION RECOVERY (2012)  RECOVERY NOTE BY POLYTECHNIC UNIVERSITY OF PUERTO RICO 2012 (KBR) DESCRIBED BY BUREAU OF LAND MANAGEMENT 1993 TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE AIRSTRIP ON CULEBRA ISLAND, GO SOUTH-SOUTHEAST ALONG PAVED ROAD 2.0 KILOMETERS (1.25 MI) TO CEMETERY ON LEFT. CONTINUE EAST ALONG PAVED ROAD UP A SMALL HILL 200 METERS (656.2 FT) TO MACHINE SHOP ON RIGHT (SOUTH) .  TURN RIGHT (SOUTH) ON PAVED ROAD AND CONTINUE SOUTH ON PAVED ROAD 0.4 KILOMETERS (0.25 MI)TO END OF PAVED ROAD AT OFFICE OF DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES.FOLLOW DIRT TRACK BETWEEN DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES AND FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE OFFICES TOWARD HOUSE WITH BLUE ROOF ABOUT 150 METERS(492.1 FT) TO ABANDONED HELIPAD. THE STATION IS A 3-1/4 INCH BRASS CAP SET IN CONCRETE AT CENTER OF ABANDONED HELIPAD AT SOUTH END OF CULEBRA ISLAND.  CAP IS STAMPED U.S.  DEPARTMENT OF INTERIOR, FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE,CUL CP 3 HELIPAD 1993.
markers.setting: OBJECT SURROUNDED BY MASS OF CONCRETE
markers.stability: MAY HOLD, BUT OF TYPE COMMONLY SUBJECT TOSURFACE MOTION

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1900 (JBB) STATION IS ON THE SLOPE OF HILL IN AN OPEN FIELD 1/2 MILE FROM HEAD OF GREAT HARBOR AND 100 METERS FROM EASTERN SHORE LINE OF HARBOR.  STATION WAS ABOUT 4 METERS S OF A FENCE RUNNING OVER HILL.  A TRIPOD SIGNAL WAS ERECTED OVER STATION, WHICH WAS MARKED BY A NAIL SET IN LEAD IN A HOLE DRILLED IN THE TOP OF A GRANITE POST ABOUT 6 BY 6 INCHES.  THE POST PROJECTS ABOUT 6 INCHES ABOVE THE SURFACE OF THE GROUND.                            STATION RECOVERY (1957)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1957 (RCD) THE AREA WAS SEARCHED BUT THE STATION WAS NOT RECOVERED.  THE FENCE RUNNING OVER THE HILL (IN PREVIOUS DESCRIPTION) IS NO LONGER STANDING, BUT SIGNS OF IT ARE VISIBLE ON PHOTOGRAPH AND CAN EASILY BE FOUND, AS A TREE AND SEVERAL BUSHES ARE LOCATED ALONG THE OLD FENCE LINE.  THE AREA IS COVERED WITH SMALL CACTI WHICH WILL PENETRATE LEATHER OF ORDINARY SHOES.  IT IS RECOMMENDED THAT HIGH, HEAVY, BOOTS BE WORN WHEN SEARCHING FOR THIS STATION.  THIS CACTI PREVENTED AN EXTENSIVE SEARCH.  THE MARK CAN PROBABLY BE RECOVERED BY A MORE INTENSIVE SEARCH.

BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 2019 STATION IS A GPS CORS.  LATEST INFORMATION INCLUDING POSITIONS AND VELOCITIES ARE AVAILABLE IN THE COORDINATE AND LOG FILES ACCESSIBLE BY ANONYMOUS FTP OR THE WORLDWIDE WEB.    https://geodesy.noaa.gov/corsdata/coord/coord_14     https://geodesy.noaa.gov/corsdata/station_log     https://geodesy.noaa.gov/CORS
markers.marker: _MARKER: STATION IS THE ANTENNA REFERENCE POINT OF THE GPS ANTENNA

markers.description: MENT IS ASSOCIATED WITH CORS SITE 'CUPR' LATEST INFORMATION INCLUDING POSITIONS AND VELOCITIES ARE AVAILABLE IN THE COORDINATE AND LOG FILES ACCESSIBLE BY ANONYMOUS FTP OR THE WORLDWIDE WEB.    https://geodesy.noaa.gov/corsdata/coord/coord_14    https://geodesy.noaa.gov/corsdata/station_log    https://geodesy.noaa.gov/CORS RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED.

BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1900 (JBB) STATION IS ON THE LEFT HAND SIDE OF THE VALLEY AS YOU GO N FROM THE HEAD OF GREAT HARBOR AND ABOUT 200 METERS FROM SAID HARBOR.  A TRAIL RUNNING UP THE VALLEY PASSES JUST TO LEFT OF STATION, WHICH WAS MARKED BY A NAIL SET IN CEMENT POST 4 BY 4 INCHES AND PROJECTING ABOUT 5 INCHES ABOVE THE GROUND.  A TRIPOD SIGNAL WAS ERECTED OVER THE STATION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1957)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1957 (RCD) THIS AREA IS NOW POPULATED AND SEVERAL ROADS HAVE BEEN BUILT THROUGH THE AREA.  THE STATION WAS NOT RECOVERED AFTER A SEARCH OF ONE AND ONE-HALF HOURS.  NATIVES WERE QUESTIONED, BUT NONE KNEW OF THE MARK.  STATION SEARCHED FOR AND NOT FOUND, BELIEVED LOST.

BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1900 (WCH) STATION IS A LARGE MASONRY STRUCTURE WITH THE USUAL FLAT ROOF AND LIGHT TOWER RISING AT CENTER.  THE ECCENTRIC STATION WAS MADE ON THE FLAT ROOF W OF THE TOWER.  ON THE SUMMIT OF CULEBRITA ISLAND.                            STATION RECOVERY (1965)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1965 (JMC) RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.  PREVIOUS DESCRIPTION ADEQUATE.                            STATION RECOVERY (1966)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JJL) THE STATION SITE WAS NOT VISITED.  THE LIGHTHOUSE IS STILL STANDING AND FROM A DISTANCE APPEARS TO BE IN GOOD CONDITION.  IT WAS USED AS AN INTERSECTION STATION AND FOR CHECK ANGLE PURPOSES.                            STATION RECOVERY (1971)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1971 (JKW) NO DESCRIPTION AVAILABLE.  THE LIGHTHOUSE WAS USED AS A CHECK AZIMUTH FROM TRIANGULATION STATION BRUSH 1918.  AIRLINE DISTANCE AND DIRECTION FROM NEAREST TOWN 1/2 MILE E. OF CULEBRA.

BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1934 STATION ORIGINALLY ESTABLISHED BY DIVISION OF PUBLIC LANDS OF THE DEPARTMENT OF THE INTERIOR OF PUERTO RICO.  THE STATION IS ALSO PROBABLY ON THE SAME KNOLL AS FORMER U.S.C. AND G.S., STATION SEBORUCO.  THE STATION IS AT THE EASTERN EDGE OF SANTURCE, JUST N OF MARTIN PENA CHANNEL AND WEST LAKE SAN JOSE, JUST S OF LAS CASAS RACE TRACK, NOW ABANDONED AND ABOUT 650 METERS NE OF LAS MONJAS BRIDGE, OVER MARTIN PENA CHANNEL, ON TOP OF SHARP REMAINS OF A LIMESTONE KNOLL, WHICH IS USED AS A STONE QUARRY KNOWN AS CANTERA DE REXACH.  THE STATION IS ON A SORT OF BENCH AT EXTREME WESTERN EDGE OF THE KNOLL.  STATION MARK IS THE CENTER OF A CAP ON A 2-INCH IRON PIPE IN A 10-INCH SQUARE CONCRETE POST.  A STEEL FLANGE ON THE PIPE BELOW THE CAP IS INSCRIBED GROVERNMENT OF PUERTO RICO-DEPARTMENT OF INTERIOR-DIVISION OF PUBLIC LANDS - TRIANGULATION STATION SURVEY MONUMENT.                            STATION RECOVERY (1941)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1941 (GBG) DESTROYED, 1941.                            STATION RECOVERY (1964)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1964 (GWM) THIS STATION WAS LOST WHEN THE HILL WAS TAKEN AWAY FOR BUILDING MATERIAL.
markers.setting: SET INTO TOP OF METAL PIPE DRIVEN INTO GROUND
markers.stability: MARK OF QUESTIONABLE OR UNKNOWN STABILITY

BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1926 (GCM) CUPOLA OF WHITE CEMENT BUILDING E OF ARROYO.  THIS BUILDING IS THE ONLY WHITE BUILDING E OF ARROYO AND SET 150 METERS BACK FROM THE BEACH.

BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1939 (EGR) LOCATED ABOUT 4 KMS. S OF RIO PIEDRAS ON LAND OWNED BY SUC MONGIL.  IT IS A RATHER LONG HILL WITH A ROUND END TO THE S HAVING A PROMINENT BUCOR TREE ON ITS HIGHEST POINT.  APPROACHED FROM RIO PIEDRAS FOLLOWING MUN. RD. TO CUPEY TO KM. 3.4 WHERE LEAVING CAR FOLLOW CANE RD. NW ALONG LOW RIDGE PASSING A HUT ON SADDLE AND PROCEEDING TO THE TOP OF HILL WHERE THE STATION IS. IT IS ABOUT 400M. FROM THE RD. TO THE HILL.  STATION MARK--STANDARD TABLET STAMPED CUPEY 1939, CEMENTED TO BOULDER.  R. M. NO. 1--R.R. SPIKE FIXED TO S SIDE OF BUCOR TREE, 6.98 METERS W OF STATION.  R. M. NO. 2--IRON BAR CEMENTED TO CONCRETE MONUMENT 13.13 METERS NW OF STATION.  SIGNAL--TRIPOD OF SAWED LUMBER WITH FLAG AND TARGET.                            STATION RECOVERY (1940)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1940 STATION AND R.M.S RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.  NEW DESCRIPTION FOLLOWS--  ABOUT 5 KMS. SOUTH OF RIO PIEDRAS.  3 KMS. E OF HIGHWAY NO. 1.  AND ABOUT 1/2 KM. W OF CUPEY MUN. RD.  ON LAND OWNED BY THE SUCESORES MONGIL - OR CENTRAL SAN JOSE.  THE STATION IS ON A GRASS-COVERED HILL, WITH A PROMINENT BUCOR TREE ON THE TOP.  AND ABOUT 100M. N OF A FENCE CORNER ON HILLSIDE.  IT IS A STANDARD TABLET STAMPED CUPEY 1939, CEMENTED TO A ROUND-TOPPED BOULDER 2 INCHES ABOVE GROUND.  R. M. NO. 1 IS A R.R. SPIKE FIXED TO S SIDE OF BUCOR TREE, 6.98M. NW OF STATION.  R. M. NO. 2 IS A TRIANGULATION STATION OF THE CENTRAL SAN JOSE.  AND IS AN IRON BAR IN CONCRETE MONUMENT 13.13M NW OF STATION.  AND PROJECTING 3 INCHES ABOVE GROUND.  TO REACH FROM RIO PIEDRAS PLAZA, GO S ON HIGHWAY NO. 1 (TOWARDS CAGUAS) 1.0 MILE.  TURN LEFT (E) ON CUPEY MUN. RD. AND FOLLOW.                            STATION RECOVERY (1958)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1958 (RWS) STATION WAS SEARCHED FOR AND COULD NOT BE FOUND.  REFERENCE MARK 1 WAS NOT FOUND BUT A HOLE AND A ROTTEN TREE WAS FOUND.  AN OLD SPIKE WAS FOUND IN HOLE.  A STATION MARKED BY AN IRON SPIKE SET IN CONCRETE WHICH WAS MARKED CUPEY (2) 1956 WAS FOUND.  THE DESCRIPTION FOR CUPEY IS GOOD UP TO K3H4.  IT IS NOW POSSIBLE TO DRIVE UP A ROAD TO A HOUSE.  CONTINUE STRAIGHT ON UP HILL TO STATION.  THERE ARE NO TREES NEAR THE STATION.
markers.setting: SET IN A BOULDER

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1941 (RLS) STATION IS ABOUT 500 METERS SW ALONG THE AMERICAN RAILROAD FROM THE ROAD CROSSING AT COLONIA ESPERANZA, ABOUT 190 METERS NE OF THE RAILROAD BRIDGE OVER QUEBRADA PALMA, ABOUT AT RAILROAD KM. 77.126, AT A CURVE IN THE RAILROAD WHERE IT PASSES THROUGH A 20-FOOT CUT, 18 METERS SE OF THE CENTER LINE OF THE TRACK, ON TOP OF THE BANK, 5 METERS SE OF THE EDGE OF THE CUT BANK, AND WITHIN THE PROPOSED BOUNDARY OF THE ROOSEVELT ROADS NAVAL RESERVATION.  THE MARK IS 3 INCHES BELOW THE SURFACE OF THE GROUND.  ELEVATION OF STATION IS 10.20 METERS (33.5 FEET).  STATION MARK IS A STANDARD BRONZE DISK SET IN CONCRETE, NOTE 1A.  THERE IS NO UNDERGROUND MARK.  REFERENCE MARK NO.1 IS 34.93 METERS (SLOPE DISTANCE) W OF THE STATION, 141 METERS NE ALONG TRACK FROM SWITCH SIGNAL AT RAMAL COROCHO (KM. 77.292), 5.1 METERS NW OF THE CENTER LINE OF THE TRACK, 1 METER FROM THE BASE OF THE CUT BANK, ABOUT THE SAME ELEVATION AS THE TRACK, AND 5.81 METERS LOWER THAN THE STATION.  THE MARK, NOTE 11A, PROJECTS 5 INCHES ABOVE GROUND.  REFERENCE MARK NO.2 IS 31.43 METERS (SLOPE DISTANCE) N OF THE STATION, 122 METERS SW ALONG THE TRACK FROM SWITCH SIGNAL AT RAMAL MARIANA (KM. 76.984), 45.1 METERS NE OF REFERENCE MARK NO.1, 5.4 METERS NW OF THE CENTER LINE OF THE TRACK, AT BASE OF CUT BANK, ABOUT THE SAME ELEVATION AS THE TRACK, AND 5.83 METERS LOWER THAN THE STATION.  THE MARK, NOTE 11A, PROJECTS 6 INCHES ABOVE GROUND.  BOTH REFERENCE MARKS ARE U.S. NAVY BENCH MARKS.  THE ELEVATION OF REFERENCE MARK NO.1 IS 4.383 METERS (14.38 FEET).  THE ELEVATION OF REFERENCE MARK NO.2 IS 4.365 METERS (14.32 FEET).

BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1934 STATION IS ABOUT 3 KILOMETERS TO THE SW OF THE CAYEY TO SALINAS ROAD.  THE PRESENT TERMINATION OF THIS ROAD IS AT KILOMETER 10 H 3.  THE STATION IS IN BARRIO CUYON.  STATION MARK IS A STANDARD U.S.G.S. BENCH MARK SET AND STAMPED ON BOULDER BURIED IN THE GROUND, BUT PROTRUDING ABOUT 4 INCHES ABOVE THE SURFACE.  REFERENCE MARK NO.1 IS A BRASS NAIL ON A TREE STUMP 23.45 FEET (OR 26.3 FEET) DISTANT, IN TRUE AZIMUTH 165 DEG 36 MIN FROM STATION.  REFERENCE MARK NO.2 IS A BRASS NAIL ON A STUMP 26.30 FEET (OR 23.45 FEET) FROM STATION IN TRUE AZIMUTH 113 DEG 48 MIN.  SIGNAL--WHITE QUADRIPOD AND BLACK CROSS TARGETS.  THE BEST WAY TO REACH THIS IS TO GO JUST BEYOND THE CRESCENT TERMINATION AND FOLLOW A PATH THAT GOES THROUGH THE HOLLOW FOLLOWING THE BROOK UP-STREAM UNTIL YOU COME TO A SMALL COFFEE GROVE.  INSTEAD OF CONTINUING ON THIS PATH TAKE THE ONE TO THE S FOLLOWING IT THROUGH THE GROVE UP THE STATION WHICH IS THE PROPERTY OF SUCESORES DE VAZQUEZ.  THIS STATION IS A SHORT DISTANCE FROM A PROMINENT ROCK KNOWN AS EL CALLAO.                            STATION RECOVERY (1966)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JJL) THE STATION MARK WAS RECOVERED AND FOUND IN GOOD CONDITION.  THE REFERENCE MARKS WERE NOT RECOVERED.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 3 AND REFERENCE MARK RMA WERE ESTABLISHED.  A COMPLETE DESCRIPTION FOLLOWS--  THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 5 MILES WEST-SOUTHWEST OF CAYEY, 3-1/2 MILES SOUTHEAST OF AIBONITO, 1/4 MILE NORTHWEST OF TWO SHARP, PROMINENT PEAKS AND ON THE HIGHEST POINT OF A BRUSHY, ROUND-TOPPED MOUNTAIN.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE JUNCTION OF HIGHWAYS 1 AND 15 THAT IS JUST SOUTHEAST OF CAYEY, GO SOUTHWESTERLY ON HIGHWAY 1 FOR 6.0 MILES TO THE JUNCTION OF HIGHWAYS 1 AND 162.  TURN RIGHT AND GO NORTHWEST AND WEST ON HIGHWAY 162 FOR 0.3 MILE TO A Y-FORK.  (A FOUR-WHEEL DRIVE VEHICLE IS REQUIRED FROM THIS POINT.) TAKE THE LEFT FORK AND GO SOUTHERLY FOR 0.5 MILE TO A GATE.  PASS THROUGH THE GATE AND CONTINUE SOUTH FOR ABOUT 50 FEET, THENCE TURN RIGHT AND GO NORTHWEST UP A GRASSY SLOPE FOR 0.05 MILE TO THE TOP OF THE MOUNTAIN AND THE STATION.  THE STATION MARK, STAMPED CUYON 1934, IS A U.S. GEOLOGICAL SURVEY DISK CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A BOULDER THAT PROJECTS 3 INCHES.  IT IS 13 FEET EAST OF A FENCE CORNER AND 5 FEET NORTHEAST OF A FENCE.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 3, STAMPED CUYON USGS NO 3 1934, IS A STANDARD DISK BRAZED TO THE TOP OF A 3-INCH CAST IRON PIPE THAT PROJECTS 6 INCHES AND IS ABOUT 4 FEET LOWER THAN THE STATION.  REFERENCE MARK RMA, STAMPED CUYON USGS RMA 1934, IS A STANDARD DISK BRAZED TO THE TOP OF A 3-INCH CAST IRON PIPE THAT PROJECTS 4 INCHES AND IS ABOUT 5 FEET LOWER THAN THE STATION.  NO SUITABLE LOCATION FOR AN AZIMUTH MARK.  AIRLINE DISTANCE AND DIRECTION FROM NEAREST TOWN 3-1/2 MILES SOUTHEAST OF AIBONITO.                            STATION RECOVERY (2004)  RECOVERY NOTE BY INDIVIDUAL CONTRIBUTORS 2004 THE STATION WAS RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.

markers.description: BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1934 STATION LOCATED 8 KILOMETERS BY ROAD AND TRAIL E OF OROCOVIS, ON A PROMINENT, SHARP, BRUSH-COVERED PEAK ON DIVIDE BETWEEN RIO BAUTA AND RIO OROCOVIS, IN BARRIO DAMIAN AND JUST N OF THE MAIN TRAIL (PROPOSED CARRETERA NO.15) FROM OROCOVIS TO CIALTOS.  THERE IS A MAIN COMMUNITY TRAIL PASSING OVER THE PEAK ON E SLOPE NEAR THE TOP.  THE SUMMIT IS VERY NARROW AND ABOUT 20 FEET IN LENGTH, THE STATION BEING NEARER THE SOUTHWESTERN END.  THE TOP ONLY WAS CLEARED OF BRUSH AND THE STATION IS 4.5 FEET SW OF THE LARGEST STUMP OF THIS CUT BRUSH.  STATION MARK IS A STANDARD U.S.G.S. TABLET, STAMPED DAMIAN 1934, CEMENTED IN LARGE ROCK SET IN GROUND.  REFERENCE MARK IS A SHALLOW 1-INCH DRILL HOLE IN EXPOSED LEDGE OF ROCK 5.29 FEET FROM STATION IN TRUE AZIMUTH 134 DEG 30 MIN.  THERE ARE SEVERAL MAIN TRAILS LEADING INTO THIS SECTION FROM THE VICINITY OF OROCOVIS.  THE SIGNAL AND OBSERVING PARTIES ENTERED BY WAY OF THE CARRETERA NO.15 FROM OROCOVIS WHICH IS AT PRESENT COMPLETED TO RIO SANA MUERTOS, 4.2 KILOMETERS FROM OROCOVIS, FROM WHICH POINT A TRAIL WAS FOLLOWED TO THE WESTWARD, CROSSING THE FIRST RIDGE BETWEEN TWO PROMINENT PEAKS, THENCE KEEPING TO THE SOUTHWARD AROUND HEAD OF NEXT DRAW, WHERE A MAIN TRAIL WAS INTERSECTED WHICH FOLLOWS THE DIVIDE AROUND TO THE STATION PEAK.  SIGNAL--A QUADRIPOD OF SAWED LUMBER WITH BLACK CROSS-TARGETS ON CENTER POLE.                            STATION RECOVERY (1966)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JJL) THE STATION MARK AND REFERENCE MARK 1 WERE FOUND AND IN GOOD CONDITION.  REFERENCE MARK 2 WAS NOT FOUND.  REFERENCE MARK 3 AND REFERENCE MARK RM A WERE SET AT THIS DATE.  A NEW DESCRIPTION FOLLOWS--  THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 8-1/2 MILES SOUTH-SOUTHWEST OF MOROVIS, 3 MILES WEST OF OROCOVIS AND ON A SHARP, BRUSH COVERED PEAK THAT IS LOCATED BETWEEN THE RIO OROCOVIS AND RIO BAUTA.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE POST OFFICE IN OROCOVIS, GO WEST FOR 1 BLOCK.  TURN RIGHT AND GO NORTH FOR 0.1 MILE TO THE JUNCTION OF HIGHWAYS 155 AND 568.  GO WEST ON HIGHWAY 155 FOR 1.8 MILES TO THE JUNCTION WITH HIGHWAY 157.  CONTINUE WEST AND FOLLOW HIGHWAY 157 FOR 1.05 MILES TO A BRIDGE OVER THE RIO SANA.  CONTINUE WESTERLY ON HIGHWAY 157 FOR 0.55 MILE TO A SIDE ROAD LEFT.  (A 4-WHEEL DRIVE VEHICLE IS REQUIRED TO REACH THE END OF TRUCK TRAVEL FROM THIS POINT.) TURN LEFT AND FOLLOW A NARROW MOUNTAIN ROAD SOUTHERLY FOR 0.3 MILE TO A SIDE ROAD RIGHT.  TURN SHARP RIGHT AND FOLLOW A MOUNTAIN ROAD WEST FOR 1.65 MILES TO A SIDE ROAD LEFT.  TURN LEFT AND GO SOUTH AND WEST ON A DIRT ROAD FOR 0.55 MILE TO A WIRE GATE ON THE LEFT. PASS THROUGH THE GATE, TURN SHARP LEFT AND GO EAST FOR 100 YARDS TO THE END OF TRUCK TRAVEL AT THE BASE OF A HILL.  PACK NORTH UP A STEEP HILL FOR 5 MINUTES TO THE STATION ON THE HIGHEST POINT OF THE HILL.  THE STATION MARK IS A U.S. GEOLOGICAL SURVEY BENCH MARK DISK STAMPED DAMIAN CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A LARGE BOULDER THAT PROJECTS 2 FEET.  REFERENCE MARK 3 IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED DAMIAN NO 3 1934, BRAZED TO THE TOP OF A 3-INCH CAST IRON PIPE THAT PROJECTS 1 FOOT AND IS 2 FEET LOWER IN ELEVATION THAN THE STATION MARK.  REFERENCE MARK RM A IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED DAMIAN RM A 1934, BRAZED TO THE TOP OF A 3-INCH CAST IRON PIPE THAT PROJECTS 6 INCHES AND IS 6 FEET LOWER IN ELEVATION THAN THE STATION MARK.  IT IS ON THE NORTH SLOPE OF THE HILL.  NO AZIMUTH MARK WAS SET.  AIRLINE DISTANCE AND DIRECTION FROM NEAREST TOWN 3 MILES WEST OF OROCOVIS.
markers.setting: SET IN UNSPECIFIED ROCK OR BOULDER
markers.stability: PROBABLY HOLD POSITION/ELEVATION WELL
