markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1901 (JN) THIS STATION IS SITUATED ABOUT 1-1/4 MILES DISTANT AND BEARS S 78 DEG W, FROM THE VILLAGE OF BARCELONETA.  SEVERAL LINES OF HILLS EXTEND W FROM BARCELONETA, AND THE STATION IS 250 METERS SW FROM THE INTERSECTION OF THREE ROADS WHICH MEET ON THE S SIDE OF THE VALLEY BETWEEN THE BLUFFS OR HILLS 1/2 MILE S OF THE FRONT LINE OF HILLS.  THE STATION IS ON THE E END OF A VERY HIGH RIDGE OF HILLS, THE N FACE OF WHICH IS PRECIPITOUS FOR NEARLY 200 FEET.  THE S AND E ENDS OF THE HILL HAVE BEEN CLEARED.  THE STATION IS ON THE HIGHEST PART OF THE E END OF RIDGE AND IS MARKED BY A GALVANIZED-IRON PIPE 2 FEET BY 2 INCHES SET IN A BED OF CEMENT.  THE PIPE IS FILLED WITH CEMENT AND THE CENTER OF A NAIL DRIVEN IN THIS MARKS THE STATION.  (FROM THIS STATION ARICIBO LIGHT HOUSE BEARS 81 DEG 30 MIN W OF N).                            STATION RECOVERY (1934)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1934 ORIGINAL DESCRIPTION ADEQUATE.  LAND NOW OWNED BY JUANA NIEVES.  ORIGINAL MARK FOUND IN PLACE.  REFERENCE MARK NO.1, A STANDARD BRASS NAIL AND WASHER CEMENTED ON NATURAL ROCK 3.07 METERS SW OF STATION, IN TRUE AZIMUTH 61 DEG 02 MIN.  REFERENCE MARK NO.2, A STANDARD BRASS NAIL AND WASHER CEMENTED ON NATURAL ROCK 2.835 METERS NNE OF STATION, IN TRUE AZIMUTH 194 DEG 39 MIN.                            STATION RECOVERY (1941)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1941 (GBG) RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.  REFERENCE MARKS OF 1934 ALSO RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.  NEW DESCRIPTION FOLLOWS--  LOCATED ABOUT 1-1/4 MILES DISTANT AND BEARING S 78 DEG W FROM BARCELONETA.  ABOUT 200 METERS N OF BARCELONETA-ARECIBO HIGHWAY.  AND ABOUT THE SAME DISTANCE W OF SAME HIGHWAY WHERE IT RUNS IN A NE-SW DIRECTION.  IT IS A LITTLE MORE THAN 1/2 MILE S OF THE S EDGE OF THE BROAD COASTAL PLAIN AND THE FRONT LINE OF HILLS.  ON THE E ONE OF A RIDGE OF HILLS.  THE HILL TO THE W IS HIGHER.  BOTH ARE COVERED WITH THICK BRUSH.  THE STATION IS ON THE HIGHEST POINT OF THE ROCKY HILL, ABOUT 300 METERS E OF EXTENSIVE QUARRIES.  IT IS MARKED BY A NAIL IN THE CENTER OF A 2- BY 2-INCH GALVANIZED-IRON PIPE, FILLED WITH, AND SET IN CEMENT.  PROJECTING ABOUT 10 INCHES.  A PILE OF STONES SURROUNDS THE STATION.  REFERENCE MARK NO.1 (1934) IS A U.S.G.S. BRASS NAIL AND WASHER CEMENTED TO ROCK.  3.07 METERS FROM STATION IN AZIMUTH 61 DEG 02 MIN.  REFERENCE MARK NO.2 (1934) IS SIMILAR TO NO.1.  AND IS 2.835 METERS FROM STATION IN AZIMUTH 194 DEG 39 MIN.  TO REACH FROM BARCELONETA, GO SW ON ROAD TO FLORIDA AND ARECIBO TO KM. 66.3 (OR 0.7 MILE NE OF JUNCTION OF THIS ROAD WITH NEW MAIN E-W HIGHWAY).  AND LEAVE CAR IN FRONT OF A HOUSE 300 METERS E OF QUARRY.  TAKE DIM TRAIL STRAIGHT UP DRAIN BETWEEN FIRST TWO HILLS TO N, TO A POINT ABOUT 50 METERS BELOW THE CREST.  HERE TURN ON DIM TRAIL TO RIGHT, AND PROCEED UP STEEPLY TO TOP AND STATION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1966)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JWC) THE STATION MARK AND REFERENCE MARK 1 WERE RECOVERED AND FOUND IN GOOD CONDITION.  A NEW REFERENCE MARK 3 WAS ESTABLISHED.  A COMPLETE NEW DESCRIPTION OF THE STATION FOLLOWS.  THE STATION IS LOCATED 10 AIRLINE MILES EAST OF ARECIBO, 5-1/2 AIRLINE MILES WEST ON MANATI AND ON THE TOP OF A LOW BRUSH COVERED HILL.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE INTERSECTION OF HIGHWAYS 2 AND 140 IN CRUCE DAVILA, GO NORTHERLY ON HIGHWAY 140 FOR 1.0 MILE TO A SIDE ROAD LEFT AT KILOMETER POST 65.9.  TURN LEFT AND GO WESTERLY ON A PAVED ROAD 0.1 MILE TO THE NORTHWEST EDGE OF A CANE FIELD AND END OF TRUCK TRAVEL.  FROM HERE PACK SOUTH AND WEST ON A TRAIL FOR ABOUT 5 MINUTES TO A HOUSE.  TURN LEFT AND PACK SOUTH AND WEST ON A TRAIL FOR ABOUT 10 MINUTES TO THE TOP OF THE BRUSH COVERED HILL AND THE STATION.  THE STATION IS THE TOP AND CENTER OF A 2-INCH ROUND IRON PIPE WHICH PROJECTS 1 FOOT.  THERE IS NO STAMPING ON THE PIPE.  REFERENCE MARK 1 IS A BRASS BOLT CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A BOULDER WHICH PROJECTS 6 INCHES.  THE BOLT HAS USGS BM STAMPED ON THE TOP.  REFERENCE MARK 3 IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED GARRO NO 3 1901, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A BOULDER WHICH PROJECTS 6 INCHES.  NO AZIMUTH MARK WAS ESTABLISHED AT THIS STATION.  AIRLINE DISTANCE AND DIRECTION FROM NEAREST TOWN 1 MILE NORTH OF CRUCE DAVILA.                            STATION RECOVERY (2004)  RECOVERY NOTE BY UNIVERSITY OF PUERTO RICO AT MAYAGUEZ 2004 (JPR) MARK NOT FOUND.
markers.setting: SET INTO TOP OF METAL PIPE DRIVEN INTO GROUND
markers.stability: MARK OF QUESTIONABLE OR UNKNOWN STABILITY

markers.description: BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1934 STATION IS ABOUT 8 KILOMETERS BY ROAD AND TRAIL, NE OF THE TOWN OF JUNCOS, ON A PROMINENT PEAK IN THE RANGE N OF RIO GURABO AND THE ONE EXTENDING FARTHEST TO THE S.  THE SUMMIT IS CROSSED BY A HEDGE OF MADGI AND THE STATION IS ON THE HIGHEST PART OF SUMMIT 10 FEET W OF THIS HEDGE, AND ABOUT 150 FEET S OF A LARGE AGUA CATE TREE GROWING IN THE LINE OF HEDGE.  STATION MARK IS A STANDARD U.S.G.S. TABLET STAMPED GAY 1934 CEMENTED IN A ROCK SET IN THE GROUND AND PROJECTING ABOUT 1 INCH.  REFERENCE MARK NO.1 IS NAIL IN BLAZE ON SIDE NEAR TOP OF TALL STUMP OF JAGUEY TREE, 43.00 FEET FROM STATION IN TRUE AZIMUTH 174 DEG 53 MIN.  REFERENCE MARK NO.2 IS NAIL IN TRIANGULAR BLAZE ON LARGE STUMP OF JAGUEY TREE, 22.93 FEET FROM STATION IN TRUE AZIMUTH 212 DEG 04 MIN.  REFERENCE MARK NO.3 IS NAIL IN BLAZE ON TALL STUMP OF ESPINO TREE, 27.99 FEET FROM STATION IN TRUE AZIMUTH 259 DEG 11 MIN.  SIGNAL--A QUADRIPOD OF SAWED LUMBER WITH BLACK CROSS TARGETS ON CENTER POLE.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM JUNCOS, FOLLOW ROAD LEADING TO CENTRAL JUNCOS, JUST BEFORE REACHING THE CENTRAL TURN RIGHT (EASTWARD) AND FOLLOW CART ROAD ALONG RAILROAD FOR 2 KILOMETERS CROSSING RIVER ONCE THEN TURN LEFT (NORTHWARD), CROSSING RIVER AGAIN AND FOLLOW THE MAIN ROAD, AND TRAIL UP RIDGE IN NE DIRECTION TO TOP, TURN S ALONG TOP OF RIDGE TO STATION ABOUT 300 METERS.  NOTE--THIS MOUNTAIN WAS REPORTED TO BE THE LOCATION OF A TRIANGULATION STATION OF THE CAGUAS SUGAR COMPANY, BUT NO MARK OR INDICATION OF STATION COULD BE FOUND.                            STATION RECOVERY (1941)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1941 THE STATION AND REFERENCE MARKS RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED.  THE HEDGE MENTIONED IN THE ORIGINAL DESCRIPTION IS NOW ALONG A FENCE LINE DIVIDING THIS PROPERTY (WHICH IS KNOWN AS THE FINCA LA CONDESA, OWNED BY JANER) FROM THE U.S. FOREST LAND.  A BOUNDARY MARKER CONSITING OF A U.S.F.S. BRASS DISK IN TOP OF SMALL CONCRETE POST IS USED AS REFERENCE MARK NO. 4.  IT IS IN THE FENCE LINE, 41.0 FT. FROM THE STATION, IN AZIMUTH 147 DEG 04 MIN 32 SEC.                            STATION RECOVERY (1963)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1963 (CPO) THE STATION MARK WAS RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED, IT NOW BEING A LITTLE LOOSE IN THE GROUND.  IT IS 17.0 FT. SOUTH-SOUTHWEST OF THE BOUNDARY FENCE LINE.  THE ONLY REFERENCE MARK RECOVERED WAS THE BOUNDARY MARK OF THE U.S. F.S.
markers.setting: SET IN UNSPECIFIED ROCK OR BOULDER
markers.stability: PROBABLY HOLD POSITION/ELEVATION WELL

markers.description: BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1982 (JCL) THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 9.5 KM (6 MI) NORTHEAST OF PONCE, 8.0 KM (5 MI) WEST-NORTHWEST OF THE SMALL TOWN OF JUANA DIAZ, AND 0.6 KM (0.4 MI) SOUTH OF THE CERRILLOS DAM PROJECT.  OWNERSHIP--U.S. ARMY CORPS OF ENGINEERS.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE JUNCTION OF HIGHWAYS 14 AND 139 ABOUT 4.0 KM (2-1/2 MI) NORTHEAST OF PONCE, GO NORTHEAST AND EAST ON HIGHWAY 14 FOR 1.9 KM (1.2 MI) TO THE ENTRANCE OF THE COLEGIO PONCENOS ON THE LEFT. CONTINUE EAST ON HIGHWAY 14 FOR 2.1 KM (1.3 MI) TO A PAVED CROSSROAD.  TURN LEFT AND GO NORTH ON A WINDING ROAD FOR 2.1 KM (1.3 MI) TO A PAVED ROAD RIGHT AT THE BOTTOM OF THE GRADE.  CONTINUE AHEAD NORTH ON THE PAVED ROAD FOR 1.8 KM (1.1 MI) PASSING THROUGH THE TOWN OF CERRILLOS, TO THE END OF THE ROAD AT HIGH GROUND BETWEEN TWO HOUSES AND THE END OF TRUCK TRAVEL.  PACK AHEAD NORTHERLY DOWN HILL FOR 50 METERS (150 FT) TO A TRAIL FORK.  BEAR RIGHT AND GO NORTHEAST UP GRADE FOR 20 METERS (70 FT) TO A FENCE, THEN LEFT DOWN HILL, PICKING UP A GOOD TRAIL, AND GO NORTHWEST THE WEST FOLLOWING RIDGE FOR 400 METERS (0.25 MI) TO THE STATION ON THE HIGHEST GROUND.  THE STATION IS A STANDARD NGS DISK STAMPED---GEORGE 1982---, CRIMPED TO THE TOP OF A STAINLESS STEEL ROD DRIVEN TO THE DEPTH OF 4 FEET AND SURROUNDED BY A ROUND MASS OF CONCRETE 33 CM IN DIAMETER AND PROJECTING 7 CM ABOVE THE GROUND.  THE STATION IS LOCATED ON THE HIGHEST GROUND.  REFERENCE MARK NUMBER 1 IS A STANDARD NGS DISK STAMPED ---GEORGE NO 1 1982---, CRIMPED TO THE TOP OF A STAINLESS STEEL ROAD DRIVER TO THE DEPTH OF 4 FEET AND SURROUNDED BY A MASS OF CONCRETE 27 CM IN DIAMETER AND PROJECTING7 CM ABOVE THE GROUND.  IT IS LOCATED 4.5 METERS (15.0 FT) NORTHWEST FROM THE HIGHEST GROUND.  MARK IS LEVEL WITH THE STATION.  REFERENCE MARK NUMBER 2 IS A STANDARD NGS DISK STAMPED ---GEORGE NO 2 1982---, CRIMPED TO THE TOP OF A STAINLESS STEEL ROD DRIVEN TO THE DEPTH OF 4 FEET AND SURROUNDED BY A MASS OF CONCRETE 27 CM IN DIAMTER AND PROJECTING 7 CM ABOVE THE GROUND.  IT IS LOCATED 4.5 METERS (15.0 FT) NORTHWEST FROM THE HIGHEST GROUND.  MARK IS BELOW STATION 0.3 METER.  HEIGHT OF LIGHT SHOWN ABOVE THE MARK WAS 1.7 METERS.  NO MEASUREMENT BETWEEN REFERENCE MARKS DUE TO TERRAIN AND TREES ON LINE.
markers.setting: METAL ROD DRIVEN INTO GROUND. SEE TEXT FOR ADDITIONAL
markers.stability: MARK OF QUESTIONABLE OR UNKNOWN STABILITY

markers.description: BY RLDA SURVEYING AND MAPPING 2010 (RLD) THE STATION IS 9.1 MI (14.6 KM) SOUTHEAST OF ADJUNTAS, 6.3 MI (10.1 KM) EAST OF PENUELAS, 5.1 MI (8.2 KM) WEST OF COTO LAUREL AND 3.8 MI (6.1 KM) NORTH OF PONCE, PUERTO RICO.   TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE INTERSECTION OF PR-9 AND PR-10 2.0 MI (3.2 KM) NORTH OF PONCE, GO NORTHWESTERLY ON PR-10 FOR 2.0 MI (3.2 KM) TO THE STATION ON THE LEFT.   THE STATION IS 84.60 M (277.6 FT) NORTH OF A METAL SIGN, 13.40 M (44.0 FT) WEST OF THE CENTERLINE OF PR-10 AND 6.25 M (20.5 FT) SOUTH OF THE SOUTH END OF A METAL GUARD RAIL.
markers.setting: SET IN ROCK OUTCROP

markers.description: BY RLDA SURVEYING AND MAPPING 2011 (RLD) THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 8.6 MI (13.8 KM) SOUTHWEST OF PIEDRA GORDA, 6.7 MI (10.8 KM) NORTHWEST OF LARES, 5.7 MI (9.2 KM) NORTH OF LAS MARIAS AND 1.4 MI (2.3 KM) EAST OF SAN SEBASTIAN.   TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE INTERSECTION OF PR-119 AND PR-111 BYPASS 0.3 MI (0.5 KM) NORTH OF SAN SEBASTIAN, GO EASTERLY ON PR-111 BYPASS FOR 1.4 MI (2.3 KM) TO THE STATION ON THE LEFT.   THE STATION IS 9.10 M (29.9 FT) SOUTH OF A FENCE, 10.10 M (33.1 FT) NORTH OF THE CENTERLINE OF PR-111, 7.6 M (24.9 FT) EAST OF THE CENTER OF A FIELD ROAD AND 2.88 M (9.4 FT) NORTH OF THE CONCRETE SWALE.

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1901 (JBB) STATION IS ON HIGHEST PART OF POINT A CABRA DE TIERRA (GOAT LAND) ON THE NE SIDE OF THE ENTRANCE TO ENSENADA HONDA, 31.2 FEET ABOVE HIGH-WATER MARK.  STATION IS MARKED BY A CEMENT BLOCK 1-1/2 FEET LONG BY 6 INCHES SQUARE.  NAIL IN CEMENT MARKS THE STATION.  U.S. IS CUT IN THE TOP OF CEMENT BLOCK.                            STATION RECOVERY (1922)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1922 (FTS) MARK FOUND AS DESCRIBED.  ORIGINAL DESCRIPTION OF STATION SUFFICIENTLY COMPREHENSIVE AND EXACTLY SUITED.  STATION MARK IN EXCELLENT CONDITION.  IT IS RECOMMENDED THAT A CONCRETE REFERENCE MARK BE PLACED NEAR THIS STATION, OR THAT A CROSS (X) BE CUT IN A NEARBY ROCK.  IF THE PRESENT STATION MARK IS DISTURBED THERE ARE NO REFERENCE POINTS FOR USE IN RE-ESTABLISHING STATION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1926)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1926 (GCM) STATION WAS RECOVERED.  STATION MARK WAS IN EXCELLENT CONDITION.  IT IS LOCATED IN THE MIDST OF AN OUTCROP OF ROCKS AND SHOULD NOT BE DIFFICULT TO FIND OR APT TO BE DISTURBED.  MEN WERE ENGAGED IN CLEANING THE BRUSH FROM THE LAND AROUND THE STATION AT THE TIME THE STATION WAS BEING VISITED.  PRESUMABLY THE LAND WAS TO BE USED FOR PASTURAGE.  THEY SEEMED TO BE AWARE OF THE STATION BY REASON OF THE LARGE TRIPOD WHICH WAS STILL STANDING AND SEEMED TO UNDERSTAND THE NATURE OF OUR WORK.  IN CASE THE LAND IS EVER USED FOR CANE, THE AREA AROUND THE STATION IS TOO ROCKY TO BE CULTIVATED.                            STATION RECOVERY (1941)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1941 (RLS) STATION WAS RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.  ON THE ROOSEVELT ROADS NAVAL RESERVATION, BETWEEN PUERCA BAY AND ENSENADA HONDA, ON THE SOUTHERLY AND LARGEST OF 3 ISLANDS CONNECTED TO EACH OTHER AND TO THE MAINLAND BY MANGROVE SWAMPS FORMING A POINT CALLED CABRA DE TIERRA, ABOUT 215 METERS N OF THE S END OF THE ISLAND, ABOUT MIDWAY BETWEEN THE E-AND-S SIDES OF THE POINT, ON THE HIGHEST POINT OF THE ISLAND, AND SURROUNDED BY A GROUP OF SMALL BOULDERS.  THE STATION IS MARKED BY A NAIL IN A 6-INCH SQUARE CONCRETE POST PROJECTING 4 INCHES ABOVE GROUND.  THE LETTERS U.S. ARE CAST IN THE TOP OF THE CONCRETE.  THE ELEVATION OF THE STATION IS ABOUT 31 FEET.  THERE ARE NO REFERENCE MARKS.                            STATION RECOVERY (1961)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1961 (MLO) STATION RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED IN GOOD CONDITION.  A STEEL PIPE TRIPOD AND CENTERPOLE WITH LEGS IMBEDDED IN CONCRETE IS CENTERED OVER THE MARK.  THE MARK IS 38.4 FEET WEST OF THE CENTERLINE OF A ROAD LEADING TO THE POINT.                            STATION RECOVERY (1965)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1965 (MTP) STATION WAS FOUND AS DESCRIBED.  WAS FOUND IN GOOD CONDITION.  IS A RED AND WHITE STEEL PIPE TRIPOD AND CENTERPOLE CONSTRUCTED OVER THE STATION ABOUT 15 FT. HIGH.  DESCRIPTION GIVEN BY R.L.S. 1941 IS ADEQUATE.
markers.setting: SET IN TOP OF CONCRETE MONUMENT
markers.stability: MAY HOLD, BUT OF TYPE COMMONLY SUBJECT TOSURFACE MOTION

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1900 (WCH) STATION IS A LARGE SIGNAL BUILT ON THE SUMMIT OF THE PROMONTORY OF THE N SIDE OF VIEQUES ISLAND, CALLED PUNTA NEGRA ON THE CHARTS AND GOLETA (SCHOONER) BY THE INHABITANTS.  MARKED AS USUAL.                            STATION RECOVERY (1901)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1901 (SF) RECOVERED.                            STATION RECOVERY (1903)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1903 (RLF) STATION RECOVERED.  SIGNAL STANDING.  MARKED BY A 2-INCH IRON GAS PIPE.  STATION IS ON SUMMIT OF PROMONTORY ON W SIDE OF PUERTO NEGRO (BLACK PORT) WHICH IS 5 MILES E OF PUERTO MULAS LIGHTHOUSE ON THE N SIDE OF VIEQUES ISLAND.  A CORAL REEF IN FRONT OF PORT PROTECTS THE SHORE FROM SEA.  THERE IS A GOOD, CLEAR ENTRANCE FOR SMALL BOATS BETWEEN THE CORAL REEFS, ABOUT MIDWAY FROM THE FORT.  THE STATION CAN ALWAYS BE REACHED FROM THE SEA BY THIS ENTRANCE THROUGH THE REEFS AND LANDING IN THE PORT.                            STATION RECOVERY (1923)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1923 (FTS) STATION SEARCHED FOR UNSUCCESSFULLY.  CONSIDERABLE CLEARING HAS APPARENTLY TAKEN PLACE IN THE VICINITY AND THE ACTION OF NATIVES IN DESTROYING ALL MARKS WHICH ARE READILY FOUND, IS REASON ENOUGH FOR NON-RECOVERY.
markers.setting: OBJECT SURROUNDED BY MASS OF CONCRETE
markers.stability: MARK OF QUESTIONABLE OR UNKNOWN STABILITY

markers.description: BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1941 V.A. ELEVATION 46.99 METERS.  UNABLE TO RECOVER GOLETA OR GOLETA 2 (WHICH WAS NOT MARKED).  NEW STATION IS LOCATED ON THE NORTHEASTERN COAST OF VIEQUES ISLAND ABOUT 8 KMS. EAST OF ISABEL II, ON THE WEST SIDE OF A SMALL BAY KNOWN AS PUERTO NEGRO AND ABOUT 100 METERS SOUTH OF THE BEACH ON THE HIGHEST OF ONE OF A RIDGE OF LOW HILLS.  STATION MARK IS A STANDARD TABLET SET IN ROCK FLUSH WITH TOP OF GROUND.  R.M. NO. 1 IS A DRILL HOLE IN BOULDER 8.87 METERS FROM STATION.  PLANE AZIMUTH 128-09.  R.M. NO. 2 IS A DRILL HOLE IN ROCK 11.93 METERS FROM STATION.  PLANE AZIMUTH 247-27.  THIS ROCK IS ABOUT 1-1/2 METERS HIGH AND IS THE HIGHEST POINT ON THE HILL.  TO REACH FROM ISABEL II DRIVE EAST ALONG NORTH COAST ROAD TO A POINT WHERE THE ROAD REACHES, THEN TURN RIGHT PARALLEL TO THE BEACH IN A GROVE OF COCONUT PALMS AT PUERTO NEGRO.  AT THIS POINT WALK WEST UP RIDGE TO STATION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1965)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1965 (MTP) STATION AND R.MS. RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED EXCEPT STATION WAS STAMPED GOLETA 4.                            STATION RECOVERY (1970)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US MARINE CORPS 1970 STATION RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.
markers.setting: SET IN UNSPECIFIED ROCK OR BOULDER
markers.stability: PROBABLY HOLD POSITION/ELEVATION WELL

markers.description: BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1922 THIS STATION IS ON A PROMINENT, LONE CLEARED PEAK, ABOUT 6-3/4 KILOMETERS DISTANT AND BEARING S 28 DEG 00 MIN W FROM THE TOWN OF ISABELA, ON LAND OWNED BY DIEGO GONZALEZ, NEAR HIS RESIDENCE AND AN OLD SUGAR MILL.  THE HILL HAS A SMOOTH, GRADUAL SLOPE TO THE E, BUT DROPS OFF ABRUPTLY TO THE W AND IS COVERED WITH BRUSH ON THIS SIDE.  THE STATION IS MARKED BY A STANDARD U.S.G.S. BENCH MARK TABLET CEMENTED IN SOLID LIMESTONE NEAR THE CENTER OF THE TOP OF THE HILL, AND IS COUNTERSUNK ABOUT 7 CENTIMETERS.  REFERENCE MARK NO.1, IS A DRILL HOLE IN LIMESTONE OUTCROP NEAR THE N EDGE OF THE HILL, 9.47 METERS DISTANT ON A TRUE AZIMUTH OF 186 DEG 21 MIN 19 SEC.  REFERENCE MARK NO.2, IS A DRILL HOLE IN A LIMESTONE OUTCROP ON THE E SLOPE OF THE HILL NEAR THE TOP, 11.25 METERS DISTANT ON A TRUE AZIMUTH OF 258 DEG 25 MIN 50 SEC.  ELEVATION ABOVE SEA LEVEL IS - 215.0 METERS.  STATION IS ABOUT 1-1/4 KILOMETERS S OF THE CARRETERA, AND CAN BE EASILY REACHED BY TAKING THE PRIVATE ROAD WHICH TURNS S FROM THE CARRETERA THRU A DOUBLE IRON GATE TO THE RESIDENCE, AND GOES BY THE BASE OF THE HILL ON WHICH THE STATION IS LOCATED.                            STATION RECOVERY (1956)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1956 (EAT) THE STATION MARK WAS RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED BY THE U.S.G.S. DESCRIPTION AND IS ADEQUATE.
markers.setting: SET IN ROCK OUTCROP
markers.stability: MOST RELIABLE AND EXPECTED TO HOLDPOSITION/ELEVATION WELL

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JWC) THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 4 MILES NORTH OF AGUADILLA, 1/8 MILE SOUTH OF THE SOUTHWEST BOUNDARY OF RAMEY AIR FORCE BASE AND ON A LOW GRASS COVERED HILL THAT IS ON THE PROPERTY OF MR. FEDEZICO ACEVEDO WHO LIVES IN AGUADILLA.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE JUNCTION OF HIGHWAYS 2 AND 107 WHICH IS 2 MILES NORTHEAST OF AGUADILLA, GO NORTHERLY ON HIGHWAY 107 FOR 2.75 MILES TO A SIDE ROAD ON THE LEFT JUST BEFORE REACHING GATE NO. 1 OF RAMEY AIR FORCE BASE.  TURN LEFT AND GO WEST ON A GRAVELED ROAD FOR 0.4 MILE TO A CEMENT PLANT.  CONTINUE WEST THROUGH THE CEMENT PLANT FOR 0.05 MILE TO A WIRE FENCE AND THE END OF TRUCK TRAVEL.  PACK SOUTHWEST FOR 50 YARDS TO THE STATION ON THE HIGHEST POINT OF A LOW HILL.  THE STATION MARK IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED GORDA 1966, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A ROCK OUTCROP THAT IS FLUSH WITH THE GROUND.  REFERENCE MARK 1 IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED GORDA NO 1 1966, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A ROCK OUTCROP THAT IS FLUSH WITH THE GROUND.  IT IS THE SAME ELEVATION AS THE STATION MARK.  THE U.S.E.D. MARK IS A 3/4-INCH IRON BOLT SET IN AN IRREGULAR MASS OF CONCRETE THAT PROJECTS 1 INCH AND HAS THE LEGEND USED ART ACROSS ITS TOP.  IT IS THE SAME ELEVATION AS THE STATION MARK.  THE U.S.G.S. MARK IS A 1/2-INCH IRON BOLT SET IN AN IRREGULAR MASS OF CONCRETE THAT IS FLUSH WITH THE GROUND AND HAS THE LEGEND PTA GORDA 2 ACROSS ITS TOP.  IT IS THE SAME ELEVATION AS THE STATION MARK.  RAMEY 1958 IS A LARGE NAIL SET IN AN IRREGULAR MASS OF CONCRETE THAT PROJECTS 2 INCHES AND HAS THE LEGEND RAMEY 1958 ACROSS ITS TOP.  (ORIGIN UNKNOWN).  IT IS THE SAME ELEVATION AS THE STATION MARK.  NO AZIMUTH MARK WAS ESTABLISHED.
markers.setting: SET IN ROCK OUTCROP

CALLED W IN THE HYDROGRAPHIC RECORD.                            STATION RECOVERY (1965)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1965 (MTP) THE BUILDING WAS FOUND AS DESCRIBED.  THE 32 FT. X 42 FT. BRICK BUILDING IS APPROXIMATELY 150 FT. NORTH FROM THE EAST-WEST SHORELINE AND APPROXIMATELY 200 FT. SOUTH FROM A SERIES OF TEN PARALLEL SIDEWALKS RUNNING IN A NORTH-SOUTH DIRECTION. THE STATION DOES NOT HAVE ANY REFERENCE MARKS.                            STATION RECOVERY (1965)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1965 (JMC) STATION SHOULD BE CONSIDERED LOST. BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1901 (JN) THIS STATION IS SITUATED ON A HIGH HILL, RISING PRECIPITOUSLY FROM THE W BANK OF THE RIO GUAJATOCA.  IT IS ABOUT 300 METERS N 43 DEG E FROM THE HIGHEST KNOB ON THIS RANGE OF HILLS.  THIS RANGE IS CALLED THE SANTA ROSA BEING ON THE PLANTATION OF THE SAME NAME.  THIS POINT IS ABOUT 1-1/2 MILES DISTANT AND BEARS S 71 DEG W FROM THE TOWN OF QUEBRADILLAS.  IT IS ABOUT 1-3/4 MILES ON THE WINDING ROAD ALONG THE RIO GUAJATOCA, AFTER CROSSING THE BRIDGE ON THE MAIN ROAD TOWARDS ISABELA.  AFTER LEAVING THE TEAM, THE APPROACH TO THIS STATION IS UP A VERY STEEP RAVINE WHICH IS FILLED WITH LARGE BOULDERS AND A GROWTH OF BANANA TREES.  THE MARK IS THE CENTER OF A GALVANIZED PIPE 2 INCHES IN DIAMETER AND 2 FEET LONG, WHICH WAS SET IN A BED OF CEMENT.  THE TOP OF THE PIPE PROJECTS ABOUT 4 INCHES ABOVE THE BED OF CEMENT.                            STATION RECOVERY (1922)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1922 THE MARK HAS BEEN DESTROYED, BUT A HOLE WAS FOUND IN THE EARTH AND ROCK FROM WHICH IT HAD BEEN REMOVED.  PIECES OF CEMENT WITH THE IMPRINT OF AN IRON PIPE WERE ALSO FOUND IN CLOSE PROXIMITY TO THE HOLE.  A LARGE LIMESTONE ROCK WAS PLANTED IN THE HOLE AND THE NEW STATION MARK CEMENTED INTO IT.  IT IS PROBABLY NOT MORE THAN 0.1 METER AWAY FROM THE OLD POSITION.  THE STATION IS MARKED BY A STANDARD U.S.G.S. BRONZE BENCH MARK TABLET CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN LIMESTONE ROCK AND PROJECTS 5 OR 6 CENTIMETERS ABOVE THE GROUND.  REFERENCE MARK NO.1, IS A DRILL HOLE IN SOLID ROCK ON THE N SLOPE OF THE HILL, 4.94 METERS DISTANT ON A TRUE AZIMUTH OF 125 DEG 20 MIN 00 SEC.  REFERENCE MARK NO.2, IS A DRILL HOLE IN SOLID ROCK ON THE W SLOPE OF THE HILL, 7.85 METERS DISTANT ON A TRUE AZIMUTH OF 263 DEG 20 MIN 56 SEC.  THE STATION IS BEST REACHED FROM THE CARRETERA ON THE S BY TAKING A SECOND CLASS ROAD WHICH LEAVES THE MAIN ROAD AT A RAILROAD CROSSING ON THE W BANK OF THE GUAJATACA RIVER, AND FOLLOWING THIS UP STREAM ABOUT 3 KILOMETERS.  ABOUT 300 METERS BEYOND THE POINT WHERE THE RIVER AND ROAD MAKE A SHARP BEND TO THE E IS A SMALL FLAT, LYING BETWEEN THE BLUFF AND THE RIVER, FROM MIDWAY OF WHICH A DIM TRAIL LEADS DIRECTLY UP THE BLUFF, THE STATION IS TO THE LEFT OR E OF THIS TRAIL ON THE RIDGE OVERLOOKING THE GUAJATACA RIVER.  ELEVATION ABOVE SEA LEVEL IS - 171.0 METERS.                            STATION RECOVERY (1934)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1934 FOUND AS DESCRIBED IN NOTES OF 1922, IT IS IN GOOD CONDITION, APPARENTLY UNDISTURBED.  THE TOP OF MOUNTAIN HAD GROWN UP WITH THICK BRUSH, WHICH WAS CUT AWAY, LEAVING A LONE CLUMP FOR THE SIGNAL.  THE TRAIL ROUTE TO THE STATION, AS DESCRIBED IN NOTES OF 1922, HAS BEEN DISCONTINUED, AND IS GROWN UP WITH BRUSH, AND AS THE RIVER SIDE OF THE MOUNTAIN IS VERY STEEP AND COVERED WITH THICK BRUSH, THE BEST ROUTE TO STATION AT PRESENT (1934), IS TO LEAVE CAR AT HOUSE ALONG ROAD, ON THE RIVER BEND MENTIONED IN NOTES OF 1922, AND FOLLOW A DIM TRAIL UP THE SLOPE AND AROUND W SIDE OF RIDGE TO THE FIRST DRAW COMING IN FROM THE LEFT (E), THEN FOLLOW UP THIS DRAW ABOUT 0.25 MILE TO FIRST MAIN DRAW COMING IN FROM THE LEFT (ABOUT 300 FEET AFTER PASSING OVER A DIFFICULT ROCK LEDGE), FOLLOW UP THIS SECOND DRAW ABOUT 200 FEET TO WHERE IT DIVIDES, THEN CROSS OVER LOW RIDGE TO THE LEFT (W) INTO ANOTHER DRAW.  TURN RIGHT UP THIS DRAW AND CONTINUE TO POINT WHERE IT FLATTENS OUT IN A GRASSY OPENING.  AT PRESENT THERE IS A SMALL THATCHED SHED HERE BUT PROBABLY WILL NOT REMAIN LONG.  THE STATION IS ON THE RIDGE JUST ABOVE AND TO THE W, THICK BRUSH COVERS THE SLOPE.  A TRAIL WAS CLEARED TO THE TOP BUT WILL NOT REMAIN CLEARED FOR LONG.
markers.setting: SET IN ROCK OUTCROP
markers.stability: MOST RELIABLE AND EXPECTED TO HOLDPOSITION/ELEVATION WELL

BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1900 (JN) THIS STATION IS ON THE POINT CALLED GUANAJIBO POINT, WHICH COMES TO THE COAST JUST S OF THE MOUTH OF THE RIO GRANDE.  IT IS ON THE SOUTHERN BOUNDARY OF THE PLAIN ON WHICH MAYAGUEZ LIES.  A WIRE FENCE CROSSES THE HILL, AT RIGHT ANGLES TO ITS AXIS, JUST AT THE S SIDE OF THE SUMMIT WHERE THE DESCENT TOWARDS THE LITTLE BAY ON THE S SIDE OF GUANAJIBO POINT BECOMES PRONOUNCED, AND INTERSECTS A FENCE WHICH RUNS PARALLEL WITH THE RIDGE.  THE STATION IS 9.30 METERS E OF THE FIRST MENTIONED FENCE AND ALMOST 28 METERS N OF THE OTHER.  THE FIELD ON THE SAME SIDE OF THE FENCE THAT THE SIGNAL IS ON IS CLEARED.  ON THE W SIDE OF THE FENCE IT IS CLEAR FOR ABOUT 30 METERS W OF THE FENCE AND THEN IS ALL BUSHY.  STATION IS MARKED BY A 2-INCH IRON PIPE, 22 INCHES LONG, PROJECTING 6 INCHES ABOVE THE GROUND.  THE PIPE IS SECURED IN THE GROUND WITH CONCRETE AND A MASS OF THIS CONCRETE WAS SMOOTHED UP AROUND THE PROJECTING PART OF THE PIPE.  THE PIPE WAS FILLED WITH CEMENT AND IN THE TOP A NAIL WAS SUNK.  THE CENTER OF THE NAIL HEAD IS THE CENTER OF STATION.  TO REACH FROM MAYAGUEZ, ONE MUST TAKE THE MILITARY ROAD TO SAN GERMAN AS FAR AS THE 4 KILOMETER POST AND THEN TURN S TO THE U.S. GOVERNMENT TARGET RANGE, AND COMING TO THE LARGE SUGAR HOUSE ON THE N BANK OF THE RIO GRANDE, TAKE A BOAT TO THE S SIDE AND THEN GO UP THE HILL TO THE HOUSE OF A PEON.  THE LAND-OWNER IS ANTONIO GARCIA, WHO KNOWS WHERE THE STATION IS.                            STATION RECOVERY (1901)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1901 (RLF) STATION RECOVERED AND FOUND IN GOOD CONDITION.  IN ADDITION TO THE ABOVE DESCRIPTION IT IS WELL TO NOTE THAT A COW TRAIL, RUNNING N AND S, PASSES 6 FEET TO WESTWARD OF STATION, WHICH CAN BE REACHED FROM THE COAST AT THE MOUTH OF THE RIO GRANDE, BY A COW TRAIL LEADING UP THE HILL.                            STATION RECOVERY (1959)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US NAVY 1959 STATION WAS DESTROYED.  PAN AMERICAN RADIO RECEIVING STATION WAS BUILT IN AREA.  IT WAS DESTROYED BY GRADING FOR NEW BUILDING.  A NEW STATION RADAR WAS ESTABLISHED IN 1958 BY U.S. ARMY.
markers.setting: SET INTO TOP OF METAL PIPE DRIVEN INTO GROUND
markers.stability: MARK OF QUESTIONABLE OR UNKNOWN STABILITY

markers.description: PTIVE TEXT AVAILABLE.

BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1900 (JN) THIS STATION IS ON THE HIGH RIDGE WHICH RISES FROM THE WESTERN SHORE OF GUANICA BAY, AND IS NEAR THE EASTERN END OF THE HIGHEST PART OF THE RIDGE.  THE POINT IS JUST FAR ENOUGH E TO LET JUST THE NORTHEASTERN PART OF THE ISLAND ON WHICH CASA STANDS TO SHOW BY THE TOP OF THE RIDGE ACROSS FROM FORT CAPRON.  THE POLE AT GUANICA CAN BE SEEN FROM THE POINT (OPPOSITE PESCADORES POINT) ABOUT TO THE MOUTH OF THE LOCO RIVER.  IT IS NOT VISIBLE AT ALL FROM THE OPPOSITE SHORE.  THE MARK IS A 2-FOOT GAS-PIPE CEMENTED IN THE ROCK.  ABOUT 14 INCHES OF THE PIPE IS CEMENTED IN THE ROCK AND ABOUT 10 INCHES PROJECT.  LANES WERE CUT TOWARDS CORAL AND LABRA AND SOME CUTTING WAS DONE TOWARDS MANGLIO.  TO REACH THE STATION TAKE THE WAGON ROAD FROM GUANICA, GO AROUND THE HEAD OF THE BAY TO THE END OF THE FIRST ENCLOSED LAND ON THE W SIDE OF GUANICA BAY, THEN TAKE LEFT-HAND ROAD AT THE FORK AT THE FOOT OF THE E END OF THE RIDGE ON WHICH GUANICA STANDS.  THIS ROAD LEADS TO THE SALINAS SALT WORKS AND IS TO BE FOLLOWED UNTIL IT TURNS TO THE LEFT UP THE HILL, THEN TAKE THE RIGHT-HAND ROAD WHICH GOES W TOWARDS A HOUSE WHICH IS UP ON THE HILLSIDE.  FOLLOW THIS RIGHT-HAND ROAD FOR 350 OR 400 METERS UNTIL A RATHER FAINTLY MARKED WOOD ROAD IS NOTED GOING TO THE RIGHT.  TAKE THE LATTER AND FOLLOW IT TO ITS END.  IT WILL BRING YOU OUT ON TOP OF GUANICA RIDGE NEAR THE W END. FOLLOWING A FAINTLY MARKED TRAIL TO THE E ALONG THE BACK-BONE OF THE RIDGE UNTIL THE STATION SITE IS REACHED. THE EXTREME CLEARING BEING A FIRST RATE MARK FOR ITS LOCATION.  JENARIO ALMODOR, ABAD AND MANUEL PARDILLA, NATIVES IN GUANICA, KNOW WHERE THIS STATION IS.
markers.setting: SET IN ROCK OUTCROP
markers.stability: MOST RELIABLE AND EXPECTED TO HOLDPOSITION/ELEVATION WELL

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1965 (MTP) GUANICA LIGHTHOUSE IS ABANDONED AND STANDS IN VERY POOR CONDITION.  THE CEILING AND WALLS OF THE BUILDING ARE HIGHLY UNSTABLE AND PARTS HAVE CAVED IN.  THE TOWER ITSELF IS IN RELATIVELY GOOD CONDITION.  STATION IS EASILY ACCESSABLE VIA THE PAVED ROAD THAT LEADS TO POINT MESETA.                            STATION RECOVERY (1966)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JMC) BUILDING NOW IN RUINS, LIGHT FOUNDATION REMAINS.  A NEW LIGHT ON A STEEL TOWER HAS BEEN CONSTRUCTED NORTHWEST OF OLD LIGHT.  TO REACH FROM INTERSECTION OF HIGHWAYS 334 AND 333 AT GUANICA GO SOUTH 2.5 MILES ON HIGHWAY 333 TO THE STATION ON EAST SIDE OF HIGHWAY.                            STATION RECOVERY (1971)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1971 (EKM) THE STATION WAS RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED BY M.T. PAULSON IN 1965.

BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JJL) THE STATION IS LOCATED AT THE NORTHEAST EDGE OF GUANICA.  THE TANK IS A CYLINDRICAL, STEEL STRUCTURE, SILVER IN COLOR, SUPPORTED BY 4 STEEL LEGS AND IT IS ABOUT 75 FEET HIGH.  POINT INTERSECTED IS THE ROUND BALL ATOP AND CENTER OF THE TANK.                            STATION RECOVERY (1970)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1970 (KAM) THE STATION WAS RECOVERED AND FOUND TO BE ALTERED.  THE STATION RETAINS ITS ORIGINAL POSITION.  A REVISED DESCRIPTION FOLLOWS.  THE STATION IS LOCATED AT THE NORTHEAST EDGE OF GUANICA.  THE TANK IS A CYLINDERICAL, STEEL STRUCTURE, AQUA IN COLOR, SUPPORTED BY 4 STEEL LEGS AND IT IS ABOUT 75 FEET HIGH.  POINT INTERSECTED IS THE ROUND BALL ATOP AND CENTER OF THE TANK.                            STATION RECOVERY (1971)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1971 (EKM) THE STATION WAS RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED BY ALS IN 1970.

BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1934 STEEL TANK ON TOWER IN GUANICA.  POINT SIGHTED WAS CENTER OF TANK.                            STATION RECOVERY (1965)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1965 (MTP) STATION NO LONGER EXISTS.  THE WATER TANK WAS DESTROYED IN 1955 AND REPLACED BY ANOTHER TANK SEVERAL HUNDRED YARDS FROM THE FORMER.

BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1900 (JN) STATION IS ON THE LAND OF JOSE YRISARRE AND IS ON THE TOP OF THE HIGHEST PART OF THE RIDGE WHOSE EXTREMITY FORMS GUANIQUILLA POINT.  AT THE FOOT OF THE RIDGE (ON THE N SIDE) IS THE LITTLE BAY OR ENSENADA CALLED BOCA PRIETA.  ON THE S THE LAND SLOPES OFF TO THE BAY OF BOQUERON.  YRISARRES HOUSE IS JUST W OF THE SIGNAL.  THE NE CORNER OF THE HOUSE IS DISTANT 7.78 METERS.  THE SE CORNER OF THE HOUSE IS DISTANT 9.28 METERS.  STATION MARK IS A 2-INCH IRON PIPE SUNK IN THE GROUND ABOUT 16 INCHES AND LEAVING ABOUT 6 INCHES EXPOSED.  IT IS SURROUNDED BY A BRICK AND CEMENT MIXTURE AND THE INTERIOR OF THE PIPE IS FILLED WITH CEMENT.  IN THE CENTER OF THE UPPER SURFACE OF THE CEMENT A NAIL WAS SET, THE NAIL HEAD BEING THE STATION MARK.  THE MOST CONVENIENT WAY TO REACH THE SIGNAL IS BY BOAT TO THE BOCA PRIETA, AND THEN TAKE THE TRAIL LEADING UP TO YRISARRES HOUSE.                            STATION RECOVERY (1904)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1904 (JCL) STATION RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED.  CONCRETE CONSIDERABLY BROKEN FROM AROUND PIPE AND NAIL, AND PART OF CEMENT FROM INSIDE PIPE GONE.                            STATION RECOVERY (1966)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JWC) THE STATION MARK WAS SEARCHED FOR BUT WAS NOT FOUND.  A NEW STATION WAS ESTABLISHED AT THIS DATE.  OFFICE NOTE--STATION IS DESTROYED.  (SEE G-16362)
markers.setting: SET INTO TOP OF METAL PIPE DRIVEN INTO GROUND
markers.stability: MARK OF QUESTIONABLE OR UNKNOWN STABILITY

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JWC) THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 5-1/2 MILES SOUTHWEST OF CABO ROJO 2-3/4 MILES SOUTH OF PUERTO REAL, 1 MILE NORTHEAST OF POINT GUANIQUILLA AND ON THE HIGHEST POINT OF A RIDGE THAT IS ON THE PROPERTY OF MR. LOUIS RIVERA.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE JUNCTION OF HIGHWAYS 103 AND 308 IN THE SOUTH PART OF CABO ROJO, GO WEST ON HIGHWAY 308 FOR 0.6 MILE TO A SIDE ROAD ON THE LEFT.  TURN LEFT AND GO SOUTHWEST ON A PAVED ROAD FOR 2.9 MILES TO A SIDE ROAD ON THE RIGHT.  TURN RIGHT AND GO WEST ON A DIRT ROAD FOR 0.8 MILE TO THE BEACH.  TURN LEFT AND GO SOUTH ALONG THE EAST SIDE OF SEVERAL BEACH HOUSES FOR 0.25 MILE TO A WIRE GATE AND THE END OF TRUCK TRAVEL.  FROM HERE PACK NORTHEAST UP A STEEP HILL FOR 5 MINUTES TO THE STATION ON THE HIGHEST POINT.  THE STATION MARK IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED GUANIQUILLA 2 1966.  BRAZED TO THE TOP OF A 3-INCH CAST IRON PIPE THAT PROJECTS 4 INCHES.  IT IS ON THE HIGHEST POINT OF THE HILL.  REFERENCE MARK 1 IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED GUANIQUILLA 2 NO 1 1966.  BRAZED TO THE TOP OF A 3-INCH CAST IRON PIPE THAT PROJECTS 4 INCHES.  IT IS THE SAME ELEVATION AS THE STATION MARK.  THE PUERTO RICO SURVEY MARK IS A 1/2-INCH IRON ROD SET IN AN IRREGULAR MASS OF CONCRETE WITH THE LEGEND GUANIQUILLA 2 1958.  THE MARK IS FLUSH WITH THE GROUND AND THE SAME ELEVATION AS THE STATION MARK.  NO SUITABLE PLACE WAS FOUND FOR AN AZIMUTH MARK.
markers.setting: SET INTO TOP OF METAL PIPE DRIVEN INTO GROUND
markers.stability: MARK OF QUESTIONABLE OR UNKNOWN STABILITY

markers.description: BY LOCAL ENGINEER (INDIVIDUAL OR FIRM) 1966 (JWC) STATION ESTABLISHED BY PRS.  STATION MARK IS A 1/2-INCH IRON ROD SET IN AN IRREGULAR MASS OF CONCRETE WITH THE LEGEND GUANIQUILLA 2 1958.  THE MARK IS FLUSH WITH THE GROUND AND THE SAME ELEVATION AS STATION GUANIQUILLA 2.

BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1939 THIS STATION IS LOCATED ON A PROMINENT HILL, ON THE NE CORNER OF LAKE TORTUGERO, ABOUT 1 KM. NE OF NATIONAL GUARD CAMP, ON LAND OWNED BY AUSTIN MOLINA AND BROS.  THE HILL IS A DOUBLE-TOPPED MASS WITH A LOWER SPUR ON THE W END.  IT IS LOCALLY KNOWN AS GUARICO.  THE STATION IS ON THE MIDDLE TOP ON A ROCKY SURFACE OF ABOUT 2 METERS IN CIRCUMFERENCE.  REACHED FROM RD. 2 FOLLOWING MUNICIPAL ROAD TO ALGERRABO STARTING AT KM --, FOLLOW IT 2 KMS. TO THE ENTRANCE ROAD TO THE CAMP, CROSS CAMP TO ITS NE LIMIT AT SWING DOOR, FOLLOW IT N, TURN RIGHT (E) AT FIRST FORK, TURN N AT FIRST BEND TO S, FOOT OF HILL NEAR HOUSE OF CANUTO MAISONET. FOLLOW N ON FOOT TO TOP OF HILL AND STATION.  STATION MARK--STANDARD TABLET STAMPED GUARICO 1939 CEMENTED TO NATURAL ROCK LEDGE.  REFERENCE MARK 1-- R.R. SPIKE FIXED TO ROCK LEDGE 2.35 METERS S OF STATION.  REFERENCE MARK 2--TWO R.R. SPIKES FIXED TO ROCKY SURFACE, NEARLY 3 METERS N OF BOUNDARY LINE ON E TOP.  REFERENCE MARK 3--R.R. SPIKE ON ROCKY LEDGE 1.47 METERS E OF STATION.
markers.setting: SET IN UNSPECIFIED ROCK OR BOULDER
markers.stability: PROBABLY HOLD POSITION/ELEVATION WELL

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JWC) THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 5 MILES WEST-SOUTHWEST OF QUEBRADILLAS, 3-1/2 MILES SOUTH OF ISABELA AND ABOUT 10 YARDS EAST OF THE HIGHEST POINT OF A LOW BRUSH COVERED HILL ON THE PROPERTY OF MR. RAMON ROSADO.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE JUNCTION OF HIGHWAY 2 AND HIGHWAY 112, AT KILOMETER POST 112.8, ABOUT 2 MILES SOUTH OF ISABELA, GO SOUTH ON HIGHWAY 112 FOR 1.2 MILES TO A SIDE ROAD LEFT.  TURN LEFT AND GO EAST ON THE PAVED ROAD FOR 1.3 MILES TO A REVERSE Y-FORK AND A STORE ON THE LEFT.  TURN SHARP LEFT AND GO 0.05 MILE TO A SMALL CONCRETE BRIDGE THAT CROSSES A CONCRETE IRRIGATION CANAL AND THE END OF TRUCK TRAVEL.  PACK WEST UP THE STEEP ROCKY SLOPE TO THE HIGHEST POINT OF THE HILL AND THE STATION.  THE STATION MARK IS A STANDARD DISK, STAMPED GUAVA 1966, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN OUTCROPPING BEDROCK THAT PROJECTS 1 INCH.  IT IS LOCATED ABOUT 10 YARDS EAST OF THE HIGHEST POINT OF THE HILL.  REFERENCE MARK 1 IS A STANDARD DISK, STAMPED GUAVA NO 1 1966, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN OUTCROPPING BEDROCK THAT PROJECTS 1 INCH.  IT IS APPROXIMATELY THE SAME ELEVATION AS THE STATION.  REFERENCE MARK 2 IS A STANDARD DISK, STAMPED GUAVA NO 2 1966, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN OUTCROPPING BEDROCK THAT IS FLUSH WITH THE SURFACE OF THE GROUND.  IT IS APPROXIMATELY THE SAME ELEVATION AS THE STATION.  AN AZIMUTH MARK WAS NOT ESTABLISHED.                            STATION RECOVERY (2000)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US POWER SQUADRON 2000 (RVH) REFERENCE MARKS NOT RECOVERED. STATION DESCRIPTION SHOULD BE AMENDED TO READ - 'THE STATION IS LOCATED APPROXIMATELY 30 FEET SOUTHEAST FROM THE BASE OF A (NEW)POWER LINE PYLON'.
markers.setting: SET IN ROCK OUTCROP
markers.stability: MOST RELIABLE AND EXPECTED TO HOLDPOSITION/ELEVATION WELL

markers.description: BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1922 THE STATION IS ABOUT 5 KILOMETERS S OF ISABELA, ON ONE OF THE FIRST HIGH RANGE OF PEAKS S OF THE COAST, WHICH RUNS GENERALLY E AND W.  IT IS ON THE WESTERLY ONE OF THE TWO MOST PROMINENT PEAKS IN THE IMMEDIATE VICINITY, WHICH HAVE A SECOND-CLASS ROAD PASSING THROUGH THE DIVIDE BETWEEN THEM.  THE HILL IS WELL CLEARED OF BRUSH ON THE N SLOPE, BUT IT IS COVERED WITH BRUSH ON THE W AND S SLOPES, AND HAS A LONE ROYAL PALM TREE ON THE NW SLOPE.  THE STATION IS BELOW THE HIGHEST PART OF THE HILL OF THE W SLOPE AND JUST S OF A BROKEN REDDISH ROCK OUTCROP.  THE STATION MARK IS A STANDARD U.S.G.S. BRONZE BENCH MARK TABLET SET IN A NATURAL HOLE IN A SOLID LIMESTONE OUTCROP, AND IS ABOUT 3 INCHES BELOW THE GENERAL LEVEL OF THE ROCK.  REFERENCE MARK NO.1, IS A DRILL HOLE IN A LIMESTONE OUTCROP ON THE W SLOPE OF THE HILL, DISTANT 12.50 METERS ON A TRUE AZIMUTH OF 130 DEG 35 MIN 04 SEC.  REFERENCE MARK NO.2, IS A DRILL HOLE IN A LIMESTONE OUTCROP ON TOP OF THE HILL AND HIGHER THAN THE STATION, DISTANT 17.00 METERS ON A TRUE AZIMUTH OF 266 DEG 33 MIN 36 SEC.  ELEVATION 198.90 METERS.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM ISABELA, TAKE THE CARRETERA S TO FIRST MAIN BEND TO W AT STORE, TURN E ON SECOND CLASS ROAD, TURN S AT FIRST GOOD SECOND CLASS ROAD, AND FOLLOW THE ROAD AS FAR AS THE ARENALES BAJOS SCHOOLHOUSE.  THEN TURN S AND FOLLOW THE ROAD TO THE DIVIDE.                            STATION RECOVERY (1934)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1934 FOUND AS DESCRIBED WITH FOLLOWING EXCEPTIONS--  REFERENCE MARK NO.2, IS 27 METERS DISTANT INSTEAD OF 17 METERS.  THE STATION MARK TABLET HAD BEEN BROKEN FROM THE ROCK AND WAS GONE.  ITS LOCATION WAS RECOVERED BY MEASUREMENT FROM THE REFERENCE MARKS AND REMAINS OF THE DRILL HOLE AND THE CEMENT THAT WAS FOUND.  NO NEW MARK WAS SET AS THE OLD LOCATION CAN BE RECOVERED AT ANY TIME BY MEASUREMENTS FROM THE REFERENCE MARKS.                            STATION RECOVERY (1966)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JWC) STATION GUAVA USGS HAS BEEN DESTROYED.
markers.setting: SET IN ROCK OUTCROP
markers.stability: MOST RELIABLE AND EXPECTED TO HOLDPOSITION/ELEVATION WELL

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1941 (RLS) STATION IS LOCATED ON POINT ALGODONES WHICH IS A LARGE BLUNT POINT AND THE WESTERLY OF 2 POINTS BETWEEN ENSENADA HONDA AND THE MOUTH OF THE DAGUAO RIVER, ABOUT 1/2 MILE W OF THE VILLAGE OF FLAYA BLANCA, ABOUT 3/4 MILE E OF THE MOUTH OF THE DAGUAO RIVER, ABOUT 0.6 MILE N OF THE S END OF POINT ALGODONES, NEAR THE N END OF A RIDGE SLOPING N FROM THE S END OF THE POINT, ON THE ROOSEVELT ROADS NAVAL RESERVATION, ABOUT 50 FEET N OF AND ABOUT 1 FOOT LOWER THAN THE HIGHEST POINT ON THE RIDGE, 26 METERS W OF A MALLA BUSH FENCE, 17.0 METERS W OF THE SW CORNER OF A SMALL HOUSE, AND 15 METERS WNW OF A 24-INCH COROCHO TREE. THE MARK PROJECTS 8 INCHES ABOVE GROUND.  THE ELEVATION OF THE STATION IS 48.84 METERS.  STATION AND REFERENCE MARK NO.2 ARE STANDARD DISKS SET IN CONCRETE, AS DESCRIBED IN NOTES 1A AND 11A.  NO UNDERGROUND MARK WAS SET.  REFERENCE MARK NO.1 IS E OF THE STATION, 4.5 METERS WNW OF THE SW CORNER OF THE HOUSE, 5.2 METERS SW OF THE NW CORNER, 10.4 METERS N OF THE WITNESS MARK, AND 0.66 METER LOWER THAN THE STATION.  IT IS A U.S. NAVY BENCH MARK SET IN CONCRETE IN A DEPRESSION IN A BOULDER WHICH PROJECTS 8 INCHES ABOVE GROUND.  THE ELEVATION IS 158.06 FEET (48.18 METERS).  REFERENCE MARK NO.2 IS S OF THE STATION, 14.5 METERS SW OF THE WITNESS MARK, 22.4 METERS SW OF REFERENCE MARK NO.1, AND 0.47 METER HIGHER THAN THE STATION.  THE MARK PROJECTS 6 INCHES ABOVE GROUND.  THE ELEVATION IS 49.31 METERS.  THE WITNESS MARK IS A TRIANGULAR BLAZE ON THE W SIDE OF THE ABOVE MENTIONED 24-INCH COROCHO TREE, 2 FEET ABOVE THE GROUND.                            STATION RECOVERY (1961)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1961 (MLO) STATION AND REFERENCE MARKS WERE SEARCHED FOR BUT NOT RECOVERED.  THE STATION SITE IS NOW A HOUSING AREA.  THE NORTH END OF THE RIDGE, AS DESCRIBED IN THE PREVIOUS DESCRIPTION, HAS BEEN GRADED AWAY.  THE 24-INCH COROCHO TREE AND THE MALLA BUSH FENCE NO LONGER EXIST.  STATION WAS PROBABLY DESTROYED DURING CONSTRUCTION OF THE HOUSING DEVELOPMENT.                            STATION RECOVERY (1966)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JJL) THE STATION WAS SEARCHED FOR BUT NOT FOUND.  IT IS BELIEVED THE MARKS WERE DESTROYED DURING CONSTRUCTION IN THE AREA WHERE THE STATION WAS.
markers.setting: SET IN TOP OF CONCRETE MONUMENT
markers.stability: MAY HOLD, BUT OF TYPE COMMONLY SUBJECT TOSURFACE MOTION

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1903 (WEP) REMAINS OF THE OLD TRIPOD AND THE CENTER MARK WERE FOUND AND A NEW TRIPOD ERECTED ON THE SITE.  CENTER MARK IS A 2-INCH IRON PIPE SET IN CEMENT.  TO REACH THE SIGNAL ROW UP THE NARROW CHANNEL TO THE NORTHWARD OF THE SIGNAL UNTIL YOU FIND A GOOD LANDING PLACE ABOUT NW OF THE SIGNAL, THEN WALK TO THE SE UNTIL YOU COME TO THE BLUFF ON WHICH THE SIGNAL IS LOCATED.  KEEP NEAR THE WATER LINE.  THE SIGNAL IS LOCATED CLOSE TO THE EDGE OF THE BLUFF AND ABOUT 50 METERS FROM ITS NORTHERN LIMIT.
markers.setting: OBJECT SURROUNDED BY MASS OF CONCRETE
markers.stability: MARK OF QUESTIONABLE OR UNKNOWN STABILITY

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JJL) THE STATION IS LOCATED 9 AIRLINE MILES WEST OF NAGUABO, 9 AIRLINE MILES SOUTH-SOUTHEAST OF FAJARDO AND IN THE SOUTHEAST EDGE OF ROOSEVELT ROADS NAVAL STATION.  TO REACH FROM GUARD GATE NUMBER 1 AT THE ENTRANCE TO ROOSEVELT ROADS NAVAL STATION, GO EASTERLY ON A PAVED ROAD FOR 0.1 MILE TO A FORK.  KEEP LEFT AND GO EASTERLY ON A PAVED ROAD FOR 1.7 MILES TO A FORK JUST AFTER CROSSING THE NORTH END OF RUNWAY NUMBER 6.  KEEP RIGHT AND GO SOUTHERLY ON FORRESTAL DRIVE FOR 0.25 MILE TO A SIDE ROAD LEFT.  TURN LEFT AND GO EASTERLY ON LANGLEY DRIVE FOR 2.1 MILES TO A SIDE ROAD LEFT.  TURN LEFT AND GO SOUTHEAST ON F D R DRIVE FOR 0.7 MILE TO A SIDE ROAD RIGHT. TURN RIGHT AND GO SOUTH AND EAST ON SARATOGA DRIVE FOR 0.65 MILE TO A PLAY GROUNDS AND THE END OF THE PAVED ROAD.  GO EASTERLY ACROSS THE PLAY GROUNDS FOR 0.05 MILE TO THE EAST EDGE OF THE PLAY GROUNDS AT THE BASE OF A CUT BANK AND THE STATION ON THE TOP OF THE CUT BANK.  THE STATION MARK IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED GUAYAGAN 2 1966, BRAZED TO THE TOP OF A 3-INCH ROUND CAST IRON SOIL PIPE WHICH PROJECTS 5 INCHES.  IT IS ABOUT 200 FEET EAST OF THE PLAY GROUNDS.  REFERENCE MARK 1 IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED GUAYACAN 2 NO 1 1966, BRAZED TO THE TOP OF A 3-INCH ROUND CAST IRON SOIL PIPE WHICH PROJECTS 10 INCHES.  REFERENCE MARK 2 IS A IRON PEG WITH NO STAMPING, SET IN THE TOP OF A 12-INCH SQUARE CONCRETE MONUMENT PROJECTING 1 FOOT.  NO AZIMUTH MARK WAS ESTABLISHED AT THIS STATION.
markers.setting: SET INTO TOP OF METAL PIPE DRIVEN INTO GROUND
markers.stability: MARK OF QUESTIONABLE OR UNKNOWN STABILITY

markers.description: BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1970 (JKW) STATION RECOVERED IN APPARENT GOOD CONDITION.

BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 2002 STATION IS A GPS CORS.  LATEST INFORMATION INCLUDING POSITIONS AND VELOCITIES ARE AVAILABLE IN THE COORDINATE AND LOG FILES ACCESSIBLE BY ANONYMOUS FTP OR THE WORLDWIDE WEB.    https://geodesy.noaa.gov/corsdata/coord/coord_14     https://geodesy.noaa.gov/corsdata/station_log     https://geodesy.noaa.gov/CORS
markers.marker: _MARKER: STATION IS THE ANTENNA REFERENCE POINT OF THE GPS ANTENNA

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1901 (JEM) THIS STATION IS ON THE HIGHEST PART OF THE HILL WHICH RUNS UP FROM BARBACOA POINT.  THE TOP OF THE HILL IS COVERED WITH A DENSE GROWTH OF TREES AND BUSHES, AND, WHILE THE SUMMIT WAS NOT OF GREAT AREA, THE DENSITY OF THE FOREST GROWTH AROUND THE SIDES NEAR THE SUMMIT AND ITS HEIGHT FORCED ME TO DO A GREAT DEAL OF CHOPPING SO THE SIGNAL COULD BE VIEWED WELL FROM ALL SIDES.  TO REACH THE STATION GO TO THE PLAYA OF YABUCCA AND THEN TAKE THE TRAIL ALONG THE BEACH NORTHWARD.  IT CAN EASILY BE FOLLOWED ON HORSEBACK UNTIL ONE REACHES THE CABIN OF DOMINGO FIGUEROA.  HERE IT WILL BE NOTED THAT A CLEARING EXTENDS UP THE SLOPE OF BARBACOA HILL ALMOST TO THE SUMMIT, BUT DENSE VEGETATION AND FOREST GROWTH STILL COVERS THE SEAWARD SLOPE OF THE HILL.  UP THE SLOPE ONE SHOULD GO TO ITS UPPER EXTREMITY AND THEN TURN IN THROUGH THE BUSHES UP TO THE SUMMIT, WHOSE DIRECTION WILL BE EVIDENT.  THE TRIPOD SIGNAL (WITH POLE) WAS BUILT ON THE VERY SUMMIT AND THE CLEARING ABOUT IT WILL BE A GOOD MARK BY WHICH TO IDENTIFY IT FOR YEARS.  IT WILL TAKE A GOOD HORSE TO CARRY A RIDER TO THIS SUMMIT.  THE OWNER OF THE GROUND IS MARCUS SOLI.  HE IS A LIME TURNER AND PLANTER.                            STATION RECOVERY (1923)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1923 (FTS) HALF OF THE STATION MARK, CONSISTING OF AN IRREGULAR MASS OF CONCRETE IN WHICH THE IMPRESS OF A TWO-INCH PIPE WAS NOTED, WAS FOUND LYING LOOSE ON THE TOP OF THE HILL.  ANOTHER STATION GUAYANES 2 WAS ESTABLISHED AND LOCATED.  THE MEASUREMENT MADE FROM THE NEW STATION TO THE SITE OF THE OLD STATION, AS DERIVED FROM THE COMPUTATIONS, DID NOT REVEAL ANY TRACES OF THIS THE OLD STATION.
markers.setting: OBJECT SURROUNDED BY MASS OF CONCRETE
markers.stability: MARK OF QUESTIONABLE OR UNKNOWN STABILITY

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1923 (FTS) LOCATED AT THE SUMMIT OF A WOODED HILL, ABOUT 400 FEET IN ELEVATION, ON THE EASTERN PART OF POINT GUAYANES.  STATION AND REFERENCE MARKS ARE STANDARD BRONZE DISKS SET IN IRREGULAR MASSES OF CONCRETE.  ONLY TWO SUBSTANTIAL MARKS WERE ESTABLISHED, THIS WAS CONSIDERED BETTER THAN ESTABLISHING THREE SMALLER MARKS.  TO HAVE ESTABLISHED A THIRD SUBSTANTIAL MARK, REQUIRING WATER, CEMENT AND SAND, WOULD HAVE DELAYED PARTY UNDULY.  STATION IS REACHED BEST FROM THE W SIDE OF THE POINT THENCE FOLLOWING TRAILS LEADING TO THE SUMMIT OF THE WESTERN HILL OF THE POINT AND THENCE FOLLOWING TRAIL ALONG THE RIDGE JOINING THE TWO HILLS.                            STATION RECOVERY (1940)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1940 THE STATION MARK AND THE REFERENCE MARK, BOTH UNSTAMPED, WERE RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.  AT PRESENT BOTH MARKS ARE WITHIN, AND NEAR NORTH EDGE OF A WIDE CLEARING THAT IS PROJECTED AS A ROAD.  TO REACH FROM HUMACAO, FROM S.E. CORNER OF PLAZA GO EAST ONE FULL BLOCK, TURN SOUTH, CROSSING R.R. AT 1.2 MILES, AND TURN LEFT AT AGUACATE (4.3 MILES BEYOND R.R.) JUST SOUTH OF KM. 93.2.  FOLLOW THIS ROAD 3.0 MILES TO WITHIN 100 YARDS OF THE PUERTO YABUCCA WHARF.  THENCE GO ON FOOT EAST ALONG BEACH ABOUT 1/2 MILE, TAKING TRAIL THROUGH FENCE BEYOND LAST OF A GROUP OF HOUSES ON SMALL POINT.  FOLLOW TRAIL ABOUT ONE MILE UP TO RIDGE AND TO STATION ON EASTERNMOST SUMMIT.  THE NEW CLEARED TRAIL CONTINUES DOWN EAST SLOPE OF HILL TO THE SHORE.                            STATION RECOVERY (1961)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1961 (MLO) STATION AND REFERENCE MARK WERE RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION BUT RM IS NOW 6 INCHES UNDER GROUND.  A NEW TO REACH FOLLOWS.  FROM HUMACAO POST OFFICE GO 2.7 MILES SOUTHWARD ON P.R. HIGHWAY 3 TO R.R. HIGHWAY 906.  TURN LEFT ON P.R. 906 AND GO 2.6 MILES TO TOP OF SMALL HILL AND END OF BLACKTOP.  PROCEED 0.6 MILE TO JUNCTION OF 4 ROADS AND PINK HOUSE AND YELLOW HOUSE ON LEFT.  FROM HERE PACK 0.2 MILE ON TRAIL TO TRAIL JUNCTION.  TAKE RIGHT FORK AND PACK 0.2 MILE TO STATION ON TOP OF HILL.                            STATION RECOVERY (1965)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1965 (JJL) THE STATION WAS RECOVERED AND FOUND IN GOOD CONDITION.  TWO NEW REFERENCE MARKS WERE ESTABLISHED.  A COMPLETE NEW DESCRIPTION OF THE STATION FOLLOWS.  THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 7 AIRLINE MILES SOUTH-SOUTHEAST OF HUMACAO AND ABOUT 5-1/4 AIRLINE MILES EAST-NORTHEAST OF YABUCOA AND ON A HIGH BRUSH COVERED HILL OVERLOOKING THE ATLANTIC OCEAN.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE SOUTHEAST CORNER OF THE PLAZA IN HUMACAO.  GO EAST ON A PAVED STREET FOR 0.1 MILE TO HIGHWAY 3, TURN RIGHT AND GO SOUTHERLY ON HIGHWAY 3 FOR 2.6 MILES TO HIGHWAY 906.  TURN LEFT AND GO EASTERLY ON HIGHWAY 906 FOR 0.4 MILE TO A FORK.  KEEP RIGHT AND GO EAST AND SOUTH ON A PAVED ROAD FOR 2.7 MILES TO A SIDE ROAD LEFT AT A SMALL STORE.  TURN LEFT AND GO EAST ON A BLADED ROAD FOR ABOUT 100 FEET TO A SIDE ROAD RIGHT, TURN RIGHT AND GO SOUTHERLY ON A TRACK ROAD FOR 0.1 MILE TO A GATE AT A HOUSE.  PASS THROUGH THE GATE AND CONTINUE SOUTHERLY ALONG A RIDGE FOR 0.35 MILE TO A DIM T-INTERSECTION.  TURN RIGHT AND GO SOUTHEAST ON A DIM TRACK ROAD FOR 0.15 MILE TO THE TOP OF THE HILL AND THE STATION ON THE LEFT.  THE STATION MARK IS A STANDARD DISK WITH NO STAMPING, SET IN THE TOP OF A 10 INCH ROUND CONCRETE MONUMENT PROJECTING 3 INCHES.  IT IS 20 FEET NORTH OF THE CENTER OF A TRACK ROAD.  (NOTE 1B 7A)  REFERENCE MARK 2 IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED GUAYANES 2 NO 2 1923, BRAZED TO THE TOP OF A 3 INCH ROUND CAST IRON SOIL PIPE PROJECTING 6 INCHES.  IT IS 11 FEET SOUTH OF THE CENTER OF THE TRACK ROAD.  REFERENCE MARK 3 IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED GUAYANES 2 NO 3 1923, BRAZED TO THE TOP OF A 3 INCH ROUND CAST IRON SOIL PIPE PROJECTING 3 INCHES.  IT IS 10 FEET SOUTH OF THE CENTER OF THE TRACK ROAD.  NO AZIMUTH MARK WAS ESTABLISHED AT THIS STATION.  AIRLINE DISTANCE AND DIRECTION FROM NEAREST TOWN 5-1/4 MILES ENE OF YABUCOA.                            STATION RECOVERY (1970)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1970 (JKW) STATION MARK WAS RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.  REFERENCE MARKS 2 AND 3 ARE LOST.  THEY APPEAR TO HAVE BEEN DESTROYED BY A BULLDOZER.  THE RECOVERY NOTE BY J.J.L. IN 1965 IS ADEQUATE WITH THE FOLLOWING REFERENCE MEASUREMENTS.  MARK IS 99.0 FT SOUTH OF SOUTHEAST CORNER OF A TIN SHED, 30.0 FT NORTH OF A RADIO ANTENNA, 11.4 FT NORTH OF NORTHWEST CORNER OF A RADIO SHACK BLOCK BUILDING, AND 6.2 FT NORTH OF A WIRE FENCE.
markers.setting: SET IN TOP OF CONCRETE MONUMENT
markers.stability: MAY HOLD, BUT OF TYPE COMMONLY SUBJECT TOSURFACE MOTION

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JJL) THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 9-1/2 MILES WEST OF PONCE, 3-1/2 MILES EAST-SOUTHEAST OF GUAYANILLA AND ON THE GROUNDS OF THE UNION CARBIDE REFINERY.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE PLAZA IN GUAYANILLA, GO EASTERLY ON HIGHWAY 2 FOR 4-1/2 MILES TO THE UNION CARBIDE REFINERY AND THE STATION ON THE RIGHT, SOUTH, SIDE OF THE HIGHWAY.  THE TANK IS A ROUND-SHAPED STEEL STRUCTURE, WHITE IN COLOR, SUPPORTED BY FOUR STEEL LEGS AND IT IS ABOUT 200 FEET HIGH.  UNION CARBIDE IS PAINTED ON THE NORTH SIDE OF THE TANK.  POINT INTERSECTED IS THE RED OBSTRUCTION LIGHT ATOP THE TANK.                            STATION RECOVERY (1969)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1969 (JKW) THE STATION WAS RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.  THE ORIGINAL DESCRIPTION IS ADEQUATE.  A NEW TO REACH FOLLOWS--FROM THE INTERSECTION OF MARINA STREET AND THE PONCE BYPASS IN PONCE, GO WEST ON PONCE BYPASS (HWY 2) FOR 8.2 MILES TO THE TALLABOA EXIT (HWY 127 AND OLD HWY2) TAKE EXIT AND GO 1.5 MILES TO THE UNION CARBIDE REFINERY.  STATION IS ON THE LEFT, SOUTH, SIDE OF ROAD AND ABOUT 0.5 MILE FROM THE ROAD.  PERMISSION MUST BE OBTAINED FROM UNION CARBIDE OFFICIALS TO VISIT THE STATION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1971)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1971 (EKM) STATION WAS RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.  THE DESCRIPTION BY JJL IN 1966 IS ADEQUATE.

BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1934 STATION IS ON GUILARTE MOUNTAIN, ABOUT 5 MILES W OF ADJUNTAS, ONE OF THE HIGHEST MOUNTAINS OF THE WESTERN SECTION OF MAIN RIDGE OF PUERTO RICO.  IT IS BETWEEN THE HEADS OF GUILARTE AND LIMANI RIVERS (TRIBUTARIES OF ANASCO) AND THE VACAS RIVER ON N AND PENUELAS AND GUAVANILLE RIVERS ON S.  STATION MARK IS U.S.G.S. BENCH MARK TABLET SET IN NATURAL ROCK, STAMPED GUILARTE 1934.  REFERENCE MARK NO.1 IS A CROSS ON NATURAL ROCK ON SLANTING FACE LOOKING AT STATION FROM SW, 5.517 METERS FROM STATION IN TRUE AZIMUTH 04 DEG 16 MIN.  REFERENCE MARK NO.2 IS A CROSS ON NATURAL ROCK, SAME ELEVATION AS STATION, 1.60 METERS TO NE, IN TRUE AZIMUTH 213 DEG 42 MIN.  APPROACHED BY ENTERING THROUGH THE GUILARTE MUNICIPAL ROAD THAT STARTS FROM KILOMETER 77 H 8 OF ADJUNTAS-LARES ROAD, FOLLOW IT S 3.2 KILOMETERS TO ITS END, THEN CONTINUE ON A HORSE TRAIL THROUGH DON ULPIANA RODRIQUEZS FARM, THROUGH BARQUINAS FARM AND THEN THROUGH THE WOOD TO TOP OF MOUNTAIN.  STATION IS ON LAND OWNED BY JOSE E. COLOM.  IT IS COVERED BY WOODS AND WILD PALMS ON ALL SIDES.                            STATION RECOVERY (1966)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JWC) THE STATION MARK WAS RECOVERED AND FOUND IN GOOD CONDITION.  A SEARCH WAS MADE FOR THE REFERENCE MARKS BUT NONE WERE FOUND.  TWO NEW REFERENCE MARKS WERE ESTABLISHED.  A COMPLETE NEW DESCRIPTION FOLLOWS--  THE STATION IS LOCATED 7 AIRLINE MILES NORTHWEST OF PENUELAS, 4 AIRLINE MILES SOUTHWEST OF ADJUNTAS AND ON THE TOP OF A HIGH BRUSH COVERED HILL.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE NORTHEAST CORNER OF THE PLAZA IN ADJUNTAS, GO NORTH ON HIGHWAY 10 FOR 1.6 MILES TO HIGHWAY 135.  TURN LEFT AND GO WESTERLY ON HIGHWAY 135 FOR 2.85 MILES TO HIGHWAY 131.  TURN LEFT AND GO SOUTHERLY ON HIGHWAY 131 FOR 2.6 MILES TO A FORK.  KEEP LEFT AND CONTINUE SOUTHERLY ON HIGHWAY 131 FOR 2.4 MILES TO A TRAIL ON THE RIGHT JUST AFTER PASSING KILOMETER POST 7.9 AND END OF TRUCK TRAVEL.  FROM HERE PACK WEST, SOUTH AND EAST ON A TRAIL FOR ABOUT 30 MINUTES TO THE TOP OF THE BRUSH COVERED HILL AND THE STATION.  THE STATION MARK IS A U.S. GEOLOGICAL SURVEY BENCH MARK DISK STAMPED GUILARTE 1934, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A BOULDER WHICH PROJECTS 3 FEET.  REFERENCE MARK 3 IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED GUILARTE USGS NO 3 1934, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A BOULDER WHICH PROJECTS 2 FEET.  (NOTE 12C)  REFERENCE MARK 4 IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED GUILARTE USGS NO 4 1934, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A BOULDER WHICH PROJECTS 2 FEET.  (NOTE 12C)  NO AZIMUTH MARK WAS ESTABLISHED AT THIS STATION.  AIRLINE DISTANCE AND DIRECTION FROM NEAREST TOWN 4 MILES SOUTHWEST OF ADJUNTAS.
markers.setting: SET IN UNSPECIFIED ROCK OR BOULDER

BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JWC) THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 7 MILES WEST-NORTHWEST OF ARECIBO, 2 MILES EAST-NORTHEAST OF CAMUY AND IN A RESIDENTIAL AREA LOCATED ABOUT 1/4 MILE NORTHEAST OF THE PLAZA IN HATILLO.  THE PROPERTY IS OWNED BY MR. FELIX GINOUO AND THE STATION IS SITUATED IN THE SOUTHEAST CORNER OF HIS YARD.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE NORTHEAST CORNER OF THE PLAZA IN HATILLO, GO NORTH FOR ONE BLOCK THEN TURN RIGHT AND GO EAST ON HIGHWAY 119 FOR 0.3 MILE TO THE TOP OF A HILL AND THE STATION ON THE LEFT, NORTH, SIDE OF THE ROAD NEAR A LARGE HOUSE ON THE LEFT.  THE STATION MARK IS A STANDARD DISK, STAMPED HATILLO 1966, SET IN THE TOP OF A 12-INCH ROUND CONCRETE MONUMENT THAT IS FLUSH WITH THE SURFACE OF THE GROUND.  IT IS LOCATED 26 FEET WEST OF THE APPROXIMATE CENTER OF THE DRIVEWAY, 24.5 FEET NORTH OF THE APPROXIMATE CENTER OF HIGHWAY 119 AND 11 FEET SOUTHEAST OF THE SOUTHEAST CORNER OF THE HOUSE.  THE UNDERGROUND MARK IS A STANDARD AZIMUTH MARK DISK, STAMPED HATILLO 1966, SET IN THE TOP OF A BLOCK OF CONCRETE ABOUT 3 FEET BELOW THE SURFACE OF THE GROUND.  REFERENCE MARK 1 IS A STANDARD DISK, STAMPED HATILLO NO 1 1966, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN THE CONCRETE SIDEWALK SURROUNDING THE HOUSE.  IT IS LOCATED 58.9 FEET NORTH OF THE APPROXIMATE CENTER OF HIGHWAY 119 AND 19.5 FEET WEST OF THE APPROXIMATE CENTER OF THE DRIVEWAY.  REFERENCE MARK 2 IS A STANDARD DISK, STAMPED HATILLO NO 2 1966, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN THE CONCRETE SIDEWALK SURROUNDING THE HOUSE.  IT IS LOCATED 51 FEET WEST OF THE APPROXIMATE CENTER OF THE DRIVEWAY, 24 FEET NORTH OF THE APPROXIMATE CENTER OF HIGHWAY 119 AND 22.8 FEET WEST OF THE SOUTHWEST CORNER OF THE HOUSE.  AN AZIMUTH MARK WAS NOT ESTABLISHED.                            STATION RECOVERY (2004)  RECOVERY NOTE BY UNIVERSITY OF PUERTO RICO AT MAYAGUEZ 2004 (JMV) MARK NOT FOUND.

markers.description: BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1934 STATION IS LOCATED ON A RIDGE OF MOUNTAINS CROWNING A WIDE PLATEAU W OF LARES.  IT IS ON LAND OWNED BY JUAN MATTEI NATAL ON BO. STA. ISABEL OF UTUADO BUT IT IS APPROACHED FROM LARES.  TAKE LARES-BUENOS AIRES ROAD THAT STARTS AT KILOMETER 43 H 3, YAUCO-LARES ROAD, AND LEAVE IT AT KILOMETER 4 H 3, TAKING HORSE TRAIL TO MATTEIS FARMHOUSE AND 1 KILOMETER E OF HOUSE IS THE HILL.  STATION MARK IS A STANDARD TABLET SET ON ROCK STAMPED, HELECHO 1934.  REFERENCE MARK NO.1 IS CROSS ON ROCK, 3.60 MILLIMETERS SW OF STATION IN TRUE AZIMUTH 52 DEG 02 MIN.  REFERENCE MARK NO.2 IS STANDARD TABLET SET ON ROCK, 3.33 MILLIMETERS N OF E OF STATION IN TRUE AZIMUTH 177 DEG 39 MIN.  SIGNAL--QUADRIPOD WITH CROSS-TARGETS AND A WHITE FLAG.                            STATION RECOVERY (1941)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1941 (GBG) ABOUT EIGHT KILOMETERS SE OF LARES AND NINE KILOMETERS SW OF UTUADO.  ON A HIGH PEAK OF THE HIGH RIDGE TO THE S OF THE CAGUANAS PLATEAU.  THE HILL IS THICKLY WOODED.  BUT A WIDE TRAIL RUNS JUST S OF THE STATION.  IT IS IN THE BARRIO SANTA ISABEL OF UTUADO.  AND ON THE LAND OF JUAN MATTEI NATAL, ABOUT A KILOMETER E OF HIS HOUSE.  THE STATION WAS FOUND LOOSE IN 1941.  BUT WAS REBUILT IN PLACE.  IT IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED HELECHO 1934 CEMENTED TO A ROCK, ON THE HIGHEST POINT OF THE HILL, BESIDE A DIM TRAIL, AND ABOUT 5 METERS N OF MAIN TRAIL.  THE REFERENCE MARKS HAD APPARENTLY BEEN DESTROYED.  THEY WERE NOT FOUND.  NEW REFERENCE MARKS ESTABLISHED 1941.  REFERENCE MARK 3 IS 2.02 METERS FROM STATION IN AZIMUTH 209 DEG 16 MIN.  REFERENCE MARK 4 IS 5.85 METERS FROM STATION IN AZIMUTH 291 DEG 19 MIN.  TO REACH FROM KM. POST 44.1 OF THE LARES-YAUCO ROAD, RUN NE ON THE BUENOS AIRES ROAD TO KM. POST 4.5.  50 METERS BEYOND HERE TURN LEFT (ESE) ON WIDE, CLAY ROAD UP HILL TO A FLAT PLACE.  LEAVE CAR.  AND CONTINUE ON ROAD DOWN TO, AND ACROSS, RIVER.  AND UP THE LONG HILL TO SENOR MATTEIS HOUSE.  CONTINUE ON SAME, MAIN TRAIL, WORKING UP SW SIDE OF HILL ABOUT ONE KM. TO TOP AND STATION.  IRON BAR IN CENTER OF 3- BY 3-INCH CONCRETE POST OF P.R.R.A.                            STATION RECOVERY (1954)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1954 (JOP) THE STATION WAS RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED AND THE STATION AND R.M. NO. 3 WAS FOUND TO BE IN GOOD CONDITION.  R.M. NO. 4 WAS NOT FOUND.  A COMPLETE AND NEW DESCRIPTION FOLLOWS--  THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 8 KILOMETERS SE OF LARES AND 9 KILOMETERS SW OF UTUADO, ON A HIGH PEAK OF THE HIGH RIDGE TO THE SOUTH OF CAGUANAS PLATEAU.  THE LAND IS NOW OWNED BY ANDRES SAANTIAGO ROMAN.  THE MARK IS 25 FEET W OF THE SW CORNER OF A CONCRETE SLAB AND 26 FEET N OF THE NORTH ROAD BANK.  THE DISK IS A U.S.G.S. DISK SET IN A ROCK AND STAMPED HELECHO 1934.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE JUNCTION OF HWYS 111 AND 128 IN SOUTH LARES, GO S ON 128 FOR 3.8 MILES TO THE JUNCTION OF HWYS 128 AND 129.  TURN LEFT ON 129 AND GO 3.25 MILES TO A DIRT T-ROAD LEFT.  TURN LEFT AND FOLLOW DIRT ROAD FOR 0.3 MILE TO A SMALL STREAM, CROSS STREAM AND FOLLOW DIRT ROAD FOR 0.3 MILE TO A HOUSE ON LEFT (SENOR JUAN MATTEL NATAL HOME), CONTINUE STRAIGHT AHEAD FOR 0.3 MILE TO A T-INTERSECTION.  TURN LEFT AND FOLLOW ROAD FOR 0.5 MILE TO STATION ON LEFT AS DESCRIBED.                            STATION RECOVERY (1966)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JJL) THE STATION MARK WAS RECOVERED AND FOUND IN GOOD CONDITION.  TWO NEW REFERENCE MARKS WERE ESTABLISHED.  A COMPLETE NEW DESCRIPTION OF THE STATION FOLLOWS--  THE STATION IS LOCATED 9-1/2 AIRLINE MILES NORTHWEST OF ADJUNTAS AND ON THE TOP OF A HIGH BRUSH COVERED HILL WHICH IS THE HIGHEST POINT IN THE IMMEDIATE VICINITY.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE NORTHWEST CORNER OF THE PLAZA IN LARES, GO EASTERLY ON HIGHWAY 111 FOR 3.0 MILES TO HIGHWAY 129.  TURN RIGHT AND GO SOUTH ON HIGHWAY 129 FOR 1.8 MILES TO THE INTERSECTION OF HIGHWAYS 129 AND 128.  BEAR LEFT AND GO SOUTHEAST ON HIGHWAY 129 FOR 4.2 MILES TO A SIDE ROAD LEFT AT KILOMETER POST 6.1.  TURN LEFT AND GO NORTHEAST ON A ROCK ROAD FOR 0.05 MILE TO A FORK.  BEAR LEFT AND GO NORTH AND EAST ON A ROCK ROAD FOR 0.35 MILE TO A SIDE ROAD RIGHT.  KEEP LEFT AND CONTINUE NORTHERLY ON THE ROCK ROAD FOR 0.65 MILE TO A SIDE ROAD RIGHT.  TURN RIGHT AND GO EAST ON A TRACK ROAD FOR 0.4 MILE TO A T-INTERSECTION, KEEP LEFT AND CONTINUE EASTERLY ON THE TRACK ROAD FOR 0.15 MILE TO A POINT WHERE A POWER LINE CROSSES A HILL AND THE STATION ON THE LEFT ON THE TOP OF THE HILL.  THE STATION MARK IS A U.S. GEOLOGICAL SURVEY BENCH MARK DISK STAMPED HELECHO 1934, SET IN THE TOP OF A MASS OF CONCRETE WHICH PROJECTS 3 INCHES.  REFERENCE MARK 4 IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED HELECHO USGS NO 4 1934 1966, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN THE SOUTHEAST CORNER ON AN OLD CONCRETE FOUNDATION WHICH PROJECTS 4 INCHES.  REFERENCE MARK 5 IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED HELECHO USGS NO 5 1934 1966, SET IN THE TOP OF A 10-INCH ROUND CONCRETE MONUMENT PROJECTING 6 INCHES. (NOTE 11B)  NO AZIMUTH MARK WAS ESTABLISHED AT THIS STATION.  AIRLINE DISTANCE AND DIRECTION FROM NEAREST TOWN 6-1/2 MILES SOUTHEAST OF LARES.
markers.setting: SET IN ROCK OUTCROP
markers.stability: MOST RELIABLE AND EXPECTED TO HOLDPOSITION/ELEVATION WELL

markers.description: BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1934 STATION IS ON A GRASS-COVERED HILL, ON DIVIDE BETWEEN ANASCO AND MAYAGUEOILLO RIVERS, 5 MILES E OF LAS MARIAS ON LAND OWNED BY ROBERTO HERENCIA.  HILL IS KNOWN AS THE CAMANTARIO DE LOS VIRUELIANTOS.  STATION MARK IS A STANDARD TABLET, STAMPED HERENCIA 1934, SET ON ROCK.  REFERENCE MARK NO.1 IS CENTER OF MANGO STUMP AT SAME LEVEL WITH STATION, 0.75 METER FROM STATION IN TRUE AZIMUTH 63 DEG (OR 281 DEG).  REFERENCE MARK NO.2 IS A NAIL AND WASHER ON CENTER OF TRIANGLE BLAZED ON MANGO TREE, 14.01 METERS FROM STATION IN TRUE AZIMUTH 163 DEG 29 MIN.  IT IS REACHED FROM LAS MARIAS BY HORSE TRAIL TO BO. BUENA VISTA, AND WHEN YOU REACH THE FARMHOUSE OF DON FORTUNATO JORGE, THE HILL IS SEEN ABOUT 0.25 MILE TO SE OF BUILDINGS.                            STATION RECOVERY (1941)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1941 (GBG) STATION IS ON A GRASS-COVERED HILL ON THE DIVIDE BETWEEN ANASCO AND MAYAGUECILLO RIVERS.  ABOUT 5 MILES E OF LAS MARIAS.  ON LAND OWNED BY ROBERTO HERENCIA.  AND ABOUT 1/4 MILE SE OF HACIENDA OF FORTUNATO JORGE.  THE HILL IS KNOWN AS THE CEMENTERIO DE LOS VIRUELIANTOS.  STATION IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED HERENCIA 1934 SET WITH CEMENT IN ROCK.  REFERENCE MARKS NOT RECOVERED.  TO REACH FROM E CORNER OF LAS MARIAS, TAKE NEW ROAD E TO BARRIO BUENA VISTA, AND GO 4.25 MILES TO A FORK.  TURN LEFT AND GO 1.0 MILE TO BUENA VISTA, HACIENDA OF FRANCISCO JORGE.  FROM HERE WALK N ON TRAIL UP CLEARED HILL, ON THE TOP OF WHICH THE STATION IS LOCATED.  JUST ABOUT 300 METERS FROM END OF AUTO TRAVEL.                            STATION RECOVERY (1952)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1952 (JOP) STATION MARK WAS RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED BY G.B.G. IN 1941 AND FOUND IN GOOD CONDITION.  THE ROUTE TO THE STATION IS ADEQUATE.  TWO NEW REFERENCE MARKS WERE ESTABLISHED.  THE STATION MARK IS STAMPED HERENCIA 1934 63R 1937.  REFERENCE MARK 1 IS 5 FT. SW OF THE FENCE LINE, AND 5 FT. NE OF THE FOOTPATH.  IT IS A STANDARD REFERENCE-MARK DISK, STAMPED HERENCIA NO 1 1934 AND CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A BOULDER.  REFERENCE MARK 2 IS 2 FT. E OF THE FOOTPATH.  IT IS A STANDARD REFERENCE-MARK DISK, STAMPED HERENCIA NO 2 1934 AND CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A BOULDER.                            STATION RECOVERY (1966)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JWC) THE STATION MARK WAS FOUND AND IN GOOD CONDITION.  REFERENCE MARKS 1 AND 2 WERE FOUND BUT THE ROCKS THEY WERE SET IN HAVE BEEN MOVED FROM THEIR ORIGINAL LOCATION AND WERE LAYING NEAR THE STATION.  A REFERENCE MARK 3 AND A REFERENCE MARK A WERE ESTABLISHED AT THIS DATE.  A COMPLETE NEW DESCRIPTION FOLLOWS--  THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 14 MILES EAST-NORTHEAST OF MAYAGUEZ, 7-1/2 MILES SOUTH-SOUTHEAST OF SAN SEBASTIAN AND ON THE HIGHEST POINT OF A CLEARED HILL.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE POST OFFICE IN LAS MARIAS, GO EAST ON HIGHWAY 124 FOR 4.3 MILES TO A SIDE ROAD ON THE LEFT AT KILOMETER POST 6.8.  TURN LEFT AND GO NORTHERLY ON A PAVED ROAD FOR 1.25 MILES TO A SIDE ROAD ON THE RIGHT AT KILOMETER POST 1.9.  TURN RIGHT AND GO WEST UP A HILL FOR 0.1 MILE TO THE STATION.  THE STATION MARK IS A U.S. GEOLOGICAL SURVEY BENCH MARK DISK STAMPED HERENCIA 1934 63R1937, SET IN AN IRREGULAR MASS OF CONCRETE THAT IS FLUSH WITH THE GROUND.  IT IS 75 FEET NORTH OF THE NORTHEAST CORNER OF A CONCRETE WATER RESERVOIR AND 9 FEET SOUTHEAST OF A POWERLINE POLE.  REFERENCE MARK 3 IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED HERENCIA USGS NO 3 1934 1966, BRAZED TO THE TOP OF A 3-INCH CAST IRON PIPE THAT IS SET FLUSH WITH THE GROUND AND IS SURROUNDED BY A ROUND MASS OF CONCRETE THAT IS 8 INCHES IN DIAMETER.  REFERENCE MARK A IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED HERENCIA USGS RM A 1934 1966, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN THE TOP OF A CONCRETE WATER RESERVOIR.  IT IS 24 FEET NORTH OF THE SOUTH EDGE OF THE RESERVOIR, 16 FEET EAST OF THE NORTHWEST CORNER OF THE RESERVOIR AND 12 FEET WEST OF THE NORTHEAST CORNER OF THE RESERVOIR.  NO AZIMUTH MARK WAS ESTABLISHED.  AIRLINE DISTANCE AND DIRECTION FROM NEAREST TOWN 3 MILES EAST OF LAS MARIAS.
