TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE POST OFFICE IN LAS MARIAS, GO EAST ON HIGHWAY 124 FOR 4.3 MILES TO A SIDE ROAD ON THE LEFT AT KILOMETER POST 6.8.  TURN LEFT AND GO NORTHERLY ON A PAVED ROAD FOR 1.25 MILES TO A SIDE ROAD ON THE RIGHT AT KILOMETER POST 1.9.  TURN RIGHT AND GO WEST UP A HILL FOR 0.1 MILE TO THE STATION ON THE TOP OF A CONCRETE WATER RESERVOIR.  THE STATION MARK IS A STANDARD REFERENCE MARK DISK STAMPED HERENCIA USGS RM A 1934 1966, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN THE TOP OF A CONCRETE WATER RESERVOIR.  IT IS 24 FEET NORTH OF THE SOUTH EDGE OF THE RESERVOIR, 16 FEET EAST OF THE NORTHWEST CORNER OF THE RESERVOIR AND 12 FEET WEST OF THE NORTHEAST CORNER OF THE RESERVOIR.
markers.setting: SET IN A MAT FOUNDATION OR CONCRETE SLAB OTHER THAN
markers.stability: MAY HOLD, BUT OF TYPE COMMONLY SUBJECT TOSURFACE MOTION

markers.description: BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1922 THIS STATION IS ABOUT 3 KILOMETERS BY MAIN ROAD NE OF THE TOWN OF AGUADILLA ON THE HIGHEST ONE OF A SERIES OF SHARP LIMESTONE PEAKS ON THE S OF THE CARRETERA.  APPROACHING ALONG THE CARRETERA FROM THE E, THE STATION IS ONE OF THE FIRST HIGH PEAKS ON THE S SIDE OF THE ROAD ON PROPERTY OWNED BY JULIO VALLE HERRERA.  THE HILL IS COVERED WITH A SPARSE GROWTH OF SCRUB BRUSH AND HAS A HIGH CLIFF ON THE W SIDE.  THE STATION IS MARKED BY A STANDARD U.S.G.S. BRONZE BENCH MARK TABLET CEMENTED IN A NATURAL HOLE OR SMALL BASIN IN SOLID LIMESTONE ON THE HIGHEST PART OF THE HILL.  REFERENCE MARK NO.1 IS A DRILL HOLE IN A LIMESTONE OUTCROP NEAR THE W EDGE OF THE TOP OF THE HILL, 8.50 METERS DISTANT IN TRUE AZIMUTH 132 DEG 09 MIN 50 SEC.  REFERENCE MARK NO.2 IS A DRILL HOLE IN A LIMESTONE OUTCROP NEAR THE E EDGE OF THE TOP OF THE HILL, 6.20 METERS DISTANT IN TRUE AZIMUTH 280 DEG 40 MIN 42 SEC.  ELEVATION ABOVE SEA LEVEL IS -213.3 METERS.  TO REACH THE STATION LEAVE THE CARRETERA AT A POINT ABOUT N OF THE FIRST PEAK APPROACHED FROM THE E, WALK S AROUND THE E SIDE OF THIS PEAK, TURN W THROUGH A LOW DIVIDE, AND THE HILL ON WHICH THE STATION IS LOCATED IS DIRECTLY AHEAD.
markers.setting: SET IN ROCK OUTCROP
markers.stability: MOST RELIABLE AND EXPECTED TO HOLDPOSITION/ELEVATION WELL

markers.description: BY RLDA SURVEYING AND MAPPING 2010 (RLD) THE STATION IS LOCATED 13.1 MI (21.1 KM) SOUTHEAST OF LAS MARIAS, 8.3 MI (13.4 KM) SOUTHEAST OF LARES, 7.6 MI (12.2 KM) SOUTHWEST OF UTUADO AND 5.5 MI (8.8 KM) NORTHWEST OF ADJUNTAS.   TO REACH THE STATION FRO THE INTERSECTION OF PR-526 AND PR-129 6.0 MI (9.7 KM) NORTHWEST OF ADJUNTAS, GO SOUTHERLY ON PR-129 FOR 1.4 MI (2.3 KM) TO THE STATION ON THE LEFT.   THE STATION IS 44.32 M (145.4 FT) SOUTHEAST OF POWER POLE A21282, 6.89 M (22.6 FT) NORTHWEST OF POWER POLE A21283 AND 6.0 M (19.7 FT) NORTHEAST OF THE CENTERLINE OF PR-129.
markers.setting: SET IN ROCK OUTCROP
markers.stability: MOST RELIABLE AND EXPECTED TO HOLDPOSITION/ELEVATION WELL

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1901 (JN) THIS STATION IS SITUATED IN THE VICINITY OF DORADO.  IT IS ON THE THIRD POINT FROM THE N END OF A VERY HIGH SPUR OF MOUNTAINS RUNNING ABOUT N AND S.  THE SPUR IS THE FIRST W OF AN ISOLATED STRING OF HILLS IN THE MIDST OF A PLAIN LYING ABOUT 1-1/2 MILES SW OF DORADO.  IT IS ABOUT 100 FEET S OF THE S FOOT OF THE HILLS MENTIONED AND IN LINE WITH MORRO CASTLE AND A CHIMNEY 3/4 MILE E OF MR. LATIMERS PLANTATION HOUSE.  IT IS IN THE SE CORNER OF A BIG ROCK AND IS MARKED BY A GALVANIZED-IRON PIPE 2 FEET BY 2 INCHES SET IN CEMENT IN A NATURAL HOLE IN THE ROCK.  THE PIPE IS FILLED WITH SMALL STONES EXCEPT THE LAST 5 INCHES WHICH IS FILLED WITH CEMENT.  THE STATION IS MARKED BY A 20-PENNY SPIKE SET IN THE EXACT CENTER OF THE CEMENT IN THE PIPE.                            STATION RECOVERY (1931)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1931 STATION RECOVERED AS ORIGINALLY DESCRIBED.  ORIGINAL MONUMENT ALL-RIGHT.  LAND OWNED BY ANTONIO POCHACO, INSULAR POLICE.  TO REACH THE HILL FOLLOW THE ASPHALT ROAD THAT GOES TO DORADO, AND 3 KILOMETERS BEFORE THE TOWN, FOLLOW W THE MUNICIPAL ROAD TOWARD HIGUILLAL TO WHERE IT CROSSES A RANGE OF HILLS IN A NARROW GORGE.  THAT RANGE RUNS N-S AND THE HILL IS THE SECOND FROM THE N.                            STATION RECOVERY (1934)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1934 STATION FOUND IN GOOD CONDITION APPARENTLY UNDISTURBED.  STATION MARK IS THE HEAD OF A SPIKE IN A 2-INCH GALVANIZED-IRON PIPE FILLED WITH CONCRETE AND CEMENTED IN THE NATURAL ROCK.  REFERENCE MARK NO.1, IS A COPPER NAIL IN TRIANGULAR BLAZE ON A 14-INCH 3-FORKED, LIVING STUMP, 8.73 FEET FROM STATION IN TRUE AZIMUTH 146 DEG 05 MIN.  REFERENCE MARK NO.2, IS A COMMON NAIL IN TRIANGULAR BLAZE ON A 7-INCH 3-FORKED STUMP OF AMASIGO TREE, 26.48 FEET FROM STATION IN TRUE AZIMUTH 288 DEG 03 MIN.  REFERENCE MARK NO.3, IS A COMMON NAIL IN TRIANGULAR BLAZE ON THE SIGNAL TREE, 12.70 FEET FROM STATION IN TRUE AZIMUTH 348 DEG 04 MIN.  TO REACH THE STATION FOLLOW THE CARRETERA LEADING FROM CARRETERA 2, TO DORADO, FOR 2.9 KILOMETERS FROM JUNCTION, TURN W ON SECOND CLASS ROAD AND FOLLOW TO FOOT OF CORAL LIMESTONE RIDGE (A DISTANCE OF 3.2 KILOMETERS), LEAVE ROAD HERE AND GO NORTHWARD ALONG FENCE ALONG E FOOT OF RIDGE TO FIRST BREAK, ABOUT 1 KILOMETER, CONTINUE UP THIS DRAW, KEEPING TO LEFT TO HEAD, THEN CLIMB RIDGE TO WESTWARD WHERE STATION IS ON HIGHEST PART.                            STATION RECOVERY (1966)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JJL) THE STATION MARK WAS RECOVERED AND FOUND IN GOOD CONDITION.  TWO NEW REFERENCE MARKS AND A NEW AZIMUTH MARK WERE ESTABLISHED.  A COMPLETE NEW DESCRIPTION OF THE STATION FOLLOWS.  THE STATION IS LOCATED 4 AIRLINE MILES NORTHEAST OF VEGA ALTA AND ON THE TOP OF A BRUSH COVERED HILL.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE SOUTHEAST CORNER OF THE PLAZA IN DORADO, GO EAST ON A PAVED STREET FOR 0.2 MILE TO THE INTERSECTION OF HIGHWAYS 693 AND 165.  TURN RIGHT AND GO SOUTH ON HIGHWAY 693 FOR 1.75 MILES TO A FORK.  KEEP RIGHT AND GO WESTERLY ON HIGHWAY 693 FOR 1.3 MILES TO THE INTERSECTION OF HIGHWAYS 696 AND 693.  TURN RIGHT AND GO NORTH AND WEST ON HIGHWAY 696 FOR 0.4 MILE TO A METAL GATE ON THE LEFT.  TURN LEFT, PASS THROUGH THE GATE AND GO SOUTH ON A BLADED ROAD FOR ABOUT 100 FEET TO THE AZIMUTH MARK ON THE LEFT.  CONTINUE SOUTHWEST ON THE BLADED ROAD FOR 0.4 MILE TO THE BASE OF A HIGH HILL AND END OF TRUCK TRAVEL.  FROM HERE PACK NORTH AND WEST AROUND THE HILL FOR ABOUT 200 YARDS TO A CANYON ON THE LEFT.  CONTINUE WESTERLY UP THE CANYON ON A TRAIL FOR ABOUT 1/4 MILE TO A SADDLE, TURN RIGHT AND GO NORTHWEST UP A RIDGE FOR ABOUT 100 YARDS TO THE TOP OF THE BRUSH COVERED HILL AND THE STATION ON THE HIGHEST POINT OF THE HILL. ALLOW 30 MINUTES FOR PACKING.  THE STATION MARK IS A IRON PEG SET IN THE TOP OF A 3 INCH ROUND GALVANIZED PIPE WHICH PROJECTS 6 INCHES.  REFERENCE MARK 4 IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED HIGH NO 4 1901, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN OUTCROPPING BEDROCK WHICH PROJECTS 1 FOOT. (NOTE 12A)  REFERENCE MARK 5 IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED HIGH NO 5 1901, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN OUTCROPPING BEDROCK WHICH PROJECTS 6 INCHES.  (NOTE 12A)  THE AZIMUTH MARK IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED HIGH 1901, SET IN THE TOP OF A 10 INCH SQUARE CONCRETE MONUMENT PROJECTING FLUSH WITH THE SURFACE OF THE GROUND.  (NOTE 16A)  AIRLINE DISTANCE AND DIRECTION FROM NEAREST TOWN 2-1/4 MILES SOUTHWEST OF DORADO.
markers.setting: SET INTO TOP OF METAL PIPE DRIVEN INTO GROUND
markers.stability: MARK OF QUESTIONABLE OR UNKNOWN STABILITY

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JWC) THE STATION IS LOCATED 10-1/2 AIRLINE MILES SOUTHWEST OF AGUADILLA, 7 AIRLINE MILES WEST-SOUTHWEST OF AGUADA, 2 AIRLINE MILES NORTHWEST OF RINCON AND ON THE POINT HIGUERO LIGHTHOUSE CATWALK.  THE STATION MARK IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED HIGUERO 1966, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN THE POINT HIGUERO LIGHTHOUSE CATWALK.  IT IS 2.7 FEET SOUTH OF THE LIGHTHOUSE DOORWAY AND 2.1 FEET NORTHEAST OF THE SOUTHWEST EDGE OF THE CATWALK.  NO REFERENCE MARKS WERE ESTABLISHED AT THIS STATION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1977)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1977 (WFP) THE STATION WAS RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION AND AS DESCRIBED IN THE 1966 DESCRIPTION.  THE STATION WAS USED AS A CHECK ANGLE FOR NUCLEAR.  AIRLINE DISTANCE AND DIRECTION FROM NEAREST TOWN 2 MILES NORTHWEST OF RINCON.                            STATION RECOVERY (2004)  RECOVERY NOTE BY UNIVERSITY OF PUERTO RICO AT MAYAGUEZ 2004 (JMV) RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.
markers.setting: SET IN A PAVEMENT SUCH AS STREET, SIDEWALK, CURB, ETC.
markers.stability: MARK OF QUESTIONABLE OR UNKNOWN STABILITY

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1927 (GCM) STATION SITE IS ON PROMINENT HILL TO THE SOUTHEASTWARD OR BACK OF THE MAGNETIC OBSERVATORY SITE.  THE WESTERN SIDE OF THE HILL INCLUDING THE STATION SITE IS CLEARED.  THERE IS A SMALL PATH UP THIS SIDE, STARTING DIRECTLY ACROSS THE HIGHWAY FROM THE MAGNETIC OBSERVATORY AND LEADING TO THE STATION SITE.  THE STATION IS APPROXIMATELY 15 FEET W OF A FENCE RUNNING N-S OVER THE TOP OF THE HILL.  THIS FENCE DIVIDES THE CLEARED PORTION OF THE HILL FROM THE UNDER BRUSH.  THE STATION IS MARKED BY A 2-INCH PIPE, 3 FEET LONG, DRIVEN INTO THE GROUND.  THE END OF THE PIPE PROJECTS 6 INCHES ABOVE THE GROUND.                            STATION RECOVERY (1937)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1937 (EHB) THIS STATION IS DEFINITELY LOST.  A 2-STORY CONCRETE HOUSE HAS BEEN BUILT ON THE SITE OF THE STATION WITH EXTENSIVE GRADING TO A DEPTH OF 4 FEET DONE IN THE VICINITY.
markers.setting: METAL ROD DRIVEN INTO GROUND. SEE TEXT FOR ADDITIONAL
markers.stability: MARK OF QUESTIONABLE OR UNKNOWN STABILITY

markers.description: BY NATIONAL OCEAN SERVICE 1993 THE STATION IS LOCATED IN ARECIBO, PR ON THE WATERFRONT AT THE WESTERN EDGE OF PUERTO ARECIBO. TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE INTERSECTION OF PR HIGHWAY 2 AND ROAD 681 ABOUT 0.75 MI (1.21 KM) EAST OF ARECIBO, PROCEED NORTH AND WEST ON 681 FOR 1.0 MI (1.6 KM) TO THE STATION ON THE RIGHT. THE STATION IS A GENERIC 7.5 CM DIAMETER BRASS DISK SET IN THE CENTER OF THE WATERFRONT SIDEWALK ON THE NORTH SIDE OF ROAD 681.  THE STATION IS 3.54 M (11.61 FT) NORTH OF THE CURB ON THE CENTERLINE PROJECTION OF AN UNMARKED RESIDENTIAL STREET  INTERSECTION ROUTE 681. THE MAGENTIC BEARING FROM THE STATION TO THE LIGHTHOUSE ON PUNTA MORRILLOS IS 82 DEGREES.
markers.setting: SET IN A PAVEMENT SUCH AS STREET, SIDEWALK, CURB, ETC.
markers.stability: PROBABLY HOLD POSITION/ELEVATION WELL

markers.description: PTIVE TEXT AVAILABLE.

BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1941 (RLS) THIS STATION IS LOCATED ON THE ROOSEVELT ROADS NAVAL RESERVATION, ON THE EASTERLY ONE OF THREE SMALL ISLANDS IN THE MANGROVE ON THE W SIDE OF ENSENADA HONDA AND N OF POINT CASCAJO, ABOUT ON THE HIGHEST POINT OF THE NEARLY FLAT TOP OF THE HILL, 15 METERS W OF THE TOP EDGE OF THE BLUFF AT THE E END OF THE ISLAND, 20 METERS S OF THE TOP EDGE OF THE BLUFF AT THE N SIDE OF THE ISLAND, AND 26 METERS E OF THE E SIDE OF A SMALL GROVE OF BANANA TREES, AND PROJECTS ABOUT 8 INCHES ABOVE GROUND.  THE ELEVATION OF THE STATION IS ABOUT 30 FEET.  STATION MARK IS A STANDARD DISK SET IN CONCRETE, AS DESCRIBED IN NOTE 1A.  NO UNDERGROUND MARK WAS SET.  REFERENCE MARK NO.1 IS ON THE S SLOPE OF THE HILL, ABOUT 10 METERS N OF THE TOP OF THE LOW STEEP BANK AT THE S SIDE OF THE ISLAND, 2.83 METERS LOWER THAN THE STATION, A STANDARD DISK SET ON TOP OF A BOULDER PROJECTING ABOUT 4 INCHES ABOVE GROUND ON THE HIGH SIDE AND 15 INCHES ON THE LOW SIDE.  REFERENCE MARK NO.2 IS ON THE SW SLOPE OF THE HILL, 19 METERS SW OF THE SW CORNER OF THE BANANA GROVE, 1.45 METERS LOWER THAN THE STATION, A STANDARD DISK SET ON TOP OF A LARGE BOULDER PROJECTING ABOUT 4 FEET ABOVE THE GROUND.  THE BOULDER IS THE SOUTHERLY ONE OF A GROUP OF BOULDERS ON THE W SLOPE OF THE HILL.  THE DISK IS SLOPING SLIGHTLY TOWARD THE STATION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1961)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1961 (MLO) STATION AND REFERENCES MARKS WERE RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED AND ARE IN GOOD CONDITION.  STATION IS 21.2 METERS WEST OF THE LARGEST TREE ON THE EAST SHORE OF THE ISLAND.  TREE IS LEANING SOUTH.                            STATION RECOVERY (1965)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1965 (MTP) STATION WAS FOUND AS DESCRIBED AND IN GOOD CONDITION EXCEPT THAT THE MANGROVE AROUND THE THREE SMALL ISLANDS HAS BEEN FILLED IN.  HEAVY GRASS ALL AROUND STATION AND HILL.  IS A RED AND WHITE STEEL PIPE TRIPOD AND CENTERPOLE ABOUT 15 FT. HIGH CONSTRUCTED OVER THE STATION.
markers.setting: SET IN TOP OF CONCRETE MONUMENT
markers.stability: MAY HOLD, BUT OF TYPE COMMONLY SUBJECT TOSURFACE MOTION

markers.description: BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1934 STATION IS ON A BARE HILL ABOUT 2.5 MILES DIRECT DISTANCE FROM THE TOWN OF GUAYAMA.  IT IS ABOUT 1 MILE W OF THE CHARCAS STATION.  THIS STATION IS EXACTLY ON A NORTHERLY DIRECTION FROM CENTRAL GUAMANI AND IS ABOUT 1200 FEET ABOVE SEA LEVEL.  THIS STATION WAS ESTABLISHED IN ORDER TO CONNECT WITH STATION CUYON OR CARITE.  STATION MARK IS A STANDARD U.S.G.S. BENCH MARK SET AND STAMPED HONDO 1934 ON HALF-BURIED BOULDER.  REFERENCE MARK NO.1 IS CROSS MARK ON HALF BURIED ROCK 17 FEET 1.5 INCHES FROM STATION IN TRUE AZIMUTH 112 DEG 20 MIN.  REFERENCE MARK NO.2 IS A CROSS MARK ON A HALF BURIED ROCK 19 FEET 8.5 INCHES FROM STATION IN TRUE AZIMUTH 248 DEG 18 MIN.  TO REACH THIS STATION, TAKE THE GUAYAMA-PONCE ROAD, AND TURN ON THE CENTRAL GUAMANI ROAD.  FROM THIS POINT, TAKE TRAIL TO THE N.  THE STATION IS ABOUT 1.5 MILES FROM THE ROAD.  ANOTHER WAY TO REACH THIS STATION IS TO DRIVE ON CAMINO POZO HONDO RURAL ROAD, WHICH BEGINS ON THE GUAYAMA-PONCE HIGHWAY AT THE GUAYAMA SANATORIUM, AND TAKE TRAIL TO THE W TO REACH THE STATION.  AT THIS TIME THERE WERE NO TRAILS OPENED.
markers.setting: SET IN A BOULDER
markers.stability: MAY HOLD, BUT OF TYPE COMMONLY SUBJECT TOSURFACE MOTION

markers.description: PTIVE TEXT AVAILABLE.
PTIVE TEXT AVAILABLE.
BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1934 THIS POINT IS ON THE ROMAN CATHOLIC CHURCH OF THE TOWN OF HORMIQUEROS.
PTIVE TEXT AVAILABLE.

BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JJL) THE STATION IS LOCATED 9-3/4 AIRLINE MILES EAST OF PATILLAS, 5 AIRLINE MILES SOUTH OF YABUCOA 1-3/4 AIRLINE MILES SOUTHEAST OF MAUNABO AND IN THE SOUTHWEST CORNER OF THE POINT TUNA LIGHTHOUSE ROOF.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE SOUTHEAST CORNER OF THE PLAZA IN MAUNABO, GO EASTERLY ON A PAVED STREET FOR 0.05 MILE TO A REVERSE Y FORK.  KEEP RIGHT AND GO EAST AND SOUTH ON A PAVED STREET FOR 0.7 MILE TO A FORK.  KEEP RIGHT AND GO SOUTHWEST AND SOUTHEAST ON A PAVED ROAD FOR 0.15 MILE TO A FORK, KEEP RIGHT AND GO SOUTHWEST AND SOUTHEAST ON A PAVED ROAD FOR 1.2 MILES TO A SIDE ROAD RIGHT.  TURN RIGHT AND GO SOUTHERLY ON A BLADED ROAD FOR 0.25 MILE TO THE POINT TUNA LIGHTHOUSE AND THE STATION ON THE ROOF OF THE LIGHTHOUSE.  THE STATION MARK IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED HOUSE 1965, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN THE SOUTHWEST CORNER OF THE LIGHTHOUSE ROOF.  IT IS 9 FEET NORTH OF THE SOUTH EDGE OF THE ROOF AND 8 FEET EAST OF THE WEST EDGE OF THE ROOF.  REFERENCE MARK 1 IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED HOUSE NO 1 1965, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN THE SOUTHEAST CORNER OF THE LIGHTHOUSE ROOF.  IT IS 5.5 FEET WEST OF THE EAST EDGE OF THE ROOF AND 4 FEET NORTH OF THE SOUTH EDGE OF THE ROOF.  REFERENCE MARK 2 IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED HOUSE NO 2 1965, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN THE WEST EDGE OF THE LIGHTHOUSE ROOF.  IT IS 3 FEET EAST OF THE WEST EDGE OF THE ROOF.  NO AZIMUTH MARK WAS ESTABLISHED AT THIS STATION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1970)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1970 (JKW) STATION MARK AND REFERENCE MARKS 1 AND 2 WERE RECOVERED AND DISTANCES CHECKED, ALL IN GOOD CONDITION.  DESCRIPTION BY JJL IN 1966 IS ADEQUATE FOR RECOVERY.                            STATION RECOVERY (1975)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1975 (JDS) THE STATION MARK AND REFERENCE MARKS 1 AND 2 WERE RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED IN 1966 AND FOUND TO BE IN GOOD CONDITION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1980)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL OCEAN SERVICE 1980 (RHH) THE STATION WAS RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED.
markers.setting: SET IN A MASSIVE STRUCTURE
markers.stability: PROBABLY HOLD POSITION/ELEVATION WELL

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1901 (JBB) STATION IS THE CENTER OF A SMALL HOUSE OR SHACK ON A BARE HILL, S SIDE OF PORT MEDIO MUNDO AND JUST BACK OF THE PROMINENT BLUFF AT THE N ENTRANCE TO PASAJE DE MEDIO MUNDO.

BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1926 (GCM) STATION IS THE GABLE OF A GRAY HOUSE ON THE HILL BACK OF POINT CARENERO.  THE ROOF OF THE HOUSE IS PRACTICALLY TORN AWAY.  HOUSE IS ABOUT 40 FEET ABOVE SEA LEVEL.

BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1934 STATION IS HOUSE NEAR TREE ON BARE HILL.  2 BUSHES NEARBY.                            STATION RECOVERY (1942)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1942 (GBG) HOUSE IS STILL STANDING.  BUT POINT WAS NOT RECOVERD, 1942.

BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1923 STATION IS THE CENTER OF ROOF OF HOUSE ON THE HILL, INCLINED RAILROAD.  DWELLING HOUSE ON TOP OF LIMESTONE KNOLL, N OF HIGHWAY BETWEEN VEGA BAJA AND MANATI.  INCLINED TRACK FROM FOOT OF HILL TO HOUSE.  NO CHECK ON THIS POSITION.

BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1934 HOUSE ON ROAD LOOP.  PROBABLY A SCHOOLHOUSE AS FLAG WAS SEEN FLYING.  IT IS LOCATED ON ONE OF THE LOWER KNOLLS IN THE RANGE OF LIMESTONE PEAKS AND LIES BETWEEN STATIONS CIBUCO AND MANATI.  IT IS VERY NOTICEABLE FROM THE S BECAUSE OF THE PROMINENT ROAD WHICH MAKES A LOOP AROUND, OR JUST IN FRONT, TO THE S OF IT.
BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1934 NO CHECK ON THIS POSITION.  HOUSE ON SADDLE, TWO BUSHES AND SMALL HOUSE ON RIGHT.

BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1934 STATION IS LOCATED ON THE BARRIO OF AGUACATE ARRIBA.  IT IS ABOUT 3 MILES TO THE SW OF HUMACAO, AND AT AN EQUAL DIRECT DISTANCE FROM YABUCCA, WHICH IS TO ITS S.  THE STATION IS ON THE MOST EASTERN END OF THE BROAD CRESTLIKE HEIGHTS AT BARRIO AGUACATE.  THESE HEIGHTS ARE THE HIGHEST ONES IN ALL THE REGION AROUND.  THERE IS A SMALL STRAW DWELLING BETWEEN BUSHES SOME 25 FEET FROM THE STATION.  THE STATION IS MARKED BY A STANDARD U.S.G.S. TABLET STAMPED HUMACAO 1934.  REFERENCE MARK NO.1 IS A CROSS MARK ON A PARTLY BURIED BOULDER 12 FEET 10 INCHES FROM THE STATION CENTER, ON TRUE AZIMUTH OF 147 DEG 26 MIN.  REFERENCE MARK NO.2 IS A CROSS MARK ON A HIGH BOULDER 21 FEET 3 INCHES FROM THE STATION CENTER, ON TRUE AZIMUTH OF 197 DEG 42 MIN.  TO REACH THE STATION, TAKE MUNICIPAL ROAD LEADING TO BARRIO MARIANA AND CENTRAL EJEMPLO, TAKING IT AT KILOMETER 85 H-7 ON THE HUMACAO-YABUCOA HIGHWAY.  ON THIS ROAD YOU CAN RIDE FOR ABOUT 2 KILOMETERS FROM THE MAIN HIGHWAY.  THE REST OF THE ROAD MUST BE TAKEN ON FOOT UP TO THE HEIGHTS AT BARRIO AGUACATE WHERE THE STATION IS LOCATED.                            STATION RECOVERY (1940)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1940 THE STATION IS LOCATED IN THE BARRIO DE AGUACATE ARRIBA, DISTRICT OF HUMACAO.  IT IS ABOUT 3 MILES SW OF HUMACAO, AND ABOUT AN EQUAL DIRECT DISTANCE N OF YABUCOA, ON THE EASTERN END OF THE LONG RIDGE OF BARRIO AGUACATE, WHICH IS THE HIGHEST IN THE REGION.  IT IS ON LAND OF BENIGNO TORRES, AND ABOUT 250 FT. E OF HUT OF EMILIO OQUENDO WHICH IS ON THE NEXT SMALL PEAK TO THE WESTWARD.  THE STATION MARK IS A STANDARD TABLET STAMPED HUMACAO 1934 SET IN A LARGE OUTCROP OF ROCK.  R. M. NO. 1 IS A CROSS MARK ON A PARTLY BURIED BOULDER 12 FT 10 IN FROM THE STATION CENTER IN AZIMUTH 147 DEG 26 MIN.  R. M. NO. 2 IS A CROSS MARK ON A HIGH BOULDER 21 FT 3 IN FROM THE STATION CENTER IN AZIMUTH 197 DEG 42 MIN.  TO REACH FROM HUMACAO, SE CORNER OF PLAZA, GO ON ROAD TO YABUCOA 0.9 MILE TO R.R. CROSSING.  TURN RIGHT AT S SIDE OF CROSSING AND FOLLOW ROAD WESTWARD PAST CENTRAL EJEMPLO AND TO END OF RD. 0.3 MILE BEYOND DAIRY FARM OF JOSE GAMALEZ ROGUE.  FROM HERE FOLLOW MAIN TRAIL ON FOOT, ABOUT 2-1/2 MILES TO STATION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1954)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1954 (CAS) STATION WAS RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 2 WAS NOT RECOVERED.  A COMPLETE NEW TO REACH THE STATION FOLLOWS.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE SOUTHEAST CORNER OF THE PLAZA IN HUMACAO, GO EAST FOR .05 MILE TO A CROSS STREET, TURN RIGHT AND GO SOUTH FOR 0.8 MILE TO A SIDE ROAD RIGHT, WHICH IS JUST AFTER CROSSING A RAILROAD, TURN RIGHT AND GO 0.45 MILE TO WHERE ROAD FORKS AND A SUGAR MILL ON THE RIGHT, BEAR LEFT AND GO 1.7 MILES TO THE END OF TRAVELED ROAD, FROM THIS POINT A FOUR WHEEL DRIVE VEHICLE MAY BE DRIVEN TO THE STATION, GO SOUTH ON DIRT ROAD, UP HILL FOR 1.3 MILES TO TOP OF RIDGE, HERE TURN LEFT ON FOOT PATH AND GO ABOUT 0.4 MILE TO THE HIGHEST POINT OF HILL AND STATION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1965)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1965 (JJL) THE STATION MARK WAS RECOVERED AND MOST OF THE STAMPING HAS BEEN OBLITERATED BUT THE MARK IS SOLID.  A SEARCH WAS MADE FOR REFERENCE MARK NO. 1 AND REFERENCE MARK NO. 2 BUT THEY WERE NOT RECOVERED.  AN AZIMUTH MARK, REFERENCE MARK NO. 3, REFERENCE MARK NO. 4 AND REFERENCE MARK RMA WERE ESTABLISHED.  A COMPLETE DESCRIPTION FOLLOWS--  THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 5-1/2 MILES SOUTH OF LAS PIEDRAS, 3-1/2 MILES SOUTHWEST OF HUMACAO, ON THE EAST END AND HIGHEST POINT OF A PROMINENT EAST-WEST RIDGE AND ON PROPERTY OWNED BY MR. AGUSTIA CABRER.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE NORTHEAST CORNER OF THE PLAZA IN HUMACAO, GO EAST ON HIGHWAY 30 FOR 0.05 MILE TO THE JUNCTION OF HIGHWAYS 30 AND 3.  TURN RIGHT AND GO SOUTH ON HIGHWAY 3 FOR 0.9 MILE TO THE JUNCTION OF HIGHWAYS 3 AND 909.  TURN RIGHT AND GO WEST AND SOUTHWEST ON HIGHWAY 909 FOR 2.7 MILES TO A REVERSE Y-FORK ON THE LEFT AND THE AZIMUTH MARK ON THE LEFT, SOUTHEAST, SIDE OF THE HIGHWAY.  CONTINUE SOUTHWEST AND WEST ON HIGHWAY 909 FOR 0.3 MILE TO A SIDE ROAD LEFT.  TURN LEFT AND GO SOUTHWEST FOR 0.05 MILE TO A STEEL GATE ON THE LEFT.  (A 4-WHEEL DRIVE VEHICLE IS REQUIRED FROM THIS POINT.) TURN LEFT, PASS THROUGH THE GATE AND GO EASTERLY, PASSING THROUGH TWO WIRE GATES, FOR 0.3 MILE TO THE END OF THE ROAD AND THE END OF TRUCK TRAVEL.  PACK EAST FOR ABOUT 100 FEET TO THE TOP OF A LOW KNOLL AND THE STATION.  THE STATION MARK IS A U.S. GEOLOGICAL SURVEY DISK CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A BOULDER THAT PROJECTS 2-1/2 FEET.  THE ONLY READABLE STAMPING ON THE DISK IS ACAO.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 3, STAMPED HUMACAO USGS NO 3 1934, IS A STANDARD DISK CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A BOULDER THAT PROJECTS 4 FEET AND IS ABOUT 3 FEET HIGHER THAN THE STATION.  (NOTE 12C)  REFERENCE MARK NO. 4, STAMPED HUMACAO USGS NO 4 1934, IS A STANDARD DISK CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A BOULDER THAT PROJECTS 1-1/2 FEET AND IS ABOUT THE SAME ELEVATION AS THE STATION.  (NOTE 12C)  REFERENCE MARK RMA, STAMPED HUMACAO USGS RMA 1934 IS A STANDARD DISK SET IN THE TOP OF A CYLINDRICAL CONCRETE MONUMENT THAT IS 12 INCHES IN DIAMETER, FLUSH WITH THE GROUND AND ABOUT 15 FEET LOWER THAN THE STATION.  (NOTE 11B)  THE AZIMUTH MARK, STAMPED HUMACAO USGS 1934, IS A STANDARD DISK CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE ON THE SOUTHWEST SLOPE OF A LARGE OUTCROPPING OF BEDROCK THAT PROJECTS ABOUT 15 FEET ON THE NORTHWEST SIDE.  IT IS 35 FEET SOUTHEAST OF THE CENTER OF HIGHWAY 909 AND 24 FEET NORTHWEST OF THE CENTER OF A DIRT ROAD.  (NOTE 17A)  AIRLINE DISTANCE AND DIRECTION FROM NEAREST TOWN 3-1/2 MILES SOUTHWEST OF HUMACAO.                            STATION RECOVERY (1978)  RECOVERY NOTE BY DEFENSE MAP AGENCY 1978 (WVM) H---ACAO DISK IS BATTERED BUT SOLID.  HUMACAO LUGS RM-A LOOSE-TOP HAS BEEN MOVED--NOT RELIABLE  RM-3 AND RM-4 SEARCHED FOR BUT NOT FOUND.  AZ. MARK FOUND IN GOOD CONDITION.  PROPERTY MANAGER IS SR. EPIFANIO CETIZ.  AIRLINE DISTANCE AND DIRECTION FROM NEAREST TOWN 3 MI. SW OF HUMACAO.                            STATION RECOVERY (2004)  RECOVERY NOTE BY UNIVERSITY OF PUERTO RICO AT MAYAGUEZ 2004 (UPR) RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.

BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1965 (JJL) THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 5-1/2 MILES SOUTH OF LAS PIEDRAS, 3-1/2 MILES SOUTHWEST OF HUMACAO, ON THE EAST END OF A PROMINENT EAST-WEST RIDGE, JUST SOUTHWEST OF AND ABOUT 15 FEET LOWER THAN THE HIGHEST POINT OF THE RIDGE AND ON PROPERTY OWNED BY MR. AGUSTIA CABRER.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE NORTHEAST CORNER OF THE PLAZA IN HUMACAO, GO EAST ON HIGHWAY 30 FOR 0.05 MILE TO THE JUNCTION OF HIGHWAYS 30 AND 3.  TURN RIGHT AND GO SOUTH ON HIGHWAY 3 FOR 0.9 MILE TO THE JUNCTION OF HIGHWAYS 3 AND 909.  TURN RIGHT AND GO WEST AND SOUTHWEST ON HIGHWAY 909 FOR 2.7 MILES TO A REVERSE Y-FORK ON THE LEFT.  CONTINUE SOUTHWEST AND WEST ON HIGHWAY 909 FOR 0.3 MILE TO A SIDE ROAD LEFT.  TURN LEFT AND GO SOUTHWEST FOR 0.05 MILE TO A STEEL GATE ON THE LEFT.  (A FOUR-WHEEL DRIVE VEHICLE IS REQUIRED FROM THIS POINT.) TURN LEFT, PASS THROUGH THE GATE AND GO EASTERLY, PASSING THROUGH TWO WIRE GATES, FOR 0.3 MILE TO THE END OF THE ROAD AND THE END OF TRUCK TRAVEL.  PACK EAST FOR ABOUT 100 FEET TO THE TOP OF A LOW KNOLL, THENCE SOUTHWEST FOR ABOUT 50 FEET TO THE STATION.  THE STATION MARK, STAMPED HUMACAO USGS RMA 1934, IS A STANDARD DISK SET IN THE TOP OF A CYLINDRICAL CONCRETE MONUMENT THAT IS 12 INCHES IN DIAMETER AND IS FLUSH WITH THE GROUND.  HUMACAO (USGS) 1934 IS A U.S. GEOLOGICAL SURVEY DISK CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A BOULDER THAT PROJECTS 2-1/2 FEET.  THE ONLY READABLE STAMPING ON THE DISK IS ACAO.  THIS MARK IS ON THE HIGHEST POINT OF THE RIDGE.                            STATION RECOVERY (1978)  RECOVERY NOTE BY DEFENSE MAP AGENCY 1978 (WVM) STATION MARK WAS FOUND LOOSE.  TOP HAS BEEN MOVED, NOT RELIABLE.

BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1941 (PR) V.A. ELEVATION 105.08 METERS.  STATION IS IN THE SOUTH CENTRAL PART OF VIEQUES ISLAND ABOUT 1 KM. NORTH OF THE COAST AND 3-1/2 KMS. NE OF POINT FERRO.  STATION MARK IS A STANDARD TABLET STAMPED INDIO 1941 AND SET IN CONCRETE MONUMENT.  R.M. NO. 1 IS A WIRE NAIL AND COPPER WASHER ON TRUNK OF HUCAR TREE 1.35 METERS ABOVE STATION MARK.  DISTANCE FROM STATION--6.99 METERS.  PLANE AZIMUTH 235-39.  R.M. NO. 2 IS A WIRE NAIL IN CENTER OF A TRIANGLE ON HUCAR TREE 1.1 METER ABOVE STATION MARK.  DISTANCE FROM STATION--8.46 METERS.  PLANE AZIMUTH 299-54.  TO REACH FROM ISABEL II DRIVE SE ON THE LUJAN ROAD TO ITS JUNCTION WITH DIRT ROAD TO AIRPORT.  FOLLOW DIRT ROAD EAST 3.3 KMS. (PASSING AIRPORT) TO LA ALDEA WELL.  WALK NW UP RIDGE TO STATION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1964)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1964 (GWM) STATION AND R.M.S DESTROYED.  A 120 MM SHELL CASING MARKED INDIO TWO 1964 WAS RECOVERED.  STATION IS LOCATED ON HILL EAST OF CAMP GARCIA HEADQUARTERS WITH TREES ON TOP.

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1899 (WCH) STATION IS ON THE SE END OF A SMALL ISLAND AT THE E ENTRANCE OF BOCA DEL INFIERNO.  THE ISLAND IS COVERED WITH MANGROVE BUSHES.  THE STATION IS ABOUT 30 FEET FROM THE BEACH.  STATION IS MARKED BY AN IRON PIPE, 2 INCHES IN DIAMETER AND ABOUT 36 INCHES LONG, EMBEDDED IN CEMENT.  A TRIPOD AND SCAFFOLD ABOUT 30 FEET HIGH WERE ERECTED OVER THIS STATION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1906)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1906 (RLF) LOCATION OF STATION RECOVERED APPROXIMATELY, SEXTANT ANGLES SHOWING THE POSITION ASSUMED TO BE ON THE STATION.  PORTIONS OF OLD TRIPOD SIGNAL WERE FOUND SCATTERED ABOUT.  PIECES OF CEMENT WERE FOUND IN DIFFERENT PLACES BUT PIPE WAS NOT FOUND.  FOR PURPOSES OF TRIANGULATION, STATION IS NO LONGER AVAILABLE.                            STATION RECOVERY (1966)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JJL) THE STATION WAS SEARCHED FOR BUT NOT FOUND.  IT IS BELIEVED THE OCEAN IS COVERING THE LAND WHERE THE STATION WAS.  A NEW STATION INFIERNO 2 WAS ESTABLISHED.
markers.setting: OBJECT SURROUNDED BY MASS OF CONCRETE
markers.stability: MARK OF QUESTIONABLE OR UNKNOWN STABILITY

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JJL) THE STATION IS LOCATED 9 AIRLINE MILES SOUTHWEST OF GUAYAMA, 7 AIRLINE MILES SOUTHEAST OF SALINAS, 3-1/2 AIRLINE MILES SOUTH OF AGUIRRE, ON THE SOUTH EDGE OF A ISLAND WHICH IS KNOWN AS INFIERNO ISLAND.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE DOCK IN AGUIRRE, GO DUE SOUTH BY BOAT FOR ABOUT 3-1/2 MILES TO THE SOUTH SIDE OF INFIERNO ISLAND AND THE STATION JUST NORTH OF THE SHORE LINE.  THE STATION MARK IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED INFIERNO 2 1966, BRAZED TO THE TOP OF A 3-INCH ROUND CAST IRON SOIL PIPE WHICH PROJECTS 4 INCHES.  IT IS 75 FEET EAST OF A LONE COCONUT TREE.  REFERENCE MARK 1 IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED INFIERNO 2 NO 1 1966, BRAZED TO THE TOP OF A 3-INCH ROUND CAST IRON SOIL PIPE WHICH PROJECTS 4 INCHES.  IT IS 45 FEET EAST OF THE LONE COCONUT TREE.  REFERENCE MARK 2 IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED INFIERNO 2 NO 2 1966, BRAZED TO THE TOP OF A 3-INCH ROUND CAST IRON SOIL PIPE WHICH PROJECTS 4 INCHES.  IT IS 90 FEET NORTHEAST OF THE LONE COCONUT TREE.  NO AZIMUTH MARK WAS ESTABLISHED AT THIS STATION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1970)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1970 (JKW) STATION MARK, REFERENCE MARK 1, AND REFERENCE MARK 2 ALL RECOVERED.  THE DISKS HAVE BEEN REMOVED FROM STATION MARK AND REFERENCE MARK 2.  THE DISTANCES WERE CHECKED, AND FOUND TO BE CORRECT.  STATION MARK IS 35.0 FT NORTH OF MHWL.                            STATION RECOVERY (1975)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1975 (RMB) REFERENCE MARK NO. 1 WAS RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION AS DESCRIBED.  THE STATION AND REFERENCE MARK NO. 2 DISKS HAVE BEEN REMOVED FROM THE PIPES.  THE PIPES ARE INTACT AND PROJECT 4 INCHES ABOVE GROUND.  A STEEL WITNESS POST, PROJECTING 1 FOOT ABOVE GROUND, WAS SET 14.2 FEET SSW OF THE STATION AND 28 FEET NNE OF THE HIGH WATER LINE AT THE LANDING ON THE SOUTHWEST SIDE OF THE ISLAND.  IT IS IN LINE WITH THE STATION AND REFERENCE MARK NO. 1.  THE DISTANCES FROM THE STATION AND THE REFERENCE MARKS CHECKED.  THE LONE COCONUT PALM TREE USED AS A WITNESS POINT WAS NOT FOUND.  THE TO REACH INSTRUCTIONS REMAIN THE SAME.
markers.setting: SET INTO TOP OF METAL PIPE DRIVEN INTO GROUND

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1965 (JJL) THE STATION IS LOCATED ON THE ROOF OF THE CONTROL TOWER FOR SAN JUAN INTERNATIONAL AIRPORT.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE MAIN FLOOR IN THE MAIN TERMINAL BUILDING, TAKE THE ELEVATOR TO THE 5TH FLOOR AND TURN RIGHT DOWN THE HALL TO A DOOR ON THE RIGHT.  PASS THROUGH THE DOOR AND GO UP THE STAIRS TO THE DOOR INTO THE CONTROL TOWER.  (PERMISSION TO ENTER THE CONTROL TOWER IS OBTAINED HERE FROM THE CONTROL TOWER MANAGER BY MEANS OF A SPEAKER BOX ON THE OUTSIDE OF THIS DOOR.) FROM INSIDE THE CONTROL TOWER, PASS THROUGH THE DOOR TO THE CATWALK THEN UP THE STEEL LADDER TO THE ROOF OF THE CONTROL TOWER AND THE STATION.  THE STATION MARK IS A STANDARD DISK, STAMPED INTERNATIONAL 1965, ATTACHED TO THE ROOF OF THE CONTROL TOWER BY MEANS OF SCREWS AND ROOFING TAR.  THERE WERE NO REFERENCE MARKS OR AZIMUTH MARK ESTABLISHED.                            STATION RECOVERY (1971)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1971 (JRH) THE STATION WAS NOT RECOVERED.  THE ROOF HAS BEEN RESURFACED AND THE MARK MAY HAVE BEEN BURIED UNDERNEATH.  AIRLINE DISTANCE AND DIRECTION FROM NEAREST TOWN AT INTERNATIONAL AIRPORT.

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1901 (JN) THIS STATION IS ON A HIGH POINT OF THE COAST ABOUT 3/4 MILE E OF THE TOWN OF ISABELA, BEARS N 78 DEG W, AND IS KNOWN LOCALLY AS POINT TUNA.  THIS IS ONE OF THE OLD SPANISH STATIONS WHICH WAS RECOVERED AND IS MARKED BY A 3-INCH IRON PIPE SET IN CEMENT.  THE TOP OF THE SURFACE MARK IS TRIANGULAR IN SHAPE AND MEASURES 34 INCHES ON A SIDE.  THE STATION IS MARKED BY THE HEAD OF A 20-PENNY NAIL IN THE CENTER OF THE PIPE.                            STATION RECOVERY (1922)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1922 THIS STATION IS ON A HIGH POINT ON THE COAST ABOUT 1.2 KILOMETERS E OF THE TOWN OF ISABELA.  IT IS ON THE MORE NORTHERLY OF THE TWO KNOLLS WHICH DROP OFF ABRUPTLY TO THE COAST, AND IS NEARER THE E SIDE OF THE TOP OF THE KNOLL.  THE U.S.C. AND G.S. MARK HAD BEEN DESTROYED BUT THE DRILL HOLE IN ROCK WAS FOUND AND APPEARED TO HAVE BEEN UNDISTURBED.  THE LARGE DRILL HOLE WAS FILLED WITH EARTH, THE IRREGULARITIES IN THE ROCK FILLED WITH CEMENT AND A NEW MARK SET IN THE SAME LOCATION AS THE OLD ONE.  THE STATION IS MARKED BY A STANDARD U.S.G.S. BRONZE BENCH MARK TABLET SET IN SOLID ROCK.  REFERENCE MARK NO.1, IS A COPPER NAIL AND WASHER DRIVEN INTO A BLAZE IN THE FORKS OF A TREE AT THE S EDGE OF A LINE OF BRUSH ON THE SLOPE OF THE HILL FACING THE OCEAN.  IT IS 52.32 METERS DISTANT FROM THE STATION ON A TRUE AZIMUTH OF 119 DEG 01 MIN 40 SEC.  REFERENCE MARK NO.2, IS A COPPER NAIL AND WASHER DRIVEN IN A LIVE STUMP ON THE E SLOPE OF THE HILL, 30.75 METERS DISTANT FROM THE STATION ON A TRUE AZIMUTH OF 234 DEG 42 MIN 44 SEC.  ELEVATION ABOVE SEA LEVEL IS - 81.1 METERS.                            STATION RECOVERY (1959)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1959 THE STATION WAS NOT RECOVERED.  IN ITS PLACE WAS FOUND ISABELA 2, DATED 1957, LOCATED ON A CONCRETE ROOF OF A HOUSE STANDING OVER THE ORIGINAL STATION.  THE HYDROGRAPHIC SURVEY PARTY DID NOT HAVE A DESCRIPTION OR POSITION OF ISABELA 2.
markers.setting: SET INTO TOP OF METAL PIPE DRIVEN INTO GROUND
markers.stability: MARK OF QUESTIONABLE OR UNKNOWN STABILITY

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JWC) THE STATION IS LOCATED 12 AIRLINE MILES NORTHEAST OF AGUADILLA, 1/2 AIRLINE MILE EAST OF ISABELA, 1/4 AIRLINE MILE SOUTH OF THE SHORE LINE AND ON THE ROOF OF MR. JOSE RODRIQUES HOUSE.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE PLAZA IN ISABELA, GO EAST ON A PAVED STREET FOR 0.55 MILE TO A SIDE ROAD LEFT.  TURN LEFT AND GO NORTHERLY ON A PAVED ROAD FOR 0.4 MILE TO A CROSSROAD.  CONTINUE STRAIGHT AHEAD AND GO NORTH AND WEST ON A TRACK ROAD FOR 0.1 MILE TO A SIDE ROAD RIGHT.  TURN RIGHT AND GO NORTH ON A TRACK ROAD FOR 100 YARDS TO THE FIRST HOUSE ON THE RIGHT AND THE STATION ON THE ROOF OF THE HOUSE.  THE STATION MARK IS AN IRON PEG CEMENTED TO THE ROOF OF THE HOUSE.  THE CONCRETE HAS ISABELA 2 1957 CARVED IN THE TOP AND IT PROJECTS 3-INCHES ABOVE THE ROOF SURFACE.  IT IS 11.9 FEET EAST OF THE WEST EDGE OF THE ROOF, 11.6 FEET WEST OF THE EAST EDGE OF THE ROOF AND 6.0 FEET NORTH OF THE SOUTH EDGE OF THE ROOF.  NO REFERENCE MARKS WERE ESTABLISHED.                            STATION RECOVERY (2004)  RECOVERY NOTE BY UNIVERSITY OF PUERTO RICO AT MAYAGUEZ 2004 (AAB) RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.

markers.stability: MAY HOLD, BUT OF TYPE COMMONLY SUBJECT TOSURFACE MOTION

markers.description: PTIVE TEXT AVAILABLE.

BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JWC) THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 4-1/2 MILES EAST-NORTHEAST OF AGUADILLA AND 3 MILES SOUTHWEST OF ISABELA.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE JUNCTION OF HIGHWAYS 2 AND 107 THAT IS 1.2 MILES NORTH OF AGUADILLA, GO EAST ON HIGHWAY 2 FOR 5.8 MILES TO THE STATION ON THE LEFT, NORTH, SIDE OF THE HIGHWAY.  THE MAST IS A STEEL-TRUSS STRUCTURE, PAINTED ALTERNATELY RED AND WHITE, SUPPORTED BY GUY WIRES AND IT HAS A REFLECTOR SCREEN ATOP.  THE MAST IS 384 FEET HIGH.  POINT INTERSECTED IS THE RED OBSTRUCTION LIGHT ATOP THE MAST.

BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JWC) THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 1/2 MILE WEST OF ISABELA.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE NORTHWEST CORNER OF THE PLAZA IN ISABELA, GO WEST FOR 1 BLOCK TO A CROSS STREET.  TURN LEFT AND GO SOUTH FOR 1 BLOCK TO A CROSS STREET.  TURN RIGHT AND GO WEST ON HIGHWAY 112 FOR 0.55 MILE TO THE STATION ON THE LEFT, SOUTH SIDE OF THE ROAD.  THE MAST IS A STEEL-TRUSS STRUCTURE, PAINTED ALTERNATELY RED AND WHITE IN COLOR AND IS SUPPORTED BY GUY WIRES.  THE MAST IS ABOUT 100 FEET HIGH.  THE POINT INTERSECTED WAS THE RED, OBSTRUCTION LIGHT ATOP.

BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1941 (RLS) THIS IS AN INTERSECTION STATION, LOCATED ON THE W SIDE OF MEDIO MUNDO PASSAGE, 0.6 MILE NNE FROM DRY DOCK AND ON THE TOP OF A SMALL MOUNT WHICH RISES 12 FEET ABOVE THE HIGH-WATER LEVEL.  IT IS ON A SANDY SPIT WHICH FORMS THE EASTERN EDGE OF AN EXTENSIVE MANGROVE AREA.  IT IS 0.6 MILE SW FROM PINERITA ISLAND, AND IS ON THE ONLY MOUND OF THIS SIZE IN THIS LOCALITY.  DREDGING AND FILLING OPERATIONS WILL PROBABLY CHANGE THE TOPOGRAPHY IN THIS AREA, AND FOR THIS REASON, NO REFERENCE MARKS WERE SET.  STATION IS MARKED BY A STANDARD BRONZE DISK SET IN CONCRETE, AS DESCRIBED IN NOTE 1A.  NO UNDERGROUND MARK WAS SET.                            STATION RECOVERY (1961)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1961 (MLO) STATION WAS RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED EXCEPT THAT THE MONUMENT NOW PROJECTS 8-INCHES ABOVE THE GROUND.  STATION IS 5.4 METERS EAST FROM THE CENTERLINE OF A ONE-LANE GRAVEL ROAD RUNNING TO PUNTA MEDIO MUNDO.  A STEEL PIPE TRIPOD AND CENTERPOLE WITH LEGS IMBEDDED IN CONCRETE IS CENTERED OVER THE MARK.                            STATION RECOVERY (1964)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1964 (GWM) THE STATION WAS FOUND AS DESCRIBED AND IS IN EXCELLENT CONDITION.  A 12 FOOT STEEL PIPE TRIPOD WAS BUILT OVER THIS STATION BY THE U.S. NAVY C.E.C.S.  THE ORIGINAL DESCRIPTION IS ADEQUATE.

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1967 (SCM) THE STATION IS LOCATED ON THE SOUTHWEST EDGE OF ROOSEVELT ROADS STATION ON CABRAS ISLAND.  TO REACH STATION FROM GATE NUMBER 1 OF ROOSEVELT ROADS NAVAL STATION, GO SOUTHEAST ON TARAWA DRIVE FOR 0.1 MILES TO A FORK.  TAKE THE LEFT FORK AND CONTINUE SOUTHEAST ON TARAWA DRIVE FOR 1.8 MILES TO A FORK.  TAKE THE LEFT FORK AND GO EAST ON FORRESTAL DRIVE FOR 0.7 MILES TO A FORK.  TAKE THE RIGHT FORK AND CONTINUE ON FORRESTAL DRIVE FOR 1.95 MILES TO A FORK.  TAKE THE RIGHT FORK AND GO SOUTHEAST ON A DIRT ROAD FOR 0.3 MILES TO A FORK.  TAKE THE LEFT FORK AND GO SOUTHWEST ON A DIRT ROAD FOR 0.4 MILES TO A SIDE ROAD LEFT.  CONTINUE STRAIGHT AHEAD FOR 0.2 MILES TO A SIDE ROAD LEFT.  CONTINUE STRAIGHT AHEAD AND DOWN HILL FOR 0.1 MILES TO OFFICERS BEACH ON THE LEFT.  CONTINUE STRAIGHT AHEAD FOR 0.1 MILES TO THE TOP OF HILL AND STATION ON THE RIGHT.  THE STATION IS A ONE INCH PIPE SET FLUSH IN THE CONCRETE FOUNDATION OF THE ISLA CABRAS LIGHT STRUCTURE.  THE STATION IS PLUMB WITH THE NAVIGATION LIGHT WHICH IS LOCATED ATOP A FOUR LEGGED SKELETON TOWER 45 FEET HIGH.  ON THE EAST AND SOUTH SIDES OF THE STRUCTURE ARE WHITE, RED, WHITE VERTICAL STRIPES FROM THE BASE OF THE TOWER TO THE TOP.  NO REFERENCE MARKS WERE SET.
markers.setting: SET IN A LARGE STRUCTURE WITH DEEP FOUNDATIONS

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1939 (HAC) SEE LIGHT LIST, U.S. LIGHTHOUSE SERVICE.                            STATION RECOVERY (1964)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1964 (GWM) ACCORDING TO THE LIGHT LIST, THIS LIGHT WAS BUILT IN A CONCRETE POST IN 1935 ON A WHITE POST AND HAS NOT BEEN MOVED SINCE.  THE LIGHT IS NOW ON A SKELETON TOWER SO STATION IS PRESUMED LOST.

BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JWC) THE STATION IS LOCATED 9 AIRLINE MILES EAST OF ARECIBO, 5 AIRLINE MILES NORTHWEST OF BARCELONETA AND ON THE TOP OF A LOW BRUSH COVERED KNOLL.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE INTERSECTION OF HIGHWAYS 2 AND 10 IN THE SOUTHEAST EDGE OF ARECIBO, GO EASTERLY ON HIGHWAY 2 FOR 0.7 MILE TO A FORK.  KEEP LEFT AND GO NORTHEAST ON A PAVED ROAD FOR 0.25 MILE TO A CROSSROAD.  CONTINUE STRAIGHT AHEAD AND GO NORTHEAST AND NORTH ON A PAVED ROAD FOR 0.8 MILE TO A FORK.  TURN RIGHT AND GO EAST ON HIGHWAY 681 FOR 7.3 MILES TO A SIDE ROAD RIGHT AT KILOMETER POST 11.5.  TURN RIGHT AND GO SOUTH AND EAST ON A TRACK ROAD FOR 0.2 MILE TO THE BASE OF THE SMALL KNOLL AND END OF TRUCK TRAVEL.  FROM HERE PACK EAST UP THE WEST SIDE OF THE KNOLL FOR ABOUT 100 YARDS TO THE TOP OF THE KNOLL AND THE STATION.  A 5 MINUTE PACK.  THE STATION MARK IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED ISLOTE 1966, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN OUTCROPPING CORAL ROCK WHICH PROJECTS 4 INCHES.  REFERENCE MARK 1 IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED ISLOTE NO 1 1966, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN OUTCROPPING CORAL ROCK WHICH PROJECTS 1 INCH.  REFERENCE MARK 2 IS A TRIANGULAR SHAPED MASS OF CONCRETE WITH AN IRON PEG SET IN THE TOP AND CENTER.  THERE IS NO STAMPING ON THE PEG.  NO AZIMUTH MARK WAS ESTABLISHED AT THIS STATION.                            STATION RECOVERY (2004)  RECOVERY NOTE BY UNIVERSITY OF PUERTO RICO AT MAYAGUEZ 2004 (JPR) MARK NOT FOUND.

markers.setting: SET IN THE ABUTMENT OR PIER OF A LARGE BRIDGE
markers.stability: PROBABLY HOLD POSITION/ELEVATION WELL

markers.description: BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1934 THIS STATION IS ON THE HIGHEST PEAK, ABOUT 2 KILOMETERS N OF THE BAJOS DE PATILLAS, BETWEEN PATILLAS AND MAUNABO.  IT IS ON THE HIGHEST HILL OF THE PEAK ON BARRIO JACABOA AND ON THE PROPERTY OF SENOR HIPOLITO ORTIZ.  STATION MARK IS A STANDARD U.S.G.S. BRONZE TABLET, STAMPED JACABOA-1934.  REFERENCE MARK NO.1 IS A LARGE NAIL ON TREE STUMP 13.63 FEET FROM STATION, IN TRUE AZIMUTH 284 DEG 10 MIN.  REFERENCE MARK NO.2 IS A LARGE NAIL ON TREE 12.23 FEET FROM STATION, IN TRUE AZIMUTH 350 DEG 31 MIN.  TO REACH THE STATION, FOLLOW THE PATILLAS-MAUNABO ROAD TO KILOMETER 116-H9, ON THE PLACE KNOWN AS BAJOS DE PATILLAS.  FROM HERE TAKE ROAD TO N FOR ABOUT 0.75 KILOMETER INLAND, THEN TAKE TRAIL ON FOOT FOR ABOUT 1.5 KILOMETER, LEADING TO THE BARRIO JACABOA WHERE THE STATION IS LOCATED.  STATION IS ON THE HIGHEST HILL REACHED BY FOLLOWING THIS ROAD.                            STATION RECOVERY (1938)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1938 THIS STATION WAS FOUND IN GOOD CONDITION, FLUSH WITH GROUND, AND COVERED WITH EARTH AND BITS OF STONE.  THE REFERENCE MARK NO. 1 WAS DESTROYED, BUT THE LOCATION WAS IDENTIFIABLE.  A NEW REFERENCE MARK CONSISTS OF A STANDARD TABLET STAMPED R.M. NO. 1 1941 AND AN ARROW POINTING TOWARD THE STATION, SET IN CONCRETE POST WAS ESTABLISHED.  IT IS 14.70 FT. WEST OF THE STATION.  THERE IS A 3 IN. GALVANIZED STEEL PIPE PROJECTING ABOUT 8 IN., 0.75 FT. NORTH OF THE STATION.  THE STATION IS ON THE HIGHEST PART OF THE PEAK, ABOUT 6 KM. WSW OF MAUNABO AND 2 KM. N OF BAJOS DE PATILLAS, WHICH IS COVERED WITH WOODS.  TO REACH FROM KM. 116 H9 OF THE MAUNABO-PATILLAS ROAD, TURN NORTH ON T-ROAD AND DRIVE ABOUT 0.75 KM. TO A ROCKY FORK.  GO FROM HERE ON FOOT, TAKING EITHER TRAIL.  THE ONE STRAIGHT AHEAD IS PROBABLY THE BETTER.  FOLLOW TRAIL UP ABOUT 1.5 KM. TO BARRIO JACABOA.  AFTER REACHING HIGHEST CULTIVATED FIELD, THERE IS NO TRAIL UNTIL ONE REACHES THE RIDGE (E.-W.), WHICH IS VERY SHARP.  FOLLOW TRAIL EASTWARD A SHORT DISTANCE AND LEAVE IT TO CLIMB HIGHEST PEAK TO STATION.

BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1926 (GCM) STATION IS IN THE VICINITY OF SANTA ISABEL, ON BEACH, 1/2 MILE E OF BARRIO POSTILLA.  THE BEACH IS LINED WITH UNDERBRUSH BEHIND THE STATION.  THE POINT IS MADE UP OF GRAVEL AND SAND AND IS FLAT.  THE ELEVATION OF THE MARK BEING NOT MORE THAN 1 FOOT.  STATION MARKED BY A 2-INCH PIPE SET IN CEMENT PROJECTING 4 INCHES ABOVE SURFACE OF CEMENT.  HEIGHT OF SIGNAL ABOVE STATION MARK - 3 METERS.                            STATION RECOVERY (1966)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JMC) SEARCHED FOR BUT NOT RECOVERED.  STATION SHOULD BE CONSIDERED LOST.  DESCRIPTION NOT ADEQUATE FOR RECOVERY.  EXTENSIVE CLEARING HAS BEEN DONE ALONG THE BEACH IN THIS AREA.
markers.setting: OBJECT SURROUNDED BY MASS OF CONCRETE
markers.stability: MARK OF QUESTIONABLE OR UNKNOWN STABILITY

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JWC) THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 3 MILES SOUTHEAST OF GUANICA, 7 MILES SOUTH-SOUTHWEST OF YAUCO AND ON A HILL ABOUT 1/2 MILE SOUTH OF HIGHWAY 333.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE NORTHWEST CORNER OF THE PLAZA IN GUANICA, GO WEST ON A PAVED STREET FOR 0.35 MILE TO ITS JUNCTION WITH HIGHWAY 116.  TURN RIGHT AND GO NORTHEAST ON HIGHWAY 116 FOR 0.25 MILE TO A SIDE ROAD ON THE RIGHT.  TURN SHARP RIGHT AND GO SOUTH AND EAST ON HIGHWAY 333, A PAVED ROAD FOR 4.15 MILES TO A SIDE ROAD ON THE RIGHT AND A SIGN SAN JACINTO BEACH RESTAURANT.  TURN RIGHT AND GO SOUTH ON A DIRT ROAD FOR 0.25 MILE TO A Y-FORK.  TAKE THE RIGHT FORK AND CONTINUE SOUTH ON A DIRT ROAD PASSING TO THE EAST SIDE OF THE SAN JACINTO BEACH RESTAURANT, UP A HILL FOR 0.25 MILE TO THE STATION ON THE HIGHEST POINT AT A CLEARED OFF AREA.  THE STATION MARK IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED JACINTO 1966, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A LARGE BOULDER THAT IS FLUSH WITH THE GROUND.  IT IS ON THE HIGHEST POINT OF THE HILL AND AT THE NORTH EDGE OF A CLEARED OFF AREA.  REFERENCE MARK 1 IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED JACINTO NO 1 1966, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A LARGE BOULDER THAT PROJECTS 1 FOOT AND IS 1 FOOT HIGHER IN ELEVATION THAN THE STATION MARK.  REFERENCE MARK 2 IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED JACINTO NO 2 1966, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN OUTCROPPING BEDROCK THAT IS FLUSH WITH THE SURFACE OF THE GROUND AND 1 FOOT LOWER IN ELEVATION THAN THE STATION MARK.  NO SUITABLE PLACE WAS FOUND FOR AN AZIMUTH MARK.                            STATION RECOVERY (1970)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1970 (KAM) THIS STATION, THE TRIANGULATION MARK, AND 2 REFERENCE MARKS, HAVE BEEN COMPLETELY DESTROYED BY BULLDOZING OPERATIONS PREPARING FOR HOUSE-BUILDING ON PRIVATE PROPERTY.  THE ROCK AND SOIL MATERIAL IN THE AREA OF THE MARKS HAS BEEN CUT APPROXIMATELY 6 FEET AND THE MATERIAL USED AS FILL IN ADJACENT AREAS.  THUS THERE WERE NO TRACES OF ANY OF THE MARKS AND NO HOPE OF FINDING ANY.  THE INTACT STATION HAD BEEN VISITED A WEEK PRIOR TO THE BULLDOZING SO IT IS DEFINITE THE STATION HAS BEEN DESTROYED.                            STATION RECOVERY (2004)  RECOVERY NOTE BY UNIVERSITY OF PUERTO RICO AT MAYAGUEZ 2004 (RCC) MARK NOT FOUND
markers.setting: SET IN A BOULDER
markers.stability: MAY HOLD, BUT OF TYPE COMMONLY SUBJECT TOSURFACE MOTION

markers.description: BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1934 STATION IS ON A PROMINENT WOODY PEAK SW OF SAN LORENZO AND AT A DIRECT DISTANCE OF ABOUT 8 KILOMETERS FROM THIS TOWN.  THE STATION IS ON BARRIO JAGUAL ON THE PEAK LOCALLY KNOWN AS CERRO GREGORIO, VERY EASILY DISTINGUISHED FROM ALL PARTS OF THE ROAD AROUND THIS REGION.  STATION MARK IS A CROSS MARK ON A FLAT STONE COVERED WITH LOOSE STONES TO PROTECT IT.  REFERENCE MARK NO.1 IS A BRASS NAIL WITH U.S.G.S. WASHER ON A 4-FOOT GUAVA TREE STUMP, 28 FEET FROM THE STATION ON A TRUE AZIMUTH OF 99 DEG 53 MIN.  REFERENCE MARK NO.2 IS A BRASS NAIL WITH U.S.G.S. WASHER ON THE RIGHT TRUNK OF A DOUBLE-TRUNKED BRANCHLESS GUAVA TREE ABOUT 12 FEET HIGH, 32 FEET 3.75 INCHES FROM THE STATION ON A TRUE AZIMUTH OF 158 DEG 07 MIN.  TO REACH THE STATION, DRIVE ON ROAD FROM SAN LORENZO TO PATILLAS TILL YOU GET TO KILOMETER H 7.  FROM HERE TAKE IMPROVED MUNICIPAL ROAD NAMED JAGUAL AND DRIVE TO THE W.  AT THIS TIME THE END OF THIS ROAD WAS AT A DISTANCE OF 2 KILOMETERS FROM THE SAN LORENZO-PATILLAS HIGHWAY.  FROM THE END OF THE JAGUAL ROAD TAKE TRAIL TO THE W LEADING FIRST TO THE FIELDS AT THE FOOT OF CERRO GREGORIO AND THEN A TRAIL LEADING TO THE TOP OF THE PEAK.                            STATION RECOVERY (1940)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1940 STATION RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED, A STANDARD TABLET STAMPED JAGUAL 1934 WAS SET AT CENTER OF CROSS.  IN DRILLING FOR THIS, THE ORIGINAL ROCK (WHICH WAS SMALL) WAS BROKEN.  HOWEVER, IT WAS CEMENTED TOGETHER.  A NEW REFERENCE MARK NO. 3 IS A NATURAL STONE IN PLACE IN THE FORM OF A SMOOTH PYRAMID, THE POINT OF WHICH IS 10.6 FT. NW OF STATION ON SLOPE.  R. M. NO. 4 IS NAIL IN STUMP OF 4 INCH GUAYABA TREE 14.48 FT. NE OF STATION.  TO REACH FROM SAN LORENZO, TAKE PATILLAS RD. TO K5 H9, AND TURN SHARP RIGHT, AT STORE ON JAGUAL RD.  AT END OF THIS RD. (2 KM.-1940) LEAVE CAR AND FOLLOW EXTENSION OF THIS ROAD, WHICH IS UNDER CONSTRUCTION, W ABOUT 1/2 KM.  FROM HERE TAKE OLD RD. DOWN TO AND ALONG CREEK, CROSSING SAME ABOUT 1 KM. FROM CAR.  THEN TAKE TRAIL, LEFT UP RIDGE TO STATION.
markers.setting: SET IN A BOULDER
markers.stability: MAY HOLD, BUT OF TYPE COMMONLY SUBJECT TOSURFACE MOTION

markers.description: PTIVE TEXT AVAILABLE.

BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1899 (WCH) STATION IS ON THE EASTERN END OF THE MOST W ONE OF THREE SMALL ISLANDS ABOUT 4 MILES E OF BERBERIA ISLAND.  STATION IS MARKED BY A BOX FILLED WITH CEMENT AND CONCH SHELLS.  THE BOX IS 2 FEET LONG, BY 6 BY 4 INCHES.  THE END OF A NAIL SUNK IN THE CEMENT AND PROJECTING ABOUT 1/2 INCH MARKS THE CENTER OF THE STATION.  A TRIPOD AND SCAFFOLD ABOUT 30 FEET HIGH WERE BUILT ABOVE THIS STATION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1926)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1926 (GCM) STATION SITE VISITED.  STATION NOT RECOVERED.  EASTERN SIDE OF JAUCA ISLAND HAD BEEN CHANGED AND DEBRIS AND SAND COVERED THAT SIDE.  NO REFERENCE MARKS WERE FOUND.  AN ATTEMPT WAS MADE TO RECOVER THE STATION AGAIN WHEN TRAVERSING FROM JAUCA 2, BUT THE ORIGINAL MARK COULD NOT BE FOUND.
markers.setting: OBJECT SURROUNDED BY MASS OF CONCRETE
markers.stability: MARK OF QUESTIONABLE OR UNKNOWN STABILITY

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1926 (GCM) STATION IS ON THE NORTHERN END OF THE WESTERN ONE OF THREE SMALL ISLANDS LYING 1 MILE S OF POINT PETRONA.  STATION IS MARKED BY A 2-INCH PIPE, 3 FEET LONG, EMBEDDED IN CONCRETE.  THE CENTER OF THE PIPE MARKS THE CENTER OF THE STATION AND PROJECTS 3 INCHES ABOVE THE SURFACE OF THE CONCRETE.  REFERENCE MARKS NOS.1 AND 2 ARE STANDARD BRONZE DISKS SET IN IRREGULAR MASSES OF CONCRETE.  HEIGHT OF SIGNAL ABOVE STATION MARK - 4 METERS.                            STATION RECOVERY (1966)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JJL) THE STATION MARK, REFERENCE MARK 1 AND REFERENCE MARK 2 WERE NOT RECOVERED.  A NEW STATION MARK, REFERENCE MARK 1 AND REFERENCE MARK 2 WERE ESTABLISHED IN THE SAME GENERAL AREA.  FOR THE NEW DESCRIPTION SEE JAUCA 3.  OFFICE NOTE--STATION IS DESTROYED.  (SEE G-16362)
markers.setting: SET IN TOP OF CONCRETE MONUMENT
markers.stability: MAY HOLD, BUT OF TYPE COMMONLY SUBJECT TOSURFACE MOTION

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JJL) THE STATION IS LOCATED ON THE NORTH SHORE OF THE WEST ONE OF THREE SMALL ISLANDS LOCALLY KNOWN AS CAYOS CABEZAZOS.  THE ISLAND IS LOCATED ABOUT 6-1/2 MILES SOUTHWEST OF SALINAS, 3-1/4 MILES SOUTH-SOUTHEAST OF SANTA ISABEL AND 1 MILE SOUTH OF POINT PETRONA.  A SMALL BOAT CAN BE LANDED ON THE BEACH AT THE STATION.  THE STATION MARK IS A STANDARD DISK, STAMPED JAUCA 3 1966, BRAZED TO THE TOP OF A 3-INCH DIAMETER CAST IRON PIPE THAT PROJECTS 3 INCHES.  REFERENCE MARK 1 IS A STANDARD DISK, STAMPED JAUCA 3 NO 1 1966, BRAZED TO THE TOP OF A 3-INCH DIAMETER CAST IRON PIPE THAT PROJECTS 2 INCHES.  REFERENCE MARK 2 IS A STANDARD DISK, STAMPED JAUCA 3 NO 2 1966, BRAZED TO THE TOP OF A 3-INCH DIAMETER CAST IRON PIPE THAT PROJECTS 3 INCHES.  THERE WAS NO SUITABLE LOCATION FOUND FOR AN AZIMUTH MARK.                            STATION RECOVERY (1975)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1975 (RMB) THE STATION MARK AND BOTH REFERENCE MARKS WERE RECOVERED.  THE DISKS ARE MISSING FROM THE STATION AND JAUCA 3 NO 1 1966, BUT THE STEEL PIPE, PROJECTING ABOUT 2 INCHES ABOVE GROUND, REMAINS.  ALL OF THE PIPES ARE FIRMLY IMPLANTED.  FROM THE SHORE IT IS APPROXIMATELY 15 FEET 9 INCHES TO THE STATION AND 13 FEET 6 INCHES TO JAUCA 3 NO 1 1966.  THE DISTANCES FROM THE STATION TO THE REFERENCE MARKS CHECKED.  THE REMAINDER OF THE DESCRIPTION, BY JJL IN 1966, REMAINS UNCHANGED.
markers.setting: SET INTO TOP OF METAL PIPE DRIVEN INTO GROUND
markers.stability: MARK OF QUESTIONABLE OR UNKNOWN STABILITY

markers.description: BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1934 STATION IS A CROSS ON BELFRY TOWER.

BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1982 (JLC) THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 9.5 KM (6 MI) NORTHEAST OF PONCE, 8 KM (5 MI) WEST-NORTHWEST OF THE SMALL TOWN OF JUANA  DIAZ, AND 0.75 KM (1/2 MI) NORTHEAST OF THE CERRILLOS DAM SITE.  THE STATION WILL BE UNDER WATER AT THE COMPLETION OF THE DAM.  OWNERSHIP--U.S. ARMY CORPS OF ENGINEERS.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE JUNCTION OF HIGHWAY 14 AND 139 ABOUT 4 KM (2.5 MI) NORTHEAST OF PONCE, GO NORTH ON HIGHWAY 139 FOR O.5 KM (0.3 MI) TO A CROSSROAD.  TURN RIGHT AND GO EAST AND NORTH OF A WINDING ROAD (HIGHWAY 139) FOR 3.1 KM (1.95 MI) TO A FORK.  TAKE THE RIGHT FORK AND CONTINUE AHEAD NORTHERLY ON HIGHWAY 139 FOR 3.7 KM (2.35 MI) TO A GATE ON THE LEFT AND THE CORPS OF ENGINEERS LABORATORY BUILDING ON THE LEFT. CONTINUE AHEAD NORTHERLY ON HIGHWAY 139 FOR 1.1 KM (0.7 MI) TO A DRIVEWAY ON THE LEFT AND THE END OF TRUCK TRAVEL. PACK NORTHWEST UP THE DRIVEWAY, PASSING THROUGH A YARD.  CONTINUE NORTHWEST UPHILL FOR 200 METERS TO THE STATION SITE ON HIGH GROUND.  THE STATION IS A STANDARD NGS DISK STAMPED---JERRY 1982---, SET INTO A ROCK OUTCROP.  IT IS LOCATED 9.9 METERS (32.5 FT) NORTHEAST FROM A POWER POLE, 0.85 METER (2.8 FT) SOUTH FROM A FENCE LINE, AND 1.5 METERS (5.0 FT) SOUTHEAST FROM A ROCK LEDGE.  REFERENCE MARK NUMBER 1 IS A STANDARD NGS DISK STAMPED ---JERRY NO 1 1982---, SET INTO THE TOP OF A PARTIALLY EXPOSED BOULDER OF 1 METERS LARGEST DIMENSION.  IT IS LOCATED 21.84 METERS (72.0 FT) EAST FROM A POWER POLE AND 2.0 METERS (6.1 FT) SOUTH FROM A FENCE LINE.  MARK IS ABOVE STATION 2.5 METERS.  REFERENCE MARK NUMBER 2 IS A STANDARD NGS DISK STAMPED ---JERRY NO 2 1982---, SET INTO A ROCK OUTCROP.  IT IS LOCATED 10.47 METERS (34.3 FT) WEST-NORTHWEST FROM A POWER POLE AND 0.39 METER (1.3 FT) SOUTH FROM AN OLD FENCE LINE.  MARK IS BELOW STATION 1.0 METERS.  HEIGHT OF LIGHT SHOWN ABOVE THE MARK WAS 1.4 METERS.  NO MEASUREMENT BETWEEN REFERENCE MARKS DUE TO ROUGH TERRAIN AND TREES.
markers.setting: SET IN ROCK OUTCROP
markers.stability: MOST RELIABLE AND EXPECTED TO HOLDPOSITION/ELEVATION WELL

markers.description: BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1922 THIS STATION IS ABOUT 7.5 KILOMETERS NE BY ROAD FROM AGUADILLA, AND IS ON TOP OF THE MOST EASTERLY OF THREE SHARP PEAKS IN THE FIRST RANGE S OF THE CARRETERA.  IT IS 1.4 KILOMETERS DISTANT AND BEARS S 26 DEG 34 MIN E OF THE CARRETERA AT A POINT WHERE A CHIMNEY AND RUINS OF AN OLD CANE MILL STANDS ON THE N SIDE OF THE ROAD.  IT IS ON THE N ONE OF A DOUBLE CONE-SHAPED HILL OWNED BY MANOLA JIMINEZ.  THE HILL IS COVERED WITH A GROWTH OF SCRUB BRUSH EXCEPT FOR A SMALL AREA ON THE S SLOPE WHICH IS UNDER CULTIVATION.  THE W SLOPE IS VERY STEEP AND ROCKY.  THE STATION MARK IS A STANDARD U.S.G.S. BRONZE BENCH MARK TABLET CEMENTED IN A PROJECTING LIMESTONE ROCK ON THE HIGHEST PART OF THE HILL.  REFERENCE MARK NO.1 IS A DRILL HOLE IN LIMESTONE RIMROCK AT THE S POINT OF THE HILL, 18.55 METERS DISTANT ON A TRUE AZIMUTH OF 13 DEG 26 MIN 47 SEC.  REFERENCE MARK NO.2, IS A DRILL HOLE IN RIMROCK ON THE E EDGE OF THE HILL, 7.48 METERS DISTANT ON A TRUE AZIMUTH OF 275 DEG 40 MIN 51 SEC.  ELEVATION ABOVE SEA LEVEL IS - 222.2 METERS.                            STATION RECOVERY (1956)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1956 (EAT) THE STATION MARK WAS RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED BY THE U.S.G.S. DESCRIPTION AND IS ADEQUATE.
markers.setting: SET IN ROCK OUTCROP
markers.stability: MOST RELIABLE AND EXPECTED TO HOLDPOSITION/ELEVATION WELL

markers.description: BY RLDA SURVEYING AND MAPPING 2010 (RLD) THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 7.4 MI (11.9 KM) NORTHWEST OF COTO LAUREL, 7.0 MI (11.3 KM) SOUTHEAST OF ADJUNTAS, 6.0 MI (9.7 KM) NORTH OF PONCE AND 5.8 MI (9.3 KM) NORTHEAST OF PENUELAS, PUERTO RICO.   TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE INTERSECTION OF PR-503 AND PR-10 5.7 MI (9.2 KM) NORTH OF PONCE, GO NORTHWEST ON PR-10 FOR 0.4 MI (0.6 KM) TO THE STATION ON THE LEFT.   THE STATION IS 15.45 M (50.7 FT) NORTH OF A GROUP OF 3 TREES, 14.57 M (47.8 FT) WEST OF THE CENTERLINE OF PR-10 AND 3.40 M (11.2 FT) SOUTHWEST OF THE NORTH END OF A METAL GUARD RAIL.
markers.setting: SET IN ROCK OUTCROP
markers.stability: MOST RELIABLE AND EXPECTED TO HOLDPOSITION/ELEVATION WELL

markers.description: BY RLDA SURVEYING AND MAPPING 2010 (RLD) THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 13.1 MI (21.1 KM) SOUTHEAST OF LAS MARIAS, 8.3 MI (13.4 KM) SOUTHEAST OF LARES, 7.2 MI (11.6 KM) SOUTHWEST OF UTUADO AND 5.5 MI (8.8 KM) NORTHWEST OF ADJUNTAS.   TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE INTERSECTION OF PR-526 AND PR-129 6.0 MI (9.7 KM) NORTHWEST OF ADJUNTAS, GO SOUTHERLY ON PR-129 FOR 0.8 MI (1.3 KM) TO THE STATION ON THE LEFT.   THE STATION IS 33.54 M (110.0 FT) EAST OF A POWER POLE, 22.61 M (74.2 FT) NORTHEAST OF A POWER POLE AND 8.43 M (27.7 FT) NORTHEAST OF THE CENTERLINE OF PR-129.
markers.setting: SET IN ROCK OUTCROP
markers.stability: MOST RELIABLE AND EXPECTED TO HOLDPOSITION/ELEVATION WELL

markers.description: BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1934 STATION IS SITUATED ON A LIMESTONE HILL BELONGING TO DIFFERENT RANGES ON HIGH PLATEAU W OF ARECIBO-UTUADO ROAD, AT KILOMETER 65.  HILL IS POINTED AND BARE.  IT IS ABOUT 500 METERS W OF JOBOS MUNICIPAL ROAD, AND ABOUT 1000 METERS N OF JOBOS RIVER.  LAND BELONGS TO MANUEL HERRARA, OF BO. JOBOS OF UTUADO.  REFERENCE MARK NO.1 IS A CROSS ON A ROCKY OUTGROWTH TO S, 2.35 METERS FROM STATION IN TRUE AZIMUTH 49 DEG 58 MIN.  REFERENCE MARK NO.2 IS A STANDARD TABLET CEMENTED ON A NATURAL ROCK TO N, 2.15 METERS FROM STATION IN TRUE AZIMUTH 109 DEG 02 MIN.  TO REACH STATION TAKE THE JOBOS MUNICIPAL ROAD AT KILOMETER 65 H 2 OF THE ARECIBO-UTUADO ROAD, FOLLOW IT UPHILL 2.75 MILES TO FARMHOUSE OF MANUEL HERRARA SITUATED ON BO. JOBOS.  FROM THERE CONTINUE W ALONG VALLEY OF THE RIVER ABOUT 200 METERS TO ENTRANCE OF A DEEP VALLEY THAT RUNS N AND S.  FOLLOW THIS VALLEY PASSING NEAR TWO SWAMPS, THE WATER RESERVOIR OF THE FARM, AND AFTER CROSSING TO DRAIN DITCHES ABOVE POLES, CLIMB TO NEARLY 800 METERS, ABOUT 15 MINUTES, IN AN E DIRECTION.  AFTER PASSING FIRST RIDGE THE NEXT HILL IS REACHED ON WHICH STATION IS LOCATED.                            STATION RECOVERY (1941)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1941 (GBG) THIS STATION IS SITUATED IN THE BARRIO JOBOS OF UTUADO.  AND IS ON THE TOP OF A SHARP, HIGH, ROCKY PEAK, ABOUT TWO KILOMETERS W OF THE DOS BOCAS DAM, AND ABOUT 1-1/2 KILOMETERS N OF THE RANGER STATION OF THE JOBOS NATIONAL FOREST.  LAND IS OWNED BY MANUEL HERRERA.  THE STATION IS A STANDARD TABLET STAMPED JOBO 1934, CEMENTED TO ROCK AT THE SUMMIT.  SEVERAL LOOSE BOULDERS ARE PILED AROUND IT.  REFERENCE MARK 1 IS A CHISELED CROSS ON ROCK LEDGE 2.35 METERS FROM THE STATION IN AZIMUTH 49 DEG 58 MIN.  REFERENCE MARK 2 IS A STANDARD REFERENCE MARK CEMENTED TO ROCK LEDGE 2.15 METERS FROM STATION IN AZIMUTH 109 DEG 02 MIN.  TO REACH FROM ARECIBO, GO S ON THE ROAD TO DOS BOCAS AND UTUADO NEARLY TO DOS BOCAS DAM.  TURN RIGHT ON THE JOBOS ROAD AT KM. 65.22.  AND GO UP HILL FOR 2.75 MILES TO A CONCRETE BRIDGE JUST BELOW RANGER STATION.  AT W END OF BRIDGE TURN RIGHT.  AND PARK CAR AT THE LAST FOREST SERVICE BUILDING 200 METERS BEYOND.  TAKE TRAIL PAST N CORNER OF HOUSE, GOING N UP VALLEY, PAST SMALL RESERVOIR.  CONTINUE ON MAIN TRAIL, CIRCLING AROUND W EDGE OF A LARGE, ROUND MOUND, IN A FLAT, OPEN VALLEY, AND TO THE SADDLE AT N END OF THIS VALLEY.  IN THE PLATANO PATCH THERE IS A DIM TRAIL TO RIGHT, WHICH SKIRTS BOTTOM OF BLUFF AND WORKS UP TO A SADDLE.  HERE TURN SHARP RIGHT ON DIM TRAIL.  AND WORK UP TO A SECOND SADDLE.  HERE BEAR LEFT, AND GO ABOUT 20 METERS TO ANOTHER SADDLE.  BEAR TO RIGHT HERE ON DIM TRAIL AT BRIM OF HIGH ESCARPMENT.  JUST BEFORE REACHING NEXT CREST, TURN LEFT UP VERY STEEP HILL TO THE STATION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1966)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JJL) THE STATION MARK AND REFERENCE MARK 2 WERE FOUND AND IN GOOD CONDITION.  REFERENCE MARK 1 WAS NOT FOUND.  A REFERENCE MARK 3 WAS ESTABLISHED AT THIS DATE.  A NEW DESCRIPTION FOLLOWS--  THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 11 MILES SOUTH-SOUTHEAST OF ARECIBO.  5 MILES NORTH-NORTHEAST OF UTUADO, 1-1/2 MILES WEST OF THE DOS BOCAS DAM AND ON A HIGH, SHARP AND ROCKY PEAK.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE JUNCTION OF HIGHWAY 2 AND 10 IN THE EAST PART OF ARECIBO, GO SOUTH ON HIGHWAY 10 FOR 11.05 MILES TO THE JUNCTION WITH HIGHWAY 621.  TURN RIGHT AND GO WEST ON HIGHWAY 621 FOR 2.9 MILES TO CAMP CROZIER ON THE RIGHT.  CONTINUE WEST ON HIGHWAY 621 FOR 0.5 MILE TO A SIDE ROAD ON THE RIGHT. TURN RIGHT AND GO NORTH ON A TRACK ROAD FOR 0.4 MILE TO A GATE. PASS THROUGH THE GATE AND CONTINUE NORTH ON THE TRACK ROAD FOR 0.1 MILE TO A DIM TRACK ROAD ON THE RIGHT.  TURN RIGHT AND GO EAST ON THE TRACK ROAD FOR 0.2 MILE TO A GATE.  PASS THROUGH THE GATE AND CONTINUE EAST ON THE TRACK ROAD FOR 0.1 MILE TO A REVERSE Y FORK.  TURN SHARP RIGHT AND GO SOUTHWEST, USING A 4-WHEEL DRIVE VEHICLE, ON A NARROW ROAD FOR 0.1 MILE TO A DIM TRAIL ON THE LEFT AND THE END OF TRUCK TRAVEL.  AT THIS POINT THERE IS A LARGE ROCK CLIFF ON THE SOUTH SIDE OF THE NARROW ROAD.  PACK SOUTH ALONG THE LEFT SIDE OF THE CLIFF THEN SOUTHEAST AND SOUTH UP A STEEP HILL FOR 20 MINUTES TO THE STATION ON THE HIGHEST POINT OF THE HILL.  THE STATION MARK IS A U.S. GEOLOGICAL SURVEY BENCH MARK DISK STAMPED JOBO 1934, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A LARGE BOULDER THAT PROJECTS 3 FEET ON THE SOUTHEAST SIDE.  NOTE--DESC.  REFERENCE MARK 2 IS A U.S. GEOLOGICAL SURVEY REFERENCE MARK DISK STAMPED NO 2, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A BOULDER THAT PROJECTS 8 INCHES.  IT IS 2 FEET LOWER IN ELEVATION THAN THE STATION MARK.  NOTE--DESC.  REFERENCE MARK 3 IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED JOBO 1934 1966 NO 3, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A BOULDER THAT PROJECTS 6 INCHES.  IT IS 2 FEET LOWER IN ELEVATION THAN THE STATION MARK.  NOTE--12C  NO SUITABLE PLACE WAS FOUND FOR AN AZIMUTH MARK.  AIRLINE DISTANCE AND DIRECTION FROM NEAREST TOWN 5 MILES NORTH-NORTHEAST OF UTUADO.                            STATION RECOVERY (1972)  RECOVERY NOTE BY THOMAS ENG AND SURV 1972 (HBW) JOBOS UNDISTURBED.  JOBOS RM 2 UNDISTURBED.  JOBOS RM 3 UNDISTURBED. markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JWC) THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 7 MILES SOUTHEAST OF PARGUERA, 3-1/2 MILES SOUTH-SOUTHWEST OF ENSENADA AND ABOUT 100 YARDS NORTH OF THE HIGHEST POINT OF A ROCKY, BRUSH COVERED POINT OF LAND LOCALLY KNOWN AS POINT JOROBADO.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE POST OFFICE IN ENSENADA, GO SOUTHWEST AND WEST ON THE PAVED ROAD, PASSING A SUGAR MILL ON THE LEFT, FOR 3.7 MILES TO A RESTAURANT ON THE RIGHT IN CALLOTA SALINAS.  GO SOUTH AND SOUTHEAST ON THE PAVED ROAD FOR 0.2 MILE TO A SIDE ROAD RIGHT AFTER PASSING A LARGE STONE WALL SURROUNDING A HOUSE ON THE LEFT.  TURN RIGHT AND FOLLOW THE PAVED ROAD, SOUTH, FOR 0.05 MILE TO THE END OF THE PAVEMENT AT THE BASE OF A LOW BRUSH COVERED HILL.  CONTINUE SOUTH AND WEST ON THE DIRT ROAD FOR 0.1 MILE TO THE CREST OF A LOW RIDGE AND THE STATION ON THE LEFT.  THE STATION MARK IS A STANDARD DISK, STAMPED JOROBADO 1966, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN BEDROCK THAT IS FLUSH WITH THE SURFACE OF THE GROUND.  REFERENCE MARK 1 IS A STANDARD DISK, STAMPED JOROBADO NO 1 1966, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN BEDROCK THAT IS FLUSH WITH THE SURFACE OF THE GROUND.  REFERENCE MARK 2 IS A STANDARD DISK, STAMPED JOROBADO NO 2 1966, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN BEDROCK THAT IS FLUSH WITH THE SURFACE OF THE GROUND.  AN AZIMUTH MARK WAS NOT ESTABLISHED.                            STATION RECOVERY (1968)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1968 (JKW) STATION MARK AND REFERENCE MARKS NO. 1 AND 2 WERE RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 1 HAS BEEN BATTERED BUT IS STILL TIGHT IN THE DRILL HOLE.  THE ORIGINAL DESCRIPTION IS ADEQUATE WITH THE FOLLOWING ADDITIONS--  STATION MARK IS 48 FEET SOUTHERLY OF THE CENTERLINE OF A DIRT ROAD AND 45 FEET SOUTHERLY OF A LARGE TREE STUMP AT THE SOUTHERLY EDGE OF THE DIRT ROAD.  THE DIRT ROAD AT THE END OF THE PAVEMENT IS VERY STEEP AND TRAVERSES ALMOST STRAIGHT UP THE RIDGE, A FOUR WHEEL DRIVE VEHICLE WOULD BE NECESSARY TO TRAVEL THIS ROAD.  THE STATION IS ABOUT 300 FEET UP THE DIRT ROAD FROM THE PAVEMENT.                            STATION RECOVERY (1970)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1970 (KAM) THE DESCRIPTION TO THE STATION AREA IS ADEQUATE.  THE TRIANGULATION MARK WAS RECOVERED IN FAIR CONDITION.  IT HAS BEEN DENTED AND CHIPPED BUT IS STILL READABLE.  R.M. NO. 2 WAS RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION WITH CORRECT DIRECTION AND DISTANCE FROM TRIANGULATION MARK.  R.M. NO. 1 WAS LOCATED WITH THE DISK BEING BROKEN OFF AND LOST.  TH STEM OF THE MARK REMAINS FIRMLY SECURED IN ROCK WITH CORRECT DIRECTION AND DISTANCE FROM TRIANGULATION MARK.                            STATION RECOVERY (1971)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1971 (EKM) THE STATION WAS RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED.

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1941 (RLS) STATION IS ON THE ROOSEVELT ROADS NAVAL RESERVATION, ON THE E SIDE OF ENSENADA HONDA, ON THE NORTHWESTERLY OF 3 ISLANDS CONNECTED TO EACH OTHER AND TO THE MAINLAND BY MANGROVE SWAMPS FORMING A POINT CALLED CABRA DE TIERRA, NEAR THE S EDGE OF THE NEARLY FLAT TOP OF THE HILL, AND 26.2 METERS S OF THE S CORNER OF A SMALL HOUSE ON TOP OF THE HILL.  STATION IS MARKED WITH A STANDARD BRONZE DISK, SET IN A CONCRETE BLOCK PROJECTING ABOUT 2 INCHES ABOVE THE GROUND.  THIS MARK IS LOCATED IN AN AREA WHERE EXTENSIVE BUILDING OPERATIONS ARE PLANNED, AND IT IS PROBABLE THAT THE WHOLE HILLTOP MAY BE GRADED OFF.  THE LINE KID - CAMP IS AT RIGHT ANGLES TO THE CENTER LINE OF THE DRY DOCK.  THIS LINE WAS USED AS A BASIC AZIMUTH IN THE LOCATION OF BUILDINGS, ROADS, PIERS, AND PIER-HEAD LINES ON THIS PROJECT.  NO UNDERGROUND MARK.
markers.setting: SET IN TOP OF CONCRETE MONUMENT
markers.stability: MAY HOLD, BUT OF TYPE COMMONLY SUBJECT TOSURFACE MOTION

markers.description: BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1982 (JCL) THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 8 KM (5 MI) NORTH-NORTHEAST OF PONCE AND 0.1 KM (0.05 MI) NORTH OF THE WEST END OF THE PROPOSED CERRILLOS DAM. OWNERSHIP--U.S. ARMY CORPS OF ENGINEERS.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE JUNCTION OF HIGHWAYS 14 AND 139 ABOUT 4 KM (2-1/2 MI) NORTHEAST OF PONCE, GO NORTHWEST ON HIGHWAY 139 FOR 0.5 KM (0.3 MI) TO A CROSS STREET AT JUNCTION OF HIGHWAY 505.  TURN RIGHT AND GO NORTHEAST ON HIGHWAY 139 FOR 3.1 KM (1.95 MI) TO A FORK.  KEEP RIGHT FORK DOWN GRADE ON HIGHWAY 139 FOR 3.5 KM (2.2 MI) TO THE CORPS OF ENGINEERS LABORATORY ON  THE LEFT. CONTINUE AHEAD FOR 0.8 KM (0.5 MI) TO A REVERSE FORK LEFT, JUST PAST A PIPE AND CONCRETE BRIDGE. TURN SHARP LEFT ON PAVED ROAD (OLD HIGHWAY) FOR 0.2 KM (0.1 MI) TO A REVERSE FORK RIGHT, TURN SHARP RIGHT UP STEEP GRADE ON DIRT ROAD FOR 0.2 KM (0.1 MI) TO A REVERSE FORK LEFT. CONTINUE AHEAD AROUND CURVE TO RIGHT UP A VERY STEEP GRADE FOR 0.08 KM (0.05 MI) TO THE STATION ON THE RIGHT ON A LOW BANK, OPPOSITE  A ROCK WALL ON THE LEFT.  THE STATION IS A STANDARD NGS DISK STAMPED---KLAUS 1982---, EPOXIED TO THE TOP OF A 1/2 INCH STEEL ROD DRIVEN 2.2 METERS INTO THE GROUND, SURRONDED BY A CONCRETE FILLED PLASTIC TILE 25 CM IN DIAMETER AND PROJECTING 8 CM ABOVE THE GROUND.  IT IS LOCATED 5.5 METERS (18 FT) WEST FROM THE CENTER OF THE ROAD AND 1.5 METERS (5 FT) ABOVE THE ROAD.  REFERENCE MARK NUMBER 1 IS A STANDARD NGS DISK STAMPED ---KLAUS NO 1 1982---, EPOXIED TO THE TOP OF A 1/2 INCH STEEL ROD DRIVEN 2.8 METERS TO ROCK, SURROUNDED BY A CONCRETE FILLED PLASTIC TILE 25 CM IN DIAMETER, AND PROJECTING 8 CM ABOVE THE GROUND.  IT IS LOCATED 4.0 METERS (13 FT) EAST FROM THE CENTER OF THE ROAD AND 3 FEET ABOVE THE ROAD.  MARK IS BELOW STATION 1.5 METERS.  HEIGHT OF LIGHT SHOWN ABOVE THE MARK WAS 1.5 METERS.  NO REFERENCE MARK 2 WAS SET FOR THIS STATION.  NO AZIMUTH MARK SET, HOWEVER TRIANGULATION STATION FRANK IS ABOUT 1 KM AWAY.
markers.setting: METAL ROD DRIVEN INTO GROUND. SEE TEXT FOR ADDITIONAL
markers.stability: MARK OF QUESTIONABLE OR UNKNOWN STABILITY

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JJL) THE STATION IS LOCATED 9 AIRLINE MILES NORTH OF COAMO, 4-1/2 AIRLINE MILES SOUTH OF ORCOVIS, 5 AIRLINE MILES WEST OF BARRANQUITAS AND ON THE TOP OF A HIGH RIDGE.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE PLAZA IN BARRANQUITAS, GO SOUTHERLY ON HIGHWAY 162 FOR 1.8 MILES TO HIGHWAY 143.  TURN RIGHT AND GO WESTERLY ON HIGHWAY 143 FOR 4.2 MILES TO A FORK.  KEEP LEFT AND GO SOUTHWEST ON HIGHWAY 143 FOR 0.75 MILE TO A SIDE ROAD RIGHT AT KILOMETER POST 7.4.  TURN RIGHT AND GO NORTH ON A BLADED ROAD FOR 0.05 MILE TO A T-INTERSECTION AT SEVERAL BUILDINGS.  TURN LEFT AND GO WEST ON A BLADED ROAD FOR 0.05 MILE TO A SIDE ROAD RIGHT AT A SMALL STORE.  TURN RIGHT AND GO NORTHERLY ON A BLADED ROAD FOR 0.15 MILE TO A FORK. KEEP RIGHT AND GO NORTHERLY ON A BLADED ROAD FOR 0.2 MILE TO A FORK.  KEEP LEFT AND GO NORTHWEST ON A BLADED ROAD FOR 0.15 MILE TO A FORK.  KEEP LEFT AND GO NORTHWEST ON A BLADED ROAD FOR 0.15 MILE TO A FORK.  (THE AZIMUTH MARK IS LOCATED 0.05 MILE SOUTHWEST OF THIS POINT).  KEEP RIGHT AND GO WESTERLY ON A BLADED ROAD FOR 0.2 MILE TO A FORK, KEEP LEFT AND GO WEST, SOUTH AND WEST ON A WINDING BLADED ROAD FOR 0.4 MILE TO THE TOP OF THE RIDGE AND THE STATION.  THE STATION MARK IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED KNIFE 1966, SET IN THE TOP OF A 10-INCH SQUARE CONCRETE MONUMENT PROJECTING 1 INCH.  IT IS 62 FEET SOUTHWEST OF A FENCE LINE.  REFERENCE MARK 1 IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED KNIFE NO 1 1966, SET IN THE TOP OF A 10-INCH SQUARE CONCRETE MONUMENT WHICH IS FLUSH WITH THE SURFACE.  IT IS 38 FEET SOUTHWEST OF THE FENCE LINE.  REFERENCE MARK 2 IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED KNIFE NO 2 1966, SET IN THE TOP OF A 10-INCH SQUARE CONCRETE MONUMENT WHICH IS FLUSH WITH THE SURFACE.  IT IS 57 FEET SOUTHWEST OF THE FENCE LINE.  THE AZIMUTH MARK IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED KNIFE 1966, SET IN THE TOP OF A 10-INCH SQUARE CONCRETE MONUMENT PROJECTING 1 INCH.  IT IS 7 FEET WEST OF A SMALL BUILDING AND 7 FEET SOUTH OF THE CENTER OF A TRACK ROAD.

TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE INTERSECTION OF PR-135 AND PR-129 1.2 MI (1.9 KM) NORTHEAST OF GUAYABO DULCE, GO NORTHERLY ON PR-129 FOR 2.2 MI (3.5 KM) TO THE STATION ON THE RIGHT. TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE INTERSECTION OF PR-111 AND PR-10 1.1 MI (1.8 KM) WEST OF UTUADO, GO NORTHERLY ON PR-10 FOR 0.9 MI (1.4 KM) TO THE STATION ON THE LEFT IN THE GRASS MEDIAN IN FRONT OF A PUMA GAS STATION.   THE STATION IS 59.55 M (195.4 FT) NORTH OF A POWER POLE, 38.8 M (127.3 FT) SOUTH OF KM POST 60.7, 15.78 M (51.8 FT) EAST OF THE CONCRETE EDGE OF GRASSY MEDIAN AND 9.278 M (30.4 FT) WEST OF THE CENTERLINE OF PR-10.
