markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1965 (JJL) THE STATION IS LOCATED 1-1/2 AIRLINE MILES NORTHWEST OF LUQUILLO, ABOUT 50 YARDS SOUTH OF THE SHORE LINE AND ON A POINT OF LAND WHICH IS LOCALLY KNOWN AS PUNTA LA BANDERA.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE NORTHWEST CORNER OF THE PLAZA IN LUQUILLO, GO WEST ON CARR EST STREET FOR 0.3 MILE TO A SIDE ROAD LEFT AT A CEMETARY.  CONTINUE WEST ON A PAVED ROAD FOR 0.2 MILE TO A SIDE ROAD RIGHT.  TURN RIGHT AND GO NORTH ON A PAVED ROAD FOR 0.55 MILE TO THE END OF THE ROAD AT A BEACH.  BEAR RIGHT ON TO THE BEACH AND GO NORTH AND WEST FOR 0.1 MILE TO THE STATION ON THE LEFT.  A 4 WHEEL DRIVE VEHICLE IS REQUIRED FOR THE LAST 0.1 MILE.  THE STATION MARK IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED LA BANDERA 1965, SET IN THE TOP OF A 12-INCH ROUND CONCRETE MONUMENT PROJECTING 4 INCHES.  IT IS 20 FEET NORTHEAST OF A COCONUT TREE WITH THREE NOTCHES.  REFERENCE MARK 1 IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED LA BANDERA NO 1 1965, SET IN THE TOP OF A 12-INCH ROUND CONCRETE MONUMENT PROJECTING 3 INCHES.  IT IS 20 FEET EAST OF THE COCONUT TREE WITH THREE NOTCHES.  REFERENCE MARK 2 IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED LA BANDERA NO 2 1965, SET IN THE TOP OF A 12-INCH ROUND CONCRETE MONUMENT PROJECTING 2 INCHES.  IT IS 18 FEET WEST OF THE COCONUT TREE WITH THREE NOTCHES.  NO AZIMUTH MARK WAS ESTABLISHED AT THIS STATION.
markers.setting: SET IN TOP OF CONCRETE MONUMENT
markers.stability: MAY HOLD, BUT OF TYPE COMMONLY SUBJECT TOSURFACE MOTION

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JJL) THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 8 MILES EAST OF GUAYANILLA, 5 MILES WEST OF PONCE AND ON THE HIGHEST POINT OF A PROMINENT, BRUSHY RIDGE.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE JUNCTION OF HIGHWAYS 10 AND 132 ON THE WEST SIDE OF PONCE, GO WEST ON HIGHWAY 132 FOR 0.4 MILE TO A CROSSROAD AND A LARGE, YELLOW BUILDING IN THE SOUTHWEST ANGLE OF THE INTERSECTION.  TURN LEFT AND GO SOUTH FOR 0.4 MILE TO A SIDE ROAD RIGHT.  TURN RIGHT AND GO SOUTHWEST AND WEST FOR 2.0 MILES TO A Y-FORK.  TAKE THE LEFT FORK FOR ABOUT 20 FEET TO A DIM Y-FORK.  TAKE THE LEFT FORK AND GO SOUTHWEST AND WEST ON A TRACK ROAD FOR 1.2 MILES TO THE END OF THE ROAD AND THE END OF TRUCK TRAVEL.  PACK SOUTH, SOUTHWEST AND WEST ALONG A DIM TRAIL FOR ABOUT 0.2 MILE TO THE HIGHEST POINT OF THE RIDGE AND THE STATION.  A 1/4 HOUR PACK.  THE STATION MARK IS A CENTER-PUNCHED, 1/2-INCH STEEL ROD SET IN THE TOP OF AN IRREGULAR MASS OF CONCRETE THAT PROJECTS 1 INCH.  LA LETRA 1961 IS INSCRIBED IN THE CONCRETE.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 1, STAMPED ETRA PRS NO 1 1966, IS A STANDARD DISK BRAZED TO THE TOP OF A 3-INCH CAST IRON PIPE THAT PROJECTS 6 INCHES.  REFERENCE MARK NO.2, STAMPED ETRA PRS NO 2 1966, IS A STANDARD DISK BRAZED TO THE TOP OF A 3-INCH CAST IRON PIPE THAT PROJECTS 6 INCHES.  IT IS 1/2 FOOT NORTH OF A FENCE.  NO SUITABLE LOCATION FOR AN AZIMUTH MARK.
markers.setting: OBJECT SURROUNDED BY MASS OF CONCRETE
markers.stability: MARK OF QUESTIONABLE OR UNKNOWN STABILITY

markers.description: BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1934 STATION LOCATED 8 KILOMETERS BY ROAD AND TRAIL NE OF JUANA DIAZ, ON THE PROMINENT, CRAGGY MOUNTAIN TO THE N OF THE ATLANTIC ORE COMPANY, MANGANESE MINE.  THESE ROUGH CRAGGY PEAKS ARE VERY NOTICEABLE FROM THE SURROUNDING COUNTRY AND ARE KNOWN BY THE LOCAL NATIVES AS THE GOLONDRINAS, A NATIVE NAME FOR THE SWALLOWS WHICH INHABIT THE PEAKS AND ALSO AS LAS CUEVAS BECAUSE OF THE MANY HOLES IN THE ROCKS.  THE STATION IS LOCATED NEAR THE MIDDLE OF THE GROUP OF HIGHEST CRAGS, BUT IS NOT ON ONE OF THE HIGHEST, THEY BEING TOO POINTED FOR SETTING UP AN INSTRUMENT. THE STATION IS ON A SLIGHTLY LOWER, SLOPING, FLAT, CORRUGATED ROCK ABOUT 20 FEET TO THE S OF THE LEDGE OF HIGHER CRAGS.  STATION MARK IS A STANDARD U.S.G.S. TABLET STAMPED LA MINA 1934 CEMENTED IN A LARGE BLOCK OF MARBLE IN PLACE.  REFERENCE MARK NO.1 IS STANDARD TABLET CEMENTED IN TOP OF ROCK CRAG, 30.40 FEET FROM STATION IN TRUE AZIMUTH 130 DEG 35 MIN.  REFERENCE MARK NO.2 IS STANDARD TABLET CEMENTED IN TOP OF ROCK CRAG, 15.88 FEET FROM STATION IN TRUE AZIMUTH 202 DEG 33 MIN.  REFERENCE MARK NO.3 IS 1-INCH DRILL HOLE IN TOP OF A SHARP POINTED ROCK, 3.50 FEET FROM STATION IN TRUE AZIMUTH 34 DEG 52 MIN.  TO REACH STATION, GO TO THE MANGANESE MINE BY ROAD, FROM THE MINE THERE ARE TRAILS LEADING TO THE VICINITY OF THE CRAGS WHERE ARE LOCATED MANY NATIVE DWELLINGS.  MOST ANY NATIVE WHO WAS LIVING IN THE VICINITY AT TIME THE STATION WAS ESTABLISHED CAN GUIDE ONE TO THE LOCATION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1966)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JJL) THE STATION WAS RECOVERED AND ALL MARKS WERE FOUND IN GOOD CONDITION.  A COMPLETE NEW DESCRIPTION OF THE STATION FOLLOWS.  THE STATION IS LOCATED 8 AIRLINE MILES WEST OF COAMO AND 4 AIRLINE MILES SOUTHEAST OF VILLALBA.  IT IS LOCATED ON THE WEST PART OF A LONG ROCK COVERED RIDGE WHICH IS THE HIGHEST POINT IN THE VICINITY.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE PLAZA IN JUANA DIAZ, GO EASTERLY ON HIGHWAY 14 FOR 1.5 MILES TO HIGHWAY 551.  TURN LEFT AND GO NORTHERLY ON HIGHWAY 551 FOR 3.2 MILES TO THE END OF THE PAVED ROAD.  CONTINUE NORTH ON A BLADED ROAD FOR 0.7 MILE TO A HOUSE ON THE RIGHT AND A TRAIL ON THE LEFT AND END OF TRUCK TRAVEL.  FROM HERE PACK NORTH UP A STEEP HILL FOR ABOUT 1/2 MILE TO THE LONG RIDGE, TURN LEFT AND GO WESTERLY ACROSS THE RIDGE FOR ABOUT 1/4 MILE TO THE HIGHEST POINT OF THE RIDGE AND THE STATION.  THE STATION MARK IS A USGS BENCH MARK STAMPED LA MINA 1934, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A BOULDER WHICH PROJECTS 4 FEET.  REFERENCE MARK 1 IS A USGS REFERENCE MARK DISK STAMPED NO 1, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A LARGE BOULDER WHICH PROJECTS 10 FEET AND ABOUT 4 FEET HIGHER THAN THE STATION.  REFERENCE MARK 2 IS A USGS REFERENCE MARK DISK STAMPED NO 2, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A BOULDER WHICH PROJECTS 12 FEET AND ABOUT 4 FEET HIGHER THAN THE STATION.  AIRLINE DISTANCE AND DIRECTION FROM NEAREST TOWN 4 MILES NORTHEAST OF JUANA DIAZ.
markers.setting: UNSPECIFIED SETTING

markers.description: BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1939 (EGR) THIS STATION IS LOCATED ON A LONG GRASSY HILL, THE SECOND OF A LINE OF HILLS RUNNING SW FROM RD. 3 AND CANOVANAS WATER RESERVOIR, ON PROPERTY OF LAWYER JOSE MA CALDERON AT BARRIO LA PALMA OF CANOVANAS.  APPROACHED FROM CAROLINA BY RD. 3 TO KM. 16.85 WHERE TURNING S BY DIRT FARM RD. NEAR THE HOUSE OF THE FOREMAN, FOLLOW ABOUT 300 METERS TO PASS E OF A ROUND HILL, CROSS A DRAIN REACHING FOOT OF STATION HILL.  STATION MARK--STANDARD TABLET STAMPED LA PALMA 1939 CEMENTED TO NATURAL ROCK ON HIGH POINT OF HILL AND N OF BIG BOULDER.  R. M. NO. 1--HOLE DRILLED ON BOULDER 2.5 METERS S OF STATION.  R. M. NO. 2--HOLE DRILLED ON SAME ROCK WHERE STATION IS AND 1.24 METERS W.  SIGNAL--POLE WITH WHITE FLAG AND BLACK CROSS TARGETS CENTERED OVER STATION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1941)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1941 STATION RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.  REDESCRIBED.  THE STATION IS ON THE BARRIO LA PALMA OF CANOVANAS, ON A LONG GRASSY HILL 0.5 MI. SW OF CANOVANAS, ABOUT 1 MI. S. OF CENTRAL CANOVANAS, 0.25 MI. SW OF CANOVANAS WATER WORKS, AND ABOUT 0.4 MI. S. OF ROAD NO. 3.  IT IS A STANDARD TABLET STAMPED LA PALMA 1939, CEMENTED TO AN OUTCROPPING LEDGE, ON HIGHEST PART OF HILL, 55 FT. WEST OF FENCE AND 7 FT. NE OF A VERY LARGE BOULDER.  IT IS ON THE PROPERTY OF JOSE M. CALDERON.                            STATION RECOVERY (1971)  RECOVERY NOTE BY THOMAS ENG AND SURV 1971 (HBW) LA PALMA 1939 UNDISTURBED.  RM NO. 1 - HOLE IN BOULDER FOUND.  RM NO. 2 SEARCHED FOR NOT FOUND.  STATION IS 2.57 M (8.4 FT) FROM REFERENCE MARK NO.1 AND 0.5 M (1.6 FT) PLUS OR MINUS LOWER THAN REFERENCE MARK NO.1.  A DOZER ROAD RECENTLY MADE TO TOP OF HILL COVERED STATION WITH 0.3 M (1.0 FT) OF DIRT BUT DID NOT DISTURB STATION (SET IN BED ROCK).
markers.setting: SET IN UNSPECIFIED ROCK OR BOULDER
markers.stability: PROBABLY HOLD POSITION/ELEVATION WELL

markers.description: BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1934 THIS STATION IS SITUATED ON A SHARP POINTED ROCKY HILL OF THE RIDGE ABOUT 2 MILES W OF GUAYNABO RIVER AND THE SAN JUAN WATER WORKS DAM.  IT IS ON LAND OWNED BY JUAN RIOS.  STATION MARK IS A STANDARD U.S.G.S. TABLET SET ON ROCK, STAMPED LA PENA 1934.  REFERENCE MARK NO.1 IS A STANDARD TABLET SET ON NATURAL ROCK, 4.91 METERS FROM STATION IN TRUE AZIMUTH 268 DEG 13 MIN.  REFERENCE MARK NO.2 IS A STANDARD TABLET SET ON NATURAL ROCK 2.75 METERS FROM STATION, IN TRUE AZIMUTH 334 DEG 21 MIN.  STATION IS APPROACHED BY CAR FROM MUNICIPAL ROAD TO THE DAM ABOUT 12 MILES FROM JUNCTION WITH THE GUAYNABO ROAD.                            STATION RECOVERY (1940)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1940 STATION AND R.M.S RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.  NEW DESCRIPTION FOLLOWS--  LOCATED ABOUT 5-1/2 MILES SW OF GUAYNABO AND 4 MILES NW OF AGUAS BUENAS, AND 1-1/4 MILES W OF SONADORA DE GUAYNABO SCHOOL.  ON THE WESTERNMOST OF A SERIES OF HIGH SHARP ROCKY PEAKS ON A RIDGE.  IT IS ABOUT ONE MILE W OF THE RIO GUAYNABO.  THE STATION IS A STANDARD TABLET STAMPED LA PENA 1934 SET IN THE ROCK.  R. M. NO. 1 IS A STANDARD R. M. TABLET STAMPED NO. 1 SET IN ROCK 4.91 METERS FROM STATION IN AZIMUTH 268 DEG 13 MIN.  R. M. NO. 2 IS SIMILAR TO NO. 1 AND IS 2.75 METERS FROM STATION IN AZIMUTH 334 DEG 21 MIN.  TO REACH FROM GUAYNABO PLAZA, GO WESTWARD ON IMPROVED ROAD TOWARDS RIO GUAYNABO 2.9 MILES.  TURN LEFT AT T-ROAD AND FOLLOW THIS ROAD UP RIVER 5.2 MILES TO STORE, AND HOUSE OF ISIDORO SANTIAGO.  HERE TAKE TRAIL DOWN TO AND ACROSS RIVER.  THEN UP HILL IN A WESTERLY DIRECTION ABOUT 1 KM. TO A BROOK CROSSING.  ABOUT 600 FT. BEYOND THIS THERE IS AN OPEN ROCKY PASTURE TO LEFT AND MAYA TO RIGHT.  TURN LEFT AND FOLLOW UP POINT OF RIDGE ON DIM TRAIL, CONTINUING THROUGH WOODS AT BASE OF CLIFFS TO RIDGE. TURN RIGHT AT RIDGE, AND GO ABOUT 200M TO STATION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1966)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JJL) THE STATION MARK AND BOTH REFERENCE MARKS WERE RECOVERED AND FOUND IN GOOD CONDITION.  A NEW AZIMUTH MARK WAS ESTABLISHED 1/2 MILE NORTHEAST OF THE STATION.  A COMPLETE NEW DESCRIPTION OF THE STATION FOLLOWS.  THE STATION IS LOCATED 7 AIRLINE MILES NORTHEAST OF COMERIO, 7 AIRLINE MILES EAST OF NARANJITO AND ON THE TOP OF A HIGH ROCK COVERED HILL WHICH IS THE HIGHEST POINT IN THE IMMEDIATE VICINITY.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE SOUTHWEST CORNER OF THE PLAZA IN GUAYNABO, GO WESTERLY ON A PAVED ROAD FOR 2.6 MILES TO A FORK.  KEEP LEFT AND GO SOUTH AND WEST ON A PAVED ROAD FOR 3.45 MILES TO A T-INTERSECTION.  TURN RIGHT AND GO NORTH AND WEST ON A PAVED ROAD FOR 0.9 MILE TO A SIDE ROAD LEFT AT A SMALL STORE. TURN LEFT AND GO SOUTH UPHILL ON A BLADED ROAD FOR 1.05 MILES TO A FORK.  KEEP LEFT AND GO SOUTHEAST DOWN STEEP HILL ON A BLADED ROAD FOR 0.35 MILE TO A FORK.  TURN LEFT AND GO NORTH AND EAST ON A BLADED ROAD FOR 0.95 MILE TO THE END OF TRUCK TRAVEL AT A FENCE CORNER.  FROM HERE PACK SOUTHWEST UP STEEP HILL ON A TRAIL FOR ABOUT 1 HOUR TO THE TOP OF THE ROCK COVERED HILL AND THE STATION ON THE HIGHEST POINT OF THE HILL. A 4 WHEEL DRIVE VEHICLE IS REQUIRED FOR THE LAST 2.35 MILES.  THE STATION MARK IS A USGS BENCH MARK STAMPED LA PENA 1934, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A LARGE BOULDER WHICH PROJECTS 6 FEET.  REFERENCE MARK 1 IS A USGS REFERENCE DISK STAMPED NO 1, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN THE NORTHEAST EDGE OF THE LARGE BOULDER.  REFERENCE MARK 2 IS A USGS REFERENCE DISK STAMPED NO 2, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN THE SOUTHEAST EDGE OF THE LARGE BOULDER.  THE AZIMUTH MARK IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED LA PENA USGS 1934, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A BOULDER WHICH PROJECTS 4 FEET.  IT IS LOCATED JUST SOUTHEAST OF THE FENCE CORNER AT THE END OF TRUCK TRAVEL.  AIRLINE DISTANCE AND DIRECTION FROM NEAREST TOWN 6 MILES SSW OF GUAYNABO.                            STATION RECOVERY (2004)  RECOVERY NOTE BY UNIVERSITY OF PUERTO RICO AT MAYAGUEZ 2004 (CRA) RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.
markers.setting: SET IN UNSPECIFIED ROCK OR BOULDER
markers.stability: PROBABLY HOLD POSITION/ELEVATION WELL

markers.description: BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1939 LOCATED ABOUT 1 KM. N OF THE TOWN OF DORADO AND 1/2 KM. W OF THE LA PLATA RIVER AND ABOUT 350 METERS E OF FRAILES TRIANGULATION STATION, ON TOP OF THE HIGHEST POINT ON THE THIRD HILL W OF THE RIVER.  ON LAND OWNED BY MR. JOSE MARIA DEL VALLE.  APPROACHED FROM DORADO BY THE MUNICIPAL ROAD THAT CROSSES THE TOWN TOWARDS THE W, FOLLOWING IT TO POST K 6.9.  LEAVE ROAD TURNING RIGHT (N) ALONG A DIRT ROAD WHICH IS FOLLOWED TO A SHARP BEND, TURN LEFT (N) FOLLOWING SAME DIRT ROAD UP HILL PASSING A RED-ROOF HOUSE THEN DOWN HILL TO A SHARP BEND, TURN RIGHT (E) FOLLOWING ROAD TO THE FIRST T-ROAD TO THE N, FOLLOW T-ROAD TO THE FOOT OF THE HILL.  THE TOP OF THE HILL IS BARE WITH SOME SCATTERED WILD BERRIES.  STATION MARK--STANDARD R.M. TABLET STAMPED LA PLATA 1939 CEMENTED TO A CONCRETE BLOCK 10- BY 10- BY 16-INCHES DEEP ANCHORED TO A NATURAL ROCK LEDGE.  REFERENCE MARK 2--R.R. SPIKE FIXED TO NATURAL ROCK LEDGE 2.74 METERS, HORIZONTAL DISTANCE, SW OF STATION.  REFERENCE MARK 1--R.R. SPIKE FIXED TO NATURAL ROCK LEDGE S OF STATION AT A DISTANCE OF 7.22 METERS, HORIZONTAL.  SIGNAL WAS 3 FEET 4-3/8 INCHES ECCENTRIC.  TOP OF FLAG--5.23 METERS ABOVE GROUND.  TOP OF TARGETS 3.8 METERS ABOVE GROUND.                            STATION RECOVERY (1966)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JJL) THE STATION WAS RECOVERED AND FOUND IN GOOD CONDITION.  TWO NEW REFERENCE MARKS AND A NEW AZIMUTH MARK WERE ESTABLISHED.  A COMPLETE NEW DESCRIPTION OF THE STATION FOLLOWS.  THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 10 AIRLINE MILES NORTHWEST OF PAYAMON AND ABOUT 1-1/2 AIRLINE MILES NORTH OF DORADO, ON A HIGH GRASSY HILL.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE SOUTHWEST CORNER OF THE PLAZA IN DORADO, GO WEST ON HIGHWAY 693 FOR 0.5 MILE TO HIGHWAY 698.  TURN RIGHT AND GO NORTH ON HIGHWAY 698 FOR 0.9 MILE TO A CHURCH ON THE RIGHT.  (THE AZIMUTH MARK IS LOCATED 0.1 MILE EAST OF THIS POINT IN THE SOUTHWEST CORNER OF A BALL PARK).  CONTINUE NORTH ON HIGHWAY 698 FOR 0.1 MILE TO A SIDE ROAD RIGHT AT A SMALL STORE.  TURN RIGHT AND GO EAST AND NORTHEAST ON A PAVED ROAD FOR 0.25 MILE TO A SIDE ROAD LEFT.  TURN LEFT AND GO NORTH UP A STEEP HILL FOR 0.05 MILE TO THE TOP OF THE HILL AND THE STATION ON THE HIGHEST POINT OF THE HILL JUST NORTHEAST OF THE ROAD.  THE STATION MARK IS A USGS BENCH MARK STAMPED LAPLATA 1939, SET IN THE TOP OF A 10X15 INCH SQUARE CONCRETE MONUMENT PROJECTING 3 INCHES.  IT IS 55 FEET NORTHEAST OF THE CENTER OF THE PAVED ROAD.  REFERENCE MARK 3 IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED LAPLATA USGS NO 3 1939, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN OUTCROPPING BEDROCK WHICH IS FLUSH WITH THE SURFACE.  (NOTE 12C)  REFERENCE MARK 4 IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED LAPLATA USGS NO 4 1939, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN OUTCROPPING BEDROCK WHICH IS FLUSH WITH THE SURFACE.  (NOTE 12C)  THE AZIMUTH MARK IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED LAPLATA 1939, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A BOULDER WHICH PROJECTS 2 FEET.  IT IS 47 FEET EAST OF A WIRE FENCE AND 18 FEET NORTH OF A WIRE FENCE.  (NOTE 17C)  AIRLINE DISTANCE AND DIRECTION FROM NEAREST TOWN 1-1/2 MILES NORTH OF DORADO.
markers.setting: SET IN TOP OF CONCRETE MONUMENT
markers.stability: MAY HOLD, BUT OF TYPE COMMONLY SUBJECT TOSURFACE MOTION

markers.description: UNK RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED.

BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1901 (JEM) THIS IS A NEW STATION, WHICH HAD TO BE SELECTED TO PERMIT OF CARRYING THE TRIANGULATION AROUND RINCON POINT.  THE RIDGE WHICH RUNS INLAND FROM RINCON, OR JIGUERO POINT (JIGUERO IS THE NAME ON THE MAPS, BUT THE LIGHTHOUSE KEEPER STATES THAT IT SHOULD BE HIGUERO, THE LATTER BEING THE NAME OF A TREE, VERY COMMON IN THIS NEIGHBORHOOD, AND BEARING A VARIETY OF GOURDS.  JIGUERO MEANS A LINNET), SEEMS TO BE CALLED LA PUNTA.  THE STATION MARK IS AN IRON PIPE 18 INCHES LONG, CEMENTED IN PLACE AND FILLED WITH CEMENT.  IN THE CENTER OF THE CEMENT IS A NAIL SET IN THE POLE, MAKING A HOLE IN THE CEMENT.  THE UNDERGROUND MARK WAS A SMALL BOTTLE, WITH THE NECK BROKEN OFF, AND THE BODY FILLED WITH FINE EARTH.  HIGUERO TREE, 4 INCHES IN DIAMETER, A SMALL TOPPED, WHITE BARKED TREE, HAVING TRUNK HACKED WITH A MACHETE CUTS IS ON N SIDE OF A SMALL GULLEY.  BELOW GULLEY AND HEDGE OF WILD PINEAPPLES IN FRONT OF EUSEBIO SANCHEZ HOUSE IS A CAYMETO TREE, WITH ITS BARK CUT ALMOST ENTIRELY OFF.  THE TOP OF THE TREE HAS BEEN BROKEN OFF ABOUT 8 FEET ABOVE THE GROUND BUT A NEW GROWTH OF LEAVES MAKES A LITTLE CROWN OF GREEN.  THESE TREES CAN BE USED TO RECOVER THE STATION.  THE PATHWAY WHICH IS USED BY THE PEOPLE IN THE VICINITY OF THE LIGHTHOUSE, IN GOING TO AGUADA, AND WHICH CROSSES THE HILL, ON WHICH STATION RINCON STANDS (A LITTLE TO THE NORTHWARD OF THE SIGNAL), GOES ALONG THE RIDGE GENERALLY AND PASSES WITHIN A FEW FEET OF LA PUNTA.  THE ROAD OR TRAIL IN GOING FROM RINCON TO LA PUNTA PASSES A LOCAL SCHOOLHOUSE.  LA PUNTA IS ON THE LAND OF MANUEL SANCHEZ, AND VERY CLOSE TO THE HOUSE OF HIS SON EUSEBIO SANCHEZ.  TO AVOID INTERFERING WITH MR. SANCHEZS CROPS, AND TO SECURE A SIGHT WHICH WOULD BE AS FREE AS POSSIBLE FROM DISTURBANCE IT WAS NECESSARY TO GO A LITTLE BELOW THE SUMMIT, WHICH WOULD BRING ONE IMMEDIATELY IN FRONT OF EUSEBIO SANCHEZS HOUSE.  MANUEL BRINONI LIVES ON THE S, JUST S OF THE SIGNAL AND BELOW IT.  THERE IS A LINE OF WILD PINEAPPLE BETWEEN THE TRAIL AND MANUEL BRINONIS PROPERTY.  E OF THE STATION, AND AT THE FOOT OF THE SLOPE, MANUEL SANCHEZ, HAS ERECTED A SMALL BUILDING, ABOUT 11 TIMES 11 FEET, WHICH HE OCCUPIES AS A STORE.  JUST E OF EUSEBIO SANCHEZS HOUSE IS A LARGE FIELD OF GANDURAS (A BUSH PEA), AND NEAR WHERE THE SW CORNER OF THE PATCH COMES TO THE TRAIL IS THE STATION.  THE MARK IS ABOUT 5.5 FEET N OF THE N SIDE OF THE FOOT PATH.
markers.setting: SET INTO TOP OF METAL PIPE DRIVEN INTO GROUND
markers.stability: MARK OF QUESTIONABLE OR UNKNOWN STABILITY

markers.description: BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1934 STATION IS ON THE BARRIO SAN SALVADOR, ABOUT 15 KILOMETERS DIRECT DISTANCE FROM THE CITY OF CAGUAS.  WE CALLED THIS STATION LA SANTA BECAUSE OF A PREACHER WOMAN WHO ONCE LIVED ON THIS MOUNTAIN WHOM THE PEOPLE CALLED LA SANTA.  THE STATION IS NOT ON LA SANTA HILL.  THE TRUE HILL NAMED LA SANTA IS AT A MAGNETIC AZIMUTH OF ABOUT 110 DEGREES FROM THE STATION.  THESE HILLS ARE THICKLY COVERED WITH WILD SIERRA PALMS AND ARE ALSO VERY FREQUENTLY UNDER CLOUDS AND FOG.  THERE IS ANOTHER HILL NAMED EL LUCERO AT A MAGNETIC AZIMUTH OF ABOUT 300 DEGREES FROM THE STATION, AND AT A DISTANCE OF ABOUT 250 METERS FROM IT.  THERE ARE TWO OTHER HILLS FROM 8 TO 10 FEET HIGHER THAN THE STATION, ABOUT 300 METERS FROM IT ON A MAGNETIC AZIMUTH OF 160 DEGREES.  A REGULAR U.S.G.S. TABLET STAMPED LA SANTA 1934 WAS USED TO MARK THE STATION.  REFERENCE MARK NO.2 IS A COPPER NAIL AND U.S.G.S. WASHER ON A TABONUCO TREE STUMP, 9 FEET 9.5 INCHES FROM STATION, ON TRUE AZIMUTH OF 124 DEG 04 MIN.  REFERENCE MARK NO.1 IS A COPPER NAIL WITH U.S.G.S. WASHER ON THE HIGH THIN TABONUCO TREE USED FOR FIXING THE SIGNAL, AT A DISTANCE OF 26 FEET 3 INCHES FROM THE STATION, ON TRUE AZIMUTH OF 19 DEG 12 MIN.  TO REACH STATION, TAKE ROAD TO BARRIO BORINQUEN AT KILOMETER 42, H 1 ON THE CAGUAS-CAYEY HIGHWAY.  DRIVE ON THIS ROAD FOR ABOUT 4 KILOMETERS UNTIL YOU REACH JUNCTION OF ROAD TO BARRIO SAN SALVADOR.  FROM HERE DRIVE TO THE END OF THE ROAD, WHICH IS AT A PLACE LOCALLY KNOWN AS LA PLACITA ON THE BARRIO SAN SALVADOR. FROM LA PLACITA TAKE TRAIL LEADING TO THE FINCA OF SENOR THOMAS RODRIGUEZ, WHICH IS ABOUT 1-1/2 KILOMETERS FROM THE STATION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1940)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1940 RECOVERED THE 1934 STATION IN GOOD CONDITION.  NEW DESCRIPTION FOLLOWS--  LOCATED ABOUT 13-1/2 KM. S AND SLIGHTLY W OF CAGUAS, IN THE CARITE NATIONAL FOREST, ABOUT A KILOMETER E OF CAMP GUAVATE, ON A HIGH WOODED RIDGE.  THERE IS A SOMEWHAT HIGHER PEAK TO NORTHWESTWARD OF THE STATION AND THE RIDGE IS HIGH TO THE SE.  THE PEAK ELLUCERO IS ABOUT 250 METERS SE OF THE STATION.  THE STATION IS A STANDARD TABLET STAMPED LA SANTA 1934 SET IN CONCRETE FLUSH WITH THE GROUND.  PRACTICALLY ON THE PROJECTION OF A LONG TANGENT OF THE FOREST ROAD.  19.0 FT. DUE E OF CENTERLINE OF TRAIL AT A POINT 13 FT. FROM ITS END.  AND 30 FT. N 61 DEG 30 MIN E (MAG.) OF A WHITE 3 BY 3 POST PROJECTING 3 FT.  R. M. NO. 2 (1941) IS A STANDARD TABLET WITH AN ARROW POINTING TOWARDS THE STATION, STAMPED R. M. NO. 2 1941, SET IN CONCRETE POST 24.5 FT. IN AZIMUTH 86 DEG 11 MIN FROM THE STATION.  IT IS 4.5 FT. W OF CENTERLINE OF TRAIL.  5.8 FT. N OF A LAUREL TREE. 5.2 FT. E OF A CUPEY TREE.  AND 3.0 FT. S OF A LAUREL TREE.  R. M. NO. 1 IS A COPPER NAIL AND WASHER ON A TABONUCO TREE, 26.2 FT. FROM STATION IN AZIMUTH 19 DEG 12 MIN.  TO REACH FROM CAGUAS, GO S ON ROAD TO CAYEY 9.4 MILES (FROM CAYEY PLAZA N 6.1 MILES) TO IMPROVED ROAD E TO CCC CAMP.  TAKE THIS ROAD 3.9 MILES TO ENTRANCE TO CARITE NATIONAL FOREST. CONTINUE 2.7 MILES TO CAMP GUAVATE.  CONTINUE EASTWARD FROM CAMP 0.9 MILE WHERE A TANGENT OF 0.2 MILE BEGINS.  THERE IS NO OTHER TANGENT SO LONG ON THE ROAD.  THE STATION IS ON THE RIDGE VIRTUALLY ON THE PROJECTION OF THIS TANGENT.  LEAVE CAR ABOUT 0.1 MILE N OF N END OF TANGENT, AND TAKE GRADED TRAIL LEFT, WHICH LEADS RIGHT TO THE STATION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1966)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JJL) THE STATION MARK AND REFERENCE MARK 3 WERE FOUND.  THE STATION MARK WAS IN GOOD CONDITION BUT REFERENCE MARK 3 WAS LOOSE.  REFERENCE MARKS 4 AND 5 WERE ESTABLISHED AT THIS DATE.  AN AZIMUTH MARK WAS ESTABLISHED AT THIS DATE.  A COMPLETE NEW DESCRIPTION FOLLOWS--  THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 10 MILES SOUTH OF CAGUAS, 9 MILES EAST OF CAYEY, ON THE TOP OF A TIMBER COVERED HILL AND ON THE PROPERTY OF THE U.S. DEPARTMENT OF AGRICULTURE.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE POST OFFICE IN CAGUAS, GO SOUTH ON HIGHWAY 1 FOR 4.05 MILES TO THE JUNCTION WITH HIGHWAY 765.  TURN SHARP LEFT AND GO EAST AND SOUTH ON HIGHWAY 765 FOR 0.8 MILE TO THE JUNCTION WITH HIGHWAY 763 AT A Y-FORK.  TAKE THE RIGHT FORK AND GO SOUTH ON HIGHWAY 763 FOR 5.2 MILES TO A SIDE ROAD ON THE RIGHT AND THE JUNCTION WITH HIGHWAY 184.  CONTINUE SOUTHERLY ON HIGHWAY 184 FOR 2.9 MILES TO CAMP GUAVATE, A PRISON CAMP. CONTINUE SOUTHERLY ON HIGHWAY 184, PASSING THROUGH THE PRISON CAMP AND GO 1.1 MILES TO A SIDE ROAD ON THE LEFT AND A SIGN LASANTA.  TURN LEFT AND FOLLOW A GRAVELED ROAD EAST AND NORTH FOR 0.4 MILE TO A SIDE ROAD ON THE LEFT AND THE END OF TRUCK TRAVEL.  (THE AZIMUTH MARK IS 58 FEET NORTH OF THIS POINT ON THE WEST SIDE OF THE ROAD NEAR A POWER LINE POLE).  FROM HERE PACK WEST AND NORTH ON A DIRT ROAD WHICH LATER BECOMES A NARROW TRAIL FOR 10 MINUTES TO THE HIGHEST POINT OF THE HILL AND THE STATION.  THE STATION MARK IS A U.S. GEOLOGICAL SURVEY BENCH MARK DISK, STAMPED LA SANTA 1934, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A BOULDER THAT PROJECTS 2 INCHES.  NOTE--DESC.  REFERENCE MARK 3 IS A U.S. GEOLOGICAL SURVEY BENCH MARK DISK, STAMPED RM NO 3 1941, CEMENTED IN THE TOP OF A ROUND CONCRETE POST THAT IS 8 INCHES IN DIAMETER AND PROJECTS 10 INCHES.  IT IS 2 FEET LOWER IN ELEVATION THAN THE STATION MARK.  NOTE--DESC.  REFERENCE MARK 4 IS A STANDARD DISK, STAMPED LA SANTA USGS NO 4 1934 1965, BRAZED TO THE TOP OF A 3-INCH CAST IRON PIPE THAT PROJECTS 2 INCHES AND IS THE SAME ELEVATION AS THE STATION MARK.  NOTE--DESC.  REFERENCE MARK 5 IS A STANDARD DISK, STAMPED LA SANTA USGS NO 5 1934 1965, BRAZED TO THE TOP OF A 3-INCH CAST IRON PIPE THAT PROJECTS 2 INCHES AND IS 2 FEET LOWER IN ELEVATION THAN THE STATION MARK.  NOTE--DESC.  THE AZIMUTH MARK IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED LA SANTA USGS 1934 1965, BRAZED TO THE TOP OF A 3-INCH CAST IRON PIPE THAT IS SURROUNDED BY CONCRETE AND PROJECTS 3 INCHES.  IT IS 58 FEET SOUTHWEST OF A RADIO ANTENNA AND 4 FEET EAST OF A POWER LINE POLE WITH A TRANSFORMER.  AIRLINE DISTANCE AND DIRECTION FROM NEAREST TOWN 9 MILES EAST OF CAYEY.

BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1934 STATION IS ABOUT 9 KILOMETERS BY ROAD S OF THE TOWN OF TRUJILLO ALTO, ON A PROMINENT JUTTING POINT OF RIDGE KNOWN LOCALLY AS LA SILLA.  THE NEW ROAD NOW UNDER CONSTRUCTION BETWEEN TRUJILLO ALTO AND GURABO WILL PASS JUST UNDER THE STATION PEAK ON THE W.  THE SUMMIT IS NEARLY FLAT FOR A DISTANCE OF ABOUT 120 FEET IN A N-S DIRECTION AND THE STATION IS NEAR THE MIDDLE OF THIS TOP AND ABOUT 10 FEET FROM THE BREAK OF THE W SLOPE.  THE RIDGE BREAKS OFF ABRUPTLY ON ITS N END AND THIS SLOPE IS COVERED WITH BRUSH.  STATION MARK IS A STANDARD U.S.G.S. TABLET STAMPED LASILLA 1934, CEMENTED IN A LARGE BOULDER SET IN THE GROUND.  REFERENCE MARK NO.1 IS A HALF-INCH DRILL HOLE IN BOULDER PROJECTING FROM W SLOPE, 19.42 FEET FROM STATION IN TRUE AZIMUTH 98 DEG 10 MIN.  REFERENCE MARK NO.2 IS HALF-INCH DRILL HOLE IN SMALL PROTRUDING BOULDER ON S SLOPE 56.45 FEET FROM STATION IN TRUE AZIMUTH 337 DEG 49 MIN.  SIGNAL--A QUADRIPOD OF SAWED LUMBER COVERED WITH WHITE CLOTH AND WITH BLACK CROSS-TARGETS ON CENTER POLE, CENTERED OVER STATION MARK.  TO REACH THE STATION, FOLLOW THE ROAD S FROM TRUJILLO ALTO TOWARDS GURABO FOR ABOUT 9 KILOMETERS THE ROAD PASSING VERY NEAR THE STATION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1940)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1940 STATION AND R. M. NO. 1 RECOVERED.  R. M. NO. 2, GONE.  NEW DESCRIPTION--  LOCATED ABOUT 9 KMS. BY ROAD S OF THE TOWN OF TRUJILLO ALTO, AND ABOUT THE SAME N OF GUARBO.  ON A PROMINENT, JUTTING POINT OF RIDGE KNOWN LOCALLY AS LA SILLA.  THE STATION IS ABOUT 500M N OF DAIRY OF JUAN BAUTISTA SOTO.  300M NE OF QUEBRADA INFIERNO SCHOOL.  AND IN ABOUT THE MIDDLE OF THE SUMMIT, WHICH IS NEARLY FLAT FOR A DISTANCE OF ABOUT 120 FT. IN A N-S DIRECTION, AND 10 FT. FROM THE BREAK OF THE W SLOPE.  IT IS A STANDARD TABLET STAMPED LA SILLA 1934 CEMENTED TO A LARGE BOULDER.  R. M. NO. 1 IS A HALF-INCH DRILL HOLE IN BOULDER PROJECTING FROM W SLOPE, 19.42 FT. FROM STATION IN AZIMUTH 93 DEG 10 MIN.  R. M. NO. 2 (1941) IS A DRILL HOLE IN ROCK PROTRUDING FROM SW SLOPE.  IT IS 30.85 FT. FROM STATION IN AZIMUTH 4 DEG 51 MIN.  AND 57 FT. NNE OF A SMALL ROBLE TREE, OR, WHEN TREE IS IN LINE WITH FRONT DOOR OF SCHOOL, MARK IS ABOUT 1 PACE W.  AZIMUTH FROM STATION TO BOTTOM OF METAL FLAG POLE AT SCHOOL 20 DEG 58 MIN 34 SEC.  TO REACH FROM GURABO, PLAZA, GO 6.5 MILES ON ROAD TO TRUJILLO ALTO TO K15 H1.  THE STATION IS AT THE TOP OF THE PEAK NE OF HERE, ABOUT 100 METERS DISTANT.
markers.setting: SET IN A BOULDER
markers.stability: MAY HOLD, BUT OF TYPE COMMONLY SUBJECT TOSURFACE MOTION

markers.description: BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1934 LOCATED 11.5 KILOMETERS BY ROAD AND TRAIL E OF SABANA GRANDE, 10.5 KILOMETERS NW OF YAUCO AND ABOUT 3 KILOMETERS N OF HIGHWAY, ON HIGHEST PEAK IN RANGE OF LOW MOUNTAINS EXTENDING E FROM CABO ROJO TO YAUCO.  PEAK IS LOCALLY KNOWN AS CERRO LA TORRE.  IT IS COVERED WITH BRUSH AND HAS TWO LARGE AMASIGO TREES ON W SLOPE, VERY NEAR THE TOP.  THE TOP WAS CLEARED OF BRUSH, LEAVING A LONE TREE 6 INCHES IN DIAMETER AS SIGNAL, AND THE TWO AMASIGO TREES, WHICH WERE TRIMMED.  STATION IS ON HIGHEST PART OF SUMMIT.  STATION MARK IS A STANDARD TABLET STAMPED LA TORRE 1934, CEMENTED IN ROCK IN PLACE.  REFERENCE MARK NO.1 IS A COPPER NAIL AND WASHER IN SMALL TRIANGULAR BLAZE ON SIGNAL TREE, 19.03 FEET FROM STATION IN TRUE AZIMUTH 89 DEG 12 MIN.  REFERENCE MARK NO.2 IS A COPPER NAIL AND WASHER IN TRIANGULAR BLAZE ON LARGE AMASIGO TREE ON W SLOPE, 60.0 FEET FROM STATION IN TRUE AZIMUTH 114 DEG 15 MIN.  REFERENCE MARK NO.3 IS A CROSS CUT ON FLAT ROCK IN PLACE, 16 FEET FROM STATION IN TRUE AZIMUTH 330 DEG 32 MIN.  TO REACH STATION, LEAVE THE HIGHWAY AT POST K 223 H 6-1/2 AT TWO TIENDAS ON N SIDE OF ROAD, FOLLOW MUNICIPAL ROAD WHICH TURNS N BETWEEN THE TWO TIENDAS TO FOOT OF PEAK, FROM WHICH POINT ANY LOCAL NATIVE CAN DIRECT ONE TO THE TOP BY TRAIL.                            STATION RECOVERY (1966)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JJL) THE STATION MARK WAS FOUND AND IN GOOD CONDITION.  REFERENCE MARKS 1, 2 AND 3 WERE NOT FOUND.  REFERENCE MARKS 5 AND 4 WERE ESTABLISHED AT THIS DATE.  A COMPLETE NEW DESCRIPTION FOLLOWS--  THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 6 MILES NORTH OF GUANICA, 5 MILES EAST-NORTHEAST OF YAUCO, 4 MILES SOUTHEAST OF SABANA GRANDE AND ON A SHARP, BRUSHY MOUNTAIN THAT IS LOCALLY KNOWN AS CERRO LA TORRE.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE POST OFFICE IN SABANA GRANDE, GO EAST ON A PAVED STREET FOR 0.2 MILE TO A FORK.  TAKE THE RIGHT FORK AND GO EAST AND SOUTHEAST ON A PAVED ROAD FOR 3.0 MILES TO A FORK.  TAKE THE LEFT FORK AND CONTINUE SOUTHEAST ON A PAVED ROAD FOR 0.6 MILE TO KILOMETER POST 6.4 AND THE END OF TRUCK TRAVEL AT THE BASE OF A HILL.  FROM HERE PACK SOUTHWEST AND WEST UP A STEEP HILL FOR 20 MINUTES TO THE STATION ON THE HIGHEST POINT OF THE HILL.  THE STATION MARK IS A U.S. GEOLOGICAL SURVEY BENCH MARK DISK STAMPED LA TORRE 1934, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A BOULDER THAT PROJECTS 6 INCHES.  NOTE--DESC.  REFERENCE MARK 4 IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED LA TORRE USGS NO 4 1934 1966, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A BOULDER THAT IS FLUSH WITH THE GROUND.  IT IS 2 FEET LOWER THAN THE STATION MARK.  NOTE-- 12C.  REFERENCE MARK 5 IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED LA TORRE NO 5 USGS 1934 1966, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A BOULDER THAT PROJECTS 3 INCHES.  IT IS THE SAME ELEVATION AS THE STATION MARK.  NOTE-- 12C.  NO SUITABLE PLACE WAS FOUND FOR AN AZIMUTH MARK.  AIRLINE DISTANCE AND DIRECTION FROM NEAREST TOWN 4 MILES SOUTHEAST OF SABANA GRANDE.
markers.setting: SET IN UNSPECIFIED ROCK OR BOULDER
markers.stability: PROBABLY HOLD POSITION/ELEVATION WELL

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1926 (GCM) LARGEST OF TWO BLACK STEEL STACKS LOCATED AT CENTRAL LAFAYETTE.  A LIGHT IS PLACED ON THE STACK AND IS USED AS A REAR RANGE FOR ROADSTEAD OF ARROYO.  THE STACK IS ON LINE WITH RANGE HILL AND THE FRONT RANGE BEACON.  CENTRAL LAFAYETTE IS 0.8 MILE N OF ARROYO.

BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1934 STATION IS 5 KILOMETERS BY ROAD AND TRAIL W OF TOA ALTA, ON HIGHEST ONE OF THE FIRST RANGE OF CORAL-LIMESTONE, BRUSH-COVERED PEAKS W OF TOA ALTA, AND ABOUT 2.5 KILOMETERS S OF CARRETERA NO.2.  THE SUMMIT OF THIS PEAK IS ABOUT 50 METERS IN LENGTH AND VERY NARROW.  THE STATION BEING NEAR THE CENTER OF THE TOP, WHICH WAS COVERED WITH HEAVY BRUSH, BUT WHICH WAS ALL CLEARED EXCEPT A LONE TREE, GROWING BELOW THE TOP AT THE N END BUT PROJECTS WELL ABOVE THE SUMMIT.  STATION MARK IS A STANDARD U.S.G.S. TABLET, STAMPED LAJAS 1934, CEMENTED IN THE LIMESTONE CAP ROCK.  REFERENCE MARK NO.1 IS A COPPER NAIL AND WASHER IN BLAZE ABOUT 15 FEET ABOVE GROUND ON A TREE GROWING BELOW THE SUMMIT AT N END OF PEAK, 76.05 FEET FROM STATION IN TRUE AZIMUTH 176 DEG 00 MIN.  REFERENCE MARK NO.2 IS A 1-INCH DRILL HOLE IN THE LIMESTONE CAP ROCK ON HIGH POINT, 47.15 FEET FROM STATION IN TRUE AZIMUTH 354 DEG 30 MIN.  TO REACH STATION FROM TOA ALTA OR VICINITY, FOLLOW THE CARRETERA NORTHWARD TO JUNCTION WITH CARRETERA NO.2, AT KILOMETER POST K 25.  FOLLOW CARRETERA NO.2, WESTWARD FOR 0.5 KILOMETER TO POST K 25 H 5.  TURN S ON PRIVATE ROAD AND FOLLOW TO FIRST FORK.  TURN LEFT (E) AND FOLLOW TO CROSSROADS ON TOP OF RIDGE.  TURN LEFT AGAIN AND FOLLOW ROAD TO END IN DRAW.  CONTINUE ON SOUTHWARD ON TRAIL, KEEPING TO RIGHT AT FIRST HOUSE, AND FOLLOW ON WESTWARD UP DRAW TO LAST HOUSE, WHICH IS AT THE FOOT OF THE PEAK ON WHICH STATION IS LOCATED.                            STATION RECOVERY (1941)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1941 (GBG) LOCATED ABOUT 5 KILOMETERS BY ROAD AND TRAIL NW OF TOA ALTA.  2 KILOMETERS S OF HIGHWAY 2.  AND ABOUT 3 KILOMETERS SW OF NEW RIO LA PLATA BRIDGE OF THIS HIGHWAY.  IT IS ON THE HIGHEST ONE OF THE FIRST RANGE OF CORAL LIMESTONE, BRUSH-COVERED PEAKS W OF TOA ALTA.  THE SUMMIT OF THIS PEAK IS ABOUT 50 METERS IN LENGTH, AND VERY NARROW.  A LONE TREE GROWS BELOW THE TOP TO THE N, AND PROJECTS ABOVE THE SUMMIT.  THE STATION IS NEAR THE CENTER OF THE TOP, AT HIGHEST POINT.  AND IS MARKED BY A BRONZE DISK STAMPED LAJAS 1934, CEMENTED TO THE TOP LEDGE.  REFERENCE MARK 1 IS A COPPER NAIL AND WASHER IN A BLAZE ABOUT 15 FEET ABOVE GROUND IN THE TREE, GROWING BELOW THE SUMMIT AT THE N.  IT IS 76.05 FEET FROM STATION IN AZIMUTH 176 DEG 00 MIN.  REFERENCE MARK 2 IS A ONE-INCH DRILL HOLE IN THE LIMESTONE CAP ROCK, ON HIGH POINT.  AND 47.15 FEET FROM STATION IN AZIMUTH 354 DEG 30 MIN.  TO REACH FROM TOA ALTA, PLAZA, GO N ON ROAD TO TOA BAJA 1.0 MILE (0.3 MILE BEYOND T-ROAD E TO BRIDGE) TO KM. 25.5.  TURN W ON PRIVATE ROAD, AND GO 0.2 MILE.  TURN LEFT (S) AND GO 0.5 MILE TO PASS THROUGH GATE.  CONTINUE ANOTHER 0.2 MILE TO CROSSROADS AND GATE ON TOP OF RIDGE.  TURN LEFT THROUGH GATE.  AND FOLLOW ROAD PAST CANE DERRICK TO ITS END IN A QUEBRADA.  CONTINUE ON TRAIL, TURNING TO RIGHT AT FIRST HOUSE (RAMON DIAS) AND WORKING N UP A LONG MEADOW.  PASS LAST HOUSE, WHICH IS AT FOOT OF THE STATION HILL.  AND CLIMB ON DIM TRAIL NEARLY TO RIDGE.  TAKE DIM TRAIL TO LEFT FOR ABOUT 7 METERS.  TURN RIGHT AND CLIMB TO SUMMIT, AND STATION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1966)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JJL) THE STATION MARK WAS FOUND AND IN GOOD CONDITION.  REFERENCE MARKS 1 AND 2 WERE SEARCHED FOR BUT WERE NOT FOUND.  A REFERENCE MARK 3 AND A REFERENCE MARK 4 WERE SET AT THIS DATE.  A NEW DESCRIPTION FOLLOWS--  THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 9 MILES WEST OF BAYAMON, 5 MILES SOUTH OF DORADO, 4-1/2 MILES SOUTHEAST VEGA ALTA, ON A HIGH BRUSH COVERED HILL AND ON THE PROPERTY OF MR. ISIDRO GARCIA.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE WEST END OF THE BRIDGE OVER THE RIO DE LA PLATA AT THE JUNCTION OF HIGHWAYS 2, 165 AND 693 WHICH IS ABOUT 2-1/2 MILES SOUTH OF DORADO, GO SOUTH ON HIGHWAY 165 FOR 0.8 MILE TO A SIDE ROAD ON THE RIGHT.  TURN RIGHT AND GO WEST ON A NARROW, PAVED ROAD FOR 0.15 MILE TO A 5-WAY INTERSECTION.  TURN LEFT AND GO SOUTHWEST, UPGRADE ON A PAVED ROAD FOR 0.5 MILE TO A SIDE ROAD ON THE LEFT AT A STORE.  CONTINUE SOUTHWEST PASSING THROUGH A WIRE GATE AND FOLLOW A TRACK ROAD FOR 0.6 MILE TO A WIRE GATE.  PASS THROUGH GATE AND CONTINUE SOUTHWEST UP A NARROW LANE FOR 0.15 MILE TO A GATE.  PASS THROUGH THE GATE, TURN RIGHT AND GO WEST AND NORTHWEST FOR 0.15 MILE TO A DIM FORK.  TAKE THE RIGHT FORK AND GO NORTHWEST AND NORTH ON A TRACK ROAD FOR 0.2 MILE TO A WIRE GATE AT A NORTHWEST FENCE CORNER AND THE END OF TRUCK TRAVEL.  PACK NORTH UP STEEP HILL THROUGH HEAVY BRUSH TO THE TOP OF A SADDLE.  TURN RIGHT AND PACK EAST ALONG THE RIDGE TO THE HIGHEST POINT OF THE HILL AND THE STATION.  A 25 MINUTE PACK.  THE STATION MARK IS A U.S. GEOLOGICAL SURVEY BENCH MARK DISK STAMPED LAJAS 1934, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A ROCK OUTCROP THAT PROJECTS 2 INCHES.  REFERENCE MARK 3 IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED LAJAS USGS NO 3 1934, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A ROCK OUTCROP THAT PROJECTS 2 INCHES AND IS ABOUT 2-1/2 FEET LOWER IN ELEVATION THAN THE STATION MARK.  NOTE--12A  REFERENCE MARK 4 IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED LAJAS USGS NO 4 1934, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A ROCK OUTCROP THAT PROJECTS 1 FOOT ON THE EAST SIDE AND 3 FEET ON THE WEST SIDE AND IS THE SAME ELEVATION AS THE STATION MARK.  NOTE--12A  NO SUITABLE PLACE WAS FOUND FOR AN AZIMUTH MARK.  AIRLINE DISTANCE AND DIRECTION FROM NEAREST TOWN 4-1/2 MILES SOUTHEAST OF VEGA ALTA.                            STATION RECOVERY (2004)  RECOVERY NOTE BY UNIVERSITY OF PUERTO RICO AT MAYAGUEZ 2004 (HCA) MARK RECOVERED IN POOR CONDITION.
markers.setting: SET IN ROCK OUTCROP
markers.stability: MOST RELIABLE AND EXPECTED TO HOLDPOSITION/ELEVATION WELL

markers.description: BY ANDREGG INCORPORATED 1995 (DJR) TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE JUNCTION OF HIGHWAYS PR 121 AND PR 328, GO NORTH ON HIGHWAY PR 121 0.35 MILES (0.56 KM) TO THE INTERSECTION OF HIGHWAY PR 121 AND THE HIGHWAY PR 2 ACCESS ROUTE  THE STATION IS LOCATED IN THE SOUTHWEST ISLAND AT THE INTERSECTION OF HIGHWAY PR 121 AND THE HIGHWAY PR 2 ACCESS ROUTE, 20 METERS (65.6 FT) SOUTH OF KILOMETER POST 0.6 (HIGHWAY PR 121) , 3.7 METERS (12.1 FT) WEST OF THE WEST EDGE OF PAVEMENT OF HIGHWAY PR 121, 7 METERS (23.0 FT) SOUTH OF THE SOUTH EDGE OF PAVEMENT OF THE HIGHWAY PR 2 ACCESS ROUTE, AND 5.1 METERS (16.7 FT) NORTHEAST OF THE NORTHEAST EDGE OF PAVEMENT OF THE RAMP FROM THE EAST-BOUND HIGHWAY PR 2 ACCESS ROUTE TO SOUTH-BOUND HIGHWAY PR 121  THE STATION IS 1 METER (3.3 FT) WEST OF A CARSONITE SURVEY MARKER WITNESS POST  THE STATION IS A 3-1/4 INCH BRASS CAP STAMPED CENTRO DE RECAUDACION DE INGRESSOS MUNICIPALES, PUERTO RICO GPS CONTROL, C.R.I.M., UNLAWFUL TO DISTURB, LAJAS 2, SET ATOP A 9/16 INCH STAINLESS STEEL ROD DRIVEN TO REFUSAL AND COVERED FLUSH WITH THE GROUND BY AN ALUMINUM COVER EPOXYED ONTO A 6 INCH SCHEDULE 40 PVC PIPE SET IN CONCRETE INSIDE AND OUT                            STATION RECOVERY (2003)  RECOVERY NOTE BY JOHN CHANCE LAND SURVEYS INC 2003 (FJO) RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.                            STATION RECOVERY (2008)  RECOVERY NOTE BY RLDA SURVEYING AND MAPPING 2008 (RLD) THE STATION WAS RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.                            STATION RECOVERY (2016)  RECOVERY NOTE BY DEWBERRY DAVIS 2016 (GDS) RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1952 (JOP) STATION IS ABOUT 5 MILES SOUTHEAST OF TOWN OF LAJAS AND ABOUT 1 MILE SOUTH OF THE LAJAS ARRIBA POST OFFICE, ON PROPERTY OWNED BY MR. JOSE B. RAMIREZ ACOSTA.  IT IS LOCATED IN THE PASTURE SOUTH OF THE WINDMILL AND CARETAKERS HOUSE, 50 FEET DUE SOUTH OF THE EAST GATE POST OF THE BULL PEN.  STATION AND REFERENCE MARKS ARE STANDARD DISKS IN CONCRETE.  STATION MARK, STAMPED LAJAS EAST BASE 1952, PROJECTS ABOUT 4 INCHES ABOVE THE GROUND.  REFERENCE MARK 1, STAMPED LAJAS EAST BASE NO 1 1952, IS IN THE FENCE LINE ABOUT 100 FEET EAST OF THE EAST GATE POST.  PROJECTS 3 INCHES ABOVE THE GROUND.  REFERENCE MARK 2, STAMPED LAJAS EAST BASE NO 2 1952, IS IN THE FENCE LINE, 2 FEET EAST OF THE EAST GATE POST.  PROJECTS 3 INCHES.  TO REACH FROM SOUTHEAST CORNER OF THE LAJAS PLAZA, GO SOUTH FOR 1.05 MILES ON LAJAS-LA PARGUERA ROAD TO A T-ROAD ON LEFT AT KILOMETER POST K6H8.  TURN LEFT, EASTERLY, FOR 4.4 MILES TO INTERSECTION WITH A BLACK-TOP ROAD ON LEFT AND A DIRT ROAD ON RIGHT AT A SMALL STORE AND POST OFFICE (LAJAS ARRIBA).  TURN RIGHT, SOUTH, ON ROUGH DIRT ROAD, FOLLOWING SIGNS RAMIREZ VAT- MATOS VAT, KEEPING SOUTH ACROSS RAILROAD TRACKS AT WAY STATION. GO THROUGH GATE ON SOUTH SIDE OF RAILROAD TRACKS THENCE THREE MORE GATES AT CORRAL.  FOLLOW TRACK ROAD SOUTH ACROSS PASTURE TO GATE AT CORNER OF FENCE.  A TOTAL DISTANCE OF 0.95 MILE. PASS THROUGH GATE, TURN SHARP RIGHT, WEST, ON HIGHLINE ROAD FOR 1/8 MILE TO CORRAL AND CONCRETE BLOCK CATTLE CHUTE MARKED RAMIREZ VAT ON LEFT.  WALK SOUTH THROUGH BULL PEN ON EAST SIDE OF CORRAL FOR ABOUT 150 FEET TO GATE.  CONTINUE FOR ABOUT 50 FEET TO STATION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1963)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1963 (CFO) NO EVIDENCE OF THE STATION MARK OR THE REFERENCE MARKS WERE FOUND.  THE AREA WHERE THE STATION WAS LOCATED IS NOW A SUGAR CANE FIELD, NATIVES STATED THE AREA WAS LEVELED WITH A TRACTOR AND DESTROYED ALL OF THE MARKS.
markers.setting: SET IN TOP OF CONCRETE MONUMENT
markers.stability: MAY HOLD, BUT OF TYPE COMMONLY SUBJECT TOSURFACE MOTION

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1952 (JOP) STATION IS ABOUT 2-3/4 MILES SOUTHWEST OF LAJAS ON PROPERTY OWNED BY MR. CORNELIO IRIZARRY OF SAN GERMAN.  IT IS ON AN EAST-WEST ROAD THROUGH A CANE FIELD, 0.2 MILE WEST OF THE MAIN NORTH-SOUTH DIRT ROAD.  STATION, UNDERGROUND AND REFERENCE MARKS ARE STANDARD DISKS IN SQUARE BLOCKS OF CONCRETE.  STATION MARK, STAMPED LAJAS WEST BASE 1952, IS 24 FEET EAST OF AN IRRIGATION DITCH CULVERT MADE OF CONCRETE AND 1 FOOT NORTH OF THE CENTER OF THE ROAD.  FLUSH WITH THE ROAD BED.  REFERENCE MARK 1, STAMPED LAJAS WEST BASE NO 1 1952, IS IN THE CENTER OF THE CANE FIELD ROAD AND FLUSH WITH THE ROAD BED.  REFERENCE MARK 2, STAMPED LAJAS WEST BASE NO 2 1952, IS ON THE WEST RIDGE OF THE IRRIGATION DITCH, ABOUT 30 FEET WEST AND 36 FEET NORTH OF THE STATION (12 PACES NORTH OF THE ROAD AT EAST EDGE OF CANE).  MARK PROJECTS 4 INCHES.  TO REACH FROM THE INTERSECTION OF ROUTE 19 AND THE TRAFFIC SIGNAL IN DOWNTOWN LAJAS, GO WEST ON PALMAREJO ROAD (BLACK-TOP) AND FOLLOW WEST, SOUTH AND SOUTHWEST FOR 2.4 MILES TO FORK AT RAILROAD TRACKS.  TURN RIGHT, WEST, ALONG RAILROAD TRACKS FOR 0.4 MILE TO STORE ON RIGHT AND AN OPEN METAL GATE ON LEFT.  TURN LEFT, SOUTH, ON DIRT ROAD FOR 0.4 MILE TO GROUP OF BUILDINGS WITH A MACHINE SHED ON RIGHT.  TURN SHARP RIGHT BETWEEN SHED AND SMALL HOUSE ON DIRT ROAD THROUGH CANE FIELD, WEST FOR 0.3 MILE.  TURN LEFT, SOUTH, ON CANE FIELD ROAD FOR 0.25 MILE. TURN LEFT, EAST, ACROSS IRRIGATION DITCH FOR 0.1 MILE TO STATION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1963)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1963 (CFO) THE STATION MARK AND THE REFERENCE MARKS WERE ALL RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED AND FOUND TO BE IN GOOD CONDITION.  THE PROPERTY IS NOW OWNED BY THE SONS OF THE ORIGINAL OWNER, WHOM STATED THEY WOULD NOT DESTROY THE MARKS.
markers.setting: SET IN TOP OF CONCRETE MONUMENT
markers.stability: MAY HOLD, BUT OF TYPE COMMONLY SUBJECT TOSURFACE MOTION

markers.description: BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1939 (EGR) STATION IS 3 KMS. E OF RIO PIEDRAS, ON A LIMESTONE HILL, THE MOST NORTHERN 3 HILLS, LOCATED AT RD. 3 AT ITS KM. 3.9 AND EASTERN END OF SAN JOSE LAGOON.  IT IS ON LAND OWNED BY FELIX RODRIQUEZ.  APPROACHED FROM RIO PIEDRAS BY RD. 3 TO KMS. 3.9.  FOLLOW DIRT RD. N TO ITS END AT A BARBED WIRE FENCE, CROSS BY TRAIL TO RD. GOING W TO A GROUP OF HOUSES AT THE FOOT OF HILL.  STATION MARK--STANDARD B.M. TABLET STAMPED SAN JOSE 1939 CEMENTED TO NATURAL ROCK.  SIGNAL--POLE ON 1- BY 4-INCH SAWED LUMBER WITH FLAGS AND TARGET CENTERED OVER STATION MARK.  R. M. NO. 1--R.R. SPIKE FIXED ON NATURAL ROCK 4.27 METERS W OF STATION.  R. M. NO. 2--STANDARD NAIL AND WASHER CEMENTED TO NATURAL ROCK 9.48 METERS NE OF STATION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1962)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1962 (MLO) THE STATION WAS RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED.  THE DISK HAS BEEN BROKEN OFF OF THE STEM.  R. M. NO. 1 WAS RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED.  THE MEASUREMENT FROM THE CENTER OF THE STEM TO THIS R. M. CHECKED.  R. M. NO. 2 WAS RECOVERED AS BEING A ONE-INCH DEEP HOLE IN ROCK WITH IMPRESSION OF WASHER AROUND TOP.  THE MEASUREMENT FROM THE CENTER OF THE STEM TO THE CENTER OF THIS HOLE CHECKED.  ANGLES FROM THE STATION TO BOTH R. M.S CHECKED THE ORIGINAL DESCRIPTION.  A 1/2-INCH IRON ROD CEMENTED IN NATURAL ROCK IS 2.67 METERS FROM STATION IN TRUE AZIMUTH 151 DEG 54 MIN.                            STATION RECOVERY (1964)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1964 (GWM) ABOUT 3 KMS E OF RIO PIEDRAS ON THE TOP OF A LONE LIMESTONE HILL NEAR THE NW CORNER OF FENCED GOLF COURSE.  THE SHAFT OF A BRASS TABLET CEMENTED IN ROCK.  AN OUTLINE OF THE TABLET IS VISIBLE.  RM 1 IS A RAILROAD SPIKE IN ROCK 4.27 METERS W OF THE STATION.  RM 2 IS A 1 IN DEEP HOLE IN ROCK WITH AN IMPRESSION OF A WASHER AROUND THE TOP 7.485 METERS NE OF THE STATION.  THERE IS A 2 INCH IRON ROD IN ROCK 2.704 METERS FROM THE STATION IN AZIMUTH 151 DEG 54 MIN.  TO REACH FOLLOW HIGHWAY 3 EAST 1.2 MILES.  FROM THE TOWN HOUSE, TURN LEFT (N) ON CALLE NO. 36 AND FOLLOW 0.9 MILE TO FOOT OF HILL.  CLIMB HILL N AND W BY TRAIL TO TOP AND THE STATION.
markers.setting: SET IN ROCK OUTCROP
markers.stability: MOST RELIABLE AND EXPECTED TO HOLDPOSITION/ELEVATION WELL

markers.description: BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1934 STATION IS ONLY CHIMNEY ON A LARGE WHITE CEMENT HOUSE BELONGING TO PARTY BY NAME OF WEYMOUTH, WHO LIVES IN SAN JUAN.  IT IS ALONG THE ROAD BETWEEN COROZOL AND OROCOVIS AND NEAR TOP OF DIVIDE GOING S FROM COROZOL.

BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1964 (GWM) STATION RECOVERED CONSIST OF A BLOCK OF CONCRETE, TRIANGULAR SHAPED ABOUT 10 FEET ON A SIDE AND PROJECTING ABOUT 2 FEET ABOVE THE WATER, IN THE CENTER OF A LONG SUBMERGED CORAL REEF ON LARGO SHOAL.  THE BEACON HAS BEEN DESTROYED.  THERE IS NO EVIDENCE OF ANYTHING MARKING THE STATION.  THREE RUSTY ENDS OF PIPE ABOUT 4 FEET APART MARK THE LOCATION OF THE BEACON THAT WAS ONCE OVER THE CONCRETE PLATFORM.

BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1899 (WCH) STATION IS SITUATED ON A POINT ABOUT 4 MILES E OF, AND ABOUT 7 MILES W OF, FIGUERA LIGHTHOUSE.  IT IS IN A GROVE OF COCOANUT TREES ABOUT 100 METERS BACK FROM THE BEACH.  STATION IS MARKED BY A 2-INCH GALVANIZED-IRON PIPE 3 FEET LONG, EMBEDDED IN CEMENT.  A TRIANGLE IS MARKED IN THE SURFACE OF THE CEMENT SURROUNDING THE PIPE.  A TRIPOD AND SCAFFOLD 46 FEET HIGH WERE ERECTED OVER THIS STATION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1906)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1906 (RLF) STATION WAS SEARCHED FOR BUT COULD NOT BE FOUND.  THE NATIVES ASSERT THAT IT WAS WASHED AWAY BY A HURRICANE, YET NO HURRICANE HAS BEEN RECORDED IN PUERTO RICO SINCE THIS STATION WAS ESTABLISHED.                            STATION RECOVERY (1926)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1926 (GCM) NOT RECOVERED.  ORIGINAL STATION SET IN SAND NEAR BEACH.  EVIDENTLY WASHED OUT.                            STATION RECOVERY (1966)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JJL) THE OLD STATION MARK WAS DESTROYED AND A NEW STATION, REFERENCE MARK 1 AND REFERENCE MARK 2 WERE ESTABLISHED IN THE SAME GENERAL LOCATION.  FOR A COMPLETE NEW DESCRIPTION SEE LAS MAREAS 2.                            STATION RECOVERY (2001)  RECOVERY NOTE BY FEDERAL AVIATION ADMINISTRATION 2001 (AC) MARK NOT FOUND
markers.setting: OBJECT SURROUNDED BY MASS OF CONCRETE

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JJL) THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 5 MILES SOUTHWEST OF GUAYAMA, 5 MILES EAST-SOUTHEAST OF CENTRAL AGUIRRE, 1 MILE WEST-SOUTHWEST OF LAS MAREAS AND ON A POINT OF LAND LOCALLY KNOWN AS PUNTA OLA GRANDE.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE SOUTHWEST CORNER OF THE PLAZA IN GUAYAMA, GO WEST AND SOUTHWEST ON HIGHWAY 3 FOR 2.7 MILES TO A SIDE ROAD LEFT.  TURN LEFT AND GO SOUTH AND SOUTHWEST ON HIGHWAY 710 FOR 2.15 MILES TO A WOODEN GATE ON THE LEFT AND A TRACK ROAD LEADING TO THE LEFT AT KILOMETER POST KM 3 HM 3.  BEAR TO THE LEFT, PASS THROUGH THE GATE AND GO SOUTHWEST ON THE TRACK ROAD THAT WINDS THROUGH THE PALM GROVE TO THE FURTHER MOST POINT ON THE BEACH AND THE STATION.  THE STATION MARK IS A STANDARD DISK, STAMPED LAS MAREAS 2 1965, SET IN THE TOP OF A 12-INCH SQUARE CONCRETE MONUMENT THAT PROJECTS 1 INCH.  REFERENCE MARK 1 IS A STANDARD DISK, STAMPED LAS MAREAS 2 NO 1 1965, SET IN THE TOP OF A 12-INCH DIAMETER CONCRETE MONUMENT THAT IS FLUSH WITH THE SURFACE OF THE GROUND.  REFERENCE MARK 2 IS A STANDARD DISK, STAMPED LAS MAREAS 2 NO 2 1965, SET IN THE TOP OF A 12-INCH DIAMETER CONCRETE MONUMENT THAT PROJECTS 3 INCHES.  THERE WAS NO SUITABLE LOCATION TO ESTABLISHED AN AZIMUTH MARK.                            STATION RECOVERY (1975)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1975 (RMB) REFERENCE MARK 1 WAS RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION AS DESCRIBED.  THE STATION AND ITS CONCRETE MONUMENT HAVE BEEN LOST TO EROSION AND WERE FOUND LYING ON THEIR SIDE IN THE SURF.  THE UNDERGROUND MARK WAS NOT SEARCHED FOR.  REFERENCE MARK 2 WAS SEARCHED FOR BUT NOT FOUND.  THE BEACH HAS APPARENTLY ERODED AT LEAST FIVE FEET FURTHER INSHORE.  NEAR THE STATION THERE ARE SEVERAL DIRT ROADS LEADING INTO THE PALM GROVE.  TAKE THE LAST ROAD TO THE WEST AND CONTINUE WEST ALONG THE BEACH TO ABOUT 50 FEET BEFORE THE END OF THE ROAD.  REFERENCE MARK 1 IS IN LINE WITH THE SECOND ROW OF PALMS INSHORE, 30 FEET FROM THE HIGH WATER LINE, AND 19.9 FEET NORTH OF THE TWO PALMS CLOSE TOGETHER.  IT IS 119.4 FEET EAST OF THE LAST VERTICAL POST AT THE EAST END OF A 6 FOOT STEEL FENCE WHICH EXTENDS TO THE ENTRANCE OF LAS MAREAS HARBOR.  THREE 4 INCH TRIANGLES WERE BLAZED IN PALM TREES 20.1 FEET WEST, 22.5 FEET NORTH, AND 2.6 FEET EAST OF REFERENCE MARK 1.                            STATION RECOVERY (2001)  RECOVERY NOTE BY FEDERAL AVIATION ADMINISTRATION 2001 (AC) MARK NOT FOUND

markers.description: BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1934 ON A PROMINENT HILL SE OF LAS MARIAS ON BO. CARROTE.  IT SPURS N OF MAIN RIDGE ABOUT 3 MILES FROM IT AND FROM THE MARICAO-INDIERA ROAD.  LEAVE CAR NEAR D. JOSE ORANCH STORE AND FARMHOUSE, ABOUT 200 METERS FROM KILOMETER 28 H 6.5.  STATION IS ON LIMITS OF LAND OWNED BY ANTONIO FRONTERA, FERNANDO GUILLOT, AND ANTONIO RULLAN.  IT IS COVERED BY WOOD ON S AND W SIDES.  FROM ORANCHS FARM FOLLOW HORSE TRAIL TO ANTONIO FRONTERAS FARM AND THEN CONTINUE NW ON A TRAIL ACROSS GRASSY LAND TO THE TOP OF THE MOUNTAIN KNOWN AS CARROTE DE LAS MARIAS.  STATION MARK IS A STANDARD U.S.G.S. BENCH MARK TABLET SET ON A ROCK SURROUNDED BY A CONCRETE FLOOR OF AN OLD HAYSTACK.                            STATION RECOVERY (2012)  RECOVERY NOTE BY POLYTECHNIC UNIVERSITY OF PUERTO RICO 2012 (CCV) RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED.

markers.description: BY ANDREGG INCORPORATED 1995 (DJR) TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE POST OFFICE IN LAS MARIAS, GO EASTERLY ON HIGHWAY PR 124, 4.4 MILES (7.1 KM) TO KILOMETER POST 6.8 ON THE WEST SIDE OF ROAD.  TURN RIGHT (WEST) ON PAVED ROAD AND GO UPHILL ON PAVED ROAD SOUTHWESTERLY 0.7 MILES (1.1 KM) TO THE STATION ON THE RIGHT JUST BEFORE INVERTED Y INTERSECTION WITH A ROAD TO THE NORTHEAST THE STATION IS LOCATED 5.8 METERS (19.0 FT) NORTH OF EDGE OF PAVEMENT OF ACCESS ROAD, 2.5 METERS (8.2 FT) SOUTH OF EDGE OF PAVEMENT OF THE SIDE ROAD, AND 7.6 METERS (24.9 FT) EAST OF POWER POLE  THE STATION IS 1 METER (3.3 FT) SOUTH OF A CARSONITE SURVEY MARKER WITNESS POST  THE STATION IS A 3-1/4 INCH BRASS CAP STAMPED CENTRO DE RECAUDACION DE INGRESSOS MUNICIPALES, PUERTO RICO GPS CONTROL, C.R.I.M., UNLAWFUL TO DISTURB, LAS MARIAS 2, SET ATOP A 9/16 INCH STAINLESS STEEL ROD DRIVEN TO REFUSAL AND COVERED FLUSH WITH THE GROUND BY AN ALUMINUM COVER EPOXYED ONTO A 6 INCH SCHEDULE 40 PVC PIPE SET IN CONCRETE INSIDE AND OUT                            STATION RECOVERY (2011)  RECOVERY NOTE BY POLYTECHNIC UNIVERSITY OF PUERTO RICO 2011 (ALL) THE DESCRIPTION IS ADECUATE, THE DISTANCE FROM ACCESS ROAD 2.5 METERS(8.2 FT), CHANGE IT TO 2.68 METERS (8.8 FT). ADD, AT WEST BOUND 6.70 METERS (22 FT) WITH A CONCRETE FENCE COLUMN. BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1934 STATION IS WHITE CROSS ON STEEPLE. markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1900 (SF) STATION IS ABOUT 1/4 MILE FROM SAN ANTONIO RAILROAD STATION AT THE WESTERN END OF SAN JUAN, ON LAND OWNED BY DON JOSE ROSE PONS AND ABOUT 40 METERS W OF HIS RESIDENCE AND JUST OUTSIDE OF A WIRE GARDEN FENCE.  WHERE THE STATION IS LOCATED IS A STONE POST 8-1/2 BY 8-1/2 INCHES SQUARE, COMING TO A POINT ON TOP, WITH THE TOP 9 INCHES ABOVE THE GROUND.  WHEN THE STATION WAS FIRST LOCATED THIS STONE WAS SUPPOSED TO MARK THE OLD SPANISH TRIANGULATION STATION CALLED LATIMER, BUT LATER THREE SIMILAR STONES WERE FOUND, RANGING S, SE AND E OF THE STATION.  MR. PONS SAID THESE STONES WERE PLACED BY SPANISH ARMY OFFICERS AND WERE USED AS RANGE MARKS.  A HOLE WAS DRILLED IN THE TOP OF THE CENTER POST AT ITS APEX, IN THIS HOLE WAS PLACED A U.S.C. AND G.S. METAL STATION MARK, THEN IT WAS FILLED IN WITH PORTLAND CEMENT.  THE TOP OF THIS MARK IS COUNTERSUNK AND HAS U.S.C. AND G.S. CUT ON IT.  IN THE CENTER OF THE TOP OF THE MARK IS A FINE PUNCH HOLE WHICH MARKS THE CENTER OF THE STATION.  THIS CENTER IS REFERRED TO 4 GLASS BOTTLES BURIED 18 INCHES IN THE GROUND, RANGING N, E, S AND W AND 2 FEET DISTANT.  IN DIGGING THE HOLES TO PLACE THE BOTTLES, IT WAS DISCOVERED THAT THE STONE POSTS REST ON A CEMENT PIER ABOUT 4 FEET SQUARE AND HOW FAR BELOW 18 INCHES WE DID NOT ASCERTAIN.
markers.setting: SET IN PREFABRICATED CONCRETE POST IMBEDDED IN GROUND
