markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1901 (JBB) STATION IS ROCK ABOUT 1 FOOT OUT OF WATER, ABOUT 1-1/2 MILES E BY N OF DOG.                            STATION RECOVERY (1964)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1964 (GWM) IT IS ABOUT 1.3 MILES NE OF ISLA CABEZA DE PERRO AND THE NAME OF THE ROCK ON THE CHART IS ROCA LAVANDERA DEL OESTA.  A REVISED DESCRIPTION FOLLOWS--  ROCK THAT BARES ABOUT 1 FOOT, ABOUT 1.3 MILES NE ISLA CABEZA DE PERRO.  IT IS NAMED ROCA LAVANDERA DE OESTA.

BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1900 (WCH) STATION IS THE TALL RED BRICK STACK OF A LARGE SUGAR MILL IN THE FIRST COVE E OF PORT MULA, N COAST OF VIEQUES.                            STATION RECOVERY (1903)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1903 (RLF) STATION STILL EXISTS AS DESCRIBED.  THIS SMOKESTACK IS A PART OF STE. MARIE (ST. MARYS) SUGAR MILL.                            STATION RECOVERY (1964)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1964 (GWM) THE BASE OF STACK WAS RECOVERED ALTHOUGH THE STACK IS DESTROYED, LEAVING ONLY THE BOTTOM THREE (3) FEET OF BASE.                            STATION RECOVERY (1970)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US MARINE CORPS 1970 STATION PRESUMED DESTROYED AS THE SMOKESTACK NO LONGER EXISTS.

BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1901 (JEM) THIS STATION IS ON A HIGH HILL WHICH WAS FORMERLY CALLED CEM DE BAHAN, FROM THE NAME OF ITS FORMER OWNER A SENOR DE BAZUN, BUT HE SOLD THE PROPERTY TO A JULIANO LEBRON AND THE LATTERS SON INSISTED THAT THE HILL WAS NOW RENO DE LEBRON.  THE NAME GIVEN IS IMMATERIAL, NEITHER ONE WOULD, IN ANY PROBABILITY, BE RECOGNIZED A MILE AWAY FROM THE STATION.  IN PUERTO RICO THE NATIVES DO NOT PAY MUCH ATTENTION TO THE NAMES OF STREAMS OR HILLS, AND MOST OF THE TIME NATIVE COURTESY IMPELS THEM TO GIVE US A NAME ON THE SPUR OF THE MOMENT BECAUSE THEY FIND THAT WE THINK ONE SHOULD BE KNOWN, NOT THAT THE PLACE HAD ONE BEFORE.  FOR A STATION MARK WE DUG AND DRILLED A HOLE IN THE ROCKY TOP FOR A PIECE OF 2-INCH IRON PIPE WHICH IS SUNK TO WITHIN ABOUT 1-1/2 INCHES FROM ITS TOP (13-1/2 INCHES ARE UNDERGROUND) AND CEMENTED INTO PLACE.  IN PREPARING THE STATION CENTER THE HOLE DUG OUT WAS PRETTY LARGE BUT THE PIPE WAS SET IN THE CORNER NEAREST TO MALA PASCUA.  THE SIDE OF THE TUBE BEING PRESSED UP TO THE S EDGE OF THE HOLE AND THE OTHER SIDES BEING SECURED, FIRST WITH WELL-RAMMED STONE, AND THEN BY CEMENT.  THREE TREES WERE BLAZED FOR WITNESS MARKS AND THE DISTANCES MEASURED TO THEM.  ONE IS A DAJO TREE ABOUT NNW.  THIS TREE DIVIDES INTO TWO PARTS ABOUT 3 FEET ABOVE ITS ROOTS.  THE E SECTION IS ABOUT 4 INCHES IN DIAMETER AND THE BLAZE ON ITS FACE IS 13.18 FEET FROM THE STATION CENTER.  THE SECOND BLAZE WAS MADE ON PALO DE VACA STUMP WHICH GREW IN SOUTHWARD FROM STATION.  IT IS 5 FEET TO THE E OF A LINE FROM THE STATION TO POINT VIENTO 2.  THIS PALO DE VACA IS ABOUT 10 INCHES IN DIAMETER, HAS A LIGHT-COLORED TRUNK AND THE TOP WAS CUT OFF BY US WHEN CLEARING THE HILLTOP.  THE STUMP IS ABOUT 4 FEET HIGH AND THE BLAZE IS 13.36 FEET FROM THE STATION MARK.  THE THIRD BLAZE IS ON A GOOJEO TREE E OF THE SIGNAL.  THIS TREE IS ABOUT 10 INCHES IN DIAMETER AND HAS LOST ITS TOP.  THE LENGTH OF THE TRUNK OF THE TREE IS ABOUT 20 FEET.  THE BLAZE IS 20.81 FEET FROM STATION CENTER.  THE DAJO TREE REFERRED TO ABOVE WAS CUT DOWN TO WITHIN 3 FEET OF THE GROUND.  THIS WAS DONE BECAUSE IT MADE A BAD BACKGROUND FOR LEBRON WHEN OBSERVED FROM MALA PASCUA.  TO REACH LEBRON ONE SHOULD FOLLOW THE ROAD BETWEEN MAUNABO AND GUAYAMA TO THE PLANTATION HOUSE OF DON BERNALDO MERLE (PRONOUNCED MU LA) A GENTLEMAN OF FRENCH EXTRACTION WHO SPEAKS ENGLISH QUITE WELL.  LOOKING INLAND FROM DON MERLES PORCH, LEBRON HILL IS A HIGH WOODED SUMMIT WHICH TOWERS ABOVE THE VALLEY TO THE NORTHWARD, HAVING A CLEARED SPACE OF SEVERAL ACRES ON ITS SOUTH SLOPE A SHORT DISTANCE BELOW THE TOP.  SENOR MERLE CAN POINT OUT THE HILL AS I SHOWED HIM THE SIGNAL FROM HIS FRONT DOOR. TO REACH IT ONE SHOULD FOLLOW THE ROUGH CART ROAD WHICH RUNS INLAND FROM THE MERLE PLANTATION (THE ROAD IS ONLY SUITABLE FOR OXCARTS, SADDLE HORSES AND PEDESTRIANS) TO THE HOUSE OF JULIANO LEBRON.  THE WALK FROM MERLES TO LEBRONS WILL TAKE ABOUT 25 MINUTES AT A MODERATE PACE.  THE SETTLEMENT NEAR THE SCHOOLHOUSE ON THIS ROAD IS CALLED JACOBY (OR JACABOA).  IN GOING TO SENOR LEBRONS A MOUNTAIN STREAM MUST BE CROSSED AT THREE DIFFERENT PLACES.  THIS CAN BE DONE ON STEPPING STONES, DRY SHOD, UNLESS THE STREAM IS SWOLLEN BY HEAVY RAINS.  AT LEBRONS EITHER OF HIS TWO SONS (MARCIAL OR VINCENTE) CAN BE HAD, WHO WILL TAKE ANYONE TO THE SIGNAL. A TRAIL STARTS FROM LEBRONS HOUSE, WHICH GOES TO THE SUMMIT, BUT IT IS EXTREMELY STEEP AND AFTER THE SECOND SUMMIT IS REACHED, A HORSE CANNOT BE USED ON IT, AS IT LEADS THROUGH DENSE BRUSH, OVER FALLEN AND MATTED TREES, AND UP PRECIPITOUS ASCENTS WHICH ARE ONLY TO BE PASSED BY MEN ON FOOT.  THE TOP OF THE HILL WAS DENSELY COVERED WITH TREES AND BUSHES.  MANY OF THESE SAN CYNACO HAD BEEN CLEANED OUT AND WE CHOPPED OUT A GREAT DEAL OF WHAT WAS LEFT.  THE TOP HAS A THIN COVERING OF SOIL BUT IS IN GENERAL PRETTY ROCKY.  AT THE STATION ONE CAN SEE THE S END OF MAUNABO VILLAGE, POINT TUNA LIGHTHOUSE, POINT VIENTO, FIGURAS LIGHTHOUSE, ARROYO, CORAZON, AND CAJO DE MUERTAS.  THE GENERAL DIRECTION OF THE SUMMIT OF THE RIDGE IS N-S.  THE SIGNAL WAS AN 18-FOOT PITCH PINE POLE BRACED BY 4 STRUTS WHICH WERE ALSO CONNECTED WITH THE CENTER POLE BY CROSS PIECES NEAR THEIR FOOT.
markers.setting: SET IN ROCK OUTCROP
markers.stability: MOST RELIABLE AND EXPECTED TO HOLDPOSITION/ELEVATION WELL

markers.description: BY US MARINE CORPS 1966 (JJL) STATION MARK IS A U.S. MARINE CORPS ARTILLERY DISK, STAMPED LEECH, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN OUTCROPPING BEDROCK THAT PROJECTS THREE FEET.  THIS MARK WAS USED AS A REFERENCE MARK FOR STATION DOLPHIN HEAD.
markers.setting: UNSPECIFIED SETTING

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JJL) THE STATION IS LOCATED ON THE SOUTH SIDE OF LEVITTOWN AND ABOUT 1/4 MILE SOUTHWEST OF HIGHWAY 165.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE NORTHEAST CORNER OF THE PLAZA IN CATANO, GO WESTERLY ON HIGHWAY 165 FOR 4.6 MILES TO A SIDE ROAD LEFT.  TURN LEFT AND GO SOUTHWEST AND WEST FOR 0.4 MILE TO THE STATION.  THE WATER TANK IS A ROUND STEEL STRUCTURE, PAINTED A LIGHT BLUE-GREEN AND IT IS SUPPORTED BY 10 LEGS.  THE WATER TANK IS APPROXIMATELY 180 FEET HIGH.  POINT INTERSECTED IS THE RED OBSTRUCTION LIGHT ATOP AND CENTER OF THE WATER TANK.
PTIVE TEXT AVAILABLE.

BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1965 (JJL) THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 6 MILES NORTHEAST OF FAJARDO ON THE CAPE SAN JUAN LIGHTHOUSE.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE FAJARDO PLAZA, GO EAST FOR 1 BLOCK, TURN LEFT AND GO NORTH ON HIGHWAY 195 FOR 0.25 MILE TO THE JUNCTION WITH HIGHWAY 184.  TURN RIGHT AND GO EAST ON HIGHWAY 195 FOR 0.3 MILE TO A SIDE ROAD ON THE LEFT.  TURN LEFT AND GO NORTH ON HIGHWAY 987 FOR 2.6 MILES TO A Y FORK.  TAKE THE LEFT FORK AND CONTINUE NORTH ON A PAVED ROAD FOR 0.45 MILE TO A Y FORK.  TAKE THE LEFT FORK AND GO NORTHERLY AS PER SIGN U.S. COAST GUARD CAPE SAN JUAN LORSTA, FOR 2.5 MILES TO A Y FORK AND A GATE.  TAKE THE LEFT FORK, PASS THROUGH THE GATE AND GO EASTERLY ON A DIRT ROAD FOR 1.35 MILES TO A FORK AND A CONCRETE WATER RESERVOIR.  (TO REACH THE AZIMUTH MARK FROM THIS POINT, TAKE THE RIGHT FORK AND CONTINUE EAST FOR 200 FEET TO THE MARK ON THE LEFT, NORTH SIDE OF THE ROAD.) TAKE THE LEFT FORK AND GO NORTH ON A PAVED ROAD FOR 0.35 MILES TO THE LIGHT HOUSE AND THE STATION ON THE UPPER LEVEL.  THE STATION MARK IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED LIGHTHOUSE 1965, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN THE OUTER WALK WAY OF THE LIGHT HOUSE.  IT IS 1 FOOT NORTHEAST OF THE GUARD RAIL AND 2 FEET SOUTHWEST OF THE DOOR.  REFERENCE MARK 1 IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED LIGHTHOUSE NO 1 1965, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A CONCRETE WALL WHICH IS LOCATED IN ABOUT THE CENTER OF THE ROOF OF THE COAST GUARD BUILDING.  IT IS 21 FEET NORTH OF THE SOUTH OUTER WALL OF THE BUILDING AND 19 FEET WEST OF THE EAST OUTER WALL OF THE BUILDING.  THE MARK PROJECTS 3 FEET ABOVE THE ROOF.  REFERENCE MARK 2 IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED LIGHTHOUSE NO 2 1965, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN THE CONCRETE WALL WHICH IS LOCATED ABOUT IN THE CENTER OF THE ROOF OF THE COAST GUARD BUILDING.  IT IS 20 FEET SOUTH OF THE NORTH WALL OF THE BUILDING AND 19 FEET WEST OF THE EAST WALL OF THE BUILDING.  THE MARK PROJECTS 3 FEET ABOVE THE ROOF.  THE AZIMUTH MARK IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED LIGHTHOUSE 1965, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN THE CONCRETE FOUNDATION OF THE FENCE WHICH SURROUNDS A CONCRETE RESERVOIR.  IT IS 6.5 FEET WEST OF THE EAST FENCE CORNER POST.                            STATION RECOVERY (1977)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1977 (WFP) STATION, REFERENCE MARKS 1, 2 AND THE AZIMUTH MARK WERE RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED IN GOOD CONDITION.  AIRLINE DISTANCE AND DIRECTION FROM NEAREST TOWN 6 MILES NE OF FAJARDO ON THE CAPE SAN JUAN LIGHTHOUSE.
markers.setting: SET IN A PAVEMENT SUCH AS STREET, SIDEWALK, CURB, ETC.
markers.stability: MARK OF QUESTIONABLE OR UNKNOWN STABILITY

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1941 (RLS) STATION IS ABOUT 1-1/4 MILES SE OF NAGUABO PLAYA, ON POINT LIMA, WITHIN THE PROPOSED BOUNDARY OF THE ROOSEVELT ROADS NAVAL RESERVATION.  THE HILL ON THE POINT IS HEAVILY WOODED EXCEPT FOR THE LOWER PART OF THE N SLOPE AND A SMALL CLEARING AT THE TOP. THE STATION IS IN THE SMALL CLEARING ON THE NEARLY FLAT TOP OF THE HILL, AND PROJECTS ABOUT 8 INCHES ABOVE GROUND.  THE ELEVATION OF THE STATION IS ABOUT 80.4 METERS.  STATION AND REFERENCE MARKS ARE STANDARD BRONZE DISKS SET IN CONCRETE, AS DESCRIBED IN NOTES 1A AND 11A.  THERE IS NO UNDERGROUND MARK.  REFERENCE MARK NO.1 IS AT THE N EDGE OF THE TOP OF THE HILL, AT THE N EDGE OF A WAGON ROAD ALONG THE N EDGE OF THE CLEARING, 8.3 METERS NE OF THE TREE WITH THE WITNESS MARK, 1.07 METERS LOWER THAN THE STATION, AND PROJECTS 6 INCHES ABOVE GROUND.  REFERENCE MARK NO.2 IS 3 METERS NW OF A LARGE BOULDER AT THE SE EDGE OF THE TOP OF THE HILL, 16.1 METERS SSW OF THE TREE WITH THE WITNESS MARK, 0.30 METER LOWER THAN THE STATION, AND PROJECTS 6 INCHES ABOVE GROUND.  THE WITNESS MARK IS A TRIANGULAR BLAZE ON THE W SIDE OF A 30-INCH TAMARINDO TREE, 1-1/2 METERS ABOVE THE GROUND.  THE TREE IS THE LARGEST AND HIGHEST ON TOP OF THE HILL.                            STATION RECOVERY (1961)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1961 (MLO) STATION MARK AND REFERENCE MARKS WERE NOT FOUND.  NO TRIANGULAR BLAZE WAS FOUND ALTHOUGH A 30-INCH TAMARINDO TREE WAS SITUATED ON TOP OF THE HILL.  A STANDARD C. AND G. S. BRONZE TABLET STAMPED LIMA 2 1941 WAS FOUND IN THE CENTER OF A CONCRETE FOUNDATION OF A TWO-STORY CONCRETE BUILDING ON TOP OF THE HILL.  THIS MARK WAS ABOUT 9 METERS FROM THE TAMARINDO TREE AND IN ABOUT THE APPROXIMATE AZIMUTH.  NO DESCRIPTION WAS FOUND THAT WOULD PROPERLY FIT THIS LIMA 2 1941.                            STATION RECOVERY (1965)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1965 (JJL) THE STATION MARK AND REFERENCE MARK NO. 2 WERE RECOVERED AND FOUND IN GOOD CONDITION.  A THOROUGH SEARCH WAS MADE FOR REFERENCE MARK NO. 1 BUT IT WAS NOT RECOVERED.  A CONCRETE BUILDING HAS BEEN CONSTRUCTED OVER THE STATION MARK WITH PROVISIONS MADE SO THAT THE POINT COULD BE PROJECTED TO THE ROOF OF THE BUILDING.  THE POINT WAS PROJECTED TO A PLUMBING BENCH AND A NEW STATION MARK WAS SET IN THE ROOF PRECISELY OVER THE ORIGINAL STATION MARK. REFERENCE MARK NO. 2 IS NOT VISIBLE FROM THE ORIGINAL STATION MARK NOR FROM THE NEW STATION MARK.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 3 AND REFERENCE MARK NO. 4 WERE ESTABLISHED.  A COMPLETE DESCRIPTION FOLLOWS--  THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 3-1/2 MILES NORTHEAST OF PLAYA DE HUMACAO, 1-1/2 MILES SOUTHEAST OF PLAYA DE NAGUABO AND ON THE HIGHEST POINT OF WHAT IS KNOWN AS PUNTA LIMA.  THE LAND IS NOW USED BY THE CAMPAMENTO PUNTA LIMA AND THE PRISON OFFICIALS SHOULD BE NOTIFIED BEFORE VISITING THE STATION.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE JUNCTION OF HIGHWAYS 3 AND 28 THAT IS 1 MILE SOUTHEAST OF NAGUABO, GO EASTERLY ON HIGHWAY 3 FOR 0.9 MILE TO A POINT WHERE THE ROAD TURNS LEFT IN PLAYA DE NAGUABO AND A SIDE ROAD RIGHT.  TURN RIGHT AND GO EASTERLY FOR 1.1 MILES TO THE ENTRANCE TO CAMPAMENTO PUNTA LIMA.  PASS THROUGH THE ENTRANCE AND GO EASTERLY FOR 0.3 MILE TO A Y-FORK.  (TO REACH THE ADMINISTRATION BUILDING FROM THIS POINT, TAKE THE LEFT FORK AND GO EAST FOR 0.3 MILE TO THE BUILDING.) TAKE THE RIGHT FORK AND GO SOUTH FOR 0.05 MILE TO A Y-FORK.  TAKE THE LEFT FORK AND GO SOUTH, EAST AND NORTH FOR 0.55 MILE TO A Y-FORK.  TAKE THE LEFT FORK AND GO NORTHWEST FOR 0.1 MILE TO THE TOP OF THE HILL, THE CONCRETE BUILDING AND THE STATION.  THE ORIGINAL STATION MARK, STAMPED LIMA 2 1941, IS A STANDARD DISK SET IN THE APPROXIMATE CENTER OF THE CONCRETE FLOOR OF THE CONCRETE BUILDING.  THE NEW STATION MARK, STAMPED LIMA 3 1941 1965, IS A STANDARD DISK SET IN CONCRETE IN THE APPROXIMATE CENTER OF THE ROOF OF THE CONCRETE BUILDING.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 2, STAMPED LIMA 2 NO 2 1941, IS A STANDARD DISK SET IN THE TOP OF A 12-INCH SQUARE CONCRETE MONUMENT THAT PROJECTS 6 INCHES.  (NOTE 11A)  REFERENCE MARK NO. 3, STAMPED LIMA 3 NO 3 1941 1965, IS A STANDARD DISK CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN THE CONCRETE WALL ON THE ROOF OF THE CONCRETE BUILDING.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 4, STAMPED LIMA 3 NO 4 1941 1965, IS A STANDARD DISK CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN THE CONCRETE WALL ON THE ROOF OF THE CONCRETE BUILDING.  AIRLINE DISTANCE AND DIRECTION FROM NEAREST TOWN 1-1/2 MILES SOUTHEAST OF PLAYA DE NAGUABO.                            STATION RECOVERY (1967)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1967 (SCM) STATION RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED.                            STATION RECOVERY (1994)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US POWER SQUADRON 1994 MARK NOT FOUND.
markers.setting: SET IN TOP OF CONCRETE MONUMENT

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1904 (JCL) THIS STATION WAS LOCATED NEAR THE STORM-WATER LINE, ON THE FIRST GRAVELLY POINT E OF PUNTA MOLINO AND ABOUT 1 MILE DISTANT.  IT IS ALSO ABOUT 1/4 MILE FROM A LIME-KILN SITUATED ON A BLUFF NEAR THE SHORE.  BACK OF THE STATION, INSHORE, ARE THICK BRUSH AND CACTI.  STATION IS MARKED BY A 2- BY 4-INCH STUB DRIVEN INTO THE GROUND ABOUT 2 FEET, LEAVING ABOUT 8 INCHES EXPOSED.  SPIKES WERE DRIVEN INTO THE TOP AND SIDES TO IDENTIFY THE STAKE.  IT WAS SURROUNDED, ABOVE AND BELOW THE SURFACE OF THE GROUND, WITH A CONCRETE OF MORTAR AND LARGE GRAVEL.  OVER THIS POINT A TRIPOD SIGNAL WAS ERECTED.

BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1941 (RLS) STATION IS ABOUT 1 MILE SE OF NAGUABO PLAYA, ON A SMALL BLUNT POINT KNOWN LOCALLY AS PUNTA PERLA AND IS THE FIRST POINT W OF AND ACROSS LIMA BAY FROM POINT LIMA.  (THE PROPOSED W LIMITS OF THE ROOSEVELT ROADS NAVAL RESERVATION LIES BETWEEN POINT LIMA AND PUNTA PERLA.) THE STATION IS ABOUT 25 METERS S OF THE HIGHEST POINT OF THE HILL ON THE POINT, 42.0 METERS NE OF A 12-INCH ALMACIGO TREE AT THE EDGE OF THE BLUFF AT THE S END OF THE POINT, ABOUT 10 METERS W OF THE EDGE OF THE BLUFF ON THE E SIDE OF THE POINT, AND PROJECTS 10 INCHES ABOVE GROUND.  THE ELEVATION OF THE STATION IS ABOUT 31.9 METERS.  STATION MARK IS A STANDARD BRONZE DISK SET IN CONCRETE, AS DESCRIBED IN NOTE 1A.  THERE IS NO UNDERGROUND MARK.  REFERENCE MARK NO.1 IS A STANDARD DISK SET IN CONCRETE, IN A DEPRESSION ON TOP OF A LARGE BOULDER IN A GROUP OF BOULDERS ON THE W SLOPE OF THE HILL, 0.17 METER LOWER THAN THE STATION, AND ABOUT 3 FEET ABOVE GROUND.  REFERENCE MARK NO.2 IS A STANDARD DISK SET IN CONCRETE, IN A DEPRESSION IN A LARGE BOULDER IN A GROUP OF BOULDERS ON THE E SLOPE OF THE HILL, 2.74 METERS LOWER THAN THE STATION, AND ABOUT 3 FEET ABOVE GROUND.                            STATION RECOVERY (1961)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1961 (MLO) STATION MARK RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 1 WAS RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 2 WAS RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED.  ALL MARKS APPEAR TO BE IN GOOD CONDITION.
markers.setting: SET IN TOP OF CONCRETE MONUMENT
markers.stability: MAY HOLD, BUT OF TYPE COMMONLY SUBJECT TOSURFACE MOTION

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JWC) THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 7 MILES SOUTH-SOUTHWEST OF LAJAS, 3.5 MILES WEST OF PARGUERA, 1 MILE NORTHWEST OF THE ISLAND OF GUAYACAN AND ON A GRASS AND BRUSH COVERED HILL WHICH IS ON THE PROPERTY OF MR. DELFIN RODRIQUIZ CARLOS WHO LIVES IN SABANA GRANDE.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE SOUTHEAST CORNER OF THE PLAZA IN IAJAS.  GO SOUTH FOR 1 BLOCK.  TURN RIGHT AND GO SOUTHWEST ON HIGHWAY 101 FOR 2.35 MILES TO ITS JUNCTION WITH HIGHWAY 303.  TURN LEFT AND GO SOUTH AND SOUTHWEST ON HIGHWAY 303 FOR 3.75 MILES TO THE END OF THE PAVEMENT.  CONTINUE SOUTHWEST ON A DIRT ROAD FOR 2.05 MILES TO A LOCKED, METAL GATE ON THE LEFT.  (A KEY FOR THE GATE MAY BE OBTAINED FROM THE CARETAKER WHO LIVES 0.5 MILE WEST OF THIS POINT ON THE RIGHT AT A DAIRY FARM).  PASS THROUGH THE GATE AND GO SOUTH ON A NARROW LANE FOR 1.15 MILES TO A WIRE GATE AT A WATER TANK AND A WIND MILL ON THE RIGHT.  PASS THROUGH THE GATE AND CONTINUE SOUTH FOR 0.2 MILE TO THE END OF THE LANE.  TURN LEFT AND GO EAST ON A DIRT ROAD FOR 0.25 MILE TO A REVERSE FORK.  TURN SHARP RIGHT AND GO SOUTHWEST ON A DIRT ROAD FOR 0.1 MILE TO A DIM TRACK ROAD ON THE RIGHT. TURN RIGHT AND GO WEST ON THE TRACK ROAD FOR 0.05 MILE TO THE STATION ON THE HIGHEST POINT OF A LOW HILL.  (NOTE--A 4-WHEEL DRIVE VEHICLE IS REQUIRED TO TRAVEL FROM THE LOCKED GATE TO THE STATION IN WET WEATHER).  THE STATION MARK IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED LLANOS 1966, SET IN THE TOP OF A 12-INCH SQUARE CONCRETE POST THAT IS FLUSH WITH THE GROUND.  REFERENCE MARK 1 IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED LLANOS NO 1 1966, SET IN THE TOP OF A 12-INCH SQUARE CONCRETE POST THAT IS FLUSH WITH THE GROUND AND IS THE SAME ELEVATION AS THE STATION MARK.  REFERENCE MARK 2 IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED LLANOS NO 2 1966, SET IN THE TOP OF A 12-INCH SQUARE CONCRETE POST THAT IS FLUSH WITH THE GROUND AND IS THE SAME ELEVATION AS THE STATION MARK.  NO SUITABLE PLACE WAS FOUND FOR AN AZIMUTH MARK.                            STATION RECOVERY (1968)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1968 (WLM) STATION AND REFERENCE MARKS 1 AND 2 WERE RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.  THE ORIGINAL DESCRIPTION IS ADEQUATE WITH THE FOLLOWING TWO CHANGES--  A.  THE LOCKED GATE IS NO LONGER LOCKED AND THE DAIRY FARM IS NO LONGER OPERATED.  B.  A FOUR-WHEEL DRIVE VEHICLE IS NECESSARY IN ORDER TO TRAVEL FROM THE END OF PAVEMENT TO THE STATION IN ANY WEATHER.                            STATION RECOVERY (1969)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1969 (WLM) THE STATION WAS RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED AND FOUND TO BE IN GOOD CONDITION.
markers.setting: SET IN TOP OF CONCRETE MONUMENT
markers.stability: MAY HOLD, BUT OF TYPE COMMONLY SUBJECT TOSURFACE MOTION

markers.description: BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1934 STATION IS IN BARRIO LLAUREL, WHICH IS TO THE N OF THE TOWN OF ARROYO, ON A RATHER SHRUBBY HILL WITH TREES ON ITS FLANKS.  IT IS ABOUT 6 KILOMETERS FROM THE ROAD.  THIS HILL IS PLAINLY VISIBLE FROM THE ROAD OFF THE TOWN OF ARROYO.  STATION MARK IS A STANDARD U.S.G.S. BENCH MARK SET AND STAMPED LLAUREL, 1934.  REFERENCE MARK NO.1 IS A HOLE DRILLED ON THE HIGHEST BOULDER FOUND ON THE CREST, 11 FEET 10 INCHES DISTANT FROM STATION, IN TRUE AZIMUTH 66 DEG 18 MIN.  REFERENCE MARK NO.2 IS A HOLE DRILLED ON FACE OF HALF BURIED ROCK, 9 FEET 5 INCHES DISTANT FROM STATION, IN TRUE AZIMUTH 109 DEG 48 MIN.  TO REACH THIS STATION GO ON THE CENTRAL LAFAYETTE ROAD UP TO BARRIO LLAUREL AND DRIVE AS FAR AS PERMISSIBLE.  THE TRAIL IS THE CONTINUATION OF THE ROAD.  THE STATION IS A SHORT DISTANCE FROM THE ROAD.                            STATION RECOVERY (1940)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1940 STATION AND R.M.S WERE RECOVERED.  THE TABLET IS STAMPED YAUREL 1934.  DISTANCES TO R.M.S WERE REVERSED.  NEW DESCRIPTION FOLLOWS--  LOCATED ABOUT 7 KM. N OF CENTRAL LAFAYETTE AND 5-1/2 KM. NW OF PATILLAS IN BARRIO LLAUREL.  IT IS ON THE HIGHEST PEAK OF THE PROMINENT, BRUSH-COVERED HILL OF THIS VICINITY.  THE STATION IS A STANDARD TABLET STAMPED YAUREL 1934 SET IN A LARGE BOULDER OR OUTCROP AT THE HIGHEST POINT OF THE HILL, AND ABOUT 300 OR 400 FT. E OF A HOUSE ON RIDGE.  R. M. NO. 1 IS 9.38 FT. IN AZIMUTH 313 DEG 22 MIN FROM THE STATION.  IT IS A DRILLED HOLE ON HIGHEST BOULDER.  R. M. NO. 2 IS A DRILLED HOLE IN FACE OF A HALF BURIED ROCK 11.8 FT. IN AZIMUTH 66 DEG 18 MIN FROM THE STATION.  TO REACH FROM ARROYO, GO N TO CENTRAL LAFAYETTE.  FROM HERE DRIVE N 1.6 MILES TO VILLAGE OF PITAALA.  TAKE T-ROAD RIGHT (N) AT STORE OF ERNESTO COLLAZO ON E SIDE OF RIO NIGUA.  DRIVE 1.9 MILES UP VALLEY TO GROUP OF SCHOOL BUILDINGS.  AND LEAVE CAR AT A T-ROAD 0.1 MILE BEYOND HERE.  FROM HERE THE STATION IS N 20 DEG E.  TAKE TRAIL, WHICH IS A CONTINUATION OF THE ROAD STRAIGHT AHEAD, AND FOLLOW SAME UP MOUNTAIN.  AT RIDGE, TURN E PASSING HOUSE AND CONTINUE A SHORT DISTANCE TO HIGHEST POINT AND STATION.  NOTE--IT IS EXPECTED THAT YAUREL WILL BE REOCCUPIED AND OBS. MADE OF THE ANGLES MARIN-JACABOA AND PATILLAS 2-TUMBAO MADE.
markers.setting: SET IN A BOULDER
markers.stability: MAY HOLD, BUT OF TYPE COMMONLY SUBJECT TOSURFACE MOTION

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JJL) THE STATION IS LOCATED ON THE HIGHEST POINT OF LOBITO CAY WHICH IS A SMALL ISLAND ABOUT 1 MILE NORTHWEST OF LOBO CAY, 2-1/4 MILES SOUTHWEST OF FUNGY BOWL AND 6 MILES WEST-NORTHWEST OF THE TOWN OF CULEBRA ON CULEBRA ISLAND.  THE ISLAND WAS REACHED WITH A SMALL BOAT BUT BECAUSE OF THE HEAVY SURF IT WAS NOT BEACHED.  PERSONNEL HAD TO CLIMB FROM THE BOAT ONTO A LARGE ROCK ON THE SOUTH SHORE OF THE ISLAND.  THIS IS A DANGEROUS OPERATION AND SHOULD BE ATTEMPTED BY EXPERIENCED PERSONNEL ONLY.  FROM THE LANDING POINT PACK TO THE HIGHEST POINT ON THE ISLAND AND THE STATION.  THE STATION MARK IS A STANDARD DISK, STAMPED LOBITO 1966, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN OUTCROPPING BEDROCK THAT PROJECTS TWO FEET.  IT IS 6 FEET SOUTHEAST OF A NAVIGATION LIGHT.  NO REFERENCE MARKS WERE ESTABLISHED.  NOTE--THIS ISLAND IS LOCATED IN THE OVER SHOT AREA OF THE U.S. NAVY FIRING RANGE WHICH IS LOCATED ABOUT 3 MILES NORTHEAST OF LOBITO CAY.  CLEARANCE MUST BE OBTAINED BEFORE VISITING THE STATION.
markers.setting: SET IN ROCK OUTCROP

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JJL) NOTE--THIS STATION IS LOCATED IN A GUNNERY RANGE.  PERMISSION MUST BE OBTAINED FROM THE U.S. NAVY OBSERVATION POST ON CULEBRA ISLAND BEFORE VISITING THE STATION.  THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 5-1/4 MILES WEST-NORTHWEST OF CULEBRA AND ON THE SOUTHEAST END OF A SMALL ISLAND KNOWN AS CRUZ, CROSS OR LOBO CAY.  THE STATION IS ABOUT 300 YARDS NORTHWEST OF THE EXTREME SOUTHEAST POINT OF THE ISLAND AND THERE IS A SLIGHTLY HIGHER POINT ABOUT 50 YARDS NORTHWEST OF THE STATION.  THE STATION MAY BE REACHED BY BOAT OR HELICOPTER.  THE STATION MARK, STAMPED LOBO 1966, IS A STANDARD DISK SET IN THE TOP OF A CEMENT AND ROCK MONUMENT THAT PROJECTS 1 INCH.  IT IS 25 FEET NORTHEAST OF A CLIFF.  REFERENCE MARKS WERE NOT ESTABLISHED.
markers.setting: UNSPECIFIED SETTING

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1900 (WCH) STATION IS ON THE DOME-LIKE SUMMIT OF ONE OF THE LITTLE ROCKY CAYS FORMING THE CHAIN OF THE CORDILLERAS.  THE EDGES OF THE LEDGE OVERHANG.  MARKED BY A TACK SET IN CEMENT.  TRIPOD SIGNAL.                            STATION RECOVERY (1901)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1901 (JBB) STATION IS ON A PROMINENT ROUND TOPPED CAY.  IT IS MARKED BY A LUMP OF CEMENT POURED ON THE ROCK.  SIGNAL STANDING IN 1901.  LOBOS CAY IS ONE OF THE CORDILLERAS REEF, ABOUT 1-1/2 MILES N OF PALOMINAS ISLAND.                            STATION RECOVERY (1961)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1961 (MLO) STATION WAS SEARCHED FOR BUT NOT RECOVERED.  IT IS BELIEVED TO HAVE BEEN DESTROYED BY EROSION OF THE LIMESTONE.
markers.setting: OBJECT SURROUNDED BY MASS OF CONCRETE
markers.stability: MARK OF QUESTIONABLE OR UNKNOWN STABILITY

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1962 (ELJ) STATION IS LOCATED NEAR THE NORTHEAST CORNER OF PUERTO RICO, ABOUT 5-1/2 MILES NORTHEAST OF THE TOWN OF FAJARDO, NEAR CAYO LOBOS, A SMALL ISLET IN THE GROUP KNOWN AS LA CORDILLERA.  STATION IS LOCATED ON A ROCKY ISLET ABOUT 0.3 MILE NORTH-NORTHEAST OF CAYO LOBOS, ON THE HIGHEST POINT AND ABOUT 40 FEET ABOVE THE WATER.  TO REACH FROM CAPE SAN JUAN LIGHTHOUSE, GO BY WATER ABOUT 2.4 MILES IN AN EASTERLY DIRECTION TO THE PASSAGE BETWEEN CAYO ICACOS AND CAYO LOBOS.  THE STATION IS ON THE SMALL ROCKY ISLET AT THE NORTHEAST END OF THE PASSAGE.  THE SIDES OF THE ISLET ARE UNDERCUT BY WAVE ACTION ABOUT 3 TO 5 FEET.  LANDING IS BEST ACCOMPLISHED BY RUNNING A SKIFF CLOSE BY THE SOUTHWEST END OF THE ISLET AND MAKING A LANDING ON THE SOUTH SIDE.  EXTREME CARE MUST BE TAKEN WHEN LANDING, SINCE WATER ACTION HAS RENDERED THE SURFACE OF THE ROCK HONEYCOMBED AND SHARP.  STATION MARK, A STANDARD DISK STAMPED LOBOS 2 1962, IS SET IN LIMESTONE BEDROCK ON THE HIGHEST POINT OF THE ISLET.  NO UNDERGROUND MARK WAS ESTABLISHED.  REFERENCE MARK 1, A STANDARD DISK STAMPED LOBOS 2 NO 1 1962, IS SET IN LIMESTONE BEDROCK ON APPROXIMATELY THE SAME LEVEL AS THE STATION.  REFERENCE MARK 2, A STANDARD DISK STAMPED LOBOS 2 NO 2 1962, IS SET IN LIMESTONE BEDROCK AND IS APPROXIMATELY 7 FEET LOWER THAN THE STATION.  NO AZIMUTH MARK WAS SET.                            STATION RECOVERY (1964)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1964 (GWM) STATION WAS RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED.
markers.setting: SET IN ROCK OUTCROP
markers.stability: MOST RELIABLE AND EXPECTED TO HOLDPOSITION/ELEVATION WELL

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1941 (RLS) STATION IS ABOUT 1-1/2 MILES S OF DAGUAO, ABOUT 1-3/4 MILES E OF COLONIA MONTIDA, ABOUT 1 MILE W OF THE MOUTH OF THE DAGUAO RIVER, WITHIN THE PROPOSED LIMITS OF THE ROOSEVELT ROADS NAVAL RESERVATION, ON TOP OF THE HIGHEST HILL IN THE IMMEDIATE VICINITY, 28 METERS N OF A 12-INCH COROCHO TREE ON THE S SLOPE OF THE HILL, ABOUT 10 METERS N OF THE S END OF THE NEARLY FLAT TOP OF THE HILL, AND PROJECTS 2 INCHES ABOVE GROUND.  THE ELEVATION OF THE STATION IS ABOUT 75.7 METERS.  STATION MARK IS A STANDARD BRONZE DISK SET IN CONCRETE, AS DESCRIBED IN NOTE 1A.  THERE IS NO UNDERGROUND MARK.  REFERENCE MARK NO.1 IS ON THE W SLOPE OF THE RIDGE, 0.49 METER LOWER THAN THE STATION, AND IS A STANDARD DISK SET IN CONCRETE IN A DEPRESSION IN A BOULDER PROJECTING 12 INCHES ABOVE GROUND.  REFERENCE MARK NO.2 IS A STANDARD DISK SET IN CONCRETE IN A DEPRESSION IN THE SOUTHERLY BOULDER OF A GROUP OF BOULDERS AMONG SMALL TREES AT THE N END OF THE TOP OF THE HILL, AND 0.34 METER LOWER THAN THE STATION.  THE BOULDER PROJECTS 8 INCHES ABOVE GROUND.                            STATION RECOVERY (1961)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1961 (MLO) STATION AND REFERENCE MARKS WERE RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED.  THEY ARE NO LONGER ON THE RESERVATION BUT ARE ABOUT 800 FEET SOUTH OF BOUNDARY FENCE.  MARKS ARE IN EXCELLENT CONDITION.
markers.setting: SET IN TOP OF CONCRETE MONUMENT
markers.stability: MAY HOLD, BUT OF TYPE COMMONLY SUBJECT TOSURFACE MOTION

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1902 (JN) STATION IS ON A PROMINENT HIGH HILL, OR MOUNTAIN, 1200 TO 1500 FEET ABOVE SEA AND ABOUT 4 MILES INLAND FROM THE N SHORE LINE.  THE SUMMIT IS BARE OF TREES EXCEPT FOR A GROWTH OF BAMBOOS, MOST OF WHICH, HOWEVER, WERE CUT DOWN AT THE TIME OF ESTABLISHING THE STATION.  THE STATION IS A NAIL EMBEDDED IN CEMENT IN THE CENTER OF A 2-INCH IRON PIPE WHICH IS SUNK IN THE GROUND FOR NEARLY 2 FEET, ITS TOP BEING ONLY AN INCH OR TWO ABOVE THE SURFACE.  THE PIPE IS FIXED IN POSITION BY SURROUNDING MASS OF HYDRAULIC CEMENT CONCRETE.  THE BEST WAY TO REACH THIS STATION IS FROM A POINT ON THE MAIL ROAD BETWEEN LUQUILLO AND FAJARDO AND ABOUT MIDWAY BETWEEN THE TWO PLACES ON THE TOP OF A HILL WHERE THE ROAD BEGINS TO DESCEND TOWARD FAJARDO.  THERE ARE NUMEROUS INHABITED HUTS ALONG THE SLOPES OF THIS MOUNTAIN NEARLY TO ITS TOP AND A SUCCESSION OF FAIRLY GOOD TRAILS MAKES THE ASCENT NOT DIFFICULT.  IT MIGHT BE BETTER, HOWEVER, FOR A STRANGER TO OBTAIN A GUIDE FROM AMONG THE LOCAL INHABITANTS.  AS THE STATION IS ON THE ACTUAL SUMMIT IT SHOULD BE EASILY LOCATED.                            STATION RECOVERY (1921)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1921 (JHP) STATION MARK WAS NOT RECOVERED.  A LARGE PALM TREE WHICH CROWNS THE SUMMIT WAS LOCATED BY TRIANGULATION.
markers.setting: SET INTO TOP OF METAL PIPE DRIVEN INTO GROUND
markers.stability: MARK OF QUESTIONABLE OR UNKNOWN STABILITY

markers.description: BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1934 STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 7 KILOMETERS BY ROAD AND TRAIL, SE OF THE TOWN OF LUQUILLO, 5.7 KILOMETERS BY ROAD AND TRAIL W OF FAJARDO, ON A BARE PEAK ON RIDGE E OF THE HEAD OF QUEBRADA JUAN MARTIN AND JUST AT THE HEAD OF QUEBRADA FAJARDO.  THIS STATION IS LOCATED ON THE SAME PEAK AS FORMER STATION LOS BURROS, NO TRACE OF WHICH COULD BE FOUND, NOR OF THE PALM TREE WHICH WAS LATER USED AS A STATION ON THIS SAME PEAK.  THE NEW STATION IS PROBABLY WITHIN 10 FEET S OF THE STATION MARK.  STATION MARK IS A STANDARD U.S.G.S. TABLET, STAMPED LOS BURROS 1934, CEMENTED IN LARGE ROCK SET IN GROUND.  REFERENCE MARKS--NO.1 IS 1-INCH DRILL HOLE IN A ROCK PROTRUDING FROM W SLOPE OF PEAK ABOUT 6 FEET BELOW TOP, 20.38 FEET FROM STATION IN TRUE AZIMUTH 38 DEG 27 MIN.  NO.2 IS A CROSS CUT ON A LARGE ROCK PROJECTING 2 FEET ABOVE SURFACE OF E SLOPE, 16.71 FEET FROM STATION IN TRUE AZIMUTH 260 DEG 30 MIN.  SIGNAL--A QUADRIPOD OF SAWED LUMBER WITH BLACK CROSS-TARGETS ON CENTER POLE.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM FAJARDO, FOLLOW ROAD LEADING PAST THE CEMETERY THROUGH SECTION KNOWN AS HATILLO, AND ON THE SCHOOLHOUSE IN QUEBRADA FAJARDO.  LEAVE CAR AT SCHOOLHOUSE, CONTINUE ON TRAIL ABOUT 0.3 KILOMETER, TURN RIGHT (W) UP DRAW AND FOLLOW TRAILS LEADING UPWARD TO TOP.  STATION IS ON HIGHEST PART OF SUMMIT.                            STATION RECOVERY (1940)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1940 THE REFERENCE MARKS WERE RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED.  BUT THE TABLET MARKING THE STATION HAD BEEN REMOVED.  THE TABLET HAD BEEN REMOVED BY SPLITTING THE ROCK IN WHICH IT WAS CEMENTED.  BUT HALF THE DRILL HOLE AND THE ROUND, CHISELED AREA FOR COUNTERSINKING WERE FIRM AND APPARENTLY IN PLACE.  REFERENCE DISTANCES AND AZIMUTH CHECKED.  A NEW STANDARD TABLET STAMPED LOS BURROS 2 1934 WAS SET IN THE TOP OF A CONCRETE POST 12 IN DIAMETER AT THE TOP, AND PROJECTING ABOUT 4 IN, BUILT IN SAME PLACE AS THE DRILL HOLE.  DESCRIPTION OF 1934 IS ADEQUATE.                            STATION RECOVERY (1965)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1965 (JJL) THE STATION MARK, REFERENCE MARK 1, AND REFERENCE MARK 2 WERE DESTROYED.  A NEW STATION MARK, REFERENCE MARK 1, REFERENCE MARK 2 AND AN AZIMUTH MARK WERE ESTABLISHED.  FOR DESCRIPTION SEE TRIANGULATION STATION BURROS.
markers.setting: SET IN TOP OF CONCRETE MONUMENT
markers.stability: MAY HOLD, BUT OF TYPE COMMONLY SUBJECT TOSURFACE MOTION

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JJL) THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 3-1/2 MILES SOUTHEAST OF BAYAMON, 1- 1/2 MILES SOUTH-SOUTHWEST OF LOS RANCHOS AND ON TOP OF A LOW BUT PROMINENT HILL.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE JUNCTION OF HIGHWAYS 20 AND 21 IN LOS RANCHOS, GO SOUTHERLY ON HIGHWAY 20 FOR 0.6 MILE TO THE JUNCTION OF HIGHWAYS 20 AND 833.  TURN RIGHT AND GO WEST AND SOUTH ON HIGHWAY 833 FOR 0.4 MILE TO A Y-FORK.  TAKE THE LEFT FORK AND GO SOUTHERLY FOR 0.6 MILE TO A SIDE ROAD LEFT AT A WATER FILTRATION PLANT.  TURN LEFT AND GO EAST AND NORTH FOR 0.1 MILE TO THE STATION.  THE MAST IS A 3-LEGGED STEEL STRUCTURE SUPPORTED BY GUY WIRES AND IS ALTERNATELY PAINTED RED AND WHITE.  THERE IS AN ANTENNA ATOP AND CENTER OF THE MAST THAT IS COMPOSED OF SQUARE OBJECTS ABOUT 1 FOOT IN DIAMETER.  THE ANTENNA SECTION OF THE MAST IS ABOUT 30 FEET HIGH AND THE OVERALL HEIGHT OF THE STRUCTURE IS APPROXIMATELY 65 FEET.  POINT INTERSECTED IS THE RED OBSTRUCTION LIGHT ATOP AND CENTER OF THE ANTENNA.

BY NATIONAL OCEAN SERVICE 1993 THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 1 MI (1.6 KM) EAST OF ARECIBO AT THE SOUTHEAST CORNER OF THE BRIDGE OVER THE RIO GRANDE DE ARECIBO. TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE VICINITY OF ARECIBO, PROCEED EAST ON PR HIGHWAY 2 TO ROAD 681.  TURN NORTH ON 681 AND GO FOR 150 M (492.1 FT) TO THE STATION ON THE EAST SIDE OF THE ROAD IMMEDIATELY SOUTH OF THE START OF A BRIDGE. THE STATION IS A GENERIC 7.5 CM BRASS DISK SET FLUSH IN THE CENTER OF THE SIDEWALK 2.4 M (7.9 FT) EAST OF THE EASTERN CURB.  IT IS 0.8 M (2.6 FT) WEST OF THE EASTERN STEEL GUARD RAIL AND 0.7 M (2.3 FT) SOUTH OF THE BEGINNING OF THE EASTERN CONCRETE GUARD RAIL.  THE STATION IS 6.1 M (20.0 FT) SOUTH OF THE JUNCTION OF THE ASPHALT AND CONCRETE PAVEMENT JUNCTION WHERE THE BRIDGE COMMENCES.  THE LETTER M ON THE DISK HAS BEEN DOUBLE STRUCK.
markers.setting: SET IN A PAVEMENT SUCH AS STREET, SIDEWALK, CURB, ETC.
markers.stability: MARK OF QUESTIONABLE OR UNKNOWN STABILITY

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1900 (WCH) THIS STATION IS ON THE SUMMIT OF THE HIGH AND STEEP ISLET CALLED S.W. CAY OR LUISPENA.  THE SUMMIT ITSELF IS RATHER FLAT AND A GOOD DEAL OF BRUSH HAD TO BE CLEARED AWAY FOR LINES OF SIGHT.  MARKED BY A NAIL SET IN A POST MADE OF CEMENT.                            STATION RECOVERY (1900)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1900 (JBB) STATION IS ON THE HIGHEST POINT OF THE ISLAND OF LUISPENA ON S.W. CAY.  A TRIPOD SIGNAL WAS ERECTED OVER THE STATION.  THE POINT OF A NAIL SET IN A CEMENT BLOCK MARKS THE STATION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1902)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1902 (RLF) RECOVERED AND SIGNAL ERECTED OVER IT.  THE STATION IS MARKED BY A 6-INCH SQUARE (ON TOP) WOODEN BOX SET IN THE GROUND, PROJECTING ABOUT 6 INCHES.  THE NAIL MARKING THE CENTER OF THE STATION WAS BADLY RUSTED AND A GALVANIZED-IRON TACK WAS DRIVEN IN ALONGSIDE OF THE NAIL.  A BLAZED TRAIL LEADS UP TO THE STATION FROM THE LANDING PLACE ON THE E SIDE OF THE CAY.  THIS LANDING PLACE IS ABREAST THE ANCHORAGE IN FIREWOOD BAY.                            STATION RECOVERY (1922)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1922 (RWW) STATION AS RECOVERED, FILLS ORIGINAL DESCRIPTION.  IT IS MARKED WITH A CONCRETE POST PROJECTING 6 INCHES ABOVE THE GROUND, HAVING A NAIL DRIVEN IN THE CENTER OF THE 5-INCH SQUARE TOP.  ONE CORNER IS CHIPPED OFF THE POST.  ABOUT 50 FEET E FROM THE STATION IS A LARGE RED-BARKED TREE (ONLY ONE OF ITS KIND ON THE SUMMIT.)  THE SUMMIT IS REACHED BY FOLLOWING THE RIDGE FROM THE LANDING PLACE ON THE E SIDE OF THE CAY, OPPOSITE FIREWOOD BAY.                            STATION RECOVERY (1954)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1954 (JOP) STATION WAS RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED BY R. W. W. IN 1922 AND WAS FOUND TO BE IN GOOD CONDITION ALTHOUGH THE MARK IS LEANING SLIGHTLY.  OLD DESCRIPTION IS ADEQUATE.                            STATION RECOVERY (1965)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1965 (MTP) THE TRIANGULATION STATION WAS RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED EXCEPT FOR THE FOLLOWING MODIFICATIONS.  THE STATION WAS SITUATED IN A CLEARING OF TREES ON THE SUMMIT OF 478 FOOT FRONDOSO HILL.  PATHS OF BRUSH HAVE BEEN CLEARED EAST AND WEST FROM THE STATION TO FACILITATE TRIANGULATION SURVEYS.  A RED BARKED TREE WAS 72 FEET EAST FROM THE STATION.  A LIGHT BROWN COLORED STUMP, CONTAINING THREE LIMBS, WAS 61.5 FEET WEST FROM THE STATION.  TO REACH THE STATION, LAND A SMALL CRAFT ON THE EAST SIDE OF LUISPENA CAY, ADJACENT TO THE BARREN LOW LYING RIDGE ON THE ISLANDS NORTHERN PENNINSULA.  WALK SOUTH APPROXIMATELY 0.3 MI. TO THE SUMMIT OF THE HILL.                            STATION RECOVERY (1966)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JJL) THE ORIGINAL STATION MARK WAS DESTROYED BY CONSTRUCTION IN THE AREA.  A NEW STATION MARK, REFERENCE MARK 1 AND REFERENCE MARK 2 WERE ESTABLISHED IN THE SAME GENERAL AREA.  SEE LUIS 2 FOR A COMPLETE NEW DESCRIPTION.

BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JJL) THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 2-1/4 MILES WEST OF THE TOWN OF CULEBRA, ON THE HIGHEST POINT OF LUIS PENA ISLAND AND ON THE CONSTRUCTION SITE OF A NAVY OBSERVATION POINT.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE DOCK ON LUIS PENA ISLAND, FOLLOW THE HARD SURFACED ROAD TO THE HIGHEST POINT OF THE ISLAND AND THE STATION AT THE NAVY INSTALLATION.  IF A VEHICLE IS NOT AVAILABLE, IT IS ABOUT A 45 MINUTE PACK, ALONG THE ROAD, TO THE TOP OF THE HILL.  THERE IS ALSO A HELICOPTOR LANDING PAD AVAILABLE AT THE NAVY INSTALLATION ON THE TOP OF THE ISLAND.  THE STATION MARK IS A STANDARD DISK, STAMPED LUIS 2 1966, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A BOULDER THAT PROJECTS 2 INCHES.  IT IS LOCATED 42 FEET SOUTHEAST OF THE SOUTHEAST CORNER OF THE GENERATOR BUILDING.  REFERENCE MARK 1 IS A STANDARD DISK, STAMPED LUIS 2 NO 1 1966, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A BOULDER THAT PROJECTS 2 INCHES.  IT IS LOCATED 75 FEET EAST OF THE SOUTHEAST CORNER OF THE GENERATOR BUILDING.  REFERENCE MARK 2 IS A STANDARD DISK, STAMPED LUIS 2 NO 2 1966, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A BOULDER THAT PROJECTS 1 INCH.  IT IS LOCATED 56 FEET SOUTH-SOUTHEAST OF THE SOUTHEAST CORNER OF THE GENERATOR BUILDING.  THE DISTANCE BETWEEN REFERENCE MARK 1 AND REFERENCE MARK 2 IS 41.09 FEET OR 12.523 METERS.
markers.setting: SET IN A BOULDER

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1941 (RLS) THIS INTERSECTION STATION IS ABOUT 3-1/2 MILES E OF CEIBA, ON THE ROOSEVELT ROADS NAVAL RESERVATION, ON PINEROS ISLAND, ON THE EXTREME WESTERLY HILL ON THE ISLAND, ABOUT 150 METERS S OF THE HIGHEST POINT OF THE HILL, ABOUT 80 METERS E OF THE W END OF THE ISLAND, AND NEAR THE S END OF THE RIDGE SLOPING DOWN AND SOUTHWARD FROM THE HIGH POINT OF THE HILL.  THE ELEVATION OF THE STATION IS ABOUT 19 METERS.  STATION MARK IS A STANDARD BRONZE DISK SET IN CONCRETE, PROJECTING ABOUT 10 INCHES ABOVE GROUND.  THERE IS NO UNDERGROUND MARK.  WITNESS MARK NO.1 IS A TRIANGULAR BLAZE ON THE N SIDE OF A 12-INCH TREE KNOWN TO THE NATIVES AS PALO DE VACA (COW TREE), AND 2 FEET ABOVE THE GROUND.  IT IS DISTANT 8.30 METERS FROM STATION, IN AZIMUTH APPROXIMATELY 2 DEG.  WITNESS MARK NO.2 IS A TRIANGULAR BLAZE ON THE NE SIDE OF AN 8-INCH ALMACIGO TREE, 5 FEET ABOVE THE GROUND.  IT IS DISTANT 16.90 METERS FROM STATION, IN AZIMUTH APPROXIMATELY 67 DEG.  THERE ARE NO REFERENCE MARKS.                            STATION RECOVERY (1961)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1961 (MLO) STATION WAS RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED.  DISK IS STAMPED LUNA 1941.  STATION IS 2.5 FEET NORTH OF A FIVE-FEET HIGH 2 X 4 WITNESS POST PAINTED WHITE.  AREA IS SURROUNDED BY THICK BRUSH 10-FEET HIGH.                            STATION RECOVERY (1963)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US NAVY 1963 (DHW) STATION WAS RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.  DESCRIPTION IS ADEQUATE.  20 FT. STEEL TRIPOD WAS ERECTED OVER STATION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1964)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1964 (GWM) THE STATION MARK WAS FOUND AS DESCRIBED AND IS IN EXCELLENT CONDITION.  A 12 FOOT STEEL PIPE TRIPOD IS BUILT PERMANENTLY OVER THIS MARK.  THE ORIGINAL DESCRIPTION IS ADEQUATE.
markers.setting: SET IN TOP OF CONCRETE MONUMENT
markers.stability: MAY HOLD, BUT OF TYPE COMMONLY SUBJECT TOSURFACE MOTION

markers.description: BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1934 NO CHECK ON THIS POSITION.  WHITE CROSS ON WHITE SPIRE WITH RED TILE ROOF AT LUQUILLO.                            STATION RECOVERY (1941)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1941 (GBG) APPARENTLY SAME POINT AS SIGHTED BY U.S.C. AND G.S. IN 1901.  THE STATION IS THE WHITE CROSS ATOP RED TILE ROOF OF TOWER OF THE LUQUILLO CATHOLIC CHURCH.                            STATION RECOVERY (1961)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1961 (MLO) STATION WAS RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED.

BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JJL) THE STATION IS LOCATED ON A LOW BRUSH COVERED HILL ABOUT 2 AIRLINE MILES NORTHEAST OF PONCE.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE INTERSECTION OF HIGHWAYS 1, 2 AND 133 IN THE EAST EDGE OF PONCE, GO EAST ON HIGHWAY 1 FOR 0.95 MILE TO A SIDE ROAD LEFT AT KILOMETER POST 124.1.  TURN LEFT AND GO NORTH ON A PAVED ROAD FOR 0.35 MILE TO A FORK.  KEEP RIGHT AND GO NORTH AND EAST ON A PAVED ROAD FOR 0.45 MILE TO A DIM TRACK ROAD RIGHT.  BEAR RIGHT AND GO EAST AND NORTH ON THE TRACK ROAD FOR 0.35 MILE TO A SIDE TRACK ROAD LEFT. TURN LEFT AND GO WEST ON THE TRACK ROAD FOR 0.15 MILE TO A GATE. PASS THROUGH THE GATE AND GO WEST ON THE TRACK ROAD FOR ABOUT 100 FEET TO A DIM TRACK ROAD LEFT. BEAR LEFT AND GO WESTERLY ON THE TRACK ROAD FOR 0.25 MILE TO A DIM FORK.  BEAR LEFT AND GO SOUTH ON A DIM TRACK ROAD FOR 0.1 MILE TO A STEEP DRAW ON THE LEFT. THIS IS END OF TRUCK TRAVEL IN WET WEATHER.  TURN LEFT AND GO EAST AND NORTH ON A TRACK ROAD FOR 0.15 MILE TO THE TOP OF THE LOW BRUSH COVERED HILL AND THE STATION.  A 4 WHEEL DRIVE VEHICLE IS REQUIRED FOR THE LAST 1.0 MILE AND IT IS A 15 MINUTE PACK IN WET WEATHER.  THE STATION MARK IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED LYNCH 2 1966, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN OUTCROPPING BEDROCK WHICH IS FLUSH WITH THE SURFACE.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 1 IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED LYNCH 2 NO 1 1966, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN OUTCROPPING BEDROCK WHICH IS FLUSH WITH THE SURFACE.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 2 IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED LYNCH 2 NO 2 1966, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN OUTCROPPING BEDROCK WHICH IS FLUSH WITH THE SURFACE.                            STATION RECOVERY (1972)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1972 (EP) THE STATION MARK AND RMS 1 AND 2 WERE FOUND IN GOOD CONDITION AS DESCRIBED.  NOTHING COULD BE ADDED TO THE DESCRIPTION TO FACILITATE FUTURE RECOVERY.  THE HILL IS NOW COVERED WITH DENSE HEAVY BRUSH ABOUT 12 FEET HIGH.  THE STATION IS REACHED BY GOING UP THE HILL TO THE SOUTHWEST, WHICH HAS AN OLD PERSONS HOME ERECTED ON IT AND GOING NORTHEAST ALONG A CUT TRAIL TO THE STATION SITE.  THIS IS PROBABLY THE ONLY WAY THE STATION CAN BE REACHED, BECAUSE OF THE HEAVY UNDERBRUSH.  AIRLINE DISTANCE AND DIRECTION FROM NEAREST TOWN 2 MILES NORTHEAST OF PONCE.                            STATION RECOVERY (1982)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1982 (JCL) THE STATION MARK AND REFERENCE MARKS 1 AND 2 WERE NOT RECOVERED. DRILL HOLES FOR THE REFERENCE MARKS WERE FOUND AND USED TO MEASURE TO THE STATION.  A PRIVATE SURVEYOR USED THE STATION DRILL HOLE TO SET A FLUSH NAIL THROUGH A WASHER INTO CEMENT AND BOLTED A NAME PLATE TO THE BOULDER WITH STATION DESIGNATION AS LYNCH 3 1978.  MEASUREMENTS INDICATE THE NAIL IS SAME POSITION AS LYNCH 2 1966.  REFERENCE MARK 3 WAS SET IN THE REFERENCE MARK 1 DRILL HOLE.  REFERENCE MARK 4 WAS ALSO ESTABLISHED.  THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 3.2 KM (2 MI) NORTHEAST OF PONCE, 0.2 KM (0.15 MI) EAST OF THE RESIDENCIA SANTA MARTA NURSING HOME, AND ON A BRUSH COVERED HILL.  OWNERSHIP--U.S. ARMY CORPS OF ENGINEERS.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE JUNCTION OF HIGHWAY 1, 2, AND 133 AT THE EAST EDGE OF PONCE, GO EAST ON HIGHWAY 1 FOR 1.1 KM (0.7 MI) TO A CROSS STREET WITH LIGHT.  TURN LEFT FOR 0.08 KM (0.05 MI) TO A T-ROAD. TURN RIGHT FOR 30 METERS (100 FT), THEN LEFT ON PAVED STREET (FOLLOWING SIGNS TO -RESIDENCIA SANTA MARTA-) FOR 0.8 KM (0.5 MI) TO A CROSS STREET.  TURN RIGHT FOR 0.08 KM (0.05 MI) TO A STREET LEFT. TURN LEFT AND GO NORTH THEN EAST FOR 0.8 KM (0.5 MI) TO -4TH OF JULY STREET-.  TURN LEFT, FOLLOWING PAVED ROAD FOR 1.3 KM (0.8 MI) TO THE SOUTHEAST CORNER OF A NURSING HOME AND THE END OF TRUCK TRAVEL (GATES LOCKED SUN UP TO SUN DOWN).  CROSS FENCE ON EAST SIDE OF NURSING HOME, PICKING UP WELL TRAVELED TRAIL THROUGH BRUSH AND GO NORTH, THEN EASTERLY, CROSSING SADDLE TO NEXT LOW HILL AND THE STATION (ABOUT 0.2 KM (0.15 MI) EAST FROM THE NURSING HOME).  THE STATION IS A NAIL IN A WASHER IMBEDDED IN A PARTIALLY EXPOSED BOULDER OF 0.75 METER LARGEST DIMENSION.  STATION HAS A 5 CM TRIANGLE CHISELED INTO THE CEMENT AND A METAL NAME PLATE EMBEDDED IN THE BOULDER.  THE PLATE IS STAMPED---LYNCH 3 FILARDI 1978--- .  REFERENCE MARK NUMBER 3 IS A STANDARD NGS DISK STAMPED ---LYNCH 2 1966 NO 3 1982---, SET INTO THE TOP OF A PARTIALLY EXPOSED BOULDER OF 0.4 METER LARGEST DIMENSION.  MARK IS BELOW STATION 0.3 METER.  REFERENCE MARK NUMBER 4 IS A STANDARD NGS DISK STAMPED ---LYNCH 2 1966 NO 4 1982---, SET INTO THE TOP OF A PARTIALLY EXPOSED BOULDER OF 0.7 METER LARGEST DIMENSION.  MARK IS LEVEL WITH STATION.  HEIGHT OF LIGHT SHOWN ABOVE THE MARK WAS 1.5 METERS.  NO AZIMUTH MARK SET, HOWEVER TRIANGULATION STATION AIRPORT 1966 CAN BE USED FOR SAME.
markers.setting: SET IN ROCK OUTCROP
markers.stability: MOST RELIABLE AND EXPECTED TO HOLDPOSITION/ELEVATION WELL

markers.description: BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1934 SURFACE MARK FOUND AS DESCRIBED AND IN GOOD CONDITION.  IRON PIPE MARKING THE STATION WAS FOUND IN PLACE BUT LOOSENED.  PIPE WAS REMOVED AND REPLACED BY A STANDARD TABLET (BENCH MARK) NOT STAMPED.  NEW SIGNAL, QUADRIPOD OF SAWED LUMBER, COVERED WITH WHITE CLOTH AND BLACK CROSS TARGETS ON CENTER POLE, CENTERED OVER STATION MARK.                            STATION RECOVERY (1954)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1954 (JOP) STATION RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED AND FOUND TO BE IN GOOD CONDITION.  MARK IS A USGS DISK SET IN CONCRETE AND IS NOT UNSTAMPED.  A NEW DESCRIPTION FOLLOWS.  STATION IS LOCATED ON THE EASTERN END AND HIGHEST POINT OF A RIDGE OF FOOTHILLS E TO W AND NE OF PONCE.  STATION SITE IS ON A BRUSHY KNOB ABOUT 3 MILES NE OF THE CENTER OF PONCE.  TO REACH FROM THE JUNCTION OF HWYS 10 AND 14 IN THE SW SECTION OF PONCE, A Y INTERSECTION, GO NE ON HWY 14 (ROUTE TO JUANA DIAZ) FOR 5.3 MILES TO A SIDE ROAD RIGHT, TURN RIGHT AND FOLLOW ROAD THRU DISTILLERY AND SUGAR REFINERY FOR 3.5 MILES TO HWY NO.1, TURN RIGHT ON HIGHWAY AND GO W 1.2 MILES TO A SIDE ROAD RIGHT*, TURN RIGHT AND FOLLOW PAVED ROAD 0.45 MILE TO A LANE, TURN RIGHT ON THE LAND AND GO N ABOUT 0.15 MILE TO A FRAME HOUSE AND ETT.  FROM HOUSE, PACK E THRU COW PASTURE, THEN N ON WELL USED COW TRAIL SLIGHTLY NNE UP A RIDGE TO TOP OF HILL AND STATION SITE.  ABOUT 45 MINUTE PACK.  *ACCORDING TO A RECENT TOPO MAP THIS ROAD INTERSECTION IS APPROXIMATELY 2 MILES E OF PONCE AT BUCANA.                            STATION RECOVERY (1963)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1963 (RWS) THE DESCRIPTION WRITTEN IN 1954 IS ADEQUATE BUT AN EASIER WAY WAS FOUND TO THE STATION.  FROM THE INTERSECTION OF ROUTES TWO AND TEN, GO EAST ON ROUTE TWO FOR 1.6 MILES TO ROUTE ONE.  TURN EAST ON ROUTE ONE FOR 0.7 MILES AND TURN LEFT ONTO A COUNTRY ROAD.  FOLLOW THIS ROAD FOR 0.4 MILES, AT THIS POINT THERE SHOULD BE A Y IN THE ROAD, AND TURN LEFT FOR 0.2 MILES AND THE RIGHT.  AT THE END OF THIS ROAD THERE IS A CEMENT PLANT, AT THIS PLANT THERE IS A BULLDOZED ROAD TO THE RIGHT.  FOLLOW THE BULLDOZED ROAD TO THE TOP OF THE HILL, PASSED A CONCRETE WATERSHED BUILDING, AND THE STATION.  RECOVERED BY U.S. NAVAL OCEANOGRAPHIC OFFICE.  A FOUR WHEEL DRIVE VEHICLE SHOULD BE USED IN GETTING TO THIS STATION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1966)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JJL) THE STATION WAS SEARCHED FOR BUT NOT FOUND.  IT IS BELIEVED THE MARKS WERE DESTROYED DURING THE CONSTRUCTION OF BUILDINGS IN THE AREA.  A NEW STATION LYNCH 2 WAS ESTABLISHED.
markers.setting: OBJECT SURROUNDED BY MASS OF CONCRETE
markers.stability: MARK OF QUESTIONABLE OR UNKNOWN STABILITY

NOTE--THE MARK IS ON THE HIGHWAY RIGHT-OF-WAY.

markers.description: BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 2002 (JMW) 1.1 KM (0.7 MI) EASTERLY ALONG STATE HIGHWAY 22 FROM THE JUNCTION OF STATE HIGHWAY 140 IN BARCELONETA, IN TOP OF THE BRIDGE DECK NEAR THE CENTER OF A 2.4 KILOMETER HIGHWAY BRIDGE SPANNING BAYURA AFUERA AND RIO GRANDE DE MANATI, 13.2 M WEST OF KILOMETER POST 53.9, 9.3 M WEST OF A METAL LIGHT POLE, 6.5 M NORTH OF AND LEVEL WITH THE CENTERLINE OF THE WESTBOUND HIGHWAY, AND 1.2 M SOUTH OF THE NORTH EDGE OF THE BRIDGE DECK. NOTE--THE MARK IS ON THE HIGHWAY RIGHT-OF-WAY.                            STATION RECOVERY (2007)  RECOVERY NOTE BY UNIVERSITY OF PUERTO RICO AT MAYAGUEZ 2007 RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED

NOTE--THE MARK IS ON THE HIGHWAY RIGHT-OF-WAY.                            STATION RECOVERY (2007)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 2007 MARK NOT FOUND. markers.description: BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 2002 (JMW) 8.2 KM (5.1 MI)  WESTERLY ALONG STATE HIGHWAY 2 FROM THE JUNCTION OF STATE HIGHWAY 485 IN QUEBRADILLAS,  44.8 M EAST OF THE NORTHEAST CORNER OF HOUSE NUMBER 4849, 24.4 M WEST OF A UTILITY POLE WITH 3 GUY CABLES, 24.0 M SOUTH OF THE CENTERLINE OF THE EASTBOUND HIGHWAY, 4.4M SOUTH OF THE CENTER OF A STREET, 3.4 M ABOVE THE LEVEL OF THE HIGHWAY, 2.6 M NORTH OF A WITNESS POST, AND 0.2 M ABOVE THE LEVEL OF THE STREET. NOTE--THE MARK IS ON THE STREET RIGHT-OF-WAY. STATION RECOVERY (2016)  RECOVERY NOTE BY DEWBERRY DAVIS 2016 (GDS) RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.

markers.description: BY JAVIER E. BIDOT AND ASSOC. 2007 THE STATION IS LOCATED IN THE NORTHWEST SECTION OF CANOVANAS ON THE EASTBOUND SHOULDER OF STATE ROAD PR-66 AT KILOMETER POST 10.8 AND THE SOUTHEAST CORNER OF OVERPASS CARRYING PR-66 OVER PR-185.   OWNERSHIP PRHTA RIGHT-OF-WAY.   TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE JUNCTION OF STATE ROAD PR-66 AND PR-3 AT THE BELTZ OUTLET, TRAVEL 1.9 MI (3.1 KM) SOUTH AND THEN WEST ALONG PR 66 TO THE MARK ON THE LEFT AT THE BEGINNING OF THE BRIDGE.   THE STATION IS A STANDARD BRONZE DISK IN A DRILLED HOLE FLUSH WITH CONCRETE SURFACE.  IT IS 25 M (82.0 FT) WEST OF MANHOLE COVER, 3.55 M (11.6 FT) NORTHWEST OF BEGINNING OF STEEL GUARD RAIL WHERE IT IS BOLTED TO THE CONCRETE PARAPET AND 0.65 M (2.1 FT) NORTH OF CONCRETE PARAPET.
markers.setting: SET IN A MASSIVE STRUCTURE
markers.stability: PROBABLY HOLD POSITION/ELEVATION WELL

markers.description: BY RLDA SURVEYING AND MAPPING 2007 THE STATION IS LOCATED 5.12 MI (8.2 KM) SOUTHEAST OF AGUADA, 4.32 MI (7.0 KM) NORTHEAST OF LA TOSCO AND 2.13 MI (3.4 KM) NORTH OF ANASCO.   TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE JUNCTION OF PR 2 AND PR 417 ABOUT 4.60 MI (7.4 KM) SOUTHEAST OF AGUADA GO SOUTH ON PR 2 FOR 0.7 MI (1.1 KM) TO A CONCRETE CATCH BASIN THAT IS APPROXINMATELY 4.7 M (15.4 FT) BY 1.2 M (3.9 FT) THAT IS FLUSH WITH THE GROUND AND THE MONUMENT ON THE RIGHT AS DESCRIBED.   THE STATION IS 46.20 M (151.6 FT) SOUTH OF A METAL ROAD SIGN, 43.0 M (141.1 FT) SOUTH OF THE SOUTH END OF A METAL GUARD RAIL, 29.60 M (97.1 FT) SOUTH OF A ROADSIDE CHICKEN STAND, 15.30 M (50.2 FT) WEST OF THE CENTER OF A MANHOLE COVER IN THE CENTER LANE OF SOUTHBOUND LANE OF PR 2, 10.50 M (34.4 FT) WEST OF THE CENTERLINE OF SOUTHBOUND LANE OF PR 2 AND 4.7 M (15.4 FT) WEST OF THE WHITE LINE OF THE EDGE OF PR 2.

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1926 (GCM) LARGE WHITE BRICK STACK LOCATED AT CENTRAL MACHETE.  IT WILL BE NOTED THAT THIS STACK WAS ERECTED IN PLACE OF BELLE (RED CHIMNEY) AND STANDS APPROXIMATELY 50 METERS TO THE SE OF THE OLD LOCATION OF BELLE.  THE LOCATION OF BELLE IS AT PRESENT OCCUPIED BY PART OF THE SUGAR MILL.  CENTRAL MACHETE IS LOCATED 1.8 MILES S OF GUAYAMA.                            STATION RECOVERY (1970)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1970 (JKW) STATION UNCERTAIN.  THERE ARE TWO OLD STACKS AND THE REMAINING BASE OF A THIRD STACK AT THIS LOCATION.  THE DESCRIPTION IS INADEQUATE FOR DISTINGUISHING WHICH, IF ANY, OF THESE STACKS IS VALID.                            STATION RECOVERY (1975)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1975 (RMB) MACHETE B IS THE ONLY STACK NOW STANDING AT MACHETE.  IT IS AN OLD OCTAGONAL CONCRETE OR BRICK CONCRETE COVERED STACK APPROXIMATELY 120 FEET HIGH, APPROXIMATELY 20 FEET ACROSS, ON A 20 FEET BY 20 FEET SQUARE BASE.  A NEW TO REACH FOLLOWS--  TO REACH THE SITE START AT THE U.S. POST OFFICE ON THE MAIN SQUARE IN GUAYAMA, GO EAST ON DERKES STREET FOR 1-1/2 BLOCKS TO STOP SIGN, TURN RIGHT ON TO ASHFORD STREET, GO 0.5 MILES TO HIGHWAY 744 AND TURN RIGHT ONTO HIGHWAY 744, GO 1.6 MILES TO X-ROAD.  JUST PAST THE X-ROAD, ROAD CURVES TO RIGHT, JUST PASS CURVE TURN LEFT ACROSS (2) RAILROAD TRACKS, GO 50 YARDS TO LOCKED METAL GATE.  STATION IS 50 YARDS ON LEFT BEYOND GATE.

BY ANDREGG INCORPORATED 1995 (DJR) TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE JUNCTION OF HIGHWAYS PR 2 AND PR 385, GO WEST ON HIGHWAY PR 2 FOR 2.8 MILES (4.5 KM) TO KILOMETER POST 208.3 TO THE STATION ON THE RIGHT (NORTH) SIDE OF THE HIGHWAY  THE STATION IS LOCATED 19.2 METERS (63.0 FT) SOUTHEAST OF KILOMETER POST 208.3, 6.4 METERS (21.0 FT) NORTHEAST OF THE NORTHEAST EDGE OF PAVEMENT OF HIGHWAY PR 2, AND 1.2 METERS (3.9 FT) SOUTHWEST OF EAST-WEST RIGHT OF WAY FENCE  THE STATION IS 0.8 METERS (2.6 FT) SOUTHWEST OF CARSONITE SURVEY MARKER WITNESS POST  THE STATION IS A 3-1/4 INCH BRASS CAP STAMPED CENTRO DE RECAUDACION DE INGRESSOS MUNICIPALES, PUERTO RICO GPS CONTROL, C.R.I.M., UNLAWFUL TO DISTURB, MAGAS, SET ATOP A 9/16 INCH STAINLESS STEEL ROD DRIVEN TO REFUSAL AND COVERED FLUSH WITH THE GROUND BY AN ALUMINUM COVER EPOXYED ONTO A 6 INCH SCHEDULE 40 PVC PIPE SET IN CONCRETE INSIDE AND OUT                            STATION RECOVERY (2008)  RECOVERY NOTE BY RLDA SURVEYING AND MAPPING 2008 (RLD) THE STATION WAS RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.                            STATION RECOVERY (2009)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 2009 (NMD) CAP IS BROKEN, BUT MARK IS IN GOOD CONDITION. MARQTEK ENGINEERING.                            STATION RECOVERY (2016)  RECOVERY NOTE BY DEWBERRY DAVIS 2016 (GDS) RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.

markers.marker: _MARKER: STATION IS THE ANTENNA REFERENCE POINT OF THE GPS ANTENNA

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1901 (JEM) THIS STATION IS ON A HILL WHICH IS ABOUT 970 FEET HIGH (BY BAROMETER), ON THE PROPERTY OF A SUGAR PLANTER NAMED GUILLERMO RICO.  THE HILL IS ON THE FIRST SUMMIT W OF THE PLAYA OF MAUNABO FROM WHICH PUNTO VIENTO CAN BE SEEN.  FROM THE BASE OF THIS HILL A PLAIN SEEMS TO EXTEND TO THE TOWN OF MAUNABO.  THE PLAYA AND POINT TUNA LIGHTHOUSE ARE ALSO IN SIGHT.  THE HILL TOP IS THE HIGHER AND MORE EASTERLY OF TWO SMALL SUMMITS.  NEAR THE SIGNAL A NUMBER OF SMALL ROCKS ARE EXPOSED.  ON THE N SIDE OF THE HILL ARE THREE ROYAL PALMS, ON THE S SIDE IS THE TRUNK OF A SMALL CEIBA TREE, ABOUT 27.9 FEET FROM THE STATION, THE TOP OF THE CEIBA HAS BEEN BLOWN OFF BUT SOME NEW SHOOTS ARE NOW PUTTING FORTH.  ON THE LOWER SUMMIT ARE SOME BANANA PLANTS AND ON ITS CENTER ONE TALL ROYAL PALM.  TO REACH THE SIGNAL WE FOLLOWED THE GUAYAMA-MAUNABO ROAD FROM GUAYAMA, PAST THE SUMMIT, WHERE THE ROAD ROUNDS THE SEA FACE OF MALA PASCUA AND BEGINS TO DESCENT TO WHERE A GATE IS SEEN ON THE LEFT SIDE OF THE ROAD.  HERE WE ENTERED AND FOLLOWED THE TRAIL WHICH WILL BE NOTED THERE, ALWAYS TURNING UPWARD UNTIL THE BACKBONE OF THE RIDGE IS REACHED.  ALONG THIS IS A FOOT PATH SOMETIMES FAINT AND AGAIN DISTINCT, WHICH WILL TAKE ONE TO THE TOP.  WHEN THE STATION WAS OCCUPIED, THE PARTY APPROACHED IT FROM MAUNABO AND FOUND A TRAIL THAT IS A LITTLE BETTER THAN THE ONE JUST MENTIONED.  THIS TRAIL LEAVES THE MAIN ROAD AT THE BRICK WORKS AND, FOLLOWING THE RIGHT-HAND TRAIL FOR THE FIRST STRETCH UP TO AND PAST TWO SETTLEMENTS AND THE LAST HOUSE ON THE SLOPE, TAKES ONE TO THE SIGNAL.  A HORSE CAN BE RIDDEN TO THE SIGNAL ALONG THIS TRAIL.                            STATION RECOVERY (1927)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1927 (GCM) DESCRIPTION DOES NOT INDICATE WHAT STATION MARK WAS.  CLEARED TOP FOR LENGTH OF 40 FEET BUT COULD NOT FIND A MARK OF ANY KIND.

BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1901 (JN) THIS STATION IS SITUATED ON LAND BELONG TO ANGENE MALDONAO, BEING ABOUT 4-1/2 MILES DISTANT AND BEARING S 62 DEG 15 MIN E FROM ARECIBO LIGHTHOUSE AND ABOUT 2-3/4 MILES DISTANT S 5 DEG E FROM TUNA.  IT IS ON A LARGE, HIGH CORAL LEDGE THAT RUNS NE ALONG THE TOP OF THE RIDGE.  IT IS 6 FEET W OF THE CENTER OF THE LEDGE AND 50 FEET NE OF THE HIGHEST POINT OF RIDGE.  IT IS ON A POINT ABOUT 2 FEET BELOW THE HIGHEST POINT OF RIDGE.  THE STATION BEARS ABOUT 20 DEG N OF E FROM MARCO MALDONAOS HOUSE.  THE STATION IS MARKED BY A 2-FOOT BY 2-INCH GALVANIZED IRON PIPE SET IN A BED OF CEMENT, THE TOP OF THE PIPE PROJECTING 4-1/2 INCHES ABOVE THE GROUND.  THE PIPE IS FILLED WITH CEMENT AND THE CENTER OF A NAIL DRIVEN IN THE CEMENT MARKS THE STATION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1934)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1934 DESCRIPTION ADEQUATE.  CENTER OF STATION REMARKED BY POINT OF A BRASS NAIL IN THE CENTER OF A CONCRETE BLOCK.                            STATION RECOVERY (1946)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US ARMY CORPS OF ENGINEERS 1946 LETTER FROM MR. E.G. RUBIO, HQ. ANTILLES DEPT., OFFICE OF DEPT. ENGR., A.P.O. 851, C/O P.M., MIAMI, FLORIDA, DATED OCTOBER 30, 1946--  THE REMANTS OF PROBABLE BASE OF PIPES FOUND.  THE IRON BAR CENTERED ON THEM, BUT WAS IN PLAIN EARTH AND NOT ROCK LEDGE.  EXACT RECOVERY WAS DOUBTFUL.
markers.setting: SET INTO TOP OF METAL PIPE DRIVEN INTO GROUND
markers.stability: MARK OF QUESTIONABLE OR UNKNOWN STABILITY

markers.description: BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1940 RECOVERED THE SAME STATION MARK FOUND BY ME IN 1931.  THIS STATION IS LOCATED ON THE SAME HILL WHERE MALD 1901 WAS ESTABLISHED BY J.N. AND WHICH WAS NOT RECOVERED IN 1927 OR 1931 BY MATTISON, AND NOW THERE ARE NO TRACES OF THE CORAL LEDGE WHERE THEY CLAIMED TO HAVE LOCATED THE PIPE AND NO PIPE WAS FOUND ON THE WHOLE HILL.  A CONE MONUMENT FLUSH WITH GROUND WAS FOUND ON PLAIN EARTH, WHERE A CENTER POINT WITH A BRASS NAIL WAS ESTABLISHED.  IN 1934 IT WAS THOUGHT THAT THIS WAS THE ORIGINAL POINT, BUT THE DIFFERENCE OF THE POINT FOUND AND THE POINT DESCRIBED DEMONSTRATE NOW THAT THE POINT IS NOT THE SAME.  THE BEST WAY TO APPROACH THIS STATION NOW IS BY FOLLOWING A SECOND CLASS ROAD WHICH STARTS N FROM KM. 76.5 RD. NO. 2, TO ITS FIRST Y FORK WHERE LEAVING MAIN ROAD FOLLOW BRANCH WHICH WINDS ABOUT NE TO QUARRY AND AN OLD TENNIS COURT ON TOP OF THE RIDGE, FOLLOW E ON FOOT PASSING FIRST SADDLE CLIMB TO TOP OF NOSE TURNING S (RIGHT) AND THEN E (LEFT) TO THE STATION.  IT IS LOCATED ABOUT NE OF THE HIGHEST POINT OF HILL.  ABOUT 25 FT. E OF NOSE RIDGE.  STATION AND REFERENCE MARKS ARE THE SAME AS DESCRIBED IN 1934.
markers.setting: SET IN TOP OF CONCRETE MONUMENT
markers.stability: MAY HOLD, BUT OF TYPE COMMONLY SUBJECT TOSURFACE MOTION

markers.description: BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1941 V.A. ELEVATION 130.46 METERS.  IN THE NW PART OF VIEQUES ISLAND ABOUT 5 KMS. EAST OF PUNTA ARENAS AND 1 KM. SOUTH OF HACIENDA ARCADIA ON THE MAIN RIDGE OF THE ISLAND.  STATION MARK IS A STANDARD TABLET STAMPED MALDONADO AND SET IN A TRIANGULAR SHAPED ROCK WHICH IS 3 FT. LONG AND 1 FT. HIGH.  R.M. NO. 1 IS A DRILL IN A ROCK 3 FT. LONG AND 2 FT. HIGH.  DISTANCE FROM STATION 8.65 METERS.  PLANE AZIMUTH 149-23.  R.M. NO. 2 IS A DRILL HOLE IN ROCK 2 FT. LONG AND 2 FT. HIGH.  DISTANCE FROM STATION 9.09 METERS.  PLANE AZIMUTH 206-10.                            STATION RECOVERY (1964)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1964 (GWM) STATION RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED.  THE FOLLOWING ADDITIONS WILL ADD IN FUTURE RECOVERIES.  STATION WAS FOUND BY TURNING SOUTH (LEFT) ON TO DIRT ROAD AT POINT WHERE MILE POST K I H5 SHOULD BE ON ISABEL II - PUNTA ARENAS ROAD.  THIS IS JUST EAST OF A DOUBLE CULVERT UNDER MAIN ROAD, IN A GROUP OF TREES.  PROCEED SOUTH DOWN DIRT ROAD PAST ELECTRIC POWER LINE ABOUT 100 FT.  THE STATION IS ON LEFT OF TWO (2) HILLS, IT IS THE LOWER OF THE TWO.  THE BEST APPROACH TO THE STATION IS TO WALK EASTERLY ABOUT 200 FEET UNTIL REACHING RIDGE LINE DESCENDING TO NORTH.  TURN SOUTH UP RIDGE LINE TO TOP OF HILL THROUGH TALL BRUSH AND BRIARS.  TOP OF HILL IS CLEAR WITH STATION IN CENTER OF CLEARING.                            STATION RECOVERY (1970)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US MARINE CORPS 1970 STATION RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION, BUT NO STATIONS INTERVISIBLE DUE TO HEAVY AMOUNT OF VEGETATION.  BEST WAY OF REACHING STATION IS TO PROCEED BY FOOT UP THE HILL DIRECTLY BEHIND NAVY BARRACKS.
markers.setting: SET IN ROCK OUTCROP
markers.stability: MOST RELIABLE AND EXPECTED TO HOLDPOSITION/ELEVATION WELL

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1965 (JJL) THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 2 MILES NORTH OF MAMEYES (PALMER) AND ON A LOW KNOLL.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE JUNCTION OF HIGHWAYS 3 AND 968 IN MAMEYES (PALMER), GO NORTH AND NORTHWEST ON HIGHWAY 968 FOR 2.5 MILES TO THE STATION ON THE RIGHT.  THE ANTENNA IS A STEEL-TRUSS STRUCTURE, PAINTED ALTERNATELY RED AND WHITE AND IT IS SELF-SUPPORTING.  FROM A DISTANCE THE ANTENNA APPEARS TO BE A RECTANGULAR-SHAPED SCREEN.  THE ANTENNA IS ABOUT 170 FEET HIGH AND 140 FEET LONG.  POINT INTERSECTED IS THE TOP AND CENTER OF THE ANTENNA.

BY ANDREGG INCORPORATED 1995 (DJR) TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE JUNTION OF HIGHWAYS PR 22 AND PR 149, NEAR THE TOWN OF MANATI, GO WEST ON HIGHWAY PR 22 FOR 1.7 MILES (2.7 KM) TO KILOMETER POST 49.9 TO THE STATION ON THE RIGHT  THE STATION IS 6.6 METERS (21.7 FT) WEST OF THE NORTHWEST CORNER OF A CONCRETE BRIDGE OVER HIGHWAY PR 685, 1.3 METERS (4.3 FT) NORTHEAST OF THE EGDE OF PAVEMENT OF HIGHWAY PR 22, AND 1 METER (3.3 FT) NORTHEAST OF GUARD RAIL AND 1.7 METERS (5.6 FT) SOUTHWEST OF TOP OF BANK  THE STATION IS 1 METER (3.3 FT) SOUTHWEST OF A CARSONITE SURVEY MARKER WITNESS POST THE STATION IS A 3-1/4 INCH BRASS CAP STAMPED CENTRO DE RECAUDACION DE INGRESSOS MUNICIPALES, PUERTO RICO GPS CONTROL, C.R.I.M., UNLAWFUL TO DISTURB, MANATI 2, SET ATOP A 9/16 INCH STAINLESS STEEL ROD DRIVEN TO REFUSAL AND COVERED FLUSH WITH THE GROUND BY AN ALUMINUM COVER EPOXYED ONTO A 6 INCH SCHEDULE 40 PVC PIPE SET IN CONCRETE INSIDE AND OUT                            STATION RECOVERY (2002)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 2002 (JMW) 4.7 KM (2.95 MI) EASTERLY ALONG STATE HIGHWAY 22 FROM THE JUNCTION OF STATE HIGHWAY 140 IN BARCELONETA, 38.3 M WEST OF THE CENTER OF STATE HIGHWAY 685, 36.1 M WEST OF KILOMETER POST 50.3, 8.1 M NORTH OF THE CENTERLINE OF THE WESTBOUND HIGHWAY, 6.6 M WEST OF THE WEST END OF THE NORTH CONCRETE GUARDRAIL OF THE HIGHWAY OVERPASS OF HIGHWAY 685, 1.0 M NORTH OF A METAL GUARDRAIL, AND 0.3 M BELOW THE LEVEL OF THE HIGHWAY, NOTE--ACCESS TO THE DATUM POINT IS THROUGH A 5-INCH LOGO CAP.  THE MARK IS ON THE HIGHWAY RIGHT-OF-WAY.                            STATION RECOVERY (2002)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 2002 (JMW) RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED.                            STATION RECOVERY (2009)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 2009 (NMD) NO CAP, DIRT INSIDE OF CASING, BRING A MACHETE FOR GPS OBS. TO CUT SOME SMALL TREES THAT CAN AFFECT THE JOB MARQTEK ENGINEERING.                            STATION RECOVERY (2011)  RECOVERY NOTE BY POLYTECHNIC UNIVERSITY OF PUERTO RICO 2011 (GIS) THE DESCRIPTION IS ADEQUATE. EXCEPT THE CENTERLINE OF THE WESTBOUND HIGHWAY 6.60 METERS, INSTEAD CHANGED TO 6.80 METERS.
markers.setting: STAINLESS STEEL ROD W/O SLEEVE (10 FT.+)

markers.description: BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1934 STATION IS THE CROSS ON A PROMINENT RED SPIRE OF THE CATHOLIC CHURCH AT MANATI.  NO CHECK ON THIS POSITION.
PTIVE TEXT AVAILABLE.

BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1900 (SF) STATION IS ON A HIGH SHARP FOOT-HILL, SE OF THE TOWN OF MANATI, HAVING A VERY SCANTY GROWTH OF TREES NEAR THE TOP AND SHOWS A LOT OF BARE WHITE ROCKS NEAR THE PEAK.  THE STATION IS MARKED BY A STANDARD COPPER STATION MARK, STAMPED U.S.C. AND G.S. SET INTO THE BEDROCK, WITH CEMENT.  IT IS REACHED FROM MANATI BY TAKING THE MAIN ROAD EASTWARD TOWARD VAGA BAJA, AFTER DRIVING FOR ABOUT 5 OR 6 MILES ALONG THIS ROAD OVER A LEVEL PLAIN ON WHICH ARE MANY FOOT-HILLS RISING PRECIPITOUSLY FROM IT, A PLAIN IS REACHED ON WHICH ARE VERY FEW HILLS.  UPON REACHING THIS PLAIN, TURN TO THE S FROM THE MAIN ROAD AND SKIRT ALONG THE FOOTHILLS TO THE WESTWARD OF THE PLAIN, ALONG A FOOTPATH WHICH CAN BE EASILY DRIVEN OVER WITH A TEAM. THE STATION IS ON A HILL NEAR THE SW CORNER OF THE ABOVE MENTIONED PLAIN AND IS THE HIGHEST PEAK WITHIN SIGHT OF IT. ON THIS LEVEL GROUND ARE SCATTERED MANY NATIVE HOUSES.  INQUIRE OF ANY OF THE FOLLOWING RESIDENTS WHO WILL KNOW THE LOCATION OF THE STATION AND THE TRAIL LEADING TO IT--ISADORE ROSADE, JUAN MARTINI, MANUEL MARTINI, FRANCISCO REY, JOSE LOPEZ, OR RAPHIEL MALENDI.  A CHIMNEY NEAR A LARGE SUGAR FACTORY BEARS 38 DEG 09 MIN N OF A LINE TO MONO LIGHTHOUSE.                            STATION RECOVERY (1930)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1930 (GM) THE METAL MARK WAS LOST, BUT THE HOLE FILLED WITH OLD CONCRETE MORTAR WAS FOUND.  A NEW METAL MARK IS GOING TO BE PLACED BY THE DEPARTMENT OF THE INTERIOR OF THE INSULAR GOVERNMENT.  TO REACH TAKE THE VAGA BAJA MOROVIS PUBLIC ROAD TO ITS POST MARKING KILOMETER 4 H 2.  HERE FOLLOW, TO THE LEFT, A MUNICIPAL ROAD, NEARLY COVERED BY MACADAM, ABOUT 5 MINUTES BY AUTOMOBILE TO WHERE THIS ROAD CURVES N.  TAKE FOOT TRAIL (ON DRY SEASON YOU CAN GO BY THE MOTOR CAR) TO A FARM OWNED BY D. JOSE REY.  N OF THE FARMERS HOME IS THE HILL OF THE STATION KNOWN BY THE PEOPLE AS CERRO DEL FAROL O DE LA BANDERA.                            STATION RECOVERY (1934)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1934 STATION RECOVERED AS RE-MARKED IN 1930.  STATION IS LOCATED 9 KILOMETERS BY ROAD AND TRAIL, SW OF VEGA BAJA AND ABOUT 1 KILOMETER E OF THE ROAD FROM THAT TOWN TO MOROVIS.  A FEW FEET AWAY FROM THE STATION MARK THERE IS A GUAYABOTA TREE ABOUT FIVE INCHES IN DIAMETER.  WE FOUND THE OLD CONCRETE MARK WITH A PLUG EMBEDDED IN IT AND WHICH STUCK OUT ABOUT 3 INCHES ABOVE CONCRETE.  THIS HILL IS ALSO KNOWN AS CERRO DEL FAROL AS THE SPANIARDS USED TO PLACE A LIGHTHOUSE.  STATION MARK IS A CROSS CUT ON TOP OF TWISTED REINFORCING IRON ROD EMBEDDED IN CEMENT AND PROJECTING ABOUT 3 INCHES ABOVE SURFACE.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 1 IS A COPPER NAIL AND WASHER IN BLAZE ON 4-INCH GUAYABOTE STUMP WHICH IS ABOUT 8 FEET HIGH 9.41 FEET FROM STATION IN TRUE AZIMUTH 49 DEG 08 MIN.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 2 IS POINT OF A SHARP PROJECTING ROCK ON HIGHEST POINT OF PEAK, 28.35 FEET FROM STATION IN TRUE AZIMUTH 216 DEG 37 MIN.  IT IS PROBABLY BEST REACHED AT THIS TIME BY TAKING A SECOND CLASS ROAD WHICH TURNS E OFF THE VEGA BAJA-MOROVIS CARRETERA (NO.30) AT KILOMETER POST K 4 H 3, KEEPING TO THE RIGHT AT 0.5 KILOMETER THENCE TO LEFT, NORTHWARD ON PRIVATE ROAD TO THE HOME OF THOMAS VAZQUEZ JUST AFTER PASSING PROMINENT CUT IN BANK AT ABOUT ONE KILOMETER FROM THE CARRETERA.  FROM THE HOUSE AT END OF ROAD THE STATION IS ABOUT 0.5 KILOMETER TO N AND A TRAIL LEADS FROM HOUSE TO TOP OF PEAK.  THE HILL CAN BE SEEN FROM THE HOUSE WHICH IS A SHORT DISTANCE FROM IT.  IT IS RATHER STEEP AND ROCKY, BUT CLEAR ON TOP.  IT IS A SHARP HILL FROM ONE ANGLE AND PROLONGED FROM THE OTHER.  THERE ARE NO HOUSES ON IT.  SIGNAL--A QUADRIPOD OF SAWED LUMBER COVERED WITH WHITE CLOTH AND WITH BLACK CROSS TARGETS ON CENTER POLE CENTERED OVER STATION MARK.                            STATION RECOVERY (1940)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1940 STATION AND R. M. NO. 1 RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED.  R.M. NO. 2 COULD NOT BE FOUND.  A NEW REFERENCE MARK NO. 3 WAS ESTABLISHED.  DESCRIPTION FOLLOWS--  LOCATED ABOUT 5 MILES ESE OF MANATI.  2-3/4 MILES SW OF VEGA BAJA.  1-1/2 MILES S OF JUNCTION OF VEGA BAJA - MANATI AND VEGA BAJA - MOROVIS ROADS.  AND ABOUT 1/2 MILE NE OF MATIENZA CINTRON SCHOOL.  ON TOP OF A STEEP, BRUSH-COVERED HILL.  THE STATION IS THE CENTER OF A 3/4 INCH REINFORCING STEEL BAR EMBEDDED IN CONCRETE AND PROJECTING ABOUT 3 INCHES.  R. M. NO. 1 (1930) IS A COPPER NAIL AND WASHER IN BLAZE ON 4 INCH GUAYABOTE STUMP, 8 FT. HIGH AND 9.41 FT. IN AZIMUTH 49 DEG 08 MIN.  R. M. NO. 2 IS POINT OF A SHARP, PROJECTING ROCK ON HIGHEST POINT OF PEAK, 28.35 FT. FROM STATION IN AZIMUTH 216 DEG 37 MIN.  (NOT FOUND, 1941).  R. M. NO. 3 (1941) IS A STANDARD TABLET CEMENTED TO ROCK ON SUMMIT, 27.25 FT. FROM STATION IN AZIMUTH 216 DEG 57 MIN.  TO REACH FROM VEGA BAJA GO WEST ON HIGHWAY TO JUNCTION OF MOROVIS ROAD.  FROM HERE GO S 2.5 MILES TO K4 H2 AND TURN LEFT.  GO 0.2 MILE AND PASS SCHOOL.  CONTINUE 0.2 MILE AND TURN RIGHT (SE) GOING THENCE 0.4 MILE TO FORK.  TAKE LEFT 0.05 MILE TO HOUSE OF JACINTO RAMOS.  THE STATION HILL IS ABOUT 400M N OF HERE.  TAKE TRAIL N BETWEEN EDGE OF CANE FIELD AND HILL, PASS ROYAL PALM AND DRAIN, CROSS SPUR RIDGE, AND ABOUT 50 METERS BEFORE REACHING A SMALL HOUSE TURN LEFT UP HILL TO STATION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1966)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JJL) THE STATION MARK WAS FOUND AND IN GOOD CONDITION.  REFERENCE MARKS 1, 2 AND 3 HAVE BEEN DESTROYED.  REFERENCE MARKS 4 AND 5 WERE ESTABLISHED AT THIS DATE.  A NEW DESCRIPTION FOLLOWS--  THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 5 MILES SOUTH-SOUTHEAST OF MANATI, 3 MILES SOUTH OF VEGA BAJA AND ON A STEEP AND SHARP HILL THAT IS COVERED WITH BRUSH.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE JUNCTION OF HIGHWAYS 2 AND 685 IN VEGA BAJA, GO WEST ON HIGHWAY 2 FOR 1.0 MILE TO THE JUNCTION OF HIGHWAY 671.  TURN LEFT AND GO SOUTH ON HIGHWAY 671 FOR 0.2 MILE TO THE JUNCTION WITH HIGHWAY 155.  TURN RIGHT AND GO WEST ON HIGHWAY 155 FOR 0.65 MILE TO A Y-FORK.  TAKE THE LEFT FORK AND CONTINUE WEST ON HIGHWAY 155 FOR 2.45 MILES TO A SIDE ROAD ON THE LEFT.  TURN LEFT AND GO SOUTH ON A PAVED ROAD FOR 0.2 MILE TO A Y-FORK.  TAKE THE RIGHT FORK AND GO SOUTHEAST ON A PAVED ROAD FOR 0.3 MILE TO A SIDE ROAD ON THE LEFT.  TURN LEFT AND GO NORTH ON A TRACK ROAD FOR 0.05 MILE TO A GATE.  PASS THROUGH THE GATE AND CONTINUE NORTH FOR 0.05 MILE TO ANOTHER GATE.  PASS THROUGH THE GATE AND CONTINUE NORTH ACROSS A PASTURE FOR 0.15 MILE TO THE END OF TRUCK TRAVEL AT THE BASE OF A HILL.  PACK NORTHWEST UP A STEEP TRAIL FOR 15 MINUTES TO THE TOP OF A SADDLE, BEAR LEFT AND PACK WEST ON A TRAIL FOR 10 MINUTES TO THE HIGHEST POINT OF THE HILL AND THE STATION.  THE STATION MARK IS A 3/4-INCH PIECE OF IRON ROD THAT IS CEMENTED IN A ROCK OUTCROP THAT PROJECTS 1 FOOT.  THE ROD HAS A CROSS CHISELED ON ITS TOP.  NOTE--DESC.  REFERENCE MARK 4 IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED MANATI NO 4 1900 1966, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A ROCK OUTCROP THAT PROJECTS 6 INCHES AND IS 2 FEET LOWER IN ELEVATION THAN THE STATION MARK.  NOTE 12A.  REFERENCE MARK 5 IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED MANATI NO 5 1900 1966, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A ROCK OUTCROP THAT PROJECTS 6 INCHES AND IS 2 FEET LOWER IN ELEVATION THAN THE STATION MARK.  NOTE--12A.  NO SUITABLE PLACE WAS FOUND FOR AN AZIMUTH MARK.  AIRLINE DISTANCE AND DIRECTION FROM NEAREST TOWN 3 MILES SOUTH OF VEGA BAJA.                            STATION RECOVERY (2004)  RECOVERY NOTE BY UNIVERSITY OF PUERTO RICO AT MAYAGUEZ 2004 (YRR) MARK NOT FOUND.
markers.setting: SET IN UNSPECIFIED ROCK OR BOULDER
markers.stability: PROBABLY HOLD POSITION/ELEVATION WELL

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1900 (JN) STATION IS NEAR THE WESTERN END OF THE LONG POINT BETWEEN THE OPEN SEA AND THE OUTSIDE ARM OF GUANICA BAY (CALLED PARDON BAY).  IT IS ABOUT 5/8 MILE BACK FROM THE OUTSIDE COAST, NEAR THE EASTERN END OF THE SUMMIT OF THE RIDGE.  FROM THE STATION, ONE CAN SEE A SMALL BIT OF WATER AND THE SHORE OF GUANICA BAY AT THE FOOT OF THE HILL ON WHICH LABRA POLE WAS PLACED.  STATION MARK IS A PIECE OF BRASS ROD ABOUT 3/8 INCHES IN DIAMETER AND 3-1/2 INCHES LONG WHICH WAS CEMENTED INTO A HOLE DRILLED IN THE ROCK ON WHICH THE SIGNAL STANDS.  TO REACH IT BY BOAT ONE SHOULD GO TO THE LITTLE BAY JUST W OF GUANICA POINT AND THEN TAKE THE WAGON ROAD LEADING TO GUANICA UNTIL THE WESTERN END OF THE RIDGE IS DUE S AND THEN TURN TO THE PLACE INDICATED ON THE PLANE-TABLE SHEET.  IF ONE COMES TO THE STATION FROM GUANICA, HE MUST TAKE THE SALINAS ROAD TO A POINT WHERE HE IS IN LINE BETWEEN THE WESTERN END OF THE BREA RIDGE AND THE RIDGE ON WHICH GUANICA IS LOCATED, AND THEN TURN TO THE S.  A DIM WOOD-ROAD LEADS FROM THE SALINAS ROAD TO THE FOOT OF THE RIDGE AND THEN A NARROW TRAIL CUT OUT BY US LEADS TO THE SUMMIT.  A TRIPOD SIGNAL WAS ERECTED AT THE STATION AND LANES WERE CUT OUT TOWARDS CASA, GUANICA, PENENES, AND CORAL.  MANUEL AND ABAD PARDILLA LIVING AT GUANICA WERE WITH THE PARTY AT THIS STATION AND CAN POINT IT OUT.  THE NATIVES SOMETIMES CALL THE HILL MANGLIO AND SOMETIMES MANGILLO, THE LATTER BEING THE DIMINUTIVE FOR THE FIRST WORD, MANGROVE IN ENGLISH.
markers.setting: SET IN A BOULDER
markers.stability: MAY HOLD, BUT OF TYPE COMMONLY SUBJECT TOSURFACE MOTION

markers.description: PTIVE TEXT AVAILABLE.

BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1941 (RLS) THE STATION IS LOCATED ON THE ROOSEVELT ROADS NAVAL RESERVATION, ON CABRAS ISLAND, ON THE MOST WESTERLY POINT ON THE S SIDE OF THE ISLAND, ABOUT 14 METERS W OF A SMALL GULLY AT THE E SIDE OF THE ROCKY POINT, ABOUT 6 METERS E OF ANOTHER SMALL GULLY, ABOUT 4-1/2 METERS N OF THE EDGE OF THE BRUSH AND VEGETATION AT THE OUTER END OF THE POINT.  CABRAS ISLAND LIGHT IS VISIBLE OVER THE TOP OF THE NEXT RIDGE TO THE E.  STATION IS MARKED BY A STANDARD BRONZE DISK SET IN A CONCRETE BLOCK WHICH PROJECTS 4 INCHES ABOVE THE SURFACE OF THE GROUND.  THERE IS NO UNDERGROUND MARK.  THE WITNESS MARK IS A TRIANGULAR BLAZE ON THE E SIDE OF A 6-INCH TREE AT THE E EDGE OF THE GULLY W OF THE STATION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1961)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1961 (MLO) THE STATION IS DESTROYED.  THE CONCRETE MONUMENT WITH MARK STAMPED MAR 1941 WAS FOUND LOOSE AT THE EDGE OF THE MEAN HIGH WATER LINE IN THE GENERAL AREA AS DESCRIBED IN THE ORIGINAL DESCRIPTION.
markers.setting: SET IN TOP OF CONCRETE MONUMENT
markers.stability: MAY HOLD, BUT OF TYPE COMMONLY SUBJECT TOSURFACE MOTION

markers.description: BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1934 STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 16 KILOMETERS BY ROAD AND TRAIL N OF PONCE, ON THE HIGHEST PEAK OF A PROMINENT RIDGE LYING BETWEEN THE HEADWATERS OF RIO PORTUGUESE AND RIO BUCANA OR CERRILLOS, IN SECTION KNOWN AS MARAGUEZ, IT IS TO THE W OF THE MAIN ROAD WHICH LEADS UP TO THE RIO BUCANA (OR CERRILLOS) INTO THE MARAGUEZ AREA AND WHICH BRANCHES OFF THE CARRETERA NO. 1 AT A POINT ABOUT 3 KILOMETERS NE OF PONCE.  STATION MARK IS A STANDARD TABLET STAMPED MARAGUEZ 1934 SET IN BLOCK OF CEMENT.  SIGNAL--A TRIPOD OF SAWED LUMBER 18 FEET HIGH WITH BLACK CROSS TARGETS ON A MAST ON TOP OF TRIPOD.  TO REACH THE STATION FOLLOW MARAGUEZ ROAD FOR 10 KILOMETERS TO A BRANCH ROAD WHICH TURNS OFF UP A DRAW JUST AFTER CROSSING A CONCRETE BRIDGE.  FOLLOW BRANCH ROAD AS FAR AS CAR CAN BE TAKEN, CONTINUE ON TRAIL WHICH LEADS TO COFFEE PLANTATION OF DRAGONI, WHO HAS QUITE A LARGE HACIENDA ON THE E SLOPE OF THE MOUNTAIN, JUST UNDER THE PEAK ON WHICH STATION IS LOCATED AND WHICH IS PLAINLY VISIBLE FROM HIS HOUSE.  INQUIRY SHOULD BE MADE HERE AS TO BEST ROUTE TO TOP AS THERE IS NO THROUGH TRAIL.
markers.setting: SET IN TOP OF CONCRETE MONUMENT
markers.stability: MAY HOLD, BUT OF TYPE COMMONLY SUBJECT TOSURFACE MOTION

markers.description: BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 2019 STATION IS A GPS CORS.  LATEST INFORMATION INCLUDING POSITIONS AND VELOCITIES ARE AVAILABLE IN THE COORDINATE AND LOG FILES ACCESSIBLE BY ANONYMOUS FTP OR THE WORLDWIDE WEB.    https://geodesy.noaa.gov/corsdata/coord/coord_14     https://geodesy.noaa.gov/corsdata/station_log     https://geodesy.noaa.gov/CORS
