markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1900 (JN) THIS STATION WAS LOCATED ON THE E END, ON THE INSIDE LINE OF CORAL FORMING PART OF THE LARGE REEF KNOWN LOCALLY AS MARGARITA REEF.  IT IS ABOUT 2 MILES OFF SHORE AND ON ABOUT THE ONLY PART OF THE REEF THAT IS NOT ALMOST PERMANENTLY COVERED WITH WATER, ON ABOUT THE ONLY PLACE WHERE AN INSTRUMENT COULD BE SET UP.  ON THE WESTERN END AND OUTSIDE EDGE OF THE BIG REEF LIE THE BOILERS AND SOME OTHER PORTIONS OF A WRECKED STEAMER.  IT IS SUPPOSED THE STEAMER WAS THE MARGARITA.  THE WRECK IS ABOUT A MILE AWAY FROM THE SIGNAL.  THE PLACE SELECTED FOR THE STATION IS WHERE THE CORAL ROCK PROJECTS ABOVE ORDINARY STAGES OF TIDE.  STATION IS MARKED BY A 2-INCH IRON PIPE WHICH WAS CEMENTED IN THE ROCK, PROTRUDING ABOUT 2 INCHES.  ON THE TOP OF THIS PIPE, A BRACED POLE WAS SET FOR A SIGNAL.  JOSE BAIS ACCOMPANIED THE PARTY TO THIS POINT FROM PARGUERA.                            STATION RECOVERY (1903)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1903 (WEP) STATION NOT RECOVERED.  REEF AWASH WHEN WE VISITED IT.
markers.setting: OBJECT SURROUNDED BY MASS OF CONCRETE
markers.stability: MARK OF QUESTIONABLE OR UNKNOWN STABILITY

markers.description: BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1934 STATION IS A LARGE IRON STACK ON A RED-ROOFED BUILDING ON TOP OF RIDGE S OF CERRO MORALES AND E OF ALTURA, ON BARRIO MAMEYES OF FLORIDA.

BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JWC) THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 8 MILES NORTH-NORTHEAST OF CABO ROJO, 2 MILES SOUTHEAST OF MAYAGUEZ AND ON THE WEST END OF A LOW, EAST-WEST RIDGE THAT IS LOCATED IN A RESIDENTIAL AREA OVERLOOKING MAYAGUEZ.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE NORTHEAST CORNER OF THE PLAZA IN MAYAGUEZ, GO EAST ON MC KINLEY STREET FOR 0.2 MILE TO A CROSS- STREET.  TURN RIGHT AND GO SOUTH ON LICEO STREET FOR 0.25 MILE TO A Y-FORK.  KEEP THE LEFT FORK AND GO EAST AND SOUTHEAST, UPHILL, FOR 0.9 MILE TO A Y-FORK.  KEEP THE LEFT FORK AND GO NORTH, EAST AND SOUTHEAST FOR 0.6 MILE TO A SIDE ROAD RIGHT. TURN RIGHT AND GO SOUTH FOR 0.1 MILE TO A SIDE ROAD RIGHT. TURN RIGHT AND GO WEST FOR 0.15 MILE TO THE STATION ON THE LEFT, SOUTH, SIDE OF THE ROAD AT THE END OF THE EAST-WEST RIDGE.  THE STATION MARK IS A STANDARD DISK, STAMPED MARI 1966, SET IN THE TOP OF A 10-INCH SQUARE CONCRETE MONUMENT THAT PROJECTS 8 INCHES.  IT IS LOCATED 17.5 FEET SOUTH OF THE APPROXIMATE CENTER OF THE PAVED ROAD AND 3.8 FEET NORTHEAST OF THE POWER POLE.  REFERENCE MARK 1 IS A STANDARD DISK, STAMPED MARI NO 1 1966, SET IN THE TOP OF A 10-INCH SQUARE CONCRETE MONUMENT THAT IS FLUSH WITH THE SURFACE OF THE GROUND.  IT IS LOCATED 38.5 FEET NORTHEAST OF THE POWER POLE AND 18 FEET NORTH OF THE APPROXIMATE CENTER OF THE PAVED ROAD.  REFERENCE MARK 2 IS A STANDARD DISK, STAMPED MARI NO 2 1966, SET IN THE TOP OF A 10-INCH SQUARE CONCRETE MONUMENT THAT PROJECTS 8 INCHES.  IT IS LOCATED 25.3 FEET EAST OF THE POWER POLE AND 15.5 FEET SOUTH OF THE APPROXIMATE CENTER OF THE PAVED ROAD.  AN AZIMUTH MARK WAS NOT ESTABLISHED.
markers.setting: SET IN TOP OF CONCRETE MONUMENT
markers.stability: MAY HOLD, BUT OF TYPE COMMONLY SUBJECT TOSURFACE MOTION

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1900 (JN) STATION IS ALMOST ON THE EXTREME WESTERN END OF THE WESTERN ONE OF THE TWO ISLETS TO WHICH THE NAME MARIA LANGUA IS GIVEN.  IT IS IN A LITTLE GLADE AMONG THE MANGROVES AND IS DISTANT ABOUT 5 METERS FROM THE HIGH-WATER MARK, AND IS THE ONLY CLEARED SPOT AT THE W END OF THE ISLET.  STATION MARK IS A 2-FOOT IRON PIPE EMBEDDED 21 INCHES IN THE GROUND AND THEN SURROUNDED AND FILLED WITH CONCRETE.  IN THE CEMENT WHICH FILLS THE PIPE AN IRON NAIL WAS SET AT THE STATION CENTER.  A LANDING PLACE HAS BEEN CLEARED BY FISHERMEN WHICH PERMITS A BOAT TO COME WITHIN 5 METERS OF THE SIGNAL, AND SITTING AT THE FOOT OF THE SIGNAL ONE CAN SEE THE POINT AT THE RIGHT-HAND ENTRANCE TO GUAYANILLA BAY, THE VALLEY IN WHICH GUAYANILLA IS LOCATED, AND AROUND TO THE LEFT TO THE BRIGHT RED NEW CHIMNEY JUST COMPLETED ON THE TRUJILLO SUGAR ESTATE.                            STATION RECOVERY (1901)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1901 (GLF) FOUND STATION MARK UNDISTURBED.
markers.setting: OBJECT SURROUNDED BY MASS OF CONCRETE
markers.stability: MARK OF QUESTIONABLE OR UNKNOWN STABILITY

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1900 (WCH) STATION IS THE TALL, RED AND WHITE STACK OF A SUGAR MILL ON THE MARIE PLANTATION BETWEEN FORT MULA AND MOUNT PIRATA, N COAST OF VIEQUES ISLAND.                            STATION RECOVERY (1903)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1903 (RLF) RECOVERED.  THE SIGNAL IS STILL STANDING AS DESCRIBED.                            STATION RECOVERY (1923)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1923 (FTS) STACK NOT IN EXISTENCE.

BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1934 STATION IS IN BARRIO MARIN ON A SHARP POINTED ROCKY HILL WHICH IS DEDICATED TO RICE CULTIVATION, AND WHICH HAS AN ADJACENT HILL VERY SIMILAR TO THIS ONE BUT WHICH IS LOWER AND FORMS A SADDLE WITH IT.  BOTH ARE RATHER STEEP TO CLIMB, BUT THE ASCENT IS NOT FAR FROM THE TRAIL.  THIS HILL IS TO THE N OF THE TOWN OF PATILLAS.  STATION MARK IS A STANDARD U.S.G.S. BENCH MARK SET ON BOULDER ON THE CREST, STAMPED MARIN 1934.  REFERENCE MARK NO.1 IS A CROSS ON BOULDER, 23 FEET 11-1/2 INCHES DISTANT FROM STATION, IN TRUE AZIMUTH 179 DEG 49 MIN.  REFERENCE MARK NO.2 IS A CROSS ON BOULDER, 14 FEET 3-1/2 INCHES FROM STATION, IN TRUE AZIMUTH 238 DEG 42 MIN.  TO REACH STATION, TAKE ROAD LEADING TO THE PATILLAS RESERVOIR AND DRIVE TO ITS TERMINATION.  CROSS THE RIVER AND TAKE CAMINO BEAL IN AN EASTERLY DIRECTION.  IT WILL TAKE YOU TO THE BASE OF THE HILL WHICH IS A SHORT DISTANCE FROM STATION.  THIS HILL IS LOCALLY KNOWN AS LA TORRECILLA BUT NOT IDENTIFIED AS TORRECILLA OF BARRANQUITAS.  THIS STATION IS ABOUT 7 KILOMETERS FROM THE ROAD.                            STATION RECOVERY (1965)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1965 (JJL) THE STATION MARK WAS RECOVERED AND FOUND IN GOOD CONDITION.  TWO REFERENCE MARKS AND AN AZIMUTH MARK WERE ESTABLISHED AT THIS STATION.  A COMPLETE NEW DESCRIPTION OF THE STATION FOLLOWS.  THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 8-3/4 MILES WEST OF YABUCOA AND ABOUT 4 AIRLINE MILES NORTHEAST OF PATILLAS, ON A HIGH WOODED HILL WITH LARGE OUTCROPPING BOULDERS ON THE HIGHEST POINT.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE NORTHWEST CORNER OF THE PLAZA IN PATILLAS, GO WEST ON A PAVED STREET FOR 0.1 MILE TO HIGHWAY 181.  TURN RIGHT AND GO NORTHERLY ON HIGHWAY 181 FOR 4.7 MILES TO A TRAIL ON THE RIGHT JUST AFTER PASSING KILOMETER POST 26.4 AND END OF TRUCK TRAVEL.  FROM HERE PACK EASTERLY UPHILL ON THE TRAIL PASSING 2 HOUSES TO A GATE.  PASS THROUGH THE GATE AND CONTINUE EASTERLY UP THE TRAIL FOR ABOUT 3/4 MILE TO A GATE IN A LOW SADDLE.  PASS THROUGH THE GATE, TURN LEFT AND PACK NORTH UP A STEEP ROCKY HILL FOR ABOUT 1/4 MILE TO THE HIGHEST POINT OF THE HILL AND STATION.  ALLOW 2-1/2 HOURS FOR PACKING.  THE STATION MARK IS A USGS BM STAMPED MARIN 1934, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A BOULDER WHICH PROJECTS 6 INCHES.  REFERENCE MARK 1 IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED MARIN USGS NO 1 1934, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A BOULDER WHICH PROJECTS 3 FEET.  REFERENCE MARK 2 IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED MARIN USGS NO 2 1934, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A BOULDER WHICH PROJECTS 3 FEET AND ABOUT 6 FEET LOWER THAN THE STATION.  THE AZIMUTH MARK IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED MARIN USGS 1934, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A CULVERT WHICH PROJECTS 1 FOOT.  IT IS 59 FEET NORTHWEST OF KILOMETER POST 23.9, 13 FEET EAST OF THE CENTER OF HIGHWAY 181 AND 1 FOOT NORTHWEST OF THE SOUTHEAST EDGE OF THE CULVERT.  TO REACH THE AZIMUTH MARK FROM THE END OF TRUCK TRAVEL, GO NORTHERLY ON HIGHWAY 181 FOR 1.5 MILE TO A SMALL STORE ON THE LEFT AND THE AZIMUTH MARK ON THE RIGHT.  AIRLINE DISTANCE AND DIRECTION FROM NEAREST TOWN 4 MILES NORTHEAST OF PATILLAS.
markers.setting: SET IN A BOULDER
markers.stability: MAY HOLD, BUT OF TYPE COMMONLY SUBJECT TOSURFACE MOTION

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1900 (JN) IT HAS BEEN VERY DIFFICULT TO DECIDE UPON WHAT IS THE TRUE NAME OF THIS HILL BECAUSE OF THE ABUNDANCE OF CHOICE OF NAMES OFFERED.  OUR FIRST INFORMANT, ABAD PARTILLO, AN EXCEPTIONALLY INTELLIGENT NATIVE OF GUANICA, TOLD US THAT THE HILL ON WHICH THE STATION WAS PLACED WAS CALLED MOZAMBIQUE (THE SPANISH NAME FOR THE SMALL BLACK BIRD LIKE THE COW BIRD OF THE SW UNITED STATES) WHICH IS VERY COMMON ON THE ISLAND AND WE BEGAN TO USE THAT NAME IN THE RECORD.  AFTER OUR ARRIVAL IN PARGUERA WE WERE TOLD THERE THAT MOZAMBIQUE WAS A SMALLER MOUNTAIN BEYOND THIS AND THAT THE NAME OF THE HILL WAS MARIQUITA.  AS OUR INFORMANTS LIVED MUCH NEARER THE HILL THAN PARTILLO, WE CONCLUDED HE WAS MISTAKEN AND CALLED THE STATION MARIQUITA, CHANGING THE NAME IN THE RECORD WHERE THE OTHER NAME HAD BEEN WRITTEN.  A FEW OBSERVATIONS HAD BEEN MADE ON IT THEN. WHEN WE REACHED BOQUERON WE COULD FIND NO ONE WHO KNEW OF ANY SUCH NAME AS MARIQUITA FOR THE MOUNTAIN, AND THE ONLY NAME KNOWN THERE WAS MOZAMBIQUE.  HEARING THAT A SURVEYOR LIVED IN THE VILLAGE, WE VISITED HIM TO GET HIS VIEWS ON THE SUBJECT.  HE ACCOMPANIED US OUT TO WHERE A GOOD VIEW OF THE STATION COULD BE HAD, AND ON THE SIGNAL BEING POINTED OUT, AND HE BEING ASKED THE NAME, SAID HAL SIERRA BERMEJAI.  ON FURTHER EXAMINATION HE SAID THAT HE KNEW THERE WAS A HILL IN THE RANGE CALLED MOZAMBIQUE BUT WHICH ONE IT WAS HE DID NOT KNOW, BUT HE WAS POSITIVE THAT THE RANGE WAS CALLED SIERRA BERMEJA (RED RANGE).  THERE IS A CONSIDERABLE RED PORPHYRY ON THE HILL AND THE EXPOSED ROCKS HAVE A GENERAL NOTICEABLE REDDISH TINT.  IT IS PROBABLE THAT THIS IS CALLED THE RED RANGE AND THAT OUR SIGNAL IS ON MOZAMBIQUE HILL.  THE HILL IS A VERY NOTICEABLE ONE.  IT IS THE HIGHEST POINT OF THE CHAIN WHICH EXTENDS ALONG THE COAST FROM BREA TO THE W COAST OF THE ISLAND, BOUNDING ON THE S THE PRETTY VALLEY WHICH EXTENDS FROM LAKE GUANICA TO BOQUERON.  THERE CAN BE NO DOUBT ABOUT WHAT HILL THE STATION IS ON TO ANYONE COMING TO THE SW COAST OF THE ISLAND, AS IT IS ON THE HIGHEST POINT OF A RIDGE WHERE LOCATION IS UNQUESTIONABLE FROM ITS RELATION TO THE VALLEY JUST MENTIONED.  MARK IS A 2-FOOT PIECE OF 2-INCH IRON PIPE OF WHICH ABOUT 17 INCHES IS BURIED IN GROUND AND SECURED BY CEMENT.  CENTER OF PIPE IS FILLED WITH CEMENT AND AT THE N POINT OF PIPE, A NAIL HAS BEEN SET WHOSE N EDGE IS THE CENTER OF STATION.  PIPE WAS SET BEFORE STATION WAS PLUMBED DOWN CAREFULLY AND SO THE NAIL IS OFF TO ONE SIDE.  ABOUT 4 METERS W OF STATION MARK AND ABOUT 16 METERS N OF IT, THE GROUND BEGINS TO SLOPE OFF FROM TOP.  OWNER OF LAND IS ANTONIO GARATASIO.  PELEGRIN TORRES OF BOQUERON AND JOSE BAIS OF PARGUERA HAVE ACCOMPANIED THE PARTY TO THIS STATION AND CAN POINT IT OUT.  TO REACH STATION FROM BOQUERON, TAKE ROAD WHICH LEADS TO DR. HERNANDEZS SUGAR HOUSE AND THEN GO S TO BASE OF HILLS THAT WILL BE IN VIEW (THESE ARE THE BERMEJA RANGE).  WHEN THE ROAD AT THE BASE OF THE HILLS IS REACHED, TURN E AND DRIVE ON TO CABIN OF DELORES GARCIA.  HERE THE VEHICLE MUST BE LEFT AND ONE MUST GO ALONG THE TRAIL LEADING UP THE VALLEY DOWN WHICH A CLEAR STREAM OF WATER FLOWS.  A SHORT DISTANCE BEYOND A SPRING THAT WILL BE MET A TRAIL WILL BE NOTICED TURNING TO RIGHT AND GOING UP HILLSIDE.  THIS LEADS TO SUMMIT OF HILL AND STATION.  FOR CONVENIENCE OF OBSERVATION, EXTENSIVE CLEARING OF TREES AND BRUSH HAS BEEN MADE ABOUT SUMMIT.  CLEARING WILL BE GOOD MARK.  TOP OF HILL IS FLAT.  NEAR THE NW EDGE OF THIS FLAT, STATION WAS LOCATED.                            STATION RECOVERY (1901)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1901 (JEM) STATION RECOVERED.  THE HILL ON WHICH IT IS LOCATED IS A VERY HIGH ONE, ABOUT 970 FEET BY BAROMETER AND IS LOCATED ON THE PROPERTY ON DON PEPI CARTAGENA, AN AGED AND WEALTHY LAND OWNER AND LAWYER, WHOSE HOME IS IN SAN GERMAN.  THE HACIENDA IS CALLED DESENGANO.  THE PEOPLE ON THE MOUNTAIN SIDE (ON THE ESTATE) AND AS FAR AS LAJAS AND SAN GERMAN CALLED THE MOUNTAIN FENAJA, THE SPANISH NAME FOR THE POROUS EARTH BOTTLES IN WHICH DRINKING WATER IS COOLED.  THE HILL IS EXTREMELY DIFFICULT TO CLIMB THE WAY WE WENT UP, THE SLOPE BEING STEEP, COVERED WITH LOOSE STONES, AND THE PATH GOING THROUGH A DENSE THORNY GROWTH OF BUSHES, BUT A PATH WAS SHOWN ME ON WHICH I CAME DOWN WHICH MAKES THE ASCENT VERY EASY.  ANYONE VISITING THE STATION HAD BETTER GET A GUIDE ON THE CARTAGENA PLANTATION, AND USE THIS PATH.
markers.setting: SET INTO TOP OF METAL PIPE DRIVEN INTO GROUND
markers.stability: MARK OF QUESTIONABLE OR UNKNOWN STABILITY

markers.description: BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1934 STATION IS ON A PROMINENT HIGH PEAK AT THE W END OF A COAST RANGE, 12.5 KILOMETERS SW OF LAJAS.  THIS IS THE HIGHEST AND MOST PROMINENT PEAK IN VICINITY AND CANNOT BE MISTAKEN.  STATION IS ABOUT 10 FEET FROM BEGINNING OF SLOPE ON HIGHEST PART OF TOP, EXTENDING FARTHEST TO N.  TOP IS RATHER BROAD IN EXTENT AND IS COVERED THICKLY WITH BRUSH.  STATION IS PROBABLY BEST APPROACHED FROM THE N AS CAR CAN BE TAKEN TO FOOT OF MOUNTAIN ON THAT SIDE AND CLIMB TO TOP IS SHORTER BY ABOUT 2 KILOMETERS.  STATION IS ON SAME PEAK AS MARIQUITA AND PROBABLY CLOSE TO IT, ALTHOUGH NO TRACE OF OLD STATION MARK COULD BE FOUND.  STATION MARK IS A STANDARD U.S.G.S. TABLET, STAMPED MARIQUITA-2-1934, CEMENTED IN A LARGE ROCK SET IN GROUND.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 1 IS A COPPER NAIL AND WASHER IN TRIANGULAR BLAZE ON SIGNAL TREE, 18.75 FEET FROM STATION IN TRUE AZIMUTH 14 DEG 12 MIN.  REFERENCE MARK NO.2 IS A COPPER NAIL AND WASHER IN OLD UNDERCUT ON LARGE TREE ON NW SLOPE, 47.55 FEET FROM STATION IN TRUE AZIMUTH 115 DEG 48 MIN.  TO REACH FROM LAJAS, FOLLOW MAIN HIGHWAY LEADING TO BOQUERON FOR 6.75 KILOMETERS TO INTERSECTION WITH SECOND CLASS ROAD N AND S, KNOWN AS CUATRO CAMINOS, TURN S ON ROAD, AND FOLLOW TO INTERSECTION WITH E AND W ROAD NEAR FOOT OF MOUNTAIN, TURN W AND FOLLOW ROAD 0.8 KILOMETER TO GROUP OF SMALL HOUSES, PLACE KNOWN AS GUANABANA, TURN S THROUGH GATE (IF LOCKED, KEY CAN BE OBTAINED AT LECHERIA) AND FOLLOW DIM ROAD THROUGH PASTURE TO LECHERIA OWNED BY SUCCESSION DE ARROYO, FROM WHICH PLACE A TRAIL LEADS UP CANYON TO TOP OF DIVIDE AND THE STATION IS TO THE LEFT (E) ON HIGHEST PART.                            STATION RECOVERY (1952)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1952 (JOP) STATION MARK WAS RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED AND FOUND IN GOOD CONDITION.  THE ROUTE TO STATION IS ADEQUATE.  TWO NEW REFERENCE MARKS WERE ESTABLISHED.  BOTH ARE STANDARD USC AND GS DISKS CEMENTED IN BEDROCK.  NO. 1, STAMPED MARIQUITA 2 1934 NO 1, IS ON THE NORTH SLOPE OF THE PEAK AND ABOUT THE SAME ELEVATION AS THE STATION.  REFERENCE MARK 2, STAMPED MARIQUITA 2 1934 NO 2, IS ON THE NORTHWEST SLOPE OF THE PEAK AND ABOUT 1 FOOT LOWER THAN THE STATION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1966)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JWC) THE STATION MARK WAS FOUND AND IN GOOD CONDITION.  REFERENCE MARKS 1 AND 2 WERE NOT FOUND.  REFERENCE MARKS 3 AND 4 WERE ESTABLISHED AT THIS DATE.  A NEW DESCRIPTION FOLLOWS--  THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 7 MILES SOUTHEAST OF CABO ROJO, 8 MILES SOUTHWEST OF SAN GERMAN AND ON A HIGH PEAK THAT IS THE MOST PROMINENT IN THE VICINITY.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE JUNCTION OF HIGHWAYS 103 AND 102 IN CABO ROJO, GO SOUTH ON HIGHWAY 103 FOR 4.95 MILES TO THE JUNCTION WITH HIGHWAY 101.  CROSS HIGHWAY 101 AND CONTINUE SOUTH ON A DIRT ROAD FOR 1.55 MILES TO A CROSSROAD.  TURN LEFT AND GO EAST ON A DIRT ROAD FOR 0.9 MILE TO A METAL GATE ON THE RIGHT.  (PERMISSION TO ENTER ON THE PROPERTY WAS GIVEN BY MR. FRANZ PHILIPPI WHO LIVES 0.40 MILE SOUTH OF THIS POINT IN THE RANCH HOME).  PASS THROUGH THE GATE AND CONTINUE SOUTH ON A TRACK ROAD FOR 0.4 MILE TO THE RANCH HOME ON THE LEFT.  (A 4-WHEEL DRIVE VEHICLE IS REQUIRED TO REACH THE STATION FROM THIS POINT).  PASS TO THE RIGHT OF THE HOUSE AND CONTINUE SOUTH UP A DRAW FOR 0.3 MILE TO A SIDE ROAD ON THE LEFT.  TURN LEFT AND GO EAST AND SOUTH ON A MOUNTAIN ROAD FOR 0.45 MILE TO A GATE ON THE LEFT.  PASS THROUGH THE GATE AND GO EAST ON THE MOUNTAIN ROAD FOR 0.15 MILE TO A T-ROAD AT THE TOP OF THE RIDGE.  TURN LEFT AND GO NORTH ALONG THE TOP OF THE RIDGE FOR 0.2 MILE TO THE STATION ON THE LEFT.  THE STATION MARK IS A U.S. GEOLOGICAL SURVEY BENCH MARK DISK STAMPED MARIQUITA 2 1934, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A BOULDER THAT PROJECTS 3 INCHES.  IT IS 63 FEET NORTH OF A WIRE FENCE.  NOTE--DESC.  REFERENCE MARK 3 IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED MARIQUITA 2 USGS NO 3 1934 1966, BRAZED TO THE TOP OF A 3-INCH CAST IRON PIPE THAT PROJECTS 6 INCHES.  IT IS 55 FEET NORTH OF THE WIRE FENCE.  NOTE--DESC.  REFERENCE MARK 4 IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED MARIQUITA 2 USGS NO 4 1934 1966, BRAZED TO THE TOP OF A 3-INCH CAST IRON PIPE THAT PROJECTS 10 INCHES.  IT IS 43 FEET NORTH OF THE WIRE FENCE.  NOTE--DESC.  NO SUITABLE PLACE WAS FOUND FOR AN AZIMUTH.  AIRLINE DISTANCE AND DIRECTION FROM NEAREST TOWN 7 MILES SOUTHEAST OF CABO ROJO.
markers.setting: SET IN A BOULDER
markers.stability: MAY HOLD, BUT OF TYPE COMMONLY SUBJECT TOSURFACE MOTION

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JJL) THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 1-1/2 MILES SOUTHEAST OF CULEBRA, ON THE SOUTHEAST TIP OF FULLADOSA COVE, NEAR TWO ABANDONED CONCRETE BUILDINGS AND ABOUT 60 FEET NORTH OF AND 5 FEET LOWER THAN THE HIGHEST POINT IN THE IMMEDIATE VICINITY.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE POST OFFICE IN CULEBRA, GO EASTERLY FOR 0.05 MILE TO A CROSSROAD.  TURN RIGHT AND GO SOUTH FOR 0.05 MILE TO A BRIDGE ACROSS A SMALL CHANNEL.  CROSS THE BRIDGE, THENCE TURN LEFT AND GO EAST AND SOUTH ALONG THE SHORE-LINE ROAD FOR 1.7 MILES TO A WELL ON THE RIGHT.  THIS IS ABOUT 150 YARDS BEFORE REACHING THE TOP OF A RIDGE.  TURN LEFT AND GO EASTERLY ALONG THE SHORE FOR 0.3 MILE TO A FENCE AND THE END OF TRUCK TRAVEL.  PACK EASTERLY FOR ABOUT 100 YARDS TO THE STATION.  THE STATION MARK, STAMPED MARK 1966, IS A STANDARD DISK CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A BOULDER THAT PROJECTS 4 INCHES.  IT IS ABOUT 150 FEET SOUTH OF TWO ABANDONED CONCRETE BUILDINGS.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 1, STAMPED MARK NO 1 1966, IS A STANDARD DISK CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A BOULDER THAT PROJECTS 4 INCHES.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 2, STAMPED MARK NO 2 1966, IS A STANDARD DISK CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A BOULDER THAT PROJECTS 18 INCHES.                            STATION RECOVERY (1993)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE 1993 (BR) A THOROUGH SEARCH WAS MADE, BUT THE STATION WAS NOT FOUND.  REFERENCE MARK 1 WAS FOUND IN DENSE BRUSH, AND WAS IN GOOD CONDITION. CONCLUDED THAT THE STATION ITSELF HAS BEEN DESTROYED.
markers.setting: SET IN ROCK OUTCROP
markers.stability: MOST RELIABLE AND EXPECTED TO HOLDPOSITION/ELEVATION WELL

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1901 (JEM) STATION MAY MAKE A GOOD HYDROGRAPHIC MARK, OR ONE CAN BE BUILT ALONGSIDE OF IT.  THE CROSS IS ABOUT 5 FEET HIGH, AND AT SEA WILL APPEAR TO BE AT THE N END OF THE FIRST LONG RIDGE DESCENDING FROM ATALAYA.  THERE IS A CABIN WITHIN 125 FEET OF IT, WHICH SHOULD MAKE A BOLD MARK TOWARDS THE SEA.  TO SHELTER THE CROSS FROM RAIN AND POSSIBLY TO PROTECT THE PRIESTS WHEN OFFICIATING, A SIMPLE STRUCTURE, CONSISTING OF FOUR UPRIGHT POLES AND A ROOF OF BANANA LEAVES, HAS BEEN BUILT AROUND AND OVER IT.  THE LITTLE SHELTER IS ABOUT 5 FEET SQUARE, ABOUT 6 OR 7 FEET HIGH, AND THE SIDES ARE ALL OPEN.

BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1941 ELEVATION 22.37 METERS PBM.  ON THE NORTH OF VIEQUES ISLAND ON POINT MARTINEAU WHICH IS ABOUT 2-1/2 KMS. WEST OF ISABEL II AND 1 KM. NE OF MARTINEAU HILL.  THE STATION IS ABOUT 50 METERS SOUTH OF AND 20 METERS ABOVE THE BEACH, 75 METERS EAST OF THE MOUTH OF A STREAM AND 350 METERS NORTH OF THE HIGHWAY AT K3 H1.  STATION MARK IS A STANDARD TABLET STAMPED MARTINEAU AND SET IN A ROCK ABOUT 2 FT. ABOVE THE GROUND.  R.M. NO. 1 IS A DRILL HOLE IN A ROCK ABOUT 3 FT. HIGH.  THIS IS THE HIGHEST ROCK ON THE HILL.  DISTANCE FROM STATION 4.76 METERS.  PLANE AZIMUTH 258-13-23.  R.M. NO. 2 IS A DRILL HOLE IN A ROCK ABOUT 2 FT. HIGH ON THE WEST SLOPE OF THE HILL.  DISTANCE FROM STATION 5.09 METERS.  PLANE AZIMUTH 55-4-11.                            STATION RECOVERY (1964)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1964 (GWM) STATION DESTROYED.  ARMY CORP. OF ENGINEERS MARK STAMPED MARTINEAU 2 FOUND IN IMMEDIATE AREA.  R.M.S TO MARTINEAU FOUND AS DESCRIBED.                            STATION RECOVERY (1965)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US MARINE CORPS 1965 REPLACED BY STANDARD C AND GS DISK IN 1963.  SET IN CONCRETE 1 BY 1-1/2 FEET.  RENAMED MARTINEAU 2.  STATION IS ON HIGHEST POINT OF LAND TOWARDS BEACH OPPOSITE HIGHWAY MARKER K-3 H-1.                            STATION RECOVERY (2004)  RECOVERY NOTE BY INDIVIDUAL CONTRIBUTORS 2004 (MA) THE LOCATION WAS FOUND BY DESCRIPTION.  HOWEVER, CONSTRUCTION OF THE CONDOMINIUMS OF THE MARTINEAU BAY RESORT HAVE DESTROYED THE MARKER.
markers.setting: SET IN ROCK OUTCROP
markers.stability: MOST RELIABLE AND EXPECTED TO HOLDPOSITION/ELEVATION WELL

markers.description: BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1940 LOCATED ON A BRUSHY HILL ABOUT 8 KM. S OF CAMUY AND 0.3 KM. SE OF ERNESTO MEMORIAL CHURCH.  LAND IS OWNED BY ANTONIO MARTINEZ.  TO REACH FROM CAMUY TAKE HY. 2 W TO KM. POST 102.0.  TURN LEFT (S) ONTO ROAD TO SAN SEBASTIAN.  DRIVE TO KM. POST 0.7 AND TURN LEFT ONTO DIRT ROAD.  DRIVE 2.9 MILES S TO ERNESTO MEMORIAL CHURCH.  TURN LEFT (E) AND DRIVE 0.1 MILE TO ROAD S THROUGH CAIN.  LEAVE CAR AND WALK S TOWARD THE N END OF RIDGE ON WHICH STATION IS LOCATED.  FOLLOW TRAIL UP E BRANCH OF HOLLOW AND SHORTLY BEFORE REACHING SADDLE TAKE TRAIL SW UP SIDE OF RIDGE TO TOP AND STATION.  STATION MARK--STANDARD TABLET SET IN ROCK OUTCROP AND STAMPED MARTINEZ.  R.M. NO. 1 20D NAIL CEMENTED IN ROCK OUTCROP 3.2 FT. S05E.  R.M. NO. 2 20D NAIL CEMENTED IN ROCK OUTCROP 3.1 FT. S80W.
markers.setting: SET IN ROCK OUTCROP
markers.stability: MOST RELIABLE AND EXPECTED TO HOLDPOSITION/ELEVATION WELL

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1967 (SCM) THE STATION IS LOCATED APPROXIMATELY 10 MILES SOUTHWEST OF ISABEL SEGUNDA AND ABOUT 2 MILES SOUTHEAST OF POINT ARENAS ON THE NORTH COAST OF VIEQUES ISLAND.  THE STATION WAS ESTABLISHED FOR THE LOCATION OF HI-FIX ANTENNA CONTROLLING HYDROGRAPHY NORTH OF VIEQUES ISLAND.  NO REFERENCE MARKS WERE SET.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE POLICE STATION AT THE PLAZA IN THE CENTER OF ISABEL SEGUNDA, PROCEED SOUTH FOR ONE BLOCK AND TURN LEFT AND GO EAST FOR ONE BLOCK, TURN RIGHT AND GO SOUTH FOR 0.25 MILE TO A SIDE ROAD LEFT.  CONTINUE STRAIGHT AHEAD FOR 0.10 MILE TO A FORK.  TAKE RIGHT FORK AND CONTINUE WESTERLY ON THE MAIN ROAD BETWEEN ISABEL SEGUNDA AND PT. ARENAS FOR 0.50 MILE TO A SIDE ROAD RIGHT.  CONTINUE STRAIGHT AHEAD 0.20 MILE TO A SIDE ROAD LEFT.  CONTINUE WESTERLY ON MAIN ROAD FOR 0.50 MILE TO CROSSROADS.  CONTINUE STRAIGHT AHEAD FOR 0.8 MILE TO THE JOB CORPS CENTER ON LEFT AND CONTINUE STRAIGHT AHEAD FOR 1.35 MILE TO THE EAST END OF THE RUNWAY OF THE NEW VIEQUES AIRPORT ON THE RIGHT.  CONTINUE STRAIGHT AHEAD FOR 0.50 MILE TO A FARM ROAD LEFT.  CONTINUE STRAIGHT AHEAD FOR 0.75 MILE TO MILEPOST K7H3 AND FARM ROAD LEFT AND A CORRAL ON LEFT.  CONTINUE WESTERLY FOR 0.30 MILE TO THE MAIN GATE OF U.S. NAVAL AMMUNITION FACILITY.  PASS THROUGH GATE AND CONTINUE WESTERLY FOR 0.50 MILE TO A SIDE ROAD RIGHT.  CONTINUE STRAIGHT AHEAD FOR 0.60 MILE AND SIDE ROAD LEFT.  CONTINUE WESTERLY FOR 0.10 MILE TO SIDE ROAD LEFT.  CONTINUE STRAIGHT AHEAD FOR 0.25 MILE AND SIDE ROAD LEFT LEADING TO THE U.S. NAVAL AMMUNITION FACILITY MOTOR POOL.  CONTINUE STRAIGHT AHEAD FOR 1.15 MILES TO A CROSSROADS.  CONTINUE STRAIGHT AHEAD FOR 0.10 MILE TO CATTLE TRAP AND FORK IN ROAD.  TAKE RIGHT FORK AND CONTINUE WESTERLY FOR 0.10 MILE TO A SIDE ROAD LEFT.  CONTINUE STRAIGHT AHEAD FOR 0.20 MILE TO PASTURE ON LEFT AND STATION ON LEFT.  THE STATION MARK, STANDARD DISK SET IN CONCRETE, STAMPED MAS 1967, IS 81 FEET SOUTH OF THE CENTERLINE OF THE ROAD, AND 125 FEET SOUTHWEST OF A 2 FOOT TREE, THE LARGEST OF TWO LARGE TREES ON THE SOUTH SIDE OF THE ROAD.  THE STATION IS SET FLUSH WITH THE GROUND.
markers.setting: SET IN TOP OF CONCRETE MONUMENT
markers.stability: MAY HOLD, BUT OF TYPE COMMONLY SUBJECT TOSURFACE MOTION

markers.description: BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1922 THIS STATION IS ABOUT 8 KILOMETERS BY ROAD NE FROM AGUADILLA, 2.25 KILOMETERS N OF THE CARRETERA, AND 1-3/4 KILOMETERS S OF THE RAILROAD, ON THE N POINT OF A CLEARED RIDGE OVERLOOKING THE FLAT COUNTRY TOWARD THE COAST, ON THE LAND OWNED BY ALTURO CHABARIA.  THE RIDGE ON WHICH THE STATION IS LOCATED IS CURVED, THE POINTS PROJECTING TO THE N.  THE STATION IS ON THE HIGHEST PART OF THE E POINT, WHICH HAS A THIN GROWTH OF TIMBER, THE MOST NOTICEABLE AMONG WHICH IS A NUMBER OF MASSIGO TREES (ALSO CALLED ALMARSIGO), AN ESPECIALLY LARGE ONE BEING ON THE NE SLOPE OF THE RIDGE.  THE W AND HIGHER POINT HAS A LINE OF LARGE BRUSH ALONG THE TOP WITH SEVERAL MAIMON TREES ON THE N SLOPE.  IN THE SADDLE BETWEEN THE TWO POINTS IS A PROMINENT LONE COCOANUT PALM.  THE STATION IS MARKED BY A STANDARD U.S.G.S. BRONZE BENCH MARK TABLET CEMENTED IN A LARGE RECTANGULAR LIMESTONE ROCK BURIED IN THE GROUND AND PROJECTING SLIGHTLY ABOVE THE SURFACE.  REFERENCE MARK NO.1, IS A DRILL HOLE IN OUTCROPPING LIMESTONE ON THE W SLOPE OF THE RIDGE, 7.23 METERS DISTANT ON A TRUE AZIMUTH OF 111 DEG 01 MIN 20 SEC.  REFERENCE MARK NO.2, IS A SPIKE IN A BLAZE IN A 30 CENTIMETER MASSIGO TREE ON TOP OF THE RIDGE, ON THE S SIDE OF THE TREE, 1.4 METERS ABOVE THE GROUND, 6.46 METERS DISTANT ON A TRUE AZIMUTH OF 177 DEG 55 MIN 05 SEC.  ELEVATION ABOVE SEA LEVEL IS - 129.1 METERS.  TO REACH THE STATION, TURN OFF THE CARRETERA ON A SECOND CLASS ROAD S AT A SMALL STORE ABOUT 6 KILOMETERS NE OF AGUADILLA, FOLLOW THIS IN A NORTHERLY DIRECTION TO A ROAD FORKS AT A SMALL SETTLEMENT (STORES AND SCHOOLHOUSE), TURN E AND FOLLOW THIS ROAD ABOUT 1 KILOMETER TO A FRAME HOUSE ON THE N SIDE OF THE ROAD. THE STATION IS ON THE RIDGE TO THE N ABOUT 300 METERS FROM THE HOUSE.
markers.setting: SET IN ROCK OUTCROP
markers.stability: MOST RELIABLE AND EXPECTED TO HOLDPOSITION/ELEVATION WELL

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JWC) THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 4-1/2 MILES NORTHEAST OF AGUADILLA, 1-3/4 MILES NORTH OF HIGHWAY 2, JUST OUTSIDE OF THE SOUTHEAST BOUNDARY OF RAMEY AIR FORCE BASE AND ON THE PROPERTY OF THE PUERTO RICAN GOVERNMENT.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE JUNCTION OF HIGHWAYS 2 AND 107 WHICH IS ABOUT 2 MILES NORTHEAST OF AGUADILLA, GO EASTERLY ON HIGHWAY 2 FOR 0.2 MILE TO THE JUNCTION WITH HIGHWAY 459.  TURN LEFT AND GO NORTHEAST ON HIGHWAY 459 FOR 2.85 MILES TO A LOCKED GATE ON THE RIGHT.  (PERMISSION TO ENTER AND AN ESCORT WAS OBTAINED FROM CAPT. JOHNSON WHO IS THE A.F.K. SUPPLY OFFICER AT RAMEY AIR FORCE BASE.) PASS THROUGH THE GATE AND GO SOUTHEASTERLY ON A PAVED ROAD FOR 0.55 MILE TO A SIDE ROAD ON THE LEFT.  TURN LEFT AND GO EAST AND NORTH ON A PAVED ROAD FOR 0.7 MILE TO A LOCKED GATE ON THE RIGHT.  PASS THROUGH THE GATE AND GO EAST ON A TRACK ROAD FOR 0.15 MILE TO A FENCE CORNER. (A 4-WHEEL DRIVE VEHICLE IS REQUIRED TO REACH THE STATION FROM THIS POINT).  TURN RIGHT AND FOLLOW THE FENCE SOUTH FOR 0.15 MILE TO A FENCE CORNER.  TURN RIGHT AND GO WEST AND SOUTHWEST ALONG A FENCE FOR 0.1 MILE TO THE STATION ON THE LEFT.  THE STATION MARK IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED MASSIGO 3 1966, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN BEDROCK THAT IS 1 INCH BELOW THE SURFACE OF THE GROUND.  IT IS 58 FEET EAST OF A WIRE FENCE.  REFERENCE MARK 1 IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED MASSIGO 3 NO 1 1966, CEMENTED IN THE TOP OF A 3-INCH CAST IRON PIPE THAT IS SURROUNDED BY CEMENT AND PROJECTS 4 INCHES.  IT IS 1 FOOT LOWER THAN THE STATION MARK.  REFERENCE MARK 2 IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED MASSIGO 3 NO 2 1966, CEMENTED IN THE TOP OF A 3-INCH CAST IRON PIPE THAT IS SURROUNDED BY CEMENT AND PROJECTS 4 INCHES.  IT IS THE SAME ELEVATION AS THE STATION MARK AND IS 32 FEET EAST OF THE WIRE FENCE.  AN AZIMUTH MARK WAS NOT ESTABLISHED AT THIS DATE.
markers.setting: SET IN ROCK OUTCROP

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1900 (JN) THE STATION IS ON THE TOP OF THE HILL FROM WHICH ARE SIGNALLED THE ARRIVALS OF INBOUND VESSELS TO THE MERCHANTS OF MAYAGUEZ.  A SMALL RED HOUSE STANDS ON THE HILL (FOR THE USE OF THE LOOKOUT AND HIS FAMILY) AND A MAST IN FRONT OF THE DOOR SHOWS THE FLAGS WHEN REQUIRED.  IT WAS EXPECTED THAT WE COULD USE THIS MAST FOR OUR STATION MARK, BUT IT IS NOT SUFFICIENTLY SYMMETRICAL, AND BESIDES BEING IN TWO PARTS, BOTH OF THE SECTIONS ARE INCLINED.  THE STATION POINT WAS SELECTED W AND S OF THE MAST SO AS TO PERMIT OF SEEING AS MANY OF OUR STATIONS AND TOPOGRAPHICAL SIGNALS AS POSSIBLE.  DISTANCES WERE MEASURED AS FOLLOWS--  SW CORNER OF MAST (AT BASE) TO CENTER OF STATION 2.441 METERS.  NW CORNER OF MAST (AT BASE) TO CENTER OF STATION 2.513 METERS.  SW CORNER OF ROUND STUB SUPPORTING SW CORNER OF PORCH TO CENTER OF STATION 4.287 METERS.  NW CORNER OF ROUND STUB SUPPORTING SE CORNER OF PORCH TO CENTER OF STATION 7.619 METERS.  NAILS WERE DRIVEN IN THE TWO STUBS JUST REFERRED TO, TO MAKE POINTS MEASURED TO.  DISTANCE FROM STATION CENTER TO TACK IN W STUB 3.594 METERS.  USED FOR HOLDING WESTERN WIRE GUYS, ONE GOING TO S END OF YARD-ARM AND ONE GOING TO TOP OF MAST.  THE SIGNAL AT THIS POINT WAS A BRACED POLE, THE STATION MARK WAS A PIECE OF IRON PIPE ABOUT 1-1/2 INCHES IN DIAMETER AND ABOUT 20 INCHES LONG.  THE PIPE WAS EMBEDDED IN CEMENT AND THE SAME MATERIAL WAS USED TO FILL UP THE INTERIOR OF THE PIPE.  ABOUT 1 INCH OF THE PIPE WAS LEFT EXPOSED.  THE HEAD OF A 10-PENNY NAIL SET IN THE CEMENT INSIDE THE PIPE MARKS THE STATION.  IN 1901, STATION MARK WAS FOUND UNDISTURBED.                            STATION RECOVERY (1910)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1910 (NHH) STATION RECOVERED.  THE MAST MENTIONED IS NO LONGER IN EXISTENCE, BUT THE STATION MARK IS IN GOOD CONDITION.
markers.setting: SET INTO TOP OF METAL PIPE DRIVEN INTO GROUND
markers.stability: MARK OF QUESTIONABLE OR UNKNOWN STABILITY

markers.description: BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1934 STATION IS LOCATED 8.8 KILOMETERS BY ROAD AND TRAIL N OF OROCOVIS, ABOUT 1 KILOMETER E OF THE CARRETERA BETWEEN OROCOVIS AND COROZAL, IN BARRIO MATACANAS, OR MATA DE CANAS, ON A PROMINENT BARE PEAK FARTHEST TO THE N IN THE RANGE OF PEAKS WHICH LIE TO THE N OF THE LOW SADDLE WHERE IS LOCATED CLAUDIO S. FIELD SCHOOL AND SETTLEMENT KNOWN AS SEGUNDO UNIDAD.  THE STATION IS 0.5 KILOMETER NE OF RESIDENCE OF JUAN MARIA TORRES.  IT IS ON HIGHEST PART OF THE SUMMIT WHICH IS VERY NARROW AND ABOUT 30 METERS IN LENGTH E AND W.  STATION MARK IS A STANDARD U.S.G.S. TABLET, STAMPED MATACANAS 1934, CEMENTED IN LARGE BOULDER SET IN THE GROUND.  REFERENCE MARKS ARE SHALLOW 1-INCH DRILL HOLES IN PROJECTING BOULDERS.  REFERENCE MARK NO.1 IS ON W SLOPE, 45.59 FEET FROM STATION IN TRUE AZIMUTH 134 DEG 11 MIN.  REFERENCE MARK NO.2 IS ON E SLOPE, 53.30 FEET FROM STATION IN TRUE AZIMUTH 298 DEG 18 MIN.  SIGNAL--A QUADRIPOD OF SAWED TIMBER WITH BLACK CROSS TARGETS ON CENTER POLE.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM OROCOVIS FOLLOW CARRATERA LEADING TO COROZAL FOR 7.8 KILOMETERS TO POST K 41 H 5, TURN RIGHT UP GRADE ON SECOND CLASS ROAD WHICH PASSES BY SCHOOLHOUSE, AND RESIDENCE OF JUAN MARIA TORRES.  CAR CAN BE TAKEN TO LATTER PLACE, FROM WHERE THE PEAK CAN BE SEEN, AND IS REACHED BY LOCAL TRAIL.                            STATION RECOVERY (1966)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JJL) THE STATION MARK WAS FOUND AND IN GOOD CONDITION.  REFERENCE MARK 1 AND 2 WERE NOT FOUND.  REFERENCE MARKS 3 AND 4 WERE ESTABLISHED AT THIS DATE.  AN AZIMUTH MARK WAS ESTABLISHED AT THIS DATE.  A NEW DESCRIPTION FOLLOWS--  THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 7 MILES SOUTH-SOUTHWEST OF COROZAL, 4 MILES NORTHEAST OF OROCOVIS AND ON A GRASS COVERED HILL WHICH IS THE HIGHEST ONE IN THE VICINITY.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE POST OFFICE IN OROCOVIS, GO WEST FOR 1 BLOCK.  TURN RIGHT AND GO NORTH FOR 0.1 MILE TO THE JUNCTION OF HIGHWAYS 155 AND 568.  TURN RIGHT AND GO NORTHEAST ON HIGHWAY 568 FOR 2.75 MILES TO THE JUNCTION WITH HIGHWAY 772.  CONTINUE NORTHEAST ON HIGHWAY 568 FOR 1.4 MILES TO A SIDE ROAD RIGHT. TURN RIGHT AND GO EAST ON A DIRT ROAD FOR 0.1 MILE TO A FORK. TAKE THE RIGHT FORK AND CONTINUE EAST FOR 0.15 MILE TO THE AZIMUTH MARK ON THE RIGHT.  CONTINUE EAST AND NORTHEAST ON THE DIRT ROAD FOR 0.2 MILE TO THE END OF TRUCK TRAVEL AT THE BASE OF A HILL.  PACK NORTHWEST TO THE TOP OF THE HILL AND THE STATION ON THE HIGHEST POINT.  NOTE--A 5 MINUTE PACK.  THE STATION MARK IS A U.S. GEOLOGICAL SURVEY BENCH MARK DISK STAMPED MATACANAS 1934, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A BOULDER THAT PROJECTS 1 FOOT.  NOTE--DESC.  REFERENCE MARK 3 IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED MATACANAS NO 3 1934, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A BOULDER THAT PROJECTS 6 INCHES AND IS 1 FOOT HIGHER IN ELEVATION THAN THE STATION MARK.  NOTE--12C  REFERENCE MARK 4 IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED MATACANAS NO 4 1934, BRAZED TO THE TOP OF A 3-INCH CAST IRON PIPE THAT PROJECTS 8 INCHES.  IT IS 1 FOOT LOWER IN ELEVATION THAN THE STATION MARK.  NOTE--DESC.  THE AZIMUTH MARK IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED MATACANAS 1934, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A LARGE BOULDER THAT PROJECTS 2 FEET.  IT IS 40 FEET SOUTH OF A CONCRETE WATER TROUGH AND 56 FEET SOUTH OF THE CENTER OF A DIRT ROAD.  NOTE--17C.  AIRLINE DISTANCE AND DIRECTION FROM NEAREST TOWN 4 MILES NORTHEAST OF OROCOVIS.                            STATION RECOVERY (2015)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 2015 MARK NOT FOUND.
markers.setting: SET IN A BOULDER
markers.stability: MAY HOLD, BUT OF TYPE COMMONLY SUBJECT TOSURFACE MOTION

markers.description: BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1941 V.A. ELEVATION 138.39 METERS.  STATION IS ON THE SOUTHERN END OF A LONG TIMBERED RIDGE ABOUT 5 KMS. FROM THE EAST END OF VIEQUES ISLAND AND ABOUT 300 METERS FROM THE WEST END OF SALINAL DEL DUR BAY.  THIS MOUNTAIN IS THE MOST CONSPICUOUS IN THE EASTERN PART OF THE ISLAND AND ALTHOUGH SHOWN IN SOME MAPS AS MT. SALOBRE IS LOCALLY KNOWN AS MATIAS.  TO REACH FROM ISABEL II DRIVE EAST ALONG NORTH COAST ROAD TO SALINAS FARM NEAR CANO HONDO BAY.  FOLLOW TRAIL SOUTH ALONG RIDGE ABOUT 1-1/2 KM. PASSING NEAR A SMALL CLEARED FIELD IN A VALLEY WHICH IS ON THE WEST SIDE OF THE MAIN RIDGE AND HAS ITS OUTLET TO THE NORTH.  FOLLOW TRAIL WEST AROUND THE HEAD OF THIS VALLEY TO THE HIGHEST POINT ON THE MOUNTAIN.  THE STATION IS A LITTLE NORTH OF AND ABOUT 2 METERS LOWER THAN THE HIGHEST POINT. THERE ARE SEVERAL BIG ROCKS ABOUT 40 METERS SOUTH OF THE STATION.  STATION MARK IS A STANDARD TABLET STAMPED MATIAS 1941 AND CEMENTED IN A ROCK WHICH WAS SET IN PLACE.  R.M. NO. 1 IS A DRILL HOLE IN A BIG ROCK 4.14 METERS FROM STATION.  PLANE AZIMUTH 178-02.  R.M. NO. 2 IS A DRILL HOLE IN ROCK LEDGE 3.83 METERS FROM STATION.  PLANE AZIMUTH 306-51.                            STATION RECOVERY (1965)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1965 (MTP) STATION WAS RECOVERED ALONG WITH R.M. 1, R.M. 2 WAS SEARCHED FOR BUT NOT FOUND.  THE FOLLOWING ADDITION OR CHANGES TO ORIGINAL DESCRIPTION WILL MAKE IT EASIER TO RECOVER.  THE STATION IS LOCATED ON CERRO MATIAS IN THE IMPACT AREA OF CAMP CARCIA.  TO REACH FROM DIVISION CAMP, DRIVE 4 WHEEL DRIVE VEHICLE ALONG SOUTH COAST ROAD PAST CERRO MATIAS AROUND EAST SIDE TO ROAD UP NORTH SIDE.  THE ROAD IS STEEP, BUT ACCESS TO TOP IS POSSIBLE IN VEHICLE.  STATION IS ABOUT 150 FEET NORTH OF SMALL OBSERVATION HOUSE ON SUMMIT.                            STATION RECOVERY (1966)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JPR) THE STATION WAS RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION AS DESCRIBED.

IT IS 157.9 FT (48.1 M) EAST-SOUTHEAST OF THE SIXTH RUNWAY LIGHT WEST OF RUNWAY END 27, 134.8 FT (41.1 M) SOUTHEAST OF THE CENTERLINE OF THE RUNWAY, AND 93.2 FT (28.4 M) SOUTH-SOUTHWEST OF THE FIFTH RUNWAY LIGHT WEST OF RUNWAY END 27. STATION RECOVERY (1996)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1996 (AJL) THE STATION IS LOCATED NEAR THE WEST COAST OF PUERTO RICO, ABOUT 5.0 MI (8.0 KM) NORTH OF MAYAGUEZ, AT THE EUGENIO MARIA DE HOSTOS AIRPORT, SOUTH OF THE RUNWAY IN THE GRASS AND ABOUT 0.05 MI (0.08 KM) WEST OF THE PAPI LIGHTS FOR RUNWAY 27.  OWNERSHIP--EUGENIO MARIA DE HOSTAS AIRPORT, BOX 710, MAYAGUEZ, PUERTO RICO 00709.  AIRPORT MANAGER IS BARBARINO FUENTES, PHONE (809) 833-0148.  PERMISSION IS REQUIRED TO ENTER THE AIRPORT COMPOUND. THIS IS A SECONDARY AIRPORT CONTROL STATION.

POINT INTERSECTED IS THE RED OBSTRUCTION LIGHT ATOP AND CENTER OF THE TOWER.

BY NATIONAL OCEAN SERVICE 1989 THE STATION IS LOCATED ON EUGENIO MARIA DE HOSTAS AIRPORT APPROXIMATELY MID FIELD. TO OBTAIN ACCESS TO THE AIRPORT AND THE STATION CONTACT MR. ANDREW BONILLA, DIRECTOR AIRPORT OPERATIONS (ACTING AIRPORT MANAGER), BOX 710, MAYAGUEZ, PUERTO RICO 00709. PHONE 809-832-3390. THE STATION IS LOCATED NEAR MIDFIELD BETWEEN RUNWAY 9-27 AND THE TERMINAL RAMP TAXIWAY NORTHEAST OF THE TERMINAL BUILDING.  THE STATION IS 110.5 FT (33.7 M) SOUTH OF THE SOUTH EDGE OF RUNWAY 9-27, 175.6 FT (53.5 M) EAST OF THE EASTERLY OF TWO ADJACENT CONNECTING TAXIWAYS AT THE TERMINAL AND 114.4 FT (34.9 M) NORTH OF THE RAMP TAXIWAY. THE STATION IS AN NOS DISK CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN THE NORTHWEST CORNER OF A STORM DRAIN.                            STATION RECOVERY (1993)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1993 THE STATION IS LOCATED AT CENTERFIELD IN THE GRASS ISLAND BETWEEN 2 N/S TAXIWAYS, NORTH OF THE RAMP AND SOUTH OF THE RUNWAY.  IT IS IN THE NW CORNER OF THE CONCRETE BASE OF THE WEST DRAIN WITHIN THE GRASS AREA.  THE STATION IS A NOS DISK STAMPED MAZ C 1989 CEMENTED INTO A DRILL HOLE IN THE NW CORNER OF THE DRAIN.                            STATION RECOVERY (1995)  RECOVERY NOTE BY ANDREGG INCORPORATED 1995 (CDR) RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED.                            STATION RECOVERY (1996)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1996 (AJL) THE STATION IS LOCATED NEAR THE WEST COAST OF PUERTO RICO, ABOUT 5.0 MI (8.0 KM) NORTH OF MAYAGUEZ, AT THE EUGENIO MARIA DE HOSTOS AIRPORT, SOUTH OF THE RUNWAY AT MIDFIELD, IN A GRASS AREA FORMED BY THE RUNWAY, TWO CONNECTOR TAXIWAYS AND THE APRON AND NORTH OF THE NEW TERMINAL BUILDING.  OWNERSHIP--EUGENIO MARIA DE HOSTAS AIRPORT, BOX 710, MAYAGUEZ, PUERTO RICO 00709.  AIRPORT MANAGER IS BARBARINO FUENTES, PHONE (809) 833-0148.  PERMISSION IS REQUIRED TO ENTER THE AIRPORT COMPOUND.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM A GATE ON THE WEST SIDE OF THE NEW TERMINAL BUILDING GO NORTH-NORTHWEST ACROSS THE APRON FOR 0.05 MI (0.08 KM) TO A GRASS AREA AND THE STATION.  THE STATION IS A NOS DISK SET INTO THE NORTHWEST CORNER OF A 4 FT (1.2 M) BY 4 FT (1.2 M) STORM SEWER DRAIN, 175.6 FT (53.5 M) EAST OF A CONECTOR TAXIWAY, 114.4 FT (34.9 M) NORTH OF THE APRON AND 110.5 FT (33.7 M) SOUTH OF THE SOUTH EDGE OF RUNWAY 09/27.  THIS IS THE PRIMARAY AIRPORT CONTROL STATION. STATION RECOVERY (2008)  RECOVERY NOTE BY RLDA SURVEYING AND MAPPING 2008 (RLD) RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION WITH THE FOLLOWING MEASUREMENTS.   THE STATION IS LOCATED IN THE NORTHWEST CORNER OF CONCRETE CATCH BASIN THAT IS APPROXIMATELY 6 FT (1.8 M) BY 6 FT (1.8 M) AND IS 46.91 M (153.9 FT) SOUTHEAST OF A RUNWAY TAXIWAY LIGHT, 40.27 M (132.1 FT) SOUTHEAST OF A RUNWAY SIGN, 35.98 M (118.0 FT) NORTH NORTHWEST OF A TAXIWAY LIGHT (CONNECTOR C TAXI), 31.98 M (104.9 FT) SOUTHWEST OF A RUNWAY LIGHT, 29.84 M (97.9 FT) NORTHEAST OF A MANHOLE AND 29.74 M (97.6 FT) NORTHWEST OF A RUNWAY SIGN.

OWNERSHIP--EUGENIO MARIA DE HOSTAS AIRPORT, BOX 710, MAYAGUEZ, PUERTO RICO 00709.  AIRPORT MANAGER IS BARBARINO FUENTES, PHONE (809) 833-0148.  PERMISSION IS REQUIRED TO ENTER THE AIRPORT COMPOUND.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM A GATE ON THE WEST SIDE OF THE NEW TERMINAL BUILDING GO NORTH ACROSS THE APRON FOR 0.05 MI (0.08 KM) TO A PARALLEL TAXIWAY, TURN LEFT AND GO WEST ON THE PARALLEL TAXIWAY FOR 0.4 MI (0.6 KM) TO THE STATION ON THE RIGHT.  THE STATION IS A NGS DISK SET INTO THE SOUTHWEST CORNER OF A 4 FT (1.2 M) BY 4 FT (1.2 M) STORM SEWER DRAIN, 146.2 FT (44.6 M) SOUTH OF THE RUNWAY CENTER AND 145.2 FT (44.3 M) NORTH OF THE PARALLEL TAXIWAY CENTER. markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1941 (RLS) STATION IS ABOUT 1 MILE S OF COLONIA ORIENTE, ABOUT 1/2 MILE NW OF THE MOUTH OF THE DAGUAO RIVER, WITHIN THE PROPOSED LIMITS OF THE ROOSEVELT ROADS NAVAL RESERVATION, ON TOP OF THE FIRST HILL W OF THE DAGUAO RIVER.  THE HILL IS UNCULTIVATED AND WITH A FEW SCATTERED TREES.  THE STATION IS ABOUT 8 METERS NNW OF A PILE OF SMALL BOULDERS ON THE HIGHEST POINT OF THE HILL, 57-1/2 METERS E OF A FENCE, AND 7 METERS S OF THE S SIDE OF A TREE-LINED LANE (UNUSED) LEADING TO THE TOP OF THE HILL.  THE MARK PROJECTS 8 INCHES ABOVE GROUND.  THE ELEVATION OF THE STATION IS ABOUT 62.4 METERS.  STATION MARK IS A STANDARD DISK SET IN CONCRETE, AS DESCRIBED IN NOTE 1A.  THERE IS NO UNDERGROUND MARK.  REFERENCE MARKS ARE STANDARD DISKS SET IN CONCRETE IN DEPRESSIONS IN BOULDERS.  REFERENCE MARK NO.1 IS S OF THE STATION, ON THE S SLOPE OF THE HILL, AND 0.26 METER LOWER THAN THE STATION.  THE MARK IS ON THE HIGHEST PART OF A BOULDER WHICH PROJECTS 15 INCHES ABOVE GROUND.  REFERENCE MARK NO.2 IS WNW OF THE STATION, ON THE S SIDE OF THE TREES ALONG THE S SIDE OF THE ABOVE MENTIONED LANE, AND 0.98 METER LOWER THAN THE STATION.  THE MARK IS ON A BOULDER WHICH PROJECTS 12 INCHES ABOVE GROUND.  THE WITNESS MARK IS A TRIANGULAR BLAZE WITH A NAIL AT EACH CORNER AND AT THE CENTER, 2 METERS NE OF THE PILE OF BOULDERS ON THE HIGHEST POINT OF THE HILL.  THE BLAZE IS ON THE NW SIDE OF A SMALL TAMARENDO TREE, 1 FOOT ABOVE GROUND.                            STATION RECOVERY (1966)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JJL) THE STATION WAS SEARCHED FOR BUT NOT FOUND.  A NEW STATION MC CONNIE 2 WAS ESTABLISHED.
markers.setting: SET IN TOP OF CONCRETE MONUMENT

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JJL) THE STATION IS LOCATED 5 AIRLINE MILES EAST-NORTHEAST OF NAGUABO, 7 AIRLINE MILES SOUTH OF FAJARDO AND 1/2 MILE EAST OF THE SECURITY BUILDING.  IT IS LOCATED ON THE SOUTHEAST WING OF BUILDING NUMBER 598 WHICH IS ROOSEVELT ROADS NAVAL BASE HOSPITAL.  THE STATION MARK IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED MC CONNIE 2 1965, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN THE HOSPITAL ROOF.  IT IS 4 FEET SOUTHWEST OF THE NORTHEAST EDGE OF THE ROOF.  REFERENCE MARK 1 IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED MC CONNIE 2 NO 1 1965, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN SOUTHWEST EDGE OF THE HOSPITAL ROOF.  REFERENCE MARK 2 IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED MC CONNIE 2 NO 2 1965, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN THE SOUTHEAST CORNER OF THE HOSPITAL ROOF.  NO AZIMUTH MARK WAS ESTABLISHED AT THIS STATION.

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1941 (RLS) STATION IS ABOUT 2-3/4 MILES E OF CEIBA, ON THE ROOSEVELT ROADS NAVAL RESERVATION, ON POINT MEDIO MUNDO, ON TOP OF THE HIGHEST HILL ON THE POINT, 44 METERS WNW OF A LARGE BOULDER AT THE E END OF THE TOP OF THE HILL, 13 METERS SW OF THE LARGEST BOULDER IN A GROUP OF BOULDERS AT THE N EDGE OF THE TOP OF THE HILL, AND PROJECTS ABOUT 5 INCHES ABOVE GROUND.  THE ELEVATION OF THE STATION IS ABOUT 132 FEET.  STATION AND REFERENCE MARK NO.1 ARE STANDARD BRONZE DISKS SET IN CONCRETE, AS DESCRIBED IN NOTES 1A AND 11A.  THERE IS NO UNDERGROUND MARK.  REFERENCE MARK NO.1 IS ON THE SW SLOPE OF THE HILL, 10 METERS E OF THE LARGEST OF A GROUP OF 3 ALMACIGO TREES WITH A SQUARE BLAZE ON THE SE SIDE 4 FEET ABOVE THE GROUND, 1.85 METERS LOWER THAN THE STATION, AND PROJECTS ABOUT 6 INCHES ABOVE GROUND.  REFERENCE MARK NO.2 IS A STANDARD BRONZE DISK SET IN TOP OF A BOULDER ABOUT 5 FEET IN DIAMETER AND PROJECTING 5 FEET ABOVE GROUND.  IT IS ON THE N SLOPE OF THE HILL, ON THE E SIDE OF A GROUP OF SMALL JAGUEY TREES ON THE STEEP SLOPE OF THE HILL.  IT IS 27.4 METERS N OF REFERENCE MARK NO.1, AND 0.92 METER LOWER THAN THE STATION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1958)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1958 (RWS) STATION AND REFERENCE MARKS RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED EXCEPT THAT THERE IS NOW A RIFLE RANGE DUE WEST OF THE STATION AND 50 YARDS AWAY.  THE ROAD TO THE STATION IS BLOCKED BY A CHAIN AND LOCK.  KEY TO LOCK CAN BE OBTAINED AT THE ARMORY AT ROOSEVELT ROADS NAVAL STATION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1961)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1961 (MLO) STATION RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED.  IT IS 4.5 METERS SW FROM THE CENTER OF A 7-FOOT SQUARE BUILDING CONSTRUCTED OF CINDERBLOCKS WHICH WAS IN RUINS.  R. M. NO. 1 WAS SEARCHED FOR BUT NOT RECOVERED.  R. M. NO. 2 WAS RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED.  A STEEL PIPE TRIPOD AND CENTERPOLE WITH LEGS IMBEDDED IN CONCRETE IS CENTERED OVER THE STATION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1964)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1964 (GWM) STATION WAS RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED, BUT A NEW DESCRIPTION WOULD BE MORE ADEQUATE.  STATION IS ABOUT 2-3/4 MILES SE OF CEIBA, ON THE ROOSEVELT ROADS NAVAL RESERVATION, ON POINT MEDIO MUNDO, ON TOP OF THE HIGHEST HILL ON THE POINT, 11.9 FEET W OF THE NW CORNER AND 11.2 FEET W OF THE SW CORNER OF A DESTROYED CONCRETE BLOCK BUILDING, 7.5 FEET SQUARE, AND 2 FEET W OF CONCRETE SLAB THAT PROJECTS 6 INCHES.  IT IS A STANDARD TRIANGULATION DISC STAMPED, MEDIO 1941, SET IN A CONCRETE POST AND PROJECTS 5 INCHES ABOVE THE GROUND.  THERE IS NO UNDERGROUND MARK.  TO REACH FROM THE CONTROL STATION AT THE RIFLE RANGE ON THE ROOSEVELT ROADS NAVAL RESERVATION, GO E. TO THE RIFLE BUTTS, CONTINUE NE UP THE HILL TO THE STATION AT THE TOP OF THE HILL.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 1 IS BELIEVED TO BE DESTROYED.  THE BASE OF THE CONCRETE POST WAS LOCATED BUT THE TOP OF THE POST AND THE MARK WERE NOT FOUND.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 2 IS A STANDARD DISC STAMPED, MEDIO NO. 2, 1941, SET IN A DRILLED HOLE IN A BOULDER ABOUT 5 FEET IN DIAMETER AND PROJECTING 5 FEET ABOVE THE GROUND, 58.45 FEET NW OF STATION.  A METAL PIPE TRIPOD HAS BEEN PLACED OVER THE STATION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1966)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JJL) THE STATION MARK AND REFERENCE MARK 2 WERE FOUND AND IN GOOD CONDITION.  REFERENCE MARK 1 WAS FOUND BUT THE UPPER PART OF THE MARK HAS BEEN KNOCKED OFF.  A REFERENCE MARK 3 WAS ESTABLISHED AT THIS DATE.  A NEW DESCRIPTION FOLLOWS--  THE STATION IS LOCATED IN THE NORTHEAST SECTION OF ROOSEVELT ROADS NAVAL STATION AND ON A LOW HILL THAT OVERLOOKS A FIRING RANGE TO THE SOUTH.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM GATE NUMBER 1 AT ROOSEVELT ROADS NAVAL STATION, GO SOUTHEAST FOR 0.1 MILE TO A FORK.  TAKE THE LEFT FORK AND CONTINUE SOUTHEAST ON TARAWA DRIVE FOR 1.7 MILES TO A FORK.  TAKE THE LEFT FORK AND GO EAST ON FORRESTAL DRIVE FOR 0.5 MILE TO A FORK.  TAKE THE LEFT FORK AND GO EAST ON ANTIETAM DRIVE WHICH LATER BECOMES ANTIETAM ROAD, FOR 1.1 MILE TO A SIDE ROAD ON THE LEFT.  TURN LEFT AND GO NORTH ON CHAMPLAIN ROAD FOR 1.65 MILES TO A LOCKED GATE.  (A KEY AND PERMISSION TO ENTER MAY BE OBTAINED AT THE WEAPONS DEPARTMENT.) PASS THROUGH THE GATE AND CONTINUE NORTH FOR 0.7 MILE TO THE RIFLE RANGE ON THE LEFT AND A FORK.  TAKE THE RIGHT FORK AND FOLLOW A DIM TRACK ROAD NORTHERLY FOR 0.15 MILE TO THE STATION ON THE HIGHEST POINT OF A LOW HILL.  (A 4-WHEEL DRIVE VEHICLE IS REQUIRED TO TRAVEL THE LAST 0.15 MILE TO THE STATION.)  THE STATION MARK IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED MEDIO 1941, SET IN THE TOP OF A 12-INCH SQUARE CONCRETE POST THAT PROJECTS 6 INCHES AND IS ON THE HIGHEST POINT OF THE HILL.  NOTE--1A 7A  REFERENCE MARK 2 IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED MEDIO NO 2 1941, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A LARGE BOULDER THAT PROJECTS 3 FEET.  IT IS ON THE NORTHWEST SLOPE OF THE HILL AND IS ABOUT 3 FEET LOWER IN ELEVATION THAN THE STATION MARK.  NOTE--12C  REFERENCE MARK 3 IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED MEDIO NO 3 1941, BRAZED TO THE TOP OF A 3-INCH CAST IRON PIPE THAT PROJECTS 1 FOOT.  IT IS THE SAME ELEVATION AS THE STATION MARK.  NOTE--DESC.  AIRLINE DISTANCE AND DIRECTION FROM NEAREST TOWN 3 MILES SOUTHEAST OF CEIBA.

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JWC) THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 9 MILES WEST-SOUTHWEST OF LAJAS, 2 MILES SOUTH-SOUTHWEST OF BOQUERON AND ON THE HIGHEST POINT OF A BRUSH COVERED KNOLL LOCATED ON THE WEST END OF A LOW RIDGE OF HILLS.  THIS IS THE HIGHEST POINT IN THE IMMEDIATE VICINITY.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE JUNCTION OF HIGHWAY 102 AND HIGHWAY 103 IN CABO ROJO, GO SOUTH ON HIGHWAY 103 FOR 5.2 MILES TO A T-ROAD, THE JUNCTION WITH HIGHWAY 101.  TURN RIGHT AND GO WEST ON HIGHWAY 101 FOR 0.7 MILE TO A SIDE ROAD LEFT.  TURN LEFT AND GO SOUTH AND WEST ON THE PAVED ROAD FOR 2.9 MILES TO A Y-FORK.  KEEP THE RIGHT FORK AND CONTINUE WEST ON THE PAVED ROAD FOR 2.15 MILES TO A T-ROAD AT KILOMETER POST 7.7.  TURN RIGHT AND GO NORTH AND NORTHWEST ON THE DIRT ROAD FOR 1.1 MILES TO A SIDE ROAD RIGHT AND A WIRE GATE ON THE RIGHT.  BEAR TO THE RIGHT, PASS THROUGH THE GATE AND GO NORTHERLY ON THE TRACK ROAD FOR 0.05 MILE THEN TURN RIGHT, ACROSS COUNTRY AND GO EAST UP THE DRAW FOR 0.1 MILE TO THE END OF TRUCK TRAVEL IN THE DRAW AT THE BASE OF THE HILL.  NOTE--A 4-WHEEL DRIVE VEHICLE IS REQUIRED TO REACH THE END OF TRUCK TRAVEL FROM THE WIRE GATE MENTIONED PREVIOUSLY IN THIS DESCRIPTION.  PACK NORTH UP THE STEEP HILL FOR 15 MINUTES TO THE HIGHEST POINT OF THE HILL AND THE STATION.  THE STATION MARK IS A CENTER PUNCHED SECTION OF 1/2-INCH SQUARE STEEL ROD THAT PROJECTS 1 INCH FROM A MASS OF CONCRETE WHICH IS FLUSH WITH THE SURFACE OF THE GROUND.  THE SURFACE OF THE CONCRETE IS INSCRIBED MELONES 1958.  IT IS LOCATED ON THE HIGHEST POINT OF THE HILL.  REFERENCE MARK 1 IS A STANDARD DISK, STAMPED MELONES PRS NO 1 1958 1966, BRAZED TO THE TOP OF A 3-INCH DIAMETER CAST IRON PIPE THAT PROJECTS 6 INCHES.  REFERENCE MARK 2 IS A STANDARD DISK, STAMPED MELONES PRS NO 2 1958 1966, BRAZED TO THE TOP OF A 3-INCH DIAMETER CAST IRON PIPE THAT PROJECTS 6 INCHES.  AN AZIMUTH MARK WAS NOT ESTABLISHED.

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1900 (JN) THIS STATION IS ON THE HIGHEST SUMMIT OF THE LITTLE RANGE OF HILLS CALLED PENONES DE MELONES.  A SMALL HILL DUE EASTWARD SEPARATES THIS HILL FROM THE VALLEY IN WHICH BOQUERON BASE LIES.  THE LINE FROM HERE TO BUENA VISTA RUNS ACROSS THE LARGE LAGOON IN BOQUERON VALLEY, CALLED PLACERO DE CANO.  JUST W OF THIS HILL AND BETWEEN IT AND THE NEXT HIGHEST HILL OF THE RANGE, A ROAD COMES INTO BOQUERON BAY AT THE W END OF THE SALT PONDS.  THE LOW HILL (FIRST REFERRED TO) WHICH SEPARATES THIS HILL FROM BOQUERON VALLEY IS WELL COVERED WITH TREES AND WE HAD TO CUT OUT A LINE ON THE N SIDE TO PERMIT THE VISIBILITY OF EAST BASE.  ON THE SUMMIT OF THE HILL ONLY A FEW BUSHES WERE STANDING AND A GREAT DEAL OF THESE WERE CUT OFF SO OBSERVATIONS COULD BE MADE WITH THE INSTRUMENT SET UP ON THE GROUND.  STATION MARK IS A 2-FOOT IRON PIPE BURIED 21 INCHES IN THE GROUND, FILLED AND SURROUNDED WITH CONCRETE.  A NAIL IN THE CENTER IS THE CENTER OF THE STATION.  RAMON PABON IS THE OWNER OF THE GROUND ON WHICH THE SIGNAL STANDS.  MELONES WHITE FLAG MUST NOT BE CONFOUNDED WITH THE STATION.  THE FORMER IS A WHITE FLAG IN A TREE-TOP ON A HIGH HILL ABOUT SSW FROM MELONES.  PELEGRIN TORRES OF BOQUERON KNOWS WHERE THIS SIGNAL IS.  TO REACH THIS POINT, ONE LEAVES BOQUERON BY THE OLD W ROAD TO CABO ROJO LIGHTHOUSE, FOLLOWING THE BEACH TO THE W END OF THE FIRST SALT PONDS MET WITH.  THEN GO AROUND THESE ON THE CABO ROJO ROAD, AND TURNING E RETRACE ONES STEPS ALONG THE ROAD, FOLLOWING THE INSIDE EDGE OF THE PONDS, TURNING FROM THEM AT THE FIRST GAP IN THE FENCE ABREAST OF A CUT FROM WHICH EARTH HAS BEEN TAKEN FOR THE SALT POND EMBANKMENT.  WHICH TAKES ONE ON TO A LARGE WELL WHICH IS CLOSE TO THE PONDS.  LEAVING THE TEAM HERE, FOLLOW THE ROAD UP TO THE GAP WHICH WILL BE S FROM THE WELL, ON THE HIGHEST AND MORE WESTERN OF THE PEAKS MAKING THE GAP, THE SIGNAL STATION WILL BE FOUND, THE SURROUNDING CLEARING BEING A GOOD MARK.                            STATION RECOVERY (1904)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1904 (JBM) FOUND STATION MARK REMOVED AND LYING ON ONE SIDE.  RESET IT WHERE STONES AND EVIDENCE OF CEMENT INDICATED CENTER.  I ALSO ERECTED A TRIPOD.  STATION CAN ALSO BE REACHED BY LANDING AT THE SALT PONDS REFERRED TO IN THE ORIGINAL DESCRIPTION AND FOLLOWING THE ROAD AS DESCRIBED.

STATION RECOVERY (1975)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1975 (RMB) THE STATION, A RED BRICK CHIMNEY ABOUT 60 FEET TALL, WAS RECOVERED IN FAIR CONDITION.  TO REACH THE STATION, FROM GUAYAMA FOLLOW HIGHWAY 1 SOUTH AND WEST ABOUT 2 MILES, TURN LEFT ON HIGHWAY 710, AND CONTINUE 0.4 MILES TO THE PHILLIPS REFINERY.  TURN LEFT ON A PAVED ROAD AND GO 0.5 MILES TOWARD BARRANCAS.  THE STATION IS IMMEDIATELY EAST OF A SMALL STREAM (THE RIO GUAMANI) AND ON THE NORTH SIDE OF THE ROAD.

BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1900 (JN) STATION IS ON THE LARGE HILL JUST E OF MAYAGUEZ.  ON ONE SIDE OF THE HILL THE MILITARY ROAD TO LAS MARIAS AND MARICAS TRAVELS ALONG A VALLEY.  ON THE S SIDE IS THE SAN GERMAN VALLEY.  THE STREET PASSING THE S SIDE OF THE BUILDING NOW USED AS A MILITARY HOSPITAL ENDS AT THE FOOT OF THE ROAD THAT CROSSES ALONG THE AXIS OF MESA HILL, AND COMES FROM THE VILLAGE OF ROSARIO.  FOLLOWING THIS ROAD, ONE ARRIVES (AFTER PASSING A PIECE OF SUNKEN ROAD) AT THE FIRST PLATEAU, AND HERE ON THE LEFT IS A FRAME COTTAGE, WITH RED ROOF, STANDING IN AN OPEN PIECE OF GROUND.  A LITTLE BEYOND (IN THE PLATEAU) IS ANOTHER HOUSE STANDING IN A NICE LITTLE GROVE.  ONE PASSES THIS PLACE AND TRAVELS ALONG FOR ABOUT 500 TO 600 METERS, ALONG A TRAIL WHICH FOLLOWS THE AXIS OF THE RIDGE AND THEN FINDS ANOTHER LITTLE ASCENT.  AT THE TOP IS A SMALL COFFEE PLANTATION, THICKLY SET OUT WITH SHADE AND COFFEE TREES, THE HOME OF MANUEL RAMON.  THE SIGNAL IS NEAR THE W END OF MR. RAMONS GROVE AND ON THE OPPOSITE SIDE OF THE ROAD.  A TRIPOD SIGNAL WAS ERECTED HERE.  THE STATION MARK IS A 2-INCH IRON TUBE SUNK IN THE GROUND FOR ABOUT 18 INCHES, LEAVING ABOUT 4 INCHES EXPOSED.  IT WAS SET IN PLACE WITH CEMENT AND ITS CENTER WAS FILLED WITH THE SAME MATERIAL.  AN IRON NAIL WAS SET IN THE CEMENT AND THE CENTER OF ITS TOP MARKS THE STATION.  THE OWNER OF THE LAND IS RAMON BELI, A RESIDENT OF MAYAGUEZ.  BESIDES MEASURING TO MANUEL RAMONS FENCE, A MEASUREMENT WAS MADE TO A LARGE MANGO TREE, ABOUT 18 INCHES IN DIAMETER, WHICH MAKES A GOOD REFERENCE.  THE STATION IS ABOUT 6 METERS S OF THE ROSARIO- MAYAGUEZ ROAD.  TRIPOD SEEN STANDING IN 1901.  THE DISTANCE FROM CENTER OF STATION TO A POINT ON MANGO TREE, ABOUT 4 FEET ABOVE BASE, WAS 9.00 METERS.  THEN A DISTANCE WAS MEASURED TO A MAMEY TREE, ABOUT 6 INCHES IN DIAMETER, TO WHICH THE WIRE OF THE FENCE IS NAILED AND THIS DISTANCE WAS 12.872 METERS.  THE DISTANCE OF THE MAMEY TREE TO THE SW CORNER OF THE FENCE WAS FOUND TO BE 16.014 METERS.                            STATION RECOVERY (1901)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1901 (JEM) THE TRIPOD AND STATION MARK WERE FOUND UNCHANGED.  DESCRIPTION OF 1900 ADEQUATE.
markers.setting: SET INTO TOP OF METAL PIPE DRIVEN INTO GROUND
markers.stability: MARK OF QUESTIONABLE OR UNKNOWN STABILITY

markers.description: PTIVE TEXT AVAILABLE.

BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1934 STATION IS ABOUT 2 MILES TO THE N OF CAGUAS, ON THE TOP OF A BARE HILL OF THE MESETA CERRO, ABOUT 700 METERS DIRECTLY W OF THE CAGUAS-RIO PIEDRAS HIGHWAY.  THE PLACE HAS BEEN USED ALSO AS A POINT FOR A TRIANGULATION STATION BY THE UNITED PUERTO RICO SUGAR COMPANY, OF CAGUAS, IN THE SURVEY OF THE CANE FIELDS BELONGING TO THIS COMPANY.  A REGULAR U.S.G.S. TABLET STAMPED MESAS 1934 WAS SET AS STATION CENTER.  REFERENCE MARK NO.1 IS A CROSS MARK ON A HALF BURIED BROAD STONE, 19 FEET 1/2 INCH FROM THE STATION, ON A TRUE AZIMUTH OF 80 DEG 39 MIN.  REFERENCE MARK NO.2 IS A CROSS MARK ON A HALF BURIED POINTED STONE, 15 FEET 4-1/2 INCHES FROM THE STATION, ON A TRUE AZIMUTH OF 165 DEG 31 MIN.  SIGNAL--A WHITE QUADRIPOD WITH BLACK CROSS TARGETS.  REACHED FROM KILOMETER H ON THE ROAD FROM CAGUAS TO RIO PIEDRAS, BY TAKING ROAD NAMED BAIROA TO THE W OF THE HIGHWAY AND DRIVE FOR ABOUT 3/4 MILE UNTIL YOU REACH ROAD LEADING TO CERRO LAS MESAS.  GOING N ON THIS ROAD YOU CAN DRIVE FOR ABOUT 1/2 MILE MORE THEN TAKE THE REST OF THE ROAD (ABOUT 1-1/2 KILOMETERS) ON FOOT TO THE STATION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1940)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1940 RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION, STATION AND R. M.S.  NEW DESCRIPTION FOLLOWS--  LOCATED ABOUT 3 MILES NW OF CAGUAS AND ONE MILE W OF THE CAGUAS- RIO PIEDRAS HIGHWAY, ON A HIGH, BARE HILL, AND ABOUT 200M E OF THE CERRO LAS MESAS SCHOOL.  THE STATION IS ON THE HIGHEST POINT OF THE HILL, ABOUT 15 METERS NE OF CORNER OF TOBACCO BARN.  AND IS A STANDARD TABLET STAMPED MESAS 1934, CEMENTED TO ROCK ABOUT FLUSH WITH GROUND.  R. M. NO. 1 IS A CROSS MARK ON A HALF-BURIED, BROAD STONE, 19.04 FT. FROM STATION IN AZIMUTH, 80 DEG 39 MIN.  R. M. NO. 2 IS A CROSS CUT ON A HALF-BURIED, POINTED STONE, 15.38 FT. FROM STATION IN AZIMUTH 165 DEG 31 MIN.  TO REACH FROM CAGUAS (NE CORNER OF PLAZA) GO ON THE HIGHWAY NO. 1 TOWARDS RIO PIEDRAS 2.7 MILES TO A HOUSE AT N END OF SMALL CONCRETE BRIDGE.  LEAVE CAR AND TAKE TRAIL WESTWARD UP TO RIDGE.  PASS HOUSE AND BARN (WHICH STAND OUT PROMINENTLY FROM BELOW), GO THROUGH FENCE, AND CONTINUE ON TRAIL SOUTHWESTWARD, AND THEN STEEPLY UP WESTWARD ALONG FENCE LINE TO TOP.  THE STATION IS ON THE TOP TO THE N OF WHERE THE TRAIL CROSSES.                            STATION RECOVERY (1954)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1954 (JOP) STATION WAS RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED IN 1940 AND FOUND TO BE IN GOOD CONDITION.  TO REACH FROM THE NE CORNER OF THE PLAZA IN CAGUAS, FOLLOW HIGHWAY 1 FOR 3.95 MI. N TO A SIDE ROAD LEFT, TURN LEFT AND GO ABOUT 0.07 MI. TO A LANE BETWEEN TWO BUILDINGS, TURN LEFT AND FOLLOW THE LANE WHICH TWISTS THROUGH BUILDINGS AND GOES NW FOR 1.43 MI. TO A DIRT SIDE ROAD LEFT, TURN LEFT AND GO 0.65 MI. TO A T-INTERSECTION, TURN LEFT AND GO 0.3 MI. TO A ROAD FORK, BEAR LEFT PAST A SCHOOLHOUSE ON THE RIGHT FOR 0.15 MI. TO END OF TRUCK TRAVEL.  FOLLOW A TRAIL SE TO THE TOP OF A HILL AND THE STATION AS DESCRIBED (ABOUT 5-MINUTE PACK).  ALL DIRT ROADS ARE PROBABLY IMPASSABLE IN WET WEATHER, AND A FOUR-WHEEL DRIVE VEHICLE WOULD BE PREFERABLE.  TELEVISION STATION WKAQ ANTENNA WAS OBSERVED FOR AN AZIMUTH MARK (99 DEG 13 MIN 44.9 SEC) AT THIS TIME.  POINT OBSERVED WAS THE TO LIGHT.  THE STATION IS LOCATED ON THE TOP OF A HIGH HILL KNOWN AS CERRO MARQUESA, ON THE EDGE OF A ROADBANK.  THE MAST IS A FOUR- LEGGED STRUCTURE PAINTED RED AND WHITE AND IS APPROXIMATELY 290 FT. HIGH.                            STATION RECOVERY (1965)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1965 (JJL) THE STATION MARK WAS RECOVERED AND FOUND IN GOOD CONDITION.  TWO NEW REFERENCE MARKS AND A AZIMUTH MARK WERE ESTABLISHED.  A COMPLETE NEW DESCRIPTION OF THE STATION FOLLOWS.  THE STATION IS LOCATED 14 AIRLINE MILES SOUTH-SOUTHWEST OF SAN JUAN, 3 AIRLINE MILES NORTHWEST OF CAGUAS AND ON THE HIGHEST POINT OF A BRUSH COVERED HILL.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE POST OFFICE IN CAGUAS, GO NORTHERLY ON HIGHWAY 1 FOR 2.8 MILES TO HIGHWAY 795.  TURN LEFT AND GO WEST, SOUTH AND SOUTHEAST ON HIGHWAY 795 FOR 2.0 MILES TO THE TOP OF A LOW HILL AT KILOMETER POST 3.5 AND THE AZIMUTH MARK ON THE LEFT.  CONTINUE SOUTHEAST ON HIGHWAY 795 FOR 0.1 MILE TO A SIDE ROAD LEFT.  BEAR LEFT AND GO EAST ON A BLADED ROAD FOR 0.2 MILE TO A HOUSE ON THE LEFT AND END OF TRUCK TRAVEL.  FROM HERE PACK NORTH UPHILL FOR ABOUT 100 YARDS TO THE HIGHEST POINT OF THE BRUSH COVERED HILL AND THE STATION.  THE STATION MARK IS A USGS BENCH MARK STAMPED MESAS 1934, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A BOULDER WHICH PROJECTS 6 INCHES.  IT IS 16 FEET NORTH OF A FENCE LINE.  REFERENCE MARK 3 IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED MESAS USGS NO 3 1934, BRAZED TO THE TOP OF A 3 INCH ROUND CAST IRON SOIL PIPE WHICH PROJECTS 8 INCHES.  IT IS 20 FEET NORTH OF THE FENCE LINE.  REFERENCE MARK 4 IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED MESAS USGS NO 4 1934, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A BOULDER WHICH PROJECTS 6 INCHES.  IT IS 4 FEET NORTH OF THE FENCE LINE.  (NOTE 12C)  THE AZIMUTH MARK IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED MESAS USGS 1934, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A BOULDER WHICH PROJECTS 2 FEET.  IT IS 26 FEET NORTHEAST OF THE KILOMETER POST 3.5, 25 FEET NORTH OF THE CENTER OF HIGHWAY 795 AND 3 FEET NORTH OF A FENCE LINE.  (NOTE 17C)  AIRLINE DISTANCE AND DIRECTION FROM NEAREST TOWN 3 MILES NORTHWEST OF CAGUAS.                            STATION RECOVERY (1995)  RECOVERY NOTE BY ANDREGG INCORPORATED 1995 (DJR) RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED.                            STATION RECOVERY (2004)  RECOVERY NOTE BY UNIVERSITY OF PUERTO RICO AT MAYAGUEZ 2004 (UPR) MARK NOT FOUND.                            STATION RECOVERY (2008)  RECOVERY NOTE BY POLYTECHNIC UNIVERSITY OF PUERTO RICO 2008 (JRT) TO REACH FROM ANY DIRECTION SAN JUAN/CAGUAS CAGUAS/SAN JUAN GO ON HIGHWAY 1,HEADING TO HIGWAY 795,THAT IS THE COMMUNITY OF LAS BARRAS AND LAS MESAS. YOU WILL PASS A SCHOOL LOCATED ON THE LEFT HAND SIDE OF THE STREET, KEEP GOING UNTIL YOU REACH THE KILOMETER 3.6, IN  THE ROAD FORK TURN LEFT AND GO 0.3 MILES. KEEP GOING ON YOUR BEAR LEFT AND PASS PUBLIC SCHOOL ANTONIO LONGO LOCATED ON THE RIGHT HAND SIDE OF THE STREET. KEEP GOING ON YOUR LEFT FOR 0.15 MILES TO END OF TRUCK TRAVEL. THE STATION IS ON THE HILL IN FRONT OF THE FONTANEZ FAMILY HOUSE. FOLLOW A TRAIL TO THE TOP OF A HILL AND THE STATION AS DESCRIBED (ABOUT 5-MINUTE PACK).                            STATION RECOVERY (2015)  RECOVERY NOTE BY POLYTECHNIC UNIVERSITY OF PUERTO RICO 2015 (UXR) RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.
markers.setting: SET IN A BOULDER
markers.stability: MAY HOLD, BUT OF TYPE COMMONLY SUBJECT TOSURFACE MOTION

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1901 (SF) STATION IS AN EMPTY GLASS BOTTLE BURIED 30 INCHES BELOW THE SURFACE OF THE GROUND.  ON THE TOP OF THIS IS PLACED A DRAIN TILE PIPE 24 INCHES LONG, 4 INCHES IN DIAMETER, BIG END DOWN, TOP OF PIPE EVEN WITH THE SURFACE OF THE GROUND.  CEMENT GROUTING IS PLACED AROUND THE OUTSIDE OF THE PIPE AND THE INSIDE IS FILLED WITH A GROUTING, 2 PARTS PORTLAND CEMENT AND 4 PARTS SAND.  INTO THE TOP OF THIS PIPE, EVEN WITH THE SURFACE OF THE GROUND, IS PLACED AND SECURED BY CEMENT A METAL C. AND G. SURVEY STATION MARK, WITH THE LETTERS U.S.C. AND G.S. ON ITS TOP, AND A SMALL HOLE DRILLED INTO THE TOP, WHICH MARKS THE CENTER OF THE STATION.
BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1926 (GCM) OLD STONE MILL E OF ARROYO.  THE MILL IS ABOUT 300 METERS FROM THE BEACH AND IS SURROUNDED BY SUGAR CANE.

BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1939 (EGR) LOCATED 3 KMS. NE OF MAYAGUEZ, ON THE HIGHEST POINT OF RIDGE S OF THE MUNICIPAL RD. TO MIRADERO.  THE RIDGE IS COVERED BY GRASS AND SOME BRUSH ON ITS N SIDE AND THE S SIDE IS PLANTED WITH CANE.  IT IS ON THE S LIMIT OF LAND OWNED BY MR. WHITEMORE ON THE EDGE OF THE CANE FIELD OWNED BY MR. RAMON DIAZ AND 250 METERS N AND E OF HIS HOME.  STATION MARK--STANDARD TABLET STAMPED MIRADERO 1938 EMBEDDED ON A CONCRETE MONUMENT 8 INCHES DIAMETER BY 36 INCHES DEEP.  R. M. NO. 1--STANDARD NAIL AND WASHER ON CENTER OF A TRIANGLE BLAZED ON ROBLE TREE 29.85 FT. DISTANT.  R. M. NO. 2--HOLE DRILLED ON HIGHEST POINT OF LARGE BOULDER 42.80 FT. IN DIST.                            STATION RECOVERY (1966)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JWC) THE STATION MARK WAS RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED AND FOUND TO BE IN GOOD CONDITION.  IT WAS FOUND TO BE LEANING TOWARD THE NORTH BUT IT REMAINED SOLID.  REFERENCE MARK 1 AND REFERENCE MARK 2 WERE NOT RECOVERED AND NEW REFERENCE MARKS 3 AND 4 WERE ESTABLISHED.  A COMPLETE NEW DESCRIPTION FOLLOWS.  THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 4-1/2 MILES SOUTH OF ANASCO, 1-1/2 MILES NORTHEAST OF MAYAGUEZ AND ON THE HIGHEST POINT OF A PROMINENT BRUSH AND TREE COVERED RIDGE THAT IS LOCATED IN A RESIDENTIAL AREA NEAR MAYAGUEZ.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE NORTHEAST CORNER OF THE PLAZA IN MAYAGUEZ, GO EAST ON MC KINLEY STREET FOR 2 BLOCKS.  TURN LEFT AND GO NORTH ON HIGHWAY 108 FOR 2.4 MILES TO A DOUBLE SIDE ROAD RIGHT.  TURN RIGHT AND GO EAST ON THE NORTH ONE OF THE TWO ROADS FOR 0.2 MILE TO THE END OF TRUCK TRAVEL AT THE CREST OF THE HILL AND A HOUSE ON THE LEFT, NORTH, SIDE OF THE ROAD.  PACK SOUTH UP THE BRUSH COVERED HILL FOR ABOUT 75 YARDS TO THE HIGHEST POINT AND THE STATION.  THE STATION MARK IS A STANDARD U.S. GEOLOGICAL SURVEY DISK, STAMPED MIRADERO 1938, SET IN THE TOP OF AN 8-INCH ROUND CONCRETE MONUMENT THAT PROJECTS 3 INCHES.  REFERENCE MARK 3 IS A STANDARD DISK, STAMPED MIRADERO NO 3 1938 1966, BRAZED TO THE TOP OF A 3-INCH DIAMETER CAST IRON PIPE THAT PROJECTS 7 INCHES.  IT IS ABOUT 2 FEET BELOW THE LEVEL OF THE STATION.  REFERENCE MARK 4 IS A STANDARD DISK, STAMPED MIRADERO NO 4 1938 1966, BRAZED TO THE TOP OF A 3-INCH DIAMETER CAST IRON PIPE THAT PROJECTS 3 INCHES.  IT IS ABOUT 2 FEET BELOW THE LEVEL OF THE STATION.  AIRLINE DISTANCE AND DIRECTION FROM NEAREST TOWN 1-1/2 MILES NORTHEAST OF MAYAGUEZ.                            STATION RECOVERY (1977)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1977 (PDC) THE STATION MARK AND REFERENCE MARK 4 WERE RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED AND IN GOOD CONDITION.  THE DISK OF REFERENCE MARK 3 IS MISSING, HOWEVER THE PIPE REMAINS IN GOOD CONDITION.  AIRLINE DISTANCE AND DIRECTION FROM NEAREST TOWN 3 KMS NE OF MAYAGUEZ.
markers.setting: SET IN TOP OF CONCRETE MONUMENT

markers.description: BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1939 (EGR) LOCATED ABOUT 3 KMS. S OF JUNCTION OF RD.  (VEGA BAJA TO MOROVIS) WITH RD. 2, 300M E OF RD. AT KM. ON LAND OWNED BY PADRO NEGROA.  IT IS A DOUBLE TOPPED HILL, WITH ITS N TOP A PROMINENT, POINTED, ROUND POINT, WHERE THE STATION IS LOCATED.  THE HILL IS LOCALLY KNOWN AS MIRAFLORES.  IT IS APPROACHED FROM KM -- OF RD. NO.-- ABOUT 80 METERS TO THE OWNERS HOUSE W OF HILL, THEN BY TRAIL UP SADDLE WHERE UP TO THE LEFT TO TOP AND STATION.  STATION MARK--STANDARD TABLET STAMPED MIRAFLORES 1939 EMBEDDED IN CONCRETE MONUMENT 10- BY 14- BY 10-INCHES ANCHORED ON NATURAL ROCK.  SIGNAL--POLE OF SAWED LUMBER WITH BLACK AND WHITE TARGETS CENTERED OVER STATION MARK.  R. M. NO. 1--STANDARD NAIL AND WASHER CEMENTED TO NATURAL ROCK W OF STATION 2.07 M.
markers.setting: SET IN TOP OF CONCRETE MONUMENT
markers.stability: MAY HOLD, BUT OF TYPE COMMONLY SUBJECT TOSURFACE MOTION

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1939 (HAC) STATION IS THE TOWER OF THE MIRAMAR APARTMENT HOUSE, THE SECOND BUILDING DIRECTLY S OF THE UNION CLUB IN THE MIRAMAR SECTION OF SANTURCE.  THIS TOWER HAS A RED TILE ROOF.  THIS TOWER IS LOCATED ON THE N SIDE OF THE APARTMENT HOUSE BUILDING.  APART IS LOCATED ON THE FLAT ROOF OF THIS BUILDING.                            STATION RECOVERY (1964)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1964 (GWM) THE ORIGINAL DESCRIPTION IS ADEQUATE FOR THE RECOVERY OF THIS STATION.

BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1934 STATION LOCATED ABOUT 3 KILOMETERS N OF THE TOWN OF MOCA, ON THE HIGHEST PEAK IN THE IMMEDIATE VICINITY, IN THE RANGE OF LIMESTONE PEAKS BORDERING CULBERBRINAS RIVER VALLEY ON THE N.  THIS PEAK HAS A VERY NOTICEABLE CLIFF ON ITS WESTERN SIDE.  IT IS ABOUT 200 METERS NE OF THE RESIDENCE OF VALENTIN ACEVEDO.  THE PEAK WAS COVERED THICKLY WITH BRUSH WHICH WAS CLEARED FROM THE TOP, LEAVING A LONE AMASIGO TREE.  THE STATION IS NEAR THE CENTER OF THE FLAT TOP IN THE NATURAL EXPOSED LIMESTONE.  STATION MARK IS A STANDARD TABLET, STAMPED MOCA 1934, CEMENTED IN NATURAL EXPOSED LIMESTONE.  REFERENCE MARK NO.1 IS A COPPER NAIL AND WASHER IN CENTER OF A TRIANGULAR BLAZE ON THE SIGNAL TREE, 11.79 FEET FROM STATION IN TRUE AZIMUTH 354 DEG 14 MIN.  REFERENCE MARK NO.2 IS A CROSS CUT ON PROJECTING LIMESTONE ROCK, 13.65 FEET FROM STATION IN TRUE AZIMUTH 162 DEG 38 MIN.  STATION IS BEST REACHED FROM MOCA BY FOLLOWING THE MUNICIPAL ROAD, WHICH TURNS N FROM THE NE CORNER OF THE PLAZA, TO THE FIRST DIVIDE AFTER REACHING THE MOUNTAINS, THENCE TURN EASTWARD ON TRAIL TO HOUSE OF VALENTIN ACEVEDO.                            STATION RECOVERY (1952)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1952 (JOP) STATION WAS RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED AND FOUND IN GOOD CONDITION.  THE ROUTE TO STATION IS ADEQUATE.  TWO NEW REFERENCE MARKS WERE ESTABLISHED.  BOTH ARE STANDARD USC AND GS DISKS CEMENTED IN DRILL HOLES IN BEDROCK (NOTE 12A).  NO. 1, STAMPED MOCA NO 1 1934, IS ABOUT 1 FOOT LOWER THAN THE STATION.  REFERENCE MARK 2, STAMPED MOCA NO 2 1934, IS ALSO ABOUT 1 FOOT LOWER THAN THE STATION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1966)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JWC) THE STATION MARK WAS RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED AND REFERENCE MARK 2, ESTABLISHED IN 1952, WAS RECOVERED.  REFERENCE MARK 1 WAS SEARCHED FOR BUT IT WAS NOT LOCATED.  REFERENCE MARK 3 WAS ESTABLISHED.  A COMPLETE NEW DESCRIPTION FOLLOWS.  THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 3-1/2 MILES SOUTHEAST OF AGUADILLA, 1-1/2 MILES NORTHEAST OF MOCA AND ON THE HIGHEST POINT OF A PROMINENT RIDGE OF LIMESTONE HILLS.  THE WEST SIDE OF THIS HILL IS A STEEP LIMESTONE CLIFF.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE SOUTHEAST CORNER OF THE PLAZA IN MOCA, GO EAST ON HIGHWAY 111 FOR 0.3 MILE TO THE JUNCTION WITH HIGHWAY 110.  TURN LEFT AND GO NORTHERLY ON HIGHWAY 110 FOR 1.7 MILES TO A SIDE ROAD RIGHT.  (A 4-WHEEL DRIVE VEHICLE IS REQUIRED BEYOND THIS POINT.) TURN RIGHT AND GO EAST ON THE ROCKY ROAD FOR 0.15 MILE TO A Y-FORK.  KEEP THE LEFT FORK AND GO EAST FOR 0.5 MILE TO A GROUP OF BUILDINGS IN THE SADDLE BETWEEN TWO HIGH HILLS ON THE RIDGE AND THE END OF TRUCK TRAVEL.  PACK EAST, NORTHEAST AND NORTH ALONG THE RIDGE FOR ABOUT 10 MINUTES TO A SADDLE ALONG THE EAST-WEST RIDGE THEN BEAR TO THE LEFT AND PACK WEST ALONG THE RIDGE TO THE HIGHEST POINT OF THE BRUSH COVERED HILL AND THE STATION.  A 20 MINUTE PACK.  THE STATION MARK IS A STANDARD U.S. GEOLOGICAL SURVEY DISK, STAMPED MOCA 1934, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN OUTCROPPING BEDROCK THAT IS FLUSH WITH THE SURFACE OF THE GROUND.  REFERENCE MARK 2 IS A STANDARD DISK, STAMPED MOCA NO 2 1934, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN OUTCROPPING BEDROCK THAT PROJECTS 3 INCHES.  NOTE 12A.  REFERENCE MARK 3 IS A STANDARD DISK, STAMPED MOCA USGS NO 3 1934 1966, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN OUTCROPPING BEDROCK THAT PROJECTS 3 INCHES.  NOTE 12A.  AN AZIMUTH MARK WAS NOT ESTABLISHED.  AIRLINE DISTANCE AND DIRECTION FROM NEAREST TOWN 1-1/2 MILES NORTHEAST OF MOCA.
markers.setting: SET IN ROCK OUTCROP
markers.stability: MOST RELIABLE AND EXPECTED TO HOLDPOSITION/ELEVATION WELL

markers.description: BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1934 STATION IS CENTER OF CROSS ON MOCA CHURCH SPIRE.

BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1900 (SF) STATION IS SITUATED ON THE HIGHEST AND MOST WESTERLY EXTREMITY OF THE MOUNTAIN OF THE SAME NAME.  THIS MOUNTAIN IS ABOUT TEN MILES N OF THE TOWN OF JUANA DIAZ, WHICH IS ON THE MILITARY ROAD RUNNING BETWEEN PONCE AND SAN JUAN, AND IS ABOUT SIX MILES E OF PONCE.  FROM JUANA DIAZ A WAGON ROAD RUNS TO THE VILLAGE OF VILLA ALTA ORBA (AS GIVEN BY A MAP OF PUERTO RICO, BUT THE LOCAL NAME IS VILLORBA), WHICH IS SEVEN MILES APPROXIMATELY N OF JUANA DIAZ.  FROM THIS VILLAGE A MOUNTAIN TRAIL LEADS TO AND ACROSS THE EASTERN EXTREMITY OF MOGOTE MOUNTAIN.  LEAVING THIS TRAIL GO ALONG THE RIDGE TO THE HIGH PEAK AT THE WESTERN EXTREMITY OF THIS MOUNTAIN, AND THERE WILL BE FOUND THE TRIANGULATION STATION.  THERE ARE NO NATURAL OBJECTS TO BE USED FOR REFERENCE, BUT THE STATION CAN BE FOUND BY THE STATION MARK AND FROM THE FACT THAT IT IS ON THE HIGHEST POINT OF THE PEAK WHICH IS OF VERY SMALL AREA.  THE STATION IS MARKED WITH A BOULDER SET INTO, AND PROJECTING SEVERAL INCHES ABOVE, THE GROUND.  THE CENTER OF A CROSS (X) CUT INTO THE TOP OF THIS ROCK MARKS THE CENTER OF STATION.  IT WILL BE WELL FOR ANY ONE DESIRING TO FIND THIS STATION TO PROCURE THE SERVICES OF A GUIDE AT THE VILLAGE OF VILLORBA (OR VILLA ALTA ORBA).  NEARLY ALL THE TREES AROUND THE STATION WERE CUT DOWN.  THE NORTHERN SIDE OF THE MOUNTAIN IS THICKLY WOODED WITH PALMS AND UNDERGROWTH.  PORTIONS OF THE SOUTHERN SLOPE ARE CULTIVATED.                            STATION RECOVERY (1930)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1930 THE TOP OF THE HILL WAS CLEARED AND THE BLUE STONE MARKED WITH A CROSS WAS FOUND.  TO REACH TAKE INSULAR ROAD TO LIMIN AND LEAVE IT 1 KILOMETER FROM THE TOWN OF VILLALBA.  HERE FOLLOW HORSE TRAIL TO BARRIO VACAS WHERE YOU CAN REACH MOGOTE MOUNTAIN.  THE TRAIL REACHES THE TOP OF A RIDGE FROM WHICH A VALLEY AND THE N COAST IS SEEN IN THE DISTANCE.  FOLLOW THE RIDGE WESTWARD 10 MINUTES UNTIL YOU COME TO A PEAK WHERE LOOKING N IS ANOTHER JOINED TO THE PRINCIPAL RIDGE.  THIS IS KNOWN IN THE VICINITY AS PEAK OF THE AMERICANS.  THE STATION IS IN THE MOGOTE PART OF FARM DA JUANA BELONGING TO EMANUELLI BROTHERS.  THE FOLLOWING MEN KNOW THE PLACE--MIGUEL ROMARO.  ANASTACIO BONILLA.  TEODORO BONILLA, MANUEL BONILLA AND VINCENTE BONILLA.                            STATION RECOVERY (1934)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1934 STATION AND ORIGINAL MARK FOUND AS DESCRIBED ON LAST RECOVERY NOTE.  APPROACHED THROUGH TRAIL STARTING S FROM K-5 H 2 OF MATRULLAS DAM ROAD.                            STATION RECOVERY (2015)  RECOVERY NOTE BY INDIVIDUAL CONTRIBUTORS 2015 (LDS) THE MARK IS MUTILATED. THE ACTUAL LOCATION DO NOT MATCH WITH THE DESCRIPTION IN THE DATASHEET. THE INFO IN THE DISK IS NOT VISIBLE.
markers.setting: SET IN A BOULDER
markers.stability: MAY HOLD, BUT OF TYPE COMMONLY SUBJECT TOSURFACE MOTION

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JWC) THE STATION IS LOCATED 10 AIRLINE MILES SOUTH OF CABO ROJO, ABOUT 100 YARDS NORTH OF THE SHORE LINE AND ON THE TOP OF A LOW BLUFF.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE SOUTHWEST CORNER OF THE PLAZA IN CABO ROJO, GO WEST ON A PAVED STREET FOR 1/2 BLOCK TO HIGHWAY 103.  TURN LEFT AND GO SOUTH ON HIGHWAY 103 FOR 5.15 MILES TO HIGHWAY 101.  TURN RIGHT AND GO WEST ON HIGHWAY 101 FOR 0.7 MILE TO A SIDE ROAD LEFT.  TURN LEFT AND GO SOUTHERLY ON A PAVED ROAD FOR 1.95 MILES TO A FORK.  CONTINUE STRAIGHT AHEAD AND GO SOUTH AND EAST ON A PAVED ROAD FOR 0.8 MILE TO A SIDE ROAD RIGHT AT KILOMETER POST 1.1.  TURN RIGHT AND GO SOUTH ON A SAND ROAD FOR 1.8 MILES TO THE SHORE LINE.  TURN RIGHT AND GO EAST ALONG THE NORTH EDGE OF THE SHORE FOR 0.5 MILE TO A GATE IN A FENCE LINE.  PASS THROUGH THE GATE AND GO EAST AND SOUTH PICKING WAY THROUGH BRUSH FOR 0.25 MILE TO THE SOUTH EDGE OF THE BLUFF AND THE STATION.  THE STATION MARK IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED MOLINO 1966, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN OUTCROPPING BEDROCK WHICH PROJECTS 2 INCHES.  IT IS ABOUT 100 FEET NORTH OF A FENCE LINE.  REFERENCE MARK 1 IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED MOLINO NO 1 1966, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN OUTCROPPING BEDROCK WHICH PROJECTS 1 INCH.  REFERENCE MARK 2 IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED MOLINO NO 2 1966, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN OUTCROPPING BEDROCK WHICH IS FLUSH WITH THE SURFACE.  NO AZIMUTH MARK WAS ESTABLISHED AT THIS STATION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1968)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1968 (JKW) STATION MARK AND REFERENCE MARK NO. 2 WERE RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 1 WAS RECOVERED IN FAIR CONDITION.  THE DISK HAS BEEN BATTERED AND IS LOOSE IN THE DRILL HOLE.  THERE IS A FOUR FOOT WOODEN O STAND OVER THE STATION MARK.  THE TO REACH IS ADEQUATE EXCEPT THAT A FOUR WHEEL DRIVE VEHICLE IS NECESSARY DUE TO THE ROAD BEING WASHED OUT.  TURN LEFT AND PROCEED EASTERLY ALONG THE SHORELINE, NOT RIGHT.
markers.setting: SET IN ROCK OUTCROP
markers.stability: MOST RELIABLE AND EXPECTED TO HOLDPOSITION/ELEVATION WELL

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1952 (JCP) STATION IS NEAR THE NORTHEAST TIP OF MONA ISLAND ABOUT 4 MILES NORTH-NORTHWEST OF MONA LIGHT HOUSE.  IT IS ON THE NORTHEAST SLOPE OF THE RIDGE ABOUT 30 YARDS SOUTHWEST OF THE SHEER CLIFF EDGE AND ABOUT 100 YARDS NORTHWEST OF A LARGE OVAL-SHAPED GROWTH OF TREES GROWING OUT OF A CAVE-LIKE DEPRESSION.  MARK IS IN A FAIRLY LEVEL CLEARING SURROUNDED BY CACTUS, LOW BRUSH AND 3 CAIRNS (FOR POSTING LIGHTS).  STATION AND REFERENCE MARKS ARE STANDARD DISKS CEMENTED IN DRILL HOLES IN CORAL BEDROCK.  STATION MARK IS STAMPED MONA 1952.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 1, STAMPED MONA NO 1 1952, IS ABOUT 2 FEET LOWER THAN STATION MARK.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 2, STAMPED MONA NO 2 1952, IS ABOUT THE SAME ELEVATION AS THE STATION MARK.  TRIANGULATION STATION MONA L.H. MAY BE USED FOR THE AZIMUTH MARK.  TO REACH FROM MONA LIGHT HOUSE, FOLLOW DIM TRAIL EASTERLY THROUGH CACTUS TO CLIFF EDGE THENCE NORTH AND NORTHWEST, KEEPING AS CLOSE TO CLIFF EDGE AS PRACTICABLE, TO NORTHEAST TIP OF ISLAND AND STATION.  THIS IS A 3-HOUR PACK AND DUE TO POISONOUS GROWTHS, NEARLY INVISIBLE CAVES AND POT-HOLES IN THE CORAL, IT IS NOT RECOMMENDED TO ATTEMPT IT AFTER DARK.  THERE ARE NO POISONOUS SNAKES.  GOATS, IGUANAS, RATS AND LIZARDS ARE IN ABUNDANCE.  WILD PIGS ARE SUPPOSEDLY HERE.  WE SAW NONE.  THE ONLY DRINKING-WATER SUPPLY IS AT THE LIGHT HOUSE.
markers.setting: SET IN ROCK OUTCROP
markers.stability: MOST RELIABLE AND EXPECTED TO HOLDPOSITION/ELEVATION WELL
