markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1952 (JOP) STATION IS NEAR THE NORTH EDGE OF THE STEEL BRIDGE DECK ON MONA ISLAND LIGHTHOUSE.  A STEEL RAILING, 3.6 FEET HIGH ENCLOSES THE BRIDGE AND STATION POINT IS 6.6 LOWER THAN THE BOTTOM OF THE BEACON.  POINT IS 1.367 METERS (4.48 FEET) NORTHEAST OF THE NORTHEAST EDGE OF STEEL DOOR ON BRIDGE, 0.137 METERS (0.45 FEET) EAST OF WELDED SEAM (SECOND SEAM EAST OF EAST EDGE OF DOOR. 0.491 METERS (1.61 FEET) SOUTH OF THE NORTH EDGE OF THE DECK AND 0.695 METERS (2.28 FEET) NORTH OF THE SOUTH EDGE OF BRIDGE PLATE.  THE LATTER TWO MEASUREMENTS MADE PARALLEL TO WELDED SEAM.  STATION IS MARKED BY A 1/4-INCH HOLE DRILLED IN THE STEEL DECK.  NO REFERENCE MARKS ESTABLISHED.  TRIANGULATION STATION MONA 1952 MAY BE USED FOR THE AZIMUTH MARK.  ASTRO OBSERVATIONS WERE MADE FROM THE CENTER OF THE CONCRETE FOUNDATION WHICH ONCE SUPPORTED A WIND-CHARGER FOR ELECTRICITY.  A BRONZE PIN IN A DRILL HOLE MARKS THE POINT.  FOUNDATION IS JUST SOUTHWEST OF THE GARAGE.  THE SHORAN STATION, STAMPED MONA USAF, IS NORTH OF MONA ISLAND LIGHTHOUSE IN A SMALL CLEARING IN BRUSH AND CACTUS.  IT IS ABOUT 1100 FEET INLAND FROM THE CLIFF LINE.  MARK IS A STANDARD USAF GEOGETIC SURVEY SHORAN STATION DISK IN A SMALL MASS OF CONCRETE.  REFERENCE MARK A, STAMPED MONA USAF R.M. A, IS A USC AND GS REFERENCE DISK IN A DRILL HOLE IN THE NORTH EDGE OF THE CONCRETE PAD, JUST EAST OF THE RADIO SHACK AND NORTH OF THE LIGHTHOUSE.  STATION WAS REACHED BY TRUCK FROM THE COAST GUARD DOCK ABOUT 3 MILES SOUTHWEST OF THE LIGHTHOUSE.  THE TOP OF THE 4-FOOT STAND ON MONA LIGHTHOUSE WAS 46.3 FEET ABOVE THE CONCRETE PAD.                            STATION RECOVERY (1974)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1974 (JDS) STATION NOT RECOVERED.  A NEW STEEL BRIDGE DECK HAS BEEN INSTALLED ON TOP OF THE OLD DECK AROUND THE LIGHTHOUSE.

BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1952 (JOP) ASTRO OBSERVATIONS WERE MADE FROM THE CENTER OF THE CONCRETE FOUNDATION WHICH ONCE SUPPORTED A WIND-CHARGER FOR ELECTRICITY.  A BRONZE PIN IN A DRILL HOLE MARKS THE POINT.  FOUNDATION IS JUST SOUTHWEST OF THE GARAGE.                            STATION RECOVERY (1974)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1974 (JDS) STATION RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.  STATION IS LOCATED ON THE EAST END OF MONA ISLAND, 170.56 FEET WEST OF THE MONA ISLAND LIGHTHOUSE.  STATION IS A BRONZE PIN IN A DRILL HOLE IN THE CENTER OF A SQUARE CONCRETE FOUNDATION THAT ONCE SUPPORTED A WIND CHARGER.  THE FOUNDATION IS JUST SOUTHWEST OF A GARAGE.
BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1974 (JDS) STATION DESTROYED.  THE RADIO TOWER HAS BEEN TORN DOWN.

BY US AIR FORCE 1952 (JOP) THE STATION MARK IS A STANDARD USAF GEODETIC SURVEY SHORAN STATION DISK, STAMPED MONA USAF, IN A SMALL MASS OF CONCRETE NORTH OF MONA ISLAND LIGHTHOUSE IN A SMALL CLEARING IN BRUSH AND CACTUS.  IT IS ABOUT 1100 FEET INLAND FROM THE CLIFF LINE.                            STATION RECOVERY (1974)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1974 (JDS) STATION RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.  STATION IS LOCATED ON THE EAST END OF MONA ISLAND, 319.6 FEET NORTH OF THE CENTER OF THE MONA ISLAND LIGHTHOUSE, AND ABOUT 1100 FEET INLAND FROM THE CLIFF LINE.  STATION IS A STANDARD USAF GEODETIC SURVEY SHORAN STATION DISK STAMPED MONA USAF SET IN A SMALL MASS OF CONCRETE THAT IS FLUSH WITH THE GROUND.                            STATION RECOVERY (1975)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1975 (JDS) THE SMALL MASS OF CONCRETE THAT THE STATION WAS SET IN WAS RECOVERED.  THE DISK HAS BEEN REMOVED FROM THE CONCRETE, HOWEVER, THE IMPRINT OF THE DISK AND THE SHANK IS STILL IN THE MASS OF CONCRETE.
markers.setting: UNSPECIFIED SETTING

markers.description: BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1922 THIS STATION IS ON THE HIGHEST POINT OF A PROMINENT GRASSY KNOLL PROJECTING WELL TO THE N FROM THE MAIN RIDGE AND OVERLOOKING A ROCKY CANYON TO THE N.  IT IS ABOUT 5.4 KILOMETERS DISTANT AND BEARS S 58 DEG 30 MIN W OF THE TOWN OF ISABELA, ON THE PROPERTY OF FRANCISCO SAAVEDRA.  IT IS ABOUT 0.9 KILOMETER NW OF HIS RESIDENCE.  THE STATION MARK IS A STANDARD U.S.G.S. BRONZE BENCH MARK TABLET SET IN CEMENT IN A LIMESTONE ROCK BURIED WITH ITS SURFACE FLUSH WITH THE GROUND.  REFERENCE MARK NO.1, IS A DRILL HOLE IN SOLID ROCK AT THE N EDGE OF A ROCK BASIN, 13.74 METERS DISTANT ON A TRUE AZIMUTH OF 169 DEG 51 MIN 00 SEC.  REFERENCE MARK NO.2, IS A DRILL HOLE IN A LARGE TILTED LIMESTONE ROCK PROJECTING ABOUT 0.6 METER ABOVE THE GROUND ON THE S SLOPE OF THE HILL.  IT IS 38.15 METERS DISTANT ON A TRUE AZIMUTH OF 356 DEG 21 MIN 25 SEC.  ELEVATION ABOVE SEA LEVEL - 130.3 METERS.                            STATION RECOVERY (1952)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US NAVY 1952 THE STATION WAS DESTROYED.  IT WAS REMOVED DURING THE CLEARING OF THE AREA.
markers.setting: SET IN ROCK OUTCROP
markers.stability: MOST RELIABLE AND EXPECTED TO HOLDPOSITION/ELEVATION WELL

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1901 (JN) THIS STATION IS ON A PROMINENT GRASSY KNOLL, PROJECTING QUITE WELL TO THE N, ABOUT 2 MILES DISTANT AND BEARING S 58 DEG W OF THE TOWN OF ISABELA, ON THE PROPERTY OF MANUEL HOLISTRU.  IT IS DISTANT ABOUT 1/3 MILE AND BEARS N 37 DEG W FROM HIS RESIDENCE AND OLD MILL.  THE STATION IS MARKED BY A GALVANIZED IRON PIPE 2 INCHES IN DIAMETER BY 2 FEET LONG SET IN A BED OF CEMENT, AND PROJECTS ABOVE THE CEMENT ABOUT 2-1/2 INCHES.  THE STATION IS MARKED BY THE HEAD OF A 20-PENNY NAIL SET IN CEMENT IN CENTER OF PIPE.
markers.setting: OBJECT SURROUNDED BY MASS OF CONCRETE

markers.description: BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1982 (JCL) THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 5.5 KM (3-1/2 MI) NORTHEAST OF PONCE, 3.75 KM (2-1/4 MI) NORTHWEST OF COTO LAUREL, 4 KM (2-1/2 MI) NORTH-NORHTEAST OF THE JUNCTION OF HIGHWAYS 14 AND 139, 0.45 KM (0.3 MI) SOUTH OF THE PROPOSED CERRILLOS DAM, 0.7 KM (0.4 MI) EAST OF HIGHWAY 139, ON THE EAST END OF A LOW RIDGE IN A GRASSY CLEARING AT A POINT WHERE THE RIDGE STARTS CLIMBING TO THE EAST, AND ABOUT 10 METERS HIGHER THAN A SMALL SADDLE.  OWNERSHIP--JACOB ALBIZU, P O BOX 299, COTO LAUREL, PONCE, PR 00644, PHONE 809-848-2123.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE JUNCTION OF HIGHWAYS 14 AND 139 ABOUT 3 KM (1.9 MI) NORTHEAST OF PONCE, GO EASTERLY ON HIGHWAY 14 FOR 1.9 KM (1.15 MI) TO THE ENTRANCE TO COLEGIO PONCENOS ON THE LEFT. CONTINUE EAST FOR 1.9 KM (1.2 MI) TO A PAVED CROSSROAD WITH A MOBIL GAS STATION ON THE LEFT. TURN LEFT AND GO NORTH ON WINDING ROAD FOR 1.9 KM (1.2 MI) TO A PAVED ROAD RIGHT AT THE BOTTOM OF A GRADE.  CONTINUE NORTHWEST ON PAVED ROAD (PASSING THROUGH VILLAGE OF CERRILLOS) TO ITS END AT HIGH GROUND BETWEEN TWO HILLS, A CONCRETE WALL ON THE RIGHT, AND A FENCE LEFT. PACK AHEAD, WEST, DOWN HILL FOR 50 METERS TO A FORK. BEAR RIGHT UP HILL FOR 20 METERS TO A FENCE LINE.  TURN LEFT DOWN HILL, PICKING UP A GOOD TRAIL, FOR 150 METERS TO A SADDLE IN THE RIDGE.  TURN SHARP RIGHT UP HILL THROUGH TALL GRASS FOR ABOUT 40 METERS TO THE STATION.  THE STATION IS A STANDARD NGS DISK STAMPED---MONROE 1982---, EPOXIED TO THE TOP OF A STEEL ROD DRIVEN 2.5 METERS INTO THE GROUND, SET IN THE CENTER OF A CONCRETE FILLED PLASTIC TILE 25 CM IN DIAMETER, AND PROJECTING 1 CM ABOVE THE GROUND.  IT IS LOCATED 4.6 METERS (15.0 FT) SOUTH FROM A STUMP 60 CM IN DIAMETER AND 2 METERS HIGH.  REFERENCE MARK NUMBER 1 IS A STANDARD NGS DISK STAMPED ---MONROE NO 1 1982---, EPOXIED TO THE TOP OF A STEEL ROD DRIVEN 2.5 METERS INTO THE GROUND, SET IN A CONCRETE FILL PLASTIC TILE 25 CM IN DIAMETER, AND PROJECTING 10 CM ABOVE THE GROUND.  IT IS LOCATED 2.6 METERS (8.5 FT) WEST FROM A STUMP 60 CM IN DIAMETER AND 2 METERS HIGH. MARK IS BELOW STATION 0.5 METERS.  REFERENCE MARK NUMBER 2 IS A STANDARD NGS DISK STAMPED ---MONROE NO 2 1982---, EPOXIED TO THE TOP OF A STEEL ROD DRIVEN 2.5 METERS INTO THE GROUND, SET IN A CONCRETE FILLED PLASTIC TILE 25 CM IN DIAMETER, AND PROJECTING 10 CM ABOVE THE GROUND.  IT IS LOCATED 2.4 METERS (7.9 FT) EAST FROM A STUMP 60 CM IN DIAMETER AND 2 METERS HIGH. MARK IS ABOVE STATION 1.5 METERS.  HEIGHT OF LIGHT SHOWN ABOVE THE MARK WAS 1.6 METERS.

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JWC) THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 1 MILE AIRLINE WEST OF MANATI.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE JUNCTION OF HIGHWAYS 2 AND 149 AT THE WEST EDGE OF MANATI, GO WEST ON HIGHWAY 2 FOR 0.7 MILE TO THE STATION ON THE RIGHT, NORTH SIDE OF THE ROAD.  THE STACK IS A CONCRETE STRUCTURE, PAINTED WHITE WITH A BLACK TOP AND HAS THE LEGEND MONSERRATE ON THE SOUTH SIDE.  IT IS 180 FEET HIGH.  THE POINT INTERSECTED WAS THE TOP AND CENTER OF THE STACK.

BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1941 (RLS) STATION IS ON THE ROOSEVELT ROADS NAVAL RESERVATION, BETWEEN PUERCA BAY AND ENSENADA HONDA, ON THE MIDDLE ONE OF 3 ISLANDS CONNECTED TO EACH OTHER AND TO THE MAINLAND BY MANGROVE SWAMPS FORMING A POINT CALLED CABRA DE TIERRA, ON THE HIGHEST POINT OF THE ISLAND, SURROUNDED BY SEVERAL BOULDERS, AND FLUSH WITH THE GROUND.  THE ELEVATION OF THE STATION IS ABOUT 59 FEET.  THE DISK UNSTAMPED.  SURFACE MARK IS A STANDARD DISK SET IN CONCRETE, AS DESCRIBED IN NOTE 1A.  THERE ARE NO UNDERGROUND OR REFERENCE MARKS.  THE STATION IS IN THE CONSTRUCTION AREA OF THE NAVAL BASE AND MAY BE DESTROYED.
markers.setting: SET IN TOP OF CONCRETE MONUMENT
markers.stability: MAY HOLD, BUT OF TYPE COMMONLY SUBJECT TOSURFACE MOTION

markers.description: BY ANDREGG INCORPORATED 1995 (DJR) TO REACH THE STATION FROM FORT BUCHANNON IN SAN JUAN, TAKE HIGHWAY PR 22 WEST TOWARD ARECIBO ABOUT 16 MILES (25.7 KM) TO THE TOLLBOOTH AT KIOMETER POST 31.4.  GO WEST THROUGH TOLL BOOTH ABOUT 54 METERS (177.2 FT) TO THE STATION ON THE RIGHT  THE STATION IS LOCATED IN A GRASS ISLAND AT A REST STOP NORTH OF THE TOLL BOOTH, THE STATION IS 3.4 METERS (11.2 FT) NORTHEAST OF THE EDGE OF PAVEMENT OF HIGHWAY PR 22, 2.6 METERS (8.5 FT) WEST OF EDGE OF PAVEMENT TO ENTRANCE OF REST AREA PARKING, 28 METERS (91.9 FT) SOUTHEAST OF STREET LIGHT STANDARD AND 12 METERS (39.4 FT) WESTERLY OF A TELEPHONE SIGN  THE STATION IS 1 METER (3.3 FT) SOUTHWEST OF A CARSONITE SURVEY MARKER WITNESS POST  THE STATION IS A 3-1/4 INCH BRASS CAP STAMPED CENTRO DE RECAUDACION DE INGRESSOS MUNICIPALES, PUERTO RICO GPS CONTROL, C.R.I.M., UNLAWFUL TO DISTURB, MONTEREY, SET ATOP A 9/16 INCH STAINLESS STEEL ROD DRIVEN TO REFUSAL AND COVERED FLUSH WITH THE GROUND BY AN ALUMINUM COVER EPOXYED ONTO A 6 INCH SCHEDULE 40 PVC PIPE SET IN CONCRETE INSIDE AND OUT                            STATION RECOVERY (2002)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 2002 (JMW) 23.8 KM (14.9 MI) EASTERLY ALONG STATE HIGHWAY 22 FROM THE JUNCTION OF STATE HIGHWAY 140 IN BARCELONETA, IN A GRASS MEDIAN ON THE NORTH SIDE OF THE WESTBOUND HIGHWAY AT A TOLL PLAZA, 21.4 M WEST OF KILOMETER POST 31.4, 6.8 M WEST OF THE EAST CURB OF THE MEDIAN, 3.6 M SOUTH OF THE NORTH CURB OF THE MEDIAN, 2.6 M NORTH OF THE NORTH EDGE OF THE HIGHWAY, 1.1 M SOUTH OF A WITNESS POST, AND 0.3 M ABOVE THE LEVEL OF THE HIGHWAY. NOTE--ACCESS TO THE DATUM POINT IS THROUGH A 5-INCH LOGO CAP.  THE MARK IS ON THE HIGHWAY RIGHT-OF-WAY. THIS MARK WILL BE DESTROYED BY CONSTRUCTION AT THE TOLL PLAZA IN THE NEAR FUTURE.  A NEW MARK, Q 1004, WAS SET ON THE OTHER SIDE OF THE HIGHWAY.
markers.setting: STAINLESS STEEL ROD W/O SLEEVE (10 FT.+)

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1941 (RLS) STATION IS ABOUT 1-1/2 MILES NE OF PLAYA NAGUABO, ABOUT 0.6 MILE E OF THE CROSSING OF INSULAR HIGHWAY 3 AND THE AMERICAN RAILROAD, ABOUT 1/4 MILE SE OF THE AMERICAN RAILROAD TRACK AT COLONIA MONTIDA, ABOUT ON LINE WITH A ROAD RUNNING SE THROUGH MONTIDA ACROSS THE TRACK AND INTO THE SUGAR CANE FIELDS, ABOUT 132 METERS E OF THE PROPOSED W BOUNDARY (LONG. 65 DEG 42 MIN) OF THE ROOSEVELT ROADS NAVAL RESERVATION, ON THE NORTHWESTERLY AND SLIGHTLY LOWER OF 2 LOW ROUNDED KNOLLS IN THE NEARLY FLAT AREA SE OF THE RAILROAD AND BETWEEN QUEBRADA PALMA AND THE HIGHER HILLS TO THE S AND SW, IN A CULTIVATED FIELD (AT PRESENT PLANTED IN CORN AND SWEET POTATOES), AND ON THE HIGHEST POINT OF THE KNOLL.  THE MARK PROJECTS 6 INCHES ABOVE THE GROUND.  THE STATION MARK IS A BRONZE DISK SET IN CONCRETE, NOTE 1A.  THERE ARE NO UNDERGROUND OR REFERENCE MARKS.  THE STATION MARK IS A U.S. NAVY BENCH MARK.  THE ELEVATION IS 11.917 METERS (39.10 FEET).
markers.setting: SET IN TOP OF CONCRETE MONUMENT

markers.description: BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1934 STATION IS ON A SHARP WOOD-COVERED PEAK ABOUT 3 MILES W OF THE TOWN OF MARICAO AND ABOUT 1 MILE N OF MAIN RIDGE AND DESCANSO TRIANGULATION STATION.  SIGNAL AND STATION--A WOODEN TRIPOD CENTERED OVER A CONCRETE MONUMENT LIMITING THREE FARMS.

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1901 (JEM) THIS STATION IS ON A HIGH HILL, WHICH IS THE PROPERTY OF SENOR DOMINGO MORALES.  THIS IS ON THE HIGHEST SUMMIT BETWEEN THE FANDURA MOUNTAIN AND THE CONICAL-TOPPED HILL (VERY NOTICEABLE) WHICH I CALLED RASPE PELA AT SANTA HELENA AND THIS STATION.  THE MEN WITH ME SAY THAT WHAT I HAVE CALLED RASPE PELA SHOULD BE CALLED MATUYA, AND SAY THAT WHAT I CALLED F IS RASPE PELA. LATER ON I LEARNED THAT MATUYA IS THE NAME OF THE BARRIO IN WHICH THE CONICAL PEAK IS SITUATED.  THIS IS BUT ANOTHER INSTANCE OF THE GENERAL EXPERIENCE WE HAVE THAT NO TWO LOTS OF NATIVES AGREE ON A NAME FOR ALMOST ANY PEAK.  THE TOP OF MORALES IS COVERED WITH GRASS, ON THE NW IS A THICK GROWTH OF VINES, AND ON THE HILL ARE A NUMBER OF LARGE MASSES OF GRANITE. ON THE SW SLOPE MORALES HAS A PLANTATION OF BANANAS AND SWEET POTATOES WHICH COMES ALMOST TO THE SUMMIT OF THE HILL.  JUST N OF THE SIGNAL THE HILL SLOPES STEEPLY DOWN INTO A PASS WHICH IS MUCH WIDER THAN THE PANDURA PASS.  THIS PASS IS BETWEEN MORALES AND HILLS WHICH SLOPE UP TO THE CONICAL (OR SUGAR LOAF HILL) RASPE PELA.  ABOUT 2 FEET E OF THE STATION MARK IS THE LARGEST STUMP ON THE HILLTOP.  STATION MARK IS A PIECE OF IRON PIPE, ALMOST 12 INCHES LONG AND 2 INCHES IN DIAMETER.  THIS IS CEMENTED IN THE GROUND AND FILLED WITH CEMENT.  A NAIL IN THE POLE ENTERED A HOLE IN THE CEMENT.  TO REACH THIS STATION FROM MAUNABO, TAKE THE ROAD WHICH PASSES BETWEEN THE NEW CENTRAL SUGAR WORKS AND THE MAUNABO RIVER AND FOLLOW ALONG THIS UP THE RIVER VALLEY.  IT SHORTLY BECOMES A TRAIL, FIT ONLY FOR FOOT AND HORSE TRAVELERS, AND SHOULD BE FOLLOWED UNTIL IT CROSSES THE RIVER AT A POINT WHICH IS ABOUT 80 FEET BELOW A GREAT REEF OF STONES OVER WHICH THE WATER FALLS. CONTINUE BEYOND THIS CROSSING TO THE NEXT SUMMIT WHERE THE TRAIL WINDS OVER A RIDGE.  HERE WILL BE NOTED THREE HOUSES, TWO ON THE RIGHT AND ONE ON THE LEFT, PROPERTY OF SERIN COLON.  AT THIS POINT LEAVE THE TRAIL AND FOLLOW THE PATH, GOING STEEPLY UP THE HILL TO THE RIGHT.  THIS WILL BRING ONE TO THE HOUSE OF DOMINGO MORALES, AND THE TRAIL WILL BE FOUND TO LEAD STRAIGHT UP TO THE SUMMIT OF MORALES HILL, WHICH IT CROSSES, (BETWEEN THE BOULDERS) A LITTLE TO THE RIGHT OF THE STATION MARK.  IN LOOKING FOR THIS SIGNAL A STRANGER MAY BE TAKEN BY MISTAKE TO THE SIGNAL CALLED RAMON WHICH IS BETWEEN 1/2 AND 5/8 OF A MILE E OF MORALES.  RAMON IS ON A SUMMIT OF VERY LIMITED GRASSY AREA WITH NO CULTIVATION ABOUT IT.  IT IS ALSO DEVOID OF THE BOULDERS WHICH ARE SO NOTABLE A FEATURE ON MORALES, BESIDES RAMON IS ON A LOWER SUMMIT.  IT WAS BUILT FIRST BUT THROWN OUT BECAUSE IT COULD NOT BE SEEN FROM HELENA.  RAMON IS ON PROPERTY WHICH BELONGS TO SENOR FLORES RAMON.  IT WAS MARKED JUST AS MORALES WAS MARKED.
markers.setting: SET INTO TOP OF METAL PIPE DRIVEN INTO GROUND
markers.stability: MARK OF QUESTIONABLE OR UNKNOWN STABILITY

markers.description: BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1934 ON A PROMINENT PEAK ABOUT 4.5 KILOMETERS NW OF JAYUYA, PROJECTING W OF A RIDGE THAT RUNS N-S, FORMING A SPUR FROM MAIN CHAIN OF MOUNTAINS, E OF COONILLO RIVER.  IT IS ON BO. PLANES OF JAYUYA AND IN THE LIMITS OF UTUADO, AND ON THE N LIMIT OF THE PROPERTY OF MIGUEL TORRES AND ON S LIMIT OF PROPERTY OF JOS. MIGUEL RUIZ.  STATION MARK IS A STANDARD U.S.G.S. BENCH MARK SET AND STAMPED MORALES 1934.  REFERENCE MARK NO.1 IS A STANDARD BENCH MARK TABLET CEMENTED ON NATURAL ROCK, 3.955 METERS, FROM STATION IN TRUE AZIMUTH 01 DEG 10 MIN.  REFERENCE MARK NO.2 IS A STANDARD BENCH MARK TABLET CEMENTED ON NATURAL ROCK, 6.537 METERS, FROM STATION IN TRUE AZIMUTH 226 DEG 18 MIN.  SIGNAL--QUADRIPOD WITH BLACK CROSS TARGETS AND WHITE FLAG CENTERED OVER STATION MARK.  TO REACH FROM K 18 H 3 OF ADJUNTAS-JAYUYA ROAD, TAKE LOS HORNOS MUNICIPAL ROAD 1.3 MILES TO STORE OF LUIS RIVERA, CONTINUE BY HORSE TRAIL DOWN AND N TO MIGUEL PONS FARM WHERE YOU CLIMB UP THE MOUNTAIN TO THE NE.  THE MOUNTAIN IS BARE ON THE VERY TOP, BUT WOODY ON THE E, N, AND S SIDES.  ITS W SIDE IS PRACTICALLY A VERTICAL WALL OF ROCKS.                            STATION RECOVERY (1966)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JJL) THE STATION AND ALL MARKS WERE RECOVERED AND FOUND IN GOOD CONDITION.  REFERENCE MARK A WAS ESTABLISHED.  A COMPLETE DESCRIPTION FOLLOWS--  THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 5 MILES EAST-SOUTHEAST OF UTUADO, 3-1/2 MILES NORTHWEST OF JAYUYA AND ON THE HIGHEST POINT OF A PROMINENT, BRUSH-COVERED MOUNTAIN THAT IS LOCALLY KNOWN AS CERRO MORALES.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE JUNCTION OF HIGHWAYS 141 AND 144 IN JAYUYA, GO EASTERLY ON HIGHWAY 141 FOR 3.5 MILES TO THE JUNCTION OF HIGHWAYS 141 AND 533.  BEAR LEFT AND GO NORTHERLY ON HIGHWAY 141 FOR 4.6 MILES TO A REVERSE Y-FORK ON THE LEFT.  (A FOUR-WHEEL DRIVE VEHICLE IS REQUIRED FROM THIS POINT.) TURN SHARP LEFT AND GO SOUTHWESTERLY FOR 1.5 MILES TO A T-INTERSECTION.  TURN LEFT AND GO SOUTH AND WEST FOR 1.0 MILE TO A Y-FORK.  TAKE THE LEFT FORK AND GO WESTERLY FOR 1.0 MILE TO A Y-FORK.  TAKE THE RIGHT FORK AND CONTINUE WESTERLY FOR 0.5 MILE TO A SCHOOL BUILDING ON THE RIGHT, NORTH, SIDE OF THE ROAD.  CONTINUE WEST AND NORTH FOR 0.9 MILE TO A 3-WAY FORK.  TAKE THE MIDDLE FORK AND GO NORTHWESTERLY FOR 0.9 MILE TO THE END OF TRUCK TRAVEL AT A GROUP OF THREE HOUSES AND A DIM SIDE ROAD RIGHT.  PACK SOUTHWEST ALONG A TRAIL FOR ABOUT 50 YARDS TO A DIM Y-FORK.  TAKE THE RIGHT FORK AND PACK SOUTHERLY ALONG THE TRAIL FOR ABOUT 1/2 MILE TO THE TOP OF A RIDGE.  BEAR RIGHT AND GO SOUTHWESTERLY ALONG THE RIDGE FOR ABOUT 1/4 MILE TO THE HIGHEST POINT OF THE MOUNTAIN AND THE STATION.  1 HOUR PACK.  THE STATION MARK, STAMPED CERRO MORALES 1934, IS A U.S. GEOLOGICAL SURVEY DISK CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN OUTCROPPING BEDROCK THAT PROJECTS 1 INCH.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 1, STAMPED NO 1, IS A U.S. GEOLOGICAL SURVEY DISK CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN OUTCROPPING BEDROCK THAT IS FLUSH ON THE SOUTH SIDE, PROJECTS 2 FEET ON THE NORTH SIDE AND IS ABOUT 2 FEET LOWER THAN THE STATION.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 2, STAMPED NO 2, IS A U.S. GEOLOGICAL SURVEY DISK CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN OUTCROPPING BEDROCK THAT IS FLUSH WITH THE GROUND AND IS ABOUT 3 FEET LOWER THAN THE STATION.  REFERENCE MARK A, STAMPED MORALES USGS RMA 1934 1966, IS A STANDARD DISK CEMENTED IN THE TOP OF A 3-INCH CAST IRON PIPE THAT PROJECTS 5 INCHES AND IS ABOUT 3 FEET LOWER THAN THE STATION.  AIRLINE DISTANCE AND DIRECTION FROM NEAREST TOWN 3-1/2 MILES NORTHWEST OF JAYUYA.
markers.setting: SET IN ROCK OUTCROP
markers.stability: MOST RELIABLE AND EXPECTED TO HOLDPOSITION/ELEVATION WELL

markers.description: BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1966 (JJL) THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 5 MILES EAST-SOUTHEAST OF UTUADO, 3-1/2 MILES NORTHWEST OF JAYUYA AND NEAR THE HIGHEST POINT OF A PROMINENT, BRUSH-COVERED MOUNTAIN THAT IS LOCALLY KNOWN AS CERRO MORALES.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE JUNCTION OF HIGHWAYS 141 AND 144 IN JAYUYA, GO EASTERLY ON HIGHWAY 141 FOR 3.5 MILES TO THE JUNCTION OF HIGHWAYS 141 AND 533.  BEAR LEFT AND GO NORTHERLY ON HIGHWAY 141 FOR 4.6 MILES TO A REVERSE Y-FORK ON THE LEFT.  (A FOUR-WHEEL DRIVE VEHICLE IS REQUIRED FROM THIS POINT.) TURN SHARP LEFT AND GO SOUTHWESTERLY FOR 1.5 MILES TO A T-INTERSECTION.  TURN LEFT AND GO SOUTH AND WEST FOR 1.0 MILE TO A Y-FORK.  TAKE THE LEFT FORK AND GO WESTERLY FOR 1.0 MILE TO A Y-FORK.  TAKE THE RIGHT FORK AND CONTINUE WESTERLY FOR 0.5 MILE TO A SCHOOL BUILDING ON THE RIGHT, NORTH, SIDE OF THE ROAD.  CONTINUE WEST AND NORTH FOR 0.9 MILE TO A 3-WAY FORK.  TAKE THE MIDDLE FORK AND GO NORTHWESTERLY FOR 0.9 MILE TO THE END OF TRUCK TRAVEL AT A GROUP OF THREE HOUSES AND A DIM SIDE ROAD RIGHT.  PACK SOUTHWEST ALONG A TRAIL FOR ABOUT 50 YARDS TO A DIM Y-FORK.  TAKE THE RIGHT FORK AND PACK SOUTHERLY ALONG THE TRAIL FOR ABOUT 1/2 MILE TO THE TOP OF A RIDGE.  BEAR RIGHT AND GO SOUTHWESTERLY ALONG THE RIDGE FOR ABOUT 1/4 MILE TO A POINT ABOUT 15 FEET NORTH OF THE HIGHEST POINT OF THE MOUNTAIN AND THE STATION.  A ONE HOUR PACK.  THE STATION MARK, STAMPED MORALES USGS RMA 1934 1966, IS A STANDARD DISK CEMENTED IN THE TOP OF A 3-INCH CAST IRON PIPE THAT PROJECTS 5 INCHES AND IS ABOUT 15 FEET NORTH AND 3 FEET LOWER THAN THE HIGHEST POINT OF THE MOUNTAIN.  MORALES (USGS) 1934, STAMPED CERRO MORALES 1934, IS A U.S. GEOLOGICAL SURVEY DISK CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN OUTCROPPING BEDROCK THAT PROJECTS 1 INCH AND IS ABOUT 3 FEET HIGHER THAN THE STATION.
markers.setting: SET INTO TOP OF METAL PIPE DRIVEN INTO GROUND
markers.stability: MARK OF QUESTIONABLE OR UNKNOWN STABILITY

markers.description: BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1934 A SQUARE RED TILE ROOFED TOWER AT WATER RESERVOIR ON HILL E OF MOROVIS.                            STATION RECOVERY (1941)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1941 (GBG) RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED.

BY US ARMY CORPS OF ENGINEERS 1965 (JJL) THE STATION MARK IS AN UNSTAMPED U.S. ARMY ENGINEERING DEPARTMENT DISK SET IN THE TOP OF A 12-INCH SQUARE CONCRETE MONUMENT THAT PROJECTS 2 INCHES.  USED 43 MORRO IS INSCRIBED IN THE CONCRETE MONUMENT.  THE MARK IS SET ON THE SOUTHWEST PARAPET OF THE CASTLE.
markers.setting: SET IN TOP OF CONCRETE MONUMENT
markers.stability: MAY HOLD, BUT OF TYPE COMMONLY SUBJECT TOSURFACE MOTION

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1899 (WCH) STATION IS ON THE SUMMIT OF MORRO CASTLE, ON TOP OF THE FIRST TRAVERSE TO THE NORTHWARD OF THE OLD SEMAPHORE TOWER.  MARKED BY AN IRON PIPE SET IN CEMENT.
markers.setting: UNSPECIFIED SETTING

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1900 (SF) STATION WAS MARKED BY A BRICK PIER, HOLLOW AND COVERED WITH CEMENT, 2 FEET 7 INCHES HIGH, WITH A STANDARD BRASS DISK SET IN THE S FACE OF THE PIER.  THE PIER HAS A TRIANGULAR HOLE THROUGH ITS CENTER, THROUGH WHICH YOU CAN PLUMB THE INSTRUMENT OVER THE SURFACE MARK.  THE SURFACE STATION MARK IS A MARBLE SLAB WITH TRIANGLE CUT IN THE TOP AND COPPER BOLT 1/2 INCH SQUARE LET INTO THE MARBLE SLAB, PUNCH HOLE ON COPPER BOLT MARKED ON CENTER OF THE STATION.  THIS SLAB IS SET INTO THE CEMENT FLOOR EVEN WITH THE SURFACE OF THE CEMENT FLOOR.                            STATION RECOVERY (1902)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1902 (JN) STATION RECOVERED.  A SCAFFOLD AND TRIPOD SIGNAL OF 20 FEET WAS NECESSARY HERE TO CLEAR LINE OF SIGHT TO LATIMER.  THIS SIGNAL WAS REMOVED ON THE COMPLETION OF THE OBSERVATIONS.
markers.setting: UNSPECIFIED SETTING

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1965 (JJL) THE STATION WAS RECOVERED AND FOUND IN GOOD CONDITION.  DISTANCES AND DIRECTIONS WERE OBTAINED TO MORRO (USED) AND PETE (USAF) 1964 AND THEY WERE USED FOR REFERENCE MARKS.  THIS STATION WAS LOCATED IN 1964 BUT WAS NOT DESCRIBED.  A COMPLETE DESCRIPTION FOLLOWS--  NOTE--BEFORE VISITING THE STATION PERMISSION MUST BE OBTAINED FROM THE U.S. NATIONAL PARK SERVICE AND THE U.S. COAST GUARD.  THE STATION IS LOCATED IN SAN JUAN, WITHIN THE BOUNDRIES OF FORT BROOKE AND ON THE CONCRETE WALK AROUND MORRO LIGHTHOUSE.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE ENTRANCE TO FORT BROOKE IN SAN JUAN, GO WESTERLY FOR 0.1 MILE THENCE BEAR RIGHT AND GO NORTHERLY FOR 0.2 MILE TO THE ENTRANCE TO MORRO CASTLE.  (OBTAIN THE KEY TO THE LIGHTHOUSE FROM THE U.S. ARMED FORCES RADIO STATION LOCATED BENEATH THE RAMP LEADING TO THE CASTLE.) CONTINUE NORTHERLY FOR ABOUT 100 YARDS, THENCE TURN RIGHT AND GO EASTERLY FOR ABOUT 200 YARDS TO THE LIGHTHOUSE.  (PERMISSION TO DRIVE A VEHICLE TO THE LIGHTHOUSE MAY BE OBTAINED FROM THE U.S. NATIONAL PARK SERVICE.)  THE STATION MARK, STAMPED MORRO LH ECC 1953, IS A U.S. CORPS OF ENGINEERS DISK CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN THE CONCRETE WALK AROUND THE LIGHTHOUSE.  IT IS 2 FEET NORTH OF THE SOUTH EDGE OF THE CONCRETE WALK.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 1 IS AN UNSTAMPED U.S. ARMY ENGINEERING DEPARTMENT DISK SET IN THE TOP OF A 12-INCH SQUARE CONCRETE MONUMENT THAT PROJECTS 2 INCHES.  USED 43 MORRO IS INSCRIBED IN THE CONCRETE MONUMENT.  THE MARK IS SET ON THE SOUTHWEST PARAPET OF THE CASTLE.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 2, STAMPED PETE USAF, IS A U.S. AIR FORCE SHORAN STATION DISK CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN THE NORTHEAST PARAPET OF THE CASTLE.  IT IS 27 FEET NORTHWEST OF A FLAGPOLE.  AIRLINE DISTANCE AND DIRECTION FROM NEAREST TOWN IN SAN JUAN.                            STATION RECOVERY (1977)  RECOVERY NOTE BY LOCAL ENGINEER (INDIVIDUAL OR FIRM) 1977 (MS) MORRO LH ECC 1953 RECOVERED GOOD.  CONTACT US COAST GUARD FOR KEY, AND US PARK SERVICE FOR PERMISSION TO DO NIGHT WORK.  DISTANCE AND DIRECTION FROM NEAREST TOWN--1 KM W. OF OLD SAN JUAN.
markers.setting: SET IN A PAVEMENT SUCH AS STREET, SIDEWALK, CURB, ETC.
markers.stability: MARK OF QUESTIONABLE OR UNKNOWN STABILITY

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1927 (GCM) STATION WAS OCCUPIED ECCENTRICALLY, AND THERE HAS BEEN NO CHANGE IN THE LIGHTHOUSE.                            STATION RECOVERY (1934)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1934 STATION WAS OCCUPIED ECCENTRICALLY, AND THERE HAD BEEN NO CHANGE IN THE LIGHTHOUSE.                            STATION RECOVERY (1942)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1942 (GBG) RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED.  CENTER OF LIGHT OR CENTER OF BLACK CUPOLA OF THIS LIGHTHOUSE.                            STATION RECOVERY (1965)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1965 (JJL) THE STATION WAS RECOVERED AND FOUND IN GOOD CONDITION.  A NEW STATION HAS BEEN ESTABLISHED IN THE NEAR VICINITY.  SEE THE DESCRIPTION FOR STATION MORRO LIGHTHOUSE ECC (USE) 1964.                            STATION RECOVERY (1966)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (DCW) STATION RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED.                            STATION RECOVERY (1977)  RECOVERY NOTE BY LOCAL ENGINEER (INDIVIDUAL OR FIRM) 1977 (MS) AS DESCRIBED.  DISTANCE AND DIRECTION FROM NEAREST TOWN--1 KM WEST OF OLD SAN JUAN.

BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1900 (WCH) STATION IS ON A LOW POINT ON THE N COAST OF VIEQUES, BETWEEN PORT MULA AND POINT ARENAS AND NEARLY ABREAST OF THE MOSQUITO REEF.  MARKED AS USUAL.  TRIPOD SIGNAL.                            STATION RECOVERY (1902)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1902 (RFL) STATION RECOVERED.  THIS STATION IS IN BAD CONDITION.  CENTER ROCK WITH PIPE MARKING STATION HAS BEEN REMOVED AND THEN REPLACED IN SAME PLACE AS BEFORE.  STATION IS ON A LITTLE ROCKY BLUFF, 18 FEET HIGH AND 7 METERS FROM EDGE OF THE PERPENDICULAR BLUFF.                            STATION RECOVERY (1922)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1922 (FTS) THIS STATION WAS NOT RECOVERED.  A SHACK IS BUILT PRACTICALLY OVER FORMER LOCATION OF STATION.  NO EVIDENCE OF STATION FOUND.

BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1941 (RLS) STATION IS ABOUT 0.85 MILE E OF CEIBA, ABOUT 560 METERS ESE OF THE AMERICAN RAILROAD TRACK, ABOUT 450 METERS WSW OF THE MOST WESTERLY POINT OF THE BEACH ON THE W SIDE OF PORT MEDIO MUNDO, ON A LOCALLY-PROMINENT, LOW-ROUNDED KNOLL IN THE NEARLY FLAT AREA BETWEEN THE RAILROAD AND THE BEACH, 65.6 METERS W OF A FENCE, ON THE HIGHEST POINT OF THE KNOLL, AND PROJECTS 6 INCHES ABOVE GROUND.  THE ELEVATION OF THE STATION IS ABOUT 23.3 METERS.  STATION AND REFERENCE MARKS ARE STANDARD BRONZE DISKS SET IN CONCRETE, AS DESCRIBED IN NOTES 1A AND 11A.  THERE IS NO UNDERGROUND MARK.  REFERENCE MARK NO.1 IS ON THE E SLOPE OF THE HILL, 1.89 METERS LOWER THAN THE STATION, AND PROJECTS 8 INCHES ABOVE GROUND.  REFERENCE MARK NO.2 IS ON THE N SLOPE OF THE HILL, 47.7 METERS ESE OF REFERENCE MARK NO.1, 2.08 METERS LOWER THAN THE STATION, AND PROJECTS 6 INCHES ABOVE GROUND.                            STATION RECOVERY (1958)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1958 (RWS) STATION AND REFERENCE MARKS WERE RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION AS DESCRIBED, EXCEPT THERE IS NOW AN ANTENNA 10.14 METERS FROM THE STATION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1961)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1961 (HLO) STATION RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED.  THE STATION IS 9.5 METERS SW OF A RADIO TOWER, AND 7.3 METERS W OF THE CENTERLINE OF A LARGE DITCH LEADING TO THE TOWER FROM THE SOUTH.  A STEEL PIPE TRIPOD AND CENTERPOLE IS CENTERED OVER THE STATION.  R. M. NO. 1 WAS SEARCHED FOR BUT NOT RECOVERED.  R. M. NO. 2 WAS FOUND, STILL IMBEDDED IN ITS MONUMENT, LAYING LOOSE ABOUT 30 METERS FROM THE STATION AND IS THUS DESTROYED.                            STATION RECOVERY (1964)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1964 (GWM) STATION RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED, BUT A NEW DESCRIPTION WOULD BE MORE ADEQUATE.  STATION IS ON THE ROOSEVELT ROADS NAVAL RESERVATION ON THE FIRST KNOLL NE OF THE NE CORNER OF THE NE-SW RUNWAY, 26 FT. SW OF THE SW LEG OF THE RADIO TOWER, 17.5 FT. W OF THE W END OF THE CONCRETE RETAINING WALL AND ENTRANCE WAY TO THE RADIO CONTROL TOWER BUILDING, NO. 224.  IT IS A STANDARD TRIANGULATION DISC STAMPED, MOUND 1941, SET IN A CONCRETE POST PROJECTING 5 INCHES ABOVE THE GROUND.  THERE IS NO UNDERGROUND MARK.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 1 AND NO. 2 WERE SEARCHED FOR BUT WERE NOT FOUND.  TO REACH FROM THE JUNCTION OF THE NE-SW RUNWAY AND THE BOUNDARY ROAD, GO NORTH 0.6 MILE TO A SIDE ROAD RIGHT, TURN RIGHT AND GO 0.1 MILE TO THE RADIO TOWER AND STATION ON LEFT.  A METAL PIPE TRIPOD HAS BEEN PLACED OVER THE MARK.                            STATION RECOVERY (1966)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JJL) THE STATION MARK WAS RECOVERED AND FOUND IN GOOD CONDITION.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 1 AND NO. 2 WERE SEARCHED FOR BUT NOT FOUND.  TWO NEW REFERENCE MARKS NO. 3 AND NO. 4 WERE ESTABLISHED AT THIS TIME.  A NEW DESCRIPTION FOLLOWS--  THE STATION IS LOCATED ON ROOSEVELT ROADS NAVAL RESERVATION.  IT IS ABOUT 1 MILE EAST OF CEIBA AND 1/2 MILE NORTHWEST OF THE NORTHEAST END OF THE MAIN RUNWAY.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE JUNCTION OF THE NORTHEAST-SOUTHWEST RUNWAY AND THE BOUNDARY ROAD, GO NORTH ON THE BOUNDARY ROAD FOR 0.6 MILE TO A SIDE ROAD ON THE RIGHT, TURN RIGHT AND GO 0.1 MILE TO BUILDING NO. 224 ON THE LEFT AND THE STATION ON TOP OF THIS BUILDING.  THE STATION MARK IS 17.6 FEET WEST OF A METAL VENT PIPE, 26 FEET SOUTHWEST OF THE SOUTHWEST LEG OF A RADIO TOWER AND UNDER A TRIANGULAR PIPE SURVEY TARGET.  IT IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED MOUND 1941, SET IN A SQUARE CONCRETE MONUMENT PROJECTING 6 INCHES.  NOTE--1A  REFERENCE MARK NO. 3 IS 7 FEET SOUTHEAST OF A METAL VENT PIPE.  IT IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED MOUND NO 3 1941, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN THE HEADWALL OF BUILDING NO. 224.  NOTE--DESC.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 4 IS 24.6 FEET SOUTHWEST OF A METAL VENT PIPE.  IT IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED MOUND NO 4 1941, CEMENTED IN THE TOP OF A 3 INCH SOIL PIPE PROJECTING 6 INCHES.  NOTE--DESC.  HEIGHT OF LIGHT ABOVE STATION MARK 4 FEET.  AIRLINE DISTANCE AND DIRECTION FROM NEAREST TOWN 1 MILE EAST OF CEIBA.
markers.setting: SET IN TOP OF CONCRETE MONUMENT
markers.stability: MAY HOLD, BUT OF TYPE COMMONLY SUBJECT TOSURFACE MOTION

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1900 (WCH) THE STATION IS ON THE SUMMIT OF THE PEAK OF THAT NAME, THE HIGHEST POINT OF VIEQUES ISLAND.  IT IS ON THE ESTATE OF SENOR BENITEZ WHO LIVES NE OF THE MOUNTAIN.  THE HILL IS QUITE STEEP AND ROUGH AND IS WOODED AT THE SUMMIT.  MARKED AS USUAL, THAT IS, IRON PIPE SET IN CONCRETE.  TRIPOD SIGNAL, 30-FOOT LEGS.                            STATION RECOVERY (1901)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1901 (SF) STATION RECOVERED.                            STATION RECOVERY (1941)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1941 (RLS) STATION IS LOST.  NO TRACE OF THE OLD MARK COULD BE FOUND EXCEPT SMALL SCATTERED BROKEN PIECES OF CONCRETE.  A NEW STATION, MOUNT PIRATA 2, WAS ESTABLISHED ON TOP OF THE SAME MOUNTAIN.
markers.setting: UNSPECIFIED SETTING

markers.description: BY ANDREGG INCORPORATED 1995 (MJB) TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE JUNCTION OF HIGHWAYS PR 3 AND PR 191 NEAR THE TOWN OF PALMER, GO SOUTH ON HIGHWAY PR 191 INTO THE CARIBBEAN NATIONAL FOREST AND EL YUNQUE MOUNTAIN ABOUT 12 KILOMETERS (7.45 MI) TO THE YOKAHU OBSERVATION TOWER.  CONTINUE ALONG HIGHWAY PR 191 THROUGH THE NATIONAL FOREST ABOUT 5 KILOMETERS (3.10 MI) TO A FORK IN THE ROAD AND A LOCKED GATE ON THE LEFT FORK.  ACCESS TO LOCKED GATE MAY BE OBTAINED THROUGH THE DISTRICT RANGER, CARIBBEAN NATIONAL FOREST, PR, PHONE (809) 766-5335.  TAKE THE LEFT FORK, AVIARY ROAD, ABOUT 2 KILOMETERS (1.25 MI) TO THE SECOND OF TWO WOODEN SIGNS INDICATING MOUNT BRITTON.  PARK VEHICLE AT THE SECOND SIGN AND PACK SOUTHERLY ABOUT 100 METERS (328.1 FT) ALONG A RIDGE LINE TO A CONCRETE AND STONE TOWER ON THE SITE OF MOUNT BRITTON  THE STATION IS AT THE TOP OF THE TOWER ATOP MOUNT BRITTON.  THE STATION IS A STANDARD USCGS CAP STAMPED MT.  BRITTON TOWER 1941 3088.0, CEMENTED TO THE TOP OF THE FLOOR OF THE TOWER.  THE TABLET IS SOLID THOUGH THE MARKINGS ARE WORN FROM FOOT TRAFFIC                            STATION RECOVERY (2011)  RECOVERY NOTE BY POLYTECHNIC UNIVERSITY OF PUERTO RICO 2011 (GDO) DESCRIPTION IS ADEQUATE                            STATION RECOVERY (2012)  RECOVERY NOTE BY POLYTECHNIC UNIVERSITY OF PUERTO RICO 2012 (REC) RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED                              STATION RECOVERY (2019)  RECOVERY NOTE BY GEOCACHING 2019 (CDH) RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.
markers.setting: SET IN A LARGE STRUCTURE WITH DEEP FOUNDATIONS
markers.stability: MOST RELIABLE AND EXPECTED TO HOLDPOSITION/ELEVATION WELL

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1941 (RLS) ON VIEQUES ISLAND, ON TOP OF MOUNT PIRATA WHICH IS THE MOST WESTERLY AND HIGHEST MOUNTAIN ON THE ISLAND, ON THE TIO (FORMERLY BENITEZ) ESTATE, NEAR THE NW END OF A SHORT RIDGE ON TOP OF THE HILL, IN A GROVE OF BANANA TREES IN AN AREA CLEARED OF NATURAL GROWTH ON THE W SIDE OF THE TOP OF THE HILL, ABOUT 8 METERS W OF THE W EDGE OF THE THICK JUNGLE GROWTH, AND PROJECTS ABOUT 12 INCHES ABOVE GROUND.  THE STATION WAS ORIGINALLY MARKED BY THE U.S. NAVY AND WAS A 1-INCH DIAMETER IRON PIPE SET IN CONCRETE. THE MARK WAS BUILT UP WITH CONCRETE AND A STANDARD DISK PLACED IN TOP WITH THE SHANK OF THE DISK INSIDE THE PIPE.  THE DISK IS A STAMPED MT. PIRATA 2 1941.  NO UNDERGROUND MARK WAS SET.  REFERENCE MARK NO.1 IS ON THE SW SLOPE OF THE HILL, 1.20 METERS LOWER THAN THE STATION, AND IS A STANDARD DISK SET IN CONCRETE IN A DEPRESSION ON TOP OF A SMALL BOULDER ABOUT FLUSH WITH THE GROUND.  REFERENCE MARK NO.2 IS ON THE N SLOPE OF THE HILL, IN A CORN FIELD ON THE N SIDE OF THE BANANA GROVE, 4.03 METERS LOWER THAN THE STATION, AND IS A STANDARD DISK SET IN CONCRETE IN A DEPRESSION ON TOP OF A BOULDER PROJECTING ABOUT 12 INCHES ABOVE GROUND.  THE WITNESS MARK A TRIANGULAR BLAZE IS IN THE THICK JUNGLE GROWTH ON THE EASTERLY PART OF THE TOP OF THE HILL, ON THE CREST OF THE RIDGE, ON THE W SIDE OF AN 8-INCH COLCHO TREE ABOUT 1 FOOT ABOVE GROUND.  THERE IS ANOTHER LARGE BLAZE ON THE TREE ABOVE THE TRIANGLE.                            STATION RECOVERY (1964)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US MARINE CORPS 1964 STATION MARK, A STANDARD DISK STAMPED MT PIRATA 2 WAS FOUND IN GOOD CONDITION.  THE REFERENCE MARK WAS NOT FOUND.  LOCATED IN A CLEARING COVERED BY VERY HIGH GRASS AND IS NEAR A WOODED AREA ON THE WEST SIDE OF CLEARING.                            STATION RECOVERY (1966)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JJL) THE STATION MARK AND REFERENCE MARK 1 WERE FOUND AND IN GOOD CONDITION.  REFERENCE MARK 2 WAS NOT FOUND.  A SLIGHT DIFFERENCE WAS FOUND IN THE DISTANCE BETWEEN THE STATION MARK AND REFERENCE MARK 1.  THE STATION MARK WAS DESTROYED AND MT PIRATA 3 WAS ESTABLISHED AT THIS DATE, DUE TO THE PROPOSED CONSTRUCTION OF A MICRO-WAVE RELAY SITE NEAR MT PIRATA 2 1941.                            STATION RECOVERY (1970)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US MARINE CORPS 1970 STATION COULD NOT BE LOCATED AND PRESUMED DESTROYED.  R.M. NO. 1 WAS FOUND APPROXIMATELY 15 METERS WEST OF MICROWAVE TOWER.  AN IRON PIPE THAT WAS ONCE SET IN CONCRETE WAS FOUND LAYING NEAR THE TOWER AND MUCH EARTH MOVING HAS BEEN DONE IN THE AREA.
markers.setting: SET INTO TOP OF METAL PIPE DRIVEN INTO GROUND
markers.stability: MARK OF QUESTIONABLE OR UNKNOWN STABILITY

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JJL) THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 1-1/2 MILES WEST-SOUTHWEST OF THE NAD NAVAL BARRACKS AND ON THE TOP OF MOUNT PIRATA WHICH IS THE MOST WESTERN AND THE HIGHEST MOUNTAIN ON VIEQUES ISLAND.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE NAD NAVAL BARRACKS, GO NORTH FOR 0.1 MILE TO A CROSSROADS.  TURN LEFT, GO WEST ON A GRAVELED ROAD FOR 0.15 MILE TO A FORK.  TAKE THE LEFT FORK AND GO SOUTHWEST FOR 0.4 MILE TO A T INTERSECTION.  TURN LEFT, GO SOUTHEAST FOR 0.2 MILE TO A FORK.  TAKE THE RIGHT FORK, GO SOUTHWEST FOR 0.4 MILE TO A T INTERSECTION.  TURN LEFT, GO SOUTHERLY FOR 0.3 MILE TO A T INTERSECTION.  TURN RIGHT, GO WEST AND NORTH FOR 0.25 MILE TO A SIDE ROAD LEFT.  TURN LEFT, FOLLOW A MOUNTAIN ROAD WEST AND SOUTH FOR 1.4 MILES TO THE TOP OF THE MOUNTAIN AND THE STATION.  THE STATION MARK IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED MT PIRATA 3 1966, BRAZED TO THE TOP OF A 3-INCH CAST IRON PIPE THAT PROJECTS 6 INCHES AND IS 2 FEET LOWER THAN THE HIGHEST POINT OF THE HILL.  IT IS 5 FEET SOUTH OF THE NORTH EDGE OF A LEVELED OFF AREA AND JUST NORTH OF THE PROPOSED FENCE ENCLOSURE OF A MICRO-WAVE SITE.  REFERENCE MARK 1 IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED MT PIRATA 2 NO 1 1941, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A BOULDER THAT IS ON THE HIGHEST POINT OF THE HILL AND IS FLUSH WITH THE GROUND.  IT IS 2 FEET HIGHER IN ELEVATION THAN THE STATION MARK AND JUST WEST OF THE PROPOSED FENCE ENCLOSURE OF A MICRO-WAVE SITE.  REFERENCE MARK 3 IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED MT PIRATA 3 NO 3 1966, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A BOULDER THAT PROJECTS 1 FOOT.  IT IS ON THE NORTHWEST SLOPE OF THE HILL AND 3 FEET LOWER IN ELEVATION THAN THE STATION MARK.                            STATION RECOVERY (1978)  RECOVERY NOTE BY DEFENSE MAP AGENCY 1978 (EAW) NOT STAMPED MARK DESTROYED, IRON PIPE IS BENT AND MANGLED.  OLD MARK FOUND BUT DESTROYED.  IRON PIPE WAS FOUND BUT NO DISK.  NO REFERENCE MARKS WERE FOUND.  STATION MT PIRATA 4 WAS ESTABLISHED AT THIS TIME.  SEE DESCRIPTION THEREOF.
markers.setting: SET INTO TOP OF METAL PIPE DRIVEN INTO GROUND
markers.stability: MARK OF QUESTIONABLE OR UNKNOWN STABILITY

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1926 (GCM) LIGHTHOUSE UNCHANGED.                            STATION RECOVERY (1934)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1934 THIS STATION IS THE CENTER OF THE LIGHT ON MUERTOS LIGHTHOUSE WHICH IS SITUATED ON MUERTOS ISLAND, ABOUT 8 MILES E OF THE ENTRANCE TO PONCE HARBOR, S COAST OF PUERTO RICO.                            STATION RECOVERY (1970)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1970 (JKW) STATION WAS RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.  THE LIGHTHOUSE WAS VISITED AND IS NOW OPERATED WITH AN AUTOMATIC LIGHT.  CONDITION OF STRUCTURE IS GOOD.                            STATION RECOVERY (1971)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1971 (EKM) STATION WAS RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.  THE KEY TO THE LIGHTHOUSE IS IN THE CUSTODY OF U.S. COAST GUARD LIGHT STATION PERSONNEL IN PLAYA DE PONCE.  THE ROAD FROM THE LANDING SITE ON THE WESTERN SIDE OF THE ISLAND TO THE LIGHTHOUSE HAS DETERIORATED BADLY AND IT IS DOUBTFUL IF ANY VEHICULAR TRAFFIC IS POSSIBLE.                            STATION RECOVERY (1975)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1975 (RMB) THE STATION WAS RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED.                            STATION RECOVERY (1982)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1982 (JCL) THE STATION, MUERTOS ISLAND LIGHTHOUSE, WAS RECOVERED AS PREVIOUSLY DESCRIBED.

BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1926 (GCM) STATION IS ON THE TOP OF A HILL ON POINT PUERCA, 3/4 MILE NNW OF THE SOUTHERNMOST TIP OF THE POINT.  THE HILL IS COVERED WITH SHORT GRASS, USED AS PASTURAGE FOR CATTLE AND GOATS.  AT THE SUMMIT ARE SEVERAL LARGE BOULDERS IN A BARBED WIRE ENCLOSURE.  THE STATION IS IN A SLIGHT HOLLOW IN THE TOP OF ONE OF THESE BOULDERS AND IS MARKED BY A TRIANGLE CUT IN CEMENT.  THE BOULDER IS THE ONE BEST ADOPTED TO THE SETTING UP OF AN INSTRUMENT.  THE BOULDER WAS WHITEWASHED AND A POLE WITH STONES PILED AROUND IT WAS PLACED OVER THE STATION TO FACILITATE OBSERVATION.  THE 2 REFERENCE MARKS ARE CROSSES CHISELED IN THE TOPS OF OTHER BOULDERS.  A PATH LEADS UP INTO THE PASTURE FROM THE BEACH ON THE N SIDE.                            STATION RECOVERY (1941)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1941 (RLS) STATION AND REFERENCE MARKS RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION AS DESCRIBED.  ABOUT 3-3/4 MILES SE OF CEIBA, ON THE ROOSEVELT ROADS NAVAL RESERVATION, ON POINT PUERCA, ON TOP OF THE THIRD CREST FROM THE W END OF THE POINT (THE SECOND CREST IS ABOUT 20 FEET HIGHER THAN THE ONE ON WHICH THE STATION IS LOCATED).  THE STATION IS ON TOP OF A BOULDER ABOUT 3 FEET HIGH AND IS ONE OF SEVERAL LARGE BOULDERS ON TOP OF THE HILL.                            STATION RECOVERY (1958)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1958 (RWS) STATION AND REFERENCE MARK 1 WERE RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED.  REFERENCE MARK 2 PROBABLY DESTROYED DURING CONSTRUCTION OF BUNKERS DURING WORLD WAR II.                            STATION RECOVERY (1961)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1961 (MLO) STATION RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED.  A STEEL PIPE TRIPOD AND CENTERPOLE IS ROUGHLY CENTERED OVER THE STATION.  R.M. NO. 1 RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED.  R.M. NO. 2 WAS SEARCHED FOR BUT NOT RECOVERED.  IT WAS PROBABLY DESTROYED WHEN SOME CONCRETE GUN MOUNTS WERE CONSTRUCTED APPROXIMATELY 10 METERS NW OF THE STATION.

THE SIGNAL STANDS BETWEEN AND S OF THE TWO SMALL SHACKS OR HOUSES.  IT IS MARKED BY A CEMENT BLOCK 6 BY 6 BY 18 INCHES, WITH A NAIL IN THE CENTER.  DISTANCES--FROM STATION TO SE CORNER OF HOUSE IS 47 FEET W.  FROM STATION TO SW CORNER OF HOUSE IS 24.3 FEET E.                            STATION RECOVERY (1902)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1902 (RLF) STATION FOUND AS DESCRIBED IN GOOD CONDITION.  DESCRIPTION ADEQUATE.                            STATION RECOVERY (1961)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1961 (MLO) STATION SEARCHED FOR BUT NOT RECOVERED.

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1922 (FTS) STATION IS LOCATED ON THE HILL NEAR S END OF RAMOS CAY, 1-1/2 MILES SE OF THE PLAYA DE FAJARDO AND E OF RED BLUFF.  IT IS SE OF THE HIGHEST POINT AND ABOUT A FOOT LOWER IN ELEVATION.  STATION IS MARKED WITH A STANDARD DISK SET IN THE TOP OF A MASS OF CONCRETE SURROUNDED BY ROCKS, THE WHOLE FLUSH WITH THE GROUND SURFACE.  THE TWO REFERENCE MARKS ARE STANDARD DISKS SET IN SIMILAR CONCRETE MASSES PROJECTING 4 INCHES ABOVE THE SURFACE.  REFERENCE MARK NO.1 IS IN RANGE WITH THE E TANGENT OF CABEZA DE PERRO.  REFERENCE MARK NO.2 IS IN RANGE WITH THE S TANGENT OF PALOMINOS ISLAND, FROM THE STATION.  REFERENCE MARK NO.1 IS 39.6 FEET SOUTHERLY FROM STATION.  REFERENCE MARK NO.2 IS 50.3 FEET EASTERLY FROM STATION.  SE CORNER SHACK IS 36.3 FEET WESTERLY FROM STATION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1940)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1940 STATION MARK, A STANDARD DISK, UNSTAMPED, WAS FOUND ON THE TOP OF A HIGH HILL ON CAYO RAMOS.  IT IS ABOUT 40 FEET E OF A SMALL SHACK.  THE MASS OF CONCRETE AND ROCK MENTIONED IN THE ORIGINAL DESCRIPTION NOW PROJECTS ABOUT 10 INCHES ABOVE GROUND.  REFERENCE MARKS WERE NOT SEARCHED FOR.  STATION MARK APPEARS TO BE IN GOOD CONDITION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1941)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1941 (RLS) STATION AND REFERENCE MARKS RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION AS DESCRIBED IN THE 1922 DESCRIPTION EXCEPT FOR THE DISTANCES AND DIRECTIONS TO THE REFERENCE MARKS.  THE STATION IS ABOUT 1-1/2 MILES SE OF PLAYA DE FAJARDO, ON RAMOS CAY, NEAR THE S END OF THE ISLAND, ON THE HIGHEST POINT OF THE ISLAND, NEAR THE NE END OF THE FLAT TOP OF THE HILL, 55.0 FEET ENE OF THE E CORNER OF A SMALL HOUSE, AND NEAR THE BREAK IN THE SLOPE ON THE SE SIDE OF THE HILL.  THE STATION IS MARKED BY A STANDARD DISK IN A MASS OF CONCRETE AND SURROUNDED BY ROCKS.  THE MARK PROJECTS 5 INCHES ABOVE THE GROUND.  THE DESCRIPTION DESCRIBES THE REFERENCE MARKS AS FOLLOWS--NO.1, 39.6 FEET FROM THE STATION IN RANGE WITH THE E TANGENT OF CABEZA DE PERRO (APPROXIMATE AZIMUTH 332 DEG 37 MIN).  NO.2, 50.3 FEET FROM THE STATION IN RANGE WITH THE S TANGENT OF PALOMINOS ISLAND (APPROXIMATE AZIMUTH 231 DEG 32 MIN).  THE REFERENCE MARKS AS RECOVERED ARE DESCRIBED AS FOLLOWS--NO.1 IS 70.22 FEET FROM THE STATION, ON THE SLOPE OF THE HILL, ABOUT 10 FEET LOWER THAN THE STATION, AND 10 FEET NE OF A LONE TREE ON THE SLOPE OF THE HILL.  NO.2 IS 69.75 FEET FROM THE STATION, ON THE NW SLOPE OF A RIDGE SLOPING NORTHEASTWARD FROM THE STATION.  BOTH REFERENCE MARKS ARE STANDARD DISKS IN CONCRETE AND PROJECT 4 INCHES.                            STATION RECOVERY (1961)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1961 (MLO) STATION AND REFERENCE MARKS HAVE BEEN DESTROYED.  A MASS OF CONCRETE ABOUT TWO FEET IN DIAMETER WAS FOUND LAYING LOOSE IN A DEPRESSION NEAR THE TOP OF THE HILL ON RAMOS ISLAND.  A 1 1/2-INCH DRILL HOLE WAS FOUND IN THE MASS OF CONCRETE.  THIS APPEARED TO HAVE BEEN THE CONCRETE MONUMENT IN WHICH MURPHY 2 WAS SET.  A CONCRETE MONUMENT (CRACKED NEAR THE CENTER), 70.0 FEET FROM THE SUPPOSED STATION, AND ABOUT 10 FEET LOWER, WAS FOUND WITH UNSTAMPED REFERENCE MARK LAYING NEARBY.  THIS WAS BELIEVED TO HAVE BEEN R. M. NO. 1.  A THIRD CONCRETE MONUMENT (BROKEN OFF AND LEANING), 69.5 FEET FROM THE SUPPOSED STATION, WAS FOUND WITH UNSTAMPED REFERENCE MARK LAYING NEARBY.  THIS WAS BELIEVED TO HAVE BEEN R. M. NO. 2.                            STATION RECOVERY (1964)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1964 (GWM) THIS STATION WAS VISITED AND THE UNMARKED STATION MARK WAS FOUND LOOSE IN THE CONCRETE BASE.  THE UNMARKED DISK WAS DAMAGED SO IT WAS REMOVED.  THERE REMAINS A ONE INCH DIAMETER HOLE IN THE BASE.  THE REFERENCE MARKS NO. 1 AND NO. 2 WERE NOT RECOVERED.  THE DESCRIPTION IS ADEQUATE FOR FINDING THE CONCRETE BASE.  NO NEW R.M.S WERE ESTABLISHED.
markers.setting: OBJECT SURROUNDED BY MASS OF CONCRETE
markers.stability: MARK OF QUESTIONABLE OR UNKNOWN STABILITY

markers.description: BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1941 (RLS) THIS IS AN INTERSECTION STATION.  ABOUT 1 MILE NW OF NAGUABO, ON A WOODED HILL. THE STATION WAS SET BY A PARTY OF THE U.S. GEOLOGICAL SURVEY IN 1941 AND LOCATED BY A 3-POINT FIX FOR AIR PHOTO CONTROL, AND A SIGNAL WAS ERECTED OVER THE STATION BY THE U.S. GEOLOGICAL SURVEY. markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1900 (JBB) STATION IS ON THE FIRST HIGH HILL BACK FROM THE POINT OF THE SAME NAME.  THE BLUFF BETWEEN MANGROVE HARBOR AND THE SOUND, ON THE EASTERN EXTREMITY OF THE ISLAND OF CULEBRA.  A TRIPOD SIGNAL WAS ERECTED AT THIS STATION, ITS LOCATION BEING DETERMINED BY TRIANGULATION.  THE STATION WAS MARKED BY A TACK DRIVEN IN A WOODEN PLUG SET IN THE GROUND.                            STATION RECOVERY (1900)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1900 (WCH) SIGNAL PUT UP BY ASSISTANT BOUTELLE ON THE SLOPING HILL SIDE ON N SIDE OF MANGROVE HARBOR, CULEBRA ISLAND.  MARKED BY MY PARTY IN THE USUAL MANNER.                            STATION RECOVERY (1904)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1904 (RLF) RECOVERED.  MARKED WITH PIPE IN CEMENT.  A SMALL PILE OF STONES SURROUNDS THE 1 1/2-INCH IRON PIPE WHICH PROJECTS ABOUT 5 INCHES ABOVE GROUND.  THE STATION IS ON THE TOP OF THE HILL AT POINT NEGRA AND 300 METERS BACK (TO NW) FROM THE END OF THE POINT, AND 160 METERS FROM THE SHORE LINE ON THE MANGROVE HARBOR SIDE.  STATION IS ON THE NE SIDE OF MANGROVE HARBOR.  THE TOP OF THE HILL IS WOODED.  THE NW SIDE IS CLEAR AND COVERED WITH BERMUDA GRASS.  THE STATION IS MOST EASILY REACHED FROM THE MANGROVE HARBOR SIDE AND GOING UP THE OPEN SIDE OF THE HILL.  THE STATION MARK IS IN GOOD CONDITION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1965)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1965 (MTP) THE STATION WAS RECOVERED.  THE TRIANGULATION STATION IS SITUATED ON TOP OF A 100 FT. KNOLL, APPROXIMATELY 1200 FT. NORTHWEST FROM NEGRA PT. AND 550 FT. NORTH FROM MANGROVE HARBORS NORTH SHORELINE.  THE STATION IS LOCATED IN A SMALL CLEARING SURROUNDED ON ALL SIDES BY SHRUBS AND TREES.  THE MARK IS A 2 IN DIAMETER IRON PIPE IMBEDDED IN CONCRETE.  THE PIPE PROJECTS 7 IN ABOVE THE GROUND.  TO REACH THE STATION DRIVE APPROXIMATELY 2.5 MI. EAST FROM THE CULEBRA AIRPORT ALONG THE NORTH SIDE OF ENSENADA HONDA.  AT PT. CABRAS BEAR LEFT (EAST) AND TRAVEL APPROXIMATELY 1.2 MI. TO THE WEST END OF MANGROVE HARBOR.  TRAVEL APPROXIMATELY 1.2 MI. EAST ALONG THE NORTH SIDE OF MANGROVE HARBOR TOWARD PT. NEGRA.  FROM A SMALL RANCH HOUSE WALK APPROXIMATELY 0.15 MI. EAST ALONG A TRAIL TO THE TRIANGULATION STATION ON THE SUMMIT OF THE KNOLL.                            STATION RECOVERY (1965)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1965 (JMC) PIPE IN GROUND RECOVERED.  A LARGE TREE IS GROWING WITHIN A FOOT OF STATION.  HILL IS NOW HEAVILY WOODED.  STATION BEST REACHED BY BOAT AS SOME OF THE GATES ON THE ROAD ARE LOCKED.

BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1939 (EGR) THIS POINT IS ON A HEAVY BRUSHY PEAK LOCATED S OF TOA BAJA, N OF RD. 2, E OF THE BRANCH RD. TO TOA BAJA AND N OF THE MUN. RD. TOA-BAJA-SAGANA SECA.  IT IS THE THIRD PROMINENT PEAK FROM THE W IN THE RIDGE.  LAND OWNED BY MR. JORGE NEVAREZ.  IT IS APPROACHED FROM THE JUNCTION OF RD. 2 AND THE TOA BAJA BRANCH FOLLOWING TOWARDS TOA BAJA 950 METERS TO ITS JUNCTION WITH THE MUN. RD. TO SABANA SECA, FOLLOW IT RIGHT (E) 800 METERS TO A SHARP BEND TO THE S, FOLLOW BY ANOTHER SHARP TO THE E AGAIN, LEAVING RD. AT SECOND BEND AT A GROUP OF HOUSES KNOWN AS LA RABUA FOLLOW DIRT RD. S TO FOOT OF HILLS WHERE ON FOOT FOLLOW LEFT (E) ABOUT 100 METERS TO FIRST DRAIN, TURN RIGHT (S) FOLLOWING UP DRAIN TO SADDLE, TURN RIGHT (W) AT SADDLE FOLLOWING RIDGE TOP OF HILL AND STATION.  STATION MARK--STANDARD TABLET STAMPED NEVARES 1939 CEMENTED TO NATURAL ROCK.  SIGNAL--WHITE FLAG ON POLE NAILED TO ALMACIGO TREE 5 FT. 3-1/2 INCHES FROM TABLET.  R.M. NO. 1--R.R. SPIKE NAILED TO JAGUEY TREE 4.19 METERS E OF N OF STATION.  R.M. NO. 2--R.R. SPIKE NAILED TO SIGNAL TREE 1.78 METERS FROM STATION.  TOP OF FLAG 5.40 METERS ABOVE GROUND.                            STATION RECOVERY (1964)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1964 (GWM) ORIGINAL DESCRIPTION IS ADEQUATE EXCEPT FOR THE TO REACH.  ON A HEAVY BUSHY PEAK S OF TOA BAJA, N OF HIGHWAY 2, E OF BRANCH ROAD TO TOA BAJA AND N OF THE MUNICIPAL ROAD, TOA BAJA- SAGANA SECA.  IT IS ON THE 3RD PROMINENT PEAK FROM THE WEST END OF THE RIDGE.  LAND OWNED BY MR. JORGE NEVAREZ.  A STANDARD DISC STAMPED NEVARES 1939, CEMENTED IN NATURAL ROCK.  THE REFERENCE MARKS WERE NOT FOUND.  TO REACH FROM BAYAMON, FOLLOW ROUTE 2 WEST TO ROUTE 165, TURN RIGHT ON 165, (SIGN SAYS TOA BAJA) AND FOLLOW IT TO CAMPANILLAS ROAD, ROUTE 865, TURN RIGHT ON 865 AND GO 0.4 MILE TO CONCRETE STRUCTURE, WHICH RESEMBLES A SMALL AQUEDUCT.  FROM THIS POINT THE STATION BEARS 155 FT MAGNETIC.  CONTINUE ON 865 0.1 MILE, TURN RIGHT ON DIRT ROAD AND FOLLOW TO THE BASE OF HILL.  FOLLOW TRAIL UP TO SADDLE, TURN LEFT (E) AND CLIMB UP THE RIDGE TO THE TOP AND THE STATION.
markers.setting: SET IN UNSPECIFIED ROCK OR BOULDER
markers.stability: PROBABLY HOLD POSITION/ELEVATION WELL

markers.description: BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1934 STATION IS LOCATED 2.2 KILOMETERS BY ROAD E OF MAYAGUEZ, 13.5 KILOMETERS BY ROAD, SW OF LAS MARIAS, ABOUT 2.5 KILOMETERS W OF HACIENDA MERLE, ON A PROMINENT TIMBERED PEAK ON A RIDGE EXTENDING E AND W ON THE N SIDE OF HIGHWAY FROM MAYAGUEZ TO LAS MARIAS.  IN ADDITION TO OTHER GROWTH OF BRUSH AND TREES, THE PEAK HAS A ROW OF LARGE MANGO TREES CROSSING THE SUMMIT N AND S AND THE STATION IS LOCATED 5 FEET SE OF THE LARGE TREE ON HIGHEST PART OF THE SUMMIT.  STATION MARK IS A STANDARD TABLET, STAMPED NISPERO 1934, CEMENTED IN A LARGE BOULDER BURIED IN THE GROUND ON HIGHEST PART OF PEAK.  REFERENCE MARKS ARE COPPER NAILS AND WASHER IN TRIANGULAR BLAZES ON MANGO TREES.  REFERENCE MARK NO.1 IS 16.50 FEET FROM STATION IN TRUE AZIMUTH 21 DEG 05 MIN.  REFERENCE MARK NO.2 IS 5.22 FEET FROM STATION IN TRUE AZIMUTH 170 DEG 35 MIN.  TO REACH THE STATION, LEAVE HIGHWAY AT TIENDA ON SUMMIT, KILOMETER POST K 17 H 2 AND FOLLOW MUNICIPAL ROAD TO HACIENDA MERLE, 0.8 KILOMETER TURN S AT EMPLOYEES QUARTERS AND FOLLOW MAIN TRAIL ALONG N SIDE OF RIDGE TO FOOT OF PEAK.  IN DRY WEATHER A CAR CAN BE TAKEN OVER THIS TRAIL, OR CAMINO, FOR ABOUT 1 KILOMETER FROM THE HACIENDA.
markers.setting: SET IN A BOULDER
markers.stability: MAY HOLD, BUT OF TYPE COMMONLY SUBJECT TOSURFACE MOTION

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1900 (JBB) STATION IS LOCATED ON HIGHEST POINT OF THE SMALL ROCKY HUMMOCK NEAR THE WESTERN POINT OF ICACOS ISLAND.  THE STATION MARK, 9 INCHES LONG IS SET IN A HOLE IN THE LIMESTONE ROCK FORMING THE HUMMOCK AND THE LEGS OF THE TRIPOD SIGNAL ARE ANCHORED BY THREE PILES OF LARGE ROCKS EACH SOME 2-1/2 FEET HIGH.                            STATION RECOVERY (1922)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1922 (FTS) STATION RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED, MARKED BY CONCRETE POST 6 INCHES SQUARE WITH NAIL IN CENTER.  PILES OF ROCK AND WOOD OF OLD SIGNAL STILL IN EVIDENCE.  TWO REFERENCE MARKS EACH A STANDARD BRONZE DISK PLACED IN CONCRETE IN HOLES IN THE CORAL, WERE ESTABLISHED.  REFERENCE MARK NO.1, IS 3.86 METERS FROM STATION, ON RANGE WITH CAPE SAN JUAN LIGHTHOUSE.  REFERENCE MARK NO.2, IS 3.88 METERS FROM STATION, ON LINE 180 DEG TO RIGHT OF LOS.                            STATION RECOVERY (1961)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1961 (MLO) STATION SEARCHED FOR BUT NOT RECOVERED.  A HOLE 6-INCHES WIDE AND ABOUT 9-INCHES DEEP WAS FOUND 3.8 METERS FROM R.M. NO. 1 ON RANGE WITH CAPE SAN JUAN LIGHTHOUSE.  THIS EMPTY HOLE WAS BELIEVED TO HAVE BEEN WHERE THE STATION MARK WAS PLACED.  R. M. NO. 1 WAS RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED.  R. M. NO. 2 WAS SEARCHED FOR BUT NOT RECOVERED.
markers.setting: SET IN TOP OF CONCRETE MONUMENT
markers.stability: MAY HOLD, BUT OF TYPE COMMONLY SUBJECT TOSURFACE MOTION

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1962 (ELJ) STATION IS LOCATED ON CAYO (ISLET) ICACOS WHICH IS THE LARGEST AND WESTERNMOST ISLAND IN THE CHAIN KNOWN AS LA CORDILLERA.  IT IS SET ON THE TOP OF THE HIGHEST LIMESTONE HUMMOCK ON THE EAST END OF THE ISLAND.  TO REACH FROM THE LOADING DOCK ON THE SOUTH SIDE OF THE ISLAND, FOLLOW THE RAILROAD TRACKS NORTH AND EAST APPROXIMATELY 1/2 MILE TO AN ABANDONED LIMESTONE QUARRY AND BASE OF HUMMOCK.  STATION MARK, A STANDARD DISK STAMPED NOB 2 1962, IS SET IN THE CENTER OF A 20 BY 20 FOOT CONCRETE PLATFORM 3 FEET THICK WHICH IS PART OF AN ABANDONED GUN EMPLACEMENT.  SEVERAL HOLES WERE DRILLED IN THE CONCRETE IN ORDER TO ERECT THE OBSERVING TENT.  REFERENCE MARK 1, A STANDARD DISK STAMPED NOB 2 NO 1 1962, IS SET IN LIMESTONE OUTCROPPING, 10 FEET EAST OF THE EAST EDGE OF THE CONCRETE PLATFORM.  REFERENCE MARK 2, A STANDARD DISK STAMPED NOB 2 NO 2 1962, IS SET IN LIMESTONE OUTCROPPING, 14 FEET WEST OF THE NORTHWEST CORNER OF THE CONCRETE PLATFORM.  NO AZIMUTH MARK WAS SET.  HEIGHT OF LIGHT ABOVE STATION MARK 1.5 METERS.                            STATION RECOVERY (1964)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1964 (GWM) STATION WAS RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED AND THE DESCRIPTION WAS ADEQUATE.  THE 1964 DIRECTIONS AND DISTANCES DID NOT CHECK THE 1962 VALUES.                            STATION RECOVERY (2004)  RECOVERY NOTE BY UNIVERSITY OF PUERTO RICO AT MAYAGUEZ 2004 MARK NOT FOUND.
markers.setting: SET IN A PAVEMENT SUCH AS STREET, SIDEWALK, CURB, ETC.
markers.stability: MARK OF QUESTIONABLE OR UNKNOWN STABILITY

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1941 (RLS) STATION IS LOCATED ON THE ROOSEVELT ROADS NAVAL RESERVATION, ON THE W SIDE OF ENSENADA HONDA, AND ABOUT 1/2 MILE NNW FROM INDIAN ROCKS.  STATION IS AT ABOUT 40 FEET ELEVATION, NEAR THE E END OF A SHOULDER EXTENDING EASTWARD TOWARD ENSENADA HONDA FROM THE BASE OF THE HIGHER HILLS, ABOUT 60 METERS W OF THE S END OF A GROUP OF TREES, ON THE CREST OF THE RIDGE.  STATION IS MARKED BY A STANDARD BRONZE DISK, SET IN A CONCRETE BLOCK PROJECTING ABOUT 4 INCHES ABOVE THE GROUND.  NO UNDERGROUND OR REFERENCE MARKS WERE SET.                            STATION RECOVERY (1963)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1963 (CFO) THE STATION MARK WAS SEARCHED FOR AND WAS NOT FOUND.
markers.setting: SET IN TOP OF CONCRETE MONUMENT
markers.stability: MAY HOLD, BUT OF TYPE COMMONLY SUBJECT TOSURFACE MOTION

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1900 (WCH) ON THE SOUTHEASTERN POINT OF THE SMALL ISLAND OF THE ABOVE NAME, AT THE EXTREME EASTERN END OF PUERTO RICO, AND NEAR PINERO ISLAND.  THE STATION IS MARKED BY A 2-INCH IRON PIPE CEMENTED INTO AN ANGLE OF THE ROCKS, LEAVING ABOUT 6 INCHES PROJECTING.                            STATION RECOVERY (1902)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1902 (RLF) STATION RECOVERED.  STATION MARK IS AS DESCRIBED AND IS ABOUT 15 FEET ABOVE THE SEA LEVEL.  SEA BREAKS HEAVILY ON THE ROCKY LEDGE IN FRONT OF THE STATION AT ALL TIMES.                            STATION RECOVERY (1922)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1922 (FTS) STATION FOUND AS DESCRIBED.  ADDITIONAL DESCRIPTION AS FOLLOWS--WEST LAVENDERA ROCK ABOUT 15 DEG CLEAR OF NEXT EASTERLY POINT.  HIGHEST POINT OF POINT PUERCA JUST VISIBLE OVER NEXT WESTERLY POINT AND CABRAS ISLAND LIGHT IN RANGE WITH THE OUTSIDE ROCKS ON LATTER POINT.  REFERENCE MARKS NOS.1 AND 2 ARES TANDARD DISKS CEMENTED IN CRACKS IN ROCKS.                            STATION RECOVERY (1926)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1926 (GCM) STATION FOUND AS DESCRIBED.  DESCRIPTION ADEQUATE.  IRON PIPE RUSTED DOWN TO THE CEMENT.  OTHERWISE, MARK IN GOOD CONDITION.  REFERENCE MARKS IN GOOD CONDITION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1941)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1941 (RLS) THE STATION WAS FOUND AS DESCRIBED BUT IN VERY POOR CONDITION.  THE IRON PIPE HAS APPARENTLY ENTIRELY RUSTED AWAY AND THE ROCKS AROUND THE STATION ARE BROKEN.  THE OLD MARK WAS REMOVED AND THIS STATION WAS RE-MARKED WITH A STANDARD BRONZE DISK SET IN A BLOCK OF CEMENT, WHICH NOW PROJECTS 6 INCHES ABOVE THE SURFACE OF THE GROUND.  BOTH REFERENCE MARKS ESTABLISHED IN 1922 WERE FOUND.  THE CONCRETE AROUND THE DISKS IS SOMEWHAT CRACKED BUT THE MARKS APPEAR NOT TO HAVE BEEN DISTURBED.  THE NAME OF THE STATION INDICATES AND THE ORIGINAL DESCRIPTION SAYS THAT THE STATION IS ON NORTH CABRAS ISLAND.  THE ISLAND IS NOW KNOWN LOCALLY AS CABEZA DE PERRO AND IT IS CALLED THAT ON CHARTS AND IN THE COAST PILOT.  THE STATION WAS OVERLOOKED AT THE TIME OF OBSERVATIONS IN THIS VICINITY.  NO OBSERVATIONS WERE MADE ON THIS STATION AND IT WAS NOT RE-DESCRIBED BY THIS PARTY.  IT IS ON THE ROOSEVELT ROADS NAVAL RESERVATION, ON A SMALL ISLAND TO THE EASTWARD OF PINEROS ISLAND AND CALLED CABEZA DE PERRO, ON THE SOUTHEASTERN POINT OF THE ISLAND, ABOUT 240 METERS S OF CABEZA DE PERRO LIGHT.                            STATION RECOVERY (1961)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1961 (MLO) STATION WAS RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED.  IT IS 2.3-METERS WEST OF A 4 BY 4 WITNESS POST IMBEDDED IN CONCRETE.  DISK IS STAMPED NORTH CABRAS ISLAND 1941.  R.M. NO. 1 WAS RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED.  R.M. NO. 2 HAS BEEN DESTROYED.  THE REMAINS OF THE CONCRETE WITH DRILL HOLE WAS FOUND 13.20 METERS FROM THE STATION IN THE APPROXIMATE DIRECTION.  DISK WAS NOT FOUND.
markers.setting: SET IN TOP OF CONCRETE MONUMENT
markers.stability: MAY HOLD, BUT OF TYPE COMMONLY SUBJECT TOSURFACE MOTION

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JJL) THE STATION IS LOCATED 6 AIRLINE MILES NORTHEAST OF NAGUABO, 5-3/4 AIRLINE MILES SOUTH OF FAJARDO AND 3/4 AIRLINE MILE EAST OF GUARD GATE NUMBER 1 AT THE ENTRANCE TO ROOSEVELT ROADS NAVAL STATION.  TO REACH FROM THE GUARD GATE NUMBER 1, GO SOUTHEAST ON A PAVED ROAD FOR 0.01 MILE TO A FORK.  KEEP LEFT AND GO EAST ON A PAVED ROAD FOR 0.8 MILE TO RUNWAY NUMBER 6.  TURN LEFT AND GO NORTH ALONG NORTHWEST EDGE OF THE RUNWAY FOR 0.1 MILE TO THE NORTHEAST EDGE OF THE RUNWAY.  TURN RIGHT AND GO SOUTHEAST ALONG THE NORTHEAST EDGE OF THE RUNWAY FOR 0.05 MILE TO THE STATION ON THE RIGHT, IN THE NORTHEAST EDGE OF THE RUNWAY.  THE STATION MARK IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED NORTHEAST 1966, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN THE NORTHEAST EDGE OF THE RUNWAY.  IT IS 3 FEET SOUTHWEST OF THE NORTHEAST EDGE OF THE RUNWAY.  REFERENCE MARK 1 IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED NORTHEAST NO 1 1966, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN THE NORTHEAST EDGE OF THE RUNWAY.  IT IS 24 FEET SOUTHWEST OF THE NORTHEAST EDGE OF THE RUNWAY.  REFERENCE MARK 2 IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED NORTHEAST NO 2 1966, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN THE NORTHEAST EDGE OF THE RUNWAY.  IT IS 3 FEET SOUTHWEST OF THE NORTHEAST EDGE OF THE RUNWAY.  NO AZIMUTH MARK WAS ESTABLISHED AT THIS STATION.  OBTAIN PERMISSION FROM THE CONTROL TOWER BEFORE VISITING THIS STATION.
markers.setting: SET IN A PAVEMENT SUCH AS STREET, SIDEWALK, CURB, ETC.
markers.stability: MARK OF QUESTIONABLE OR UNKNOWN STABILITY

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1939 (HAC) STATION IS THE NE TOWER OF THE TWO RADIO TOWERS AT THE U.S. NAVAL RADIO STATION IN PUERTA DE TIERRA, SAN JUAN.

BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1901 (JN) THIS STATION IS ON PROPERTY BELONGING TO JOSE MARIO CASANOVA ABOUT 3 MILES E OF CAMUY.  IT IS ON A BARE HILL AND, AS A REFERENCE MARK, THERE STANDS A LONE TREE ABOUT 40 FEET NE OF THE STATION.  THE STATION IS ABOUT 1 MILE S OF THE COAST LINE.  THE STATION IS MARKED BY A 2-FOOT BY 2 1/2-INCH GALVANIZED IRON PIPE SET IN CEMENT.  THE PIPE IS FILLED WITH CEMENT AND THE CENTER OF A 10-PENNY NAIL, DRIVEN INTO THE CEMENT, MARKS THE STATION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1946)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US ARMY CORPS OF ENGINEERS 1946 LETTER FROM MR. E.G. RUBIO, HQ. ANTILLES DEPARTMENT, OFFICE OF DEPT. ENGR., A.P.O. 851, C/O P.M., MIAMI, FLORIDA, DATED OCTOBER 30, 1946--  THE HOLE WITH LEAD FOUND AND REMAINS OF TRIPOD.  REPLACED IRON BAR IN HOLE.                            STATION RECOVERY (1959)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1959 (MM) THE STATION WAS NOT FOUND.  ITS POSITION WAS LOCATED IN A PLOWED FIELD, AND IT IS ASSUMED THAT THE STATION IS DESTROYED.                            STATION RECOVERY (1966)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JWC) THE STATION WAS SEARCHED FOR BUT NOT FOUND.  IT IS BELIEVED ALL MARKS WERE DESTROYED.  A NEW STATION NOVA 2 WAS ESTABLISHED.
markers.setting: SET INTO TOP OF METAL PIPE DRIVEN INTO GROUND
markers.stability: MARK OF QUESTIONABLE OR UNKNOWN STABILITY

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JWC) THE STATION IS LOCATED 8 AIRLINE MILES WEST OF ARECIBO, 5 AIRLINE MILES SOUTH-SOUTHEAST OF CAMOY AND ON THE TOP OF A GRASS COVERED HILL.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE INTERSECTION OF HIGHWAYS 2 AND 129 IN ARECIBO, GO WESTERLY ON HIGHWAY 2 FOR 5.0 MILES TO A SIDE ROAD LEFT AT KILOMETER POST 85.2.  TURN LEFT AND GO SOUTH ON A PAVED ROAD FOR 0.65 MILE TO A CROSSROAD.  TURN LEFT AND GO EAST AND SOUTH ON A PAVED ROAD FOR 0.15 MILE TO A CROSSROAD.  CONTINUE STRAIGHT AHEAD AND GO SOUTH ON A TRACK ROAD FOR 0.2 MILE TO A FENCE LINE JUST SOUTH OF A FARMHOUSE AND END OF TRUCK TRAVEL.  FROM HERE PACK SOUTH UPHILL FOR ABOUT 100 YARDS TO THE HIGHEST POINT OF THE HILL AND THE STATION.  THE STATION MARK IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED NOVA 2 1966, BRAZED TO THE TOP OF A 3-INCH ROUND CAST IRON SOIL PIPE WHICH PROJECTS 2 INCHES.  IT IS 106 FEET EAST OF A FENCE LINE.  REFERENCE MARK 1 IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED NOVA 2 NO 1 1966, BRAZED TO THE TOP OF A 3-INCH ROUND CAST IRON SOIL PIPE WHICH PROJECTS 6 INCHES.  IT IS 1 FOOT EAST OF THE FENCE LINE.  REFERENCE MARK 2 IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED NOVA 2 NO 2 1966, BRAZED TO THE TOP OF A 3-INCH ROUND CAST IRON SOIL PIPE WHICH PROJECTS 6 INCHES.  IT IS 1 FOOT EAST OF THE FENCE LINE.  NO AZIMUTH MARK WAS ESTABLISHED AT THIS STATION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1966)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1993)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL OCEAN SERVICE 1993 RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1995)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1995 (CSM) RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.  NOTE--THE MONUMENT BEARS THE APPEARANCE OF HAVING BEEN REINFORCED.  THE STATION IS IN A CATTLE PASTURE. RECOVERED BY J.A.  SWALLOW AND M.A.  ASLAKSEN.                            STATION RECOVERY (1995)  RECOVERY NOTE BY ANDREGG INCORPORATED 1995 (MJB) RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED.                            STATION RECOVERY (2001)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 2001 (JMW) 2.4 KM (1.5 MI) WESTERLY ALONG STATE HIGHWAY 2    FROM THE JUNCTION OF STATE HIGHWAY 22 IN CARRIZALES, THENCE 1.3 KM (0.8 MI) SOUTHERLY ALONG A PAVED TAKING A JOG TO THE LEFT AND CONTINUING TO A T-JUNCTION,  THENCE 0.6 KM (0.4 MI) WESTERLY ALONG A PAVED ROAD, THENCE 0.6 KM (0.4 MI) SOUTHERLY ALONG A PAVED ROAD PASSING THROUGH A GATE, THENCE 0.2 MI EASTERLY ALONG A TRACK ROAD TO A HOUSE,  THEN PACK 130 METERS NORTHEAST CROSSING 3 FENCES TO THE HIGHEST POINT ON A HILL, 35.6 M EAST-SOUTHEAST OF A REFERENCE PIPE BETWEEN 2 FENCE POSTS, 32.8 M EAST-NORTHEAST OF A REFERENCE PIPE BETWEEN 2 FENCES, 27.8 M EAST OF A TRACK ROAD, 24.9 M EAST OF THE MOST EASTERLY OF 2 FENCES, 1.4 M WEST OF A METAL PIPE WITNESS POST.  NOTE--THE PIPE IS ENCASED IN A 4-INCH PVC PIPE WITH A SCREW CAP. THE PVC PIPE IS SURROUNDED BY AND FILLED WITH CONCRETE AND PROJECTS 0.2 M ABOVE THE GROUND SURFACE.  THE MARK IS ON PROPERTY OWNED BY BERNARDINO LINARES DELGADO, B.O. CARRIZALES HATILLO.                            STATION RECOVERY (2007)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 2007 MARK NOT FOUND.                            STATION RECOVERY (2011)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 2011 MARK NOT FOUND.
markers.setting: SET INTO TOP OF METAL PIPE DRIVEN INTO GROUND
markers.stability: MARK OF QUESTIONABLE OR UNKNOWN STABILITY

markers.description: BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1934 STATION IS SITUATED ON A POINTED BARE PEAK N OF RIDGE OF MOUNTAINS RUNNING E AND W BETWEEN THE TANAMA RIVER ON N AND THE ADJUNTAS-LARES ROAD AND FARMHOUSE OF JAIME CASTANER ON S, AND ABOUT 3 KILOMETERS FROM ROAD.  STATION MARK IS A STANDARD U.S.G.S. TABLET CEMENTED ON NATURAL ROCK AND STAMPED NOVILLO 1934.  REFERENCE MARK NO.1 IS A STANDARD TABLET SET ON NATURAL ROCK, 2.48 METERS FROM STATION IN TRUE AZIMUTH 269 DEG 57 MIN.  REFERENCE MARK NO.2 IS A STANDARD TABLET SET ON NATURAL ROCK, 4.45 METERS FROM STATION MARK, IN TRUE AZIMUTH 322 DEG 18 MIN.  TO REACH STATION LEAVE CAR AT KILOMETER 76.850 OF LARES-ADJUNTAS ROAD AT FARMHOUSE OF JAIME CASTANER, TAKE THE HORSE TRAIL THAT CLIMBS N TO TOP OF RIDGE OF MOUNTAINS AND FROM THE POINT WHERE TRAIL REACHES THE DIVIDE, YOU WILL SEE THE PEAK TO THE W OF N ABOUT 1 KILOMETER AWAY.  STATION IS ON PROPERTY OF NICOLAS MEDINA ON BO. PORTILLO ADJUNTAS.
markers.setting: SET IN UNSPECIFIED ROCK OR BOULDER
markers.stability: PROBABLY HOLD POSITION/ELEVATION WELL

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1901 (JN) STATION IS ON LAND BELONGING TO PACO NOYA, ABOUT 3 MILES W OF TOWN OF CAMUY.  IT IS IN A FIELD ABOUT 125 FEET S OF THE COAST BRUSH ON THE HIGHEST POINT OF GROUND ON THE COAST WITHIN 2 MILES E OR W.  IT IS N OF THE BUILDING OCCUPIED BY REPE NOYA, AND 275 FEET NW OF A LARGE WATER HOLE NEAR THE TOP OF THE HILL SURROUNDED BY COCOANUT PALMS.  IT IS ALSO 300 FEET E OF A LINE OF DENSE BRUSH AND VINES THAT RUN AT RIGHT ANGLES TO THE COAST.  THE STATION IS MARKED BY A GALVANIZED IRON PIPE 2 FEET BY 2 INCHES SET IN CEMENT AND PROJECTING 2 INCHES ABOVE THE SURFACE OF THE GROUND.  THE PIPE IS FILLED WITH CEMENT AND THE CENTER OF A NAIL DRIVEN INTO THIS MARKS THE STATION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1959)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1959 (MM) THE STATION WAS NOT FOUND.  ITS POSITION WAS LOCATED IN A PLOWED FIELD, AND IT IS ASSUMED THAT STATION NOYA IS DESTROYED.                            STATION RECOVERY (1966)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JWC) THE STATION MARK WAS NOT RECOVERED AND IT IS PRESUMED TO HAVE BEEN DESTROYED.  A NEW STATION MARK AND REFERENCE MARKS 1 AND 2 WERE ESTABLISHED IN THE SAME GENERAL VICINITY.  FOR THE NEW DESCRIPTION SEE NOYA 2.  AIRLINE DISTANCE AND DIRECTION FROM NEAREST TOWN 3 MILES WEST OF CAMUY.
markers.setting: UNSPECIFIED SETTING

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JWC) THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 3-1/2 MILES EAST-NORTHEAST OF QUEBRADILLAS, 3 MILES WEST OF CAMUY AND LOCATED ALONG THE NORTH EDGE OF A PASTURE WHICH LIES ON A LOW GRASS COVERED HILL.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE NORTHWEST CORNER OF THE PLAZA IN CAMUY, GO NORTH FOR 0.05 MILE THEN TURN LEFT AND GO WESTERLY ON THE PAVED ROAD FOR 3.0 MILES TO A SIDE ROAD RIGHT.  (THIS ROAD IS 0.1 MILE WEST OF A SCHOOL HOUSE ON THE NORTH SIDE OF THE ROAD.) TURN RIGHT AND GO NORTH ON THE PRIVATE ROAD FOR 0.15 MILE TO A FARM HOUSE ON THE LEFT.  CONTINUE NORTHERLY, PASSING THROUGH THE BARN LOT AND ACROSS THE PASTURE, FOR 0.2 MILE TO THE TOP OF A LOW GRASS COVERED HILL AT THE NORTH END OF THE PASTURE AND THE STATION.  (A 4-WHEEL DRIVE VEHICLE MAY BE NEEDED TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE FARM HOUSE IN WET WEATHER.)  THE STATION MARK IS A STANDARD DISK, STAMPED NOYA 2 1966, BRAZED TO THE TOP OF A 3-INCH DIAMETER CAST IRON PIPE THAT IS SET IN AN IRREGULAR MASS OF CONCRETE AND PROJECTS 4 INCHES.  IT IS LOCATED 42.1 FEET EAST OF THE FENCE LINE.  REFERENCE MARK 1 IS A STANDARD DISK, STAMPED NOYA 2 NO 1 1966, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN BEDROCK THAT IS FLUSH WITH THE SURFACE OF THE GROUND.  IT IS LOCATED 64.4 FEET EAST OF THE FENCE LINE.  REFERENCE MARK 2 IS A STANDARD DISK, STAMPED NOYA 2 NO 2 1966, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN OUTCROPPING BEDROCK THAT PROJECTS 1 INCH.  IT IS LOCATED 20.4 FEET EAST OF THE FENCE LINE.  AN AZIMUTH MARK WAS NOT ESTABLISHED.                            STATION RECOVERY (2004)  RECOVERY NOTE BY UNIVERSITY OF PUERTO RICO AT MAYAGUEZ 2004 (FGP) MARK NOT FOUND.
markers.setting: SET INTO TOP OF METAL PIPE DRIVEN INTO GROUND
markers.stability: MARK OF QUESTIONABLE OR UNKNOWN STABILITY

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JWC) THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 5-1/4 MILES WEST-SOUTHWEST OF AGUADA, 2 MILES NORTHWEST OF RINCON AND ON THE PROPERTY OF THE PUERTO RICO WATER RESOURCES AUTHORITY.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE NORTHEAST CORNER OF THE PLAZA IN RINCON, GO NORTHERLY ON HIGHWAY 115 FOR 0.15 MILE TO A SIDE ROAD ON THE LEFT.  TURN LEFT AND GO NORTHWEST ON A PAVED ROAD FOR 1.55 MILES TO A FORK.  TAKE THE LEFT FORK AND CONTINUE NORTHWEST ON A PAVED ROAD FOR 0.1 MILE TO A GUARD GATE.  PASS THROUGH THE GATE AND CONTINUE ON A PAVED ROAD FOR 0.5 MILE TO A DIM TRACK ROAD ON THE RIGHT.  TURN RIGHT AND FOLLOW THE TRACK ROAD NORTHERLY FOR 0.55 MILE TO THE TOP OF THE HILL AND THE STATION AT TWO SILVER TANKS.  THE STATION MARK IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED NUCLEAR 1966, SET IN THE TOP OF A 12 X 14-INCH CONCRETE POST THAT PROJECTS 3 INCHES.  IT IS 54.8 FEET NORTH OF A POWERLINE POLE AND 44.5 FEET WEST OF THE NORTH ONE OF TWO SILVER TANKS.  REFERENCE MARK 1 IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED NUCLEAR NO 1 1966, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A 12-INCH SQUARE CONCRETE POST THAT SUPPORTS A PIPE WHICH IS CONECTED TO THE SILVER TANKS.  THE POST IS THE SOUTH ONE OF FOUR.  REFERENCE MARK 2 IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED NUCLEAR NO 2 1966, SET IN THE TOP OF A 12-INCH SQUARE CONCRETE POST THAT PROJECTS 3 INCHES.  IT IS 2.4 FEET EAST OF THE POWERLINE POLE.  NO AZIMUTH MARK WAS ESTABLISHED AT THIS DATE.  PERMISSION TO ESTABLISH THE STATION ON THIS POINT WAS GIVEN BY MR. CARLOS GALVAN WHO IS THE RESIDENT ENGINEER AT THE NUCLEAR PLANT.                            STATION RECOVERY (1977)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1977 (WFP) THE STATION MARK, REFERENCE MARK 2 WERE RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.  REFERENCE MARK 1 HAD BEEN REMOVED WITH THE STEM INTACT.  REFERENCE MARK 3 WAS SET IN THE SAME CONCRETE POST.  THE SOUTH ONE OF TWO SILVER TANKS HAD BEEN REMOVED.  DIRECTIONS AND DISTANCE TO REFERENCE MARK 2 CHECKED THE 1966 DESCRIPTION WHICH IS ADEQUATE FOR STATION RECOVERY.  THE STATION MARK WAS USED AS THE ANTENNA SITE FOR GEOCEIVER STATION 51192.  AIRLINE DISTANCE AND DIRECTION FROM NEAREST TOWN 2 MILES NORTHWEST OF RINCON.                            STATION RECOVERY (2004)  RECOVERY NOTE BY UNIVERSITY OF PUERTO RICO AT MAYAGUEZ 2004 (JMV) MARK NOT FOUND.
markers.setting: SET IN TOP OF CONCRETE MONUMENT
markers.stability: MAY HOLD, BUT OF TYPE COMMONLY SUBJECT TOSURFACE MOTION

markers.description: BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1934 STATION IS ABOUT 6 KILOMETERS BY ROAD AND TRAIL N OF THE TOWN OF GURABO, ON A PROMINENT BARE PEAK IN THE RANGE JUST TO THE N OF RIO GURABO.  THERE ARE TWO HIGHER PEAKS IN THIS RANGE BETWEEN THIS STATION AND STATION GAY.  IT IS ABOUT 1.5 KILOMETERS E OF THE POINT WHERE THE PROPOSED GURABO-TRUJILLO ALTO CARRETERA CROSSES THE RANGE, AT PRESENT THERE IS A MAIN TRAIL CROSSING ABOUT 1/2 KILOMETER W OF THE STATION.  THERE ARE SEVERAL LARGE BOULDERS PROJECTING FROM THE SUMMIT OF THE PEAK AND THE STATION MARK IS LOCATED IN THE HIGHEST ONE OF THESE.  STATION MARK IS A STANDARD U.S.G.S. TABLET, STAMPED NUEVO 1934, CEMENTED IN TOP OF LARGE PROJECTING BOULDER.  REFERENCE MARKS ARE ONE-INCH DRILL HOLES IN PROJECTING BOULDERS IN PLACE.  REFERENCE MARK NO.1 IS ON S SLOPE 14.90 FEET FROM STATION IN TRUE AZIMUTH 80 DEG 27 MIN.  REFERENCE MARK NO.2 IS ON E SLOPE, 15.18 FEET FROM STATION IN TRUE AZIMUTH 274 DEG 47 MIN.  SIGNAL--A QUADRIPOD OF SAWED LUMBER WITH BLACK CROSS-TARGETS ON CENTER POLE.  THE BEST WAY TO REACH THE STATION IS TO FOLLOW THE ROAD LEADING NORTHWARD FROM GURABO TOWARDS TRUJILLO ALTO FOR 4.5 KILOMETERS (PRESENT END OF IMPROVED PORTION), LEAVE ROAD AND FOLLOW TRAIL LEADING E ALONG RIDGE, PAST SEVERAL NATIVE HOUSES, TO INTERSECTION WITH A MAIN TRAIL RUNNING N AND S, FOLLOW THIS TRAIL N TO POINT NEAR SUMMIT, TURN E, CLIMB TO TOP OF RIDGE AND FOLLOW SAME TO STATION PEAK.                            STATION RECOVERY (1940)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1940 STATION AND R.M.S RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED, IN GOOD CONDITION.  THE ORIGINAL DESCRIPTION IS GOOD.  BUT IT SHOULD BE ADDED THAT THE MARK IS IN A FENCE CORNER.  ALSO, TO REACH STATION, TAKE ROAD FROM GURABO TO TRUJILLO ALTO TO ABOUT 30 METERS N OF KM. 17.8.  HERE TAKE TRAIL AFOOT E ABOUT 2 KM. TO PROPERTY OF LUIZ DIAZ, WHERE STATION IS LOCATED.                            STATION RECOVERY (1965)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1965 (JJL) THE STATION MARK WAS RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED IN THE 1934 DESCRIPTION AND FOUND TO BE IN GOOD CONDITION.  TWO NEW REFERENCE MARKS WERE ESTABLISHED AND THE DISKS WERE SET IN THE DRILL HOLES DESCRIBED AS REFERENCE MARKS IN THE 1934 DESCRIPTION.  A COMPLETE NEW DESCRIPTION FOLLOWS.  THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 7 MILES NORTHEAST OF CAGUAS, 6-1/2 MILES SOUTH-SOUTHEAST OF TRUJILLO ALTO, 2-1/2 MILES NORTH-NORTHEAST OF GURABO AND ON THE HIGHEST POINT OF A PROMINENT BARE PEAK ALONG AN EAST-WEST RANGE OF HILLS KNOWN AS LA CUCHILLA DE NATO NUEVO.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE JUNCTION OF HIGHWAY 3 AND HIGHWAY 181 ON THE EAST EDGE OF GURABO, GO NORTH ON HIGHWAY 181, TOWARD TRUJILLO ALTO, FOR 4.5 MILES TO A SIDE ROAD ON THE RIGHT.  TURN SHARP RIGHT AND FOLLOW THE NARROW PAVED ROAD, EAST, FOR 0.35 MILE TO A Y-FORK JUST AFTER THE END OF THE PAVED ROAD.  KEEP THE LEFT FORK AND GO NORTHERLY ON THE DIRT ROAD FOR 0.8 MILE TO TWO AUSTRALIAN PINE TREES ON THE RIGHT AT THE BASE OF THE HILL AND THE END OF TRUCK TRAVEL.  PACK SOUTH UP THE GRASSY HILLSIDE FOR ABOUT 100 YARDS TO THE HIGHEST POINT OF THE HILL AND THE STATION.  NOTE--A 4-WHEEL DRIVE VEHICLE IS REQUIRED TO REACH THE STATION IN WET WEATHER.  THE STATION MARK IS A U.S. GEOLOGICAL SURVEY DISK, STAMPED NUEVO 1934, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A BOULDER THAT PROJECTS 2 FEET. NOTE 12C  REFERENCE MARK 2 IS A STANDARD DISK, STAMPED NUEVO USGS NO 2 1934, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A BOULDER THAT PROJECTS 12 INCHES. STATION RECOVERY (1957)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1957 (MV) THE WOODEN FLAGPOLE MARKING THE STATION WAS PULLED DOWN ( 6/25/57 ) DUE TO ITS BASE BEING ALL DETERIORATED.  IT WAS DECIDED NOT TO MARK THE LOCATION OF THIS STATION, BECAUSE ITS VALUE AS SUCH HAD BEEN LOST ON ACCOUNT OF THE LARGE NUMBER OF TREES THAT SURROUND THE OBSERVATORY GROUNDS HIDING THE POLE FROM VIEW AT ANY DISTANCE GREATER THAN 150 FT.  SEE OFFICE LETTER--605.2, 41-FS.  STATION NO LONGER EXISTS.  ANOTHER FLAGPOLE HAS BEEN ERECTED ON A NEW SITE.
PTIVE TEXT AVAILABLE.

THE MARK IS FLUSH WITH GROUND.  NOTE 1A.  NO UNDERGROUND MARK WAS SET.  REFERENCE MARK NO.1 IS S OF THE STATION, 4.9 METERS NW OF THE CENTER LINE OF THE TRACK, 0.4 METER SE OF THE RIGHT-OF-WAY FENCE, AND 13.2 METERS SW OF THE WITNESS TREE.  THE MARK PROJECTS 4 INCHES ABOVE GROUND.  NOTE 11A.  REFERENCE MARK NO.2 IS E OF THE STATION, 3.0 METERS NW OF THE CENTER LINE OF THE TRACK, AT THE SW END OF THE NW HEADWALL OF A DOUBLE 32-INCH PIPE CULVERT THROUGH WHICH THE ABOVE MENTIONED CREEK RUNS UNDER THE TRACK, 0.3 METER NE OF THE SW END AND 0.15 METER FROM THE OUTER EDGE OF THE HEADWALL, AND 1.27 METERS LOWER THAN THE TOP OF THE RAIL.  A STANDARD DISK CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN TOP OF CONCRETE HEADWALL.  THE WITNESS MARK, A TRIANGULAR BLAZE, IS 1 METER ABOVE GROUND ON THE NW SIDE OF AN 8-INCH JAGUEY TREE ON THE RIGHT-OF-WAY FENCE LINE.  STATION AND REFERENCE MARKS ARE U.S. NAVY BENCH MARKS.  ELEVATIONS.  STATION MARK 14.353 METERS 47.09 FEET.  R.M.NO.1 14.298 METERS 46.91 FEET.  R.M.NO.2 12.967 METERS 42.56 FEET. NO. 1 WAS RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED EXCEPT THAT THERE IS NO LONGER A WITNESS TREE.  THE MARK WAS COVERED WITH LONG GRASS AND BUSHES.  R.M. NO. 2 WAS RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED. markers.description: BY RLDA SURVEYING AND MAPPING 2010 (RLD) THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 4.4 MI (7.1 KM) NORTHWEST OF SAN SEBASTIAN, 4.4 MI (7.1 KM) NORTHWEST OF LA PARADA, 4.2 MI (6.8 KM) SOUTHWEST OF LA VEGA AND 1.0 MI (1.6 KM) SOUTHEAST OF CAPA, PUERTO RICO.   TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE INTERSECTION OF PR-125 AND PR-111 2.3 MI (3.7 KM) NORTHEAST OF SAN SEBASTIAN, GO NORTHWESTERLY ON PR-111 FOR 2.2 MI (3.5 KM) TO THE STATION ON THE RIGHT.   THE STATION IS 15.28 M (50.1 FT) EAST OF A WOOD POWER POLE, 11.46 M (37.6 FT) WEST OF A WOOD POWER POLE, 8.50 M (27.9 FT) NORTH OF THE CENTERLINE OF PR-111 AND 5.47 M (17.9 FT) SOUTHEAST OF A CONCRETE POWER POLE.
markers.setting: SET IN TOP OF CONCRETE MONUMENT
markers.stability: MAY HOLD, BUT OF TYPE COMMONLY SUBJECT TOSURFACE MOTION

markers.description: BY RLDA SURVEYING AND MAPPING 2010 (RLD) THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 7.2 MI (11.6 KM) SOUTHEAST OF BAYANEY, 3.1 MI (5.0 KM) NORTHWEST OF LA PLAYA, 3.0 MI (4.8 KM) NORTH OF UTUADO AND 2.4 MI (3.9 KM) NORTHEAST OF CAYUCO, PUERTO RICO.   TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE INTERSECTION OF PR-111 AND PR-10 1.1 MI (1.8 KM) WEST OF UTUADO, GO NORTHERLY ON PR-10 FOR 3.2 MI (5.1 KM) TO THE STATION ON THE RIGHT.   THE STATION IS 66.00 M (216.5 FT) SOUTH OF KM POST 65.1, 11.00 M (36.1 FT) SOUTHEAST OF THE CENTERLINE OF PR-10, 5.70 M (18.7 FT) NORTHWEST OF A METAL GUARD RAIL AND 3.37 M (11.1 FT) SOUTHWEST OF A METAL SIGN (PR-10N).
markers.setting: SET IN TOP OF CONCRETE MONUMENT
