markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1941 (RLS) ON THE ROOSEVELT ROADS NAVAL RESERVATION, BETWEEN POINT PUERCA AND PINEROS ISLAND, ON PINERITA ISLAND, ON THE HIGHEST POINT OF THE ISLAND, ABOUT 3 METERS W OF THE TOP OF THE STEEP BANK AT THE E END OF THE ISLAND, AND ABOUT 4 METERS S OF THE TOP OF THE BANK AT THE N SIDE.  STATION IS MARKED BY A STANDARD BRONZE DISK SET IN A BLOCK OF CONCRETE WHICH PROJECTS 6 INCHES ABOVE THE SURFACE OF THE GROUND.  NO UNDERGROUND MARK.  REFERENCE MARKS ARE THE SAME ONES AS ESTABLISHED FOR STATION PINERITA IN 1926.  BOTH REFERENCE MARKS ARE CHISELED CROSSES ON BOULDERS.  NO.1 IS AT THE E END OF THE HILL AND ABOUT 1 FOOT LOWER THAN THE STATION.  NO.2 IS ON THE SE POINT OF THE ISLAND AND ABOUT 6 FEET LOWER THAN THE STATION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1961)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1961 (MLO) STATION WAS RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED EXCEPT THAT IT IS NOW PROJECTING ONLY ONE-INCH ABOVE GROUND.  IT IS STAMPED PINERITA 1941.  BOTH REFERENCE MARKS WERE RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED.
markers.setting: SET IN TOP OF CONCRETE MONUMENT
markers.stability: MAY HOLD, BUT OF TYPE COMMONLY SUBJECT TOSURFACE MOTION

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1902 (JN) THIS STATION IS ON A HIGH HILL NEAR THE E COAST OF PUERTO RICO, AND AT THE FOOT OF W SLOPE OF THE HILL IS THE PINERO SUGAR PLANTATION.  THE HILL IS ABOUT 1-1/2 MILES SE FROM THE TOWN OF FAJARDO, AND IN FULL VIEW OF IT.  THE TOP IS STREWN WITH LARGE GRANITE BOULDERS, ONE OF WHICH, WITH A FLAT TOP, WAS SELECTED AS THE TRIANGULATION STATION.  IT IS NOT THE HIGHEST ROCK BUT WAS DEEMED BEST ADAPTED FOR THE PURPOSE AND A HOLE 1 INCH IN DIAMETER AND 1 INCH DEEP WAS DRILLED IN ITS FLAT SURFACE AND THE CENTER OF THIS HOLE IS THE TRIANGULATION STATION.  TO REACH THE STATION FOLLOW THE MAIL-ROAD TO THE S (TOWARDS HUMACAO, ETC.) FOR ABOUT 3/4 MILE, THEN TURN TO THE LEFT OVER ROADS THROUGH THE CANE FIELDS TO THE HOUSES OF THE PINERO ESTATE, WHICH IS AS FAR AS WAGONS CAN GO.  AN EASY TRAIL LEADS THENCE TO THE SUMMIT OF THE HILL, WHICH IS BARE OF TREES BUT COVERED WITH A COARSE GRASS AND SMALL BUSHES.                            STATION RECOVERY (1921)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1921 (JHP) DESCRIPTION IS ADEQUATE.  PINERO ESTATE MENTIONED IS NOW PART OF FAJARDO SUGAR COMPANY.
markers.setting: SET IN ROCK OUTCROP
markers.stability: MOST RELIABLE AND EXPECTED TO HOLDPOSITION/ELEVATION WELL

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1901 (JBB) STATION IS A TRIPOD SIGNAL ON POINT OF SAND BEACH ON THE N SIDE OF PINEROS ISLAND.  THE FIRST POINT E OF THE PASAJO DE MEDIO MUNDO.  SIGNAL IS AT HIGH-WATER MARK.  IT IS MARKED BY A CEMENT POST 1-1/2 FEET LONG AND 6 INCHES SQUARE WITH A NAIL IN THE CENTER.                            STATION RECOVERY (1922)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1922 (FTS) ORIGINAL TRIPOD STILL STANDING AT END OF SAND SPIT, BUT THE STATION MARK IS GONE.
markers.setting: SET IN TOP OF CONCRETE MONUMENT
markers.stability: MAY HOLD, BUT OF TYPE COMMONLY SUBJECT TOSURFACE MOTION

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1941 (RLS) STATION IS ABOUT 4 MILES ESE OF CEIBA, ON THE ROOSEVELT ROADS NAVAL RESERVATION, ON PINEROS ISLAND, ABOUT ON THE HIGHEST POINT OF THE ISLAND 4 METERS NW OF THE LARGEST AND HIGHEST BOULDER ON TOP OF THE HILL.  THE MARK PROJECTS ABOUT 8 INCHES ABOVE GROUND.  THE ELEVATION OF THE STATION IS ABOUT 250 FEET.  STATION MARK IS A STANDARD BRONZE DISK SET IN CONCRETE, AS DESCRIBED IN NOTE 1A.  NO UNDERGROUND MARK.  REFERENCE MARKS ARE STANDARD BRONZE DISKS SET IN CONCRETE IN DEPRESSIONS IN BOULDERS.  REFERENCE MARK NO.1 IS ON THE SW SLOPE OF THE HILL, 3.53 METERS LOWER THAN THE STATION, ON TOP OF A BOULDER PROJECTING ABOUT 15 INCHES ABOVE GROUND.  REFERENCE MARK NO.2 IS AT THE SE END OF A SLOPING RIDGE ON TOP OF THE HILL, 1.37 METERS LOWER THAN THE STATION, AND ON A BOULDER PROJECTING ABOUT 8 INCHES ABOVE GROUND.  THE HIGHEST POINT OF THE BOULDER IS S OF AND ABOUT 3 INCHES HIGHER THAN THE REFERENCE MARK.  THE DISK IS SLOPING SLIGHTLY TOWARD THE STATION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1961)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1961 (MLO) STATION AND REFERENCE MARKS WERE SEARCHED FOR BUT NOT RECOVERED.  THEY WERE THOUGHT TO BE DESTROYED BY CONSTRUCTION OF PILLBOX, TOWER, AND UNDERGROUND STRUCTURES ON TOP OF THE HILL.
markers.setting: SET IN TOP OF CONCRETE MONUMENT
markers.stability: MAY HOLD, BUT OF TYPE COMMONLY SUBJECT TOSURFACE MOTION

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JJL) THE STATION IS LOCATED ON THE TOP OF A CONCRETE BUNKER ON THE HIGHEST POINT OF ISLA PINEROS.  IT IS 2-1/2 MILES EAST OF THE NORTHEAST END OF THE AIRSTRIP AT ROOSEVELT ROADS NAVAL RESERVATION.  THE STATION MARK IS 2.5 FEET NORTHWEST OF THE SOUTHEAST EDGE OF BUNKER WALL, 2.3 FEET SOUTHWEST OF THE NORTHEAST EDGE OF BUNKER WALL AND 2.1 FEET EAST OF A 4 INCH VENT PIPE.  IT IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED PINEROS 3 1966 CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN THE EAST CORNER OF THE BUNKER, 8 INCHES UNDER THE ROCK AND DIRT COVERING THE TOP OF BUNKER.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 1 IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED PINEROS 3 NO 1 1966 CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN THE SOUTH CORNER OF BUNKER WALL.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 2 IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED PINEROS 3 NO 2 1966 CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN THE WEST CORNER OF BUNKER WALL.  HEIGHT OF LIGHT ABOVE STATION MARK 1.6 METERS.
markers.setting: SET IN A MASSIVE RETAINING WALL
markers.stability: PROBABLY HOLD POSITION/ELEVATION WELL

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1903 (WEP) THE OLD FLAGSTAFF WAS FOUND AND REPLACED BY A LARGER AND HEAVIER SIGNAL.  THE SIGNAL IS A POLE NAILED TO A MANGROVE TREE, THE WHOLE TOP OF THE TREE HAVING BEEN CUT AWAY TO CLEAR THE SIGNAL.                            STATION RECOVERY (1904)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1904 (JCL) FRAMEWORK OF SIGNAL STANDING, SEEN ABOVE MANGROVE TREES.

BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1965 (JJL) THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 4 AIRLINE MILES SOUTH-SOUTHWEST OF CAPE SAN JUAN LIGHTHOUSE, ABOUT 2 AIRLINE MILES NORTHEAST OF FAJARDO AND ABOUT 1/2 AIRLINE MILES NORTH OF PUERTO REAL.  ON A LOW BLUFF WHICH OVERLOOKS THE ATLANTIC OCEAN.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE POST OFFICE IN PUERTO REAL, GO WEST ON UNION STREET FOR 0.2 MILE TO A SIDE ROAD RIGHT.  TURN RIGHT AND GO NORTHERLY ON A PAVED STREET FOR 0.2 MILE TO HOUSE NUMBER 22 ON THE RIGHT AND END OF TRUCK TRAVEL.  FROM HERE PACK EAST UPHILL PASSING TO THE SOUTH OF THE HOUSE FOR ABOUT 100 YARDS TO THE TOP OF THE BLUFF AND THE STATION.  ALLOW 10 MINUTES FOR PACKING.  THE STATION MARK IS A IRON PEG SET IN A MASS OF CONCRETE WITH PLAFA 1956 INSCRIBED IN THE TOP OF THE CONCRETE.  THE MONUMENT PROJECTS 1 INCH ABOVE THE SURFACE.  REFERENCE MARK 1 IS A IRON PEG SET IN THE TOP OF A MASS OF CONCRETE WITH REF 1 INSCRIBED IN THE TOP OF THE CONCRETE.  THE MONUMENT PROJECTS 2 INCHES ABOVE THE SURFACE AND IT IS ABOUT 2 FEET LOWER THAN THE STATION.  REFERENCE MARK 3 IS A IRON PEG SET IN THE TOP OF A MASS OF CONCRETE WITH REF 3 INSCRIBED IN THE TOP OF THE CONCRETE.  THE MONUMENT PROJECTS 3 INCHES AND IT IS ABOUT 3 FEET LOWER THAN THE STATION.  NO SUITABLE PLACE TO SET AN AZIMUTH MARK.
markers.setting: OBJECT SURROUNDED BY MASS OF CONCRETE
markers.stability: MARK OF QUESTIONABLE OR UNKNOWN STABILITY

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1941 (RLS) STATION IS ON THE ROOSEVELT ROADS NAVAL RESERVATION, ON POINT MEDIO MUNDO, ABOUT 250 METERS W ON A LOW KNOLL WHICH RISES STEEPLY FROM THE BEACH AT ABOUT THE CENTER OF THE SE SIDE OF THE POINT, ABOUT 10 METER NW OF HIGH-WATER LINE, AND ON THE ROCKY BEACH.  THE STATION IS MARKED BY A STANDARD BRONZE DISK, SET IN A CONCRETE BLOCK WHICH PROJECTS 6 INCHES ABOVE THE GROUND.  NO UNDERGROUND MARK.  THE STATION WAS ESTABLISED FOR CONTROL OF TOPOGRAPHY AND IS OF VERY LITTLE PERMANENT VALUE.                            STATION RECOVERY (1961)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1961 (MLO) STATION WAS RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED AND IS IN EXCELLENT CONDITION.  IT IS NOW ABOUT 8.9 METERS FROM HIGH-WATER LINE.  ROCKY BEACH IS NOW COVERED WITH SMALL BUSHES AND CACTUS.
markers.setting: SET IN TOP OF CONCRETE MONUMENT
markers.stability: MAY HOLD, BUT OF TYPE COMMONLY SUBJECT TOSURFACE MOTION

markers.description: PTIVE TEXT AVAILABLE.

BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1934 STATION IS THE TALLEST BLACK IRON CHIMNEY ON THE SUGAR FACTORY N OF BARCELONETA.                            STATION RECOVERY (1941)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1941 (GBG) DESTROYED.

BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1941 (RLS) STATION IS LOCATED ON THE ROOSEVELT ROADS NAVAL RESERVATION, ON THE SW SIDE OF ENSENADA HONDA, ON POINT CASCAJO, ABOUT 75 METERS SW OF THE NE END OF THE POINT, ABOUT 50 METERS NW OF THE HIGH-WATER LINE, ABOUT 30 METERS NW OF THE TOP OF THE STEEP BANK, AND PROJECTS ABOUT 8 INCHES ABOVE GROUND.  THE ELEVATION OF THE STATION IS ABOUT 32 FEET.  STATION AND REFERENCE MARKS ARE STANDARD DISKS SET IN CONCRETE, AS DESCRIBED IN NOTES 1A AND 11A.  THERE IS NO UNDERGROUND MARK.  REFERENCE MARK NO.1 IS 2.68 METERS LOWER THAN THE STATION AND PROJECTS ABOUT 8 INCHES ABOVE GROUND.  REFERENCE MARK NO.2 IS 7 METERS NW OF THE TOP OF THE STEEP BANK ALONG THE SE SIDE OF THE POINT, AT THE NW EDGE OF THE THICK BRUSH ALONG THE TOP OF THE STEEP BANK, 1.76 METERS LOWER THAN THE STATION, AND PROJECTS ABOUT 6 INCHES ABOVE GROUND.  THE AREA AROUND THE STATION AND REFERENCE MARKS IS COVERED WITH LOW SCATTERED BRUSH, CACTUS, AND WEEDS.                            STATION RECOVERY (1961)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1961 (MLO) STATION AND REFERENCE MARKS SEARCHED FOR BUT NOT RECOVERED.  THE MARKS WERE PROBABLY DESTROYED WHEN HOUSES WERE BUILT ON PUNTA CASCAJO.
markers.setting: SET IN TOP OF CONCRETE MONUMENT
markers.stability: MAY HOLD, BUT OF TYPE COMMONLY SUBJECT TOSURFACE MOTION

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1899 (WCH) STATION IS ON THE SMALL SEMI-CIRCULAR BATTERY JUST ABOVE THE WATER, AT THE EXTREME POINT OF THE MORRO.

BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JJL) THE STATION IS LOCATED ON ROOSEVELT ROADS NAVAL STATION ON A POINT OF LAND IN THE SOUTHEAST SECTION OF THE NAVAL STATION.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM GATE NO. 3, SOUTH GATE, GO SOUTHERLY FOR 0.05 MILES TO A SIDE ROAD ON THE LEFT, LANGLEY DRIVE, TURN LEFT ON LANGLEY DRIVE AND GO EASTERLY FOR 1.8 MILES TO A SIDE ROAD ON THE RIGHT, TURN RIGHT ON F.D.R. DRIVE AND GO SOUTHEAST FOR 2.4 MILES TO THE END OF THE ROAD AT A CIRCLE DRIVE, TURN LEFT AND GO DOWN HILL FOR ABOUT 50 YARDS TO THE STATION IN A LARGE GRASSY LAWN.  THE STATION IS 103 FEET SOUTHEAST OF THE SOUTHEAST CORNER OF BUILDING NO. 672.  IT IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED POINT 2 1966 BRAZED TO THE TOP OF A 3 INCH SOIL PIPE AND SET IN A MASS OF CONCRETE FLUSH WITH LAWN.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 1 IS 95 FEET EAST OF THE SOUTHEAST CORNER OF BUILDING NO. 672.  IT IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED POINT 2 NO 1 1966 BRAZED TO THE TOP OF A 3 INCH SOIL PIPE PROJECTING 2 INCHES.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 2 IS 35 FEET SOUTH OF THE SOUTHEAST CORNER OF BUILDING NO. 672.  IT IS A 12 INCH SQUARE CONCRETE MONUMENT WITH A 2 INCH PIPE SET IN THE TOP.  THE 2 INCH PIPE HAS A WOODEN CENTER WITH A NAIL DRIVEN IN IT, THE NAIL IS THE POINT OBSERVED.  THE MARK PROJECTS 7 INCHES ON THE LOW SIDE.  HEIGHT OF LIGHT ABOVE STATION MARK 1.3 METERS.
markers.setting: SET IN CONCRETE IN A CLAY TILE PIPE
markers.stability: MARK OF QUESTIONABLE OR UNKNOWN STABILITY

markers.description: BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1934 STATION IS CENTER OF LIGHT TOWER.  NOTE--THIS APPARENTLY IS NOT THE SAME LIGHTHOUSE REPORTED BY THE U.S.C. AND G.S. IN 1901.  THIS LIGHTHOUSE APPEARS TO BE BETWEEN POINT AGUJEREADA AND POINT BORINQUEN.                            STATION RECOVERY (1975)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1975 (JDS) THE STATION WAS RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED IN THE 1952 DESCRIPTION AND FOUND TO BE IN GOOD CONDITION.

BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1952 (JOP) STATION IS LOCATED AT THE NW CORNER OF RAMEY AIR FORCE BASE, AND ON THE CONCRETE RUNWAY WHICH ENCIRCLES THE UPPER PART OF THE PT. BORINQUEN LIGHTHOUSE.  IT IS A STANDARD TRIANGULATION-STATION DISK, STAMPED PT BORINQUEN L H 1952 AND CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN THE RUNWAY.  IT IS 7.55 FT. SE OF THE CENTER OF THE LIGHTHOUSE.  NO REFERENCE MARKS WERE SET.  STATION RAMEY (U.S.A.F.) IS LOCATED ABOUT 0.4 MI. S OF THE STATION, ABOUT 500 FT. SW OF THE GOLF CLUBHOUSE, AND 45 FT. W OF THE 18TH GREEN OF THE GOLF COURSE.  IT IS A STANDARD U.S. AIR FORCE SHORAN TRIANGULATION-STATION DISK, STAMPED RAMEY 1953 USAF AND CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN OUTCROPPING BEDROCK.  HEIGHT OF LIGHT ABOVE STATION MARK 1 METER.                            STATION RECOVERY (1977)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1977 (WFP) THE STATION WAS RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION AND AS DESCRIBED IN THE 1952 DESCRIPTION.  RAMEY AFB IS NOW IN-ACTIVE.  THE STATION WAS USED AS A CHECK ANGLE FOR NUCLEAR.
markers.setting: SET IN A PAVEMENT SUCH AS STREET, SIDEWALK, CURB, ETC.
markers.stability: MARK OF QUESTIONABLE OR UNKNOWN STABILITY

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1902 (JN) STATION IS LOCATED ON A PROMINENT POINT ON THE N COAST OF PUERTO RICO, ABOUT 10 MILES E OF SAN JUAN.  THE POINT IS CALLED CONGREJOS BY THE NATIVES LIVING IN THE VICINITY.  AN INLET TO A LAGOON MAKES IN JUST W OF THE STATION AND THIS INLET IS CALLED LALOCA DE LA CONGREJOS.  ABOUT 1 MILE TO THE EASTWARD IS POINT MALDANADO.  THE STATION IS ABOUT 60 FEET BACK FROM THE SHORE BLUFF.  IT IS IN AN OPEN PLACE ON THE HIGHEST PART OF THE POINT.  A TRIPOD SIGNAL WITH BLACK AND WHITE FLAGS WAS ERECTED HERE AND A WHITE LOZENGO FACING E AND W WAS PLACED ON THE POLE ABOUT 4 FEET ABOVE THE CROTCH.  THE STATION WAS MARKED BY A 2-INCH PIPE 2 FEET LONG SET INTO THE CEMENT.  THE PIPE PROJECTS ABOVE THE GROUND ABOUT 3 INCHES.  THE CENTER OF THE HEAD OF A NAIL CEMENTED INTO THE CENTER OF THE PIPE IS THE STATION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1921)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1921 (JHP) STATION RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED IN GOOD CONDITION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1962)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1962 (MLO) THE STATION WAS SEARCHED FOR BUT NOT RECOVERED.  A LARGE CONCRETE BUNKER HAS BEEN CONSTRUCTED IN THIS AREA.  SAND HAS BEEN PILED ON TOP OF THE BUNKER MAKING A SMALL KNOLL.  THE STATION WAS PROBABLY DESTROYED DURING THIS CONSTRUCTION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1964)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1964 (GWM) THE POINT WAS VISITED BUT THE MARK WAS NOT FOUND.  IT IS PROBABLY LOST SINCE IT WAS ONLY ABOUT 60 FEET BACK FROM THE SHORE BLUFF.  TWO LARGE CONCRETE MONUMENTS WERE FOUND ON THE EDGE OF THE BLUFF.  IN EACH CENTER WAS A BRASS ROD.  THE TOP OF ONE HAS THE LETTERS US NO. 3 AND THE OTHER US NO. 4 CUT IN THE CONCRETE. IT IS POSSIBLE THAT THESE WERE REFERENCE MARKS TO THE STATION PUT IN AT SOME TIME BY SOMEBODY IN AN ATTEMPT TO PRESERVE THE LOCATION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1965)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1965 (JJL) A SEARCH WAS MADE FOR THE STATION BUT IT WAS NOT RECOVERED.  A NEW STATION WAS ESTABLISHED IN THE NEAR VICINITY.  SEE THE DESCRIPTION FOR POINT CONGREJOS 2.  OFFICE NOTE--STATION IS LOST.  (SEE G-16362)
markers.setting: SET INTO TOP OF METAL PIPE DRIVEN INTO GROUND
markers.stability: MARK OF QUESTIONABLE OR UNKNOWN STABILITY

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JJL) THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 10 MILES EAST OF SAN JUAN, 4-1/2 MILES EAST-NORTHEAST OF SANTURCE, ON A POINT OF LAND KNOWN AS POINT CONGREJOS AND ABOUT 300 FEET WEST OF THE HIGHEST POINT IN THE GENERAL VICINITY.  THE LAND IS OWNED BY THE COMMONWEALTH GOVERNMENT.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE LOIZA STREET POST OFFICE IN SANTURCE, GO EASTERLY ON LOIZA STREET FOR 5.2 MILES TO A CONCRETE BRIDGE AND A LARGE BOAT DOCK ON THE RIGHT, SOUTH, SIDE OF THE ROAD.  CONTINUE EAST FOR ABOUT 200 FEET TO A Y-FORK.  TAKE THE LEFT FORK AND GO NORTH FOR 0.05 MILE TO A Y-FORK.  TAKE THE RIGHT FORK AND GO EAST FOR 0.05 MILE TO THE STATION ON THE RIGHT, SOUTH, SIDE OF THE ROAD.  THE STATION MARK, STAMPED POINT CONGREJOS 2 1965, IS A STANDARD DISK SET IN THE TOP OF A CYLINDRICAL CONCRETE MONUMENT THAT IS 12 INCHES IN DIAMETER AND IS FLUSH WITH THE GROUND.  IT IS 70 FEET SOUTH OF THE CENTER OF THE ROAD AND 67 FEET EAST OF THE SOUTHEAST CORNER OF AN ABANDONED CONCRETE FOUNDATION.  REFERENCE MARK NO.1, STAMPED POINT CONGREJOS 2 NO 1 1965, IS A STANDARD DISK SET IN THE TOP OF A 12-INCH SQUARE CONCRETE MONUMENT THAT IS FLUSH WITH THE GROUND.  IT IS 128 FEET SOUTH OF THE CENTER OF THE ROAD AND 127 FEET SOUTHEAST OF THE SOUTHEAST CORNER OF THE ABANDONED CONCRETE FOUNDATION.  REFERENCE MARK NO.2, STAMPED POINT CONGREJOS 2 NO 2 1965, IS A STANDARD DISK SET IN THE TOP OF A CYLINDRICAL CONCRETE MONUMENT THAT IS 12 INCHES IN DIAMETER AND IS FLUSH WITH THE GROUND.  IT IS 133 FEET SOUTH OF THE CENTER OF THE ROAD AND 87 FEET SOUTH-SOUTHEAST OF THE SOUTHEAST CORNER OF THE ABANDONED CONCRETE FOUNDATION.  NO SUITABLE LOCATION FOR AN AZIMUTH MARK.
markers.setting: SET IN TOP OF CONCRETE MONUMENT
markers.stability: MAY HOLD, BUT OF TYPE COMMONLY SUBJECT TOSURFACE MOTION

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1901 (JEM) THIS IS THE PINNACLE (OR FINAL) MARKING CENTER OF ROOF OF THE LAMP ROOM AT FIGURAS LIGHTHOUSE.  THERE HAS BEEN NO CHANGE IN THE LIGHTHOUSE SINCE 1899.                            STATION RECOVERY (1966)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JJL) THE STATION WAS RECOVERED AND FOUND IN POOR CONDITION.  THE LIGHTHOUSE HAS BEEN ABANDONED.  A NEW STATION WAS ESTABLISHED IN THE NEAR VICINITY.  SEE THE DESCRIPTION FOR STATION FIGG.                            STATION RECOVERY (1970)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1970 (JKW) LIGHTHOUSE RECOVERED STILL INTACT.  A NEW AUTOMATIC LIGHT HAS BEEN INSTALLED ATOP THE OLD STRUCTURE.  THE LIGHT, WHICH IS ON A SKELETON STEEL SUPERSTRUCTURE, IS UNDOUBTEDLY NOT THE SAME AS THE PUBLISHED POSITION.  ANY OBSERVATIONS UPON THE LIGHTHOUSE WOULD HAVE TO BE MADE ON THE CENTER OF THE OLD STRUCTURE.                            STATION RECOVERY (1971)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1971 (EKM) THE STATION WAS RECOVERED AND IS THE CENTER OF THE OLD STRUCTURE.  THE DESCRIPTIONS BY JJL IN 1966 AND JKW IN 1970 INDICATE THE CONSTRUCTION OF THE NEW STRUCTURE IN THE IMMEDIATE VICINITY.                            STATION RECOVERY (1975)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1975 (RMB) A NEW U.S. COAST GUARD LIGHT (LIGHT LIST, VOLUME II, 1975, 1379) HAS BEEN INSTALLED IN THE CENTER OF WHAT WAS PROBABLY THE ORIGINAL LAMP ROOM OF THE LIGHTHOUSE.  ALTHOUGH THE NEW LIGHT IS PROBABLY WITHIN LESS THAN ONE FOOT OF THE SAME LOCATION, THE PINNACLE MARKING THE STATION IN THE CENTER OF THE ROOF HAS BEEN REMOVED.  THE LIGHTHOUSE WAS ABANDONED FOR A NEW STEEL TOWER ON THE POINT FROM THE EARLY 1960S UNTIL RECENTLY, WHEN THE LIGHT WAS RE-INSTALLED IN THE ORIGINAL 1899 STRUCTURE.  THE BUILDING IS STILL ABANDONED EXCEPT FOR THE NEW UNMANNED LIGHT.

BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JWC) THE STATION IS LOCATED 14 AIRLINE MILES NORTHWEST OF MAYAGUEZ, 10-1/2 AIRLINE MILES SOUTHWEST OF AGUADILLA AND 2 AIRLINE MILES NORTHWEST OF RINCON.  IT IS LOCATED ON A POINT OF LAND KNOWN AS POINT HIGUERO.  THE LIGHTHOUSE IS A CYLINDRICAL CONCRETE STRUCTURE, PAINTED GREY IN COLOR AND IT IS ABOUT 50 FEET HIGH.  A TRAVERSE CONNECTION WAS MADE TO TRIANGULATION STATION HIGUERO, THE DISTANCE BEING 5.87 FEET AND 1.790 METERS NORTH-NORTHEAST OF STATION HIGUERO.

BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1901 (JEM) THIS STATION WAS OCCUPIED ECCENTRICALLY, THE INSTRUMENT BEING MOUNTED ON THE BRICK ROOF, NEAR THE SE CORNER OF THE MAIN BUILDING.  A MARK ON A BRICK, CONSISTING OF A NUMBER OF RADIATING LINES FROM THE CENTER, INDICATES THE CENTER OF THE INSTRUMENT.                            STATION RECOVERY (1952)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US NAVY 1952 THE STATION WAS DESTROYED.  A NEW STRUCTURE WAS ERECTED AT PT. JIGUERO LIGHT IN 1921.

BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1901 (JEM) THIS STATION IS AT THE N END OF THE BASE MEASURED ALONG THE RAILROAD TRACK, TO CONNECT POINT JIGUERO LIGHT HOUSE AND RINCON.  THE STUB WAS SET IN THE EDGE OF THE EMBANKMENT, ON THE E SIDE OF THE TRACK, NEAR THE STATION, ON W SIDE OF THE TRACK IS ONE OF THE RAILROAD COMPANYS HOUSES FOR ITS EMPLOYEES.  ON THE S SIDE OF THIS HOUSE IS A FRAME WORK OF FOUR POLES APPARENTLY FOR DRYING PURPOSES.  THE STUB IS IN LINE WITH THE TWO SOUTHERLY POLES.  IT WAS BUT 5 OR 6 INCHES FROM FOOTPATH, AND WILL PROBABLY NOT REMAIN LONG UNDISTURBED.

BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1901 (JEM) THIS STATION IS USED IN REFERRING POINT JIGUERO LIGHT HOUSE TO RINCON POINT.  THE STATION MARK WAS A WOODEN PLUG DRIVEN DOWN IN RAILROAD EMBANKMENT (W OF TRACK), ABOUT 10 INCHES S OF S END OF TANGENT, WHICH IS N OF CURVE IN FRONT OF THE LIGHTHOUSE.  THE STUB WITH A TACK IN THE TOP IS ABOUT 1 FOOT W OF THE FOOTPATH ALONG THE W RAIL.

BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JJL) THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 6 MILES EAST-NORTHEAST OF SAN JUAN, 5 MILES NORTH OF HIGHWAY 3 AND ON PUERTO RICO COMMONWEALTH PROPERTY.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE SAN JUAN, LOIZA STREET STATION POST OFFICE IN CONDADO, GO EAST ON LOIZA STREET FOR 5.0 MILES TO THE END OF THE PAVEMENT JUST AFTER CROSSING A SMALL BRIDGE.  CONTINUE EASTERLY ON A DIRT ROAD FOR 0.9 MILE TO A FORK.  TAKE THE LEFT FORK AND CONTINUE EAST AND NORTHEAST ON A TRACK ROAD FOR 0.05 MILE TO A FORK.  TAKE THE RIGHT FORK AND CONTINUE NORTHEAST ON A TRACK ROAD FOR 0.1 MILE TO A SIDE ROAD ON THE RIGHT AND THE END OF TRUCK TRAVEL.  FROM HERE PACK SOUTH FOR 25 YARDS TO AN OLD WATER RESERVIOR AND THE STATION.  THE STATION MARK IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED POINT MALDONADO 1965, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN THE TOP OF A CONCRETE WATER RESERVIOR.  IT IS 10.6 FEET WEST OF THE EAST END OF THE RESERVOIR AND 2.3 FEET SOUTH OF THE NORTH EDGE OF THE RESERVIOR.  REFERENCE MARK 1 IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED POINT MALDONADO NO 1 1965, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A ROCK OUTCROP THAT IS FLUSH WITH THE SURROUNDING SURFACE.  IT IS 8 FEET SOUTHEAST OF THE SOUTHEAST CORNER OF THE RESERVIOR.  REFERENCE MARK 2 IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED POINT MALDONADO NO 2 1965, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN THE TOP OF THE CONCRETE WATER RESERVIOR.  IT IS 1 FOOT NORTHEAST OF THE SOUTHWEST CORNER OF THE RESERVIOR.  NO SUITABLE PLACE WAS FOUND FOR AN AZIMUTH MARK.
markers.setting: SET IN A MAT FOUNDATION OR CONCRETE SLAB OTHER THAN
markers.stability: MAY HOLD, BUT OF TYPE COMMONLY SUBJECT TOSURFACE MOTION

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1902 (JN) STATION IS LOCATED ON POINT MARIA, ON THE N COAST OF PUERTO RICO, ABOUT 5 MILES E OF SAN JUAN.  IT IS ABOUT 200 FEET BACK FROM HIGH-WATER LINE.  THE GROUND IS LOW, SANDY AND COVERED WITH GRASS.  A TRIPOD SIGNAL WITH BLACK AND WHITE FLAGS WAS ERECTED HERE AND THE STATION WAS MARKED BY AN IRON PIPE 2 INCHES IN DIAMETER AND 2 FEET LONG SET IN CEMENT.  THE PIPE PROJECTS ABOUT 3 INCHES ABOVE THE SURFACE OF THE GROUND.  STATION IS THE CENTER OF THE HEAD OF A NAIL CEMENTED INTO THE CENTER OF THE IRON PIPE.  THERE IS AN OLD SPANISH STATION ABOUT 100 FEET SE OF THE STATION.  THE SPANISH STATION IS MARKED BY A STONE POST ABOUT 8 INCHES IN DIAMETER SET INTO THE GROUND AND PROJECTING 6 INCHES.  THERE IS A 2 INCH HOLE IN THE TOP OF THE STONE.                            STATION RECOVERY (1964)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1964 (GWM) THE POINT IS ALL BUILT UP NOW.  THE HOUSES ARE ON A SAND FILL ABOUT 6 FEET HIGH.  THERE IS A SCHOOL WHERE THE STATION IS SUPPOSED TO BE.  THE STATION WAS NOT FOUND AND IT CAN BE CONSIDERED PROBABLY LOST.                            STATION RECOVERY (1965)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1965 (JJL) THE STATION WAS SEARCHED FOR BUT NOT FOUND.  IT IS BELIEVED ALL MARKS WERE DESTROYED DURING THE CONSTRUCTION OF SEVERAL BUILDINGS WHICH ARE NOW IN THE AREA OF THE STATION.  A NEW STATION POINT MARIA 2 WAS ESTABLISHED, SEE DESCRIPTION THEREOF.
markers.setting: SET INTO TOP OF METAL PIPE DRIVEN INTO GROUND
markers.stability: MARK OF QUESTIONABLE OR UNKNOWN STABILITY

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JJL) THE STATION IS LOCATED 3 AIRLINE MILES EAST OF SAN JUAN, 1 AIRLINE MILE EAST-NORTHEAST OF SANTURCE AND ON A POINT OF LAND WHICH IS LOCALLY KNOWN AS PUNTA LAS MARIAS.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE LOIZA POST OFFICE IN SANTURCE, GO EASTERLY ON LOIZA STREET FOR 1.1 MILES TO EMA JAGUA STREET.  TURN LEFT AND GO NORTHERLY ON EMA JAGUA STREET FOR 0.2 MILE TO THE END OF THE STREET AT A SCHOOL.  THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 50 FEET WEST OF THIS POINT IN A OUTCROP OF CORAL ROCK.  THE STATION MARK IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED POINT MARIA 2 1965, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN OUTCROPPING CORAL ROCK WHICH PROJECTS 1 FOOT.  IT IS 6 FEET NORTH OF A WOVEN WIRE FENCE AND ABOUT 150 FEET SOUTH OF THE SHORE LINE.  REFERENCE MARK 1 IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED POINT MARIA 2 NO 1 1965, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN OUTCROPPING CORAL ROCK WHICH PROJECTS 4 INCHES.  REFERENCE MARK 2 IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED POINT MARIA 2 NO 2 1965, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN OUTCROPPING CORAL ROCK WHICH PROJECTS 1 FOOT.  NO AZIMUTH MARK WAS ESTABLISHED AT THIS STATION.
markers.setting: SET IN ROCK OUTCROP
markers.stability: MOST RELIABLE AND EXPECTED TO HOLDPOSITION/ELEVATION WELL

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1902 (JN) THIS STATION IS ON A LONG LOW SANDY POINT JUST E OF THE MOUTH OF THE RIO GRANDE RIVER, AND ABOUT 5 MILES, IN A STRAIGHT LINE, FROM THE VILLAGE OF LOIZA.  THE STATION IS ABOUT ON THE N-AND-S AXIS OF THIS TONGUE OF LAND ABOUT 80 FEET S OF THE SHORE LINE AND ABOUT 20 FEET S OF THE EDGE OF THE CULTIVATED LAND.  THERE ARE TWO ISOLATED COCOANUT PALMS NEAR THE STATION, ONE OF WHICH IS ABOUT DUE N AND THE OTHER NE FROM THE STATION.  AN IRON PIPE 2 INCHES IN DIAMETER AND 2 FEET LONG MARKS THE STATION.  ABOUT 4 INCHES OF THE PIPE PROJECTS ABOVE THE GROUND.  THE CENTER OF THE HEAD OF A NAIL CEMENTED INTO THE CENTER OF THE PIPE MARKS THE STATION.  A TRIPOD SIGNAL WAS ERECTED OVER THIS STATION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1961)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1961 (MLO) STATION WAS SEARCHED FOR BUT NOT RECOVERED.  THE AREA IS NOW THICKLY COVERED WITH COCOANUT PALMS.
markers.setting: SET INTO TOP OF METAL PIPE DRIVEN INTO GROUND
markers.stability: MARK OF QUESTIONABLE OR UNKNOWN STABILITY

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JJL) THE STATION IS LOCATED ON A LOW, SANDY, PALM-COVERED PENINSULA EXTENDING ABOUT 1-1/4 MILES OUT FROM THE MAINLAND AND IS LOCALLY KNOWN AS POINT MIQUILLO.  IT IS ABOUT 3-1/2 MILES NORTHEAST OF THE RIO GRANDE RIVER.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE POST OFFICE IN RIO GRANDE, GO EAST FOR 0.05 MILE TO HIGHWAY 187, TURN RIGHT AND GO SOUTHEAST ON HIGHWAY 187 FOR 0.35 MILE TO ITS JUNCTION WITH HIGHWAY 3.  TURN LEFT AND GO EAST ON HIGHWAY 3 FOR 1.35 MILES TO A SIDE ROAD ON THE LEFT (JUST BEFORE REACHING KILOMETER POST 26.9), TURN LEFT AND GO 0.05 MILE TO A CHAIN LINK GATE, PASS THROUGH THE GATE AND GO NORTHERLY FOR 4.75 MILES TO THE NORTH END OF THE POINT, THEN EASTERLY FOR ABOUT 0.1 MILE TO THE STATION.  THE STATION IS ABOUT 50 YARDS NORTHWEST OF THE SOUTHEAST SHORE AND 35 FEET SOUTHWEST OF THE NORTHEAST SHORE.  IT IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED POINT MIQUILLO 2 1965, BRAZED TO THE TOP OF A 3 INCH SOIL PIPE SET IN CEMENT AND PROJECTING 4 INCHES.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 1 IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED POINT MIQUILLO 2 NO 1 1965, BRAZED TO THE TOP OF A 3 INCH SOIL PIPE SET IN CEMENT AND PROJECTING 4 INCHES.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 2 IS A NAIL SET IN CEMENT INSIDE A 3 INCH SOIL PIPE WHICH PROJECTS 2 INCHES.  R M 2 IS ETCHED IN THE CEMENT.  THERE WAS NO SUITABLE PLACE FOR AN AZIMUTH MARK.
markers.setting: SET INTO TOP OF METAL PIPE DRIVEN INTO GROUND
markers.stability: MARK OF QUESTIONABLE OR UNKNOWN STABILITY

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JJL) THE STATION IS LOCATED 5-1/4 AIRLINE MILES NORTHWEST OF LUQUILLO, 5-1/4 AIRLINE MILES NORTHEAST OF RIO GRANDE AND 3 AIRLINE MILES NORTH OF MAMEYES.  IT IS ON A POINT OF LAND KNOWN AS PUNTA PICUA.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE INTERSECTION OF HIGHWAYS 3 AND 968 IN THE NORTHEAST EDGE OF MAMEYES, GO NORTHERLY ON HIGHWAY 968 FOR 0.8 MILE TO A SIDE ROAD RIGHT.  TURN RIGHT AND GO EASTERLY ON A BLADED ROAD FOR 0.25 MILE TO A FORK AT SEVERAL BUILDINGS.  TURN RIGHT AND GO SOUTH, EAST AND NORTHEAST ON A WINDING BLADED ROAD FOR 1.35 MILES TO A FORK.  KEEP RIGHT, GO NORTHWEST AND WEST ON A SAND ROAD FOR 0.35 MILE TO A GATE. PASS THROUGH THE GATE AND CONTINUE WESTERLY ON A WINDING SAND ROAD FOR 0.7 MILE TO A REVERSE Y FORK.  KEEP LEFT AND GO NORTHWEST AND NORTH ON A SAND ROAD FOR 0.7 MILE TO THE STATION ON THE RIGHT.  THE STATION MARK IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED POINT PIGUA 1965, SET IN THE TOP OF A 12 INCH ROUND CONCRETE MONUMENT PROJECTING 4 INCHES.  IT IS 17 FEET NORTH OF THE CENTER OF THE SAND ROAD.  REFERENCE MARK 1 IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED POINT PICUA NO 1 1965, SET IN THE TOP OF A 12 INCH ROUND CONCRETE MONUMENT PROJECTING 2 INCHES.  IT IS 20 FEET SOUTH OF THE CENTER OF THE SAND ROAD.  REFERENCE MARK 2 IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED POINT PICUA NO 2 1965, SET IN THE TOP OF A 12 INCH ROUND CONCRETE MONUMENT PROJECTING 2 INCHES.  IT IS 24 FEET SOUTH OF THE CENTER OF THE SAND ROAD.  NO AZIMUTH MARK WAS ESTABLISHED AT THIS STATION.
markers.setting: SET IN TOP OF CONCRETE MONUMENT
markers.stability: MAY HOLD, BUT OF TYPE COMMONLY SUBJECT TOSURFACE MOTION

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1901 (JN) THE STATION IS ON THE HIGHEST POINT OF THE S END OF AN ISLAND E OF A PROMONTORY OF THAT NAME ABOUT 4 MILES W OF SAN JUAN.  THE POINT IS ON THE OPEN GROUND OF A GRASSY KNOLL AND IS MARKED BY A GALVANIZED IRON PIPE 2 FEET BY 2 INCHES SET IN A SOLID BED OF CEMENT.  THE CEMENT BED IS 1-FOOT IN DIAMETER AT TOP AND IS 1 INCH ABOVE THE SURFACE OF THE GROUND AND 4 INCHES BELOW TOP OF PIPE.  THE PIPE IS FILLED WITH SMALL STONES TO WITHIN 5 INCHES OF THE TOP AND THE REMAINDER WITH CEMENT.  THE POINT IS THE CENTER OF THE HEAD OF A WIRE NAIL DRIVEN IN THE CEMENT IN THE PIPE FLUSH WITH ITS SURFACE.  THE POINT IS CLOSE TO AN OLD SPANISH TRIANGULATION POINT AS EVIDENCED BY THE FACT THAT A LARGE TRIANGULAR BED OF CEMENT 3-1/2 INCHES ON A SIDE WITH THE CENTRAL PIPE HOLE WAS FOUND BROKEN IN 3 PIECES.  ALSO TWO PIECES OF CAST-IRON PIPE WERE FOUND IN THE VICINITY.                            STATION RECOVERY (1931)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1931 STATION RECOVERED AS ORIGINALLY DESCRIBED.  CEMENT BED AROUND TUBE REPLACED.                            STATION RECOVERY (1946)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1946 LETTER OF MR. E.G. RUBIO, HQ. ANTILLES DEPT., OFFICE OF DEPT. ENGR., APO 851, -- PM, MIAMI, FLA. DATED 10/30/46--  STATION RECOVERED AND THE PIPE STILL IN PLACE.  SET A PIECE OF IRON BAR CENTERED INTO THE PIPE.                            STATION RECOVERY (1961)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1961 (FEN) STATION RECOVERED AT LOCATION DESCRIBED.  STATION IS MARKED BY A 2 IN IRON PIPE SET IN A ROUNDED MOUND OF CEMENT 18 IN IN DIAMETER AND 8 IN ABOVE THE GROUND.  THE PIPE IS FLUSH WITH THE TOP OF THE CEMENT AND IS FILLED WITH CEMENT.  THE POINT IS THE INTERSECTION OF A CROSS STAMPED IN THE HEAD OF AN IRON BOLT SUNK IN THE CEMENT IN THE PIPE AND FLUSH WITH ITS SURFACE.  THE CONCRETE IS MARKED WITH THE NUMBER 1898 AND THE INITIALS ZM AND LQ SCRATCHED IN THE SURFACE.  NO EVIDENCE OF THE OLD SPANISH TRIANGULATION POINT WAS FOUND IN THE AREA, WHICH IS OVERGROWN WITH BRUSH 6-12 FEET HIGH.  ON U.S. GEOLOGICAL SURVEY QUADRANGLE CHART BAYAMON (1--20 000, 1957), THE STATION IS NOTED AS BOLT.  THE CHIEF OF THE TOPOGRAPHIC BRANCH, PUERTO RICO DEPARTMENT OF PUBLIC WORKS, WHO SUPERVISED A SUBSEQUENT SURVEY AND THE RECONSTRUCTION OF THE MONUMENT, ADVISES THAT THE DESIGNATION BOLT IS IN ERROR AND THE STATION IS ACTUALLY POINT SALINAS.                            STATION RECOVERY (1964)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1964 (GWM) ABOUT 4 MILES W OF SAN JUAN AT POINT SALINAS ON THE S END OF EAST ISLAND.  ON THE HIGHEST POINT OF THE SOUTHERN END OF THE ISLAND.  THERE IS A DIM TRAIL LEAD-TO IT.  THE MARK IS AN IRON PIPE SET IN CONCRETE WITH A WIRE NAIL SET IN THE CENTER.  THE 2 IN IRON PIPE IS SET IN A ROUNDED MOUND OF CONCRETE 18 IN IN DIAMETER AND 8 IN ABOVE THE GROUND.  THE CONCRETE IS MARKED WITH 1898 AND THE INITIALS ZM AND LQ SCRATCHED IN THE SURFACE.  THE STATION IS CALLED BOLT ON THE 1--20,000,1957, USGS, QUAD. SHEET. STATION SAL (PAA, 1961) IS 191.04 METERS N.                            STATION RECOVERY (1966)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JJL) THE STATION MARK WAS RECOVERED AND FOUND IN GOOD CONDITION.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 1 AND REFERENCE MARK NO. 2 WERE ESTABLISHED.  A COMPLETE DESCRIPTION FOLLOWS--  THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 5-1/2 MILES EAST-NORTHEAST OF DORADO, 5 MILES NORTHWEST OF CATANO AND ON THE HIGHEST POINT OF A POINT OF LAND KNOWN AS POINT SALINAS.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE PLAZA IN DORADO, GO EASTERLY FOR 0.75 MILE TO A T-INTERSECTION.  TURN LEFT AND GO NORTH AND EAST ON HIGHWAY 165 FOR 5.4 MILES TO A SIDE ROAD LEFT AND SIGN US ARMY PUNTA SALINAS TRAINING AND REC. AREA.  TURN LEFT AND GO NORTH FOR 0.75 MILE TO A Y-FORK.  TAKE THE RIGHT FORK AND CONTINUE NORTHERLY FOR 0.2 MILE TO A STEEL GATE.  PASS THROUGH THE GATE AND GO NORTHEASTERLY FOR 0.25 MILE TO THE TOP OF A RIDGE AND THE END OF TRUCK TRAVEL.  PACK SOUTHEASTERLY FOR ABOUT 100 YARDS TO THE HIGHEST POINT IN THE GENERAL VICINITY AND THE STATION.  THE STATION MARK IS A CENTER-PUNCHED, 1/2-INCH STEEL ROD SET IN THE TOP OF AN IRREGULAR MASS OF CONCRETE THAT PROJECTS 6 INCHES.  1898 LQ IS INSCRIBED IN THE CONCRETE.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 1, STAMPED POINT SALINAS NO 1 1901, IS A STANDARD DISK SET IN CONCRETE IN THE TOP OF A 3-INCH, CAST-IRON PIPE THAT PROJECTS 6 INCHES.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 2, STAMPED POINT SALINAS NO 2 1901, IS A STANDARD DISK SET IN CONCRETE IN THE TOP OF A 3-INCH, CAST-IRON PIPE THAT PROJECTS 1 FOOT.  AIRLINE DISTANCE AND DIRECTION FROM NEAREST TOWN 5 MILES NORTHWEST OF CATANO.
markers.setting: SET INTO TOP OF METAL PIPE DRIVEN INTO GROUND
markers.stability: MARK OF QUESTIONABLE OR UNKNOWN STABILITY

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1901 (JBB) STATION IS ON THE N END OF THE PROMINENT CAPE 1-1/2 MILES W OF CAPE SAN JUAN LIGHTHOUSE.  IT IS AT THE EDGE OF THE BUSH LINE AND ABOUT 50 YARDS BACK FROM THE N END OF THE CLIFF.  MARKED BY A CEMENT BLOCK 1-1/2 FEET LONG BY 6 INCHES SQUARE, WITH A NAIL IN THE CENTER.  THE LETTERS U.S. ARE CUT ON THE TOP.                            STATION RECOVERY (1902)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1902 (JN) THIS POINT, WHICH IS CALLED SAN DIEGO ON THE U.S.C. AND G.S. CHART OF 1901, BUT IS NOT KNOWN LOCALLY BY THAT NAME, IS A ROCKY PROMONTORY ON THE NE CORNER OF THE ISLAND AND IS THE FIRST POINT W FROM CAPE SAN JUAN LIGHTHOUSE ON THE N COAST OF THE ISLAND AND ABOUT 2 MILES DISTANT FROM IT, AIR LINE.  IT HAS APPARENTLY BEEN USED AS A TRIANGULATION, OR, PERHAPS, A HYDROGRAPHIC AND TOPOGRAPHIC POINT WITHIN RECENT YEARS BECAUSE A ROUGHLY DRESSED WHITE STONE BLOCK ABOUT 6 INCHES SQUARE AND WITH THE LETTERS U.S. CUT IN ITS TOP SURFACE AND WITH A SMALL HOLE MARKING ITS CENTER WAS FOUND EMBEDDED IN THE GROUND ON ABOUT THE HIGHEST POINT OF THE PROMONTORY.  THERE WAS ALSO EVIDENCE THAT THE LOW TREES OR BUSHES WITH WHICH THE POINT WAS COVERED HAD BEEN CUT SO AS TO COMMAND THE SEAWARD VIEW.  A SIGNAL POLE WAS PLUMBED OVER THE ABOVE MENTIONED BLOCK.                            STATION RECOVERY (1964)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1964 (GWM) STATION RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED AND FOUND TO BE IN GOOD CONDITION.  DESCRIPTION OF STATION IS ADEQUATE.  NO REFERENCE MARKS WERE FOUND.  STATION SHOWS REPEATED USE BY SURVEYORS.  TO REACH THE STATION BY BOAT, LAND AT THE WESTWARD SAND BEACH IN BAHIA LAS CABEZAS, (A SMALL ROCK POINT AFORD A LEA FOR THIS BEACH), PACK WESTWARD TO SADDLE OF RIDGE, THEN NORTH TO HIGHEST POINT AND STATION AS DESCRIBED.  THE STATION AREA IS COVERED WITH LOW BRIER AND CACTUS.                            STATION RECOVERY (1965)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1965 (JJL) THE STATION MARK WAS RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED IN THE 1901 DESCRIPTION AND WAS FOUND TO BE IN GOOD CONDITION.  TWO REFERENCE MARKS WERE ESTABLISHED.  A COMPLETE NEW DESCRIPTION FOLLOWS--  THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 3-1/2 MILES NORTH OF FAJARDO AND ON THE NORTH END OF A PROMINENT, ROCKY CAPE APPROXIMATELY 2 MILES WEST OF THE CAPE SAN JUAN LIGHTHOUSE.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE PLAZA IN FAJARDO, GO EAST-SOUTHEAST FOR 1 BLOCK TO A CROSS STREET.  TURN LEFT AND GO NORTH ON CELIS AGUILERAI STREET FOR 0.25 MILE TO A Y-FORK.  KEEP THE RIGHT FORK AND GO EAST ON HIGHWAY 195 FOR 0.3 MILE TO A SIDE ROAD LEFT.  TURN LEFT AND GO NORTH ON HIGHWAY 927 FOR 2.7 MILES TO A Y-FORK.  KEEP THE LEFT FORK AND GO NORTH ON THE PAVED ROAD FOR 0.45 MILE TO A Y-FORK AND A SIGN U.S. COAST GUARD CAPE SAN JUAN LORSTA.  KEEP THE LEFT FORK, AS PER SIGN, AND GO NORTHEAST ON THE PAVED ROAD FOR 0.3 MILE TO WHERE THE ROAD CURVES TO THE EAST AND A BOAT DOCK ON THE NORTH SIDE OF THE ROAD AND THE END OF TRUCK TRAVEL.  PACK WEST AND NORTHWEST ALONG THE SHORELINE, CROSSING AREAS OF LARGE ROCKS, FOR APPROXIMATELY 1-1/2 MILES TO THE FURTHER MOST POINT OF LAND AND THE STATION ON THE HIGHEST POINT OF THE CAPE.  (A 1 HOUR PACK.)  THE STATION MARK IS THE POINT OF A NAIL PROTRUDING FROM THE TOP CENTER OF A 6-INCH SQUARE, CONCRETE MONUMENT THAT PROJECTS 5 INCHES WITH THE LETTERS U.S. INSCRIBED ON TOP.  REFERENCE MARK 1 IS A STANDARD DISK, STAMPED CAPE NO 1 1901, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN OUTCROPPING BEDROCK THAT PROJECTS ABOUT 1 FOOT AND IT IS APPROXIMATELY 2 FEET BELOW THE LEVEL OF THE STATION.  REFERENCE MARK 2 IS A STANDARD DISK, STAMPED CAPE NO 2 1901, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN OUTCROPPING BEDROCK THAT PROJECTS ABOUT 6 INCHES AND IT IS APPROXIMATELY 3 FEET BELOW THE LEVEL OF THE STATION.  AIRLINE DISTANCE AND DIRECTION FROM NEAREST TOWN 3-1/2 MILES NORTH OF FAJARDO.
markers.setting: SET IN TOP OF CONCRETE MONUMENT
markers.stability: MAY HOLD, BUT OF TYPE COMMONLY SUBJECT TOSURFACE MOTION

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1924 (GCM) LIGHTHOUSE SAME AS IN 1901.                            STATION RECOVERY (1934)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1934 MALA PASCUA LIGHTHOUSE, AT CAPE MALA PASCUA.                            STATION RECOVERY (1970)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1970 (JKW) STATION WAS RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.  THE ORIGINAL DESCRIPTION IS NOT INCLUDED IN THE RECOVERY DATA, BUT THE LIGHTHOUSE WAS VISITED, AND THERE IS NO RECORD OF ANY CHANGE.                            STATION RECOVERY (1975)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1975 (JDS) THE STATION WAS RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION AS REPORTED IN THE 1970 RECOVERY BY J.K.W..

BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1901 (JEM) THIS STATION BEARS N 97 DEG E FROM POINT VIENTO, AND IS AT THE SE CORNER OF POINT VIENTO.  IT IS ON A BANK OF SHINGLE JUST AT THE JUNCTURE OF THE BARE SHINGLE BEACH AND THE OUTSIDE EDGE OF BUSHES, 30 METERS SE IS A SMALL CLUMP OF WILD GRAPE BUSHES WHICH ARE ON THE SW CORNER OF THE BAY JUST E OF POINT VIENTO. FROM THE UVAS (WILD GRAPES) THE SHINGLE BEACH FALLS TO A LOWER LEVEL (ABOUT 5 FEET LOWER) AND THEN EXTENDS ABOUT 20 METERS FARTHER TO ORDINARY HIGH-WATER MARK.  THE STATION CAN BE SEEN FROM NEARLY EVERY SPOT IN THE BAY E OF POINT VIENTO.  FIGURAS LIGHTHOUSE SHOWS JUST CLEAR OF THE LINE OF BUSHES W OF STATION. TO SEE CORAZON A LANE 11 FEET WIDE AND ABOUT 60 METERS LONG WAS CLEARED INLAND.  A SMALL CLEARING WAS ALSO MADE TOWARDS LEBRON (PEAKS E AND E).  STATION MARK IS A 2-INCH IRON PIPE SUNK IN THE SHINGLE UNTIL FLUSH WITH THE SURFACE OF GROUND WITH CEMENT PACKED AROUND IT.  THE PIPE WAS FILLED WITH CEMENT AND PEBBLES AND A NAIL IN THE BASE OF THE SIGNAL POLE WAS PLACED IN THE CENTER OF CEMENT AND PIPE.                            STATION RECOVERY (1902)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1902 (JEM) THE SIGNAL IS INTACT AND, WHILE A FEW MINOR REPAIRS WERE MADE, SEEMS LIKELY TO STAND FOR SOME TIME.  THE STATION MARK WAS IN GOOD CONDITION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1966)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JJL) THE STATION MARK, AS DESCRIBED IN THE 1901 DESCRIPTION, WAS NOT FOUND AND IS PRESUMED TO HAVE BEEN DESTROYED.  A NEW STATION MARK, REFERENCE MARK 1 AND REFERENCE MARK 2 WERE ESTABLISHED IN THE SAME GENERAL LOCATION.  FOR THE NEW DESCRIPTION SEE TRIANGULATION STATION POINT VIENTO 3.
markers.setting: SET INTO TOP OF METAL PIPE DRIVEN INTO GROUND
markers.stability: MARK OF QUESTIONABLE OR UNKNOWN STABILITY

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JJL) THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 6-1/2 MILES SOUTHWEST OF MAUNABO, 4 MILES SOUTHEAST OF PATILLAS AND ON THE SOUTHEAST CORNER OF A COCOANUT PALM TREE COVERED POINT OF LAND LOCALLY KNOWN AS POINT VIENTO.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE POST OFFICE IN PATILLAS, GO SOUTH AND SOUTHEAST ON HIGHWAY 3 FOR 2.7 MILES TO A SIDE ROAD ON THE RIGHT AND A STORE ON LEFT AT KILOMETER POST 122 HM 7.  TURN RIGHT AND GO EAST ON THE TRACK ROAD FOR 0.25 MILE TO A WIRE GATE AT A HOUSE ON THE LEFT JUST AFTER PASSING THROUGH THE GATE. (PERMISSION TO ENTER THE PROPERTY MAY BE OBTAINED HERE.) PASS THROUGH THE GATE AND CONTINUE EASTERLY ON THE TRACK ROAD FOR 0.45 MILE TO A CONCRETE BRIDGE.  CROSS THE BRIDGE AND CONTINUE EASTERLY ON THE TRACK ROAD FOR 0.7 MILE TO THE SOUTHEAST END OF THE POINT AND THE STATION ON THE RIGHT, SOUTH, SIDE OF THE TRACK ROAD.  THE STATION MARK IS A STANDARD DISK, STAMPED POINT VIENTO 3 1965, SET IN THE TOP OF A 12-INCH ROUND CONCRETE MONUMENT THAT PROJECTS 3 INCHES.  IT IS LOCATED 45.5 FEET SOUTH OF THE APPROXIMATE CENTER OF THE CENTER OF THE TRACK ROAD.  REFERENCE MARK 1 IS A STANDARD DISK, STAMPED POINT VIENTO 3 NO 1 1965, SET IN THE TOP OF A 12-INCH SQUARE CONCRETE MONUMENT THAT PROJECTS 2 INCHES.  IT IS LOCATED 48.7 FEET SOUTH OF THE APPROXIMATE CENTER OF THE TRACK ROAD.  REFERENCE MARK 2 IS A STANDARD DISK, STAMPED POINT VIENTO 3 NO 2 1965, SET IN THE TOP OF A 12-INCH SQUARE CONCRETE MONUMENT THAT PROJECTS 2 INCHES.  IT IS LOCATED 23 FEET SOUTH OF THE APPROXIMATE CENTER OF THE TRACK ROAD.  THE DISTANCE BETWEEN REFERENCE MARK 1 AND REFERENCE MARK 2 IS 40.81 FEET OR 12.440 METERS.                            STATION RECOVERY (1970)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1970 (JKW) STATION MARK, REFERENCE MARK 1, AND REFERENCE MARK 2 ALL RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.  THE DISTANCES WERE CHECKED, AND FOUND TO BE ACCURATE.  NOTE THAT ALL DISKS ARE STAMPED 1965 INSTEAD OF 1966.  THE BASE OF POINT FIGURAS LIGHTHOUSE, 1899 IS SUITABLE AS AN AZIMUTH MARK.  THE ORIGINAL DESCRIPTION BY J.J.L. IN 1966 IS ADEQUATE WITH THE FOLLOWING CHANGE--THE KILOMETER POST AT THE TURN IS 118.9, AND NOT 122.7.                            STATION RECOVERY (1975)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1975 (JDS) STATION MARK, REFERENCE MARK 1, AND REFERENCE MARK 2 WERE NOT RECOVERED.  WHAT APPEARED TO BE THE REMAINS OF ONE REFERENCE MARK WAS FOUND AND THE AREA WAS THOROUGHLY SEARCHED BY THREE MEN FOR ONE HOUR.  SINCE THERE DID NOT APPEAR TO BE ANY RECENT CONSTRUCTION IN THE AREA THE MARKS WERE PROBABLY DESTROYED BY VANDALS.
markers.setting: SET IN TOP OF CONCRETE MONUMENT
markers.stability: MAY HOLD, BUT OF TYPE COMMONLY SUBJECT TOSURFACE MOTION

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1965 (JJL) THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 2 MILES SOUTH-SOUTHEAST OF PATILLAS, 0.1 MILE NORTH OF HIGHWAY 3 AND ON THE SOUTHERN MOST ONE OF TWO LOW, TREE COVERED HILLS THAT LIE WITHIN A SHARP CURVE IN THE HIGHWAY.  THE STATION IS ON THE LOWER ONE OF THE TWO HILLS.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE POST OFFICE IN PATILLAS, GO SOUTHEAST ON HIGHWAY 3 FOR 2.0 MILES TO A DRIVEWAY AND A STEEL GATE ON THE LEFT, NORTH, SIDE OF THE HIGHWAY.  TURN LEFT AND FOLLOW THE DRIVEWAY NORTH AND NORTHWEST, UPHILL, FOR 0.15 MILE TO A HOUSE AT THE BASE OF THE HILL.  PACK NORTHEASTERLY UP THE HILLSIDE, THROUGH TALL GRASS AND BRUSH, FOR ABOUT 0.1 MILE TO A GROUP OF LARGE BOULDERS AND TREES AT THE HIGHEST POINT OF THE HILL AND THE STATION.  (A 5 MINUTE PACK)  THE STATION MARK IS A STANDARD DISK, STAMPED POLLOS 1965, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A LARGE BOULDER THAT PROJECTS ABOUT 6 FEET.  REFERENCE MARK 1 IS A STANDARD DISK, STAMPED POLLOS NO 1 1965, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A LARGE BOULDER THAT PROJECTS ABOUT 7 FEET.  REFERENCE MARK 2 IS A STANDARD DISK, STAMPED POLLOS NO 2 1965, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A LARGE BOULDER THAT PROJECTS ABOUT 2 FEET.  NO SUITABLE PLACE WAS FOUND FOR AN AZIMUTH MARK.                            STATION RECOVERY (1971)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1971 (EKM) THE STATION WAS RECOVERED AND THE DESCRIPTION BY JJL IN 1965 IS ADEQUATE.
markers.setting: SET IN A BOULDER
markers.stability: MAY HOLD, BUT OF TYPE COMMONLY SUBJECT TOSURFACE MOTION

markers.description: BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1934 STATION IS LOCATED 5 KILOMETERS W OF N FROM PONCE POST OFFICE, ON ONE OF THE ROUNDED, BRUSH-COVERED, KNOLLS LYING IMMEDIATELY BACK OF THE CITY.  ANOTHER KNOLL, SLIGHTLY HIGHER AND BROADER IN EXTENT, LIES TO THE NE ABOUT 300 METERS DISTANT.  THE STATION IS ON HIGHEST PART OF TOP, JUST S OF A NATURALLY OPEN GRASSY PLOT, THE OTHER BRUSH WAS CLEARED FROM TOP BUT WILL PROBABLY GROW UP AGAIN IN A FEW YEARS.  STATION MARK IS A STANDARD U.S.G.S. TABLET, STAMPED PONCE 1934 CEMENTED IN A SOFT LIMESTONE ROCK SET IN THE GROUND.  REFERENCE MARK NO.1 IS A COPPER NAIL AND WASHER IN TRIANGULAR BLAZE ON STUMP OF A CORCHO TREE, 71.25 FEET FROM STATION IN TRUE AZIMUTH 06 DEG 28 MIN.  REFERENCE MARK NO.2 IS A 1-INCH DRILL HOLE IN EXPOSED ROCK, ON N SLOPE 44 FEET, INCLINED DISTANCE, FROM STATION IN TRUE AZIMUTH 184 DEG 43 MIN.  TO REACH STATION, FROM PONCE, GO N ON BERTOLY STREET, FROM END OF WHICH A PAVED ROAD WINDS UP THE SIDE OF FIRST KNOLL TO A LOOP NEAR TOP, FROM THIS LOOP FOLLOW A SECOND-CLASS ROAD, WHICH PASSES JUST ABOVE COTTAGE BRITTANIA AND ENDS AT FENCE LINE, FROM END OF THIS ROAD FOLLOW TRAIL ALONG RIDGE TO FORKS TO RIGHT, TURN RIGHT ON TRAIL, CROSS HEAD OF DRAW AND CONTINUE TO FIRST DIVIDE, JUST AFTER PASSING PROMINENT ROCK OUTCROP TURN RIGHT ON SMALL TRAIL AND FOLLOW TO A PROMINENT CLEARED SPOT ON SLOPE TO RIGHT.  LEAVE MAIN TRAIL AND GO UP THROUGH THIS OPENING AND CONTINUE THROUGH BRUSH TO HIGHEST POINT AND STATION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1966)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (DCW) STATION RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.  THE PREVIOUS DESCRIPTION IS ADEQUATE FOR RECOVERY.
markers.setting: SET IN ROCK OUTCROP
markers.stability: MOST RELIABLE AND EXPECTED TO HOLDPOSITION/ELEVATION WELL

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JJL) THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 2-1/2 MILES NORTH OF PONCE, 3/4 MILE NORTHWEST OF THE HOTEL PONCE, AND ON A LOW BRUSH COVERED HILL THAT IS RATHER FLAT ON THE TOP.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE SOUTHWEST CORNER OF THE PLAZA IN PONCE, GO WEST AND NORTH ON HIGHWAY 10 FOR 3.25 MILES TO A SIDE ROAD RIGHT.  TURN RIGHT AND GO EAST FOR 0.65 MILE TO THE PONCE COUNTRY CLUB ON THE LEFT.  CONTINUE EAST ON A DIRT ROAD FOR 0.3 MILE TO A FORK.  TAKE THE RIGHT FORK AND GO SOUTH AND EAST ON A DIRT ROAD FOR 0.5 MILE TO A CROSSROAD.  TURN RIGHT AND GO SOUTH ALONG THE RIDGE ON A DIRT ROAD FOR 0.35 MILE TO THE CREST OF THE RIDGE AND A TRAIL ON THE LEFT.  FROM HERE PACK EAST FOR 100 YARDS TO THE HIGHEST POINT OF THE RIDGE AND THE STATION.  THE STATION MARK IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED PONCE 2 1966, BRAZED TO THE TOP OF A 3-INCH CAST IRON PIPE THAT PROJECTS 4 INCHES.  REFERENCE MARK 1 IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED PONCE 2 NO 1 1966, BRAZED TO THE TOP OF A 3-INCH CAST IRON PIPE THAT PROJECTS 6 INCHES AND IS THE SAME ELEVATION AS THE STATION MARK.  REFERENCE MARK 2 IS A 1-INCH SQUARE PIECE OF STEEL ROD, WITH A CROSS CHISLED ON THE TOP.  IT IS EMBEDDED IN A 1-FOOT IN DIAMETER MOUND OF CONCRETE THAT IS INSCRIBED PONCE 2 1961 AND PROJECTS 3 INCHES.  IT IS THE SAME ELEVATION AS THE STATION MARK.  NO SUITABLE PLACE WAS FOUND FOR AN AZIMUTH MARK.                            STATION RECOVERY (1970)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1970 (JKW) STATION MARK WAS SEARCHED FOR BUT NOT FOUND.  REFERENCE MARK 1 WAS RECOVERED BUT ONLY THE CAST IRON PIPE REMAINS.  THE DISK IS GONE AND THE PIPE IS LOOSE.  REFERENCE MARK 2 WAS RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION (METAL BOLT SET IN CONCRETE, MARKED PONCE 2, 1961).  A NEW TO REACH IS AS FOLLOWS--FROM THE PARKING LOT AT THE REAR OF THE PONCE INTERCONTINENTAL HOTEL, CROSS THE FENCE AND PACK UP THE TRACK ROAD 3/4 MILE TO A ROUND TOP HILL.  FOLLOW A DIM FOOT PATH TO THE RIGHT 150 FEET TO THE STATION (REFERENCE MARK 2) AT THE TOP OF THE HILL.
markers.setting: SET INTO TOP OF METAL PIPE DRIVEN INTO GROUND
markers.stability: MARK OF QUESTIONABLE OR UNKNOWN STABILITY

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JJL) THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 1/2 MILE SOUTH-SOUTHEAST OF PLAYA DE PONCE, 0.2 MILE NORTH-NORTHEAST OF THE PORT OF PONCE AND JUST WEST OF HIGHWAY 10.  THE STATION IS THE NAVIGATION LIGHT THAT SETS ATOP AND CENTER OF A WHITE, 4-LEGGED STEEL STRUCTURE THAT IS 35 FEET HIGH.                            STATION RECOVERY (1970)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1970 (KAM) THE ANCHORAGE LIGHT HAS BEEN DISCONTINUED AND THE STRUCTURE DESTROYED.  SEE NOTICE TO MARINERS 52/69, PARAGRAPH 6946.

BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JJL) THE STATION IS LOCATED IN PLAYA DE PONCE AND ABOUT 200 FEET NORTHWEST OF THE PONCE BAY U.S. COAST GUARD STATION.  THE STATION IS THE NAVIGATION LIGHT THAT SETS ATOP AND CENTER OF A WHITE, 4-LEGGED STEEL STRUCTURE THAT IS 49 FEET HIGH.                            STATION RECOVERY (1970)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1970 (KAM) THE STATION WAS RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED IN 1966 EXCEPT LINE 4 TO THE END SHOULD READ AS FOLLOWS--A WHITE, 4 LEGGED STEEL STRUCTURE THAT SUPPORTS A RED RECTANGULAR DAYMARK WITH A WHITE VERTICAL STRIPE.  THE STRUCTURE IS 49 FEET HIGH.                            STATION RECOVERY (1971)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1971 (EKM) THE STATION WAS RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION AS DESCRIBED.

BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JJL) THE STATION IS LOCATED IN PLAYA DE PONCE, JUST EAST OF HIGHWAY 10 AND ON THE ROOF OF THE PUERTO RICO IRON WORKS.  THE STATION IS THE NAVIGATION LIGHT THAT SETS ATOP AND CENTER OF A WHITE, 4-LEGGED STEEL STRUCTURE THAT IS ABOUT 20 FEET HIGH.  THE HEIGHT OF THE STRUCTURE AND THE BUILDING OVERALL IS 75 FEET.                            STATION RECOVERY (1970)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1970 (KAM) THE STATION WAS RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED IN 1966 EXCEPT FROM LINE 4 TO THE END SHOULD BE CHANGED TO READ AS FOLLOWS--A WHITE, 4 LEGGED STEEL STRUCTURE THAT IS ABOUT 20 FEET HIGH AND SUPPORTS A RED RECTANGULAR DAYMARK WITH A WHITE STRIPE.  THE HEIGHT OF THE STRUCTURE AND THE BUILDING OVERALL IS 75 FEET.                            STATION RECOVERY (1971)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1971 (EKM) THE STATION WAS RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION AS DESCRIBED.

BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JJL) THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 1/2 MILE WEST OF PLAYA DE PONCE, 250 YARDS SOUTH OF THE SOUTH END OF 65TH INFANTRY AVENUE AND AT THE SEAWARD END OF A 24-INCH STEEL SEWERAGE PIPE THAT EXTENDS ABOUT 200 YARDS INTO THE BAY FROM THE NORTH SHORE OF PONCE BAY.  THE STATION IS THE NAVIGATION LIGHT THAT SETS ATOP THE 12-INCH SQUARE CONCRETE COLUMN THAT IS 12 FEET HIGH.                            STATION RECOVERY (1971)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1971 (EKM) THE STATION WAS RECOVERED IN GOOD ORDER WITH THE EXCEPTION THAT THE LIGHT IS OUT (PRIVATELY MAINTAINED) AND HAS BEEN FOR SOME TIME.                            STATION RECOVERY (1975)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1975 (RMB) THE STRUCTURE HAS BEEN REMOVED AND THE STATION IS LOST.

BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1934 STATION IS THE SOUTHERN SPIRE ON THE CATHOLIC CATHEDRAL OF THE CITY OF PONCE.  CROSS ON SPIRE WAS THE POINT OBSERVED.  THIS IS A NO CHECK POSITION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1966)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JMC) STATION WAS RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.  LOCATED ON THE PLAYA DEGETAU.                            STATION RECOVERY (1971)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1971 (EKM) THE STATION WAS RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED.  DESCRIPTION IN 1934 IS ADEQUATE.
BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JMC) STATION WAS RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.  LOCATED ON THE PLAYA DEGETAU.

BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JJL) THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 3-1/2 MILES EAST-NORTHEAST OF PONCE AND 3/4 MILE NORTH OF THE PONCE MERCEDITA AIRPORT.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE PONCE MERCEDITA AIRPORT CONTROL TOWER, GO NORTH ON A PAVED ROAD FOR 0.75 MILE TO THE STATION.  THE STACK IS A CYLINDRICAL, CONCRETE STRUCTURE, WHITE IN COLOR, WITH AN OVERALL HEIGHT OF ABOUT 80 FEET AND IT IS THE TALLEST STACK OF TWO STACKS.  POINT INTERSECTED IS THE TOP AND CENTER OF THE STACK.                            STATION RECOVERY (1972)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1972 (EP) THIS INTERSECTION STATION WAS RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION AS DESCRIBED.  IT IS THE SOUTH ONE OF TWO STACKS OR SIMILIAR CONSTRUCTION, EXCEPT THAT IT IS LARGER IN DIAMETER.  THE TWO STACKS ARE ABOUT THE SAME HEIGHT.  THE SOUTH STACK HAS DON Q IN LARGE BLACK LETTERS WRITTEN ON THE SOUTH SIDE.  AIRLINE DISTANCE AND DIRECTION FROM NEAREST TOWN 3-1/2 MILES NORTHEAST OF PONCE.                            STATION RECOVERY (1975)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1975 (RMB) THE STATION WAS RECOVERED AND IS AS PREVIOUSLY DESCRIBED.                            STATION RECOVERY (1982)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1982 (JCL) THE STATION, PONCE DON Q RUM COMPANY STACK, WAS RECOVERED AS PREVIOUSLY DESCRIBED.

BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1934 THIS POINT IS THE CENTER OF TALL WHITE STACK ON THE ELECTRIC LIGHT PLANT OF THE TOWN OF PONCE (S OF THE CITY).                            STATION RECOVERY (1966)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (DCW) THIS STATION IS DESTROYED.  THE STACK WAS REMOVED IN 1964.

BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JJL) THE STATION IS LOCATED IN THE SOUTH PART OF PONCE, ON THE EAST SIDE OF HIGHWAY 10 AND 0.4 MILE NORTH OF THE JUNCTION OF HIGHWAYS 10 AND 2 BY-PASS.  THE STACK IS A CYLINDRICAL, STEEL STRUCTURE THAT IS GRAY IN COLOR.  IT IS 6 FEET IN DIAMETER AND IT IS ABOUT 150 FEET HIGH.  POINT INTERSECTED IS THE TOP AND CENTER OF THE STACK.  NOTE--THE STACK IS NO LONGER IN USE.                            STATION RECOVERY (1970)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1970 (JKW) THE STATION WAS NOT RECOVERED AS IT WAS DESTROYED IN 1969 TO MAKE ROOM FOR FOMENTO OFFICES.  THIS FACT WAS VERIFIED BY AN ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT ADMINISTRATION OFFICIAL.
PTIVE TEXT AVAILABLE.

BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JJL) THE STATION IS LOCATED IN THE SOUTH PART OF PONCE, 0.15 MILE NORTH OF THE JUNCTION OF HIGHWAYS 10 AND 2 AND JUST WEST OF HIGHWAY 10.  THE TANK IS A CYLINDRICAL, STEEL STRUCTURE, SILVER IN COLOR, SUPPORTED BY FOUR STEEL LEGS AND IT IS ABOUT 100 FEET HIGH.  POINT INTERSECTED IS THE BALL ATOP AND CENTER OF THE TANK.                            STATION RECOVERY (1971)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1971 (EKM) THE STATION WAS RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION AS DESCRIBED.

BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JJL) THE STATION IS LOCATED IN THE SOUTH PART OF PONCE.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE JUNCTION OF HIGHWAYS 10 AND 2 IN THE SOUTH PART OF PONCE, GO SOUTH ON HIGHWAY 10 FOR 1.15 MILES TO A CROSSROAD.  TURN LEFT AND GO EAST ON A PAVED STREET FOR 0.25 MILE TO A FORK.  TAKE THE LEFT FORK AND GO NORTHEAST AND EAST ON A PAVED STREET FOR 0.25 MILE TO THE STATION ON THE RIGHT.  THE MAST IS A STEEL-TRUSS STRUCTURE, PAINTED ALTERNATELY RED AND WHITE, SUPPORTED BY GUY WIRES AND IT IS ABOUT 150 FEET HIGH.  POINT INTERSECTED IS THE RED OBSTRUCTION LIGHT ATOP THE MAST.                            STATION RECOVERY (1971)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1971 (EKM) THE STATION WAS RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION AS DESCRIBED.

BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JJL) THE STATION IS LOCATED IN THE SOUTH PART OF PONCE.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE JUNCTION OF HIGHWAYS 10 AND 2 IN THE SOUTH PART OF PONCE, GO WEST ON HIGHWAY 2 FOR 0.1 MILE TO THE STATION ON THE RIGHT, NORTH, SIDE OF THE HIGHWAY.  THE MAST IS A STEEL-TRUSS STRUCTURE, PAINTED ALTERNATELY RED AND WHITE, SUPPORTED BY GUY WIRES AND IT IS ABOUT 150 FEET HIGH.  POINT INTERSECTED IS THE RED OBSTRUCTION LIGHT ATOP AND CENTER OF THE MAST.                            STATION RECOVERY (1970)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1970 (KAM) STATION WAS MOVED 200 METERS IN 1967.  THE STATION NEED NOT BE RE-ESTABLISHED AS IT IS NO LONGER DISTINCTIVE.  APPROXIMATE NEW LOCATION 17 DEG 59 MIN 58 SEC N.  66 DEG 37 MIN 12 SEC W. AS RECEIVED FROM STATION MANAGER.

BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JJL) THE STATION IS LOCATED IN THE SOUTHWEST PART OF PONCE.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE JUNCTION OF HIGHWAYS 10 AND 2 IN THE SOUTH PART OF PONCE, GO WEST ON HIGHWAY 2 FOR 0.6 MILE TO THE STATION ON THE LEFT, SOUTH, SIDE OF THE HIGHWAY.  THE MAST IS A STEEL-TRUSS STRUCTURE, PAINTED ALTERNATELY RED AND WHITE, SUPPORTED BY GUY WIRES AND IT IS 258 FEET HIGH.  POINT INTERSECTED IS THE RED OBSTRUCTION LIGHT ATOP AND CENTER OF THE MAST.                            STATION RECOVERY (1971)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1971 (EKM) THE STATION WAS RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION AS DESCRIBED.

BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JJL) THE STATION IS LOCATED IN THE SOUTHWEST PART OF PONCE.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE JUNCTION OF HIGHWAYS 10 AND 2 IN THE SOUTH PART OF PONCE, GO WESTERLY ON HIGHWAY 2 FOR 0.95 MILE TO THE JUNCTION OF HIGHWAYS 2 AND 132.  TURN LEFT AND GO SOUTH ON HIGHWAY 132 FOR 0.5 MILE TO THE STATION ON THE LEFT, EAST, SIDE OF THE HIGHWAY.  THE MAST IS A STEEL-TRUSS STRUCTURE, PAINTED ALTERNATELY RED AND WHITE, SUPPORTED BY GUY WIRES AND IT IS 319 FEET HIGH.  POINT INTERSECTED IS THE RED OBSTRUCTION LIGHT ATOP AND CENTER OF THE MAST.                            STATION RECOVERY (1971)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1971 (EKM) THE STATION WAS RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.  THE FIFITH LINE OF THE DESCRIPTION SHOULD BE CHANGED TO READ--132 FOR 0.5 MILE TO THE STATION ON THE RIGHT (WEST) SIDE OF THE HIGHWAY.

BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JJL) THE STATION IS LOCATED IN THE SOUTHWEST PART OF PONCE.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE JUNCTION OF HIGHWAYS 10 AND 2 IN THE SOUTH PART OF PONCE, GO WEST ON HIGHWAY 2 FOR 1-1/2 MILES TO THE STATION ON THE RIGHT, NORTH, SIDE OF THE HIGHWAY.  THE MAST IS A STEEL-TRUSS STRUCTURE, PAINTED ALTERNATELY RED AND WHITE, SUPPORTED BY GUY WIRES AND IT IS ABOUT 150 FEET HIGH.  POINT INTERSECTED IS THE RED OBSTRUCTION LIGHT ATOP AND CENTER OF THE MAST.                            STATION RECOVERY (1971)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1971 (EKM) THE STATION WAS RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION AS DESCRIBED.

BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1899 (WCH) THIS STATION IS SITUATED ON A SLIGHT RISE OF GROUND, SW OF A LITTLE HOLLOW ON THE SOUTHEASTERN SIDE OF THE PONCE AND YAUCO RAILROAD, AT THE FIRST CURVE IN THE LINE SW OF THE CROSSING OF THE WAGON ROAD.                            STATION RECOVERY (1899)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1899 (JN) STATION IS AT THE SEAWARD END OF THE BASE MEASURED EARLY IN 1899.  THE TRIPOD AND INSTRUMENT WERE CENTERED OVER A 2-INCH PIECE OF IRON PIPE CEMENTED IN THE GROUND, WHICH MARKED THE END OF THE BASE.  IT IS S OF THE RAILROAD TRACK AND IS ABOUT 11 METERS S OF A WIRE FENCE WHICH SEPARATES THE RAILROAD PROPERTY FROM THE ESTATE ON WHICH THE SIGNAL STANDS.  STNADING AT THE STATION ONE CAN LOOK DOWN THE RAILROAD TRACK FOR A DISTANCE OF 1-1/2 MILES (THE BASE WAS MEASURED ALONG THIS TANGENT) AND THIS TANGENT IF EXTENDED WOULD PASS ABOUT 100 FEET W OF THE U.S. MILITARY HOSPITAL.  JUST ABREAST OF THE SIGNAL, ON THE RAILROAD RIGHT-OF-WAY, IS A RAILROAD POST WITH A BOARD MARKED THUS--6 OVER 440, 0 OVER 460.                            STATION RECOVERY (1966)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JMC) RAILROAD NO LONGER IN EXISTENCE.  STA. SHOULD BE CONSIDERED LOST.  PREVIOUS DESCRIPTION NOT ADEQUATE FOR RECOVERY.
markers.setting: SET IN TOP OF CONCRETE MONUMENT
markers.stability: MAY HOLD, BUT OF TYPE COMMONLY SUBJECT TOSURFACE MOTION

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JJL) THE STATION IS LOCATED IN THE NORTH PART OF PONCE AND ON THE ROOF OF THE PONCE INTERCONTINENTAL HOTEL.  THE ANTENNA IS A STEEL-TRUSS STRUCTURE, PAINTED ALTERNATELY RED AND WHITE, SUPPORTED BY GUY WIRES AND IT PROJECTS ABOUT 30 FEET ABOVE THE ROOF OF THE HOTEL.  POINT INTERSECTED IS THE TOP AND CENTER OF THE ANTENNA.                            STATION RECOVERY (1970)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1970 (JKW) STATION WAS RECOVERED IN APPARENT GOOD CONDITION.  THE ANTENNA IS STILL IN USE AND IN GOOD REPAIR.  DESCRIPTION BY JJL IN 1966 IS ADEQUATE FOR RECOVERY.                            STATION RECOVERY (1971)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1971 (EKM) THE STATION WAS RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION AS DESCRIBED.

BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JWC) THE STATION IS LOCATED 16 AIRLINE MILES SOUTH OF AGUADILLA, 3 AIRLINE MILES SOUTHWEST OF ANASCO, 2 AIRLINE MILES NORTH OF MAYAGUEZ AND ON THE TOP OF A HIGH CUT-BANK.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE VIADUCT AT THE INTERSECTION OF CALLE VIGO AND HIGHWAY 2 IN MAYAGUEZ, GO NORTH ON HIGHWAY 2 FOR 1.6 MILES TO THE HIGH CUT BANK ON THE RIGHT AND END OF TRUCK TRAVEL.  FROM HERE PACK EASTERLY UP THE CUT-BANK FOR ABOUT 100 YARDS TO THE TOP OF THE CUT-BANK AND THE STATION.  THE STATION MARK IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED PONY 1966, BRAZED TO THE TOP OF A 3-INCH ROUND CAST IRON SOIL PIPE WHICH PROJECTS 10 INCHES.  IT IS ABOUT 50 YARDS SOUTH OF A HIGHLINE TOWER.  REFERENCE MARK 1 IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED PONY NO 1 1966, BRAZED TO THE TOP OF A 3-INCH ROUND CAST IRON SOIL PIPE WHICH PROJECTS 8 INCHES.  REFERENCE MARK 2 IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED PONY NO 2 1966, BRAZED TO THE TOP OF A 3-INCH ROUND CAST IRON SOIL PIPE WHICH PROJECTS 5 INCHES.  NO AZIMUTH MARK WAS ESTABLISHED AT THIS STATION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1971)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US ARMY CORPS OF ENGINEERS 1971 STATION FOUND IN GOOD CONDITION.  UNABLE TO RECOVER THE REFERENCE MARKS.
markers.setting: SET INTO TOP OF METAL PIPE DRIVEN INTO GROUND
markers.stability: MARK OF QUESTIONABLE OR UNKNOWN STABILITY

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JJL) THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 8-1/2 MILES SOUTHEAST OF PATILLAS, 2 MILES SOUTH-SOUTHWEST OF MAUNABO AND NEAR THE SOUTHEAST END OF A NORTHWEST-SOUTHEAST RIDGE THAT IS COVERED WITH BRUSH.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE POST OFFICE IN MAUNABO, GO WESTERLY ON HIGHWAY 3 FOR 2.3 MILES TO KILOMETER POST 113.6 AND THE END OF TRUCK TRAVEL.  HERE CROSS THE FENCE ON THE NORTH SIDE OF THE HIGHWAY AND PACK NORTHWEST AND NORTH, KEEPING TO ALL UPHILL TRAILS FOR 20 MINUTES TO A POINT WHERE A POWERLINE CROSSES THE RIDGE AND THE STATION.  THE STATION MARK IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED POOR 1965, BRAZED TO THE TOP OF A 3-INCH CAST IRON PIPE THAT PROJECTS 4 INCHES.  IT IS 50 FEET SOUTHWEST OF THE NORTH ONE OF A SET OF DOUBLE POWER POLES, 19 FEET SOUTH OF THE WEST GUY WIRE TO THE DOUBLE POWER POLES AND ON THE SOUTH SLOPE OF THE RIDGE.  REFERENCE MARK 1 IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED POOR NO 1 1965, BRAZED TO THE TOP OF A 3-INCH CAST IRON PIPE THAT PROJECTS 8 INCHES.  IT IS 34 FEET SOUTHWEST OF THE NORTH ONE OF THE SET OF DOUBLE POWER POLES AND 1 FOOT HIGHER IN ELEVATION THAN THE STATION MARK.  REFERENCE MARK 2 IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED POOR NO 2 1965, BRAZED TO THE TOP OF A 3-INCH CAST IRON PIPE THAT PROJECTS 6 INCHES.  IT IS 62 FEET WEST-SOUTHWEST OF THE NORTH ONE OF THE SET OF DOUBLE POWER POLES AND THE SAME ELEVATION AS THE STATION MARK.  NO SUITABLE PLACE WAS FOUND FOR AN AZIMUTH MARK.
markers.setting: UNSPECIFIED SETTING

markers.description: BY RLDA SURVEYING AND MAPPING 2010 (RLD) THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 8.7 MI (14.0 KM) SOUTHEAST OF ADJUNTAS, 5.3 MI (8.5 KM) NORTHWEST OF COTO LAUREL, 5.0 MI (8.0 KM) NORTHEAST OF TALLABOA ALTA AND 4.4 MI (7.1 KM) NORTHWEST OF PONCE, PUERTO RICO.   TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE INTERSECTION OF PR-9 AND PR-10 2 MI (3.2 KM) NORTHWEST OF PONCE, GO NORTHWESTERLY ON PR-10 FOR 2.6 MI (4.2 KM) TO THE STATION ON THE LEFT.   THE STATION IS 8.55 M (28.1 FT) WEST OF THE CENTERLINE OF PR-10, 4.40 M (14.4 FT) WEST OF THE WEST EDGE OF PR-10, 0.8 M (2.6 FT) WEST OF A METAL GUARD RAIL AND IN THE EDGE OF BRUSH ON THE WEST SIDE OF PR-10.
markers.setting: SET IN TOP OF CONCRETE MONUMENT
markers.stability: MAY HOLD, BUT OF TYPE COMMONLY SUBJECT TOSURFACE MOTION

markers.description: BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1941 V.A. ELEVATION 58.42 METERS.  STATION LOCATED ABOUT 6 KMS. FROM THE EAST END OF VIEQUES ISLAND, ABOUT 200 METERS FROM THE NORTH COAST AND ABOUT 400 METERS EAST OF CAPE KNOWN AS PORTO DIABLO (DEVILS PORT).  THE STATION IS NEAR THE MIDDLE OF A LONG RIDGE COVERED WITH LARGE BOULDERS AND SCRUB TIMBER.  CONSIDERABLE CLEARING WAS NECESSARY TO OCCUPY THIS STATION.  TO REACH FROM ISABEL II DRIVE EAST ALONG NORTH COAST ROAD TO PORTO DIABLO.  FROM A POINT WHERE THE ROAD PASSES THROUGH A LOW SADDLE WALK NORTH UP RIDGE ABOUT 200 METERS TO TOP AND STATION.  STATION MARK--STANDARD TABLET STAMPED PORTO DIABLO 1941 AND SET IN ROCK SHAPED LIKE A TRUNCATED PYRAMID ABOUT ONE METER SQUARE AT ITS BASE WHICH IS NORTH OF A GROUP OF HIGHER ROCKS.  R.M. 1 CHISELED CROSS ON N FACE OF ROCK 1.10 METERS FROM THE STATION.  PLANE AZIMUTH--21-42.  R.M. 2 CHISELED CROSS ON W FACE OF ROCK 3.83 METERS FROM STATION.  PLANE AZIMUTH--263-28.  SIGNAL--CLOTH TARGET AND FLAG CENTERED OVER STATION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1965)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1965 (JMC) STATION MARK AND RM 1 RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.  RM 2 FOUND BROKEN OFF FROM BOULDER.                            STATION RECOVERY (1965)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1965 (MTP) STATION AND R.M.S. RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED.  STATION IS LOCATED IN THE BOMB IMPACT AREA OF CAMP GARCIA.  IT IS ON A HILL THAT HAS BEEN HIT BY BOMBS NUMEROUS TIMES, THERE IS EVIDENCE OF A DESTROYED TANK ON HILL, AND MANY BOMB SCARS.  THE HILL IS JUST EAST OF A WHITE SAND BEACH THAT THE ROAD COMES CLOSE TO.                            STATION RECOVERY (1970)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US MARINE CORPS 1970 STATION RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.
markers.setting: SET IN ROCK OUTCROP
markers.stability: MOST RELIABLE AND EXPECTED TO HOLDPOSITION/ELEVATION WELL

markers.description: BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1941 COORDINATES WERE PUBLISHED FOR THIS STATION BY THE C. AND G. S. ALTHOUGH IT WAS NOT OCCUPIED OR DESCRIBED.  IT WAS NOT POSSIBLE TO DETERMINE WHETHER THERE HAD BEEN ANY CHANGES IN THE LIGHT SINCE 1901 BUT AS THE POSITION DETERMINED FOR THE LIGHT IN 1941 DID NOT AGREE WITH THE 1901 COORDINATES IT WAS CONCLUDED THAT THE LIGHT HAD BEEN CHANGED.  SEE U.S.G.S. STATION PORT FERRO LIGHTHOUSE 2 (1941).

BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1941 SUGAR CANE LOADING DERRICK ABOUT 1 KM EAST OF CABALLO POINT AND 50 FT. NORTH OF THE ISABEL II-PUNTA ARENAS HIGHWAY AT K6 H8.  STATION MARK--CHISELED CROSS IN THE SOUTH CORNER OF THE CONCRETE BASE.                            STATION RECOVERY (1964)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1964 (GWM) STATION DESTROYED.  NUMEROUS PIECES OF CONCRETE IN AREA BUT COULD NOT FIND ONE WITH A CROSS IN IT.
markers.setting: SET IN A RETAINING WALL OR CONCRETE LEDGE
markers.stability: MAY HOLD, BUT OF TYPE COMMONLY SUBJECT TOSURFACE MOTION

markers.description: BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1941 SUGAR CANE LOADING DERRICK ABOUT 2 KMS. EAST OF CABALLO POINT AND ABOUT 75 FT. NW OF THE ISABEL II-PUNTA ARENAS HIGHWAY AT K5 H0.  STATION MARK--CHISELED CROSS IN SE CORNER OF THE CONCRETE BASE.                            STATION RECOVERY (1964)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1964 (GWM) STATION FOUND AS DESCRIBED.  THE DERRICK NO LONGER STANDS BUT THE BASE WITH CROSS IS INTACT.  THERE IS A SMALL SHACK ABOUT 20 METERS EAST OF MARK.                            STATION RECOVERY (1965)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1965 (MTP) STATION RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED.  STATION WAS RECOVERED IN 1964, BUT NOW THE SHACK IS ABOUT 8 METERS N.E. OF MARK.  THE GATE FENCE ALONG HIGHWAY IS ABOUT 6 METERS S E OF STATION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1966)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JPR) STATION WAS RECOVERED AS RECOVERED AND DESCRIBED BY G.W. MOORE IN 1964.  STATION WAS IN GOOD CONDITION.

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1900 (WCH) STATION IS A MASONRY STRUCTURE OF MODERATE SIZE ON THE EASTERN SIDE OF THE LITTLE BIGHT CALLED PORT MULAS, N COAST OF VIEQUES.  THE ECCENTRIC STATION WAS ON THE FLAT ROOF ON THE NW SIDE OF THE TOWER.                            STATION RECOVERY (1901)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1901 (SF) RECOVERED.  STATION IS MARKED ECCENTRICALLY BY A U.S.C. AND G.S. STATION MARK.  IT IS IN A BRICK ON THE TOP OF THE FLAT ROOF OF THE LIGHTHOUSE.  THE MARK IS IN A BED OF PORTLAND CEMENT LEVEL WITH THE TOP OF THE BRICK, AND IS LOCATED ON THE NW SIDE OF THE ROOF.                            STATION RECOVERY (1941)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1941 (RLS) THE STATION WAS NOT VISITED BY THIS PARTY.  IT WAS REPORTED BY THE U.S. GEOLOGICAL SURVEY THAT THE LIGHT IS THE SAME ONE AS THE 1900 STATION BUT THAT PART OF THE LIGHTHOUSE HAD BEEN RE-BUILT RECENTLY AND THE ECCENTRIC STATION IS DESTROYED.  THE LIGHT IS DESCRIBED IN THE 1939 LIGHT LIST AS FOLLOWS--NO.3376.  ON POINT, E SIDE OF PORT MULAS, N SHORE OF VIEQUES ISLAND.  LIGHT 68 FEET ABOVE THE WATER.  WHITE OCTAGONAL TOWER IN CENTER OF FRONT OF FLAT-ROOFED DWELLING.  LIGHT 32 FEET ABOVE THE GROUND.  ESTABLISHED 1885.  RE-BUILT 1896.  OBSERVATIONS BY THIS PARTY WERE MADE IN THE DAYTIME ON THE CENTER OF THE WHITE OCTAGONAL TOWER.                            STATION RECOVERY (1941)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1941 STATION RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED.  NO CHANGES HAD BEEN MADE IN THE LIGHTHOUSE SINCE 1900 EXCEPT THAT THE ROOF HAD BEEN REPAIRED AND THE TABLET MARKING THE ECCENTRIC STATION HAD BEEN DESTROYED.  THE CENTER OF THE LIGHT IS THE STATION AND THE PUBLISHED COORDINATES ARE FOR SAME.  (THIS IS NOT MADE CLEAR IN THE ORIGINAL DESCRIPTION BUT WAS VERIFIED BY THE WASHINGTON OFFICE OF THE C. AND G.S.)                            STATION RECOVERY (1970)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US MARINE CORPS 1970 STATION WAS RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.                            STATION RECOVERY (2004)  RECOVERY NOTE BY INDIVIDUAL CONTRIBUTORS 2004 (MA) THIS STATION WAS RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.  THE LIGHTOUSE IS NOW A RESOTED FACILITY FOR MEETINGS AND SPECIAL OCCASIONS.
PTIVE TEXT AVAILABLE.

BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1939 (HAC) STATION IS A TALL CONCRETE STACK OF THE PUERTO RICO RAILWAY LIGHT AND POWER COMPANY, LOCATED AT THE SOUTHEASTERLY END OF THE CONDADO BAY IN SANTURCE, SAN JUAN.  THERE IS A BLACK STEEL STACK CLOSE BY.  THIS BLACK STEEL STACK WAS LOCATED (WITHOUT CHECK) IN 1927.                            STATION RECOVERY (1964)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1964 (GWM) THERE ARE TWO CONCRETE STACKS NOW IN THE SAME GENERAL AREA.  THE SUPERINTENDENT OF THE PLANT SAID THAT BOTH OF THESE STACKS WERE BUILT AFTER 1939.  THE STATION IS PRESUMED DESTROYED.                            STATION RECOVERY (1965)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1965 (MTP) THIS STATION NO LONGER EXIST.  STACK WAS REMOVED BY THE POWER COMPANY IN APRIL, 1965.

markers.description: BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1934 STATION IS ABOUT 2 MILES W OF NAGUABO ON A BARE GRASSY HILL, THE MOST PROMINENT ONE S OF THE JUNCOS-NAGUABO HIGHWAY AND ABOUT 2 KILOMETERS DIRECT DISTANCE FROM THE ROAD.  STATION IS MARKED BY A REGULAR U.S.G.S. DISK STAMPED PRIETO 1934.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 1 IS A CROSS MARK ON A STONE 15 FEET 6-1/2 INCHES FROM THE STATION CENTER, AND ON A TRUE AZIMUTH OF 190 DEG 04 MIN.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 2 IS A CROSS MARK ON A STONE 13 FEET 1-1/2 INCHES FROM THE STATION CENTER, AND ON A TRUE AZIMUTH OF 311 DEG 07 MIN.  SIGNAL--A WHITE QUADRIPOD WITH BLACK CROSS-TARGETS.  TO REACH THE STATION DRIVE UP TO KILOMETER 4 H-9 ON THE JUNCOS-NAGUABO HIGHWAY.  FROM HERE TAKE TRAIL THROUGH CANE FIELD UNTIL YOU GET TO THE FOOT OF THE HILLS AROUND THE VICINITY OF THE STATION.  THE STATION IS THEN REACHED BY THE TRAIL OVER THE CRESTS OF THE GENTLE-SLOPED HILLS AT THE RIGHT (N) OF THE MOST PROMINENT HILL WHERE THE STATION PRIETO IS LOCATED.                            STATION RECOVERY (1940)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1940 STATION AND R.M.S FOUND AS DESCRIBED IN GOOD CONDITION.  STATION IS A STANDARD TABLET STAMPED PRIETO 1934 CEMENTED IN A ROCK, 14.6 FT. N 45 DEG E OF FENCE CORNER ON HILL TOP.  IT IS ALSO ABOUT 400 FT. DISTANT IN AZIMUTH 271 DEG 10 MIN 11 SEC FROM A SQUARED CONCRETE POST PROJECTING ABOUT 2-1/2 FT. AT AN ANGLE IN THE FENCE LINE AT TOP OF NEXT HILL BELOW THE STATION.  AND ABOUT 700 FT. W OF HOUSE OF JULIO BERRIO.  TO REACH FROM NAGUABO, GO W FROM SW CORNER OF TOWN ON RD. KNOWN AS CAMINO MATANZAS OR CAMINO BRAZO SECO.  THIS RD. LEADS IN A STRAIGHT LINE ALMOST DIRECTLY TOWARDS THE STATION.  CAR CAN BE DRIVEN TO WOODEN BRIDGE ACROSS RIO BLANCO.  ABOUT 250 FT. BEYOND BRIDGE TAKE RIGHT LANE PAST HOUSES OF JUANA DIAZ.  AT NEXT FORK TURN LEFT, PASS RIO BRAZO SCHOOL AND TAKE LEFT FORK UP HILL AT STREAM CROSSING AND HOUSE OF OLIVE MORALES, AND CONTINUE UP TO RIDGE AND TURN RIGHT ALONG FENCE TO STATION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1941)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1941 (RLS) STATION IS ABOUT 2-3/4 MILES NW OF PLAYA DE HUMACAO, ABOUT 2-1/4 MILES WSW OF NAGUABO, ABOUT 1 MILE S OF COLONIA LA FE ON THE NAGUABO-JUNCOS HIGHWAY, ON THE HIGHEST HILL IN AN E-AND-W RANGE OF LOW HILLS (THE VILLAGE OF SANGHAI IS ON THE N SLOPE OF THE HILL), ON PROPERTY OWNED BY LUIS GONZALES, ON THE HIGHEST POINT OF THE CONE-SHAPED HILL, 4.5 METERS N OF THE JUNCTION OF 2 FENCES, AND IN A CULTIVATED FIELD.  THE STATION IS MARKED BY A U.S. GEOLOGICAL SURVEY STANDARD DISK STAMPED PRIETO 1934 SET IN A DRILL HOLE IN THE FLAT TOP OF A BOULDER ABOUT 12 BY 18 INCHES AND PROJECTING FROM 4 TO 6 INCHES ABOVE GROUND.  THE ELEVATION OF THE STATION IS ABOUT 172 METERS.  THERE IS NO UNDERGROUND MARK.  BOTH OLD REFERENCE MARKS WERE RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED BY THE GEOLOGICAL SURVEY.  THEY ARE CHISELED CROSSES ON BOULDERS.  REFERENCE MARK NO.1 IS ON THE SLOPING TOP OF A SMALL BOULDER PROJECTING 6 INCHES ABOVE GROUND.  REFERENCE MARK NO.2 IS ON A BOULDER ABOUT 3 FEET IN DIAMETER AND PROJECTING ABOUT 24 INCHES ABOVE GROUND.  REFERENCE MARK NO.2 IS DIFFICULT TO IDENTIFY AS A CROSS WITHOUT THE DISTANCE AND DIRECTION FROM THE STATION.  TWO NEW REFERENCE MARKS WERE SET.  REFERENCE MARK NO.3 (NOTE 12D) IS A U.S.C. AND G. SURVEY STANDARD DISK STAMPED PRIETO USGS 1934 NO.3 1941.  IT IS ON THE S SLOPE OF THE HILL, 5.3 METERS SSW OF A FENCE, 4.2 METERS SE OF A FENCE, 1.25 METERS LOWER THAN THE STATION, ON A BOULDER ABOUT 2 BY 3 FEET ON TOP AND PROJECTING 12 TO 24 INCHES ABOVE GROUND.  THE FLAT TOP OF THE BOULDER SLOPES SLIGHTLY TO THE S.  REFERENCE MARK NO.4 (NOTE 12D) IS A U.S.C. AND G. SURVEY STANDARD DISK STAMPED PRIETO USGS 1934 NO.4, 1941.  IT IS ON THE W SLOPE OF THE HILL, 8.3 METERS NW OF A FENCE, 4.0 METERS S OF A FENCE, 1.63 METERS LOWER THAN THE STATION, ON TOP OF A LARGE BOULDER AMONG SEVERAL LARGE BOULDERS ON THE SLOPE OF THE HILL.                            STATION RECOVERY (1954)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1954 (CAS) REFERENCE MARK NOS 1,2 AND 3 WERE RECOVERED.  THE STATION MARK AND REFERENCE MARK NO. 4 WERE NOT FOUND.  A THOROUGH SEARCH WAS MADE FOR THESE TWO MARKS, BUT EVIDENCE SHOWS THAT THE ROCKS THESE MARKS WERE IN HAVE BEEN DESTROYED.                            STATION RECOVERY (1965)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1965 (JJL) THE STATION MARK AND REFERENCE MARK 3 WERE RECOVERED AND FOUND IN GOOD CONDITION.  A NEW REFERENCE MARK 5 AND A NEW AZIMUTH MARK WERE ESTABLISHED.  A COMPLETE NEW DESCRIPTION OF THE STATION FOLLOWS--  THE STATION IS LOCATED 2 AIRLINE MILES SOUTHWEST OF NAGUABO, ON THE TOP OF A BRUSH COVERED HILL WHICH IS OWNED BY LUIS GONZALES.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE SOUTHWEST CORNER OF THE PLAZA IN NAGUABO, GO WEST ON A PAVED STREET FOR 0.05 MILE TO A T-INTERSECTION.  TURN LEFT AND GO SOUTH ON A PAVED STREET FOR 0.05 MILE TO A CROSSROAD, TURN RIGHT AND GO WESTERLY ON A PAVED STREET FOR 0.35 MILE TO A RAILROAD CROSSING.  CONTINUE WESTERLY ON A ROCK ROAD FOR 0.7 MILE TO A CONCRETE BRIDGE AND THE AZIMUTH MARK IN THE NORTHWEST ABUTMENT OF THE BRIDGE.  CONTINUE WESTERLY ON A BLADED ROAD FOR 0.5 MILE TO A SIDE ROAD LEFT.  TURN LEFT AND GO SOUTHERLY ON A BLADED ROAD CROSSING A NARROW BRIDGE FOR 0.05 MILE TO A DIM T-INTERSECTION.  TURN RIGHT AND GO WESTERLY ON A BLADED ROAD FOR 0.2 MILE TO A SIDE ROAD LEFT.  TURN LEFT AND GO SOUTHERLY ON A BLADED ROAD FOR 0.4 MILE TO A TRAIL ON THE LEFT AND END OF TRUCK TRAVEL.  FROM HERE PACK SOUTHWEST UP THE TRAIL FOR ABOUT 0.1 MILE TO A GATE ON THE RIGHT.  TURN RIGHT, PASS THROUGH THE GATE AND PACK SOUTHWEST UP A STEEP HILL FOR ABOUT 0.2 MILE TO THE TOP OF THE HILL AND THE STATION.  ALLOW 30 MINUTES FOR PACKING.  THE STATION MARK IS A IRON PEG SET IN THE TOP OF A MASS OF CONCRETE WHICH PROJECTS 1 INCH.  THE MONUMENT HAS NO STAMPING.  REFERENCE MARK 3 IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED PRIETO USGS NO 3 1934 1941, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A BOULDER WHICH PROJECTS 1 FOOT.  (NOTE 12C)  REFERENCE MARK 5 IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED PRIETO USGS NO 5 1934, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A BOULDER WHICH PROJECTS 1 FOOT.  (NOTE 12C)  THE AZIMUTH MARK IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED PRIETO USGS 1934, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN THE NORTHWEST ABUTMENT OF THE BRIDGE WHICH PROJECTS 1 FOOT.  IT IS 10 FEET NORTH OF THE CENTER OF THE BRIDGE, 3.5 FEET EAST OF THE WEST EDGE OF THE BRIDGE AND 3 INCHES SOUTH OF THE NORTH EDGE OF THE BRIDGE.  AIRLINE DISTANCE AND DIRECTION FROM NEAREST TOWN 2 MILES SOUTHWEST OF NAGUABO.
markers.setting: SET IN A BOULDER
