markers.description: BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 2002 (JMW) 5.4 KM (3.35 MI) WESTERLY ALONG STATE HIGHWAY 22 FROM THE JUNCTION OF STATE HIGHWAY 2 IN SAN JUAN, 24.9 M NORTH OF THE CENTER OF THE WESTBOUND HIGHWAY, 1.6 M NORTHWEST OF A UTILITY POLE, 16.8 M NORTHEAST OF A STREET LIGHT POLE AND A SIGN (OESTE 22), 16.2 M SOUTH OF A WITNESS POST AND THE CORNER OF 2 CONCRETE WALLS, AND 2.0 M BELOW THE LEVEL OF THE HIGHWAY. NOTE--ACCESS TO THE DATUM POINT IS THROUGH A 5-INCH LOGO CAP.  THE SLEEVE DEPTH DOES NOT MEET THE SPECIFICATIONS FOR A CLASS A MARK.  THE MARK IS ON THE HIGHWAY RIGHT-OF-WAY.                            STATION RECOVERY (2002)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 2002 (JMW) RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED.                            STATION RECOVERY (2009)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 2009 (NMD) NO COVER, BUT MARK IS GOOD. WELL PROTECTED BY STEEL PIPES AROUND IT. MARQTEK ENGINEERING.                            STATION RECOVERY (2013)  RECOVERY NOTE BY POLYTECHNIC UNIVERSITY OF PUERTO RICO 2013 (JLR) NO COVER, BUT MARK IS GOOD TO USE.                            STATION RECOVERY (2016)  RECOVERY NOTE BY DEWBERRY DAVIS 2016 (GDS) RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.
markers.setting: STAINLESS STEEL ROD IN SLEEVE (10 FT.+)
markers.stability: PROBABLY HOLD POSITION/ELEVATION WELL

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1965 (JJL) THE STATION IS LOCATED ON THE SHORELINE ABOUT 5-1/4 MILES NORTH-NORTHEAST OF CAROLINA, 5 MILES EAST OF SAN JUAN INTERNATIONAL AIRPORT, 3-1/2 MILES WEST-NORTHWEST OF LOIZA ALDEA AND ON THE WEST EDGE OF A LARGE GROVE OF COCOANUT PALM TREES.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE SAN JUAN POST OFFICE, LOIZA STREET STATION, GO EASTERLY ON LOIZA STREET FOR 5.1 MILES TO THE END OF THE PAVED ROAD JUST AFTER CROSSING A CONCRETE BRIDGE AT THE YACHT BASIN.  CONTINUE EASTERLY ON THE SAND ROAD FOR 0.95 MILE TO A Y-FORK.  KEEP THE RIGHT FORK AND CONTINUE EASTERLY ALONG THE SAND ROAD FOR 2.9 MILES TO SOME HOUSES ON THE RIGHT AND THE AZIMUTH MARK ABOUT 100 FEET TO THE LEFT, NORTH, SIDE OF THE ROAD. CONTINUE EASTERLY ALONG THE SAND ROAD FOR 0.55 MILE TO FENCE CORNERS ON BOTH SIDES OF THE ROAD AND A WIRE GATE ON THE LEFT, NORTH, SIDE OF THE ROAD.  TURN LEFT, PASS THROUGH THE GATE AND GO NORTH ALONG THE FENCE FOR ABOUT 100 FEET TO THE HIGHEST POINT OF THE SANDY HILL AND THE STATION.  THE STATION MARK IS A STANDARD DISK, STAMPED SANDY 1965, SET IN THE TOP OF A 12-INCH SQUARE CONCRETE MONUMENT THAT PROJECTS 3 INCHES.  IT IS 125.5 FEET NORTH OF THE APPROXIMATE CENTER OF THE SAND ROAD AND 14.3 FEET EAST OF THE FENCE LINE.  REFERENCE MARK 1 IS A STANDARD DISK, STAMPED SANDY NO 1 1965, SET IN THE TOP OF A 12-INCH SQUARE CONCRETE MONUMENT THAT PROJECTS 2 INCHES.  REFERENCE MARK 2 IS A STANDARD DISK, STAMPED SANDY NO 2 1965, SET IN THE TOP OF A 12-INCH SQUARE CONCRETE MONUMENT THAT PROJECTS 3 INCHES.  IT IS 12 FEET EAST OF THE FENCE LINE.  THE AZIMUTH MARK IS A STANDARD DISK, STAMPED SANDY 1965, SET IN THE TOP OF A 12-INCH SQUARE CONCRETE MONUMENT THAT PROJECTS 6 INCHES.  IT IS 113 FEET NORTH OF THE APPROXIMATE CENTER OF THE SAND ROAD.
markers.setting: SET IN TOP OF CONCRETE MONUMENT
markers.stability: MAY HOLD, BUT OF TYPE COMMONLY SUBJECT TOSURFACE MOTION

markers.description: BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1939 (EGR) THIS STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 4 KMS. S OF RD. 2.  KMS. N OF COROZAL ON BARRIO LAJAS OF TOA ALTA LOCALITY KNOWN BY NARICAO ON FARM OWNED BY SUCN. OF JOSE ANTOLINO DIAZ.  THE HILL SHAPED LIKE A FLATTENED CONE IS LOCATED ON LIMESTONE REGION, ABOUT 9 KMS. OF THE EDGE OF THE PLATEAU, IT IS THE MOST PROMINENT HILL LOCATED BETWEEN THE EDGE OF THE PLATEAU AND THE FIRST RIDGE TO THE N.  APPROACHED FROM RD. 2 BY TAR SURFACE MUN. RD. WHICH RUNS PRACTICALLY S ABOUT 4 KMS. PROCEED FROM ITS END WESTWARD AT FIRST AND SECOND FORKS, CROSS THE HEAD WATERS OF RIO LAJAS, CLIMB SLIGHTLY ON THE S EDGE OF A LOW HILL, THEN DOWN TO THE STORE OF MR. PEDRO VELEZ. CONTINUE BY FOOT SOUTHWARD BY WIDE TRAIL ALONG RIDGE ABOUT HALF A KM. TO TOP OF HILL AND STATION.  HILL LOCALLY KNOWN AS STA. BARBARA OR CARRUJAS.  STATION MARK--STANDARD B.M. TABLET STAMPED STA BARBARA 1939 EMBEDDED ON TOP OF CONCRETE MONUMENT 16- BY 32- BY 18-INCHES ANCHORED ON NATURAL ROCK LEDGE.  R.M. NO. 1--R.R. SPIKE FIXED HORIZONTALLY TO NATURAL PEAK .55 METERS FROM STATION.  R.M. NO. 2--R.R. SPIKE CEMENTED TO BOULDER 3.58 FROM STATION.  SIGNAL--POLE WITH BLACK AND WHITE FLAG NAILED TO PENDALA BRUSH 1 FT. 3 INCHES AND 7/9 OF AN INCH.                            STATION RECOVERY (1941)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1941 (GBG) ON AN OPEN, ROUNDED HILL KNOWN LOCALLY AS SANTA BARBARA OR CARRUJAS.  IN THE BARRIO LAJAS OF TOA ALTA.  ON FARM OWNED BY SUCCESORES OF ANTONIO DIAZ.  THE STATION IS ON THE TOP OF THE HILL, BY A SMALL TREE.  AND IS MARKED BY A STANDARD DISK STAMPED SANTA BARBARA 1939, SET IN TOP OF A CONCRETE MONUMENT 16- BY 18- BY 32-INCHES SET ON ROCK LEDGE.  REFERENCE MARK 1 IS A RAILROAD SPIKE SET IN ROCK LEDGE 0.55 METERS FROM STATION.  REFERENCE MARK 2 IS A RAILROAD SPIKE CEMENTED TO BOULDER 3.58 METERS FROM STATION.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM VEGA ALTA (PLAZA) GO E ON MAIN HIGHWAY TOWARDS BAYAMON 3.5 MILES.  TAKE T-FORK S.  AT 0.8 MILE KEEP STRAIGHT AHEAD.  AND GO ANOTHER 0.85 MILE.  TURN SHARP RIGHT AT FINCA.  CONTINUE STRAIGHT AHEAD FOR 0.95 MILE, AND TURN LEFT AT FORK JUST AFTER CROSSING CULVERT OVER RIO LAJAS.  PROCEED TO END OF THIS ROAD WHICH IS ABOUT 100 METERS BEYOND THE RIO LAJAS SCHOOL AND AT STORE OF MANUEL MARZAN.  THIS STORE IS ABOUT 100 METERS SE OF THE STATION, AT THE E FOOT OF THE HILL.
markers.setting: SET IN TOP OF CONCRETE MONUMENT
markers.stability: MAY HOLD, BUT OF TYPE COMMONLY SUBJECT TOSURFACE MOTION

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1901 (JEM) THIS SIGNAL IS ON SANTA HELENA MOUNTAIN, THE HIGHEST SUMMIT BETWEEN THE MAUNABO-YABUCCA ROAD THROUGH PANDURA PASS AND THE COAST.  FROM THE SUMMIT, I AM TOLD, CULEBRA, VIEQUES, SAINT THOMAS, SANTA CRUZ AND SAINT JOHN ISLANDS CAN BE SEEN.  TODAY IS HAZY AND I CAN ONLY SEE VIEQUES AND CULEBRA.  THE HILLTOP WHERE THE SIGNAL IS LOCATED IS GRASSY AND CLEAR.  ON THE SUMMIT IS A WILD ORANGE TREE.  A SMALL BOULDER, ABOUT 3 FEET HIGH AND 6 FEET LONG, IS BETWEEN THE STATION AND THE ORANGE TREE.  A BARBED-WIRE FENCE COMES UP THE HILL FROM THE DIRECTION OF THE NEAREST HOUSE (NEARLY IN LINE WITH MATA PASCUA), AND WHEN 35.5 FEET FROM THE STATION CHANGES DIRECTION AND RUNS PARALLEL WITH HILLTOP FOR A DISTANCE.  INSIDE THE FENCE IS A LUXURIANT GROWTH OF BANANAS, OUTSIDE THE FENCE UP TO THE STATION IS GRASSY.  THE FENCE, AFTER RUNNING SOME LITTLE DISTANCE PARALLEL WITH SUMMIT, TURNS EASTWARD AGAIN AND DESCENDS TOWARDS THE SEA.  IT IS SAID BY PEOPLE LIVING NEAR, THAT A SPANISH SIGNAL STOOD HERE UNTIL THE CYCLONE OF 1899. SANTA HELENA IS KNOWN TO NEARLY EVERYONE IN MAUNABO AND THERE WILL BE NO TROUBLE IN FINDING THE HILL.  A TRAIL WHICH CAN BE TRAVELED BY A GOOD HORSE LEADS TO THE STATION.  FROM THE SUMMIT AT HELENA, POINT TUNA LIGHTHOUSE IS IN PLAIN VIEW AND THE COAST LINE AND INTERIOR IS VISIBLE FOR MILES N OF HUMACAO.  STATION MARK IS A 15-INCH LENGTH OF IRON PIPE, 2 INCHES IN DIAMETER, SET IN THE GROUND ALMOST FLUSH WITH THE SURFACE THEN CEMENTED IN PLACE.  THE WILD ORANGE TREE USED FOR REFERENCE MARK CONSISTS OF TWO TRUNKS, EACH ABOUT 5 INCHES IN DIAMETER.  ON ONE OF THESE TRUNKS I MADE A BLAZE AND DROVE AND BENT TWO NAILS SO AS TO MAKE A CROSS.  THE DISTANCE FROM STATION TO CROSS IS 38.18 FEET (SLOPE DISTANCE).  AT THE SE CORNER OF THE FENCE, IN THE POST WHERE THE FENCE CHANGES DIRECTION, I DROVE A NAIL.  DISTANCE FROM STATION TO THIS NAIL IS 33.55 FEET (SLOPE).                            STATION RECOVERY (1927)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1927 (GCM) FENCE LINE AND ORANGE TREE ARE GONE.  BOULDER COULD NOT BE IDENTIFIED.  AN AREA 10 METERS ACROSS WAS CLEARED, AND WE DUG INTO GROUND BUT COULD NOT FIND STATION MARK.                            STATION RECOVERY (1963)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1963 (CFO) NO EVIDENCE OF THIS STATION WAS FOUND.

BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1902 (JN) STATION IS LOCATED ON THE HIGHEST PART OF THE PEAK OF THAT NAME ABOUT 2 MILES S OF THE VILLAGE OF LOIZA.  THE PEAK IS THE HIGHEST OF A NUMBER OF SHARP TIMBERED PEAKS IN THAT LOCALITY.  IT IS ABOUT 1-1/2 MILES E OF THE RIVER RIO GRANDE DE LOIZA.  THE STATION IS MARKED BY A 2-INCH PIPE, 14 INCHES LONG SET IN CEMENT AND PROJECTING ABOVE THE GROUND ABOUT 4 INCHES.  THE CENTER OF THE HEAD OF A NAIL CEMENTED IN THE CENTER OF THE PIPE MARKS THE STATION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1934)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1934 STATION RECOVERED AND FOUND IN GOOD CONDITION, APPARENTLY UNDISTURBED.  LOCATED ABOUT 7 KILOMETERS BY ROAD AND TRAIL, N OF CANOVANAS (OR LOIZA-NUEVA), 2 KILOMETERS E OF CARRETERA FROM LOIZA NUEVA TO LOIZA VIEJA.  DIRECTLY NE OF CENTRAL CANOVANAS OF THE LOIZA SUGAR COMPANY.  SIGNAL IS A QUADRIPOD OF SAWED LUMBER COVERED WITH WHITE CLOTH AND WITH BLACK CROSS TARGETS ON CENTER POLE.  TO REACH STATION, FOLLOW CARRETERA LEADING FROM LOIZA-NUEVA TO LOIZA VIEJA TO KILOMETER POST K4 H7, TURN E ON CART ROAD THROUGH CANE FIELDS TO FOOT OF HILLS, CLIMB TO SADDLE W OF STATION, THENCE LEFT TO STATION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1939)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1939 RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1940)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1940 THE STATION WAS RECOVERED.  BUT IT IS MARKED BY A U.S.G.S. TABLET STAMPED SANTA INEZ 1902, SET IN CEMENT BUILT UP ON THE LIMESTONE ROCK PEAK.  THIS ROCK IS THE HIGHEST POINT ON THE HIGHEST OF SEVERAL FORMING A LOW SAW-TOOTH, BRUSH-COVERED RANGE RUNNING NORTH AND SOUTH, AND IN THE MIDST OF SURROUNDING FLAT COUNTRY.  IT IS ABOUT 4 KM. NE OF CANOVANAS, AND ABOUT 3 KM. NE OF CENTRAL CANAVANSE.  AND 2 KM. EAST OF ROAD FROM CANOVANAS (LOIZA NUEVA) TO LOIZA VIEJA.  THERE ARE TWO REFERENCE MARKS CONSISTING OF COPPER NAIL AND WASHER (U.S.G.S.B.M.) CEMENTED INTO THE LIMESTONE.  ONE IS 3.65 FEET WEST OF THE STATION.  THE OTHER 5.08 FEET SOUTH OF THE STATION.  TO REACH FROM CANOVANAS PLAZA, GO EAST ON FAJARDO ROAD 0.4 MILE.  TAKE T-ROAD LEFT, AND DRIVE 0.8 MILE NORTH TO A DIRT ROAD THROUGH GATE AT A DIPPING VAT, JUST BEYOND RR CROSSING.  GO ON THIS DIRT ROAD 0.5 MILE AND TURN RIGHT AFTER PASSING SECOND OF A GROUP OF HOUSES.  CONTINUE ANOTHER 0.6 MILE ON ROAD TO A SMALL SETTLEMENT.  CROSS RR AND PASS THROUGH GATE, CONTINUING ON TRAIL AROUND NORTH EDGE OF LOW FIELD AND ACROSS LOW HUMP 0.3 MILE TO GATE.  PASSING THROUGH SAME, TURN SHARP RIGHT ON TRAIL ALONG FENCE, AND PASS BETWEEN TWO LOW HILLS.  THEN BEAR LEFT AROUND FOOT OF HILL TOWARDS ROCK CLIFF.  LEAVE CAR HERE.  AND CONTINUE ON TRAIL OVER LOW HUMP AND PAST HOUSE.  AFTER PASSING FENCE 400 FEET BEYOND HOUSE, TAKE FIRST PROMINENT TRAIL UP HILL.  AT RIDGE TURN RIGHT AND CONTINUE TO STATION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1961)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1961 (MLO) STATION WAS RECOVERED AS A U.S.G.S. TABLET STAMPED SANTA INEZ 2, 1939 SET IN CEMENT BUILT UP ON THE LIMESTONE PEAK.  R.M. NO. 1 WAS RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED.  R.M. NO. 2 WAS RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED.  A NEW TO REACH FOLLOWS--FROM CANOVANAS PLAZA TAKE P. R. 958 EAST 0.7 MILE TO JUNCTION WITH P. R. 3.  PROCEED TOWARDS THE EAST ON P. R. 3, FOR 0.3 MILE TO P. R. 185.  TURN LEFT AND GO NORTH 1.8 MILES ON P. R. 185 TO A LARGE CUT.  PARK VEHICLE AND PACK EAST ALONG NORTH EDGE OF THE RANGE OF HILLS TO THE FIFTH PROMINENT KNOB.  TAKE FIRST PROMINENT TRAIL UP HILL TO SADDLE BETWEEN FOURTH AND FIFTH KNOBS.  AT RIDGE TURN LEFT AND CONTINUE TO STATION ON TRAIL ALONG RIDGE.                            STATION RECOVERY (1966)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JJL) THE STATION MARK AND REFERENCE MARKS WERE RECOVERED AND FOUND IN GOOD CONDITION.  IT WAS NOTED AT THIS TIME THAT THE STATION DISK IS STAMPED SANTA INES 2 1939 AND NOT AS PREVIOUSLY DESCRIBED.  A COMPLETE NEW DESCRIPTION OF THE STATION FOLLOWS.  THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 5 MILES NORTHWEST OF RIO GRANDE, 2 MILES NORTH-NORTHEAST OF LOIZA AND 1-1/2 MILES SOUTH OF LOIZA ALDEA.  IT IS ON THE HIGHEST POINT OF A LONG RIDGE THAT IS SURROUNDED BY LOW WET LAND.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE BRIDGE OVER HIGHWAY 3 AT LOIZA, GO EASTERLY ON HIGHWAY 3 FOR 0.9 MILE TO HIGHWAY 188 ON THE LEFT, TURN LEFT ON HIGHWAY 188 AND GO NORTHERLY FOR 1.5 MILES TO A STEEP CUT BANK ON THE RIGHT, AT KILOMETER POST NO. 2.6 AND THE END OF TRUCK TRAVEL.  PACK EAST ALONG THE EDGE OF HILL AND THROUGH A GARBAGE DUMP FOR ABOUT 0.1 MILE TO A SMALL SADDLE, CONTINUE EASTERLY ALONG THE EDGE OF THE HILL FOR ABOUT 400 YARDS TO A GATE BY A LARGE TREE, PASS THROUGH THE GATE AND GO ABOUT 60 YARDS THEN TURN LEFT AND GO NORTHERLY UP THE HILL TO A SADDLE, TURN RIGHT AND GO EASTERLY UP THE STEEP HILL TO THE HIGHEST POINT AND THE STATION.  (IT IS ABOUT A 25 MINUTE PACK.)  THE STATION MARK IS CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN ROCK OUTCROP AND REINFORCED ON THE NORTH SIDE WITH CEMENT.  IT IS A U.S. GEOLOGICAL BENCH MARK DISK STAMPED SANTA INES 2 1939.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 1 IS A COPPER WASHER AND NAIL CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN ROCK OUTCROP.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 2 IS A COPPER WASHER AND NAIL CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN ROCK OUTCROP.  AIRLINE DISTANCE AND DIRECTION FROM NEAREST TOWN LOIZA ALDEA 1-1/2 MILES SOUTH.                            STATION RECOVERY (1971)  RECOVERY NOTE BY THOMAS ENG AND SURV 1971 (HW) STATION MARK FOUND UNDISTURBED.  COPPER NAIL AND WASHER 3.65 FEET WEST OF STATION FOUND.  STATION WAS REACHED FROM INTERSECTION OF P.R. ROUTES 3 (FAJARDO RD) AND 185 BY GOING NORTH ON RT. 185 (PAVED) FOR 5.2 KILOMETERS THROUGH THE VILLAGE OF SAN ISIDRO AND THERE LEAVING THE VEHICLE.  WALK EAST ALONG THE BASE OF THE HILL (RIDGE) ON A GOOD TRAIL FOR 450 METERS TO A FENCE.  TURN LEFT (NORTH) AND FOLLOW A TRAIL NORTH TO A SADDLE.  THEN FOLLOW A DIM TRAIL EAST (RIGHT) 80 METERS TO THE TOP OF THE RIDGE AND THE STATION.  (15 MINUTE PACK)                            STATION RECOVERY (1993)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL OCEAN SERVICE 1993 THE STATION WAS RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION. THERE IS NOW A GATE AND HOUSE ON THE EAST SIDE OF HILL AT MAIN ROAD. UPON GAINING PERMISSION ENTER GATE AND FOLLOW TRACK ROAD EAST TO ITS END. PACK NORTHERLY UP STEEP HILL TO TOP OF RIDGE AND STATION.  THE TRAIL IS WELL MARKED AT THIS TIME BUT DUE TO JUNGLE NATURE OF THIS AREA IT MAY BE DIFFICULT TO FIND.  THE AREA AROUND THE STATION HAS BEEN CLEARED OF ALL TREES.  PUERTO RICAN GOVERNMENT SURVEYORS ASSISTED IN FINDING THIS STATION.
markers.setting: SET IN ROCK OUTCROP
markers.stability: MOST RELIABLE AND EXPECTED TO HOLDPOSITION/ELEVATION WELL

markers.description: PTIVE TEXT AVAILABLE.
PTIVE TEXT AVAILABLE.

BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JJL) THE STATION IS LOCATED AT THE NORTHWEST EDGE OF SANTA ISABEL.  THE TANK IS A CYLINDRICAL, STEEL STRUCTURE, SILVER IN COLOR, SUPPORTED BY FOUR STEEL LEGS AND IT IS ABOUT 100 FEET HIGH.  IT IS THE MOST EASTERLY TANK OF TWO TANKS.  POINT INTERSECTED IS THE ROUND BALL ATOP AND CENTER OF THE TANK.                            STATION RECOVERY (1971)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1971 (EKM) THE STATION WAS RECOVERED USING DESCRIPTION BY JJL IN 1966.  INSERT THE FOLLOWING IN JJL DESCRIPTION--COLOR, WITH RUST COLORED TOP, SUPPORTED-----                            STATION RECOVERY (1975)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1975 (RMB) THE STATION WAS RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED PREVIOUSLY.  IT IS 95 FEET HIGH.  ADD TO REACH  TO REACH THE STATION PROCEED NORTH FROM THE NORTHEAST CORNER OF THE SANTA ISABEL PLAZA ON HIGHWAY 153 FOR 0.3 MILE TO THE TOWN LIMIT.  THE STATION IS THE EASTERN-MOST TANK OF 2 TANKS WEST OF THE HIGHWAY.

BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JJL) THE STATION IS LOCATED AT THE NORTHWEST EDGE OF SANTA ISABEL.  THE TANK IS A CYLINDRICAL, STEEL STRUCTURE, SILVER IN COLOR, SUPPORTED BY 4 STEEL LEGS AND IT IS ABOUT 100 FEET HIGH.  IT IS THE MOST WESTERLY TANK OF TWO TANKS.  POINT INTERSECTED IS THE ROUND BALL ATOP AND CENTER OF THE TANK.                            STATION RECOVERY (1971)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1971 (EKM) THE STATION WAS RECOVERED USING DESCRIPTION BY JJL IN 1966.  INSERT THE FOLLOWING IN JJL DESCRIPTION--COLOR, WITH RUST COLORED TOP, SUPPORTED ----                            STATION RECOVERY (1975)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1975 (RMB) THE STATION WAS RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED PREVIOUSLY.  IT IS 98 FEET HIGH.  ADD TO REACH  TO REACH THE STATION PROCEED NORTH FROM THE NORTHEAST CORNER OF THE SANTA ISABEL PLAZA ON HIGHWAY 153 FOR 0.3 MILE TO THE TOWN LIMIT.  THE STATION IS THE WESTERN-MOST TANK OF 2 TANKS WEST OF THE HIGHWAY.

BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1941 (RLS) THIS INTERSECTION STATION IS ABOUT 1 MILE NE OF CEIBA, AT SANTA MARIA, ABOUT 215 METERS W OF THE AMERICAN RAILROAD TRACK, 90 METERS E OF THE CENTER LINE OF INSULAR HIGHWAY 3, AT THE N EDGE OF THE VILLAGE OF SANTA MARIA.  A RED-BRICK STACK ABOUT 75 FEET HIGH.  THE STACK IS THE ONLY REMAINS OF A SMALL SUGAR REFINERY AND IS ITSELF PARTLY IN RUINS.  THE STATION IS THE CENTER OF THE STACK.                            STATION RECOVERY (1964)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1964 (GWM) STATION RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED.

BY LOCAL ENGINEER (INDIVIDUAL OR FIRM) 1966 (JWC) RECOVERED BY PRS.  THE STATION MARK IS AN IRON PEG SET IN THE TOP OF A 14-INCH SQUARE CONCRETE MONUMENT WHICH PROJECTS 1 INCH.  IT HAS SANTONI INSCRIBED IN THE TOP OF THE CONCRETE MONUMENT.
markers.setting: SET IN TOP OF CONCRETE MONUMENT
markers.stability: MAY HOLD, BUT OF TYPE COMMONLY SUBJECT TOSURFACE MOTION

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1902 (JN) STATION IS ON A BARE KNOLL, WITH THE EXCEPTION OF A ROYAL PALM ABOUT 40 FEET S OF IT, ON THE PROPERTY OF GONZOLES DE LOS SANTOS.  IT IS ABOUT 4 MILES INLAND FROM THE COAST AND NOT FAR FROM THE SMALL TOWN OF MEMELLA, BUT CAN ONLY BE REACHED ON HORSE BACK OVER A ROUGH TRAIL LEAVING FROM THE ABOVE NAMED TOWN.  THE STATION IS AT AN ELEVATION OF ABOUT 900 FEET.  IT IS MARKED BY A GALVANIZED IRON PIPE 2 INCHES IN DIAMETER AND 3 FEET LONG, SET IN CEMENT.  THE TOP OF THE PIPE PROJECTS ABOUT 1/2 INCH ABOVE THE BED OF CEMENT.  A NAIL INSIDE THE PIPE SUNK IN THE CEMENT MARKS THE CENTER.
markers.setting: SET INTO TOP OF METAL PIPE DRIVEN INTO GROUND
markers.stability: MARK OF QUESTIONABLE OR UNKNOWN STABILITY

markers.description: BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1934 STATION IS 3 KILOMETERS BY ROAD AND TRAIL SW OF THE VILLAGE OF MEMEYES, S OF THE CARRETERA BETWEEN RIO GRANDE AND LUQUILLO, ON ONE OF THE FOOTHILLS TO THE N OF YUNQUE.  THERE IS A MORE PROMINENT PEAK OF NEARLY EQUAL HEIGHT ABOUT 1 KILOMETER TO THE NW AND A MUCH HIGHER BRUSH-COVERED ONE ABOUT THE SAME DISTANCE TO THE SE.  THE SUMMIT HAS A DOUBLE TOP, THE STATION BEING LOCATED ON THE MOST NORTHERLY, 3.2 FEET N OF A LARGE BOULDER AND 15 FEET W OF ANOTHER NOT QUITE SO LARGE.  (NOTE--THIS STATION IS VERY NEAR THE U.S.C. AND G.S. STATION SANTOS ESTABLISHED IN 1902.  A CONCRETE POST, 8 INCHES SQUARE AND PROJECTING ABOUT 10 INCHES ABOVE GROUND WITH 1 1/2-INCH HOLE IN TOP, WAS FOUND, BUT NATIVES LIVING IN THE VICINITY SAY THIS WAS PLACED THERE ONLY ABOUT FIVE OR SIX YEARS AGO AND NO INFORMATION COULD BE OBTAINED INDICATING IT MARKED THE EXACT ORIGINAL POSITION.  THE NEW STATION MARK WAS SET IN THE HOLE IN THIS CONCRETE POST).  STATION MARK IS A STANDARD U.S.G.S. TABLET, STAMPED SANTOS 2, 1934, CEMENTED IN TOP OF CONCRETE POST.  REFERENCE MARK NO.1 IS A CROSS CUT ON BENCH OF A LARGE BOULDER, 17.88 FEET FROM STATION IN TRUE AZIMUTH 220 DEG 49 MIN.  NO.2 IS A CROSS CUT ON SLOPING FACE OF LARGE BOULDER, 34.26 FEET FROM STATION IN TRUE AZIMUTH 339 DEG 03 MIN.  SIGNAL--A QUADRIPOD OF SAWED LUMBER WITH BLACK CROSS-TARGETS ON CENTER POLE.  TO REACH STATION FOLLOW CART ROAD LEADING SOUTHWARD FROM THE CARRETERA AT STORE AND HOUSES ONE KILOMETER W OF MEMEYES, FOR 2 KILOMETERS, THIS ROAD CONTINUING AS A TRAIL, PASSES JUST UNDER THE PEAK TO THE E.                            STATION RECOVERY (1940)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1940 RECOVERED STATION AND REFERENCE MARKS AS DESCRIBED, IN GOOD CONDITION.
markers.setting: SET IN TOP OF CONCRETE MONUMENT

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JJL) THE STATION IS LOCATED IN THE CENTRAL PART OF SANTURCE AND ON TOP OF THE FIRST FEDERAL SAVINGS BUILDING.  THE FIRST FEDERAL SAVINGS BUILDING IS A 14 STORY BLUE AND WHITE BUILDING AT THE NORTHEAST CORNER OF THE INTERSECTION OF PONCE DE LEON AVENUE AND DEL PARQUE STREET.  THE MAST IS A 3-LEGGED STEEL STRUCTURE, SUPPORTED BY GUY WIRES, PAINTED ALTERNATELY RED AND WHITE AND IT HAS TWO RED OBSTRUCTION LIGHTS ON TOP.  IT PROJECTS ABOUT 30 FEET ABOVE THE BUILDING.  POINT INTERSECTED IS THE TOP AND CENTER OF THE MAST.

BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JJL) THE STATION IS LOCATED IN THE NORTHWEST PART OF SANTURCE AND ON THE U.S. NAVAL STATION SAN JUAN.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE ENTRANCE TO ISLA GRANDE AIRPORT THAT IS NEAR THE JUNCTION OF HIGHWAYS 1,25,26 AND 35 GO WEST AND SOUTH TOWARD THE AIRPORT FOR 0.8 MILE, THENCE TURN LEFT AND GO EAST FOR 0.1 MILE TO THE STATION.  THE WATER TANK IS A CYLINDRICAL STEEL STRUCTURE WITH A SLOPING ROOF, SUPPORTED BY 6 LEGS, PAINTED ALTERNATELY RED AND WHITE AND IT HAS TWO RED OBSTRUCTION LIGHTS ON TOP.  THE TANK IS ABOUT 200 FEET HIGH.  POINT INTERSECTED IS THE VENT ATOP AND CENTER OF THE TANK.

BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JJL) THE STATION IS LOCATED IN THE CENTRAL PART OF SANTURCE AND ON TOP OF THE PROFESSIONAL BUILDING.  THE PROFESSIONAL BUILDING IS AN ELEVEN STORY YELLOW BUILDING AT 310 JOSE DE DIEGO AVENUE.  THE ANTENNA POLE IS A 4-INCH STEEL POLE, PAINTED ALUMINUM, SUPPORTED BY GUY WIRES AND IT PROJECTS ABOUT 30 FEET ABOVE THE BUILDING.  POINT INTERSECTED IS THE TOP AND CENTER OF THE POLE.

BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1900 (WCH) STATION IS ON THE SUMMIT AND NEARLY IN THE MIDDLE OF THIS SMALL ROCKY ISLET, LYING NEAR THE NE COAST OF CULEBRA.  MARKED BY AN IRON PIPE (2-INCH) CEMENTED INTO A NARROW CLEFT IN A LARGE ROCK.  SIGNAL, A BRACED POLE.                            STATION RECOVERY (1926)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1926 (GCM) RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED.  STATION MARK IN GOOD CONDITION.  STATION MARK IN OUTCROPPING BEDROCK ABOUT 20 FEET IN CIRCUMFERENCE.                            STATION RECOVERY (1957)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1957 (RCD) RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED.  STATION MARK IN GOOD CONDITION.

BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1902 (JN) THIS STATION IS ON A SHARP WOODED HILL ABOUT 3 MILES E OF SANTURCE.  IT IS 1/4 MILE S OF A LARGE LAGOON AND NEAR A QUARRY WHERE THEY PROCURE STONE FOR THE MILITARY ROAD.  THE STATION IS MARKED BY A BRASS BOLT 6 INCHES LONG EMBEDDED IN CEMENT FLUSH WITH THE SURFACE.  THE BOLT IS IN A CORAL ROCK.  CENTER OF HEAD OF THE BRASS BOLT IS THE STATION.  IT IS DISTANT FROM BLAZED TREES, MARKED WITH NAILS, AS FOLLOWS--SW OF TREE IS 11.3 (METERS), E OF TREE 19.0 (METERS) AND NW OF TREE 22.5 (METERS).                            STATION RECOVERY (1964)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1964 (GWM) STATION HAS BEEN DESTROYED.  THE HILL IS GONE.
markers.setting: SET IN ROCK OUTCROP
markers.stability: MOST RELIABLE AND EXPECTED TO HOLDPOSITION/ELEVATION WELL

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1901 (JN) STATION IS 0.2 MILE S OF SABANA SECA STATION OR CROSSING, AND SITUATED ABOUT 2-1/2 MILES W OF STATION BAYAMON ON THE FENO CANIL RAILROAD, ABOUT 100 METERS S FROM THE TRACK.  IT IS ON A HILL ABOUT 250 FEET HIGH, WHICH IS MUCH FARTHER N THAN ANY OTHER IN THE LINE OF HILLS.  THE POINT IS MARKED BY A GALVANIZED IRON PIPE 2 FEET BY 2 INCHES SET IN A SOLID BED OF CEMENT.  THE PIPE IS FILLED WITH SMALL STONES TO WITHIN 5 INCHES OF THE TOP AND THE REMAINDER WITH CEMENT.  A 20-PENNY SPIKE IS SET IN THE CEMENT IN THE PIPE AND THE CENTER OF THIS IS THE MARK.                            STATION RECOVERY (1931)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1931 TAKE THE AMERICAN RAILROAD TRAIN TO PALO SECA.  THE ORIGINAL HILL SELECTED APPROACHED THE RAILROAD NEAR THE POST MARK KILOMETERS 22-400.  TUBE DISAPPEARED, BUT CEMENT BED FOUND.  THIS STATION WAS MOVED TO ANOTHER HILL SE OF THE FIRST AND SEPARATED FROM IT ABOUT 200 METERS.  THE HILL IS KNOWN AS EL HORNO.  LAND OWNED BY SUC. JAIME PIZA.  CONCRETE MONUMENT WITH IRON ROD MARKING CENTER OF STATION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1946)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US ARMY CORPS OF ENGINEERS 1946 LETTER FROM MR. E.G. RUBIO, HQ. ANTILLES DEPT., OFFICE OF DEPT. ENGR., A.P.O. 851, C/O P.M., MIAMI, FLORIDA, DATED OCTOBER 30, 1946--  NO EFFORT WAS MADE FOR ITS RECOVERY SINCE IT WAS TOO LOW FOR EXPANSION INLAND.  SECA 2 1930 WAS ESTABLISHED NEAR HILL.
markers.setting: SET INTO TOP OF METAL PIPE DRIVEN INTO GROUND
markers.stability: MARK OF QUESTIONABLE OR UNKNOWN STABILITY

markers.description: BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1939 THIS STATION IS NOT SECA 1901.  IT IS LOCATED ON ANOTHER HILL 150 METERS SE OF THE SITE OF THE OLD STATION.  SECA 2 IS A ROUND POINT AT SPUR, THE SECOND ONE E OF THE VILLAGE AND SCHOOL OF SABANA SECA AND 7.50 METERS FROM THEM.  APPROACHED FROM BAYAMON BY THE MUNICIPAL ROAD TO SABANA SECA, FROM THERE FOLLOW ROAD NE TO THE R.R. CROSSING WHERE TURNING RIGHT (E) FOLLOW DIRT ROAD 350 METERS TO THE ENTRANCE OF THE VALLEY W OF WHICH IS THE STATION.  LAND IS OWNED BY MANUEL GONZALEZ.  STATION MARK--CENTER POINT OF A 3/4-INCH IRON BAR ON A CONCRETE BLOCK 6- BY 19-INCH ANCHORED TO NATURAL ROCK.  REFERENCE MARK 1--STANDARD BRASS NAIL AND WASHER CEMENTED TO ROCK E OF STATION, DISTANT 1.18 METERS, HORIZONTAL.  REFERENCE MARK 2--STANDARD BRASS NAIL AND WASHER CEMENTED TO ROCK S OF STATION, DISTANT 1.705 METERS, HORIZONTAL.  TOP OF TARGETS ABOVE STATION MARK IS 5.01 METERS.                            STATION RECOVERY (1964)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1964 (GWM) THE STATION WAS PLOTTED ON A USGS QUAD. SHEET AND THE QUAD. SHEET WAS USED TO FIND THE HILL AS WELL AS THE LOWER HILL SECA WAS TO BE ON.  THE TOPS OF BOTH HILLS WERE SEARCHED AND THE MARKS COULD NOT BE FOUND.  THERE IS NO CONSTRUCTION ON THESE HILLS.
markers.setting: UNSPECIFIED SETTING

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JWC) THE STATION IS LOCATED 10 AIRLINE MILES WEST-NORTHWEST OF SAN GERMAN, 7 AIRLINE MILES SOUTH OF MAYAGUEZ, 2 AIRLINE MILES NORTHWEST OF CABO ROJO AND ON THE TOP OF A LOW CULTIVATED HILL.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE NORTHEAST CORNER OF THE PLAZA IN CABO ROJO, GO NORTH FOR 1 BLOCK TO HIGHWAY 102.  TURN LEFT AND GO WEST ON HIGHWAY 102 FOR 0.25 MILE TO HIGHWAY 311.  TURN RIGHT AND GO NORTH ON HIGHWAY 311 FOR 1.5 MILES TO A GATE ON THE LEFT.  TURN LEFT, PASS THROUGH THE GATE AND GO WEST ON A TRACK ROAD FOR 0.25 MILE TO A REVERSE Y FORK.  KEEP RIGHT AND CONTINUE WESTERLY ON THE TRACK ROAD FOR 0.35 MILE TO THE WEST EDGE OF THE CULTIVATED HILL AND THE STATION.  THE STATION MARK IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED SEDA 1966, SET IN THE TOP OF A 10-INCH SQUARE CONCRETE MONUMENT WHICH IS FLUSH WITH THE SURFACE.  REFERENCE MARK 1 IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED SEDA NO 1 1966, SET IN THE TOP OF A 10-INCH SQUARE CONCRETE MONUMENT WHICH IS FLUSH WITH THE SURFACE.  REFERENCE MARK 2 IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED SEDA NO 2 1966, SET IN THE TOP OF A 10-INCH SQUARE CONCRETE MONUMENT WHICH IS FLUSH WITH THE SURFACE.  NO AZIMUTH MARK WAS ESTABLISHED AT THIS STATION.

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1900 (WCH) NATIVE NAME FOR LOCALITY.  STATION IS ON THE SUMMIT OF THE SUMMIT OF THE NORTHWESTERN KNOB OF THE DENSELY WOODED ISLAND CALLED NE CAY.  THE STATION IS MARKED BY A TRIANGLE CUT IN THE UPPER SURFACE OF A LARGE STONE HALF BURIED IN THE GROUND, WITH EDGES CEMENTED.  TRIPOD SIGNAL 30 FEET TO FLAG.                            STATION RECOVERY (1965)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1965 (MTF) THE STATION WAS NOT RECOVERED.  THE ORIGINAL TRIANGULATION STATION, A TRIANGLE CUT IN THE UPPER SURFACE OF A LARGE STONE HALF BURIED IN THE GROUND, WAS NOT FOUND AFTER A TWO HOUR SEARCH.  A 1/2 IN DIAMETER METAL ROD WITH A CROSS ETCHED IN ITS CENTER WAS FOUND IMBEDDED IN A 9.5 IN X 9.5 IN CONCRETE PAD SET FLUSH WITH THE GROUND.  THE PAD HAD 16 INSCRIBED ON THE WEST SIDE OF ITS TOP SURFACE.  THE PAD WAS 9 FT. EAST OF THE 2.5 FT. X 6.0 FT. X 4.5 FT. (HIGH) BOULDER ON THE SUMMIT OF A 230 FT. KNOLL ON THE NORTHWEST END OF NORTHEAST CAY.  A LARGE CACTUS PLANT WAS SITUATED APPROXIMATELY 30 FT. WEST FROM THE CONCRETE PAD.  THICK VEGETATION SURROUNDED THE SMALL CLEARING ON TOP OF THE SUMMIT.

BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1925 (GCM) STATION IS LOCATED ON THE HIGHEST PART OF SHARK ROCK AND IS MARKED BY A STANDARD BRASS DISK WEDGED IN A DRILL HOLE IN OUTCROPPING BEDROCK.  NO REFERENCE MARKS ESTABLISHED.  AN 8-FOOT POLE WITH BANNER USED AS A SIGNAL.

markers.description: BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 2000 (AFL) THE STATION IS LOCATED AT THE LUIS MUNOZ MARIN INTERNATIONAL AIRPORT, SAN JUAN, PUERTO RICO, IN A GRASS ISLAND AT THE JUNCTION OF TAXIWAYS HZ AND HH NEAR THE APPROACH END OF RUNWAY 10.  OWNERSHIP--PUERTO RICO PORTS AUTHORITY, P.O.  BOX 362829, SAN JUAN, PUERTO RICO 00936-2829. CHIEF OF OPERATIONS IS FELIX RIVERA DE JESUS.  PHONE 809-791-0067 OR 809-791-0314, FAX 809-791-4835.  CONTACT HIM FOR PERMISSION TO OCCUPY THIS STATION AND TO ARRANGE FOR AN ESCORT.  OTHER CONTACTS ARE--HARRY NARVAEZ-MUNET, ASSISTANT AVIATION DIRECTOR, L.M.M.  INTERNATIONAL AIRPORT, P.O.  BOX 37250, AIRPORT STATION, SAN JUAN, P.R.  00937, PHONE 809-791-4219 OR 809-791-1010, FAX 809-791-4835, AND JOSE M. MURILLO, AIR TRAFFIC MANAGER, SAN JUAN ATCT, L.M.M.  INTERNATIONAL AIRPORT, CAROLINA, P.R.  00979, PHONE 809-253-4546, FAX 809-253-4576. TO REACH FROM THE JUNCTION OF HIGHWAY 26 AND THE AIRPORT ENTRANCE ROAD GO EAST ON THE ENTRANCE ROAD FOR ABOUT 0.59 KM (0.35 MI) TO A OFF RAMP LEADING TO CHECKPOINT 1 ON THE RIGHT.  BEAR RIGHT ON RAMP AND FOLLOW THE CLOVERLEAF AND CROSS BACK OVER THE AIRPORT ENTRANCE ROAD TO A T-JUNCTION.  TURN LEFT AND GO EASTERLY ON PAVED ROAD FOR 0.16 KM (0.10 MI) TO A GUARD SHACK AND CHECKPOINT 1 ON THE LEFT.  CHECK IN WITH SECURITY AND GO THROUGH GATE.  MAKE WAY NORTHERLY ON APRON FOR 0.16 KM (0.10 MI) TO TAXIWAY SS.  TURN LEFT AND GO WESTERLY ON TAXIWAY SS FOR 0.30 KM (0.20 MI) TO TAXIWAY HZ (THE WESTERNMOST TAXIWAY) .  TURN LEFT ONTO TAXIWAY HZ AND GO SOUTHERLY FOR 0.30 KM (0.20 MI) TO THE JUNCTION OF TAXIWAYS HZ AND H AND THE MARK ON THE LEFT IN A GRASS ISLAND.  THE STATION IS A HORIZONTAL CONTROL DISK SET IN SOUTHWEST CORNER OF AN 7X7 FOOT CONCRETE ELECTRICAL VAULT.  IT IS 33.4 M (109.6 FT) EAST OF THE CENTERLINE OF TAXIWAY HZ, 10.9 M (35.8 FT) NORTHWEST ON A CONCRETE STORM WATER DRAIN, 10.7 M (35.1 FT) SOUTHWEST OF A TAXIWAY SIGN, 1.8 M (5.9 FT) NORTH OF A TAXIWAY SIGN, 0.1 M (0.3 FT) NORTHEAST OF THE SOUTHWEST CORNER OF THE ELECTRICAL VAULT AND SET LEVEL WITH THE GROUND.  NOTE--THIS STATION IS A SECONDARY AIRPORT CONTROL STATION (SACS) .

W OF VEGA BAJA ON TOP OF THE MOST PROMINENT POINT OF A RIDGE RUNNING PARALLEL TO RD. 2 N OF KM. 49.9 ON LAND OWNED BY RAMON SOBRINO.  APPROACHED FROM RD. 2 FOLLOWING CAR ROAD W MAIN FARMHOUSE AND THAT RUNS BY DERRICK TO STEEP PART GOING DOWN BETWEEN TWO LOW HILLS FOLLOWING ON FOOT NW THROUGH GRAPEFRUIT ORCHARD ABOUT A HUNDRED METERS TO A POINT DUE S OF FIRST SADDLE E OF STATION. markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JJL) THE STATION IS LOCATED ON THE SOUTHEAST EDGE OF ROOSEVELT ROADS NAVAL STATION AND ON CABRAS ISLAND.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM GATE NUMBER 1 OF ROOSEVELT ROADS NAVAL STATION, GO SOUTHEAST ON TARAWA DRIVE FOR 0.1 MILE TO A FORK.  TAKE THE LEFT FORK AND CONTINUE SOUTHEAST ON TARAWA DRIVE FOR 1.8 MILES TO A FORK.  TAKE THE LEFT FORK AND GO EAST ON FORRESTAL DRIVE FOR 0.7 MILE TO A FORK.  TAKE THE RIGHT FORK AND CONTINUE ON FORRESTAL DRIVE FOR 1.95 MILES TO A FORK.  TAKE THE RIGHT FORK AND GO SOUTHWEST ON A DIRT ROAD FOR 0.3 MILE TO A FORK.  TAKE THE LEFT FORK AND GO SOUTHWEST ON A DIRT ROAD FOR 0.5 MILE TO THE STATION ON THE LEFT, NORTHWEST SIDE OF THE ROAD.  THE STATION MARK IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED SOL 2 1965, SET IN THE TOP OF A CONCRETE MONUMENT THAT IS 12 INCHES IN DIAMETER.  IT IS 103 FEET NORTHWEST OF THE APPROXIMATE CENTER OF A DIRT ROAD, 20.6 FEET SOUTH OF A POWER POLE AND ON THE HIGHEST GROUND IN THE IMMEDIATE AREA.  REFERENCE MARK 1 IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED SOL 2 NO 1 1965, SET IN THE TOP OF A CONCRETE MONUMENT THAT IS 12 INCHES IN DIAMETER AND PROJECTS 3 INCHES.  IT IS 44 FEET SOUTH OF THE POWER POLE AND 77 FEET NORTHWEST OF THE DIRT ROAD.  REFERENCE MARK 2 IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED SOL 2 NO 2 1965, SET IN THE TOP OF A CONCRETE MONUMENT THAT IS 12 INCHES IN DIAMETER AND IS FLUSH WITH THE SURFACE OF THE GROUND.  IT IS 29 FEET SOUTHWEST OF THE POWER POLE.                            STATION RECOVERY (1977)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1977 (WFP) THE STATION MARK, REFERENCE MARK 1 AND REFERENCE MARK 2 WERE RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION AS DESCRIBED IN 1966.  THE STATION MARK WAS USED AS A CHECK ANGLE FOR STATION PUERCA 3.  DUE TO ROAD CHANGES, A NEW DESCRIPTION FOLLOWS.  (TO REACH)  THE STATION IS LOCATED ON THE SOUTHEAST EDGE OF ROOSEVELT ROADS NAVAL STATION AND ON CABRAS ISLAND.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM GUARD GATE 1 AT THE ENTRANCE TO ROOSEVELT ROADS NAVAL BASE, GO EASTERLY ON PAVED ROAD FOR 0.1 MILE TO A FORK, KEEP LEFT AND CONTINUE EASTERLY ON PAVED ROAD FOR 0.8 MILE TO A T-INTERSECTION.  TURN LEFT AND GO EAST AND SOUTH ON PAVED WINDING ROAD FOR 1.9 MILE TO A T-INTERSECTION.  TURN LEFT AND GO SOUTHEASTERLY ON PAVED ROAD FOR 0.6 MILE TO A FORK, KEEP LEFT AND CONTINUE SOUTHEASTERLY FOR 0.8 MILE TO A FORK, KEEP LEFT ON MAIN ROAD, SOUTHEASTERLY, FOR 0.4 MILE TO A FORK AND A SIGN SAYING FLTAC FIELD OFFICE.  KEEP LEFT FORK AND CONTINUE SOUTHEAST ON ANTIEDAM FOR 0.3 MILE TO THE JUNCTION OF BARNES ST. AND ANTIEDAM.  TURN RIGHT ONTO BARNES ST. AND GO NORTHEASTERLY FOR 0.35 MILES TO A BEND.  CONTINUE AROUND BEND FOR 0.1 MILE TO A T-INTERSECTION.  TURN LEFT AND FOLLOW THE MAIN ROAD SOUTHWESTERLY FOR 0.25 MILE TO A 4-WAY INTERSECTION.  TURN LEFT AND FOLLOW THE WINDING PAVED ROAD FOR 1.2 MILES TO THE CAUSEWAY GATE.  CONTINUE THROUGH GATE AND OVER CAUSEWAY FOR 0.45 MILE TO A DIRT SIDE ROAD LEFT.  TURN LEFT ONTO DIRT ROAD FOR APPROX. 0.05 MILE TO STATION ON THE RIGHT, BENEATH A NAVY RANGE POLE STRUCTURE, ABOUT 40 FEET SOUTHEAST OF DIRT ROAD.  AIRLINE DISTANCE AND DIRECTION FROM NEAREST TOWN ON CABRAS ISLAND, ROOSEVELT RDS. NAV. STA.

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1900 (JBB) STATION IS ON SOLDIER POINT, LOCALLY CALLED PUNTA DA SOLDADO, THE SOUTHERN EXTREMITY OF THE ISLAND OF CULEBRA.  THE SIGNAL WAS ON THE HIGH GROUND ABOUT 150 METERS FROM THE END OF THE POINT AND 20 METERS FROM THE CLIFF ON THE WESTERN SIDE.  THE STATION WAS MARKED BY A TACK DRIVEN IN A WOODEN STUB SET IN THE GROUND.  A TRIPOD SIGNAL WAS ERECTED OVER THE STATION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1902)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1902 (RLF) STATION RECOVERED.  MARKED BY A CEMENT BLOCK - 6 INCHES CROSS-SECTION ON TOP.  THE NUMBER 1900 MARKED ON TOP.  IN GOOD CONDITION.  A WAGON ROAD LEADS UP ON THE RIDGE NEAR THE STATION FROM THE COVE ON THE W SIDE OF THE POINT.                            STATION RECOVERY (1923)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1923 (FTS) STATION PROBABLY UNDER THE HUGE MOUND OF ROCKS ON THE TOP OF WHICH SOLDADO 2 WAS ESTABLISHED.

BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1923 (FTS) STATION IS A CONCRETE POST HAVING A STANDARD DISK IN THE TOP, WHICH IS CEMENTED IN THE TOP OF A LARGE CAIRN OF ROCKS.  THIS CAIRN OF ROCKS IS ABOUT 15 FEET HIGH AND 20 FEET ON EACH SIDE OF A TRIANGLE.  IT IS QUITE A REMARKABLE HEAP OF ROCKS BEING BUILT UP MUCH THE SAME AS MASONRY.  STATION AND REFERENCE MARKS ARE STANDARD DISKS SET IN CONCRETE, AS DESCRIBED IN NOTES 1A AND 11A.  REFERENCE MARKS WERE PLACED IN RANGE WITH POINT VACA AND POINT SOLDADO.                            STATION RECOVERY (1965)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1965 (MTP) THE TRIANGULATION STATION WAS RECOVERED AT THE SOUTH END OF PT SOLDADO ON SOUTHERN PEN.  TO REACH THE STATION DRIVE APPROXIMATELY 2.5 MILES SOUTHEAST FROM THE POST OFFICE IN CUELEBRA ALONG THE SOUTHERN SIDE OF ENSENADA HONDA TO CONCHA COVE.  APPROXIMATELY 0.15 MILES EAST OF CONCHA COVE WALK ALONG A TRAIL OVER A BRUSHY MOUNTAIN RIDGE.  PASS TO THE WEST OF SUENO COVE ENROUTE TO PT. SOLDADO.  A TWENTY MINUTE HIKE IS REQUIRED.  A STANDARD TRIANGULATION MARK DISK WAS NOT FOUND.  IN ITS PLACE WAS A 6 FT. X 6 FT. CONCRETE PAD, 1 FOOT THICK SITTING ON A CAIRN OF ROCKS APPROXIMATELY 6 FT. HIGH.  IN THE CENTER OF THE PAD WAS A 20 FT. TOWER.  THE REFERENCE MARK DISKS WERE FOUND AS DESCRIBED.                            STATION RECOVERY (1965)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1965 (JMC) STATION SHOULD BE CONSIDERED LOST.  THE NAVY HAS BUILT A LIGHT ON THE CAIRN OF ROCKS.  RM 1 RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.  RM 2 APPEARS TO HAVE BEEN DISTURBED, MARK IS LEANING AND LOOSE IN GROUND.  THIS POINT CAN NOT BE REACHED BY ROAD, BEST REACHED BY LANDING ON SMALL SANDY BEACH NW OF POINT AND FOLLOWING TRAIL TO TOP OF HILL.
markers.setting: SET IN TOP OF CONCRETE MONUMENT

markers.description: BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1940 LOCATED 11 KM. S OF CAMUY AND 8 KM. N OF LARES ON BRUSHY TOP.  LAND IS OWNED BY THE SOLLER CENTRAL.  TO REACH FROM LARES DRIVE TO KM. POST K19 H7.  TURN LEFT (NW) ONTO GRAVEL ROAD LEADING TO CENTRAL SOLLER.  FOLLOW MAIN ROAD TOWARD CENTRAL 3.5 MILES.  TURN RIGHT (N) AT T-ROAD WHICH IS 0.2 MILE BEYOND A DISTINCT JOG IN THE MAIN ROAD.  FOLLOW CART ROAD 0.9 MILE TO FOOT OF HILL.  WALK N TO GAP AND W UP RIDGE TO TOP AND STATION.  STATION MARK--STANDARD TABLET SET IN ROCK OUTCROP.  R.M. NO. 1--20D NAIL DRIVEN IN STUMP OF SMALL TREE 6.8 FT. S86E.  R.M. NO. 2--20D NAIL DRIVEN IN STUMP OF SMALL TREE 4.5 FT. S74W.                            STATION RECOVERY (1941)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1941 (GBG) LOCATED 11 KILOMETERS S CAMUY.  AND 8 KILOMETERS N OF LARES, ON A BRUSH-COVERED HILL OWNED BY THE CENTRAL SOLLER.  THE HILL SLOPES ABRUPTLY TO THE SOUTHWARD, AND MORE GENTLY TO THE NORTHWARD.  THE STATION MARK IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED SOLLER 373.12.  IT IS SET IN A SMALL, FLAT, ROCK ABOUT FLUSH WITH THE GROUND.  REFERENCE MARK 1 IS A 20-PENNY NAIL IN STUMP OF SMALL TREE 6.8 FEET FROM THE STATION, BEARING S 86 DEG E.  REFERENCE MARK 2 IS A 20-PENNY NAIL IN STUMP OF SMALL TREE 4.5 FEET FROM THE STATION, BEARING S 44 DEG W.  TO REACH FROM LARES, GO NE ON THE ARECIBO ROAD TO KM. 19 H.7 AND TURN LEFT.  GO 1.2 MILES AND TAKE T-ROAD LEFT (W) GOING 0.25 MILE TO BIG, TWO-STORY, YELLOW HOUSE.  BEAR RIGHT AND FOLLOW MAIN ROAD FOR 1.9 MILES.  TAKE T-ROAD RIGHT (N) WHICH IS ABOUT 0.2 MILE BEYOND ANOTHER SIMILAR ROAD, AND GO 0.75 MILE TO A CANE DERRICK.  CONTINUE STRAIGHT AHEAD 0.2 MILE IN LANE TO END OF CAR TRAVEL.  GO ON FOOT NORTHWARD TO LOW GAP, TURN W THROUGH FENCE AND GO UP HILL TO ANOTHER FENCE.  AND TURN S ALONG DIM TRAIL UP TO TOP AND THE STATION.
markers.setting: SET IN ROCK OUTCROP

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1927 (GCM) STATION IS ON SHARP PEAK BETWEEN PANDURA AND SANTA HELENA.  THE CROWN OF THIS HILL RESEMBLES THE CROWN OF A HAT.  A GOOD TRAIL LEADS TO THE SUMMIT FROM MAUNABO.  STATION IS ON HIGHEST PART OF SUMMIT, AND W OF CACTUS HEDGE.  MARKED BY A 3/4-INCH GALVANIZED-IRON PIPE, 20 INCHES LONG, DRIVEN FLUSH WITH GROUND. markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1941 (RLS) THIS IS AN INTERSECTION STATION LOCATED ON THE ROOSEVELT ROADS NAVAL RESERVATION, ON POINT ALGODONES, WHICH IS A LARGE BLUNT POINT AND THE WESTERLY OF 2 POINTS BETWEEN ENSENADA HONDA AND THE MOUTH OF THE DAGUAO RIVER, ABOUT 200 METERS NE OF THE SW END OF THE POINT, ABOUT 90 METERS N OF THE HIGH-WATER LINE IN A SMALL COVE BETWEEN 2 SMALL BLUNT POINTS, ABOUT 20 METERS SE OF THE HIGHEST POINT OF THE SOUTHWESTERLY SUMMIT ON POINT ALGODONES, 39 METERS W OF A GROUP OF BOULDERS ON THE E SLOPE OF THE HILL, AND PROJECTS ABOUT 6 INCHES ABOVE GROUND.  THE ELEVATION OF THE STATION IS ABOUT 27.9 METERS.  STATION MARK IS A STANDARD DISK SET IN CONCRETE, AS DESCRIBED IN NOTE 1A.  NO UNDERGROUND MARK WAS SET.  THE WITNESS MARK IS A TRIANGULAR BLAZE ON THE SW SIDE OF A 10-INCH MUNECO TREE, 1 METER ABOVE THE GROUND.  IT IS 17.0 METERS DISTANT FROM THE STATION IN APPROXIMATE AZIMUTH 244 DEG.  THE TREE IS THE LARGEST ON TOP OF THE HILL AND IS AT THE E EDGE OF THE TOP OF THE HILL.  THERE ARE NO REFERENCE MARKS.                            STATION RECOVERY (1961)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1961 (MLO) STATION WAS RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED.  IT IS IN EXCELLENT CONDITION.  HEAVY GROWTH OF BUSHES AND TREES NOW COVER THIS AREA.

THE STATION IS MARKED BY A WOODEN PINE STUB, 2 INCHES BY 3 INCHES, DRIVEN IN THE GROUND AND PROJECTING ABOUT 6 INCHES.  A PILE OF WHITEWASHED ROCKS SURROUNDS THE STUB. markers.description: BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1934 STATION IS YELLOW HOUSE SE OF PRIETO.                            STATION RECOVERY (1941)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1941 (GBG) NOT RECOVERED.

BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JJL) THE STATION IS LOCATED ON THE WEST CORNER OF THE SOUTHWEST END OF THE CONCRETE TAXIWAY TO RUNWAY 6 AT ROOSEVELT ROADS NAVAL STATION.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM GATE NUMBER 1 AT ROOSEVELT ROADS NAVAL STATION, GO SOUTHERLY ON THE PAVED ROAD FOR 0.15 MILE TO A Y-FORK.  KEEP THE RIGHT FORK AND GO SOUTHWEST ON BOXER DRIVE FOR 0.95 MILE TO A Y-FORK.  TAKE THE LEFT FORK AND GO SOUTHERLY FOR 0.55 MILE TO THE PARKING LOT AT THE NORTH SIDE OF THE CONTROL TOWER.  (OBTAIN PERMISSION AND AN ESCORT AT AIR OPERATIONS BEFORE PROCEEDING ONTO THE AIRCRAFT PARKING APRON OR THE TAXIWAY.) GO WESTERLY FOR ABOUT 50 FEET TO THE EDGE OF THE AIRCRAFT PARKING APRON THEN BEAR SOUTHERLY ACROSS THE APRON TO THE TAXIWAY.  TURN RIGHT AND GO SOUTHWEST ON THE TAXIWAY FOR 1.5 MILES TO THE SOUTHWEST END OF THE TAXIWAY AND THE STATION.  THE STATION MARK IS A STANDARD DISK, STAMPED SOUTHWEST 1966, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN THE WEST CORNER OF THE CONCRETE TAXIWAY AT THE SOUTHWEST END OF RUNWAY 6.  REFERENCE MARK 1 IS A STANDARD DISK, STAMPED SOUTHWEST NO 1 1966, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN THE NORTHWEST EDGE OF THE CONCRETE TAXIWAY AT THE SOUTHWEST END OF RUNWAY 6.  REFERENCE MARK 2 IS A STANDARD DISK, STAMPED SOUTHWEST NO 2 1966, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN THE SOUTHWEST EDGE OF THE CONCRETE TAXIWAY AT THE SOUTHWEST END OF RUNWAY 6.  THERE WAS NOT AN AZIMUTH MARK ESTABLISHED.

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1939 (HAC) STATION IS THE SW TOWER OF THE TWO RADIO TOWERS AT THE U.S. NAVAL RADIO STATION IN PUERTA DE TIERRA, SAN JUAN.

BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1899 (WCH) STATION IS SITUATED UPON A SHARP WOODED HILL, ABOUT 1-1/4 MILES NE OF COAMO SPRINGS AND 2 MILES S OF COAMO.  THE HILL IS ABOUT 1000 FEET HIGH.  IT IS THE SECOND HILL E OF THE ROAD BETWEEN COAMO SPRINGS AND COAMO AND IS REACHED BY A TRAIL RUNNING N OF THE HILLS AND STRIKING THE MAIN ROAD ABOUT 200 METERS N OF A SMALL STORE.  THE TIMBER, WHICH WAS ABOUT 20 FEET HIGH, WAS CUT IN THE IMMEDIATE VICINITY OF THE STATION.  STATION IS MARKED BY A TACK IN THE CENTER OF A STUB 18 INCHES LONG AND 4 INCHES IN DIAMETER, PROJECTING ABOVE THE GROUND ABOUT 4 INCHES.  THE STUB IS ABOUT ONE FOOT S OF A STUMP, 7 INCHES IN DIAMETER AND 18 INCHES HIGH.
markers.setting: UNSPECIFIED SETTING

markers.description: BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1934 STATION LOCATED 6 KILOMETERS BY ROAD S OF THE TOWN OF COAMO, 2 KILOMETERS BY ROAD NE OF COAMO SPRINGS, ON A PROMINENT CONE-SHAPED PEAK ABOUT 1 KILOMETER TO THE E OF THE CARRETERA FROM COAMO TO COAMO SPRINGS.  THE STATION IS ON THE HIGHEST PART OF THE SUMMIT, NEAR THE WESTERN END.  THIS IS THE SAME PEAK ON WHICH C AND GS STATION SPRING WAS LOCATED, BUT NO TRACE OF THIS STATION COULD BE FOUND.  STATION MARK IS A STANDARD TABLET (NOT STAMPED) CEMENTED IN A ROCK SET IN GROUND.  SIGNAL--A QUADRIPOD OF SAWED LUMBER WITH BLACK CROSS-TARGETS ON CENTER POLE.  TO REACH STATION FROM COAMO OR COAMO SPRINGS, FOLLOW THE ROAD LEADING TO SALINAS FOR 1 KILOMETER FROM FORKS OF ROAD LEADING TO COAMO SPRINGS, AT SHARP BEND IN MAIN ROAD TO THE S CONTINUE ON EASTWARD ON MUNICIPAL ROAD WHICH PASSES THE FOOT OF THE PEAK ON THE S.  A GOOD ROUTE IS UP SPUR RIDGE ON THIS SIDE.                            STATION RECOVERY (1963)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1963 (RWS) THE DESCRIPTION WRITTEN IN 1934 IS ADEQUATE.  RECOVERED BY U.S. NAVAL OCEANOGRAPHIC OFFICE.                            STATION RECOVERY (1966)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JJL) THE STATION MARK WAS RECOVERED AND FOUND TO BE BROKEN OFF AT GROUND LEVEL.  NO TIE WAS MADE TO THE MARK DUE TO THE POOR CONDITION OF IT.  A NEW STATION WINTER WAS ESTABLISHED.  OFFICE NOTE--STATION IS LOST.  (SEE G-16362)
markers.setting: SET IN UNSPECIFIED ROCK OR BOULDER
markers.stability: PROBABLY HOLD POSITION/ELEVATION WELL

markers.description: BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1934 PROBABLY ABANDONED SUGAR MILL.  NO CHECK ON THIS POSITION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1971)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1971 (EKM) A ONE HALF HOUR SEARCH WAS MADE FOR THIS STACK OR ITS FOUNDATION.  ITS PLOTTED POSITION PLACED IT WITHIN A PLOWED CANE FIELD AND THERE ARE NO REMAINS OF THE STACK.  THE STATION IS LOST.

BY RLDA SURVEYING AND MAPPING 2010 (RLD) THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 7.8 MI (12.6 KM) WEST OF FLORIDA, 5.9 MI (9.5 KM) SOUTH OF BAJADERO, 5.4 MI (8.7 KM) NORTH OF UTUADO AND 5.1 MI (8.2 KM) NORTHEAST OF CAYUCO, PUERTO RICO.   TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE INTERSECTION OF PR-111 AND PR-10 1.1 MI (1.8 KM) WEST OF UTUADO, GO NORTHERLY ON PR-10 FOR 7.1 MI (11.4 KM) TO THE STATION ON THE LEFT, WEST SIDE OF PR-10.   THE STATION IS 50.20 M (164.7 FT) NORTHWEST OF KM POST 70.5, 16.25 M (53.3 FT) SOUTHWEST OF THE CENTERLINE OF PR-10 AND 7.30 M (24.0 FT) SOUTH OF THE SOUTH END OF A METAL GUARD RAIL.

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1901 (GCM) THIS INTERSECTION STATION IS THE CENTER OF CROSS AND CUPOLA ON HIGHEST TOWER OF ST. AUGUSTINE CATHEDRAL, IN PUERTO DE TIERRA.  TOWERS ARE OF GREY CONCRETE.                            STATION RECOVERY (1971)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1971 (JRH) THE STATION WAS RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION AS ORIGINALLY DESCRIBED.  AIRLINE DISTANCE AND DIRECTION FROM NEAREST TOWN AT PUERTO DE TIERRA.                            STATION RECOVERY (1994)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US POWER SQUADRON 1994 RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.                            STATION RECOVERY (2005)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US POWER SQUADRON 2005 (KEN) RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.

BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1939 (EGR) STATION IS LOCATED ON A PROMINENT LONG HILL, ON THE NE LIMIT OF THE PROPERTY OF PUERTO RICO RECONSTRUCTION ADM, AT TRUJILLO ALTO (KNOWN AS ST. JUST), ITS TOP RUNNING E-W IS ABOUT 100 METERS LONG.  THE STATION IS -- FT. FROM THE N LINE OF BARBED WIRE BOUNDARY AND -- METERS FROM THE E LINE.  IT IS APPROACHED FROM RIO PIEDRAS, FOLLOWING RD. 23 TO THE ST. JUST PROPERTY WHERE FOLLOWING ITS MAIN ENTRANCE TO ITS JUNCTION WITH ST. 6 WHICH IS FOLLOWED TO ITS N END AT THE FOOT OF THE HILL.  STATION MARK--STANDARD TABLET CEMENTED TO A CONCRETE MONUMENT 8- BY 8- BY 36-INCHES.  SIGNAL--POLE OF 1- BY 4-INCH SAWED LUMBER WITH BLACK AND WHITE CROSS TARGETS 5 FT. 3 INCHES ECC.  R. M. NO. 1--R.R. SPIKE ON ALMOCIGO STUMP 6.18 METERS W OF STATION.  R. M. NO. 2--R.R. SPIKE ON YOUNG ROBLE TREE 18.795 METERS NE OF STATION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1941)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1941 (GBG) THE STATION IS LOCATED ON A PROMINENT, LONG E-W HILL AT THE NE LIMIT OF THE P.R.R.A. DEVELOPMENT KNOWN AS ST. JUST.  ABOUT 3 KILOMETERS N OF TRUJILLO ALTO.  THE STATION IS ON THE HIGHEST PART OF THE RIDGE, ABOUT N OF CALLE 6, ST. JUST.  AND IS 7.8 FEET SE OF FENCE LINE ALONG RIDGE.  AND ABOUT ON THE PROJECTION OF A LINE OF TALL AUSTRALIAN PINES ON THE S SLOPE OF THE HILL.  THE STATION IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED ST. JUST 1940, SET IN TOP OF AN 8-INCH DIAMETER ROUND CONCRETE MONUMENT.  REFERENCE MARK 1 IS A RAILROAD SPIKE IN AN ALMACIGO TREE 6.18 METERS W OF THE STATION.  REFERENCE MARK 2 IS A RAILROAD SPIKE ON ROBLE TREE 18.795 METERS NE OF THE STATION.  TO REACH FROM JUNCTION OF RIO PIEDRAS-CAROLINA ROAD AND TRUJILLO ALTO ROAD, GO S TOWARDS TRUJILLO ALTO 2.4 MILES (1.7 MILES N OF TRUJILLO ALTO) AND TURN E INTO THE ST. JUST DEVELOPMENT.  AT 1.3 MILES BEAR LEFT ON MACADAM ROAD, AND GO ANOTHER 0.4 MILE TO CALLE 6.  TURN SHARP LEFT (N) AND GO 0.1 MILE TO FOOT OF HILL.  LEAVE THE CAR AND THEN GO DIRECTLY UP THE HILL, WORKING EAST TO THE LINE OF AUSTRALIAN PINE TREES, WHICH POINTS TO THE STATION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1964)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1964 (GWM) THE STATION HILL WAS NOT CLIMBED BUT IT IS PRESUMED THE MARK IS THERE SINCE NO CONSTRUCTION IS EVIDENT.  SOME SLIGHT CHANGES ARE NEEDED IN THE TO REACH.  A COMPLETE DESCRIPTION FOLLOWS--  ON A PROMINENT LONG E-W HILL AT THE NE LIMIT OF ST JUST.  ABOUT 3 KMS N OF TRUJILLO ALTO.  ON THE HIGHEST PART OF THE RIDGE, 7.8 FEET SE OF FENCE LINE AND ABOUT ON THE PROJECTION OF A LINE OF TALL AUSTRAILIAN PINES WHICH ARE ON THE S SLOPE OF THE HILL.  A STANDARD DISK STAMPED ST JUST 1940 IN THE TOP OF AN 8 IN DIAMETER ROUND CONCRETE MONUMENT.  RM 1 IS A RAILROAD SPIKE IN AN ALMACIGO TREE 6.18 METERS WEST OF THE STATION.  RM 2 IS A RAILROAD SPIKE IN A ROBLE TREE 18.795 METERS NE OF THE STATION.  FROM THE SAN JUAN TOWN HOUSE GO S ON HIGHWAY 181 FOR 2.2 MILES, BEAR LEFT (E) OFF 181 FOR 0.8 MILES TO ST JUST POST OFFICE.  CONTINUE EASTERLY 0.5 MILE AND BEAR LEFT AT STORE AND GO NORTHERLY 0.4 MILE AND CALLE 6, TURN SHARP LEFT (N) AND GO 0.2 MILE TO FOOT OF HILL AND WOVEN WIRE GATE.  CLIMB HILL WORKING EASTERLY TO THE LINE OF AUSTRAILIAN PINES WHICH POINTS TO THE STATION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1965)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1965 (JJL) THE STATION MARK WAS RECOVERED AND FOUND IN FAIR CONDITION.  DUE TO THE CONCRETE AROUND THE MARK HAVING BEEN CHIPPED AWAY THE MARK WAS REINFORCED WITH AN IRREGULAR MASS OF CONCRETE.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 1 AND REFERENCE MARK NO. 2 WERE NOT RECOVERED.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 3 AND REFERENCE MARK NO. 4 WERE ESTABLISHED.  A COMPLETE DESCRIPTION FOLLOWS--  THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 4 MILES EAST OF RIO PIEDRAS, 2-1/2 MILES WEST OF CAROLINA, 1/2 MILE SOUTH OF THE EL COMANDANTE RACE TRACK, ON THE HIGHEST POINT OF AN EAST-WEST RIDGE THAT IS COVERED WITH BRUSH AND PINE TREES AND ON PROPERTY OWNED BY THE EL COMANDANTE RACE TRACK.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE JUNCTION OF ROOSEVELT AVENUE AND HIGHWAY 1 (MUNOZ RIVERA AVENUE) IN HATO REY, GO SOUTHERLY ON HIGHWAY 1 FOR 1.8 MILES TO THE JUNCTION OF HIGHWAYS 1 AND 3.  BEAR LEFT AND GO EAST ON HIGHWAY 3 FOR 3.9 MILES TO THE ENTRANCE TO THE EL COMANDANTE RACE TRACK ON THE RIGHT.  TURN RIGHT AND GO SOUTH AND EAST FOR 0.6 MILE TO A SECURITY GATE AND A SIDE ROAD RIGHT.  TURN RIGHT, PASS THROUGH THE GATE THENCE BEAR LEFT AND GO EAST FOR 0.05 MILE TO A SIDE ROAD RIGHT. TURN RIGHT AND GO SOUTH, WEST, SOUTH AND EAST FOR 0.3 MILE TO A Y-FORK AND THE RACE TRACK SECURITY OFFICE IN THE ANGLE FORMED BY THE INTERSECTION.  (OBTAIN KEY FOR LOCKED GATE AT THIS OFFICE.) TAKE THE RIGHT FORK AND GO EAST AND SOUTH FOR 0.1 MILE TO A SIDE ROAD RIGHT AT STABLE NO. 32.  TURN RIGHT AND GO WEST FOR 0.05 MILE TO A LOCKED STEEL GATE.  PASS THROUGH THE GATE AND GO SOUTHEAST FOR 0.3 MILE TO A DIM REVERSE Y-FORK.  (A 4-WHEEL DRIVE VEHICLE IS REQUIRED FROM THIS POINT.) TURN SHARP LEFT AND GO NORTH FOR 0.1 MILE TO THE TOP OF THE RIDGE AND THE STATION.  THE STATION MARK, STAMPED ST JUST 1939, IS A U.S. GEOLOGICAL SURVEY DISK SET IN THE TOP OF AN IRREGULAR MASS OF CONCRETE THAT PROJECTS 6 INCHES.  IT IS 10 FEET NORTH OF A PINE TREE WITH A TRIANGULAR BLAZE.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 3, STAMPED ST JUST USGS NO 3 1939, IS A STANDARD DISK BRAZED TO THE TOP OF A 3-INCH CAST-IRON PIPE THAT PROJECTS 4 INCHES.  IT IS 53 FEET NORTH OF THE PINE TREE WITH THE TRIANGULAR BLAZE.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 4, STAMPED ST JUST USGS NO 4 1939, IS A STANDARD DISK CEMENTED IN THE TOP OF A 3-INCH CAST-IRON PIPE THAT PROJECTS 15 INCHES.  IT IS 32 FEET SOUTH-SOUTHEAST OF THE PINE TREE WITH THE TRIANGULAR BLAZE.  AIRLINE DISTANCE AND DIRECTION FROM NEAREST TOWN 2-1/2 MILES WEST OF CAROLINA.                            STATION RECOVERY (1971)  RECOVERY NOTE BY THOMAS ENG AND SURV 1971 (HBW) ST. JUST 1939 UNDISTURBED.  RM NO. 3 FOUND UNDISTURBED.

markers.description: BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1972 THE STATION IS LOCATED ON THE MERCEDITA AIRPORT AT THE WEST END OF THE AIRPORT, WEST OF THE VASIS, IN PONCE. TO OBTAIN ACCESS TO THE AIRPORT AND THE STATION CONTACT MR. MIGUEL CASIUAS, MERCEDITA AIRPORT, MERCEDITA, PUERTO RICO 00715-1305, PHONE 809-842-6292. THE STATION IS ON THE WEST SIDE OF THE AIRPORT 61.4 M (201.4 FT) SOUTH-SOUTHWEST OF THE SOUTHERLY EDGE OF THE TAXIWAY PARALLEL TO RUNWAY 12, 41.8 M (137.1 FT) EAST OF THE SECOND RUNWAY LIGHT EAST OF TAXIWAY A AND 32.3 M (106.0 FT) NORTHWEST OF THE THIRD RUNWAY LIGHT EAST OF TAXIWAY A. THE STATION IS A STANDARD TOPOGRAPHIC STATION DISK SET IN A CONCRETE MONUMENT FLUSH WITH THE GROUND.                            STATION RECOVERY (1993)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1993 THE STATION IS LOCATED AT THE WEST END OF THE AIRPORT, NORTHEAST FROM THE RUNWAY END 12 AND ON AN EXTENDED LINE OF THE SOUTH SET OF VASIS SERVING END 12.  IT IS 131.4 FT (40.1 M) WEST FROM THE CENTER OF A TELEPHONE MANHOLE COVER BETWEEN THE WEST PAIR OF VASIS, 136.7 FT (41.7 M) NORTHEAST FROM THE SECOND RUNWAY LIGHT FROM THE TWY INT, 105.7 FT (32.2 M) NORTHWEST FROM THE THIRD RUNWAY LIGHT, AND 54.9 FT (16.7 M) NORTHEAST OF THE NORTH EDGE OF THE RUNWAY SHOULDER.  IT IS A STANDARD CGS TOPOGRAPHIC DISK STAMPED AP 1972 STA A2 PSE SET IN THE TOP OF A CONCRETE POST FLUSH WITH THE GROUND.                            STATION RECOVERY (1996)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1996 (AJL) THE STATION IS LOCATED NEAR THE SOUTH COAST OF PUERTO RICO, ABOUT 3.0 MI (4.8 KM) EAST OF PONCE, AT THE MERCEDITA INTERNATIONAL AIRPORT AND WEST OF THE FIRST SET OF VASI LIGHT FOR RUNWAY 12. OWNERSHIP--MERCEDITA INTERNATIONAL AIRPORT, PONCE, PUERTO RICO. AIRPORT MANAGER IS MR.  MYGUEL CASILOS, PHONE (787) 842-6292.  THIS IS A CONTROLLED AIRPORT AND PERMISSION IS REQUIRED TO ENTER THE AIRPORT COMPOUND.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE GATE ON THE WEST SIDE OF THE FIRE STATION GO SOUTHERLY ON THE APRON FOR 0.05 MI (0.08 KM) TO A PARALLEL TAXIWAY, TURN RIGHT AND GO WESTERLY ON THE PARALLEL TAXIWAY FOR 0.25 MI (0.40 KM) TO THE STATION ON THE LEFT. THE STATION IS 131.2 FT (40.0 M) WEST-NORTHWEST OF THE CENTER OF A MANHOLE COVER LOCATED BETWEEN THE VASI LIGHTS AND 54.5 FT (16.6 M) NORTHEAST OF THE NORTHEAST EDGE OF THE RUNWAY PAVEMENT.  THIS IS A SECONDARY AIRPORT CONTROL STATION.                            STATION RECOVERY (2012)  RECOVERY NOTE BY AERO-METRIC ENGINEERING INCORPORATED 2012 (CPF) CURRENT AIRPORT MANAGER IS JOSE IRIZARRY. VASI LIGHTS ARE GONE, MANHOLE IS STILL THERE. MONUMENT IS FLUSH WITH THE SURFACE.

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1941 (RLS) THIS INTERSECTION STATION IS ABOUT 2-1/2 MILES NW OF NAGUABO PLAYA, AND ABOUT 2-3/4 MILES SW OF NAGUABO, ON THE S SIDE OF AN E-AND-W RANGE OF LOW HILLS WITH A HIGHER CONE-SHAPED HILL ABOUT AT THE CENTER, IN AN OPEN FIELD WITH NO OTHER STRUCTURES AROUND IT.  FROM A DISTANCE THE STACK APPEARS TO BE THE ONLY REMAINS OF A SMALL SUGAR REFINERY.  THE STACK IS RED BRICK AND ABOUT 75 FEET HIGH.  THE STATION WAS NOT VISITED FOR A MORE COMPLETE DESCRIPTION.

BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1899 (WCH) STATION IS ON THE LOW FLAT POINT AT THE VILLAGE OF CATANO S OF SAN JUAN.  THE SPANISH HAD A STATION NEAR THIS SPOT WHICH THEY CALLED CATANO.  IT COULD NOT BE FOUND.  STATION IS MARKED BY A 2-INCH PIPE AND CEMENT.                            STATION RECOVERY (1909)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1909 (WCH) A REPORT THAT START HAD BEEN RECOVERED PROVED TO BE A MISTAKE.  THE POINT OVER WHICH THE SIGNAL WAS BUILT IS ON THE E SIDE OF CATANO POINT, WHILE START WAS RATHER ON THE W SIDE OF THE POINT.  THE NEW STATION WAS NAMED CATANO.

BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1941 (RLS) STATION IS ABOUT 4 MILES ESE FROM CEIBA, ON THE ROOSEVELT ROADS NAVAL RESERVATION, ON PINEROS ISLAND, ON THE S SIDE OF THE ISLAND, ON THE BEACH, ABOUT 3 METERS NE OF THE HIGH-WATER LINE, AT THE NW END OF THE THICK BRUSH ON THE SLOPE OF THE HILL CLOSE TO THE BEACH. STATION IS MARKED BY A STANDARD BRONZE DISK, SET IN A CONCRETE BLOCK WHICH PROJECTS ABOUT 4 INCHES ABOVE THE GROUND.  NO UNDERGROUND MARK. markers.description: BY US NAVY 1966 (JWC) THE STATION IS LOCATED 11-1/2 AIRLINE MILES SOUTH OF CABO ROJO, 11-1/2 AIRLINE MILES SOUTHWEST OF LAJAS, 1/2 MILE EAST OF THE CABO ROJO LIGHTHOUSE AND ON THE TOP OF A LOW BRUSH AND CACTUS COVERED BLUFF.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE SOUTHWEST CORNER OF THE PLAZA IN CABO ROJO, GO WEST ON A PAVED STREET FOR 1 BLOCK TO HIGHWAY 103.  TURN LEFT AND GO SOUTH ON HIGHWAY 103 FOR 4.85 MILES TO HIGHWAY 101.  TURN RIGHT AND GO WESTERLY ON HIGHWAY 101 FOR 0.7 MILE TO A SIDE ROAD LEFT.  TURN LEFT AND GO SOUTHERLY ON HIGHWAY 301 FOR 2.8 MILES TO A SIDE ROAD RIGHT.  TURN RIGHT AND GO WESTERLY ON A PAVED ROAD FOR 2.0 MILES TO A T-INTERSECTION. TURN LEFT AND GO SOUTH ON A PAVED ROAD FOR 0.25 MILE TO A SIDE ROAD RIGHT.  CONTINUE STRAIGHT AHEAD AND GO SOUTH AND WEST ON A SAND ROAD FOR 3.85 MILES TO A FORK JUST SOUTHEAST OF THE CABO ROJO LIGHTHOUSE.  KEEP LEFT AND GO SOUTHEAST ON A SAND ROAD FOR 0.3 MILE TO THE NORTHEAST EDGE OF A RIDGE.  TURN RIGHT AND GO SOUTHWEST UP THE RIDGE PICKING WAY THROUGH THICK BRUSH AND CACTUS FOR 0.2 MILE TO THE TOP OF THE LOW BLUFF AND THE STATION.  THE STATION MARK IS A U.S. NAVY HYDROGRAPHIC BRONZE DISK STAMPED SUCIA 1963, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN OUTCROPPING BEDROCK WHICH IS FLUSH WITH THE SURFACE.  REFERENCE MARK 2 IS A U.S. NAVY HYDROGRAPHIC REFERENCE MARK DISK STAMPED RM 2 1963, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN OUTCROPPING BEDROCK WHICH IS FLUSH WITH THE SURFACE.  REFERENCE MARK 3 IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED SUCIA NO 3 1966, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN OUTCROPPING BEDROCK WHICH IS FLUSH WITH THE SURFACE.  NO AZIMUTH MARK WAS ESTABLISHED AT THIS STATION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1970)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1970 (JKW) STATION MARK, REFERENCE MARK 2, AND REFERENCE MARK 3 WERE ALL RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.  THE STAMPINGS AND THE DISTANCES WERE VERIFIED.  THE ORIGINAL DESCRIPTION BY J.W.C. IN 1966 IS ADEQUATE.

markers.description: BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1982 (JCL) THE STATION IS LOCATED 5 KM (3 MI) NORTHEAST OF PONCE, 4 KM (2-1/2 MI) NORTH OF THE JUNCTION OF HIGHWAY 14 AND 139, 1 KM (0.6 MI) WEST-SOUTHWEST OF THE PROPOSED CERRILLOS DAM, 50 METERS EAST OF A DIRT ROAD, AND ON A PARTIALLY CLEARED LOW PROMONTORY.  OWNERSHIP--U.S. ARMY CORPS OF ENGINEERS.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE JUNCTION OF HIGHWAYS 14 AND 139 ABOUT 5 KM (3 MI) NORTHEAST OF PONCE, GO NORTHWEST OF HIGHWAY 139 FOR 0.5 KM (0.3 MI) TO A CROSS STREET AND JUNCTION OF HIGHWAY 505.  TURN RIGHT AND GO NORTHEAST ON HIGHWAY 139 FOR 2.9 KM (1.8 MI) TO A FORK (ABOUT 1/4 MI PAST A VILLAGE).  BEAR LEFT UP GRADE ON PAVED ROAD FOR 2.7 KM (1.7 MI) TO A DIRT ROAD RIGHT AND A SMALL STORE ON THE LEFT. TURN RIGHT (THIS WILL BE HIGHWAY 139 AFTER THE DAM IS COMPLETED) FOR 0.9 KM (0.55 MI) TO A DIM ROAD RIGHT ON THE NORTH SIDE OF A SMALL PROMONTORY. TURN SHARP RIGHT FOR 50 METERS TO A SMALL CUT BANK AND THE STATION OF THE RIGHT.  THE STATION IS A STANDARD NGS DISK STAMPED---SUE 1982---, SET INTO THE TOP OF A ROUND CONCRETE MONUMENT 30 CM IN DIAMETER RECESSED 15 CM BELOW THE GROUND.  IT IS LOCATED 15.0 METERS (49.2 FT) EAST FROM THE APPROXIMATE TOP OF THE HILL, 5.5 METERS (18.0 FT) WEST FROM A DIM ROAD, AND ON A 20 DEGREE SLOPE ON THE EAST SIDE OF THE PROMONTORY. THE STATION VIEW IS FROM NORTHEAST TO SOUTHWEST (CLOCKWISE).  THE UNDERGROUND MARK IS A STANDARD NGS DISK STAMPED---SUE 1982---, SET INTO AN IRREGULAR MASS OF CONCRETE 1 METER BELOW THE SURFACE.  REFERENCE MARK NUMBER 1 IS A STANDARD NGS DISK STAMPED ---SUE NO 1 1982---, SET INTO THE TOP OF A SQUARE CONCRETE MONUMENT 30 CM ON A SIDE FLUSH WITH GROUND.  IT IS LOCATED 12.8 METERS (42.0 FT) WEST FROM A DIM ROAD, 4 FEET LOWER THAN THE TOP OF THE HILL, AND 8 FEET ABOVE THE PATH (DIM ROAD).  MARK IS ABOVE STATION 2.4 METERS.  REFERENCE MARK NUMBER 2 IS A CORPS OF ENGINEERS PLUG STAMPED ---C 14 150 12 12 80---, SET INTO THE TOP OF AN IRREGULAR MASS OF CONCRETE 37 CM IN DIAMETER FLUSH WITH THE GROUND.  IT IS LOCATED 5.0 METERS (16 FT) WEST FROM A DIM ROAD (PATH).  MARK IS LEVEL WITH STATION.  HEIGHT OF LIGHT SHOWN ABOVE THE MARK WAS 1.7 METERS.  DOPPLER OBSERVATIONS WERE MADE FROM THIS STATION.

BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1934 THIS STATION IS SITUATED ON A BARE LIMESTONE HILL E OF ARECIBO-LARES ROAD, AT KILOMETER 23 H 9, AND THE CAMUY RIVER, ON LAND OWNED BY AGAPITO CRESPO.  IT IS ABOUT 1/2 MILE SE OF THE PLACE WHERE THE RIVER SINKS TO RUN UNDERGROUND.  STATION MARK IS A STANDARD U.S.G.S. BENCH MARK SET ON NATURAL ROCK AND STAMPED SUMIDERO 1934.  REFERENCE MARK NO.1 IS A STANDARD TABLET SET ON NATURAL ROCK 2.165 METERS FROM STATION IN TRUE AZIMUTH 238 DEG 53 MIN.  REFERENCE MARK NO.2 IS A STANDARD TABLET SET ON NATURAL ROCK, 3.100 METERS FROM STATION IN TRUE AZIMUTH 325 DEG 52 MIN.  SIGNAL, A QUADRIPOD AND BLACK CROSS-TARGETS AND A WHITE FLAG CENTERED OVER STATION MARK.  TO REACH STATION, LEAVE ROAD ON SAID KILOMETER AND S OF A LONG RETAINING WALL, FOLLOW DOWN TO THE RIVER ON A TRAIL, CROSS RIVER, FOLLOW A TRAIL UP VALLEY DRAINING INTO THE RIVER TO FIRST RIDGE, CONTINUE E ON RIDGE TO THE HILL WHERE THE STATION IS LOCATED.  IT IS THE MOST PROMINENT HILL IN VICINITY AND IS SHARP POINTED AND ALMOST BARE.                            STATION RECOVERY (1941)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1941 (GBG) THIS STATION IS ON A BARE LIMESTONE HILL, ABOUT 0.8 KILOMETER E OF THE ARECIBO-LARES ROAD AT KM. 23 H 9.  ABOUT TWO MILES NE OF THE JUNCTION OF THE ARECIBO-LARES AND LARES-UTUADO ROADS.  AND ABOUT 1/2 MILE SE OF THE PLACE WHERE THE CAMUY RIVER GOES UNDERGROUND.  THE STATION MARK IS A STANDARD TABLET STAMPED SUMIDERO 1934, SET ON A LARGE LEDGE ROCK ON THE HIGHEST POINT OF THE SHARP HILL.  REFERENCE MARK 1 IS A STANDARD REFERENCE-MARK DISK SET IN ROCK 2.165 METERS FROM THE STATION IN AZIMUTH 238 DEG 53 MIN.  REFERENCE MARK 2 IS A STANDARD REFERENCE-MARK DISK SET IN ROCK 3.10 METERS FROM THE STATION IN AZIMUTH 325 DEG 52 MIN.  TO REACH FROM JUNCTION OF LARES-ARECIBO AND LARES-UTUADO ROADS.  GO NE ON THE ARECIBO ROAD 2.3 MILES TO KM. 23 H 9, WHICH IS 30 FEET S OF S END OF RETAINING WALL.  FROM HERE THE STATION BEARS S 30 DEG E.  TAKE TRAIL NE DOWN TO RIVER.  BEYOND RIVER CROSSING TAKE A T-TRAIL RIGHT, WHICH FOLLOWS BANK OF RIVER.  FOLLOW THIS ABOUT 100 METERS.  THEN TURN LEFT UP DIM TRAIL FOLLOWING VALLEY EDGE TO A SADDLE.  TURN LEFT AT SADDLE.  AND FOLLOW TRAIL WHICH WORKS EASTWARD OVER THE RIDGE TO THE BASE OF THE SHARP PEAK ON WHICH THE STATION IS LOCATED.
markers.setting: SET IN ROCK OUTCROP
markers.stability: MOST RELIABLE AND EXPECTED TO HOLDPOSITION/ELEVATION WELL

THE BOTTLE IS IN A BED OF CEMENT GROUTING AND THE PIPE IS FILLED WITH PORTLAND CEMENT AND COVERED WITH CEMENT, AND IN THE MIDDLE OF THIS IS A U.S.C. AND G.S. MARK, AND IN THE MIDDLE OF THIS THERE IS A HOLE WHICH MARKS THE STATION.

markers.description: BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1941 V.A. ELEVATION 160.55 METERS.  THE U.S.C. AND G.S. STATION SUMMIT COULD NOT BE RECOVERED.  EXTENSIVE DIGGING WAS DONE IN THE VICINITY OF THE STATION BUT NO EVIDENCE OF THE CONCRETE FILLED PIPE OR BOTTLE MARKING THE OLD STATION WAS FOUND.  A RAILROAD RAIL WAS FOUND DRIVEN WELL INTO THE GROUND ON THIS HILL AND IT MAY MARK THE LOCATION OF THE OLD STATION MARK.  HOWEVER, NO INFORMATION ON THIS QUESTION COULD BE FOUND.  THE NEW STATION IS LOCATED ON THE SAME TOP WHICH IS ABOUT 3 KM. S.W. OF ISABEL II AND 1-1/2 KM. S.E. OF MARTINEAU HILL.  THE TOP IS WOODED ON THE NORTH SLOPE AND IS BARE ON TOP.  TO REACH THIS STATION FROM ISABEL II DRIVE WEST TOWARD PUNTA ARENAS 1.4 MILES TO K1 H9.  TURN LEFT (S) ONTO ROAD TO PLAYA GRANDE.  DRIVE 1.1 MILE TO A CURVE IN THE ROAD AND TURN LEFT (S) ONTO A DIRT ROAD WHICH LEADS TO A HOUSE ABOUT 400 METERS FROM THE HIGHWAY. FROM THIS HOUSE THE TOP CAN BE SEEN TO THE EAST.  STATION MARK--CENTER OF RAILROAD RAIL WHICH IS SURROUNDED WITH CONCRETE.  THE TOP OF THE RAIL PROJECTS 0.36 METERS ABOVE THE SURFACE OF THE CONCRETE.  R.M. 1 CHISELED CROSS ON TOP OF AN IRREGULAR SHAPED ROCK ABOUT 3 FT. HIGH.  DISTANCE FROM STATION--1.92 METERS PLANE AZIMUTH--252-22.  R.M. 2 CHISELED CROSS ON TOP OF A ROCK ABOUT 2 FT. HIGH AND 6 FT. LONG.  DISTANCE FROM STATION--6.25 METERS PLANE AZIMUTH--133-25.  SIGNAL--CLOTH TARGET AND FLAG CENTERED OVER STATION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1964)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1964 (GWM) STATION AND R.M.S RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED.  THERE IS NO EVIDENCE OF HOUSE AS ROAD NOW LEADS ALONG A FENCE TO A COW PASTURE.                            STATION RECOVERY (1970)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US MARINE CORPS 1970 STATION WAS RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.
markers.setting: UNSPECIFIED SETTING

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1900 (WCH) THIS STATION IS ON TOP OF THE ROCKY POINT CALLED BY THE NATIVES PUNTA DE LOS FLAMINGOS.  AS THE NAME FLAMINGO HAD BEEN USED BY ASSISTANT BOUTELLE, THIS POINT WAS NAMED FROM THE HEAVY SURF WHICH GRADUALLY AND GENERALLY BEATS IN HERE AND WHICH MADE THE LANDING DIFFICULT.  THE STATION IS ON THE SLOPING GRASSY RIDGE, ABOVE THE CLIFFS, WHICH FORMS THE MAIN (WESTERN) PART OF THE POINT.  IT IS MARKED BY AN IRON PIPE IN CEMENT AS USUAL.  TRIPOD SIGNAL, 30 FEET TO FLAG.                            STATION RECOVERY (1926)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1926 (GCM) LOCATION OF STATION RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED.  STATION MARK (2-INCH IRON PIPE SET IN CEMENT) HAS BEEN REMOVED FROM HOLE IN GROUND.  IRON PIPE AND CEMENT STILL LYING NEAR HOLE.  CEMENT BROKEN AWAY FROM PIPE.  SMALL TRIPOD BEACON ERECTED OVER HOLE.  THIS BEACON TO BE USED AS SIGNAL FOR WIRE DRAG WORK.                            STATION RECOVERY (1945)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US NAVY 1945 (HTG) RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED.                            STATION RECOVERY (1957)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1957 (RCD) STATION DESTROYED.  NO PIECES OF MARK FOUND.  SIX CONCRETE POSTS IN PLACE WERE FOUND AND BELIEVED TO BE REMAINS OF TRIPOD BEACON ERECTED IN 1926 BY GCM, OR TRIPOD ERECTED BY NAVY FOR GUNFIRE CONTROL.                            STATION RECOVERY (1965)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1965 (MTP) THE TRIANGULATION STATION WAS NOT RECOVERED.  IN 1957 THE STATION WAS REPORTED AS BEING DESTROYED.  SIX 6 IN X 6 IN CONCRETE BLOCKS WERE FOUND ON FLAMINGO POINT WHICH APPEARED TO BE THE FOOTINGS FOR A TRIPOD BEACON.  THE PADS FORMED A RECTANGLE 9.4 FEET IN THE EAST-WEST DIRECTION.  4.7 FEET CENTER TO CENTER.  AND 4.7 FEET WIDE IN THE NORTH-SOUTH DIRECTION.  FROM THE MIDDLE PAD ALONG THE RECTANGLES SOUTHERN BOUNDRY, THE DISTANCE NORTH TO THE CLIFF WAS 61 FEET AND TO THE WEST 46 FEET.  TO REACH THE SITE OF THESE FOOTINGS DRIVE APPROXIMATELY 2.0 MI. NORTH FROM CULEBRA AIRPORT TO THE U.S. NAVY OBSERVATION POST.  THEN WALK APPROXIMATELY 0.3 MI. NORTH DOWN THE STEEP MOUNTAIN SLOPE TO FLAMINGO POINT.                            STATION RECOVERY (1966)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JJL) A THOROUGH SEARCH WAS MADE FOR THE STATION BUT IT WAS NOT RECOVERED.  SURF 2 WAS ESTABLISHED IN THE NEAR VICINITY.  SEE DESCRIPTION THEREOF.

BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JJL) THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 2-1/2 MILES NORTH-NORTHWEST OF CULEBRA, ON THE NORTH END OF POINT FLAMENCO, ABOUT 100 FEET ABOVE THE WATER AND 50 FEET EAST OF THE CLIFF ON THE WEST SIDE OF THE POINT.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE POST OFFICE IN CULEBRA, GO EASTERLY FOR 0.05 MILE TO A Y-FORK.  TAKE THE LEFT FORK FOR 0.05 MILE TO A REVERSE Y-FORK.  BEAR LEFT AND GO NORTHEASTERLY FOR 0.5 MILE TO A Y-FORK, JUST BEFORE REACHING THE AIRPORT.  TAKE THE LEFT FORK AND GO NORTHERLY FOR 1.0 MILE TO A Y-FORK.  TAKE THE RIGHT FORK AND GO NORTHEASTERLY FOR 1.0 MILE TO THE U.S. NAVY OBSERVATION POST AND THE END OF TRUCK TRAVEL.  PACK NORTHWESTERLY, DOWNHILL, FOR ABOUT 100 YARDS TO AN ABOVE GROUND SEPTIC TANK.  BEAR RIGHT AND PACK WESTERLY ALONG A WELL-DEFINED TRAIL FOR ABOUT 1/4 MILE TO THE NORTH END OF A GRASSY POINT AND THE STATION.  A 1/4 HOUR PACK.  THE STATION MARK, STAMPED SURF 2 1966, IS A STANDARD DISK SET IN THE TOP OF AN IRREGULAR MASS OF CONCRETE THAT PROJECTS 1 INCH.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 1, STAMPED SURF 2 NO 1 1966, IS A STANDARD DISK CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN OUTCROPPING BEDROCK THAT PROJECTS 6 INCHES AND IS ABOUT 5 FEET LOWER THAN THE STATION.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 2, STAMPED SURF 2 NO 2 1966, IS A STANDARD DISK CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A 6 X 8 INCH CONCRETE MONUMENT THAT PROJECTS 2 INCHES AND IS ABOUT 1 FOOT HIGHER THAN THE STATION.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 3 IS AN X-ED COPPER PIN SET IN THE TOP OF AN IRREGULAR MASS OF CONCRETE THAT PROJECTS 1 INCH.  R 21 IS INSCRIBED IN THE CONCRETE.                            STATION RECOVERY (1993)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE 1993 (BR) STATION FOUND ON GRASSY POINT OF RIDGE, BUT VERY DIFFICULT TO REACH. VERY DENSE BRUSH ON RIDGE BETWEEN STATION AND NAVY OBSERVATION POST. PREVIOUS DESCRIPTION SHOULD SAY EASTERLY RATHER THAN WESTERLY FROM OBSERVATORY POST, AND THERE IS NO LONGER A DEFINED TRAIL.  VERY STEEP WITH ROUGH WATER ON OCEAN SIDE.  GPS VISIBILITY IS EXCELLENT.

markers.description: BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1934 STATION IS SITUATED ON A LIMESTONE HILL ABOUT 300 METERS S OF UTUADO-ARECIBO ROAD. THE PLACE IS KNOWN AS EL OJO DE AGUA.  IT IS ABOUT 7 KILOMETERS S OF ARECIBO.  STATION MARK IS A STANDARD TABLET CEMENTED ON NATURAL LIMESTONE, STAMPED TANAMA 1934.  REFERENCE MARK NO.1 IS A STANDARD TABLET SET ON A NATURAL ROCK, 3.88 METERS FROM STATION IN TRUE AZIMUTH 217 DEG 46 MIN.  REFERENCE MARK NO.2 IS A STANDARD TABLET SET ON NATURAL ROCK, 1.50 METERS FROM STATION IN TRUE AZIMUTH 285 DEG 40 MIN.  REACH IT BY A TRAIL UPHILL STARTING ON KILOMETER 74 H 4.5 NEAR HOUSE OF JOSE A. QUITES.  LAND OWNED BY SOLOMON THE ARAB.                            STATION RECOVERY (1940)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1940 RECOVERED O.K.  SIGNAL, POLE OF SAWED LUMBER WITH B. AND W. TARGETS AND W. FLAG CENTERED OVER STATION MARK.                            STATION RECOVERY (1941)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1941 (GBG) STATION AND REFERENCE MARKS RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED IN GOOD CONDITION.  THE STATION IS W OF THE ROAD INSTEAD OF S AS STATED IN THE DESCRIPTION.  TRAIL GOES UP VALLEY DIRECTLY BACK OF KM. 74, H 4.5, TO A RIDGE.  THEN TURN LEFT 100 MILES.  THEN LEFT AGAIN TO REACH TOP.                            STATION RECOVERY (1966)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JWC) THE STATION MARK AND BOTH REFERENCE MARKS WERE RECOVERED AND FOUND IN GOOD CONDITION.  A NEW REFERENCE MARK 3 WAS ESTABLISHED.  A COMPLETE NEW DESCRIPTION OF THE STATION FOLLOWS.  THE STATION IS LOCATED 15 AIRLINE MILES WEST OF MANATI AND ON THE TOP OF A HIGH BRUSH COVERED HILL.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE INTERSECTION OF HIGHWAYS 2 AND 10 IN THE SOUTHEAST EDGE OF ARECIBO, GO SOUTH AND EAST ON HIGHWAY 10 FOR 4.45 MILES TO END OF TRUCK TRAVEL AT KILOMETER POST 79.4.  FROM HERE PACK SOUTH UPHILL FOR ABOUT 20 MINUTES TO A SMALL CLEARING AND A DIM TRAIL ON THE RIGHT.  BEAR RIGHT AND PACK SOUTHWEST UPHILL ON THE TRAIL FOR ABOUT 10 MINUTES TO A SADDLE.  TURN LEFT AND PACK SOUTH FOR ABOUT 200 FEET TO THE TOP OF THE BRUSH COVERED HILL AND THE STATION.  THE STATION MARK IS A U.S. GEOLOGICAL SURVEY BENCH MARK DISK STAMPED TANAMA 1934, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A BOULDER WHICH PROJECTS 8 INCHES.  REFERENCE MARK 1 IS A U.S. GEOLOGICAL SURVEY REFERENCE MARK DISK STAMPED NO-1, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A BOULDER WHICH PROJECTS 1 FOOT.  REFERENCE MARK 2 IS A U.S. GEOLOGICAL SURVEY REFERENCE MARK DISK STAMPED NO-2, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A BOULDER WHICH PROJECTS 1 INCH.  REFERENCE MARK 3 IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED TANAMA USGS NO 3 1934, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A BOULDER WHICH PROJECTS 1 FOOT.  NO AZIMUTH MARK WAS ESTABLISHED AT THIS STATION.  AIRLINE DISTANCE AND DIRECTION FROM NEAREST TOWN 4-1/2 MILES SSE OF ARECIBO.

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1900 (JBB) THIS STATION IS LOCATED ON HIGHEST POINT OF RIDGE BETWEEN TARGET BAY AND HEAD OF GREAT HARBOR SOME 10 M (32.8 FT) EAST OF RUINED THATCH HOUSE.  STATION IS MARKED BY A NAIL SET IN A CEMENT BLOCK SET IN THE GROUND.  A TRIPOD SIGNAL WAS ERECTED OVER THE STATION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1922)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1922 (FTS) DESCRIPTION OF LOCATION ADEQUATE.  HILL IS BARREN AND USED AS PASTURE LAND.  STATION MARK RECOVERED IN MAY IN GOOD CONDITION.  SIGNAL ERECTED.  LATER SIGNAL FOUND WRECKED AND MARK BROKEN OFF BENEATH SURFACE.  STATION RE-MARKED IN OCTOBER WITH CONCRETE POST 6 BY 6 BY 18 INCHES, PROJECTING 5 INCHES ABOVE SURFACE.  A STANDARD BRONZE DISK IS EMBEDDED IN THE TOP OF CONCRETE POST.  TWO REFERENCE MARKS WERE ESTABLISHED.  REFERENCE MARK NO.1 IS A STANDARD DISK CEMENTED IN TOP OF BOULDER 10 FEET HIGH AND 15 FEET IN DIAMETER ON BROW OF HILL FACING E END OF VIEQUES ISLAND.  REFERENCE MARK NO.2 IS STANDARD DISK CEMENTED IN TOP OF BOULDER, TRIANGULAR IN SHAPE, 6 FEET HIGH AND 15 FEET ON A SIDE, ON BROW OF HILL FACING S.W. CAY.                            STATION RECOVERY (1926)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1926 (GCM) STATION EASILY RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED.  STATION AND REFERENCE MARKS ESTABLISHED IN 1922 BY F.B.T. SIEMS IN EXCELLENT CONDITION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1963)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US NAVY 1963 (DHW) DESCRIPTION OF LOCATION IS ADEQUATE, EXCEPT THAT A SMALL CONCRETE BUILDING HAS BEEN ERECTED NEAR THE STATION.  6 X 6 X 18 IN. POST WAS RECOVERED, BUT IT WAS BROKEN AND DISC REMOVED.  POST WAS LOOSE AND DIDNT CHECK WITH THE REFERENCE MARKS.  IT WAS PROBABLY DESTROYED DURING CONSTRUCTION OF THE BUILDING. REFERENCE MARK NO. 1 WAS RECOVERED IN VERY GOOD CONDITION. REFERENCE MARK NO. 2 WAS RECOVERED IN POOR CONDITION - DISC HAD BEEN REMOVED BUT GOOD IMPRESSION REMAINED IN CEMENT, WHICH WAS USED TO SET IT.                            STATION RECOVERY (1965)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1965 (JMC) STATION MARK NOT RECOVERED.  RM 1 RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.  REFERENCE MARK 2 DISK HAS BEEN REMOVED.  DISTANCE FROM REFERENCE MARK WOULD PLACE THE STATION IN A SHALLOW DEPRESSION NEAR THE NORTHEAST CORNER OF A SMALL ABANDONED BUILDING. NO EVIDENCE OF STATION FOUND IN THIS POSITION.  STATION SHOULD BE CONSIDERED LOST.                            STATION RECOVERY (1965)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1965 (MTF) THE DESCRIPTION OF THE STATIONS LOCATION IS ADEQUATE.  THE STATION CAN BE REACHED AS FOLLOWS--DRIVE 0.4 MILE NORTH FROM THE POST OFFICE IN THE TOWN OF CULEBRA ALONG THE ROAD PARALLELING ENSENADA HONDA.  TURN WEST (LEFT) OFF THE ROAD AND PASS THROUGH A CORRAL ADJACENT TO A HOUSE WITH A RED ROOF.  DRIVE WEST APPROXIMATELY 0.4 MILE THROUGH SOME BALD GRAZING LAND TO THE TOP OF A HILL, 350 FEET ABOVE SEA LEVEL.  A PORTION OF THE STATIONS CONCRETE BLOCK HAS BEEN BROKEN OFF.  THE CONCRETE BLOCK EXTENDS 2 IN ABOVE THE GROUND.  A NEW CONCRETE BUILDING, WHOSE NORTHWEST CORNER IS 9.5 FEET EAST FROM THE TRIANGULATION STATION HAS BEEN ERECTED NEAR THE MARK.  THE REFERENCE MARK DISK FOR RM NO. 2 HAS BEEN REMOVED FROM THE TRIANGULAR SHAPED ROCK.  ONLY THE ROUND PUNCH MARK FROM THE DISK REMAINS.
BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1926 (GCM) STATION IS THE W GABLE OF A SMALL THATCHED HOUSE, 1.0 MILE W OF ARROYO.  THE HOUSE SETS NEAR THE EDGE OF THE BANK AT THE BEACH.

BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JJL) THE STATION MARK, REFERENCE MARK 2 AND A U.S. ARMY ENGINEERS DEPARTMENT SURVEY MARK WERE FOUND AND IN GOOD CONDITION.  A COPPER PLUG HAS BEEN SET TO REPLACE THE COPPER NAIL WHICH WAS PREVIOUSLY USED TO MARK THE STATION.  AN AZIMUTH MARK WAS ESTABLISHED AT THIS DATE.  A NEW DESCRIPTION FOLLOWS--  THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 15 MILES EAST OF SAN JUAN, 9 MILES NORTHWEST OF RIO GRANDE, 6-1/2 MILES NORTH OF LOIZA AND ON A BRUSH COVERED HILL THAT IS LOCALLY KNOWN AS POINT TELEGAS.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE SAN JUAN, LOIZA STREET STATION POST OFFICE IN CONDADO, GO EAST ON LOIZA STREET FOR 5.0 MILES TO THE END OF THE PAVED ROAD, JUST AFTER CROSSING A SMALL BRIDGE.  CONTINUE EASTERLY ON A DIRT ROAD FOR 0.9 MILE TO A FORK.  TAKE THE RIGHT FORK AND GO SOUTHEAST AND EAST ON A DIRT ROAD FOR 4.9 MILES TO THE AZIMUTH MARK ON THE LEFT, NORTH SIDE OF THE ROAD, JUST BEFORE REACHING A HOUSE ON THE RIGHT. CONTINUE EAST ON THE DIRT ROAD FOR 0.6 MILE TO AN OPENING IN A WIRE FENCE ON THE LEFT, NORTH SIDE OF THE ROAD.  PASS THROUGH THE OPENING IN THE FENCE AND FOLLOW A TRACK ROAD EAST, NORTH AND WEST THROUGH HIGH BRUSH FOR 0.2 MILE TO AN OLD, ABANDONED U.S. ARMY OBSERVATION BUILDING AND THE STATION.  THE STATION MARK IS A 1-INCH COPPER BOLT WITH A CHISELED CROSS ON ITS TOP, CEMENTED IN A 2-INCH METAL PIPE THAT PROJECTS 2 INCHES AND IS SURROUNDED BY A MASS OF CONCRETE THAT IS 2 FEET IN DIAMETER AND HAS THE LEGEND 1954 ACROSS ITS TOP.  IT IS 55 FEET SOUTHWEST OF THE SOUTHWEST CORNER POST OF AN OLD U.S. ARMY OBSERVATION BUILDING.  THE U.S. ARMY ENGINEERS DEPARTMENT SURVEY DISK IS UNSTAMPED AND IS SET IN THE TOP OF A 12-INCH SQUARE CONCRETE POST THAT PROJECTS 3 INCHES AND IS 3.5 FEET SOUTHEAST OF THE NORTHWEST CORNER POST OF THE OBSERVATION BUILDING.  REFERENCE MARK 2 IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED GA TAL RM 2, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A 3 BY 4 FOOT CONCRETE FOUNDATION THAT PROJECTS ABOUT 6 INCHES.  IT IS 15 FEET SOUTHWEST OF THE SOUTHWEST CORNER POST OF THE OBSERVATION BUILDING.  THE AZIMUTH MARK IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED TELEGAS 1902 1965, SET IN THE TOP OF A 12-INCH SQUARE CONCRETE POST THAT PROJECTS 8 INCHES.  IT IS 12 FEET NORTH OF THE APPROXIMATE CENTER OF A DIRT ROAD AND 1 FOOT NORTH OF A WIRE FENCE.  THE DISTANCE BETWEEN REFERENCE MARK 2 AND THE U.S. ARMY ENGINEERS SURVEY MARK IS 23.17 FEET OR 7.063 METERS.  AIRLINE DISTANCE AND DIRECTION FROM NEAREST TOWN 6-1/2 MILES NORTH OF LOIZA.
