markers.description: BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1934 STATION IS CENTER OF ROOF OF LARGE WHITE TANK LOWER THAN A BLACK TANK ON POINT OF RIDGE ON E SIDE OF GUAYANILLA BAY.                            STATION RECOVERY (1970)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1970 (KAM) STATION WAS RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.  IT IS THE THIRD IN A STRAIGHT LINE OF FOUR TEXACO PETROLEUM STORAGE TANKS, COUNTING FROM THE WEST END OF THE LINE.  ALL OF THE TANKS ARE WHITE, AND ARE ON THE POINT OF THE RIDGE OF PUNTA PEPILLO ON THE EAST SIDE OF GUAYANILLA BAY AND ARE AT THE TEXACO BULK PLANT.  TEXACO COMPANY RECORDS SHOW THE STATION TANK WAS BUILT IN 1923, AND THE NEXT TANK UPHILL TO THE EAST-NORTHEAST WAS BUILT IN 1919.                            STATION RECOVERY (1971)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1971 (EKM) STATION RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.  ANOTHER TANK HAS BEEN PLACED JUST BELOW THE SOUTH SIDE OF THE WESTERNMOST TANK.

BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JJL) THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 2 MILES WEST OF CULEBRA AND IN A CLEARED AREA ATOP THE KNOLL ON THE SOUTH END OF LUISPENA ISLAND.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE DOCK ON LUISPENA ISLAND, PACK SOUTHERLY ALONG A BULLDOZED TRAIL FOR ABOUT 0.15 MILE TO THE TOP OF THE KNOLL AND THE STATION.  A 1/4 HOUR PACK.  THE STATION MARK, STAMPED THE 2 1966, IS A STANDARD DISK CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A BOULDER THAT PROJECTS 6 INCHES.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 1, STAMPED THE 2 NO 1 1966, IS A STANDARD DISK CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A BOULDER THAT PROJECTS 2 FEET.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 2, STAMPED THE 2 NO 2 1966, IS A STANDARD DISK CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A BOULDER THAT PROJECTS 2 FEET.                            STATION RECOVERY (1993)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE 1993 (BR) STATION FOUND AS DESCRIBED, BUT AREA AND TRAIL IS NO LONGER CLEARED OUT.  GPS VISIBILITY IS EXCELLENT ONCE BRUSH WAS CLEARED.  STATION USED FOR GPS SURVEY.
markers.setting: SET IN ROCK OUTCROP
markers.stability: MOST RELIABLE AND EXPECTED TO HOLDPOSITION/ELEVATION WELL

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JWC) THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 5 MILES WEST OF CAMUY, 1 MILE NORTHEAST OF QUEBRADILLAS AND ON A HILL THAT IS LOCALLY KNOWN AS TIERRA NOVA.  THE STATION IS ON THE PROPERTY OF MR. MANUEL VIERA.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE JUNCTION OF HIGHWAYS 2 AND 485 WHICH IS 1/4 MILE NORTHEAST OF QUEBRADILLAS, GO NORTHERLY ON HIGHWAY 485 FOR 0.65 MILE TO A CROSSROADS.  TURN LEFT AND GO WESTERLY ON A PAVED ROAD FOR 0.9 MILE TO A HOUSE ON THE LEFT, JUST AFTER PASSING KILOMETER POST 1.4 AND THE END OF TRUCK TRAVEL.  FROM HERE PACK SOUTHERLY, PASSING TO THE WEST SIDE OF THE HOUSE AND FOLLOW A GOOD TRAIL UP THE HILL SOUTH AND THEN EAST FOR ABOUT 10 MINUTES TO THE HIGHEST POINT OF THE HILL AND THE STATION.  THE STATION MARK IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED TIERRA 1966, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A ROCK OUTCROP THAT PROJECTS 4 INCHES.  IT IS 41.5 FEET NORTH OF A WIRE FENCE.  REFERENCE MARK 1 IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED TIERRA NO 1 1966, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A ROCK OUTCROP THAT PROJECTS 12 INCHES.  IT IS 28.6 FEET NORTH OF THE WIRE FENCE.  REFERENCE MARK 2 (ORIGIN UNKNOWN) IS A METAL T STAKE, SET IN AN IRREGULAR MASS OF CONCRETE THAT PROJECTS 4 INCHES.  IT IS 38.7 FEET NORTH OF THE WIRE FENCE.
markers.setting: SET IN ROCK OUTCROP
markers.stability: MOST RELIABLE AND EXPECTED TO HOLDPOSITION/ELEVATION WELL

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1901 (JN) STATION IS ABOUT 5 MILES W OF CAMUY, ON A HILL CALLED TIERRE NOVE AND OWNED BY SACOLA RUIE, A WIDOW.  IT IS N 45 DEG E DISTANT 2/3 MILE FROM QUEBRADILLAS, AND ABOUT 1,600 FEET S OF THE OCEAN.  IT IS ON VERY ROCKY GROUND.  THE STATION IS MARKED BY A BRASS BOLT CEMENTED INTO A HOLE IN A ROCK ABOUT 2 FEET SQUARE AND PROJECTING ABOUT 2-1/2 INCHES ABOVE THE GROUND.  THE CENTER OF THE HEAD OF THE BOLT MARKS THE STATION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1934)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1934 STATION FOUND IN GOOD CONDITION, APPARENTLY UNDISTURBED.  OCCUPIED OVER OLD U.S.C. AND G.S. STATION MARK.  SIGNAL IS WHITE FLAG ON POLE SURROUNDED BY MONUMENT OF ROCK.
markers.setting: SET IN ROCK OUTCROP
markers.stability: MOST RELIABLE AND EXPECTED TO HOLDPOSITION/ELEVATION WELL

markers.description: BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1941 V.A. ELEVATION 155.45 METERS.  IN THE SOUTHEASTERN PART OF VIEQUES ISLAND ABOUT 1 KM. SW OF PLAYA GRANDE AND 1/2 KM. NORTH OF THE COAST ON THE MOST EASTERLY OF A SERIES OF HILLS WHICH FORM THE RIDGE WHICH EXTENDS EAST FROM MOUNT PIRATA.  THE NORTH SLOPE OF THE HILL IS BRUSH COVERED AND THE TOP IS GRASSY.  STATION MARK--STANDARD TABLET STAMPED TIO AND SET IN A ROCK WHICH IS ABOUT 1 FT. HIGH AND ABOUT 15 FT. EAST OF THE EXTREME TOP OF THE HILL.  R.M. 1 DRILL HOLE IN A FLAT TOPPED ROCK WHICH IS ABOUT 4 FT. LONG AND 2 FT. HIGH.  DISTANCE FROM STATION--25.18 METERS.  PLANE AZIMUTH--257-08-09.  R.M. 2 CHISELED CROSS ON THE SOUTH SIDE OF AND ABOUT SIX INCHES BELOW THE TOP OF A DIME SHAPED ROCK WHICH IS ABOUT 4 FT. HIGH. DISTANCE FROM STATION--13.43 METERS.  PLANE AZIMUTH--162-02-58.  SIGNAL--CLOTH TARGET AND FLAG CENTERED OVER STATION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1964)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1964 (GWM) STATION AND R.M.S RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED.  MARK IS ON HIGHEST PART OF HILL.  THERE IS A GRASS COVERED HILL ABOUT 100 FEET LESS IN ELEVATION TO THE SOUTH EAST ABOUT 1000 FEET.                            STATION RECOVERY (1970)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US MARINE CORPS 1970 STATION WAS RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.
markers.setting: SET IN ROCK OUTCROP
markers.stability: MOST RELIABLE AND EXPECTED TO HOLDPOSITION/ELEVATION WELL

markers.description: BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1934 THIS STATION IS SITUATED ON THE MOST PROMINENT POINT OF A RIDGE OF MOUNTAINS W OF LA PLATA RIVER, AND OF THE BAYAMON-COMERIC ROAD, AND N OF THE COMERIO-AGUAS BUENAS ROAD.  THE POINT IS ABOUT 5 KILOMETERS FROM THE W END OF RIDGE, 2 KILOMETERS N OF THE COMERIO-AGUAS BUENAS ROAD, AND 6 KILOMETERS NE OF THE TOWN OF COMERIO.  THE PLACE IS KNOWN AS NARANJALES.  THE STATION IS ON A ROCKY POINT SURROUNDED BY OTHERS ON ITS SW AND E SIDES.  STATION MARK IS A STANDARD U.S.G.S. BENCH MARK TABLET CEMENTED ON NATURAL ROCK.  REFERENCE MARK NO.1 (NOT DESCRIBED) AZIMUTH 92 DEG 03 MIN, 3.496 METERS FROM STATION.  REFERENCE MARK NO.2 (NOT DESCRIBED) AZIMUTH 303 DEG 14 MIN, 2.59 METERS FROM STATION.  TO REACH FROM KILOMETER POST 27, OF THE COMERIO AGUAS BUENAS ROAD IN FRONT OF THE FARMHOUSE OF MR. LINO LONGO, FOLLOW A TRAIL CLIMBING A RIDGE TO THE SUMMIT IN A NORTHERLY DIRECTION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1966)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JJL) THE STATION MARK AND REFERENCE MARK 2 WERE FOUND AND IN GOOD CONDITION.  REFERENCE MARK 1 WAS NOT FOUND.  A REFERENCE MARK 3 WAS SET AT THIS DATE.  A NEW DESCRIPTION FOLLOWS--  THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 12 MILES WEST OF CAGUAS, 11 MILES NORTH OF CAYEY, 6 MILES WEST-SOUTHWEST OF AGUAS BUENAS AND ON A HILL THAT IS COVERED WITH HEAVY BRUSH AND TREES.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE NORTHWEST CORNER OF THE PLAZA IN CIDRA, GO NORTHWEST ON HIGHWAY 173 FOR 0.8 MILE TO THE JUNCTION WITH HIGHWAY 782.  TAKE THE LEFT FORK AND GO NORTHWEST AND NORTH ON HIGHWAY 782 FOR 6.4 MILES TO THE JUNCTION WITH HIGHWAY 156.  CROSS HIGHWAY 156 AND GO NORTH UP A STEEP HILL ON A DIRT ROAD FOR 0.75 MILE TO A SIDE ROAD ON THE LEFT AND A HOUSE ON THE LEFT.  (THIS IS THE END OF TRUCK TRAVEL IN WET WEATHER.) PACK WESTERLY ON A DIM TRACK ROAD FOR 20 MINUTES, BEAR RIGHT, LEAVE THE TRAIL AND PACK NORTH FOR 50 FEET TO THE STATION MARK ON THE HIGHEST POINT OF THE HILL.  THE STATION MARK IS A U.S. GEOLOGICAL SURVEY BENCH MARK DISK STAMPED TIZA 1934, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A LARGE BOULDER THAT PROJECTS 3 FEET AND IS ON THE HIGHEST POINT OF THE HILL.  REFERENCE MARK 2 IS A METAL BOLT THAT IS CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A BOULDER THAT PROJECTS 3 FEET AND IS THE SAME ELEVATION AS THE STATION MARK.  THE BOLT IS UNSTAMPED.  REFERENCE MARK 3 IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED TIZA NO 3 1934, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A LARGE BOULDER THAT PROJECTS 3 FEET AND IS THE SAME ELEVATION AS THE STATION MARK.  NO SUITABLE PLACE WAS FOUND FOR AN AZIMUTH MARK.  AIRLINE DISTANCE AND DIRECTION FROM NEAREST TOWN 6 MILES WEST-SOUTHWEST OF AGUAS BUENAS.
markers.setting: SET IN UNSPECIFIED ROCK OR BOULDER
markers.stability: PROBABLY HOLD POSITION/ELEVATION WELL

markers.description: BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1940 (EGR) STATION IS LOCATED ON THE SECOND (FROM THE W) PROMINENT POINT OF THE RIDGE WHICH RUNS E-W, N OF RD. 42 (TOA ALTA BAYAMON).  IT IS ABOUT 2 KMS. SE OF THE TOWN OF TOA ALTA, ON LAND OWNED BY MR. RAFAEL FERNANDEZ, IT IS ABOUT 300 METERS NW OF THE RD. AT A POINT WHERE IT MAKES A HOOK N TO GO AROUND A DRAIN.  THE STATION IS ABOUT 200 METERS W OF A CANE FIELD.  IT IS ABOUT 200 METERS E OF A RIDGE WHICH RUNS N-S HALF BARE AND HALF BRUSHY.  HILL IS AROUND POINT, BARE WITH A BUNCH OF TREES, 8 METERS TO W OF STATION, HAS A FENCE LINE (BARBED WIRE) WITH MAYA ON S AND E, 35 AND 50 METERS FROM TOP.  APPROACHED FROM TOA ALTA BY FOLLOWING RD. 42 ABOUT 2-1/2 KMS. TO THE LOOP, THEN FOLLOWING TRAIL UP DRAIN ABOUT 40 METERS, WHERE IT FORKS, FOLLOW BRANCH TO W, CROSSING CREEK AND RUNNING S OF RIDGE, PASSING A LOW ROUND, WIDE TOP, A SADDLE AND REACH A SHARP NOSE, TURN THERE N CROSS FENCE NEAR BIG MANGO TO GET TO TOP AND STATION.  R.M. NO. 1--R.R. SPIKE ON A ALMACIGO TREE NW OF STATION 10.13 INCLINED DISTANCE FROM STATION TO NAIL.  R.M. NO. 2--R.R. SPIKE ON A ROYAL PALM S OF STATION, 41.00 HOR. DIST.  SIGNAL--POLE OF 1- BY 4-INCH ROUGH LUMBER 4 FT. 2 INCHES FROM STATION WITH WHITE FLAG AND CROSS TARGET.                            STATION RECOVERY (1941)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1941 (GBG) THE STATION IS LOCATED ON THE SECOND FROM THE W PROMINENT TOP OF A RIDGE RUNNING E AND W TO THE N OF THE TOA ALTA-BAYAMON ROAD.  AND N OF THE RIO LA PLATA.  IT IS ABOUT 2 KILOMETERS SE OF TOA ALTA, ON LAND OWNED BY RAFAEL FERNANDEZ.  AND ABOUT 300 METERS NW OF THE HIGHWAY WHERE IT MAKES A LOOP N TO CROSS A DRAIN.  THE STATION IS ON THE HIGHEST POINT OF THE SHARP, BARE, HILL.  200 METERS W OF CANE FIELD.  200 METERS E OF A N-S RIDGE.  8 METERS E OF A GROUP OF TREES.  50 METERS W OF BARBED-WIRE AND MAYA FENCE.  AND 35 METERS N OF BRUSHY, BARBEDWIRE AND MAYA FENCE.  IT IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED TOA ALTA 1940 SET IN TOP OF CONCRETE POST 2 INCHES ABOVE GROUND.  REFERENCE MARK 1 IS A RAILROAD SPIKE IN AN ALMACIGO TREE 10.13 METERS (SLOPE DISTANCE) NW OF THE STATION.  REFERENCE MARK 2 IS A RAILROAD SPIKE ON A ROYAL PALM 41.00 METERS S OF THE STATION.  TO REACH FROM TOA ALTA, GO S FROM PLAZA ON ROAD 42, TO BAYAMON FOR 0.90 MILE.  TAKE LEFT FORK, AND GO 0.85 MILE TO ROAD LOOP AT DRAIN CROSSING.  FROM HERE THE STATION BEARS N 70 DEG W.  TAKE TRAIL UP DRAIN ABOUT 40 METERS, TURN LEFT AND FOLLOW TRAIL W ON S SIDE OF RIDGE.  PASS A LOW, ROUND, WIDE, TOP.  THEN CROSS A SADDLE AND HEAD FOR LARGE MANGO TREE ON FENCE LINE.  PASS FENCE HERE.  AND GO DIRECTLY TO TOP AND STATION.
markers.setting: SET IN TOP OF CONCRETE MONUMENT
markers.stability: MAY HOLD, BUT OF TYPE COMMONLY SUBJECT TOSURFACE MOTION

markers.description: BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1934 POINT SIGHTED UPON WAS THE CENTER OF STEEL ON THE STEEL TOWER.

BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1900 (JN) STATION IS ON THE FIRST HILL W OF THE RIDGE FORMING POINT BARACO AND POINT POBRE.  TORO IS THE LOCAL NAME OF THE HILL ON WHICH THE SIGNAL STANDS.  IT IS JUST E OF POINT VENTANO.  THERE IS NOTHING, OF A NATURAL CHARACTER, WHICH IS VERY STRIKING ABOUT THE STATION POINT.  IT IS VERY NEAR THE WESTERN END OF THE SUMMIT OF THE RIDGE ON AS HIGH A POINT AS CAN BE FOUND.  FROM THE STATION POINT LINES WERE CUT THROUGH THE BRUSH AND TREES TO CRIOLLO, TURN, AND MARIA.  THESE LANES ARE ABOUT 15 FEET WIDE AND WILL SERVE TO INDICATE THE WHEREABOUTS OF THE SIGNAL FOR SEVERAL YEARS.  PERHAPS AFTER THAT THE HEAPS OF STONES PILED ABOUT THE TRIPOD LEGS WILL BE SOME HELP.  STATION MARK IS A 2-INCH GAS PIPE CEMENTED IN THE ROCK.  ITS SURFACE PROJECTS FOR ABOUT 4 INCHES AND A SMALL MOUND OF STONES IS HEAPED ABOUT IT.  IT IS NOT PROBABLE THAT THIS WILL BE DISTURBED, BECAUSE OF THE ISOLATED CHARACTER OF THE HILL, ITS REMOTENESS FROM HOUSES, AND THE ABUNDANCE OF THE MEANEST CACTI IN THE ISLAND WHICH THRIVE HERE.  GOING IN THE DIRECTION OF CRIOLLO FROM THE STATION, 50 YARDS WILL TAKE ONE TO WHERE THE BLUFF BECOMES PRECIPITOUS.  TOWARDS TURN AT ABOUT 35 YARDS THE BLUFF HAS A SHARP DESCENT OF ABOUT 6 FEET AND THEN SLOPES DOWN PRETTY RAPIDLY.  LOOKING TOWARD MARIA, THE FLAT SUMMIT OF THE RIDGE EXTENDS OUT FOR ABOUT 30 YARDS AND THEN A STEEP SLOPE COMMENCES.  TO REACH IT BY LAND ONE SHOULD GO TO SENOR LLUVERAS PLANTATION AND THERE ANYONE CAN INDICATE THE ROAD THAT MUST BE TAKEN.  AFTER REACHING THE FOOT OF THE HILL, ONE SHOULD TAKE A TRAIL THAT IS FOUND NEAR THE E END OF THE HILL AND WHICH RUNS TO THE OUTSIDE BEACH.  FOLLOW THIS TO ITS HIGHEST POINT AND THEN TAKE A TRAIL WE HAVE CUT AND WHICH FOLLOWS THE CENTER OF THE RIDGE TO THE SIGNAL.                            STATION RECOVERY (1901)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1901 (GLF) FOUND STATION MARK UNDISTURBED AND TRIPOD STANDING.                            STATION RECOVERY (1959)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US NAVY 1959 STATION WAS DESTROYED AND PIPE WAS MISSING.  FOUND PIECES OF BROKEN CONCRETE IN VICINITY OF MARK.  FOUND LARGE ROCK WHERE PIPE WAS CEMENTED TO.  BUILT ROCK CAIRN OVER POINT, WITH TWO REFERENCE ROCK CAIRNS 10 FEET FROM MARK.  ONE TO THE EAST AND ONE TO THE SOUTH OF MARK.
markers.setting: SET IN ROCK OUTCROP
markers.stability: MOST RELIABLE AND EXPECTED TO HOLDPOSITION/ELEVATION WELL

markers.description: BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1934 THIS STATION IS ON THE HIGHEST PEAK W OF A RIDGE ABOUT 3 KILOMETERS E OF BARRANQUITAS.  THIS IS KNOWN ALL OVER AS THE TORRECILLAS HILL.  IT IS ON LAND OWNED BY JUAN D. SANTINI AND IS ABOUT 1 KILOMETER N OF KILOMETER 13 H 3 OF BARRANQUITOS-BARROS ROAD.  STATION MARK IS A STANDARD U.S.G.S. BENCH MARK TABLET SET IN BOULDER AND STAMPED TORRECILLA 1934.  REFERENCE MARK NO.1 IS A STANDARD TABLET SET IN BOULDER, 22.04 METERS FROM STATION IN TRUE AZIMUTH 28 DEG 50 MIN.  REFERENCE MARK NO.2 IS A BRASS NAIL AND WASHER CEMENTED ON BOULDER, 4.40 METERS FROM STATION IN TRUE AZIMUTH 218 DEG 00 MIN.  REFERENCE MARK NO.3 IS WILD PALM 4.90 METERS FROM STATION IN TRUE AZIMUTH 186 DEG 10 MIN.  REFERENCE MARK NO.4 IS WILD PALM 7.60 METERS FROM STATION IN TRUE AZIMUTH 358 DEG 17 MIN.
markers.setting: SET IN A BOULDER
markers.stability: MAY HOLD, BUT OF TYPE COMMONLY SUBJECT TOSURFACE MOTION

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1899 (JN) STATION IS ON THE SIDE OF A HILL WHICH CONTINUES TO ASCEND FOR SEVERAL HUNDRED FEET BACK OF THE SIGNAL.  A RIDGE JUST TO THE E CUTS OFF ANY VIEW OF PONCE PROPER BUT THE PLAYA IS VISIBLE.  SOUTHWEST BASE IS ALSO CUT OFF BY THIS RIDGE.  A SOLITARY BRICK CHIMNEY NEAR THE FOOT OF THE RIDGE, JUST REFERRED TO, IS VERY NEARLY IN LINE WITH THE SE EXTREMITY OF THE GROUP OF BUILDINGS WHICH COMPRISES THE QUARTERMASTERS WAREHOUSE, CUSTOM HOUSE, AND THE LARGE RESTAURANT AND DELICATESSEN STORE E OF THE CUSTOM HOUSE.  THE MOST SOUTHERN AND EASTERN OF THESE BUILDINGS IS A COUPLE OF HUNDRED FEET TO THE LEFT OF A LINE FROM TORREY TO THE CHIMNEY.  THE FIRST PALM TREE TO THE LEFT OF THE LIGHTHOUSE ON CARDONA ISLAND IS ALMOST EXACTLY IN LINE WITH THE EXTREME LEFT HAND EDGE OF CAJA DE MUERTOS ISLAND. ANOTHER RANGE IS MADE BY THE FISHERMENS HOUSES ON THE POINT IN FRONT OF TORREY, ON THE SIDE NEAREST RATONES ISLAND, AND THE REEF NEARBY.  THE LEFT HAND BUILDING IS VERY NEARLY ON LINE WITH THE LEFT HAND END OF THE REEF EXTENDING E FROM RATONES ISLAND AND THE LEFT HAND EDGE OF THE INTERMEDIATE REEF. AT THE FOOT OF THE RIDGE TO THE E IS A LARGE LAKE OR LAGOON, AND AT THE FOOT OF THE STATION RIDGE IS A SMALL POND (ABOUT 150- BY 25-FEET).  STATION IS ON THE FIRST BENCH ABOVE THE HIGH ROAD.  THERE ARE NO HIGH BUSHES ON THIS SHELF UNTIL THE STATION IS PASSED.  THE RIDGE UP TO THE SIGNAL IS FAIRLY OPEN.  HERE A TRIPOD SIGNAL AND POLE WERE BUILT AND ON THE POLE A LOZENGE AND FLAG WERE FIXED.  THE TEMPORARY MARK WAS A STUB DRIVEN IN THE GROUND, IN WHOSE TOP WAS DRIVEN A TACK MARKING THE STATION, AND OVER THIS THE INSTRUMENT WAS CENTERED.  AFTERWARDS THE PORTION OF THE STUB PROJECTING ABOVE THE GROUND WAS SURROUNDED BY A SMALL MASS OF CONCRETE, THE TOP OF THE STUB BEING LEFT CLEAR.  IN THE CONCRETE A 20 PENNY NAIL WAS EMBEDDED.  THE NAIL IS AT RIGHT ANGLES TO THE LINE TORREY-CARDONA ISLAND LIGHTHOUSE, AND IS DISTANT 0.85 INCH FROM THE STATION MARK.  TORREY IS ABOUT 160 FEET IN ELEVATION ABOVE HIGH WATER.                            STATION RECOVERY (1901)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1901 (GLF) TRIPOD AND POLE STANDING.  DID NOT GO TO STATION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1963)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1963 (RWS) ORIGINAL DESCRIPTION IS ADEQUATE FOR GETTING TO THE STATION.  AN IRON BOLT SET IN CONCRETE WITH TORREY ADT. WAS FOUND.  RECOVERED BY U.S. NAVAL OCEANOGRAPHIC OFFICE.                            STATION RECOVERY (1966)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JMC) NOT RECOVERED.  SEE STATION REY, 1966.
markers.setting: OBJECT SURROUNDED BY MASS OF CONCRETE
markers.stability: MARK OF QUESTIONABLE OR UNKNOWN STABILITY

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JWC) THE STATION IS LOCATED 6 AIRLINE MILES SOUTHWEST OF AGUADILLA, 5 AIRLINE MILES NORTHEAST OF RINCON, 2 AIRLINE MILES WEST-NORTHWEST OF AGUADA AND ON THE TOP OF A LOW GRASS COVERED HILL.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE PLAZA IN AGUADA, GO WESTERLY ON HIGHWAY 115 FOR 1.4 MILES TO A SIDE ROAD RIGHT AT KILOMETER POST 21.1.  TURN RIGHT AND GO WESTERLY.  NORTHWEST AND NORTH ON A PAVED ROAD FOR 0.4 MILE TO A GATE ON THE RIGHT AND THE END OF TRUCK TRAVEL.  FROM HERE PACK EAST UP THE WEST SIDE OF A RIDGE FOR ABOUT 50 YARDS TO THE WEST EDGE OF A HILL.  CONTINUE EASTERLY UP THE HILL FOR ABOUT 75 YARDS TO THE TOP OF THE HILL AND THE STATION.  THE STATION MARK IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED TOSQUERO 1966, BRAZED TO THE TOP OF A 3-INCH ROUND CAST IRON SOIL PIPE WHICH PROJECTS 2 INCHES.  IT IS 10 FEET NORTH OF A FENCE LINE.  REFERENCE MARK 1 IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED TOSQUERO NO 1 1966, BRAZED TO THE TOP OF A 3-INCH ROUND CAST IRON SOIL PIPE WHICH PROJECTS 4 INCHES.  REFERENCE MARK 2 IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED TOSQUERO NO 2 1966, BRAZED TO THE TOP OF A 3-INCH ROUND CAST IRON SOIL PIPE WHICH PROJECTS 6 INCHES.  NO AZIMUTH MARK WAS ESTABLISHED AT THIS STATION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1999)  RECOVERY NOTE BY UNIVERSITY OF PUERTO RICO AT MAYAGUEZ 1999 THE NAME OF THE STATION IS TOSQUERO AND IT IS LOCATED IN THE MUNICIPALITY OF AGUADA AND NOT AGUADILLA AS STATED IN THE REPORT. THE STATION WASN'T FOUND.
markers.setting: SET INTO TOP OF METAL PIPE DRIVEN INTO GROUND
markers.stability: MARK OF QUESTIONABLE OR UNKNOWN STABILITY

markers.description: BY JAVIER E. BIDOT AND ASSOC. 2010 (JEB) THE MARK IS LOCATED ABOUT 11.8 KM (7.3 MI) SOUTHEAST OF COAMO TOWN AND ABOUT 3.7 KM (2.3 MI) NORTHEAST OF SALINAS TOWN.  THE MARK IS IN THE WEST SECTION OF SALINAS.   TO REACH FROM THE INTERSECTION OF INTERSTATE PR-1 AND PR-154, GO NORTHERLY ON PR-154 TO REACH A INTERSECTION T TYPE WITH A RURAL ROAD. TURN TO THE RIGHT AND GO ON FOR 1.1 KM (0.7 MI) TO REACH THE USAF TRANSMITTING STATION, BUILDING 600 OF SANTIAGO CAMP AND MARK TO THE RIGHT.   THE MARK IS 1.2 M (3.9 FT) DEEP AND 0.3 M (1.0 FT) DIAMETER 13.6 M (44.6 FT) WEST OF THE SOUTH FENCE CORNER OF BUILDING 600 AND 1.97 M (6.5 FT) SOUTH OF THE RURAL EDGE OF PAVEMENT.   OWNERSHIP--U.S ARMY.                            STATION RECOVERY (2016)  RECOVERY NOTE BY ATKINS NORTH AMERICA INC 2016 (DWD) MARK RECOVERED DURING THE COURSE OF A TOPOGRAPHIC SURVEY FOR CAMP SANTIAGO, PUERTO RICO ARMY NATIONAL GUARD FACILITY.
markers.setting: SET IN TOP OF CONCRETE MONUMENT
markers.stability: MAY HOLD, BUT OF TYPE COMMONLY SUBJECT TOSURFACE MOTION

markers.description: BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1934 STATION IS ABOUT 4 MILES NE OF GUAYAMA IN BARRIO CAIMITAL, ON A WOODY HILL WHICH HAS A TALL DEAD STUMP ON ITS CREST AND WHICH WAS USED AS A SECONDARY POINT BEFORE THE QUADRIPOD WAS PUT UP.  STATION MARK IS A STANDARD U.S.G.S. BENCH MARK SET ON A BOULDER, STAMPED TUMBAO, 1934.  REFERENCE MARK NO.1 IS BRASS NAIL ON TREE TRUNK, 18 FEET 1-1/2 INCHES DISTANT FROM STATION, IN TRUE AZIMUTH 105 DEG 12 MIN.  REFERENCE MARK NO.2 IS BRASS NAIL, 27 FEET 11 INCHES DISTANT FROM STATION, IN TRUE AZIMUTH 07 DEG 45 MIN.  TO REACH THIS STATION TURN E AT KILOMETER 25 WHICH IS A GRAVEL ROAD IN GOOD CONDITION, AND RIDE TO THE END OF IT.  THE TRAIL THAT LEADS OFF THE ROAD IS ITS CONTINUATION AND IS KNOWN AS THE CAMINO REAL WHICH IS THE OLD RURAL ROUTE USED IN THE SPANISH REGIME.  THE STATION IS ABOUT 5 KILOMETERS FROM THE RURAL ROAD.  THIS IS A WINDING TRAIL WHICH IS ON THE S FLANK, OF THE HILL.  THIS STATION IS LOCATED ON THE HIGHEST HILL.                            STATION RECOVERY (1966)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JJL) THE STATION MARK WAS FOUND AND IN GOOD CONDITION.  THE REFERENCE MARKS WERE SEARCHED FOR BUT WERE NOT FOUND.  A REFERENCE MARK 3 AND A REFERENCE MARK 4 WERE SET AT THIS DATE.  A NEW DESCRIPTION FOLLOWS--  THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 9 MILES SOUTHEAST OF CAYEY, 5 MILES NORTH-NORTHWEST OF PALMAS, 4 MILES NORTH-NORTHEAST OF GUAYAMA AND ON A HIGH WOODED MOUNTAIN THAT IS LOCALLY KNOWN AS CERRO TUMBADO.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE PLAZA IN GUAYAMA, GO NORTH ON HIGHWAY 15 FOR 1.05 MILES TO A BRIDGE ON THE LEFT AT THE JUNCTION WITH HIGHWAY 179.  CONTINUE NORTH ON HIGHWAY 179 FOR 0.05 MILE TO A FORK.  TAKE THE RIGHT FORK AND GO EAST ON A PAVED ROAD FOR 0.55 MILE TO A SIDE ROAD ON THE LEFT AND THE END OF THE PAVED ROAD.  TURN LEFT AND GO NORTH AND EAST ON A DIRT ROAD FOR 1.6 MILES TO A HOUSE AND THE END OF THE ROAD.  FROM HERE PACK NORTH ON A WELL USED TRAIL FOR 1 HOUR AND 30 MINUTES TO A CONCRETE WATER RESERVOIR AT THE EDGE OF THE TIMBER LINE. PACK EAST AND NORTHEAST UP THE STEEP HILL, THROUGH HEAVY BRUSH AND FRUIT TREES FOR 30 MINUTES TO THE STATION ON THE HIGHEST POINT OF THE HILL.  THE STATION MARK IS A U.S. GEOLOGICAL SURVEY DISK STAMPED TUMBAO 1934, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A LARGE BOULDER THAT PROJECTS 8 FEET.  REFERENCE MARK 3 IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED TUMBAO USGS NO 3 1934, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A LARGE BOULDER THAT PROJECTS ABOUT 50 FEET ON THE EAST SIDE.  IT IS 3 FEET LOWER IN ELEVATION THAN THE STATION MARK.  NOTE--12C.  REFERENCE MARK 4 IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED TUMBAO USGS NO 4 1934, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A SMALL BOULDER THAT PROJECTS 1 FOOT AND IS 8 FEET LOWER THAN THE STATION MARK IN ELEVATION.  NOTE--12C.  NO SUITABLE PLACE WAS FOUND FOR AN AZIMUTH MARK.  AIRLINE DISTANCE AND DIRECTION FROM NEAREST TOWN 4 MILES NORTH-NORTHEAST OF GUAYAMA.
markers.setting: SET IN A BOULDER
markers.stability: MAY HOLD, BUT OF TYPE COMMONLY SUBJECT TOSURFACE MOTION

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1901 (JN) THIS STATION IS SITUATED 3 MILES E OF ARECIBO, AND ABOUT 2 MILES E OF ARECIBO LIGHTHOUSE.  IT IS UPON THE HIGHEST OF A SERIES OF 8 CORAL ISLANDS AND POINTS IN THIS VICINITY.  THE ROCK IS CALLED LAS TUNAS OWING TO THE PLANT THAT GROWS HERE.  THE WAVES HAVE PERFORATED THE UNDER PART OF THE POINT LEAVING AN IMMENSE ARCH.  THE STATION IS ON THE HIGHEST PART OF THE POINT AND IS MARKED BY THE CENTER OF A BRASS BOLT SET INTO A BED OF CEMENT AND FLUSH WITH ITS TOP SURFACE.                            STATION RECOVERY (1946)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US ARMY CORPS OF ENGINEERS 1946 LETTER FROM MR. E.G. RUBIO, HEADQUARTERS.  ANTILLES DEPARTMENT, OFFICE OF DEPARTMENT ENGR., A.P.O. 851, C/O P.M., MIAMI, FLORIDA, DATED OCTOBER 30, 1946-- HOLE AND LEAD FOUND.  IRON BAR REPLACED.                            STATION RECOVERY (1966)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JJL) THE STATION MARK WAS FOUND AND IN GOOD CONDITION.  REFERENCE MARKS 1 AND 2 WERE ESTABLISHED AT THIS DATE.  A NEW DESCRIPTION FOLLOWS--  THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 6 MILES EAST-NORTHEAST OF ARECIBO, 4-1/2 MILES EAST-NORTHEAST OF THE ARECIBO LIGHTHOUSE, 3-1/2 MILES NORTH OF HIGHWAY 2 AND ON A HIGH AND ROCKY POINT THAT IS LOCALLY KNOWN AS LAS TUNAS.  THE WAVES HAVE PERFORATED THE UNDER PART OF THE POINT LEAVING AN IMMENSE ARCH.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE JUNCTION OF HIGHWAYS 2 AND 10 IN THE EAST PART OF ARECIBO, GO EAST ON HIGHWAY 2 FOR 0.7 MILE TO A Y-FORK.  TAKE THE LEFT FORK AND GO EAST ON A PAVED ROAD FOR 0.25 MILES TO A CROSSROADS.  CONTINUE EAST AND NORTH ON THE PAVED ROAD FOR 0.8 MILE TO A T-ROAD JUST AFTER CROSSING A CONCRETE BRIDGE.  TURN RIGHT AND GO EAST ON A PAVED ROAD FOR 4.05 MILES TO A SIDE ROAD ON THE LEFT AT KILOMETER POST 16.6. TURN LEFT AND GO NORTH ON A SAND ROAD FOR 0.1 MILE TO THE BASE OF A ROCKY POINT AND THE END OF TRUCK TRAVEL.  PACK NORTH FOR ABOUT 50 YARDS TO THE HIGHEST POINT OF THE ROCKY POINT AND THE STATION.  THE STATION MARK IS A 1/2-INCH SQUARE IRON ROD, SET IN A 12-INCH SQUARE CONCRETE POST THAT PROJECTS 8 INCHES AND IS INSCRIBED U H A EGR OCTOBER 18 1901.  NOTE--DESC.  REFERENCE MARK 1 IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED TUNA NO 1 1901, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN THE LARGE ROCK WHICH FORMS THE POINT.  IT IS ON THE EAST SLOPE AND IS 2 FEET LOWER THAN THE STATION MARK.  NOTE--12A  REFERENCE MARK 2 IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED TUNA NO 2 1901, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN THE LARGE ROCK WHICH FORMS THE POINT.  IT IS ON THE WEST SLOPE AND IS 3 FEET LOWER THAN THE STATION MARK.  NOTE--12A  NO SUITABLE PLACE WAS FOUND FOR AN AZIMUTH MARK.  AIRLINE DISTANCE AND DIRECTION FROM NEAREST TOWN 6 MILES EAST-NORTHEAST OF ARECIBO.                            STATION RECOVERY (1995)  RECOVERY NOTE BY ANDREGG INCORPORATED 1995 (MJB) RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED  THE STATION IS WITNESSED BY A 3-1/4 INCH BRASS CAP STAMPED CENTRO DE RECAUDACION DE INGRESSOS MINICIPALES, PUERTO RICO GPS CONTROL, C.R.I.M., UNLAWFUL TO DISTURB, TUNA, CEMENTED HORIZONTALLY INTO A DRILL HOLE IN THE EAST SIDE OF THE 12 INCH CONCRETE BLOCK.                            STATION RECOVERY (2002)  RECOVERY NOTE BY INDIVIDUAL CONTRIBUTORS 2002 (LAM) WE VISITED STATION TUNA PID  WE FOUND THE ORIGINAL MONUMENT FROM 1901 BUT THE WITNESS MARK ON THE EAST FACE OF THE CONCRETE MONUMENT PLACED BY ANDREGG INCORPORATED ON 1995 WAS MISSING.  THIS MARK WAS PLACED AT THE TIME THE STATION WAS CONVERTED TO DE PUERTO RICO B ORDER NETWORK.  LUIS A. MALDONADO PROFESSIONAL LAND SURVEYOR LICENSE 16773                            STATION RECOVERY (2002)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 2002 (JMW) 8.1 KM (5.05 MI) EASTERLY ALONG STATE HIGHWAY 681 FROM THE JUNCTION OF STATE HIGHWAY 2 IN ARECIBO, THENCE 0.2 KM (0.1 MI) NORTHERLY ALONG A DRIVEWAY THROUGH A GATE TO ANOTHER GATE AND  HOUSE WITH A SIGN (SAN VINCENTE) AND THE END OF VEHICLE TRAVEL, PACK ABOUT 100 M EAST ALONG A TRAIL TO THE BEACH , THEN PACK ABOUT 190 M NORTH AND THEN WEST ACROSS THE BEACH AND ON A CORAL OUTCROP TO THE HIGHEST POINT CALLED PUNTA LAS TUNAS,  THE MARK IS A BOLT IN A 2-INCH SQUARE CONCRETE POST CONNECTED TO THE CORAL ROCK, THE CONCRETE POST PROJECTS 0.2 M ABOVE THE ROCK SURFACE.  NOTE--THE MARK IS ON PROPERTY OWNED BY THE STATE BUT YOU MUST CROSS PRIVATE PROPERTY.  CONTACT LIC RAFAEL CARDONA CAMPAS, P.O. BOX 1802, ARECIBO, PR 00613.

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1900 (JN) TO GO TO TURN FROM PONCE, ONE MUST FOLLOW THE WAGON ROAD TO THE CROSSING TO THE TALLABOA RIVER (AT TALLABOA) AND CONTINUE W UNTIL THE WAGON ROAD MAKES ITS FIRST CROSSING OF THE RAILROAD W OF THE TALLABOA RIVER.  IMMEDIATELY AFTER THE CROSSING, THE RAILROAD PASSES AROUND THE HILL ON WHICH TURN STANDS.  A CUTTING BEING MADE IN THE ROCKY BASE OF THE N FACE OF THE HILL.  AFTER CROSSING THE RAILROAD, WE CONTINUED IN THE WAGON ROAD FOR A COUPLE OF HUNDRED YARDS AND THEN TOOK A WOODCHOPPERS TRAIL AT THE W END OF THE RAILROAD CUT TO THE SUMMIT.  THE RAILROAD CUT (ALONG THE N BASE OF THE HILL ON WHICH TURN STANDS) IS A CURVED ONE.  AT THE W END OF THIS CUT, AND AT ITS INTERSECTION WITH A SHORT TANGENT WHICH POINTS DIRECTLY TO THE MOST SW HOUSE (A PINK ONE) IN THE PLAYA OF GUAYANILLA, THE TRAIL TO TURN LEAVES THE RAILROAD RIGHT-OF-WAY.  THERE ARE TWO SUMMITS TO THE HILL, AND THE SIGNAL WAS ERECTED ON THE HIGHEST.  THIS IS THE SUMMIT NEAREST TALLABOA.  THE TOP WAS CLEARED OFF PRETTY WELL TO PERMIT OBSERVATIONS FROM THE GROUND.  TO MARK THE STATION, A 2-FOOT IRON PIPE, 2 INCHES IN DIAMETER, WAS SUNK 21 INCHES IN THE GROUND AND THE HOLE HAD TO BE CUT OUT OF THE ROCK WITH A CROW-BAR.  AFTER THE PIPE WAS SET IT WAS SURROUNDED WITH LOOSE STONES AND THEN RICH CEMENT POURED IN FILLING ALL INTERSTICES AND INSURING A GOOD BOND TO THE STONE AND A FIRM SETTING TO THE PIPE.                            STATION RECOVERY (1901)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1901 (GLF) FOUND STATION MARK UNDISTURBED.                            STATION RECOVERY (1905)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1905 (RLF) LOCATION OF STATION RECOVERED APPROXIMATELY, WITHIN ABOUT 3 FEET.  STATION MARK DESTROYED.  NO TRACES OF CEMENT OR GAS PIPE WERE FOUND.  PORTIONS OF OLD TRIPOD SIGNAL YET REMAINED.  THE HOLES FOR LEGS OF TRIPOD WERE FOUND AND CENTER OF STATION ESTIMATED.  FOR PURPOSES OF TRIANGULATION THIS STATION IS NO LONGER AVAILABLE.                            STATION RECOVERY (1966)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JJL) A THOROUGH SEARCH WAS MADE FOR THE STATION BUT IS WAS NOT RECOVERED.  TURN 2 WAS ESTABLISHED IN THE NEAR VICINITY.  (SEE DESCRIPTION THEREOF.)  OFFICE NOTE--STATION IS LOST.  (SEE G-16362)
markers.setting: METAL ROD DRIVEN INTO GROUND. SEE TEXT FOR ADDITIONAL
markers.stability: MARK OF QUESTIONABLE OR UNKNOWN STABILITY

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JJL) THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 5 MILES SOUTHWEST OF PENUELAS, 3-1/2 MILES EAST-SOUTHEAST OF GUAYANILLA AND ON THE EAST END AND HIGHEST POINT OF A LOW, BRUSH-COVERED HILL.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE SOUTHEAST CORNER OF THE PLAZA IN GUAYANILLA, GO SOUTHEASTERLY ON HIGHWAY 2 FOR 3.0 MILES TO A SIDE ROAD RIGHT, JUST BEFORE REACHING A REFINERY.  TURN RIGHT AND GO WEST FOR 0.2 MILE TO A SIDE ROAD RIGHT.  (A FOUR-WHEEL DRIVE VEHICLE IS REQUIRED FROM THIS POINT.) TURN RIGHT AND GO NORTH AND EAST ON THE DIRT ROAD FOR 0.15 MILE TO A DIM TRAIL ON THE RIGHT, NORTH, SIDE OF THE ROAD AND THE END OF TRUCK TRAVEL. PACK NORTH ALONG THE TRAIL FOR ABOUT 50 FEET TO THE TOP OF A RIDGE.  BEAR RIGHT AND PACK EASTERLY FOR ABOUT 100 YARDS TO THE HIGHEST POINT OF THE HILL AND THE STATION.  A 5-MINUTE PACK.  THE STATION MARK, STAMPED TURN 2 1966, IS A STANDARD DISK CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN OUTCROPPING BEDROCK THAT PROJECTS 1 INCH.  IT IS ABOUT 50 FEET SOUTHWEST OF A SMALL, ALUMINUM TOWER THAT IS ABOUT 20 FEET HIGH.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 1, STAMPED TURN 2 NO 1 1966, IS A STANDARD DISK CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN OUTCROPPING BEDROCK THAT PROJECTS 1 INCH.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 2, STAMPED TURN 2 NO 2 1966, IS A STANDARD DISK CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN OUTCROPPING BEDROCK THAT IS FLUSH WITH THE GROUND.  NO SUITABLE LOCATION FOR AN AZIMUTH MARK.                            STATION RECOVERY (1969)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1969 (JKW) THE STATION MARK AND REFERENCE MARKS WERE RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.  THE ORIGINAL DESCRIPTION IS ADEQUATE.  A NEW TO REACH FOLLOWS.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE INTERSECTION OF MARINA STREET AND PONCE BY-PASS (HWY 2) IN PONCE, GO WESTERLY ON HWY 2 FOR 8.2 MILES TO THE TALLABOA EXIT (HWY 127 AND OLD HWY 2).  TAKE EXIT AND GO WESTERLY FOR 3.0 MILES ON HWY 127, PASSING THROUGH A REFINERY AREA, TO A SIDE ROAD LEFT (A 4 WD VEHICLE IS NECESSARY FROM THIS POINT), TURN LEFT AND IMMEDIATELY CROSS A DIRT ROAD.  CONTINUE STRAIGHT AHEAD UP THE HILL FOR 0.10 MILE TO A SMALL GRADED CLEARING (THE TRAIL UP THE HILL HAS ALSO BEEN GRADED) AND A DIM TRAIL ON THE RIGHT.  TURN RIGHT AND PROCEED 300 FEET TO THE STATION AS DESCRIBED.                            STATION RECOVERY (1970)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1970 (KAM) THE STATION MARK AND REFERENCE MARKS WERE RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.  A NEW DESCRIPTION FOLLOWS.  THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 5 MILES SOUTHWEST OF PENUELAS, 3-1/2 MILES EAST-SOUTHEAST OF GUAYANILLA AND ON THE EAST END AND HIGHEST POINT OF A LOW, BRUSH-COVERED HILL.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE MARINA STREET AND PONCE BY-PASS (HWY 2) IN PONCE, GO WESTERLY ON HWY 2 FOR 8.2 MILES TO THE TALLABOA EXIT (HWY 127 AND OLD HWY 2).  TAKE EXIT AND GO WESTERLY FOR 3.0 MILES ON HWY 127, PASSING THROUGH A REFINERY AREA, TO A SIDE ROAD LEFT LEADING UP A HILL (A 4WD VEHICLE IS NECESSARY FROM THIS POINT), TURN LEFT AND IMMEDIATELY CROSS A DIRT ROAD.  CONTINUE STRAIGHT AHEAD UP THE HILL FOR 0.10 MILE TO A SMALL GRADED CLEARING (THE TRAIL UP THE HILL HAS ALSO BEEN GRADED) AND A DIM TRAIL ON THE RIGHT.  TURN RIGHT AND PROCEED 300 FEET TO THE STATION AS DESCRIBED.  THE STATION MARK, STAMPED TURN 2 1966, IS A STANDARD DISK CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN OUTCROPPING BEDROCK THAT PROJECTS 1 INCH.  IT IS ABOUT 50 FEET SOUTHWEST OF A CONCRETE SLAB 15 FT. BY 15 FT. SQUARE AND ON A LINE WITH FOUR (4) TEXACO STORAGE TANKS.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 1, STAMPED TURN 2 NO 1 1966, IS A STANDARD DISK CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE, IN OUTCROPPING BEDROCK THAT PROJECTS 1 INCH.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 2, STAMPED TURN 2 NO 2 1966, IS A STANDARD DISK CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN OUTCROPPING BEDROCK THAT IS FLUSH WITH THE GROUND.  NO SUITABLE LOCATION FOR AN AZIMUTH MARK.  THE STATION IS LOCATED SO AS TO VIEW ALL ISLANDS IN BAHIA DE TALLABOA.  ALSO THAT PORTION OF BAHIA DE GUAYANILLA EAST OF A LINE FROM THE STATION TO PUNTA VERRACO AND SOUTH OF ABOUT LATITUDE 18 DEG 00 MIN.  ALSO VISIBLE ARE MOST OF THE TANKS AND STRUCTURES ON THE PROPERTIES OF UNION CARBIDE AND COMMONWEALTH OIL REFINING COMPANY WHICH ARE LOCATED AROUND BAHIA DE TALLABOA.                            STATION RECOVERY (1971)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1971 (EKM) STATION WAS RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION AS DESCRIBED BY KAM IN 1970.  ADD--A TRIPOD, 7 FEET HIGH, (WOOD) COVERS THE STATION.

markers.description: BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1941 V.A. ELEVATION 20.47 METERS.  ON THE SOUTHERN COAST OF VIEQUES ISLAND ABOUT 1-1/2 KMS. SE OF THE VILLAGE OF PUERTO REAL.  THE MORE EASTERLY OF A PAIR OF ISLANDS WHICH LIE SOUTH OF THE VILLAGE OF PUERTO REAL FORMS THE WESTERN BOUNDARY OF A SMALL BAY KNOWN AS ENSENADA SUMBE.  A POINT FORMS THE EASTERN BOUNDARY OF THIS SAME BAY.  THE STATION IS ABOUT 400 METERS EAST OF THE POINT WHERE THE SHORE TURNS NORTH INTO THE BAY.  THE CLIFF OVERLOOKING THE WATER IS HIGHER IN THE VICINITY OF THE STATION THAN AT ANY OTHER POINT. AT THE HIGHEST PART THERE IS A CRESCENT SHAPED INDENTATION IN THE CLIFF AT THE FOOT OF WHICH THERE ARE BONES OF MANY HORSES AND COWS.  THIS EVIDENTLY BEING A PLACE USED BY THE NATIVES TO DISPOSE OF THE DEAD ANIMALS.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 1 IS ABOUT 4 METERS EAST OF THE EASTERN END OF THIS INDENTATION AND R.M. NO. 2 IS AT THE WESTERN PART.  THE STATION IS ON THE SOUTH EDGE OF A DIM TRAIL AND IS ABOUT 8 METERS FROM THE EDGE OF THE CLIFF.  THE STATION MARK IS SET IN LIMESTONE BEDROCK FLUSH WITH THE SURFACE OF THE GROUND.  IN THIS SAME ROCK THERE IS A NATURAL HOLE ABOUT 5 INCHES IN DIAMETER ABOUT 1 FOOT SOUTH OF THE STATION.  TO REACH THIS STATION FROM VILLAGE OF PUERTO REAL, DRIVE EAST ALONG A DIRT ROAD WHICH PARALLELS AN OLD RAILROAD.  AT A POINT 0.6 MILES FROM THE VILLAGE TURN RIGHT (S) AND DRIVE 1/4 MILE TO A POINT WHERE THE ROAD ENTERS A COCONUT GROVE.  TURN LEFT (E) AND DRIVE TO THE EAST END OF THE COCONUT GROVE (THIS IS ALSO THE EAST END OF THE ABOVE DESCRIBED BAY ENSENADA SUMBE).  AT THIS POINT THE RUINS OF AN OLD MASONRY FOUNDATION CAN BE SEEN IN THE WEST SIDE OF THE HILL.  FOLLOW THE TRAIL AROUND THE FOOT OF THIS HILL AND CONTINUE TO THE SOUTHERN EDGE OF THE POINT.  STATION MARK--STANDARD TABLET STAMPED (PUNTO NEGRO) SET IN BEDROCK.  R.M. 1 CHISELED CROSS IN BEDROCK ABOUT 1 METER FROM THE EDGE OF THE CLIFF.  DISTANCE FROM STATION--10.33 METERS.  PLANE AZIMUTH--02-00-30.  R.M. 2 CHISELED CROSS IN BEDROCK ABOUT 1 METER FROM THE EDGE OF THE CLIFF.  DISTANCE FROM STATION--31.78 METERS.  PLANE AZIMUTH--81-01-15.  SIGNAL--CLOTH TARGET AND FLAG CENTERED OVER STATION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1964)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1964 (GWM) STATION RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED.  FOUR WHEEL DRIVE VEHICLE CAN DRIVE TO WITHIN TWO (2) METERS OF STATION AT END OF TRAIL.                            STATION RECOVERY (1965)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1965 (JMC) STATION RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.  PREVIOUS DESCRIPTION ADEQUATE.  U.S.M.C. 2D TOPO CO. INDICATED THAT A STANDARD REFERENCE MARK DISK WITH A STAMPED ARROW POINTING TO STATION IS 20.47 METERS W OF STATION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1970)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US MARINE CORPS 1970 STATION RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.                            STATION RECOVERY (2004)  RECOVERY NOTE BY INDIVIDUAL CONTRIBUTORS 2004 (MA) THIS STATION WAS RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.  DIM TRAIL IS GONE, PROCEED SOUTH FROM T INTERSECTION OF TRAIL LEADING UPHILL TO THE POINT TO FORM THE T INTO A +, WHICH IS WHERE THE OLD TRAIL WAS.  DESCRIPTION OF THE CLIFF SHAPE IS ACCURATE.

THE SUMMIT OF THE PEAK IS VERY NARROW AND THE STATION IS LOCATED ON THE HIGHEST PART.  STATION MARK IS A STANDARD U.S.G.S. TABLET, STAMPED AND CEMENTED IN A LARGE FLAT ROCK SET IN GROUND. SIGNAL--A QUADRIPOD OF SAWED LUMBER WITH BLACK CROSS TARGETS ON CENTER POLE.

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1900 (JBB) ABOUT 100 METERS FROM THE EXTREME NW POINT OF CULEBRA AND 10 METERS NW OF THE LARGER OF TWO LARGE ROCKS ON TOP OF RIDGE.  ANGLE AT THE STATION BETWEEN LUIS AND THE ROCK IS 37 DEG.  STATION WAS MARKED BY A NAIL SET IN A CEMENT BLOCK.  BLOCK WAS ENCASED IN A PINE BOARD BOX AND PROJECTED SOME 6 INCHES ABOVE SURFACE.  NAIL SHOWED THROUGH TOP OF BOX.                            STATION RECOVERY (1945)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US NAVY 1945 (HTG) RECOVERED MONUMENT IN THREE PIECES, NONE OF WHICH WERE IN UNDISTURBED POSITION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1965)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1965 (MTP) THE TRIANGULATION STATION IS ON NORTHWEST PEN APPROXIMATELY 800 FEET SOUTH FROM THE EXTREME NORTHWESTERN TIP OF CULEBRA ISLAND, APPROXIMATELY 35 FEET EAST FROM THE STEEP SLOPE BREAKING DOWN TO THE BEACH, 115 FEET SOUTH-SOUTHWEST FROM THE CENTER OF AN 8 FEET DEEP BY 30 FEET DIAMETER BOMB CRATER, 60 FEET SOUTH FROM AN 8 FEET DEEP BY 30 FEET DIAMETER BOMB CRATER, AND 30 FEET NORTH FROM THE HIGH POINT ON THE LARGER OF TWO BOULDERS.  THE STATION IS IN A THICKET SURROUNDED ON ALL SIDES BY BRUSH AND CACTUS 5 TO 8 FEET IN HEIGHT.  THE MARK IS A 1-3/4 IN DIAMETER STEEL PIPE WHICH PROJECTS 9 IN ABOVE THE NATURAL GROUND.  IT IS SURROUNDED ON ALL SIDES BY COBBLES AND BOULDERS 3 IN TO 6 IN IN DIAMETER.  NO BRONZE REFERENCE MARK DISKS WERE SET.  TO REACH ULT, TRAVEL NORTHWEST 1.0 MI. FROM THE HIGHWAY JUNCTION AT THE SOUTH END OF CULEBRAS AIRPORT, TURN WEST (LEFT) AT FLAMINGO LAGOON AND DRIVE 0.9 MI. ALONG THE WEST SIDE OF FLAMINGO LAGOON, OPEN A GATE AND ENTER THE U.S. NAVY FIRING RANGE, DRIVE APPROXIMATELY 2.0 MI. TO THE END OF THE DIRT ROAD ON NORTHWEST PEN.  A TWENTY MINUTE HIKE IS REQUIRED TO REACH THE STATION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1966)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JJL) A THOROUGH SEARCH WAS MADE BUT THE MARK WAS NOT RECOVERED. STATION ULT 2 WAS ESTABLISHED AT THIS TIME.

BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JJL) THE STATION IS LOCATED ON THE EXTREME NORTHWEST END OF CULEBRA ISLAND.  IT IS ABOUT 4 MILES NORTH-NORTHWEST OF THE TOWN OF CULEBRA AND ON PROPERTY USED AS A FIRING RANGE BY THE U.S. NAVY.  CLEARANCE MUST BE OBTAINED BEFORE VISITING THIS STATION.  TO OBTAIN PERMISSION GO TO THE U.S. NAVY OBSERVATION POINT ON CULEBRA ISLAND.  TO REACH FROM THE POST OFFICE IN CULEBRA GO EAST FOR 0.05 MILE TO A Y-FORK.  TAKE THE LEFT FORK FOR 0.05 MILE TO A REVERSE Y-FORK.  BEAR LEFT AND GO NORTHEASTERLY FOR 0.5 MILE TO A Y-FORK.  TAKE THE LEFT FORK AND GO NORTHERLY FOR 1.05 MILES TO A Y-FORK.  TAKE THE LEFT FORK AND GO NORTHWESTERLY 0.4 MILE TO A GATE.  PASS THROUGH THE GATE, KEEP RIGHT AND CONTINUE NORTHWESTERLY FOR 0.5 MILE TO A LOCKED GATE AT THE ENTRANCE TO THE FIRING RANGE.  (OBTAIN THE KEY AT THE U.S. NAVY OBSERVATION POINT).  PASS THROUGH THE GATE, KEEP RIGHT AND CONTINUE NORTHWESTERLY 2.4 MILES TO A CONCRETE HELICOPTER LANDING PAD ON THE LEFT AND THE END OF TRUCK TRAVEL.  PACK NORTHWEST FOR 100 YARDS TO A CLEARED AREA AT THE TOP OF A SMALL HILL AND THE STATION.  THE STATION MARK IS A STANDARD DISK, STAMPED ULT 2 1966, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A ROCK 4 INCHES BELOW THE GROUND SURFACE.  IT IS 7 FEET EAST OF THE CLIFF ON THE WEST AND 10 FEET NORTH AND 3 FEET BELOW THE HIGHEST POINT OF THE HILL.  NO REFERENCE MARKS WERE ESTABLISHED.
markers.setting: UNSPECIFIED SETTING

markers.description: BY UNIVERSITY OF PUERTO RICO AT MAYAGUEZ 2005 (LLV) STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 16.7 KILOMETERS SOUTHEAST OF THE CITY OF RINCON, 14.0 KILOMETERS  NORTH OF THE CITY OF CABO ROJO, AND 7.6 KILOMETERS SOUTH OF THE CITY OF ANASCO, AT THE  MIRADERO WARD OF THE MUNICIPALITY OF MAYAGUEZ ON PROPERTY OF THE UNIVERSITY OF  PUERTO RICO MAYAGUEZ CAMPUS LOCATED AT THE PARKING ON THE NORTH SIDE OF THE CIVIL ENGINEERING BUILDING. STOP  AT THE CAFETERIA TRAILER ON THE RIGHT.  BETWEEN THE TWO SIDEWALKS THAT LEAD TO THE CIVIL ENGINEERING BUILDING IS A WITNESS POST AND THE STATION. MAYAGUEZ PUNTO DE  CONTROL ON THE OUTER CIRCLE, AND AGRIMENSURA Y TOPOGRAFIA GPS ON THE INNER CIRCLE AND  STAMPED 13.                            STATION RECOVERY (2016)  RECOVERY NOTE BY DEWBERRY DAVIS 2016 (GDS) RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1964 (GWM) STATION UVERO 1964 IS LOCATED ON THE NORTH COAST OF PUERTO RICO AT PUNTA UVERO.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM LOIZA ADEA, GO EAST FOR 3 MILES ON ROUTE 187, AND 0.1 MILE FROM DISTANCE MARKER K6H2 TO LA ESQUINA FAMOSA RUM SHACK.  TURN LEFT (NORTH) ON TO A PAVED ROAD.  CONTINUE FOR 0.6 MILES TO THE BEACH.  AT THE WATERS EDGE, TURN RIGHT (SOUTH) FOR 100 FEET TO A BARBED WIRE FENCE ON THE RIGHT (SOUTH).  SIX FEET SW OF THE NE STEEL POST IS THE STATION.  THE STATION IS FLUSH WITH THE SAND AND IT IS MARKED WITH A NAIL RECESSED IN CONCRETE THAT WAS POURED INTO A 4 IN PIPE SET 4 FT IN THE SAND.  ON THE CONCRETE ARE THE WORDS USC AND GS UVERO 1964.  NO REFERENCE MARKS WERE ESTABLISHED.                            STATION RECOVERY (1965)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1965 (MTP) THIS STATION WAS RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED.                            STATION RECOVERY (1966)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JJL) THE STATION MARK WAS NOT RECOVERED AND IS PRESUMED TO HAVE BEEN DESTROYED.  A NEW STATION MARK AND TWO REFERENCE MARKS WERE ESTABLISHED IN THE SAME GENERAL AREA.  FOR THE NEW DESCRIPTION SEE UVERO 2.

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JJL) THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 4 MILES NORTH OF RIO GRANDE, 3 MILES EAST OF LOIZA ALDEA AND ON A POINT OF LAND COVERED WITH COCONUT PALM TREES LOCALLY KNOWN AS POINT UVERO.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE EAST CORNER OF THE PLAZA IN LOIZA ALDEA, GO NORTHEAST AND EAST ON HIGHWAY 187 FOR 0.25 MILE TO THE T-JUNCTION OF HIGHWAY 187 AND HIGHWAY 185.  CONTINUE AHEAD, EASTERLY, ON HIGHWAY 187 FOR 2.35 MILES TO A WIRE GATE ON THE LEFT, NORTH, SIDE OF THE ROAD, ABOUT 50 YARDS AFTER PASSING KILOMETER POST K5 68.  TURN LEFT, PASS THROUGH THE GATE AND GO NORTHERLY ON THE TRACK ROAD THAT WINDS THROUGH THE COCONUT GROVE, FOR 0.75 MILE TO THE FURTHER MOST POINT OF LAND AND THE STATION.  THE STATION MARK IS A STANDARD DISK, STAMPED UVERO 2 1965, SET IN THE TOP OF A 12-INCH SQUARE CONCRETE MONUMENT THAT PROJECTS 2 INCHES.  IT IS 8.5 FEET SOUTHWEST OF THE FENCE LINE.  REFERENCE MARK 1 IS A STANDARD DISK, STAMPED UVERO 2 NO 1 1965, SET IN THE TOP OF A 12-INCH ROUND CONCRETE MONUMENT THAT PROJECTS 2 INCHES.  IT IS 37.2 FEET SOUTHWEST OF THE FENCE LINE.  REFERENCE MARK 2 IS A STANDARD DISK, STAMPED UVERO 2 NO 2 1965, SET IN THE TOP OF A 12-INCH ROUND CONCRETE MONUMENT THAT PROJECTS 1 INCH.  IT IS 19.2 FEET SOUTHWEST OF THE FENCE LINE.  THE DISTANCE BETWEEN REFERENCE MARK 1 AND REFERENCE MARK 2 IS 49.83 FEET OR 15.190 METERS.  THERE WAS NO SUITABLE PLACE FOUND FOR AN AZIMUTH MARK.

THE STATION IS 4.34 M (14.2 FT) SOUTH OF THE CENTER OF PR-111 AND PR-129, 2.78 M (9.1 FT) EAST OF KM POST 23.1, 1.87 M (6.1 FT) SOUTHEAST OF A POWER POLE AND 1.04 M (3.4 FT) NORTH OF AN ORNAMENTAL METAL FENCE.
markers.setting: SET IN TOP OF CONCRETE MONUMENT

TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE INTERSECTION OF PR-110 AND PR-111 3.7 MI (6.0 KM) SOUTHEAST OF AGUADILLA, GO WEST ON PR-111 FOR 0.7 MI (1.1 KM) TO THE STATION ON THE RIGHT.   THE STATION IS 9.96 M (32.7 FT) NORTH OF THE CENTERLINE OF WEST BOUND LANE OF PR-111, 3.10 M (10.2 FT) EAST OF CONCRETE POWER POLE NO. MCP H665, 2.15 M (7.1 FT) SOUTH OF THE EDGE OF PAVED PARKING AREA AND 1.88 M (6.2 FT) WEST OF A METAL SIGN FOR PARQUE LA MOCA.

TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE INTERSECTION OF PR-621 AND PR-10 0.6 MI (1.0 KM) SOUTHWEST OF DOS BOCAS, GO NORTHERLY ON PR-10 FOR 3.1 MI (5.0 KM) TO THE STATION ON THE LEFT.   THE STATION IS 40.58 M (133.1 FT) SOUTH OF KM POST 74.7, 14.98 M (49.1 FT) WEST OF THE CENTERLINE OF PR-10 AND 3.44 M (11.3 FT) EAST OF THE CUT OF A ROCK CLIFF.

markers.description: BY JAVIER E. BIDOT AND ASSOC. 2008 THE STATION IS LOCATED IN THE NORTHEAST SECTION OF RIO GRANDE AT KILOMETER POST 28.0 ON THE WESTBOUND SHOULDER OF STATE ROAD PR 3 AND SOUTH OF EXISTING FAST FOOD ESTABLISHMENTS.   OWNERSHIP PRHTA RIGHT-OF-WAY.   TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE INTERSECTION OF STATE ROAD PR 3 AND PR 66, DRIVE 6.1 MI (9.8 KM) EAST ON PR 3 TO THE MARK ON THE LEFT JUST PAST AVENUE A.   THE STATION IS A STANDARD BRONZE DISK ON TOP OF CONCRETE POST IN GRASS AREA FLUSH WITH THE GROUND.  IT IS 24.50 M (80.4 FT) WEST OF A POWER POLE, 18.50 M (60.7 FT)EAST OF ANOTHER POWER POLE AND 12.54 M (41.1 FT) SOUTHWEST OF MANHOLE COVER ACROSS THE STREET.
markers.setting: SET IN TOP OF CONCRETE MONUMENT

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1900 (JBB) STATION IS ON THE CREST OF THE SOUTHERN EXTREMITY OF THE POINT OF THE SAME NAME, CALLED BREEZE POINT, BETWEEN MOSQUITO BAY AND MANGOVE HARBOR.  THE STATION IS ABOUT 50 METERS BACK FROM THE EDGE OF THE BLUFF.  IT IS MARKED BY A TACK SET IN A WOODEN STUB DRIVEN IN THE GROUND.  A TRIPOD SIGNAL WAS ERECTED OVER THE STATION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1904)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1904 (RLF) RECOVERED, WOODEN STUB HAD BEEN REMOVED BUT A HUDDLE OF CEMENT WHICH SURROUNDED THE STUB WAS FOUND WITH HOLE IN CENTER WHERE THE STUB HAD BEEN.  THIS HUDDLE OF CEMENT NOW MARKS THE STATION.  DESCRIPTION OF STATION IS AMPLE.                            STATION RECOVERY (1922)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1922 (FTS) STATION NOT RECOVERED.  PROBABLE LOCATION EASILY FOUND.  NEW STATION VACA 2 WAS ESTABLISHED.

BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1922 (FTS) STATION WAS ESTABLISHED ON BLUFF AS NOTED IN ORIGINAL DESCRIPTION FOR VACA.  A SIGNAL WAS ERECTED UPON THE SITE OF WHAT WAS THOUGHT TO BE VACA AND A CENTER MARK ESTABLISHED ECCENTRICALLY, WHICH WAS CALLED VACA 2, ABOUT 3.8 METERS DISTANT.  STATION MARK IS A STANDARD BRONZE DISK SET IN CONCRETE, AS DESCRIBED IN NOTE 1A.  REFERENCE MARK NO.1 CONSISTS OF AN IRREGULAR MASS OF ROCKS CEMENTED TOGETHER WITH A ROUGH ARROW IN THE SURFACE OF THE CEMENT ON TOP, POINTING TO THE STATION.  THIS MARK IS ON RANGE WITH CULEBRITA ISLAND LIGHTHOUSE.  REFERENCE MARK NO.2 IS A SMALL CROSS WITH LETTERS R.M. NEARBY CHISELED ON AN IRREGULAR ROCK, WHICH IS SOLIDLY EMBEDDED IN THE GROUND.                            STATION RECOVERY (1926)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1926 (GCM) STATION RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED.  PART OF TOP OF CEMENT POST HAD BEEN BROKEN AWAY AND STATION MARK REMOVED, LEAVING IMPRESSION IN CEMENT OF 1/2 OF STEM OF STATION MARK.  A NEW STATION MARK WAS NOT INSTALLED BECAUSE OF THE POSSIBILITY OF BEING REMOVED BY NATIVES.  THE IMPRESSION OF THE STEM OF THE STATION MARK WAS USED IN ERECTING INSTRUMENT FOR OBSERVING.  A TRIPOD SIGNAL IN GOOD CONDITION WAS FOUND STANDING OVER THE STATION. TRIPOD SIGNAL PROBABLY ERECTED BY MR. OGRAM WHILE MAKING A CADASTRAL SURVEY IN 1924.  REFERENCE MARKS IN GOOD CONDITION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1965)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1965 (MTP) THE TRIANGULATION STATION WAS NOT RECOVERED.  A FIVE HOUR SEARCH WAS MADE WITH THE ASSISTANCE OF MR. CHARLES FISHBACK, A LONG TIME RESIDENT OF THE ISLAND, AND NEITHER THE TRIANGULATION STATION NOR THE REFERENCE MARK DISKS COULD BE FOUND ON THE 150 FT. KNOLL BETWEEN VACA PT AND BREEZE PT.  A 4 IN X 4 IN CONCRETE BLOCK, OVERALL LENGTH 19 IN, WAS FOUND BROKEN IN TWO PIECES WITH THE 1/2 IN DIAMETER DISK STEM HOLE SPLIT LONGITUDINALLY FOR 4 IN.  THE TWO CONCRETE BLOCKS WERE LAYING LOOSE ON THE GROUND, HAVING BEEN MOVED FROM THEIR ORIGINAL LOCATION.
markers.setting: SET IN TOP OF CONCRETE MONUMENT

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1941 (RLS) THIS INTERSECTION STATION IS ABOUT 1-1/2 MILES SSW OF DAGUAO, ABOUT 0.6 MILE S OF ESPERANZA, ABOUT 650 METERS SE OF THE AMERICAN RAILROAD, WITHIN THE PROPOSED BOUNDARY OF THE ROOSEVELT ROADS NAVAL RESERVATION, ABOUT 250 METERS NW OF THE INNER EDGE OF THE MANGROVE SWAMP AT THE MOUTH OF QUEBRADA PALMA, IN A PASTURE, ON LINE WITH A WAGON ROAD THROUGH CANE FIELDS LEADING S FROM ESPERANZA, 90 METERS E OF A SMALL GROUP OF BAMBOO TREES ON THE W BANK OF QUEBRADA PALMA AT POINT WHERE FENCE W OF STATION CROSSES CREEK, 42 METERS SW OF THE SW CORNER OF A SUGAR CANE FIELD, 28 METERS SSE OF A FENCE BETWEEN 2 PASTURES AND A TREE ON THE FENCE LINE WITH A HOLE IN THE TRUNK, AND PROJECTS ABOUT 8 INCHES ABOVE GROUND.  THE ELEVATION OF THE STATION IS ABOUT 0.75 METER.  STATION MARK IS A STANDARD BRONZE DISK SET IN CONCRETE, AS DESCRIBED IN NOTE 1A.  THERE ARE NO UNDERGROUND OR REFERENCE MARKS.  THE WITNESS MARK IS A TRIANGULAR BLAZE ON THE SE SIDE OF A 24-INCH JOBO TREE ABOUT 4 FEET ABOVE THE GROUND.  IT IS 30.9 METERS DISTANT FROM THE STATION IN APPROXIMATE AZIMUTH 117 DEG.
markers.setting: UNSPECIFIED SETTING

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1901 (JN) THIS STATION IS 1-1/3 MILES DISTANT AND BEARS S 73 DEG W FROM THE TOWN OF ISABELA, AND IS ABOUT 3/4 MILE FROM THE COAST.  IT IS 1/3 MILE DISTANT AND BEARS S 15 DEG E FROM THE HOUSE OF JUAN NIEVES, ON THE PROPERTY OF E. VALLE.  IT IS ABOUT 80 METERS S OF AN E-W LINE OF COCOANUT TREES AND 110 FEET N OF AN E-W HEDGE OF WILD PINEAPPLE.  THE HIGHEST POINT OF THIS HILL IS IN THE HEDGE.  THE STATION IS ABOUT 3 FEET LOWER, BEARS N 27 DEG E AND IS 117 FEET FROM THE HIGHEST POINT IN A CULTIVATED FIELD.  THIS STATION IS MARKED BY A GALVANIZED IRON PIPE 2 INCHES IN DIAMETER AND 2 FEET LONG, SET IN A BED OF CEMENT.  THE TOP OF THE PIPE PROJECTS ABOUT 4 INCHES ABOVE THE BED OF CEMENT.  A 20-PENNY NAIL CEMENTED ON THE INSIDE OF THE PIPE MARKS THE STATION.

BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1922 THIS STATION IS 2.3 KILOMETERS DISTANT AND BEARS S 73 DEG 30 MIN W OF THE TOWN OF ISABELA AND ABOUT 2.2 KILOMETERS S OF THE COAST.  IT IS ABOUT 0.65 KILOMETER S OF THE ROAD, WHICH RUNS DIRECTLY W FROM ISABELA, AND ABOUT 325 METERS N OF A ROAD CROSSING.  THE STATION IS IN A CULTIVATED FIELD ABOUT 40 METERS N OF THE HIGHEST POINT OF THE KNOLL AND 40 METERS W OF A N AND S FENCE LINE.  THE STATION MARK IS A STANDARD U.S.G.S. BRONZE BENCH MARK TABLET SET IN A LIMESTONE ROCK BURIED IN THE GROUND.  REFERENCE MARK NO.1, IS A 20-PENNY NAIL IN THE TRUNK OF AN ALMARSIGO TREE ON THE W SLOPE OF THE HILL, ABOUT 1.4 METERS ABOVE THE GROUND.  IT IS 64.50 METERS DISTANT FROM STATION ON AN AZIMUTH OF 59 DEG 15 MIN 27 SEC.  REFERENCE MARK NO.2, IS A 20-PENNY NAIL IN THE ROOT OF A CAHIMBO TREE ON THE E SIDE OF A TRAIL NEAR A SMALL THATCHED ROOF HOUSE.  IT IS 34.30 METERS DISTANT FROM STATION ON AN AZIMUTH OF 349 DEG 15 MIN 30 SEC.  ELEVATION 100.1 METERS.  THE POINT IS BEST REACHED BY TAKING THE CAMINO SW WHICH FOLLOWS THE RAILROAD OUT OF ISABELA.  ABOUT 2.5 KILOMETERS OUT THERE IS A ROAD FORK N FROM THE END OF WHICH A TRAIL LEADS DIRECTLY PAST THE STATION.  THIS STATION IS NEAR THE U.S.C. AND G.S. POSITION OF THE SAME NAME WHICH COULD NOT BE RECOVERED.
markers.setting: UNSPECIFIED SETTING

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1900 THIS STATION IS NEAR THE EASTERN EDGE OF THE EASTERN POINT OF THE LITTLE BAY CALLED THE BALLENA.  THE SIGNAL IS JUST N, ONE LEG STANDS AT THE INSIDE EDGE OF A VIGOROUS CLUMP OF BEACH GRAPES.  THIS IS THE MOST NOTICEABLE MARK ABOUT.  THE WILD GRAPES STAND ABOUT 6 FEET IN HEIGHT AND IS ABOUT 6 INCHES IN DIAMETER AT THE GROUND.  STATION MARK IS A NAIL WHICH IS CEMENTED IN THE ROCK.  SENOR TORRES (A BOAT OWNER AT GUANICA) BROUGHT THE PARTY HERE FROM GUANIOA, AND CAN POINT OUT THIS STATION.  HE SAYS THAT A SPANISH DETACHMENT WAS ENCAMPED FOR A TIME AT THIS POINT.                            STATION RECOVERY (1966)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JWC) THE NAIL WHICH WAS PREVIOUSLY USED TO MARK THE STATION WAS FOUND.  THE ORIGINAL POINT WAS HELD AND A STANDARD STATION MARK DISK WAS SET TO REPLACE THE NAIL.  REFERENCE MARKS 1 AND 2 WERE ESTABLISHED AT THIS DATE.  A COMPLETE NEW DESCRIPTION FOLLOWS--  THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 6 MILES SOUTH OF YAUCO, 4-1/2 MILES EAST-SOUTHEAST OF GUANICA, NEAR THE EASTERN EDGE OF THE EASTERN POINT OF A LITTLE BAY KNOWN AS BALLENA AND ON WHAT IS LOCALLY KNOWN AS POINT VAQUERO.  THE LAND IS OWNED BY THE U.S. FORESTRY DEPARTMENT.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE NORTHWEST CORNER OF THE PLAZA IN GUANICA, GO WEST ON A PAVED STREET FOR 0.35 MILE TO ITS JUNCTION WITH HIGHWAY 116.  TURN RIGHT AND GO NORTHEAST ON HIGHWAY 116 FOR 0.25 MILE TO A SIDE ROAD ON THE RIGHT.  TURN RIGHT AND GO SOUTH AND EAST ON HIGHWAY 333 FOR 5.25 MILES TO THE END OF THE PAVEMENT AT KILOMETER POST 10.0.  CONTINUE EAST ON A DIRT ROAD FOR 0.1 MILE TO A GATE.  PASS THROUGH THE GATE AND CONTINUE EAST ON A DIRT ROAD FOR 0.65 MILE TO A DUG OUT PLACE ON THE RIGHT AND THE END OF TRUCK TRAVEL.  (THIS IS 0.1 MILE AFTER REACHING THE CREST OF A LOW RIDGE).  FROM HERE PACK SOUTH FOR 50 YARDS TO THE STATION NEAR AN OUTSTANDING GROWTH OF SEA GRAPES WHICH CAN BE SEEN FROM THE ROAD AT THE END OF TRUCK TRAVEL.  THE STATION MARK IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED VAQUERO 1900 1966, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A ROCK OUTCROP.  NOTE 2.  REFERENCE MARK 1 IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED VAQUERO NO 1 1900 1966, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A ROCK OUTCROP THAT PROJECTS 2 INCHES AND IS THE SAME ELEVATION AS THE STATION MARK.  NOTE 12A.  REFERENCE MARK 2 IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED VAQUERO NO 2 1900 1966, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A ROCK OUTCROP THAT PROJECTS 6 INCHES AND IS THE SAME ELEVATION AS THE STATION MARK.  NOTE 12A.  NO AZIMUTH MARK WAS ESTABLISHED AT THIS DATE.  AIRLINE DISTANCE AND DIRECTION FROM NEAREST TOWN 4-1/2 MILES EAST-SOUTHEAST OF GUANICA.                            STATION RECOVERY (1971)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1971 (EKM) STATION MARK AND REFERENCE MARKS RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.  CHANGE HOW TO REACH SENTENCES AS FOLLOWS--DELETE PORTIONS AFTER  ...DIRT ROAD FOR 0.65 MILE TO A DUG OUT PLACE ON THE RIGHT.  ...GROWTH OF SEA GRAPES WHICH CAN BE SEEN FROM THE ROAD.
markers.setting: SET IN ROCK OUTCROP
markers.stability: MOST RELIABLE AND EXPECTED TO HOLDPOSITION/ELEVATION WELL

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JJL) THE STATION IS LOCATED 4-1/2 AIRLINE MILES SOUTH OF MOROVIS, 3-3/4 AIRLINE MILES NORTH OF OROCOVIS AND ON THE TOP OF A HIGH GRASS COVERED HILL.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE NORTHEAST CORNER OF THE PLAZA IN OROCOVIS, GO NORTH AND WEST ON HIGHWAY 155 FOR 2.0 MILES TO A FORK.  TURN RIGHT AND GO NORTH ON HIGHWAY 155 FOR 2.55 MILES TO A SIDE ROAD LEFT AT KILOMETER POST 34.6.  (TO REACH THE AZIMUTH MARK FROM THIS POINT, CONTINUE NORTH ON HIGHWAY 155 FOR 0.95 MILE TO A CONCRETE DRIVE ON THE LEFT AND THE AZIMUTH MARK) TURN LEFT AND GO WEST ON A BLADED ROAD FOR 0.35 MILE TO THE BASE OF A HIGH HILL AND END OF TRUCK TRAVEL.  FROM HERE PACK WEST UPHILL FOR ABOUT 100 YARDS TO THE HIGHEST POINT OF THE HILL AND STATION.  THE STATION MARK IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED VAZQUEZ 1965, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN OUTCROPPING BEDROCK WHICH PROJECTS 1 INCH.  REFERENCE MARK 1 IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED VAZQUEZ NO 1 1965, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN OUTCROPPING BEDROCK WHICH PROJECTS 6 INCHES.  REFERENCE MARK 2 IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED VAZQUEZ NO 2 1965, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN OUTCROPPING BEDROCK WHICH PROJECTS 1 FOOT.  THE AZIMUTH MARK IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED VAZQUEZ 1965, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN THE NORTHWEST CURB OF A CONCRETE DRIVE.  THE MARK PROJECTS ABOUT 10 FEET ON THE NORTHWEST SIDE AND IT IS FLUSH WITH THE ROAD SURFACE ON THE SOUTHEAST SIDE.  IT IS 23 FEET NORTHWEST OF THE CENTER OF HIGHWAY 155 AND 20 FEET SOUTH OF KILOMETER POST 36.
markers.setting: SET IN ROCK OUTCROP
markers.stability: MOST RELIABLE AND EXPECTED TO HOLDPOSITION/ELEVATION WELL

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1900 (JN) THIS STATION IS SITUATED MOST CONVENIENTLY TO GUANICA.  HEAVY CUTTING CLEARED OFF THE SUMMIT AND DEEP CUTS WERE MADE TO PERMIT OBSERVATION OF VAQUERO, CASA, AND LABRA.  THE EVIDENCE OF THIS CUTTING WILL REMAIN FOR YEARS.  STATION MARK IS A NAIL SET IN CEMENT IN A HOLE DRILLED IN A ROCK ON THE HILLTOP.  TO REACH IT, ONE TAKES THE ROAD (TO THE EASTWARD) CROSSING THE FRONT OF THE PLAYA OF GUANICA FOLLOWING PATHS TO THE WOOD ROAD WHICH GOES UP THE FIRST CANON N OF FORT CAPRON.  THE ROAD IS KEPT TO THE TOP OF THE CANON AND THEN ONE TURNS ALONG THE ROAD LEADING TO THE RIGHT CONTINUING TO THE CLEARING IN WHICH STANDS THE CABIN OF SANDALIO ALLALA.  THE PATH ALONG THE N SIDE OF THE HOUSE IS TAKEN AND KEPT FOR A FEW HUNDRED YARDS THROUGH A PASS TO WHERE ONE REACHES A WELL MARKED CUT THAT IS MADE IN THE HILLTOP LEADING TO A SUMMIT.  ON THIS SUMMIT VEGA WAS ESTABLISHED.  FRANCISCO DEFON, AN ELDERLY MAN, AND RAMON CHAVARRIA, A YOUNG MAN, NATIVES, AND RESIDENTS OF GUANIOA ACCOMPANIED THE PARTY TO THIS STATION.
markers.setting: SET IN A BOULDER
markers.stability: MAY HOLD, BUT OF TYPE COMMONLY SUBJECT TOSURFACE MOTION

markers.description: PTIVE TEXT AVAILABLE.

BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (JWC) THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 6 MILES EAST-NORTHEAST OF MANATI AND 3-1/2 MILES NORTH OF VEGA BAJA.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE JUNCTION OF HIGHWAYS 2 AND 686 IN VEGA BAJA, GO WEST ON HIGHWAY 2 FOR 1.1 MILES TO A CROSSROAD.  TURN RIGHT AND GO NORTHERLY FOR 1.7 MILES TO A SIDE ROAD RIGHT.  TURN RIGHT AND GO EAST FOR 0.1 MILE TO THE STATION.  THE MAST IS A STEEL-TRUSS STRUCTURE, PAINTED ALTERNATELY RED AND WHITE, SUPPORTED BY GUY WIRES AND IT IS ABOUT 180 FEET HIGH.  POINT INTERSECTED IS THE RED OBSTRUCTION LIGHT ATOP AND CENTER OF THE MAST.

BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 2002 (JMW) 0.1 KM (0.05  MI)  WESTERLY ALONG STATE HIGHWAY 107  FROM THE JUNCTION OF STATE HIGHWAY 2 IN AGUADILLA, SET IN A 1 BY 2-FOOT AREA OF OUTCROPPING BEDROCK NEAR THE CENTER OF A ROADSIDE PARK, 31.8 M SOUTH OF THE CENTER OF A STREET, 31.7 M SOUTHWEST OF A UTILITY POLE 28.9 M NORTHEAST THE CENTER OF    A CONNECTING ROAD FROM THE HIGHWAY LEADING TO STATE HIGHWAY 107, 18.8 M SOUTHEAST OF A UTILITY POLE, 17.0 M EAST OF THE CENTER OF A SIDEWALK, 11.4 M WEST OF THE CENTER OF A SIDEWALK, 11.1 M SOUTH OF THE CENTER OF A SIDEWALK, 7.3 M NORTHEAST OF THE CENTER OF A SIDEWALK, AND 0.4 M BELOW THE LEVEL OF THE ROAD. NOTE--THE MARK IS ON THE HIGHWAY RIGHT-OF-WAY.                            STATION RECOVERY (2004)  RECOVERY NOTE BY UNIVERSITY OF PUERTO RICO AT MAYAGUEZ 2004 (LLV) RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED.                            STATION RECOVERY (2007)  RECOVERY NOTE BY UNIVERSITY OF PUERTO RICO AT MAYAGUEZ 2007 RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.                            STATION RECOVERY (2007)  RECOVERY NOTE BY RLDA SURVEYING AND MAPPING 2007 (RLD) RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED.                            STATION RECOVERY (2009)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 2009   MARQTEK ENGINEERING.                            STATION RECOVERY (2013)  RECOVERY NOTE BY ATKINS NORTH AMERICA INC 2013 (DWD) THIS STATION WAS RECOVERED AS PART OF A 2013 AERIAL MAPPING CAMPAIGN FOR UNITED STATES NAVY FACILITIES THROUGHOUT PUERTO RICO.
markers.setting: SET IN ROCK OUTCROP
markers.stability: MOST RELIABLE AND EXPECTED TO HOLDPOSITION/ELEVATION WELL

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1941 (RLS) THIS INTERSECTION STATION IS ABOUT 3/4 MILE SW OF COLONIA ORIENTE, ABOUT 0.4 MILE SE OF DAGUAO, ABOUT 1/4 MILE S OF A ROAD LEADING E FROM DAGUAO ALONG THE S SIDE OF THE DAGUAO RIVER, WITHIN THE PROPOSED BOUNDARY OF THE ROOSEVELT ROADS NAVAL RESERVATION, NEAR THE SE END OF THE FIRST HILL S OF THE DAGUAO RIVER AND SE OF THE AMERICAN RAILROAD (STATION CANA IS ON TOP OF THE SAME HILL), ON THE SE SLOPE OF THE HILL, IN AN UNCULTIVATED AREA COVERED WITH SMALL BOULDERS.  STATION MARK IS A STANDARD BRONZE DISK SET IN CONCRETE, NOTE 1A, PROJECTING ABOUT 8 INCHES ABOVE GROUND.  THE ELEVATION OF THE STATION IS ABOUT 51.1 METERS.                            STATION RECOVERY (1963)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1963 (GFO) THE STATION MARK WAS SEARCHED FOR AND NOT FOUND.  THE AREA IS COVERED WITH DENSE GRASS ABOUT 4 FEET HIGH AND MADE THE SEARCH DIFFICULT.  BELIEVE MARK SHOULD BE RECOVERABLE.
markers.setting: SET IN TOP OF CONCRETE MONUMENT
markers.stability: MAY HOLD, BUT OF TYPE COMMONLY SUBJECT TOSURFACE MOTION

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1926 (GCM) STATION IS A SHORT, RED, BRICK STACK, LOCATED 0.6 MILE W OF ARROYO, ABOUT 200 METERS BACK FROM THE BEACH.  THE STACK IS SURROUNDED BY SUGAR CANE AND IS PARTLY DESTROYED.

BY LOCAL ENGINEER (INDIVIDUAL OR FIRM) 1966 (JJL) RECOVERED BY PRS.  THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 6 MILES SOUTH-SOUTHEAST OF YAUCO, 3-1/2 MILES SOUTH OF GUAYANILLA AND ON A LOW HILL THAT IS COVERED BY BRUSH AND TREES.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE NORTHWEST CORNER OF THE PLAZA IN GUAYANILLA, GO NORTH ON HIGHWAY 2 FOR 0.1 MILE TO A CROSS STREET.  TURN LEFT AND GO WEST AND SOUTHWEST ON A PAVED ROAD FOR 0.7 MILE TO THE RUFINA SUGAR CANE MILL.  CONTINUE SOUTHWEST ON THE PAVED ROAD FOR 2.1 MILES TO THE END OF THE PAVEMENT. CONTINUE SOUTHWEST ON A GRAVELED ROAD FOR 0.55 MILE TO A SIDE ROAD ON THE LEFT.  TURN LEFT, CROSSING A BRIDGE AND GO SOUTHWEST ON A GRAVELED ROAD FOR 0.45 MILE TO A SIDE ROAD ON THE LEFT AT THE SAN FRANCISCO SUGAR MILL.  TURN LEFT AND GO EAST ON A GRAVELED RAOD FOR 0.3 MILE TO A GATE.  PASS THROUGH THE GATE AND GO EAST AND SOUTH ON A GRAVELED ROAD FOR 0.75 MILE TO A SIDE ROAD ON THE LEFT JUST BEFORE REACHING A GATE.  TURN LEFT AND GO EAST ON A DIRT ROAD FOR 0.4 MILE TO A T-ROAD. TURN LEFT, PASSING THROUGH A GATE AND GO NORTH ON A DIRT ROAD FOR 0.15 MILE TO A Y-FORK.  TAKE THE RIGHT FORK AND GO NORTHEAST UP A HILL FOR 0.15 MILE TO ASIDE ROAD ON THE RIGHT.  (A 4-WHEEL DRIVE VEHICLE IS REQUIRED TO REACH THE STATION FROM THIS POINT). TURN RIGHT AND FOLLOW A TRACK ROAD SOUTHERLY FOR 0.5 MILE TO THE STATION AT A LARGE CLEARED AREA.  THE STATION MARK IS A 1/2-INCH IRON ROD WITH A CHISELED CROSS ON ITS TOP, SET IN AN IRREGULAR MASS OF CONCRETE THAT IS INSCRIBED ESTADO LIBRE ASOCIA VERRACO 1961 AND PROJECTS 2 INCHES.  IT IS 150 FEET WEST OF THE HIGHEST POINT OF THE HILL.  REFERENCE MARK 1 IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED VERRACO PRS NO 1 1966, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A CORAL ROCK THAT PROJECTS 6 INCHES AND IS 1 FOOT LOWER IN ELEVATION THAN THE STATION MARK.  REFERENCE MARK 2 IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED VERRACO PRS NO 2 1966, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A CORAL ROCK THAT PROJECTS 3 INCHES AND IS 1 FOOT LOWER IN ELEVATION THAN THE STATION MARK.  NO AZIMUTH MARK WAS SET.                            STATION RECOVERY (1970)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1970 (KAM) THE STATION AND REFERENCE MARKS WERE RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.  A NEW DESCRIPTION FOLLOWS.  THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 6 MILES SOUTH-SOUTHEAST OF YAUCO, 3-1/2 MILES SOUTH BY WEST OF GUAYANILLA, ON A LOW BRUSH COVERED HILL OVERLOOKING THE OCEAN, AND KNOWN AS CERRO TORO.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE WEST CORNER OF THE PLAZA IN GUAYANILLA, GO NORTHWEST ON HIGHWAY 2 FOR 0.1 MILE TO A CROSS STREET.  TURN LEFT AND GO SOUTHWEST AND SOUTH ON A PAVED ROAD FOR 0.7 MILES TO THE RUFINA SUGAR MILL.  CONTINUE GENERALLY SOUTHWEST ON THE PAVED ROAD FOR 2.75 MILES TO A DIRT ROAD AND A BRIDGE ON THE LEFT.  TURN LEFT, CROSSING THE BRIDGE, AND PROCEED GENERALLY SOUTH FOR 0.45 MILES TO THE CENTRAL SAN FRANCISCO SUGAR MILL.  TURN LEFT, AND GO 0.3 MILE TO A WIDE CROSSROAD, PASSING THROUGH A SUGAR COMPANY GATE ENROUTE. TURN RIGHT AND GO 0.40 MILE SOUTHEAST TO A BEND IN THE ROAD TO THE EAST.  CONTINUE FOR 0.45 MILE TO A TEXACO CO. GATE. PASS THROUGH THE GATE (THE KEY MUST BE OBTAINED FROM TEXACO, LAS AMERICAS AVENUE, PONCE) AND CONTINUE EAST FOR 0.44 MILES TO THE PRESENT END OF THE GRADED ROAD.  TURN RIGHT ACROSS THE DITCH ON A TRACK ROAD, AND GO SOUTH FOR 0.21 MILES TO A Y FORK.  TAKE THE RIGHT FORK AND GO FOR 0.1 MILE TO A TRACK ROAD ON THE RIGHT.  TURN RIGHT AND GO UPHILL FOR 0.1 MILE TO THE END OF TWO WHEEL DRIVE TRAVEL.  FROM THIS POINT THE STATION MAY BE REACHED BY CONTINUING WITH 4-WHEEL DRIVE OR PACKING FOR ABOUT 0.5 MILE ON THE TRACK ROAD TO THE CREST OF CERRO TORO, AND THE STATION.  THE STATION IS ON THE WEST SIDE OF A LARGE OPEN BUT BRUSHY AREA, AND SEVERAL FEET LOWER, AND APPROXIMATELY 200 FEET WEST OF THE HIGHEST POINT OF THE HILL.  THE HOLE THROUGH THE CLIFF ON PTA. VENTANA IS VISIBLE FROM THE STATION, BEARING ABOUT SOUTHWEST.  CENTRAL RUFINA SUGAR MILL STACK IS VISIBLE FROM THE STATION BEARING NORTH BY EAST, AND A WHITE TANK, AND WHITE TOWER 1/2 MILE NORTH-NORTHWEST OF PLAYA DE GUAYANILLA ARE VISIBLE BETWEEN THE LIMBS OF A LARGE TREE OVER THE BROW OF THE HILL TO THE NORTHEAST.  TRIANGULATION STATIONS CRIOLLO 2 (USGS) 1934, AND TURN 2, 1966 ARE VISIBLE FROM THE GROUND. IN 1970 THERE WAS A 4 FOOT STAND WITH A 15 FOOT UPRIGHT 4 IN X 4 IN TIMBER SURMOUNTED BY A BANNER ON THE STATION.  THE 4 FOOT STAND IS ALMOST EATEN AWAY BY TERMITES AND WONT LAST MUCH LONGER.  THE STATION WILL BE DIFFICULT TO RECOVER WHEN IT IS GONE.  THE STATION MARK IS A 1/2 INCH IRON ROD, WITH A CHISELED CROSS ON ITS TOP, SET IN AN IRREGULAR MASS OF CONCRETE, THAT IS INSCRIBED ESTADO LIBRE ASOCIA VERRACO 1961, AND PROJECTS 2 INCHES.  REFERENCE MARK 1 IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED VERRACO PRS NO. 1, 1966 CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN ROCK OUTCROP THAT PROJECTS 6 INCHES AND IS SOUTHEAST OF AND ABOUT ONE FOOT LOWER THAN THE STATION.  REFERENCE MARK 2 IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED VERRACO PRS NO. 2, 1966, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN ROCK OUTCROP THAT PROJECTS 3 INCHES.  IT IS SOUTHWEST OF AND ABOUT ONE FOOT LOWER THAN THE STATION.  THERE IS NO AZIMUTH MARK.  RUFINA SUGAR MILL STACK MAKES AN EXCELLENT AZIMUTH REFERENCE.  AIRLINE DISTANCE AND DIRECTION FROM NEAREST TOWN 3-1/2 MILES SOUTH BY WEST OF GUAYANILLA.
markers.setting: OBJECT SURROUNDED BY MASS OF CONCRETE
markers.stability: MARK OF QUESTIONABLE OR UNKNOWN STABILITY

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1964 (GWM) THE STATION IS A STANDARD DISC STAMPED VEVE 1964.  IT IS LOCATED ON THE EAST COAST OF PUERTO RICO, 0.3 MILES SSW OF CAPE SAN JUAN LIGHT (KNOWN LOCALLY AS FAJARDO LIGHT).  TO REACH FROM FAJARDO PLAYA TAKE THE ROAD LEADING TO THE U.S. COAST GUARD STATION, CAPE SAN JUAN LIGHT HOUSE--AT THE BASE OF THE HILL ON WHICH THE LIGHT IS LOCATED AND THE ROAD TURNS SHARPLY TO THE NORTH.  AT THIS SAME POINT IS A STEEL GATE.  PROCEED EASTWARD FROM THE GATE (TOWARD THE BEACH), 100 METERS AND 10 METERS FROM THE WATERS EDGE TURN SOUTH FOR 90 METERS TO THE STATION. TO THE EAST OF THE STATION IS A PROMINENT RIDGE 6 METERS IN ELEVATION AND 100 METERS LONG.  THE RIDGE IS COVERED WITH SCRUB BRUSH AND ON THE EXTREME SOUTHERN END ARE SEVERAL PROMINENT BOULDERS.  THE STATION IS LOCATED PERPENDICULAR TO THE RIDGE AND 30 METERS EAST OF THE ROCKS.  REFERENCE MARK NO 1 IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED VEVE RM NO 1 1964 SET IN A 12 IN CONCRETE SQUARE FLUSH WITH THE GROUND.  REFERENCE MARK NO 2 IS A STANDARD DISC STAMPED, VEVE RM NO 2, 1964, SET IN A 12 IN CONCRETE SQUARE FLUSH WITH THE GROUND.  NO AZIMUTH MARK WAS ESTABLISHED.
markers.setting: SET IN TOP OF CONCRETE MONUMENT
markers.stability: MAY HOLD, BUT OF TYPE COMMONLY SUBJECT TOSURFACE MOTION

markers.description: BY ANDREGG INCORPORATED 1995 (MJB) TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE VIEQUES ISLAND AIRPORT, GO EAST ALONG HIGHWAY PR 200 3.3 KILOMETERS (2.05 MI) TO THE INTERSECTION OF CALLE MONTESANTO PLAYA, A PAVED ROAD.  TURN LEFT (NORTH) AND GO 150 METERS (492.1 FT) TO A T INTERSECTION WITH A PAVED ROAD.  TURN LEFT (WEST) AND GO 120 METERS (393.7 FT) TO A T INTERSECTION.  TURN RIGHT (NORTH) AND GO 50 METERS (164.0 FT) TO A T INTERSECTION ON THE SOUTH SIDE OF A CEMETERY  THE STATION IS IN THE TOP OF THE ROLLED CURB ON THE NORTH SIDE OF THE T INTERSECTION, 8 METERS (26.2 FT) NORTH OF A MANHOLE, 16 METERS (52.5 FT) NORTHEAST OF A FIRE HYDRANT, AND 10.7 METERS (35.1 FT) NORTHEAST OF THE EDGE OF PAVEMENT OF THE SOUTHWEST CORNER OF THE INSECTION  THE STATION 3-1/4 INCH BRASS CAP STAMPED CENTRO DE RECAUDACION DE INGRESSOS MUNICIPALES, PUERTO RICO GPS CONTROL, C.R.I.M., UNLAWFUL TO DISTURB, VIEQUES, SET FLUSH INTO DRILL HOLE IN TOP OF CONCRETE ROLLED CURB                            STATION RECOVERY (2004)  RECOVERY NOTE BY INDIVIDUAL CONTRIBUTORS 2004 (MA) THIS DESCRIPTION IS ACCUARTE FOR THIS STATION, THOUGHT SOME NEW ROADS HAVE BEEN BUILT.  THE STATION WAS MARKED WITH WHITE HASH MARKS ON CURB.  THE STATION DISK HAS BEEN REMOVED, BUT ITS DEPRESSION IS VISIBLE.

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1899 (WCH) THIS STATION WAS OCCUPIED ECCENTRICALLY.  THE SIGNAL IS AN OLD SPANISH SIGNAL FLAG POLE, USED FOR GIVING NOTICE OF THE ARRIVAL OF VESSELS TO THE HARBOR OF PONCE.  IT IS LOCATED UPON A HILL SOME 300 FEET HIGH, JUST NW OF PONCE.  DISTANCE OF STATION OCCUPIED TO CENTER OF POLE 1.04 METERS.  ECCENTRIC STATION WAS MARKED BY A STUB 9 INCHES LONG BY 1-1/2 INCHES IN DIAMETER.  A NAIL IN THE TOP OF STUB MARKS CENTER OF STATION.
markers.setting: UNSPECIFIED SETTING

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1901 (JN) THE STATION IS ABOUT 1-1/2 MILES DISTANT N 20 DEG E FROM STATION AGUADILLA.  STATION IS ON THE E SPUR OF A VERY HIGH, BARE HILL PROJECTING TOWARDS PUNTA GORDA.  THIS STATION IS ON THE LAND OF DOCTOR VALLE WHO RESIDES IN SAN JUAN.  THE STATION IS ON THE HIGHEST PART OF THIS SPUR AND IS MARKED IN THE USUAL WAY WITH THE GALVANIZED-IRON PIPE SET IN A BED OF CEMENT.                            STATION RECOVERY (1922)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1922 THE U.S.C. AND G.S. MARK WAS FOUND APPARENTLY UNDISTURBED.  THE STATION IS SITUATED ABOUT 1 KILOMETER W OF A ROAD WHICH LEADS FROM THE MAIN ROAD ABOUT 2 KILOMETERS NE OF AGUADILLA, IN A NORTHERLY DIRECTION TO CAMACEYES STATION ON THE AMERICAN RAILROAD.  THE STATION IS NOT ON THE HIGHEST PART OF THE HILL, BUT ON A SPUR TO THE E ON PROPERTY OWNED BY SILVESTRE ASAVEDO, AND IS 20 METERS W OF A WIRE FENCE WHICH DIVIDES HIS PROPERTY FROM THAT OF ANDRES MORALLES.  THE U.S.C. AND G.S. STATION MARK WAS USED.  ELEVATION ABOVE SEA LEVEL IS - 148.3 METERS.  TO REACH THE STATION, FOLLOW THIS ROAD FOR ABOUT 2 KILOMETERS TO A POINT FROM WHICH THE OCEAN CAN BE SEEN, LOOKING NW THRU A GAP IN THE HILLS.  THE HILL ON WHICH THE STATION IS LOCATED IS TO THE N OF THIS GAP AND CAN BE REACHED EASILY BY WALKING ACROSS COUNTRY.
markers.setting: SET INTO TOP OF METAL PIPE DRIVEN INTO GROUND
markers.stability: MARK OF QUESTIONABLE OR UNKNOWN STABILITY

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1899 (WCH) THE STATION IS MARKED BY A STUB 9 INCHES LONG BY 1-1/2 INCHES IN DIAMETER.  A NAIL IN THE TOP OF STUB MARKS CENTER OF STATION.
markers.setting: UNSPECIFIED SETTING

markers.description: BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1934 THIS STATION IS SITUATED ON A GRASS-COVERED HILL IN THE VICINITY OF BARRIO BUENA VISTA OF BAYAMON, 1-1/4 KILOMETERS E OF THE ROAD OPPOSITE KILOMETER POST K 10 H 7.  THE HILL IS THE WESTERN POINT OF A RIDGE RUNNING W TOWARD THE ROAD AND LOCATED BETWEEN TWO LARGE CREEKS.  STATION MARK IS A STANDARD U.S.G.S. TABLET CEMENTED ON ROCK, N OF E OF HIGHEST POINT AND 1 FOOT BELOW.  REFERENCE MARKS ARE BRASS NAILS AND WASHERS CEMENTED ON ROCK.  REFERENCE MARK NO.1 IS 1.40 METERS IN TRUE AZIMUTH 30 DEG 43 MIN.  REFERENCE MARK NO.2 IS 1.90 METERS IN TRUE AZIMUTH 237 DEG 52 MIN.  STATION IS REACHED BY TRAIL FROM POST K 10 H 7 E, CROSSING BROOK 1/2 KILOMETER FROM ROAD AND THEN CLIMBING E ALONG A RIDGE TO THE SUMMIT.                            STATION RECOVERY (1941)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1941 (GBG) RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED IN GOOD CONDITION.
markers.setting: SET IN UNSPECIFIED ROCK OR BOULDER
markers.stability: PROBABLY HOLD POSITION/ELEVATION WELL

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1901 (JN) STATION IS ON A HILL CALLED BUENA VISTA ABOUT 1-3/4 MILES FROM THE OCEAN AND S 50 DEG E DISTANT 2 MILES FROM QUEBRADILLAS.  IT IS ON LAND BELONGING TO VENTURAL OCASIO, ON A SOLID ROCKY PLACE IN THE NE CORNER OF THE GARDEN.  IT IS N 31 DEG E DISTANT 125 FEET FROM THE N WINDOW OF HIS CABIN.  THE STATION IS MARKED BY A GALVANIZED-IRON PIPE SET IN CEMENT AND PROJECTING ABOUT 3 INCHES ABOVE THE GENERAL SURFACE OF THE GROUND.  THE LOWER END OF THE PIPE RESTS IN A HOLE CUT IN THE SOLID CORAL ROCK.  THE PIPE IS FILLED WITH CEMENT AND THE CENTER OF A SPIKE DRIVEN IN THIS MARKS THE STATION.
markers.setting: UNSPECIFIED SETTING

markers.description: BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1934 STATION IS ON THE BARRIO OF CERRO GORDO, ON A VERY PROMINENT HILL LOCALLY KNOWN AS CERRO VIVIANA SOME 6 KILOMETERS DIRECT DISTANCE TO THE S OF SAN LORENZO.  IT IS ON THE TOP OF A BARE HILL, WHICH HAS SEVERAL LARGE BARE BOULDERS ON ITS SLOPES AND WHICH STANDS ALONE ON THIS REGION.  STATION IS MARKED BY A REGULAR U.S.G.S. TABLET STAMPED VIVIANA 1934.  REFERENCE MARK NO.1 IS A CROSS MARK ON THE FACE OF A BIG BROAD BARE BOULDER, 24 FEET 3 INCHES FROM STATION, ON A TRUE AZIMUTH OF 193 DEG 37 MIN.  REFERENCE MARK NO.2 IS A CROSS MARK ON TOP OF A HALF BURIED BROAD BOULDER, 27 FEET 7 INCHES DISTANT FROM THE STATION, ON A TRUE AZIMUTH OF 345 DEG 14 MIN.  SIGNAL--A WHITE QUADRIPOD WITH BLACK CROSS TARGETS.  TO REACH THE STATION, YOU MUST STOP AT KILOMETER 14, H 4 ON THE SAN LORENZO-LAS PIEDRAS HIGHWAY.  FROM HERE YOU MUST TAKE ALL THE TRAIL ON FOOT, WHICH IS ABOUT 5 KILOMETERS IN LENGTH, TO REACH THE CERRO VIVIANA ON CERRO GORDO, WHERE THE STATION IS LOCATED.  THERE IS NO OTHER HILL, TO CONFUSE YOU, AT THE END OF THE TRAIL.  CERRO VIVIANA IS THE MOST PROMINENT HILL YOU WILL FIND ON BARRIO CERRO GORDO.                            STATION RECOVERY (1940)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1940 THE TABLET OF 1934 WAS NOT FOUND.  BUT THE POSITION WAS RELOCATED FROM THE REFERENCE MARKS.  AND A NEW TABLET WAS SET IN A CONCRETE POST IN THIS LOCATION.  NEW DESCRIPTION FOLLOWS--  THE STATION IS ON THE BARRIO DE CERRO GORDA, ON A PROMINENT HILL LOCALLY KNOWN AS CERRO VIVIANA, SOME 6 KM. DIRECT DISTANCE TO THE SE OF SAN LORENZO.  THE HILL IS BARE AND CULTIVATED NEARLY TO THE TOP.  AND THERE ARE SEVERAL LARGE BOULDERS ON ITS SLOPES.  THE STATION IS A STANDARD TABLET STAMPED VIVIANA 1934 SET IN CONCRETE POST PROJECTING ABOUT 3 INCHES ON THE TOP OF THE HILL.  R.M. NO. 1 IS A CROSS MARK ON THE FACE OF A BIG, BROAD BARE BOULDER 24.25 FT. FROM STATION IN AZIMUTH 193 DEG 37 MIN.  R.M. NO. 2 IS A CROSS MARK ON TOP OF A HALF-BURIED BROAD BOULDER 27.58 FT. FROM STATION IN AZIMUTH 345 DEG 14 MIN.  R.M. NO. 3 IS A STANDARD TABLET STAMPED R.M. NO. 3, 1940 SET IN TOP OF A HUGE BOULDER, -- FT. FROM STATION IN AZIMUTH 286 DEG 30 MIN 55 SEC.  TO REACH FROM SAN LORENZO, CROSS BRIDGE ON ROAD TO LAS PIEDRAS AT E END OF TOWN, AND, ABOUT 300 FT. BEYOND, TURN RIGHT ON A PAVED ROAD DOWN HILL.  FOLLOW THIS ROAD 2.7 MILES TO END OF PAVING, AND THEN DIRT ROAD STRAIGHT ON TO STORE OF CARLOS ZAYAS, END OF CAR TRAVEL.  TAKE ROAD TO LEFT, AND FOLLOW MAIN ROAD AND TRAIL UP TO STATION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1965)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1965 (JJL) THE STATION WAS RECOVERED AND FOUND IN GOOD CONDITION.  A NEW REFERENCE MARK 4 WAS ESTABLISHED.  A COMPLETE NEW DESCRIPTION OF THE STATION FOLLOWS.  THE STATION IS LOCATED 7 AIRLINE MILES WEST OF HUMACAO, 5-1/4 AIRLINE MILES SOUTHWEST OF LOS PEDRAS AND ON A HIGH BRUSH COVERED HILL.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE INTERSECTION OF HIGHWAYS 916 AND 183 IN THE EAST EDGE OF SAN LORENZO, GO EASTERLY ON HIGHWAY 183 FOR 1.65 MILES TO A CROSSROAD.  TURN RIGHT AND GO SOUTH AND EAST OF HIGHWAY 183 FOR 2.0 MILES TO THE INTERSECTION OF HIGHWAY 919.  TURN RIGHT AND GO SOUTH AND WEST ON HIGHWAY 919 FOR 2.0 MILES TO A SIDE ROAD LEFT.  TURN SHARP LEFT AND GO SOUTHERLY ON A BLADED ROAD FOR 1.1 MILES TO A POINT WHERE THE ROAD CURVES WEST AND END OF TRUCK TRAVEL.  FROM HERE PACK SOUTHEAST UP STEEP HILL FOR ABOUT 100 YARDS TO THE HIGHEST POINT OF THE HILL AND THE STATION IN A LARGE BOULDER.  THE STATION MARK IS A USGS BENCH MARK STAMPED VIVIANA 1934, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A BOULDER WHICH PROJECTS 4 INCHES.  REFERENCE MARK 3 IS A USGS BENCH MARK STAMPED RM NO 3 1940, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A LARGE BOULDER WHICH PROJECTS 6 FEET.  REFERENCE MARK 4 IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED VIVIANA NO 4 1934, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A LARGE BOULDER WHICH PROJECTS 6 FEET.  NO AZIMUTH MARK WAS ESTABLISHED AT THIS STATION.  AIRLINE DISTANCE AND DIRECTION FROM NEAREST TOWN 4-1/2 MILES SOUTHEAST OF SAN LORENZO.                            STATION RECOVERY (2004)  RECOVERY NOTE BY UNIVERSITY OF PUERTO RICO AT MAYAGUEZ 2004 (JMA) THE WORDS IN THE BENCH MARK ARE ERODED.
markers.setting: SET IN A BOULDER
markers.stability: MAY HOLD, BUT OF TYPE COMMONLY SUBJECT TOSURFACE MOTION

markers.description: BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1938 STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 4 KM. SW OF SAN SEBASTIAN AND 7 KM. SE OF MOCA IN BARRIO VOLADORES ON THE N SIDE OF DIRT ROAD OPPOSITE A SMALL HOUSE.  TO REACH FROM SAN SEBASTIAN DRIVE W ON HIGHWAY TOWARD MOCA ABOUT 15 KMS. TO KM. POST 10.4.  TURN SHARP LEFT ONTO SECOND CLASS ROAD AND DRIVE 0.3 MILE TO HOUSE AT ROAD FORK.  TAKE RIGHT FORK AND DRIVE 0.1 MILE TO LARGE HOUSE AT TOP OF HILL.  LEAVE CAR HERE AND FOLLOW CART ROAD 200 METERS SW TO POINT WHERE ROAD CROSSES RIDGE.  STATION IS ON RIGHT SIDE OF ROAD, NEAR CREST OF RIDGE AND OPPOSITE SMALL HOUSE.  THIS STATION IS NOT ON THE HIGHEST PART OF THIS HILL AS THE TOP IS USED IN RAISING SUGAR CANE.  STATION MARK--STANDARD TABLET CEMENTED IN ROCK SET IN PLACE AND STAMPED VOLADORES.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 1--E CORNER OF SMALL HOUSE, 23.1 FEET FROM STATION MARK IN TRUE AZIMUTH 273 DEG 36 MIN.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 2--CHISELED CROSS ON ROCK SET IN PLACE IN FENCE LINE, 14.0 FEET FROM STATION MARK IN TRUE AZIMUTH 23 DEG 11 MIN.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 3--NAIL IN CENTER OF BLAZED TRIANGLE ON GUAMA TREE IN FENCE LINE, 19.4 FEET FROM STATION MARK IN TRUE AZIMUTH 107 DEG 49 MIN.
markers.setting: SET IN UNSPECIFIED ROCK OR BOULDER
markers.stability: PROBABLY HOLD POSITION/ELEVATION WELL
